HEADLINE: Peru Suggests U.S. Rethink Eradication in Land Where Coca Is Still King

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UCHIZA, Peru, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Slipping his pistol into a desk drawer, Uchiza's Mayor smoothed his shirt and posed proudly by the city seal formally adopted here last month.
"These leaves represent our most important crop," the Mayor, Demetrio Diaz Guevara, said with civic pride, pointing to an embroidered sprig of coca leaves.
Indeed, as if jumping to life off the new municipal flag, coca is everywhere in this Amazon boomtown: soft and leafy in backyard gardens and on hillside plots, or crackly and brown on black plastic drying sheets. 
 At tax time, some peasants even trudge into City Hall bearing 100-pound sacks as tribute.
 
Eradication Effort's Failings
 This bumper crop is bad news for the United States, which is the major consumer of the end products of the jungle harvest: cocaine and crack.
During the 1980's, the United States Government spent millions of dollars seeking to eradicate coca-leaf cultivation here in Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, source of the raw material for half of the world's cocaine.
A few miles from here, on the far bank of the muddy Huallaga River, stands the most visible evidence of the American effort, Santa Lucia base. From this heavily fortified base, helicopter-borne teams of American and Peruvian anti-drug agents destroyed in the last year about 150 coca-leaf processing laboratories and dozens of coca-bush nurseries.
The eradication campaign has slowed crop expansion to a 10 percent annual increase. Paradoxically, without the American effort, coca cultivation probably would have exploded, setting off a price collapse and bankruptcy for many coca farmers.
 
Drug Issue Becomes Marginal
 Today, many Peruvians and Americans are suggesting a reassessment of policies toward coca production.
President Alberto Fujimori, an agronomist who took office on July 28, has retired top police officers involved in eradication efforts and declined to accept $36 million in American military aid. The money was to be used in part to intercept the small planes that take off daily from Uchiza's dirt airstrip, carrying up to 1,500 pounds of coca paste for cocaine powder refineries in neighboring Colombia.
Advocating a gradual approach, the President proposed making alternative farm crops attractive by clearing away bureaucratic and infrastructure obstacles that peasants face here.
In Washington, the drug issue has become increasingly marginal. With hundreds of thousands of American soldiers massed for war in the Persian Gulf, drugs no longer seem to be nation's "gravest domestic threat" -- a phrase used by President Bush last year.
 
American Reporter Slain
 While Peruvians and Americans debate a new approach to the coca harvest, leaders of the new coca-growers union here complain that few policy makers make the 230-mile flight from Lima to this frontier town of 50,000 people, the largest in the Huallaga Valley.
The dearth of visitors stems largely from the region's reputation for danger.
Last year, a visiting American freelance reporter, Todd Smith, was kidnapped while he waited at Uchiza's airstrip for a plane out of here. Several days later, his mutilated body was found on Uchiza's main square, bearing a placard that said, "This is how Yankees die."
More recently, on Oct. 19, the Peruvian Army general in charge of troops in the valley was ambushed and severely wounded as he drove on a road near here.
 
Changing Town's Violent Ways
 Such incidents are variously attributed to drug traffickers or two Marxist guerrilla armies that seek to win growers' support in the valley.
Today, having just come from the wake of a former Mayor who was shot to death Wednesday night, Mr. Diaz said he was working to change Uchiza's violent ways. Carefully stepping around a sawed-off shotgun he keeps within reach of his swivel chair, Mr. Diaz warmly greeted a visitor to the town offices and handed out copies of Uchiza's first "Trade, Tourism and Services Guide."
Published last month, the full-color brochure reveals that Uchiza has one Roman Catholic church, five Evangelical Protestant churches, five pool halls, 20 air-taxi services and 28 bars. Advertisers include two of Mr. Diaz's businesses -- Uchiza's only television station and Porky's, a discotheque that regularly attracts some of the best salsa bands from Lima.
Turning on a overhead fan to move the humid tropical air through his office, the 34-year-old Mayor then pressed into a visitor's hand copies of the city's first newspaper, a monthly that started publication in September.
 
Dependence on Coca Harvest
 "Eradication is not the solution," the current edition's editorial said about the coca harvest.
"Violent eradication would leave peasants without an economic base to survive, increasing the chances that 200,000 peasants would join the subversive groups" it continued, echoing a widespread sentiment here.
Mr. Diaz, a native son who was overwhelmingly elected last November, estimated that 80 percent of Uchiza's economy revolved around the coca leaf. The coca growers, inhabitants of the tin-roof shacks that dot the deforested hills around here, are largely refugees from the left-wing terrorism that plagues the Peruvian Andes.
Peru's Government calculates that one million people of the nation's population of 22 million depend on coca harvests for their livelihood. Probably the nation's largest export, Peru's coca-leaf harvest annually sells for $1 billion to $1.5 billion.
Climbing behind the wheel of his car for a tour of the town, Mr. Diaz said that the major obstacle blocking a switch to legal crops is transportation.
He said the road to Lima was so bad that it takes 38 hours for a truck to travel the 270 miles to the capital on the Pacific Ocean.
Because of high transportation costs, bribes demanded by guerrillas and policemen, and export monopolies, coffee growers in the valley receive only 30 percent of their export price. In constrast, American farmers generally receive 90 percent of the price of products at the port, according to the Institute of Freedom and Democracy, a free-market research group that prepared Mr. Fujimori's anti-drug proposal.
"To send a load of wood to the coast is as expensive as sending the same wood from the coast to Rotterdam," said another member of the city tour, Rolando del Aguila Hidalgo, adviser for the newly created Institute for the Integrated Development of the Upper Huallaga.
 
Change 'If It's Profitable'
 On the city tour, Mr. Diaz took pains to point out the kind of American aid that locals appreciate: a steamroller, three dump trucks and a road grader, all provided by the United States Administration for International Development.
Working on clearing new city streets, the American-provided road building equipment is the kind of development aid that residents here say could eventually allow crop substitution.
"All our 1,400 members grow coca," Justo Silva Vallon, manager of the Upper Huallaga Agricultural Cooperative, said in an interview at the cooperative's newly inaugurated office building.
"The peasants want to change -- if it's profitable," he continued, referring to such alternative crops as coffee, cocoa and corn.
A more militant stance was taken by Mario Campo Roldon, a board member of a new group, the Defense Front Against Coca Eradication in the Upper Huallaga.
"We are tired of studies, speeches and promises," Mr. Campo said, his chest glistening with sweat in the Amazon heat. "We want to substitute, but we want concrete facts -- better roads, agricultural extension services."
Growers here said they were skeptical of Mr. Fujimori's drug proposal of Oct. 26, saying it was intended more to mollify American public opinion than to deliver services here. Indeed, the speech was written by officials in Lima who are keenly aware that six months from now, the United States Congress must certify that Peru is cooperating in the war on drugs in order for Peru to win a large portion of the $250 million in American aid proposed for Peru in 1991.
The minimal interest shown by Peru's army in stopping the drug trade was illustrated at the end of the day at the airport here, one of the busiest of 150 strips estimated to be used to ship coca paste north to Colombia.
Asked about the large number of late-model, long-haul airplanes parked in the grass by the dirt strip, the local army commander replied, "What's the point of arresting drug dealers if more are just going pop up to take their place?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Demetrio Diaz Guevara, right, the mayor of Uchiza, Peru, visiting villagers as they worked with coca leaves spread out on the ground to dry. "These leaves represent our most important crop," he said; The city seal that appears on Uchiza's flag includes an embroidered sprig of coca leaves. (Photographs by James Brooke/The New York Times); map: Peru, indicating Uchiza (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Insurers Press Use of Cheaper Drugs

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Health insurers, which used to pay for prescription drugs with little attention to price, are increasingly influencing Americans' choice of medicines. Trying to curb drug costs, the fastest-growing expense in many health plans, they are offering financial incentives to people who select a lower-price version of a medicine when a choice is available.
The intervention in a decision that used to involve only the doctor and the patient is a big change in the way Americans buy medicine and follows similar efforts by insurers to influence patients' choices of doctors and hospitals. But some physicians are concerned that pressure to reduce the cost of drugs could conflict with the patient's best interest. 
 Typical of the incentives being offered by insurers are those under one Blue Cross plan in California. Employees at the Ventura Entertainment Group, based in Los Angeles, pay $5 for each prescription if they get the Johnson & Johnson analgesic Tylenol 3 with codeine, which averages $17 wholesale for 100 pills. But the employees pay only $2 for generic acetaminophen with codeine, which costs $11.60 for the same number of pills without the Tylenol brand name. (The insurer pays the rest, plus a small markup for the druggist.)
 
Change in Payment Procedure
 As another incentive under the new method, the customer does not have to pay the entire price of the prescription up front. Historically, the customer has paid the entire bill and then sought to be reimbursed for most of it by the insurer. But under the new system, the pharmacy contacts the insurer by computer and is told what small share the customer must pay and what the insurer will pay.
Some health maintenance organizations use even stronger incentives to steer patients toward drugs they deem to be the best value for the money. Their physician and pharmacist advisers typically make lists of approved drugs, based on both medical and economic criteria, and people covered by these plans must pay the entire price of any drug not on the list.
"The pharmacy business is now being driven by what the payer will pay for and not by what the physician prescribes," said Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, director of the Pharmaceutical Economic Research Institute at Purdue University.
Although the Food and Drug Administration requires the generic versions to be "bio-equivalent" to the higher-priced original products, some physicians say that for some patients their effects may still be different. "If you substitute a generic, you may have a problem, which can be dangerous," said Dr. Lonnie R. Bristow, a member of the American Medical Association board of trustees. For example, he said, patients who take the anticonvulsive drug Dilantin for epilepsy sometimes cannot tolerate a change to a generic. "They could have a seizure while driving," he said.
 
Effect on Doctors
 To be sure, doctors still decide what is prescribed, and some physicians forbid such substitutions. But pharmacists and representatives of insurers often call doctors who do not cooperate and tell them that they are out of step with their peers. Insurers sometimes tell doctors of the medical merits of a lower-priced alternative and seek permission to change a prescription. To become a participating doctor in some health plans, the physician must agree to prescribe the less-expensive drug unless there are medical reasons not to.
By paying the pharmacy directly rather than reimbursing the patient, the insurer can better dictate the price of the drug. If the pharmacy refuses to lower its prices, as some have, some insurers simply remove the store or chain from the list of pharmacies with which they deal directly and for which they offer financial incentives to patients.
 
Limiting Profits on Drugs
 The new arrangements please many people. "All we pay is $5 per prescription for everything we need," said Christina Greer of Penns Grove, N.J., a longstanding customer at the West Main Pharmacy there. The rest of the price is paid directly to West Main by the Blue Cross plan that covers her husband, an electrician at a General Motors plant.
But the new programs are sharply limiting profits on drugs, which used to be pharmacies' best source of earnings. And even some pharmaceutical manufacturers are being forced to offer discounts on some patented drugs to get the business of certain insurers, like large health maintenance organizations.
Another force limiting profits for pharmaceutical companies is that under the 1991 budget law that President Bush signed this month, all drug makers will have to provide rebates to the states on the wholesale price of drugs used by low-income Medicaid patients.
Insurers and many employers that ultimately pay the bill say that drug spending has become their fastest-growing health cost. Drug prices have been rising almost twice as fast as general inflation, and the number of prescriptions has soared as patients are increasingly treated in doctors' offices and clinics instead of hospitals.
Americans spent $28.2 billion on prescription drugs last year at the nation's 55,000 pharmacies, almost triple the $9.7 billion in 1980, according to a study by Mr. Schondelmeyer and Joseph Thomas 3d published in Health Affairs, a quarterly journal.
Druggists say that some large health maintenance organizations and other insurers now refuse to deal with pharmacies that do not meet their demands for deep discounts or cooperate in promoting lower-priced drugs.
At least 14 million people belong to health maintenance organizations that offer rewards for choosing less-costly drugs. And Medicaid programs for the indigent, which have similar drug restrictions in many states, cover 25.2 million people.
Many other health plans are considering similar programs, said Richard D. Ekstrom, president of the Cost Containment Corporation, which assists companies like the Westinghouse Electric Corporation with employee drug programs.
 
Incentives in Blue Cross Plans
 Greg Amato, a pharmacist consultant in Chicago with the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, said that about one-third of the Blue Cross plans offer incentives to use generics.
Many health maintenance organizations pay the full cost only if a drug is on a list, or formulary, usually compiled by doctors and pharmacists who advise the organization. When there are medically similar products -- for example, among drugs to treat blood pressure or ulcers -- the lower-priced ones are favored.
Some large, self-insured employers are also considering establishing such lists, said John Middleton, president of Diversified Pharmaceutical Services, based in Minnetonka, Minn.
Direct-payment plans will probably cover at least 60 percent of all retail prescriptions within five years, Mr. Schondelmeyer said.
 
Concessions by Drug Makers
 As insurers have increased their control over drug choices through direct payments to pharmacies, drug makers have had to make concessions on prices and adopt their sales strategies. The manufacturers' salespeople made 30 million visits to physicians last year to try to persuade them to prescribe their products. But most drug makers have also added units that try to persuade health maintenance organizations and other cost-conscious health-care networks that even the most expensive drugs can be cost-effective.
"Ultimately you have to show that you have value," said Ernest Mario, chief executive of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., which makes Zantac, an ulcer drug that had $2.7 billion in worldwide sales last year and costs the pharmacies at least 15 percent more than Tagamet, its nearest competitor.
Glaxo touts a product's effectiveness in shortening a patient's absence from work and preventing recurrences of an illness, Mr. Mario said.
 
INCENTIVES FOR LOWER--PRICED DRUGS

 
 
Trying to curb drug costs that are the fastest-growing expense in many health plans, some insurers offer financial inventives to people who choose a lower-cost medicine when a choice is available. Here's how one health plan does it.
 
1. An employee at General Motors' Delco unit in Kokomo, Ind., brings a doctor's prescription for an antibiotic called Keflex to Moore Drugstore in Kokomo.
 
2. Don Moore, the pharmacist, uses a computer to call Blue Cross, Delco's insurer, to determine what the customer's insurance covers.
 
3. The insurer's computer informs Mr. Moore that Delco employees have a lower-priced alternative: They can pay $3 for a 10-day supply of cephalexin, a generic antibiotic that costs Delco's Blue Cross plan $15.50. Employees who choose Keflex, a brand-name antibiotic that costs Delco $41.42, must pay the 25.92 additional cost plus $3, or $28.92.
 
4. If the doctor prescribes Keflex and writes "dispense as written," the employee pays only $3; the health plan pays the rest. Blue Cross will try to persuade the doctor to prescribe the lower-cost drug next time.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 628 words

HEADLINE: What's Wrong With the Siege?

 BODY:
How badly has Iraq been hurt by near-total siege that the United Nations imposed in August? The only available information is anecdotal, and it suggests that Iraq has been hurt by a lack of vital spare parts. And yet President Bush is suddenly determined to build up U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia massively, in the implicit belief that the embargo isn't biting hard enough to evict Iraqi occupiers from Kuwait.
He still hasn't answered the obvious question: What's the rush? 
 In the first days of the gulf crisis, Administration officials cautioned that the embargo might need six months or a year to impel Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait. By abruptly doubling the military stakes and seeking offensive capability, Mr. Bush guarantees that time now presses the besieging coalition rather than Iraq.
Does that mean that U.S. intelligence is persuaded that the embargo isn't working? Has satellite surveillance confirmed fears of substantial violation of U.N. sanctions across the borders of Jordan, Syria, Iran or Turkey? Are economic analysts compiling data on Iraq's known dependence on imported technology to keep factories running, workers employed and military equipment operable?
The questions are sensible and urgent, but even senators seeking answers find themselves groping in fog.
William Webster, director of Central Intelligence, came closest on Oct. 25 to a public response, in a question-and-answer session before a world affairs council. He reported that sanctions were having some effect on the economy, but no significant impact on the Iraqi military: Saddam Hussein has amply stockpiled spare parts and has added to his store by looting Kuwait.
At a closed White House briefing last week, one of the senators present asked if any detailed studies had been prepared on Iraq's vulnerability to the embargo. Secretary of State Baker seemed taken aback by the question.
Yet Western journalists visiting Baghdad relate that factories and power plants have been crippled by shortages, that elevators have stopped running, that tractors and trucks lie abandoned on roadsides. And reports from Saudi Arabia assert that Iraq is short of de-icing chemicals needed for high-altitude flights and of fuel additives essential for firing ballistic missiles.
No one expected the embargo to cause mass starvation. Indeed, the Security Council resolution provides an exception for humanitarian aid. But semi-industrialized Iraq is crucially reliant on imported technology and foreign expertise to sustain a largely urbanized population. Unless there is significant violation of the U.N. embargo, Iraq's civilians face prolonged hardship, joblessness, rationing and demoralizing isolation. The blockade has stopped Iraqi oil exports, sealed its seaports and curtailed air traffic.
Has the embargo sprung any significant leaks? Kuwaiti diplomats contend that smuggling, with or without the tacit approval of neighboring states, is providing a vital lifeline. Yet a U.N. monitoring committee has yet to receive a single formal charge of sanction-busting. That alone proves little. But neither is there known evidence, from satellites or on-the-ground informants, of much in the way of truck convoys.
The familiar argument against the embargo is that such sanctions never work, or, if they do, work too slowly. The historical record is mixed; sanctions have clearly contributed to liberalizing political change in South Africa. But in any case, the embargo is the weapon supported by every country in the coalition opposing Saddam Hussein. Iraq is more isolated and vulnerable than any previous target.
Yet the Administration now hastens to give up this sound, widely supported policy and replace it with a sudden escalation. What's the rush?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
California Tried Democracy, And Look What's Happened Now

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
HERE in the land of new beginnings, what might be called the end of politics has begun.
A new Governor waits in the wings, having been elected by the lowest turnout in California history. Members of the State Legislature return to work next month, having had their budgets, staffs and terms clipped by angry voters. And if representative democracy has approached paralysis in California, the voters have also spurned the alternative, direct democracy by voter initiative, at least for now. This month, in a spasm of exasperation, confusion and resentment against new taxes, the voters said 'no' to almost everything on their ballot; one of the few exceptions was the proposition putting sharp limits on the terms of their representatives and leaders in Sacramento. 
 If, as the cliche goes, California leads the nation in trends, few would want to follow now when it comes to government. Chronic optimism has changed to pessimism in this state of irrepressible prosperity, the Golden State, which has reached a population of 29.3 million and is expected to grow by more than half a million people a year if recent trends persist. And if they find smog, congestion and crime at the end of the California rainbow, it is not clear that political leadership can help.
Nor does it seem that anyone can break the gridlock into which circumstances have forced the state government. "I try to be an optimist, a reformer," said Walter A. Zelman, former executive director of California Common Cause. "But I think we are in for a very bleak political period."
On Election Day, the voters of California seemed to say to their lawmakers: We pay you to write our laws. Don't make us do it. At the same time they took much of the legislators' power away, by imposing lifetime term limits of six years in the Assembly and eight years in the Senate and cutting their budgets by about 40 percent. Already, many senior lawmakers are looking for other work or offices to run for.
Most political scientists agree that this has shifted the balance of power from the Democratic-controlled Legislature toward the Republican Governor-elect, Senator Pete Wilson.
All of this represents something of a reversal of a generation-long trend in California government. From a corrupt amateur Legislature that could be bought for the price of lunch from the famed lobbyist Artie Samish, who ultimately was convicted of tax evasion in 1953, the Legislature was turned into a full-time professional body in 1966 under the late Democratic Speaker of the Assembly, Jesse M. Unruh. That trend spread nationwide.
"But we have now entered into a phase of weakening of the Legislature, and the Governor's office may try to pick up the slack," said Prof. Bruce Cain of the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California, Berkeley.
But Mr. Wilson faces no picnic. He is regarded as a moderate and expected to work much more closely with the Legislature in Sacramento than the fiscally conservative Republican incumbent, George Deukmejian, but he is not fully beloved among lawmakers of either party, who widely believe that it was his support for the term-limits measure, called Proposition 140, that put it over the top.
The day after his victory over Dianne Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco, Mr. Wilson said he would "get along just fine" with the Legislature; in response, the President Pro Tempore of the Senate, David Roberti of Los Angeles, said, "We are going to be sitting across the table from this guy who helped bring in this 300-pound gorilla named Prop 140, and it's going to be hard to forget that in human terms." The view was no different in the office of the powerful Speaker of the Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco.
The first thing that Mr. Wilson and the Legislature will tangle over is the politically charged question of how to erase a shortfall in the state's $55 billion budget that is expected to reach $2 billion by the time Mr. Wilson takes office on Jan. 7. With tax revenues falling and demands for government services rising because of the weakening economy, it is now questionable whether Mr. Wilson can keep his campaign pledge not to raise income taxes and to respect the voters' resounding rejection of more taxes and spending. After that, he and the Legislature will face off on reapportioning Congressional districts in California, which is to gain seven seats in 1992. Amid this, hundreds of the Governor's political appointees will have to pass muster in Mr. Roberti's Senate.
"The potential for public policy gridlock has never been greater," observed Mr. Roberti's spokesman, Bob Forsyth.
Critics say the Legislature is gridlocked because it is excessively beholden to industry special interests for campaign funds, and the conviction of a State Senator and former Senator earlier this year on vote-selling charges in part of a widening Federal corruption investigation has done little to alter that view.
Instead, voters in recent years have turned to the initiative, that especially California tool of making law by dynamite that began in 1911 as part of Gov. Hiram Johnson's Progressive Era measures to clean up government. The process remained mostly dormant until the late 1970's, when it became a "de facto branch of government," in the words of Bill Bradley, editor of New West Notes, a California political newsletter. Over and over again, voters here made law and history -- with Proposition 13 in 1978, which capped property tax increases, with Proposition 65 in 1986, which forced the labeling or reformulation of products with hazardous ingredients, with Proposition 103 in 1988, which promised to roll back insurance rates. And over those years, voters in the 22 other states that permit voters to make law by ballot intiative joined this revolution.
But this year the revolution seemed to turn against the initiative process itself, which Prof. Eugene C. Lee of Berkeley calls "an idea whose time has passed." Paradoxically, this citizen tool of government has become just another tool of well financed interests that have seized on it to write law without the hindrance of legislative compromise. The growing accumulation of such initiative-passed laws has also tied the hands of the Governor and the Legislature because the ballot measures often award set budget allocations to programs that cannot be trimmed in the budget process.
On Nov. 6, the voters of California rejected all but 6 of the 28 statewide initiatives and bond measures on the ballot, including the environmental initiative known as Big Green, which was once thought a sure winner, higher taxes on alcholic beverages, and even bonds for child care centers, parks, water projects and prison construction. "The despair over the lack of efficacy of government institutions has now spread to the initiative process," said Mr. Bradley.
Among the few measures that passed were one that forbids use of gill nets for fishing that snare marine mammals and another that will exclude building improvements to strengthen against earthquakes from property tax assessments. Both are the California equivalent of apple pie.
 
No on Everything
 "Many people simply decided to vote no on everything, either in disgust or out of feeling that the Legislature ought to be handling this stuff," said Prof. Gordon Baker, a political scientist at the University of California's campus in Santa Barbara. "But it's ironic because the reason they are on the ballot is that the Legislature hasn't handled them."
Some said that this was just a passing voter mood, that people were voting their pocketbooks, and they note that much the same happened in other states, in Virginia, Washington, Oregon. New York State's big environmental bond proposal, which would have cost $800 million, also failed.
If the voters were resisting the price of the ballot initiatives rather than the idea of initiatives, this argument goes, the next California ballot will again be jammed with confusing proposals. "If there is a temporary learning, I have complete faith it will be forgotten," said Professor Cain.
A movement is growing to make it more difficult to govern by ballot measure, by raising the number of signatures required, requiring them to pass pre-election technical review and permitting the Legislature and Governor to amend or repeal them after a certain time. Anticipating this, the remnants of Howard Jarvis's and Paul Gann's anti-tax and spending crusades of a decade ago put together an initiative that would have changed the California constitution to require that any change in the initiative and referendum process be approved by the voters. But that measure failed, too, by 55 percent to 45 percent.
Meanwhile, California continues to grow, its lure for migrants, American and foreign -- drawn by its glamor, wealth, climate, opportunities -- hardly diminished by its problems. How long this persists may well depend on whether a new Governor and newly chastened legislators can resolve their differences and get on with the public's business.

HEADLINE: TACTICAL POSITIONS;
Congress Asks What It Should Do In the Gulf, and How

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
CONGRESS, or at least enough of it to form the sort of critical mass that attracts media attention, reappeared briefly here last week and found itself engaged in a confusing, ad-hoc debate on American policy in the Persian Gulf.
The debate in the corridors might never have occurred had not Congress been away, listening to the voters, when President Bush ordered additional troops to the gulf. Had he moved the nation closer to war with Iraq? If so, some lawmakers, including leaders in Mr. Bush's own party, said that Congress ought to reconvene immediately to vote its acquiescence or disapproval. 
 But faced with a choice that stark, and mindful of a public increasingly nervous about the talk of war, Democratic congressional leaders concluded that support for Mr. Bush's initial gulf policy and official ambiguity on his more recent actions was the better course for now.
Part of the reason lies with the ambiguity of the Constitution, which divides responsibilities for warmaking between the President as Commander in Chief and the Congress as the sole authority for declaring war. In a modern world, where the enemy armada no longer arrives with three months' notice and where hostilities thousands of miles away require an immediate response, the congressional role has at best become a legal nicety.
Desperate to be heard in a military matter more serious than any since Vietnam, Congress has had difficulty deciding how that is best accomplished. Should it act as critic and face blame for undermining the President in an international crisis, or accept consultant status to the White House and share political responsibility for policies it is not a full partner in shaping?
In the end, Senate Democrats settled on hearings by the Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees as a way to force the Administration to outline its goals and military plans more clearly.
"We have a Hobson's choice," said Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, the second-ranking Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee. "Either we ratify or reject a declaration of war once it is presented to us, or we attempt to affect the thinking of the Administration prior to its committing the nation to a course of action that leaves us only a third, unattractive option -- pulling the plug somewhere down the road and weakening our country."
But any effort to affect the Administration's thinking requires some consensus among members of Congress. Judging by the cacophony on Capitol Hill, it is hard to imagine what that might be.
 
A Plethora of Opinions
 "You have 535 opinions," said Representative Dante Fascell, the Florida Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee. "Actually, you have 635 because you have to count the Senate twice. Each senator has two opinions."
For most lawmakers, the overriding concern was the President's decision to order at least another 150,000 American troops to join the 230,000 already dispatched to the gulf since Iraq invaded Kuwait. Some complained that Mr. Bush should have consulted Congress first. Others, like Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, warned that the new deployments had shifted the mission from a defensive to an offensive one that would lead inexorably to war unless Congress stepped in now. "It's my sense after being around here and seeing Panama, Grenada, Libya and Vietnam that members are very unwilling to do anything other than support the men and women under fire," he said. "Historically, we have winked at the Constitution and simply put our fingers to the wind."
Even Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee and is a traditional Administration ally, worried that logistics had begun to drive policy. "The President has made a very good case for sending troops to defend Saudi Arabia and to enforce the United Nations economic embargo against Iraq," he said. "He has yet to make the case that liberating Kuwait is in our vital interest and worth American lives." Asked whether he thought Kuwait was in America's vital interest, Mr. Nunn replied: "The burden is on the President. I'll let him make the case before I respond."
At a White House meeting on Wednesday, Mr. Bush managed to quell some criticism by assuring Congressional leaders that he had made no decision to take offensive action against Iraq. The additional troops were necessary, he said, to make the threat of force credible to Mr. Hussein.
Mr. Fascell said the meeting was hardly conclusive. "I don't have the answer," he said. "You can't keep the troops there forever unless you are really willing and able to use them, and in the end it's going to be a political decision. In a technical sense, the economic sanctions are working just great, but I've never had any illusions that the embargo by itself would get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait."
While the Administration and lawmakers in both parties have affirmed support for the sanctions, there are deep disagreements on how long they should be relied on. At the White House meeting, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley spoke for many Democrats in telling the President that perhaps a year and a half would be needed for the sanctions to work. An hour later, the House Republican leader, Bob Michel of Illinois, was telling reporters that such a time frame was "far beyond" what he considered appropriate.
Senator Bob Kasten of Wisconsin, the senior Republican on the Appropriations foreign operations subcommittee, explained the impatience: "The sanctions may be working perfectly and not matter. The question is what do you do with a dictator who doesn't care about the welfare of his people, doesn't care whether there is enough food or medicine?"
Apply more aggressive psychological pressure, said Senator Bill Bradley, a New Jersey Democrat, who argues that the sanctions have already begun to bite on Iraq's industrial base and that within six to nine months the effects on the military establishment should be visible as well. "We should be telling the Iraqis that the sanctions are working, and what's going to happen to them next month and the month after that," he said.
And if Mr. Hussein is still in Kuwait six or nine months out? "Then we have air power," he said. "We don't have to have a full-scale land war."
 
Looking to the Future
 Some lawmakers have tried to focus the debate on the longer term. "The important thing is to think ahead," said the House Majority Leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. "If we precipitously use force to achieve our short-term objectives, if we kill a lot of people, where do we wind up in the Arab world over the long run?
"I want to spend some time talking to Arab experts," he added, "to try and figure out how the Arabs view this, to see if we can understand what Saddam Hussein is thinking."
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, a senior Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, is also thinking long term, but with a different purpose. Convinced that there will be military action by the spring if Mr. Hussein has not left Kuwait voluntarily, he said the real issue is what happens afterward.
"I'm talking about a change of leadership in Iraq and a winding up of their chemical and nuclear weapons potential," he said. "That is the threat to the Middle East and to world peace, and it must be met, because if it is not met, it will grow."
A valid point, agreed Representative Henry Hyde of Illinois, the senior Republican on the House Intelligence Committee. "But to talk about it is implicitly to talk about war. Nobody believes Saddam Hussein is going to give up that capability simply because we ask him to."
Senator Daniel P. Moynihan rued the ad-hoc debate as a poor substitute for the formal one he said should have taken place. He blamed the Administration for not seeking a formal statement of support from Congress. And he blamed Congress.
"I think it was our responsibility," the New York Democrat said. "If they didn't, we should have. Maybe it was too much to ask with the gridlock of the budget and on the eve of the election."
Mr. Lugar echoed those sentiments. "Ultimately, people in public life have to take responsibility. If our democracy works so badly that we can't even risk having a debate because we'd make a hash of it, that would be a very severe indictment."

HEADLINE: Shrinking Returns For Bush's Journeys?

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
SOMETIMES, President Bush's cadence seems a bit off.
 In 1989, as change swept the Continent, the President declined to visit Eastern Europe. Now, as Mr. Bush finally visits the region, arriving in Prague on the first anniversary of Czechoslovakia's democratic revolution, Eastern Europe is no longer the center-ring attraction. 
 The world's attention is focused elsewhere: on the Persian Gulf, where Mr. Bush will make an appearance on Thanksgiving Day. And the optimism of this capital has faded as economic hardship replaced the headiness of revolution.
 None of that seemed to bother the Czechoslovak leaders or the residents of Prague, who gave Mr. Bush an enthusiastic reception. And it certainly did not bother Mr. Bush as he left behind the part of the Presidency he likes the least, domestic governance, and took up his favorite part, aerobic diplomacy.
 Over the next week, in five countries, Mr. Bush will meet with dozens of heads of state at a security conference in Paris. He will sign a landmark arms control treaty that reduces conventional armed forces in Europe for the first time since World War II. He is the first American President to visit Czechoslovakia and will be the first since Lyndon B. Johnson to visit front-line combat troops.
 The schedule, grueling even by Mr. Bush's Marco Polo standards, is only the beginning. Now that the domestic demands of campaign travel are gone, Mr. Bush plans at least one foreign trip a month through April, with Mexico on his schedule for next week and South America in December.
 Is all this activity worthwhile? The novelty of these international dashes certainly has worn off after nearly two years of frequent flying. The political value also may be diminishing -- public approval of Mr. Bush's handling of the Gulf crisis has been slipping in poll after poll. But the President and his aides still are convinced that the nonstop diplomatic caravan plays to Mr. Bush's strengths and gives respite to a President whose chief aides are admitting that they really have no domestic agenda.
 Here in Prague, the budget battles and the disappointing mid-term election results seemed distant indeed. Mr. Bush got a rousing ovation from a legislature that did not care whether he kept his no-taxes pledge; and as he stood in Wenceslas Square, virtually every office window sported his portrait.

HEADLINE: The World;
To Serve Its New Politics, Poland Re-Invents the TV Ad

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
NONE of the candidates speak in sound bites. Nobody has climbed atop a tank, and space-age graphics seem light years away. But as Poland prepares to hold its first free presidential elections since 1922, its voters are being electronically courted as never before.
The television advertising is an important aspect of this nation's halting steps toward developing a political style. For 45 years, virtually every political institution, from speechmaking to voting to advertising, was discredited by its service to a system in which political choice was sham. Poland's 10 million-strong opposition movement sprang up overnight in 1980 precisely because people had long since disengaged from that charade. 
 Now Poland's political leaders are gingerly trying to put new life into the country's political institutions, building credibility by finding new visual or rhetorical styles that do not evoke the Communist past. Nowhere has that effort been more evident than with the television advertising aired in preparation for the Nov. 25 presidential election. Each night the six candidates have several minutes of free time on state-run television to present their commercials. These have ranged from visually arresting cartoons to stultifyingly dull shots of politicians intently reading from prepared texts.
None of the candidates have tried an American-style attack video, and officials from several campaigns said the choice was deliberate.
"We all grew up in the Solidarity movement and it seemed to us that mudslinging would be a bad method," said Jacek Skalski, the movie director who directs television advertising for Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. "This is what Communist propaganda was, denigrating others as bad candidates. Slandering opponents, that was their technique."
Mr. Skalski never produced a commercial before he was hired, on two days' notice, by the Mazowiecki camp, though he said he has looked at Western advertisements. The ideas and designs of the television spots here are based largely on instinct; the results of public opinion polls come in about a week after the commercials appear, too late to gauge what is working and what is not.
Unlike Czechoslovakia, where the elections earlier this year featured the work of several Western advertising agencies, the political ads here are being prepared by home-grown talents. Ryszard Grabowski, the head of the television campaign for Lech Walesa, the Solidarity chairman, worked on clandestine television programs during the martial law years in the early 1980's. For the last year, he has been a reporter for Polish television. "This is our first campaign," Mr. Grabowski said. "And none of us has any experience doing this."
In their speeches and essays in newspapers, some of Mr. Walesa's opponents have depicted the Solidarity chairman as a headstrong, unstable politician with dictatorial tendencies. Mr. Grabowski said that some voters believe this portrait, and that many of his early commercials were designed to reassure the public. They showed Mr. Walesa in a suit and tie, speaking calmly to the audience. Several of the spots show videotapes of Mr. Walesa being extravagantly praised by the same leading political figures who now call him a dangerous candidate.
Last week, however, Mr. Mazowiecki and Mr. Walesa both took daring risks.
Mr. Walesa aired a new commercial: a cartoon showing a thick black line drawn across the screen. It stretches but does not break until vigorously attacked by an ax. The spot is an allusion to two of the most widely quoted images in the Polish campaign. When Mr. Mazowiecki took office last year, he said he was drawing a "thick line," and he offered former Communists a fair chance to contribute their talents to the new Poland. Earlier this year, Mr. Walesa declared that Poland needs a president who can wield an ax and root out former Communists, a remark seized upon by his critics as evidence of the Solidarity chairman's dictatorial tendencies.
Meanwhile, Mr. Mazowiecki tried out a commercial last week that breaks the mold. It opens with visually arresting black-and-white scenes of a 1980 hunger march in Lodz, one of Poland's grimmest industrial cities. The spot then cuts to close-ups of rationing coupons and empty store shelves before closing with white block letters that read: "It can return. Do you want it? If not, vote Mazowiecki." The commercial touches on one of the central themes of the Mazowiecki campaign: that any deviation from the rigorous economic reform program under way will bring a return of scarcity.
Some people here saw the commercial as scare tactics, and said its tone was reminiscent of the Communist propaganda of the mid-1980's, which juxtaposed shots of empty stores with footage of Solidarity protesters. It is in sharp contrast to Mr. Walesa's commercials, which open with a shot of cheering crowds and a logo that reads "Tak" -- the Polish word for "yes."
None of the candidates seem completely at ease on television. Roman Bartoszcze, the Peasants Party candidate, read stiffly from a prepared text in his first appearance. Mr. Mazowiecki, in an early attempt to personalize his candidacy, was shown awkwardly playing badminton and walking in the park with two hulking security guards dogging his footsteps. Mr. Walesa, for his part, has refused to allow his television advisers to shoot videotape of his family for use in the election.
In an interview last week, Mr. Mazowiecki acknowledged the primacy of television in modern democracies but said his experiences with it have left him uneasy. "I feel comfortable as a spokesman for my ideas," said Mr. Mazowiecki, who spent most of his adult life as a journalist at a Catholic weekly. "As a spokesman for my own person, I feel unnatural."

HEADLINE: The World;
Recovering Marcos Assets Proves Trying For Aquino

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
NEARLY five years after former Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos fled the country carrying with him crates of jewels, gold and pesos, the Philippine Government has recovered relatively little of what officials in Manila say was $5 billion to $10 billion in money and assets pillaged from the country he ruled for two decades.
Now negotiations between the Philippines and lawyers for Imelda Marcos to return some of the wealth have stirred deep unease among some Filipinos, who see any settlement as a retreat from the crusade that has been waged by Corazon C. Aquino since before she became president in 1986. 
 The negotiations seek an agreement to drop a civil suit in Los Angeles Federal court in return for Marcos funds in Hong Kong banks amounting to at least $200 million. The suit, which has frozen nearly all Marcos assets worldwide, is the lead case in a complex of court actions around the world that Mrs. Marcos inherited along with her husband's well-hidden fortune.
"Our lawyers," Mrs. Marcos said recently, "were going crazy. We had to be in Virginia, in Hawaii, in New York, in Pittsburgh, in Seattle, in New Jersey. At some time we had several dozens of cases not only worldwide but around the United States."
But the negotiations to settle the Los Angeles case, combined with the acquittal of Mrs. Marcos in July on Federal racketeering charges in New York, make it seem evident that as time goes by and the possibilities of finding and recovering the money fade, so does the Philippine Government's momentum.
"They are cutting their losses, and Imelda is going to get away with most of the money," said one Philippine lawyer. "For the Philippine Government to agree to drop the suit is a serious admission that it is unable to bring her to justice."
 
Problems at Home
 The slow pace of the recovery effort, and the disillusionment that has accompanied it, reflect a fading of hope and idealism in the Philippines as Mrs. Aquino's Government continues to struggle with corruption, inefficiency, human-rights abuses, economic stagnation, and violence from the far left and the far right.
Her administration came in with the hope for the quick recovery of vast wealth from Mr. Marcos and his friends, to be used, among other things, to pay for far-reaching land redistribution -- a program which itself never went very far beyond the planning stage.
"It's exactly the Aquino Government in microcosm," said Severina Rivera, who was legal director of Manila's international asset-recovery efforts until 1988. "Any Filipino you talk to will talk about lost opportunities. And I think the asset-recovery program is like that: lost opportunities."
In addition to the problems at home that have impeded the recovery attempts, Mrs. Marcos has armed herself with a phalanx of lawyers who have delayed proceedings, or successfully argued that she knew nothing about where the money came from. The Philippine Government was also hoping that a Federal racketeering conviction would aid in its civil suits.
In the meantime, the buildings and paintings Manila is seeking to recover have depreciated in value and, it seems likely, Mr. Marcos's associates have had the opportunity to further hide their assets. As with other hopes of 1986 that now appear exaggerated, Ms. Rivera said it now seems unlikely that the Marcos wealth was ever as vast as imagined, or that the Philippine Government will recover a significant portion of it.
And if the political winds shift dramatically when Mrs. Aquino's term is up in 1992, some Filipinos now suggest, the emphasis might also shift to an investigation of corruption during the Aquino years. It is not clear how aggressively a post-Aquino Government would continue the attempt to recover the Marcos wealth. Scandals involving the Presidential Commission on Good Government, the Philippine agency charged with recovering the Marcos wealth, has contributed to public cynicism.
"We had the best-situated effort ever of all the asset-recovery attempts by governments all around the world," Ms. Rivera said. "We had world sympathy, a very sophisticated knowledge of the U.S. courts and Swiss courts, concrete evidence of the thefts and the assets. And now it's just falling apart."
Even if the Los Angeles case proceeds, said Michael Doyen, one of the attorneys for the Philippine Government, the multimillion-dollar search for hidden funds could continue for years.
"The Marcoses were nothing if not experts at putting their money in some of the world's great havens for people with an interest in secreting their funds," he said. "It's all the greatest hits here of secret hideaways: the Cayman Islands, Lichtenstein, Switzerland."
So far, less than $1 billion of the Marcos wealth has been identified, of which more than $100 million is in the United States in the form of real estate, jewelry and art. In the Philippines the Government says it has identified about $200 million, of which half has been recovered.
In Switzerland, Philippine officials say about $400 million has been frozen in deposits in about 50 bank accounts. The full amount could be far greater. The Swiss Government has indicated that Manila has the right to the money if it can convict Mrs. Marcos in a Philippine criminal court. But Mrs. Aquino has barred Mrs. Marcos from returning to the Philippines, a stand that ultimately serves to block the recovery of those tantalizing hundreds of millions of dollars.

HEADLINE: WOMAN IN THE NEWS: Joan B. Campbell;
'Seasoned Ecumenist' Takes Charge

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 15

 BODY:
Until she was 40 years old, the Rev. Joan Brown Campbell was a full-time mother, wife, housekeeper and community volunteer.
Just two days after her 59th birthday, Ms. Campbell was elected to the top ecumenical position in the nation, the general secretary of the National Council of Churches. 
 "Imagine what she would be doing if she had started at 22," her daughter, Jane Louise Campbell, said Wednesday night on the eve of her mother's election.
The elder Ms. Campbell was described by colleagues as a "seasoned ecumenist," a "motivator, enabler and reconciler" and a woman with a deep faith and open mind.
But to her daughter, the eldest of her three children (Ms. Campbell has two sons, Paul Jr. and James), the new general secretary was a towering role model.
"She gave us a sense of social responsibility and a sense of responsibility to the family and home," said the younger Ms. Campbell, the mother of two young children and a Representative in the Ohio Legislature.
 
Memories of the 1960's
 The daughter remembered when, in the 1960's, her family got bomb threats after they invited the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to preach in their church in the Cleveland suburb of Shaker Heights. "My mother's reaction was: 'Clean up under your beds. The police will be looking for bombs, and I don't want them to find any mess under there.' "
Ms. Campbell, currently the head of the American office of the World Council of Churches, will take the helm of the National Council in March. She will succeed James A. Hamilton, a United Methodist layman, who did not run for re-election.
Mrs. Campbell will be the second woman and the first female minister to serve in the post in the organization's 40-year history.
The National Council of Churches is the nation's largest ecumenical body, encompassing 32 Christian denominations with 42 million members. These include the so-called mainline churches, like the Methodists, Presbyterians and Episcopalians; the historically black churches, like the African Methodist Episcopal Church, and the Orthodox churches, including the Antiochian, Armenian, Coptic, Greek, Syrian and the Orthodox Church in America.
 
Policy and Charity
 While the denominations act independently, the council links them in activities from interfaith dialogue to overseas relief. The council also issues public-policy statements, like the one approved this week condemning the American military buildup in the Persian Gulf.
The council suffered a loss of influence and a decline in membership in the 1980's, when it was overshadowed on the national scene by the Roman Catholic bishops, who spoke out on nuclear arms and abortion, and the evangelical Protestant churches, who made their influence felt through organizations like the Moral Majority. It was also battered by internal divisions and strife that resulted from a huge reorganization.
In an interview, Ms. Cambell said she did not expect the council to return to the influence it exerted in 1958, when President Dwight D. Eisenhower laid the cornerstone for its headquarters at 475 Riverside Drive in Manhattan.
"I'm not nostalgic," she said. "I think we need to be as strong a voice as we can exercise in this period of history."
 
Searching for the Spiritual
 "Never during the 20 years I have worked within the ecumenical movement have I sensed a time when unity was more urgent," she added. "We are a nation on the brink of war, faced with increased racism and economic insecurity. We are a people searching for spiritual answers in the face of an uncertain future."
Ms. Campbell said she hopes to strengthen the council by emphasizing its variety of churches, and by reaching out and inspiring the young who she said are ready to be brought into the churches. "When people think of the council, they think of the mainline churches," she said. "We have to work hard in making our diversity known."
Joan Brown Campbell, who was born Nov. 13, 1931, in Youngstown, Ohio, has standing as a minister in both the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and the American Baptist Churches (U.S.A.). She received a bachelor's degree in English and speech and a master's in education from the University of Michigan and studied urban ministry at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland before being ordained in 1980.
Ms. Campbell, who was divorced when her children were teen-agers, continues to have a cordial relationship with her former husband, Paul Campbell Sr., a lawyer. The two get together each year with their children and grandchildren for Thanksgiving dinners. She lives in Manhattan, said she enjoys Broadway plays and walking along Riverside Drive. She will use almost any business trip as an excuse to stop in Cleveland to visit her four grandchildren, ages 4, 3, 2 and 1.
 
Ms. Inside, Ms. Outside
 Ms. Campbell said that she relished and never regretted the years she devoted to raising her family. "It taught me patience, perseverance and risk-taking," she said.
Margaret Sonnenday of St. Louis, who headed the search committee that chose the new general secretary, said Ms. Campbell had the advantage of being both an insider in the council (she worked there before going to the World Council in 1985) and being an outsider during its difficult years in the late 1980's.
If she had heard any criticism of the candidate, Ms. Sonnenday said, it was that "in her enthusiasm" Ms. Campbell would forge ahead with projects before building a consensus.
Ms. Campbell said she was aware of the criticism. In her new job, she said, she would "keep testing" and keep looking behind her to make sure "the people are with me."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2764 words

HEADLINE: The Partners' Revolt at Peat Marwick

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
IN THE END, it was the suit that gave him away, a hand-tailored symbol of how far Larry D. Horner had fallen.
 Mr. Horner -- who had led the world's largest accounting firm through six years of tumult, growth and change -- was moving out of his corner office at KPMG Peat Marwick a few weeks ago, vacating it for his successor, when a meeting of retired partners took place in Florida. One morning at the podium, he paraphrased Longfellow, expressing the wistful hope that his years as Peat's chairman would enable him to "leave behind us footprints on the sands of time." 
But the following evening, in a room blackened with tuxedos, it was clear that the footprints were already fading. "No one told Larry," said Walter O'Connor, a former Peat board member, that the dress code had been changed to black tie. He was one of the only dignitaries without a cummerbund.
 "He looked really disgruntled and unhappy," said another retired board member, who insisted on anonymity. "No one was paying any attention to him. It was a jolt to his ego."
 It was also a sharp reminder of why he was no longer in his job. A partners' revolt, arousing passions rarely seen in the staid world of accountancy, had forced him out even though he may have been the best man to lead Peat through the treacherous times it now faces. The players could have been lifted straight out of a board game -- or Greek tragedy: a charismatic, but stubborn, protagonist too proud to bend to the wishes of those who elected him; a group of young, impatient partners who believe they should be making more than their already-six-figure incomes; an agitator preoccupied with a personal grudge, and a loyal, but ambitious, underling maneuvering to win center stage if his mentor stumbles.
 By the time the game played itself out, Larry Horner's departure had ramifications well beyond the Fifth Avenue office overlooking Central Park that was being readied for Jon C. Madonna, the new chairman. Peat, after all, has thousands of clients, including some of America's bluest-chip companies, and its policies and actions, shaped by the chairman, spill into offices around the globe.
 At home, the departure left Peat with a relatively inexperienced chairman with little overseas background at a time when the firm is bumping along in a soft economy and the international business is more important than ever. And it brought into sharp relief the thorny issue of partnership, where, in Peat's case, 1,850 people were told they owned the firm, but many ended up doubting it.
 Private partnerships, where compensation is determined by one's peers, are never tranquil places to work. And Peat Marwick has had more than its share of unrest. In October 1979, for example, 1,053 partners of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., as the firm was then known, gathered at a posh Florida resort for a meeting that should have been just a formality. But when Walter E. Hanson, then chairman, asked them to accept his hand-picked successor, a few partners brought on a groundswell and an insurgent candidate breezed into office. That, in company lore, was the "Battle of Boca Raton."
 
A Populist View
 Now, more than a decade later, those populist stirrings still run deep at KPMG Peat Marwick, as the American firm has been known since 1987, when it merged with KMG Main Hurdman, an Anglo-Dutch firm. The merger created the world's largest accounting firm, a loose collection of powerful national entities with the American operation contributing a whopping $1.8 billion to the parent's total $5 billion in revenues in fiscal 1990.
 Even the American operation is far from being a united one. "When it comes time for a big election, the partners do whatever they want," said Thomas L. Holton, the insurgent who won at Boca Raton.
 The latest sparks of unrest began flashing in January, when compensation figures at four competing accounting firms were reported in the press. Partners at three of those firms had averaged $228,100 or more in the previous year, the reports said.
 Peat had long told its partners that they were at -- or near -- the top of the industry in terms of compensation. So the press reports "hit Peat Marwick like a thunderbolt," said a former tax partner, who contends that Peat partners averaged less than $200,000 in fiscal 1989.
 Younger partners, in particular, started questioning Peat's pyramid-like pay system. Mr. Horner was making $1.2 million by the end of his term as chairman, roughly 10 times what the lowest-level Peat partner earns. And there were 12 rather well-paid vice chairmen, three added during the Horner days.
 The younger partners were irritated, and their political clout made their voices important. The numbers are telling: of the 1,850 current Peat partners, 751 got their spots in just the last six years, giving the younger group more votes than usually mandated by seniority and performance.
After the press reports, Robert W. Beecher, then Peat's deputy chairman, promptly circulated a memo saying that partner compensation at Peat averaged $246,000 a year. But partners say that figure was inflated because it included interest earned on the capital that partners invested in the firm and was not adjusted downward to reflect the $15,000 average contribution that partners make to their pension plan every year. Failing to Change
 To blunt criticism, Mr. Horner named a task force to study the firm's governance structure, including its possibly bloated upper management. But he put several of the controversial vice chairmen on it. In April, when it recommended keeping the prevailing structure, many partners were outraged. "The committee was too beholden to Larry," said one.
 By June, the softening American economy and the slowdown in deals -- ranging from mergers and acquisitions to initial public offerings -- were taking their toll on all three of Peat's basic businesses: auditing, tax and consulting. After years of double-digit increases, Peat's domestic revenues for the year ended June 30 rose only 3 percent. Worse, the American partners made only $180 a share, flat from the year before, fanning fears that the KMG merger had yet to pay off for them. It was also becoming clear that some of softer spots -- like consulting, which Mr. Horner had neglected in favor of pursuing such new international clients as Pepsico -- were unable to hide behind prosperous lines of business.
 "Larry was really focused externally," said Mr. Madonna, expressing a view that Mr. Horner shares. "Larry viewed his role as the chairman to put in place our international network and to be the lead guy with our major clients, and that is where he focused his energies."
 If all this was like a cauldron waiting to boil over, it was Charles T. Smith who turned up the heat. Mr. Smith, a retired partner in Greenville, S.C., served on Peat's board from 1984 to 1986. He calls himself a big booster of the firm who "certainly doesn't want to say anything detrimental." But several former board members and partners say that he has nursed a grudge against Peat ever since he rejoined it in late 1969 after a nearly three-year absence.
 At that time, Mr. Smith asked Peat to consider his 13 years with the firm prior to 1967 in calculating his pension. "The plan was clear," said Mr. Hanson, who, as chairman of the firm, first handled the complaint. "He knew when he came back that he had no right to an extended pension." Fueling Mr. Smith's bitterness, partners say, was that he retired in December 1986, 10 months before changes in the partners' pension plan would have provided fatter benefits.
 Mr. Smith's complaints, detailed in a one-inch-thick, double-sided letter sent to all 1,850 Peat partners at his own expense in June, found a wide audience.
 The letter, an abridged version of a roughly 300-page tome he had sent to the board, saved its most pointed barbs for Mr. Horner, according to several current and former partners who read it. "I don't think there was any question that he intended to put Larry in a bad light," said D. Edward Martin, a former Peat partner.
 The letter complained about the nearly $1 million that Mr. Horner borrowed from the firm at the prime rate plus 1 percentage point so he could buy a $2 million apartment in Manhattan after becoming chairman in 1984. A Peat spokesman said that because of the profession's conflict of interest rules, accountants must avoid borrowing from banks audited by their firms. That is a problem for Peat partners because of the firm's many financial services clients. To get around it, Peat gave Mr. Horner a loan -- one of 442 now outstanding to various partners -- to help him relocate from California, where he had been a vice chairman in the Los Angeles office.
 The letter also griped about the chauffeur-driven grey Cadillac which Peat paid for whenever Mr. Horner traveled on business. And it objected to the firm's handling of a messy real estate investment, which, although it was independent of the firm itself, could have resulted in bankruptcy for roughly 60 key partners, including most of the the firm's Boston office and Mr. Beecher, then deputy chairman.
 Peat officials insist that the firm poured no money into the problem beyond advancing the Boston group some money against the balances in their capital accounts and the modest amount that Peat spent on its own legal fees. But many Peat partners still fume over the incident.
 Finally, the letter raised complaints about changes in the pension fund, which entitled partners retiring after October 1987 to receive up to 40 percent of their pay, up from about 35 percent under the old formula. The partners had approved the changes, but Mr. Smith and others contended it would unduly enrich senior managers because the plan did not cap the maximum annual benefit at $200,000.
 The timing of the letter proved to be as vexing as its contents. It came just a few weeks before Mr. Horner and K. Dane Brooksher, his hand-picked running mate, started visiting partners in six cities to discuss their candidacies for chairman and deputy chairman. Both men were already endorsed by the board but it was the partners who would have final say. The Stubborn Leader
 Mr. Horner's choice of Mr. Brooksher had been troubled from the beginning. Months before going on the campaign trail, Mr. Horner faced growing support for another running mate -- and rejected it.
 As several partners recounted the incident, the seeds of dissatisfaction had been planted the previous fall, at the firm's annual meeting. At the head table at dinner one evening, crowded with Peat's most powerful international partners, Mr. Horner had seated a young newcomer, a raven-haired man with an incandescent smile. At a firm in need of an heir-apparent, reading tea leaves had become a sport, and the partners at the other tables buzzed: So this would be Larry's choice for running mate, they murmured approvingly.
 The man beside Mr. Horner was Jon C. Madonna, head of Peat's San Francisco office. With the 56-year-old Mr. Horner nearing the firm's age-60 retirement date, the partners wanted an heir apparent who was young, charismatic, responsive to partner needs. Mr. Madonna, 47, fit the bill.
 But Mr. Horner, in fact, chose Mr. Brooksher, 51, who seemed far less promising and certainly not as charismatic, or so the partners said. And he compounded the error by refusing to switch running mates even after the partners told him, in meetings around the country, that Mr. Brooksher would not do. Mr. Horner said he did not want to drop Mr. Brooksher because it might cost Mr. Brooksher the respect of his clients and that could hurt the firm.
 The decision did not sit well in-house. And on Aug. 7, at the Plaza Hotel in New York, Mr. Horner called a special meeting of the board to announce that he would pull out of the race for chairman. He said he was doing it "for the benefit of the firm." He wanted to move on. The new chairman, he said, would need more than three years to wrestle with the long-term problems facing Peat, such as the viability of the partnership issue. "He made his case so convincingly that there wasn't a lot of room left for discussion," said J. Neal Purcell, who was present at the meeting. "It was irreversible."
 Within 24 hours, three partners were vying to fill Mr. Horner's job: Mr. Madonna, James G. Brocksmith Jr., the 49-year-old head of the Chicago office, and David C. Smith, the firm's vice chairman for taxes.
 When it became clear that Mr. Madonna and Mr. Brocksmith were the favorites, Mr. Smith dropped out. The remaining two contenders formed a ticket, with Mr. Madonna heading it. On Oct. 4, the partners voted them in.
 
Epilogue
 Mr. Madonna now fills the corner suite that Mr. Horner once held. Mr. Horner will remain chairman of KPMG, the parent operation, through December, but it is largely a ceremonial job and a non-paying one.
 He seems to have learned some lessons. As one of his last official acts, he authorized three new task forces to study compensation, retirement benefits and the firm's governance structure. Last month, the firm reconfigured its board to make it more democratic, cutting all 12 controversial vice chairmen from the board and expanding the number of nonmanagement members to 19 from 14. The changes turn what had been a management-heavy board into an oversight body, much like an outside board of directors at a corporation.
 Partners say they were pleased by the 11th-hour actions. But, for the man who had played such an important role at KPMG Peat Marwick, the grand gesture had come too late. SIZING UP A NEW BOSS
 IT is clearly too early to say how Jon Madonna will handle his new job. Partners have high hopes that he will get profits flowing again at Peat Marwick's American operation, revive areas that had grown lackluster under Larry Horner -- such as consulting -- and be more responsive to partner demands.
 But there are some sticking points. In an interview, a question on the Federal budget crisis, usually a favorite topic of debate for accountants, drew a rather tepid response. And at a firm whose leader must be as comfortable doing business in Frankfurt as in Wichita, he does not appear sure-footed dealing with world events. Asked about the implications of the Persian Gulf crisis, he had little to say, and then confused Egypt and Kuwait in describing which Peat partners might have had to make hasty escapes.
 "The international aspects of the firm are important, and that's something they are going to have to grow into," said Walter Hanson, a former chairman, speaking of the new team.

 
THE CURIOUS DISAPPEARING RUNNING MATE
 WHY Larry Horner refused to pick a running mate acceptable to Peat's partners remains a mystery, even to his successor, Jon Madonna.
 Mr. Madonna said that if Mr. Horner had offered him the No. 2 spot, he would have accepted it. Such a ticket might have been unbeatable. To many Peat partners, Mr. Horner, who had headed the firm's West German practice and won kudos in carrying out the off-again, on-again merger with KMG Main Hurdman, was just hitting his stride at the age of 56. With white hair and thickening waist, he looked like an amiable professor. But his appearance belied highly praised strategic planning skills and a willingness to use guerrilla tactics, such as hiring away the entire Canadian staff of Ernst & Whinney, a major competitor now part of Ernst & Young. Those traits helped make Peat a fearsome competitor in the profession.
 Mr. Madonna, by contrast, is a 47-year-old Californian whose sunny manner and chiseled features could have landed him a job anchoring the evening news. He fit the partners' youthful image of themselves and was smart enough to cast himself as the reformer who would make management more responsive to younger partners. He had won rave reviews for the way he ran the San Francisco office, and the way he cemented the firm's ties to once-shaky clients like Wells Fargo.
 "Madonna is just an outstanding partner, a partner's partner," said Robert B. Harman, a consultant at McKinsey & Company who used to be a partner at Peat.
 For his part, Mr. Horner said he "would have been delighted" to have linked up with Mr. Madonna. But, he said, the younger man was too much of an unknown to have won the board's approval and stood a better shot in three years, when the next election is scheduled. Clearly, Peat partners thought otherwise.
