HEADLINE: Tourism Industry Now No. 1 on Island

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
FOR the first time in Long Island history, tourism is the leading industry, in both revenue and employment, and there is growing recognition that the need to promote tourism is greater than ever.
Tourism has become better understood as a "clean" industry that attracts revenues and a wide range of jobs without major effects on the environment, Suffolk County Planning Director Arthur Kunz said. 
 Agriculture and tourism have traditionally been the two largest revenue-producing industries on Long Island. Travel-related spending on the Island rose, from $613 million in 1977 to slightly more than $2 billion in 1987, the most recent year for which statistics are available.
That was an increase of 226 percent over 10 years, Mr. Kunz said.
 
Travel-Related Jobs Rise
 In 1988, there were 95,000 travel-related jobs on the Island, making tourism the No. 1 industry in employment. That compared with 90,000 jobs in military industries, the second group in employment.
"To effectively promote tourism on the Island, we need to work with both New York City and the state in cooperative promotions, Mr. Kunz said. "The biggest shortfall of promotion efforts up to now has been their fragmented approach. Tourism has been promoted by individual hotels, museums and other attractions. But we have to change the focus and promote Long Island as a multiseason facility."
To determine the best direction to promote tourism, the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau has surveyed hotels, and the results are being analyzed. When asked how business this year compared with last year, 20 percent responded that business was much improved, 15 percent slightly improved, 5 percent the same, 40 percent slightly worse and 20 percent much worse.
Hotels on eastern Long Island were more positive, and those in Nassau were more pessimistic, the president of the bureau, Michael Davidson, said. Other preliminary findings show that the majority of recreational visitors to the East End are travelers from Nassau and Suffolk Counties, whereas business travelers tend to come from the entire New York metropolitan region, and a significant number are from California, Mr. Davidson said.
"We have always had a local market," he said. "One of our challenges is to draw from elsewhere. The survey so far is showing us that we should be concentrating on drawing from the New York metropolitan area. There's enough potential business within that range that our focus should be there. With a lower economy and people's reluctance to travel as far as in the past, Long Island is well positioned to draw the numbers."
The potential effect of a proposed 3 percent tax on all hotel rooms in Suffolk, part of the budget proposal in September, has met with mixed reactions. The indications are mixed on whether the tax will deter tourism, Mr. Davidson said, but his group officially opposes the tax as being an unfair burden on one industry.
A spokeswoman for County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, Lisa Mirabella, said most of the revenue from the tax would be specifically the advertising and promoting tourism.
 The Long Island Regional Planning Board study, financed by a grant from the State Economic Development Department, was completed last month.
 
List of Recommendations
 The study results indicated, Mr. Kunz said, there is a need to promote larger conventions at hotels, develop and promote recreational activities for families with children, build discount shopping outlets on the East End and direct part of the taxes from hotels to promotion.
The State Economic Development Department gave a grant last month to the Convention and Visitors Bureau, formerly the Long Island Tourism and Convention Commission, in the "I Love New York" matching-funds program. The program helps finance tourism promotion of 47 agencies.
Of the $5.2 million available through the program, the Long Island bureau applied for $250,000 and received $143,860. The money has to be spent on luring visitors from outside the region, Mr. Davidson said.
The bureau submitted this five-point marketing program in August:
*The promotion of charter-bus tours.
*A point-of-interest campaign.
*An arts-and-entertainment campaign.
*International promotion.
*The promotion of conventions and meetings.
 
Ample Space on Hand
 With the development of full-service hotels, there is now ample space to attract small and medium conventions, Mr. Davidson said.
A Meeting Planners Guide, to be published next month, will include "spouse trips." It will be mailed to selected planners and distributed at trade shows, Mr. Davidson said.
The new hotels and softness in business travel have resulted in an overabundance of hotel space, and conventions should be promoted, said Dianne Conway, director of convention sales for the Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Forty-eight hotels on Long Island may be suitable for meetings or conventions, she said. All provide full services geared to the corporate traveler, including meeting rooms, health clubs and concierges.
The six newest are the Huntington Hilton, formerly the Royce Carlton; the Marriott Windwatch in Hauppauge, the Marriott Residence Inn in Plainview, the Days Hotel in Brookhaven, the Radisson Islandia in Islandia and the Radisson Plaza in Melville, which opened in May.
 
What the Message Says
 "We want to bring the message to meeting planners that Long Island is an ideal spot to hold conferences, meetings and seminars," Ms. Conway said.
"When people are done with their business, there are so many sights and attractions to visit. During their free time, they can tour the Gold Coast mansions on the North Shore, visit the beautiful beaches, go whale watching off Montauk or tour the wineries on the North Fork. Long Island is a unique package."
To promote conventions and meetings, representatives of the bureau have attended trade shows in the Northeast.
Also, the responses to advertisements in business magazines have been favorable, she said, adding that one of the most-effective points had been areas and other features that allow guests to do "fun things" in their free time.
There has to be a connection between conventions and special attractions, said Theodora Bookman, executive director of Friends of the Arts, a sponsor of cultural events. Tying ticket sales for special events to conventions improves the likelihood that planners will pick the Island for meetings and conventions, she said.
 
Attractions of Happenings
 "There is no doubt that tourism in every place you go is promoted through the arts," Ms. Bookman said. "Happenings are what attract people; festivals unite people and pump money into the economy."
In recent years, attendance and cultural events have declined, except for outdoor summer concerts and programs, Ms. Bookman said.
A first-time Wild West festival, "Buffalo Bill Comes to the Planting Fields," is scheduled for June in Oyster Bay, sponsored by Planting Fieldsand Friends of the Arts.
 Lack of money is a major problem in promoting tourism, said William L. Maher, chairman of the Convention and Visitors Bureau.
"We are handicapped because we are trying to promote a region of approximately three million people, and working with a budget of about $250,000," he said. "Other regions that compete with us have far fewer people and much larger budgets."
The Old Bethpage Village Restoration, one of the Island's most popular attractions, is part of the Nassau County Department of Parks and Recreation, which has not had a budget increase in a few years.
 
Rise in Attendance Sought
 Attendance at the village last year was 177,811. The goal is 250,000, said Edward J. Smits, director of the county's museum services division.
Because it is owned by the county, the village is unable to promote itself like a private attraction and depends largely on the Convention and Visitors Bureau to increase attendance.
Last year, a financial dispute with Suffolk County threatened the bureau's activities. The problem concerned money and the level of promotion, and Mr. Davidson was hired as president of the bureau. When he took office in June, the bureau was late in starting to promote the 1990 tourism season, Mr. Maher said.
The general manager of the Long Island Marriott, Nick Smart, said the greatest need now is to have the public understand what was available on the Island.
"We are trying to make the connection between conventions and recreation and to capitalize on the Island's culture, historical significance and recreational facilities," he said.
"On the Island are vineyards, beaches and deep-sea fishing that are unsurpassed. There is so much here of which the public is not aware. We have to reach them and tell them Long Island's story."

HEADLINE: Worlds Apart

BYLINE: BY JOYCE JOHNSON; Joyce Johnson is the author of a memoir, "Minor Characters," and a novel, "In the Night Cafe."

 BODY:
THE ROAD WE ARE ON NOW," our guide Nikolai announces dryly to the busload of American writers and their spouses, "was once called the Boulevard of the Enthusiasts." It picked up that name in the 19th century when political prisoners were herded along it in chains for the long walk to Siberia. Fortunately, we're now headed in the opposite direction, back to Moscow and the seedy comforts of the Hotel Ukraine, after our day trip to the ancient city of Suzdal and its innumerable wooden churches.
At this point, the jet-lagged passengers reserve their enthusiasm for supper and bed. We arrived just yesterday for our conference with the Soviet Writers' Union, now going through its own glasnost. Since 9 A.M., we have spent nine hours in this lurching un-air-conditioned vehicle. The poet Sharon Olds has given away all the trail mix she brought with her from Manhattan, where she also stuffed her suitcase with tuna fish. Unfortunately, the cans are in her room. 
 I, too, set out for the Soviet Union with such a suitcase. How carefully I prepared myself! I memorized the Cyrillic alphabet; I studied "Coping With Russia," which taught me the all-purpose pozhaluista (please) and how to get by without verbs. "Bring gifts," advised Richard Lourie, translator of the Sakharov memoirs. Panty hose, disposable cigarette lighters, bottles of shampoo and aspirin: I put all this stuff and some copies of my own books into a blue nylon bag, which vanished en route to Moscow, as Lourie had warned me it might. After my bag disappeared, I felt more authentic, less anxious, slightly less the American tourist. Or so I hoped until I saw the crowded itinerary that Tatyana Kudryavtseva, our tireless hostess, had arranged for us. It included four more days of visits to ancient churches and kremlins in provincial cities farther north.
To tell the truth, I'd be quite content to spend the entire two weeks in Moscow. The Hotel Ukraine is an elephantine, rose-colored wedding cake, a prime example of the style known as Stalin Gothic. My cavernous pink room is decorated with imitation Biedermeier, as if some genteel maiden aunt had chosen the furnishings. The ironed linen towels that hang in the bathroom are the kind my mother dried my hair with in the early 1940's.
The Ukraine's broad entranceway is not genteel. Men, who sometimes shout and scuffle with each other, lounge on the steps, smoking. I understand they're cabdrivers who will no longer drive for rubles. For Marlboros, maybe they'll take you. Some have the red-and-white packs taped suggestively to their dashboards. Moscow has become Marlboro Country. A few blocks away, "Married to the Mob" is playing to packed houses.
The Ukraine is filled with foreigners trying to get in on the ground floor for the various opportunities presented by perestroika. There are elevatorloads of Japanese businessmen, anorexic ballerinas from Winnipeg, German film makers, California fundamentalists carrying Bibles to Armenia. One American I talked to has opened a Moscow branch of B.B.D.& O., in anticipation of the Soviet need for advertising.
I never dreamt I'd miss advertising. The mysterious Hotel Ukraine does not advertise the presence of its restaurants. This morning, I asked the concierge on the sixth floor where I might find something to eat. She pointed down a block-long corridor: "Go the boofet." I went there, but the door was locked. "Go to the fifth floor," the concierge said scornfully. That boofet was also closed, as was the dingy coffee bar in the lobby. By accident, I noticed people walking through a deserted dining room and decided to follow. I found myself in a large inner dining room, invisible from the lobby, where you could eat all you wanted for two rubles.
Back from Suzdal at last, lying on my narrow bed, I think of an observation made by the Marquis de Custine over 150 years ago in "Empire of the Czar": "Generally, the first effect of civilization is to render what may be called material life easy; but here everything is difficult -- a cunning apathy is the secret of existence."

I'VE HEARD GRUMBLES from some of my colleagues about the leaden theme of our conference: "The Moral Effects of Social Change." To me, "moral effects" is redolent of "moral majority." Perhaps it sounds more inspiring in Russian. Originally, we were slated to discuss "religious effects" as well.
Did that idea originate in Moscow or in Malibu, Calif., the home of Pepperdine University, the main sponsor of the conference? Richly endowed by its Church of Christ founder with some of the immense profits from the Western Auto Supply Company, the conservative institution evidently finds it worthwhile to invest in some hands-across-the-sea ecumenism by sending to Russia the likes of Harrison Salisbury, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., David Halberstam, William Gass, Elizabeth Hardwick, Alfred Kazin, Studs Terkel and Louis Auchincloss. My smaller group, sponsored by the American Quaker group known as the Religious Society of Friends, includes the poets Sharon Olds and F. D. (Frank) Reeve and Mary Ward Brown, a writer from Alabama.
We met in Washington in May 1989, when our work was published in "The Human Experience," a Soviet-American joint publishing effort organized by Janet Riley of the Society of Friends, our United States sponsor. It was a warm, themeless conference at which everything under the sun was discussed, particularly during some memorable evenings away from the round table. The visiting novelists and poets were unabashedly curious about our situation, and vice versa. All the American writers felt a thrill when it was announced that in just a few weeks the 100th birthday of the great poet Anna Akhmatova (twice expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union) would be celebrated all over Russia. Our next feeling was embarrassment: such an event would be inconceivable in the United States, where no one is more marginal than a poet.
The Russians couldn't quite grasp this. They were impressed by our obvious health, our seeming prosperity, our freedom to write whatever we wished. Yet we kept speaking of our sense of irrelevance, our insecurity, the decline of our publishing houses. "What is the average pension of the American writer?" an elderly member of the Soviet Writers' Union asked. "The literature I think most typical of the United States is the agrarian novel," observed Tatyana Kudryav tseva, who after years of opposition had managed to get her translation of "Gone With the Wind" into print.
In Washington, Yunna Morits, a poet, spoke out fiercely, right in front of Aleksandr A. Mikhailov, head of the Moscow division of the Soviet Writers' Union, and Vladimir Belov, a Ukrainian nationalist, about the great harm Russia had done to its writers. During the years before she was accepted into the union, Morits told Sharon Olds and me, she had suffered from malnutrition and tuberculosis.
Not that the conservative writers weren't vocal as well. When Mikhailov warned against the negative moral consequences of publishing certain books, Georgi Andzhaparidze, the Soviet publisher of "The Human Experience," responded with the declaration: "We will publish anything and let the people decide what they want to read."

ANDZHAPARIDZE GREETS me warmly at the Writers' Club, a mansion right out of "Anna Karenina," and I catch a glimpse of Mikhailov, but I see few other familiar faces. Where, I wonder, is the radiantly fatalistic Anatoly Kim, the Soviet novelist of Korean parentage whose writing seems so much in the Tolstoyan tradition?
Norvel M. Young, the chancellor emeritus of Pepperdine, and his wife, Helen (co-author of "Time Management for Christian Women"), are shaking hands with various union officials and presenting them with plastic-wrapped maroon umbrellas that say Pepperdine, as Harrison Salisbury and Secretary of the Union Yuri I. Surovtsev, who will alternately chair this session, take their seats.
Ten thousand belong to the union. The majority have conformed for years to the dictates of the Communist Party, but even writers like Yunna Morits or Anatoly Kim still find membership an absolute necessity. There are, of course, the important benefits that have made the existence of the Soviet writer one of comparative privilege: access to the best available housing and medical care, to scarce foods and consumer goods, to underwritten travel, vacations and residences at writers' retreats. But even more essential is the right to be published, which up until now has been absolutely contingent upon membership. Although the works of exiled writers are beginning to appear, the union's grip on publishing has weakened now that publishing houses are no longer financially dependent upon the State.
I see only three female members at the long narrow table. Recently, female writers from 20 cities, outraged when yet another male editor was appointed to a major publishing house, formed an organization called the Honey Bee; 85 percent of the union members are male. Most of those who will be speaking today are distinctly middle-aged, heavy smokers with beat-up faces who don't look at all like the privileged elite. There is not a writer under 35 in the room. "The young are published in 'Youth' " was the uninformative answer I got when I asked one official whether there were important new writers emerging in Russia.
At the conference in Washington, there was optimism as well as astonishing openness. Here, the mood is bleak, apprehensive. Is it because glasnost has been threatened by an intervening year of increasingly hard times, or because the privileged life of the union writer is threatened by Gorbachev's goal of a free-market economy?
The first American speakers are resolutely upbeat. Arthur Schlesinger Jr. rejoices in history's capacity to produce surprises, hailing "the revolution of 1989" in Eastern Europe that has "refuted all determinism." Right after Schlesinger's statement, Viktor Rozov, a playwright who is the Russian equivalent of Arthur Miller, delivers an emotional appeal for American support: "There's a war being waged in this country. Be with us in this war. You must trust us, resolutely trust us in everything. Don't condemn us even if we suffer defeat. We suffered defeats in World War II, and you didn't leave us."
The novelist and playwright Aleksandr Borshchagovsky, who like Rozov lauds Gorbachev, describes his country's current situation as "radical, tragic, absolutely acute. We sense it with our skin, in every argument that erupts."
"Freedom is not undangerous," observes Grigory Baklanov, a novelist and editor who helped found a society to build a monument to Stalin's victims. "It's no accident that fascism is emerging in Eastern Europe, here and in France."
I note that Baklanov carefully makes no outright references to anti-Semitism. Nor do other speakers. I've discovered that if you try to discuss this topic with a Russian, you are apt to be told: "We have greater problems." Yet manifestations of hatred for Jews are all too evident in Moscow. On Saturday, in the lobby of the Hotel Rossiya, a middle-aged Russian was proudly sporting a large "Goyim for Jesus" button that some religious fanatics from California had just given him. At the Writers' Club, last January, a writers' meeting was disrupted by a group of anti-Semitic Pamyat roughnecks. I have never felt more conscious of being a Jew than I do in Moscow.
Harrison Salisbury and David Halberstam make statements about the vital role the investigative journalist plays in America, but most of our delegates do not present an encouraging picture of the serious writer in the free market, competing for an audience with the electronic media and even with journalism. "Both your country and ours are in danger of being overrun by banality," warns Studs Terkel. The lost, empty young Russians he saw last night in a bar reminded him of lost young Americans.
Sharon Olds has the misfortune of being the last speaker before the 2 P.M. lunch break. She has chosen to read a powerful poem about an encounter with an underprivileged black teen-ager on a Manhattan subway. She reads it to an emptying room. While the Russians politely remain seated, a number of her famished countrymen are already rushing toward the lobby leading to the famous Writers' Club dining room.

EVERYTHING IS RELATIVE. Some of the luxuries the union members enjoy, which cause so much resentment among the less elite, are quite modest by American standards. The writers' restaurant, reputedly one of the best in the whole country, has been hit hard by food shortages; its capacities are strained to the utmost by having so many additional guests. "It used to be more fun than it is now," a fiftyish Siberian writer tells me wistfully. "In the old days, it was always full of beautiful young ladies."
From the smoked-fish appetizers and carrot salad to the inevitable vanilla ice cream, the fare the waitress keeps bringing is essentially the same one can eat twice a day around town, if admitted to a restaurant. Even Americans are rudely treated until the word "dollars" registers. "Come in," the bouncer may then graciously say, opening the door just enough to let you slip through the crowd of infuriated ruble-paying citizens. A waiter will ceremoniously hand you a large menu listing nothing that is currently available; you may, however, be quietly offered caviar, which appears to be far more plentiful than lettuce. In the Writers' Club dining room, with its hunting-lodge decor, the quickly corrupted visiting writer can dine without guilt.
The American delegates have become obsessed with the quest for food, a major conversational theme. Forgetting all caloric considerations, we eat every drop of our two daily servings of ice cream. As for me, my daydreams are filled with oranges.

ON THE LAST DAY OF our conference, when Georgi Andzhaparidze takes over the Soviet chair, attention shifts to the possible effects a free-market economy may have upon the publishing of Soviet literature. There's nothing like some foreboding remarks from a book publisher to get authors of any nationality riled up.
Extrapolating from his own recent experiences as the Soviet publisher of our anthology, "The Human Experience," Andzhaparidze analyzes the implications of what he considers its "very poor sale" in the United States. How can it be that the affluent American public bought fewer than 6,000 copies of a book that sold 50,000 in the Soviet Union? Why, asks Andzhaparidze, did Alfred A. Knopf invest nothing in promotion and advertising? (American publishers now invest as little as possible in books that will sell only 6,000 copies, even if the titles are prestigious. They will no longer gamble that such books might break out.) While bottom-line publishing has come to make perfect sense to American publishers, Andzhaparidze is almost as reluctant as most writers to accept its philosophy. Nonetheless, one prediction he makes in dramatic language is probably quite realistic: "The Soviet Union is on the threshold of a new kind of censorship -- economic rather than political."
Like all publishers in his country, Andzhaparidze usually prints only one edition of a work in response to advance demand from state booksellers, pays the writer accordingly before publication and does not go back to press. "If our book industry is played on a market basis," Andzhaparidze reasons, "only 1,000 out of 10,000 union members will be able to live on earnings. Our literature largely prepared perestroika." What will happen to such literature if "soon we may find ourselves under the dictates of the market?" He finds it alarming that he has only "an indecent" 15,000 advance orders (a very respectable figure by American standards) for an upcoming edition of Vaclav Havel's plays.
Some members of the Pepperdine group react as if Andzhaparidze is advocating the return of political censorship. Aleksandr Borshchagovsky compounds the misunderstanding: "Political censorship leads to distortion of experience. Market censorship will lead to integrity."
"I do not share your optimism," Andzhaparidze says gloomily, reminding Borshchagovsky and the Americans who are unfamiliar with his efforts that he's the publisher of Solzhenitsyn and Joseph Brodsky. As for increased integrity in writing, he cannot name a single Soviet work that "reflects what's happening today."
It's the final hour by this time, and the proceedings seem to go into a tailspin. The statements from American writers in particular take on an increasingly embittered tone. James Ragan, a poet from Los Angeles, worries that economic self-censorship is making American poets imitative and predicts that they will now knuckle under to the proposed anti-obscenity standards of the National Endowment for the Arts when they apply for grants. But the Russians are not up on the N.E.A. and Jesse Helms, and Ragan is insulted when Elizabeth Hardwick breaks into one of his sentences. She clearly does not think the prospect of craven poets censoring themselves worthy of discussion. For the serious writer, "it should be enough that his book exists, that even one copy is in the library."
Throughout all this, Alfred Kazin has been brooding. "Literature, for my purpose, does not exist any more," he declares. "The literary tradition is individually held, mostly by writers. What is being threatened is not our sales but literature itself." His final melancholy reflection is about journalism, which he calls "one of the banes of our existence -- everything turns into journalism."
Responding to Hardwick's earlier comment, Larisa Vasilyeva, a poet and a founder of the Bee, attacks the individualistic thinking of American writers: "You want your book to be on the library shelf. We are people of community, unconsoled by the book being in the library but nobody will read it."
"We didn't understand each other," Salisbury admits as he closes the meeting. "Each side was talking in its own world."

"WRITERS WANT A market economy for everything except publishing," Georgi Andzhaparidze says with an ironic shrug when I visit him at his publishing house, Khudozhestvennaya Literatura, the following day. He has a rather grand, handsomely paneled office in one of those old pastel stucco buildings that make some streets in Moscow look like Italy.
This year, the house is celebrating its 60th anniversary. It specializes in literary fiction and poetry. "We pay poets from the money of Pushkin," Andzhaparidze says, passing some chocolates down the table. "This is a poet-preserving country. But in a market situation, editions of 5,000 will be pushed out."
The best-selling poet on the list is Yevgeny Yevtushenko. Two hundred fifty thousand copies of his last book sold out immediately. "I told him when we start market industry," Andzhaparidze says, "I will make a poet bigger than you, but maybe not as good."
At the present, the greatest problem for Khudozhestvennaya Literatura is one inconceivable to American publishers: excess of demand. (The Russians even have an expression, knizhny golod, which translates as book hunger.) "The demand is big," Andzhaparidze explains, "the paper is short," The 90-year-old paper mills are "falling to pieces."
Nonetheless, he has big printing plans for the kinds of books that have huge readership these days: a half-million copies of Solzhenitsyn's "Cancer Ward"; 100,000 copies of Joseph Brodsky's poems; five-volume collections of Pasternak and Mikhail Bulgakov in editions of 400,000; an illustrated boxed edition of Tolstoy -- "a coffee book for intellectuals." Soon he'll be adding I. B. Singer, John Updike and John Barth to the already sizable American writers series. Pearl Buck as well. In the race to catch up with several decades of American writing, some surprising choices crop up. Even in publishing there's the sense of a time warp -- of living in 1990 and 1940 simultaneously.
In a black Volga, Andzhaparidze gives me a lift to the Writers Club' for a luncheon with Georgian champagne before leaving Moscow on an overnight train to visit Novgorod and Pskov. On the way, almost casually, Andzhaparidze makes a surprising prediction: "There are great splits in the Writers' Union. Soon it may splinter into Lithuanians, Georgians, Muscovites, Russians. Who knows what will happen? By next year, the Soviet Writers' Union may no longer exist."

"PUSHKIN," PEOPLE reverently say in the Soviet Union, "Dostoyevsky, Lermontov, Tolstoy . . . " as though their works were published just yesterday. The homes and graves of these dissident writers of the past are national shrines.
From Pskov, we travel to the estate where Pushkin, exiled from St. Petersburg because of his support of the Decembrists, spent two years and wrote some of his finest poems. The original house, totally destroyed by the Nazis, has been painstakingly reconstructed. The Nazis also mined Pushkin's tomb, but the Red Army liberated it just in time. The day of our visit, it's strewn with wildflowers.
The dacha in Peredelkino, the writers' retreat where Boris Pasternak lived under house arrest after winning the Nobel Prize during the Khrushchev era, is the newest of these sacred places. We go there as well, with Yevgeny Yevtushenko as our host, a few days before our departure for the United States. We see the monastic room in which Pasternak died, and I read the titles on his bookshelves. There's a row of Americans -- William Faulkner, Henry James, even a copy of a 1957 Evergreen Review with contributions by Allen Ginsberg and Jack Kerouac.
Yevtushenko leads us past hayfields to the grave. Rather self-consciously we pick dandelions and forget-me-nots to drop on the mound. Our host pours wine into paper cups; it is the custom to have a drink by the graveside, he says. We all, even the nondrinking Dr. and Mrs. Norvel Young, raise our paper cups as Yevtushenko makes a toast: "To the great writer, the great composer." Then, mischievously: "To the great womanizer."

PASTERNAK published "Dr. Zhivago" four decades after the Russian Revolution. There is no sign as yet of the great glasnost novel. Perhaps it will appear 10 years from now, or even 25. Novelists do not respond instantaneously to convulsive change the way journalists do. Perhaps the future author of the great glasnost novel is now only 15 years old, a person who already sees the world in a way that would surprise or disconcert those who came of age during the war or the Stalin, Khrushchev or Brezhnev years.
"You came at the most interesting moment," says Anatoly Kim, the day our small group departs for the United States. Back from a visit to South Korea, he has driven over to the Hotel Ukraine with gifts of books, vodka and matryoshka dolls for Frank Reeve, Mary Ward Brown and me. As we sit talking in Frank's room, Anatoly seems to get closer to the heart of things than anyone did at the conference.
"The Soviet Man," he says, pausing to let Frank translate, "is being forced to turn into the human being. Just as the Tsarist Man passed, the Soviet Man is passing. You must understand -- it's a time of great anguish and emptiness. The Soviet Man is buried deep in the character of many Russians. He does not know how to be free."
Anatoly tells us a story: "A flock of wild geese flies over a peasant village. The tame geese look up at them. Oh, yes, they flap their wings. But they do not fly."
Then, steadily looking into our American faces, he finds a different image for us to take home: "It's as though a dead stick was planted and grew leaves."

HEADLINE: Which Industries Should New York Help?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
From "New York Fears Exodus of Jobs on Wall Street" (front page, Nov. 3), one would think that the $100 million in grants, tax breaks and energy subsidies that the city is contemplating for the commodities exchanges is supported by rational economic policy. However, the folly of spending $100 million of public aid for private profit is economically unjustified in this case.
A 1989 Coopers & Lybrand study found that the economic multiplier for financial services is sixth, compared with other city industries. Substantial public funds to support the commodities exchanges would generate meager returns. By contrast, other enervated economic sectors, long neglected by city policy makers, have higher economic multipliers and thus would produce greater gains if supported and subsidized.
Both the apparel industry and the printing and publishing industry are, according to the 1989 study, ranked third for New York City economic multipliers. This can be attributed to a largely indigenous work force, living in all five boroughs and reflecting the racial, social and ethnic composition of the city. Note that the printing industry in New York City has a sales volume of more than $3 billion a year, with a work force three times that cited for the commodities exchanges.
 In his campaign, Mayor David N. Dinkins espoused support for the graphic arts and apparel industry and bemoaned misguided policy that emphasized subsidies and support for financial services. Yet the city's development policy appears still riveted on Wall Street, at the expense of the city's manufacturing base, which has lost 150,000 jobs in a decade. It is in the best interest of New York City to realign its support for those who manufacture the tangible, as opposed to those who barter the speculative.
 
WILLIAM A. DIRZULAITIS
President, Assn. of the Graphic Arts
New York, Nov. 8, 1990

HEADLINE: BUSINESS SCENE;
The Disappearing Labor Shortage

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
REMEMBER the days, only a year ago, when the fast-food restaurants couldn't find enough counter help? Outfits like McDonald's and Wendy's even recruited teen-agers in city neighborhoods and bused them to suburban restaurants. Help-wanted signs appeared in many windows, and the scramble for entry-level workers in the fast-food industry became the most popular evidence that the nation suffered from a shortage of young workers.
Now, suddenly, the hiring problems at the fast-food restaurants have evaporated. The busing has become a rare event, and the help-wanted signs are mostly gone. Job applications are rising and hourly wages, which had inched up to more than $6 an hour in the Northeast, the Northwest and a few other sections of the country, have leveled off. 
 "The markets no longer require that we jump wages significantly; the pressure began to come off toward the end of last year," said David Gillen, director of personnel at McDonald's, where the average wage for hourly workers at the 1,700 company-owned outlets is $4.89 an hour. At Burger King, the average is $4.40 an hour; at Wendy's, $4.10.
Clearly, the downturn in the American economy has eased the labor shortage for entry-level and low-wage jobs. Hiring freezes and layoffs have forced many more people to seek this work, which is mostly consigned to young people under 24 years old. Much publicity has been given to the fact that the current generation in this age group is much smaller than its predecessor, the baby boom generation. Until the economic downturn fattened the pool of job applicants, many executives had blamed demographics for their difficulty in finding enough qualified young workers.
 But low wages have been equally at fault because they discourage people from seeking these jobs, some economists argue. Aside from the fast-food industry, with its more than 3.5 million workers, the labor shortages showed up at restaurants in general, and at hotels, resorts, retail stores and other big employers of unskilled hourly workers. They are among 28.7 million people, or 24 percent of all the jobholders in America, who earn less than $7 an hour.
The personnel practices at the fast-food restaurants help to explain why the wages of workers in this under $7-an-hour category rose much less in the 1980's than the incomes of better-paid Americans. Wendy's and McDonald's, for example, recruit heavily among retirees, who seek to supplement their pensions and are less likely than younger workers to apply pressure for higher wages. More than 9 percent of all fast-food employees were over 55 in the late 1980's, a Government survey found.
Mothers of young children are another source of recruits, the lure being flexible work schedules at a store near their homes. The flexibility allows them to be home when they wish. The mothers aremostly part-time workers; in fact, most workers in fast-food restaurants are part-time employees, and part-time employees tend to be less insistent on wage increases than full-time workers. Wendy's, for instance, says 90 percent of the 120,000 people at its restaurants work part time, and it does not provide health benefits for them -- another major savings.
Perhaps the most important damper on wages has been the willingness of the fast-food industry to operate short of staff, rather than offer slightly higher pay to attract young people from among the millions who have been reluctant to enter the labor force. If a restaurant manager with a normal staff of 20 needs five more employees to complete his roster, and he offers $5.50 an hour to get them, then the 15 counter workers making $4.50 an hour are likely to seek the same pay.
Dennis Lynch, a Wendy's spokesman, tells of a rival fast-food operator in Pittsburgh who tired of being chronically short of help. He raised the wage of his workers to $6 an hour, although Wendy's and other competitors in the neighborhood were paying $4.50. "He was right. He quickly got a full staff," Mr. Lynch said. "But sales did not rise, his costs were too much and he had to retrench on wages."
The shortage of young workers and the temptation to raise wages were particularly acute in Massachusetts in 1988. With the unemployment rate below 3 percent, fast-food restaurants scrambled for hourly workers and pay rose to $6.50 an hour -- the highest for McDonald's in the nation -- from about $4 in 1984. The line held at $6.50, and when the economic downturn finally came, starting pay was still at this level and the pressure for another wage increase disappeared.
That makes the downturn a "double whammy" for young, less-educated hourly workers, says Lawrence Katz, a Harvard University labor economist. "Their best shot at breaking the wage ceiling came in 1988, and it failed," he said. "Now with labor more plentiful, it is not as easy for them to get a job, and when they do, the wage is frozen."

SECTION: Section D; Page 8; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 531 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Tough Times Cut Opportunities for Minority Journalists

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Reduced advertising and tight economic conditions at most newspapers appear to be hurting the industrywide effort to increase diversity in the nation's newsrooms.
"We know it's getting harder for people to find jobs," said Diane Yen-Mei Wong, executive director of the Asian American Journalists Association. 
 Some leaders of minority journalist organizations are expressing concern that hiring freezes and slashed budgets may become more a rationalization than a reason for slowing the effort to hire and promote black, Hispanic, Asian and Native American journalists.
"We see the recession as an excuse not to keep the commitment made through the years to vastly increase the number of minorities in newsrooms," said Thomas Morgan, president of the National Association of Black Journalists and a reporter for The New York Times.
For years, the American Society of Newspaper Editors has tracked the slow progress of minority hiring, and the annual announcement that little or no progress had been made was a regular refrain during the 1980's.
For instance, in 1989, the percentage of minority journalists at the nation's newspapers increased to 7.86 percent from 7.56 percent in 1988.
Cornelius F. Foote, minority affairs director for the society, said the 1990 report would probably show a slight increase at best, though no employment figures were yet available.
Members of minority groups are often among the most junior employees at a newspaper, and layoffs tend to hit them disporportionately hard. For instance, when The Wall Street Journal announced last week that it was closing its Philadelphia bureau, four of the six people who lost their jobs were minority journalists.
Roger B. May, a Journal spokesman, said the paper was committed to an affirmative action policy. He said the overall percentage of minority journalists at the paper was likely to be unchanged by companywide cutbacks.
 
Budget Constraints
 Mr. Foote said efforts to place minority journalists in more senior positions at newspapers had also been slowed by budget constraints.
There are clear signs that minority hiring is receiving less attention.
Mr. Foote said 25 to 30 news organizations had sent recruiters this year to job fairs for minority journalists. Last year, 35 to 50 news organizations were represented at job fairs, and one fair attracted 75 recruiters.
"From what I hear, we are filling fewer positions," said Rebecca M. Baybrook-Heckenbach, director of employment for Knight-Ridder Inc. "But for those we do fill, we are looking more fervently for minority talent than we ever have."
Carolyn Lee, assistant managing editor for administration and personnel at The New York Times, said the paper expected to keep its affirmative action efforts "absolutely intact," though she added that the paper was "somewhat slower and more cautious in filling positions."
Over all, the message to minority journalists seems to be that entering the newspaper business is becoming even more difficult.
"Minorities looking for a job now have to be that much more enterprising and that much more willing to go to places they never thought they would before," Mr. Foote said.

HEADLINE: To Victors Go the Trials After Races Against Taxes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich., Nov. 13

 BODY:
In his campaign for governor, John Engler told voters what they apparently wanted to hear.
He promised to allocate half of future state budgets to education. He promised a crackdown on crime that would put white-collar criminals in chain gangs and deny drug offenders school loans, welfare grants and driver's licenses. And in what was apparently his most effective pledge, he promised to reduce local property taxes by 20 percent. On Election Day, the 40-year-old Republican unexpectedly defeated James J. Blanchard, the two-term Governor, by 19,000 votes out of 2.5 million cast. 
 Now Mr. Engler and other new governors elected on anti-tax, anti-incumbent platforms face the challenge of delivering on their promises. It will not be easy.
 "With the anti-tax climate out there," said Marcia A. Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Officers, "it's going to make it all the more interesting to watch how the new governors deal with problems in most states. When they realize how bad the fiscal condition of their state is, they will have to call on all their creative powers to balance budgets without tax increases or significant cutbacks, never mind any tax decreases."
 
Michigan in Middle of Pack
 Michigan is one of six states in which voters rejected incumbent Governors and one of 14 in which the governor's office changed parties. Most governors, new and old, will begin 1991 facing an array of financial problems, including state economies that are declining and tax revenues that are dwindling just as more people are applying for social services, welfare and unemployment benefits. The "new federalism" of the Ronald Reagan years placed growing responsibility on the states, especially for health costs.
Financial problems vary considerably around the nation. On one extreme is Alaska, where Governor-elect Walter J. Hickel will be figuring out how to spend a projected $1 billion surplus from oil profits; on the other is Oklahoma, whose oil producers have still not recovered from the price collapse of the early 1980's. There, Governor-elect David L. Walters will be dealing with what he calls an "economy that has been in such depths of depression there is almost no place to go but up."
Many Northeastern states that boomed in the 1980's, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, are in deep trouble, too.
Ms. Howard said Michigan's budget deficit and a deteriorating economic situation put it in the middle of the pack of the 33 states that face fiscal problems this year.
 
Facing a $1 Billion Deficit
 Mr. Engler faces the immediate problem of a projected $1 billion budget deficit in the 1991 fiscal year and campaign promises that would reduce state revenue. But he seems confident that he can succeed by eliminating waste in state government.
"The public wants leadership," Mr. Engler said in an interview this week at the state Capitol, where he is the majority leader of the State Senate. "I know where all the sacred cows are out in pasture, and the people elected me to go get them. Is 10 percent of the budget misspent or able to be refocused? Most people believe yes; I believe yes."
In addition to the property tax cut, Mr. Engler also proposed limiting increases on home assessments, exempting the state's large elderly population from school taxes and reimbursing local school districts for the lost revenue. But in his position paper on tax reform he offered no blueprint for managing the state without all the revenue.
 
Plans Do Not Match Needs
 In the interview he mentioned some specific reductions, but nothing that would provide the kind of money needed to balance the budget and grant tax relief. He said, for example, that he would strictly enforce an existing freeze on state hiring, eliminate most state contracts for consultants and studies, weed out programs like a $25 million seasonal job program for teen-agers from middle-income families and eliminate most public relations activities.
A dispirited Governor Blanchard predicted in an interview that Mr. Engler would fail because the "Legislature's appetite for spending" was growing twice as fast as state revenues.
Mr. Engler will inherit a $373 million deficit left from the last fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, and faces a projected deficit of nearly $1 billion for the current fiscal year, according to a new report from the State Senate Fiscal Agency, the research arm of the Republican-controlled Senate. Combined, these deficits would wipe out the state's reserve fund and require a cut of about $1 billion in this year's $9.5 billion budget or a host of creative accounting measures to balance it, as required by the state Constitution.
 
Working Toward Bigger Deficit
 If Mr. Engler rolls back property taxes as promised, the deficit would increase by about $500 million more this year. Both houses of the Legislature have passed bills that would reduce local property taxes, but they were unable to resolve the differences.
With that kind of political momentum, the taxes may be reduced, but Ms. Howard at the association of budget officers said, "It is impossible to imagine how it would work."
The state has much less flexibility to deal with the problem now than in 1982, said Warren C. Gregory, associate director of the Michigan House Fiscal Agency. a research arm of the Democratic-controlled House, Back then the budget crisis occurred after a decade of growth, he said, but now the state faces a financial problem of similar magnitude after a decade of retrenchment.
 
Automobile Cutbacks Hurt
 The state's economy has become more diversified, but primarily because of the decline in the automobile industry. Unemployment, higher than the national average for years, is now about 7.6 percent and expected to reach 8.5 percent next year, and to be much higher in urban centers like Detroit. There are more service jobs, but they pay much less than manufacturing jobs. Since 1982, personal income has declined by 7 percent.
"I'm getting by," said Ken Robinson, a taxi driver in Lansing who said he works 12 hours a day, six days a week and still does not make as much as he did before the General Motors Corporation laid him off two years ago.
The poor have gotten poorer: Michigan's $479-a-month welfare allotment for a family of three ranks 12th highest in the nation, but over the decade, the subsidy's purchasing power has declined by almost 30 percent.
State taxes do not bring in as much money as they once did, Mr. Gregory said, because legislators have written exemptions into the 4.6 percent income tax, the 4 percent sales tax and assorted business taxes. He said these exemptions, which receive little legislative review, have grown rapidly in the last decade and are now about equal to the $9.5 billion state budget.
A particularly vexing problem is a criminal justice system that is absorbing an ever-larger portion of the state budget. Annual spending on corrections increased to $668 million, or 7.2 percent of the budget, in 1990 from $146 million, or 2.8 percent, in 1980. In the same period, annual state spending on elementary and secondary education increased to $2.8 billion from $1.9 billion, but education's share of the budget decreased from 37 percent to 30 percent.
Michigan, which ranked sixth in the nation for major crimes last year, expects to imprison a larger percentage of its population than any other state when it completes its 28th prison in 1992.
It is in this environment that Mr. Engler proposes that the state get even tougher on crime, particularly drug-related crime. "I don't claim to be an expert in this area," he said, "but we need to make improvements across the board in prevention, education, law enforcement. We'll fine tune it as we learn more."
 As a deterrent, as well as a way to improve highways, Mr. Engler has said he would revive chain gangs and put white-collar criminals on them along with those convicted of violent crimes.
Since Mr. Engler has promised to improve anti-crime and education programs, the only major expenditures left to reduce in the state budget are social services and mental health programs, said State Representative David C. Hollister, chairman of a House subcommittee on social services. "I'm expecting major cuts, pain, a bloodbath," he said.
Because most social services have Federal mandates and subsidies, Michigan legislators have recently proposed trimming or eliminating optional programs, like a general assistance program that helps unemployed or part-time workers and people who are not eligible for Federal assistance. The program costs about $240 million a year.
 
A Diabetic Tells of Need
 Karen R. Nevins, for example, works in a Lansing convenience store and takes home wages of about $600 a month. She is diabetic and receives a general assistance grant of about $150 a month to buy medication; she has no health insurance. "As it is, I eat once a day and walk to work to save bus fare," she said. "If I lost the grant, I don't know what I would do. I've had more diabetic comas than I have fingers and toes; I would die without my medication."
But Cheryl and Philip Neuroth, Republicans who voted for Mr. Engler, say public assistance benefits are too generous, and they say they should know because they received state food subsidies of about $45 a month during most of the past two years.
"We were eligible because our income fell below $18,600," Mrs. Neuroth said. "Now that's pretty high to get free food, don't you think?" She said she applied for the state program because she lost her job as a corporate manager and a drought had ruined corn and wheat crops on her husband's 700-acre farm in Riga Township, in southeast Michigan.
Mr. Neuroth said, "You can only tax people so long and so much and they will rebel against it."

HEADLINE: As Connecticut Budget Picture Darkens, Weicker Faces Grim Tax Choice

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Throughout his campaign for governor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. sidestepped questions on whether he would raise sales taxes or propose a state income tax to close Connecticut's budget gap.
On several occasions, he called both options unappealing but refused to rule them out, saying he needed "flexibility to deal with circumstances that no one contemplates." 
 But now, the Governor-elect has found that he faces a projected $2.1 billion revenue shortfall for the next 18 months. That is almost a third of the state's current $7.1 billion budget.
The shortfall, which is part of a preliminary 1991-92 budget prepared by Gov. William A. O'Neill, may force Mr. Weicker to consider higher taxes, short-term bonds, deep cuts in state spending and possibly even a broader income tax to close the gap.
 
Economy Is Seen Diving
 Mr. Weicker, who is expected to release his first budget proposal before he takes office on Jan. 9, may be further spurred by fears that the shortfall -- the difference between state spending and the amount of revenue it collects -- could widen further in 1991, as Connecticut slips deeper into what many economists and lawmakers here believe is a recession.
"They will have to raise taxes no matter how much you implement in cost cutting," said State Senator Joseph H. Harper Jr., a Democrat of New Britain who is co-chairman of the Appropriations Committee. "In my opinion, the stage is set for tax reform, something that would bring in a progressive income tax with some decrease in other taxes."
But preparing the budget is muddled by the state's odd political mix. Both chambers of the General Assembly, which convenes in February for a three-month session that will be dominated by fiscal issues, are controlled by the Democratic Party. Mr. Weicker, a former three-term Senator, is a liberal Republican who ran as an independent. He was elected with 40 percent of the vote in a three-way race chiefly on the support of Democratic voters.
Democratic legislative leaders expect Mr. Weicker to espouse a moderate to liberal Republican agenda. They note that one of his two chiefs of staff will be Thomas J. D'Amore Jr., a campaign co-chairman and a former Republican state chairman.
 
Highest Sales Tax in Nation
 Some Republicans, particularly conservatives who have long scorned Mr. Weicker, worry that he will forge an alliance with liberal Democrats. For decades, the Democrats have sought a broader income tax to help increase the state's revenue and make it more consistent than the current system, which is based largely on an 8 percent sales tax, the highest in the nation.
"It's a dire situation," said Senator M. Adela Eads, a moderate Republican from Kent, who was elected Senate minority leader. "I'm afraid I see an income tax coming down the road, and I don't like that."
Mr. Weicker, citing a need to make administration appointments and study Mr. O'Neill's 1991-92 budget proposal, has not specified how he plans to reduce the $2.1 billion shortfall, which includes $562 million for the fiscal year that ends on June 30.
An indication of his administration's fiscal course may come on Monday, though, when Mr. Weicker announces a new Secretary of the Office of Policy and Management.
 
'Gasoline on a Fire'
 The top candidates appear to be State Representative William J. Cibes Jr., a liberal Democrat from New London, and Senator Reginald J. Smith of New Hartford. a liberal Republican.
Connecticut is one of only 10 states that has no tax on wages. It does, however, tax income on dividends, interest and capital gains at 14 percent, the highest rate in the nation.
Mr. Weicker has attributed the $2.1 billion shortfall to a recession, citing drops in revenue from sales and corporation taxes. He has also said he opposes a tax on wages during a recession, likening it "to throwing gasoline on a fire."
A $2 billion shortfall could force the issue, which has led some income tax opponents to question whether the size of Mr. O'Neill's projected budget gap is an exaggeration.
 
An Unrealistic Wish List?
 The critics say that the estimate is based on a wish list of expenditures and revenues that are unrealistic. The figure was derived from an $8.64 billion budget proposal for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1991. It includes a 21 percent spending increase, which many consider to be unaffordable. It is also based on what many legislators believe are overly optimistic revenue projections.
"I'm not sure it's a $2 billion hole," said Representative Richard O. Belden, a Republican of Shelton and the deputy minority leader in the House.
Republicans have urged a freeze on state spending, including delaying an 8 percent raise scheduled for state employees next year. They also want to enact $300 million to $500 million in spending cuts recommended by a commission that has been studying government efficiency. Revenue increases, if needed, would be minor and limited to proposals like removing some exemptions from the sales tax.
 
Politics May Bar Deep Cuts
 Income-tax proponents, however, believe that deep spending cuts are not politically feasible, and that reducing some tax exemptions would not be well received.
Even the most comprehensive income tax proposal presented so far would collect only $598 million more in state revenue. That plan, offered by Mr. Cibes during the Democratic gubernatorial primary, recommended a tax on wages starting at 4 percent of adjusted gross income over $25,000, with a peak of 8 percent for income over $100,000. The sales tax would be cut to 5 percent, and corporate taxes would be cut to 10 percent, from 13.8.
"If you polled the Assembly now, I don't think they will be able to make the kinds of cuts needed to balance the budget," Mr. Harper said. "And even if we cut a billion, which would be miraculous, you still have to come up with another billion in revenue."

HEADLINE: Real Estate Woes Seen Worsening

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The slump in commercial real estate is almost certain to get worse before it gets better, real estate executives, bankers and other business people say.
In a recent survey of 400 real estate executives conducted by Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, many predicted that prices of commercial property would fall sharply in the next two to three years and might not recover for four or five years. 
 Despite the hard times that many banks and builders have reported this year, "I think the most amazing thing is that people will look back at the fourth quarter of 1990 and say things weren't that bad," said David N. Webb, head of real estate financing at Merrill Lynch, echoing what appears to be a prevailing sentiment.
 
'We Haven't Hit Bottom Yet'
 There are myriad reasons why the commercial property market will probably weaken further. One, some experts say, is that banks have kept prices from caving in faster by putting off the unpleasant task of foreclosing on developers.
"We haven't hit bottom yet, partly because there are innumerable projects where the lenders have not yet taken title to properties that are now in default," said Arthur Sonnenblick, vice chairman of the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, one of the country's largest commercial brokers. "When that starts to happen you're going to see things hit the bottom."
And more properties are expected to come to market over the next several years as lenders refuse to extend or renegotiate many of the record number of five- and seven-year commercial mortgages they wrote in the late 1980's. Developers who are now straining to make payments on mortgages issued in 1986, for instance, when interest rates were at their lowest level in 13 years, will be even more likely to default if those mortgages are rolled over at the current higher rates.
 
Defaults by Developers
 Unable to refinance their mortgages, many developers will walk away, forcing lenders to take over their properties. Other builders may file for bankruptcy protection.
In the New York metropolitan region several big development companies have recently defaulted on mortgages for large projects. The Lefrak Organization defaulted this month on a $150 million mortgage on a huge apartment complex called Newport, in Jersey City. And in July, Milstein Properties, another well-known New York development company owned by a well-respected family, defaulted on a $100 million mortgage on a large Manhattan rental complex.
Almost no region of the country is escaping the growing real estate problems. Even California, whose diversified economy, rapid growth and position on the Pacific Rim led many experts to conclude that it was immune to the troubles of the East and the Southwest, has begun to stumble as job growth has slowed and layoffs have picked up steam. A nationwide recession would further hurt real estate demand and the economy in California, which accounts for nearly one in nine jobs in the country.
 
Alarmingly High Vacancy Rates
 Vacancy rates are already alarmingly high across the country, and even in pockets of growth, like Seattle, the specter of recession threatens to quash demand. As of September, the office vacancy rates in cities nationwide averaged almost 20 percent. Some cities have enough vacant space to supply their needs for nearly 20 years, based on today's leasing rates and assuming no new buildings are added.
In New York City, the picture is not much brighter. The vacancy rate in downtown Manhattan has climbed to 18.7 percent, up from 14.1 percent at the end of 1989, according to Coldwell Banker, the national real estate brokerage subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company. Prime Manhattan office space that rented for $40 a square foot a year ago can be found on the market today for $33, and in September and October, leasing of commercial space in Manhattan was down 11 percent, to 3.5 million square feet, from the comparable period in 1989, according to a report by Julien J. Studley Inc.
Values are eroding for all but the highest-quality office and retail properties, which are generally immune from market downturns, and certain types of industrial buildings, like high-tech warehouses and manufacturing plants.
 
Few Buyers or Renters
 These rising vacancy rates and falling real estate values are already making it difficult for many developers to find buyers or renters willing to pay prices high enough for them to meet their mortgage payments or to sell their properties at a profit.
And the search could become even more difficult as buyers and renters, worried about the uncertainties, demand deeper discounts. "There are some horrendous times coming," said J. Steven Manolis, a managing director at Salomon Brothers in charge of the real estate group, "and I think that between now and the next 18 months will be the worst because the buyers' and sellers' attitudes are at their widest."
 
Options for Lenders
 The decline in credit for real estate transactions prevents developers from borrowing money to meet cash shortfalls or to pay for tenant improvements that make their properties more attractive to buyers or renters in the glutted market. As a result, some will be forced to lower their sale or rental prices sharply to generate cash, depressing the market further, while others will default on their mortgages.
That result will put lenders in the position of either foreclosing and selling properties themselves, possibly at cheap prices for quick sales, or renegotiating the terms with the borrowers, an option they have exercised so as to avoid increasing their real estate holdings.
The sluggish economy will continue to put downward pressure on property values and rents. As more companies cut jobs and close down operations, additional office space will come onto the market, driving down prices. For instance, since the 1987 stock market crash, Wall Street has reduced its work force by nearly 30,000 employees. Based on an estimated 250 square feet of space for each employee, that could create 7.5 million square feet of office space.
But the biggest factor in the continuing decline of the real estate market is the credit squeeze. In an attempt to limit their vulnerability to the real estate downturn, and in response to pressure from regulators, commercial banks have sharply reduced their lending to the real estate industry for construction or commercial mortgages over the last 12 months. To write a commercial mortgage now banks have been forced by regulators to reserve twice the amount of capital needed for a single-family mortgage.
Citicorp, for instance, staggering under at least $2.2 billion of nonperforming real estate loans, announced last week that it would close half its real estate lending offices across the nation.
 
Less Money From S.& L.'s
 There is also less money available for these projects from savings and loans. Under the Federal bailout legislation, savings and loans must now have more capital in reserve for real estate acquisition, development and construction loans, and each institution is limited in the amount of money it can lend to one borrower.
"The dominant market factor is that there is extremely little liquidity in the real estate markets," Mr. Webb of Merrill Lynch said, "and the largest amount of liquidity is in the hands of conservative investors like life insurance companies and pension funds."
While pension funds and insurance companies have millions of dollars designated for real estate, industry executives say they are waiting for the markets to collapse further before they invest.
"The liquidity in the system has to come from pension funds," said Daniel M. Neidich, the head of Goldman, Sachs & Company's real estate group, "and some of the pension funds have been burnt and won't want to buy buildings for a while."
 
Japanese Buyers Skittish
 Adding to the liquidity problem is that Japanese buyers, who bolstered commercial property values in the 80's, have apparently become skittish.
"The Japanese, almost more than we do, determine the market," said Richard B. Stearns, chairman of Prudential Real Estate Investors.
So far this year, the Japanese have invested $9.1 billion in real estate in the United States, with only $1.2 billion of it going into office space, according to Kenneth Leventhal & Company, an accounting firm that specializes in the real estate industry. Last year, the Japanese invested $14.8 billion in United States real estate, including $3.4 billion in office space.
Like many pension fund investors, the Japanese are wary of the disappointing returns on office complexes in the United States and are troubled by the vacancy rates. As a result, they have shifted more of their investment into American resorts and hotels.
Falling land prices in Tokyo and the unstable stock market there have reduced the lending power of the big Japanese banks, further dampening real estate investment. Higher Japanese interest rates have also made it more expensive for Japanese investors to buy property abroad.
 
An International Problem
 Indeed the surge in troubled real estate loans is causing problems not only for major American banks and insurance companies, but also for other international financial institutions, as real estate markets sink simultaneously worldwide -- a development made possible in large part by the increasing linkage of the global financial markets.
From London to Tokyo, real estate loan losses are threatening to undermine the health of major banking companies. Japan led the world in the declining returns of its real estate stocks in the third quarter of this year, according to Salomon Brothers. Real estate loans made by Japan's big banks have risen to $380 billion, or 22.7 percent of their total assets. They approach 40 percent of assets at some of the smaller regional banks.
In London, interest rates in the 15 percent range have kept the real estate market in a rut. It is estimated that up to 20 percent of the real estate loans made by British banks are in trouble.

HEADLINE: FISCAL TURMOIL;
More Painful Cuts for New York City

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
The Cuomo administration's proposed $100 million cut in state aid to New York City would strike hardest at schools, health services and social programs and, coming atop the city's own retrenchments, could force painful new cuts in essential services, city officials said yesterday.
While cutbacks appear to be unavoidable, the officials said, their nature and extent will not be evident for days or weeks, until the State Legislature considers the measures urged by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on Saturday to close a $1 billion gap in the state's current budget. 
 "It's going to be painful -- it's going to be noticeable," the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said in an interview yesterday. "We cannot spare essential services: education, hospitals, social services. We have no other place to turn to get these reductions."
City schools, which have sustained more than $270 million in budget cuts in the last year and would lose $75 million more in state aid in the current year under the Governor's proposals, would be especially hard hit, city and union officials said.
 
Consequences Called Severe
 "A cut like that would be very damaging," said James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for the Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez. And Bert Shanas, speaking for the United Federation of Teachers, said, "These cuts, if they went through, would devastate the school system."
Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, urged the City Council and the State Legislature yesterday to reject a 5.5 percent pay raise that the city recently negotiated with the teachers. "It's completely unrealistic," Mr. Stein said at a news conference.
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who left yesterday for an eight-day vacation at Hilton Head, S.C., said through a spokesman, Leland Jones, "It is clear that the cuts are deep and the consequences will be severe on the people of New York City."
But the Mayor and other city officials, apparently acknowledging that the state's fiscal problems were large and real, did not say they would fight the Governor's plans in the Legislature and seemed inclined to accept Mr. Cuomo's pledge that the state would work with the city to keep the cuts to $100 million.
State officials, expanding yesterday on the Governor's budget plan, said that the proposed cuts in state aid to the city actually totaled about $183 million, but would be offset by more than $82 million in savings in Medicaid and foster-care costs.
Anne Crowley, a spokeswoman for the Governor, said that the state plan called for cuts in aid to the city of $75 million for education, $63.6 million in Medicaid reimbursements, $27 million for revenue sharing and $20 million for social services, transportation, economic development and other categories of assistance.
Offsetting these cuts, Ms. Crowley said, would be $42 million in savings to the city from a cutback in mandated Medicaid costs, and $40 million in Federal money for foster care that the state planned to pass along to the city.
 
Gauging the Impact
 Like many aspects of the developing fiscal crisis, the real impact of the proposed cuts -- the programs that might be slashed, the number of people who might lose their jobs, the extent of service cutbacks -- was hard to gauge, obscured by clouds of numbers and doomsday warnings.
But Mr. Michael said: "New layoffs are a strong possibility, and we may have to eliminate full programs. There is no other way to satisfy these cuts. We've already cut what is least needed. We have gone deeply into real programs, so more cuts will involve more of those essential programs."
And, Mr. Michael and others pointed out, the cuts would be imposed over less than half the state's remaining fiscal year, which runs from March to March; that would more than double the impact, making a 2.5 percent school-aid cut more like a 6 percent cut in the four and a half months left in the state's fiscal year.
The loss of state aid for Medicaid reimbursements, Mr. Michael said, could drive many elderly and poor patients from private to public hospitals for state-subsidized care. And the loss of $27 million in revenue-sharing money would hurt the city budget across the board, since the money may be used any way the city sees fit.
"Painful as the current cuts are going to be, there are a lot more to go," Mr. Michael said. He noted that the city's budget gap for next year has been estimated at $1.3 billion and the state's gap for next year could be more than $3 billion.
"It's not insoluble, but we are certainly embarking upon very difficult times," he said. "And the problems will be with us until the reversal of the economic cycle that is the cause of it all. This austerity is certainly in the cards for some time to come -- for a year or two at least."

HEADLINE: Charities Face Large Losses In Failed Bank

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Charitable organizations that maintained more than one account in the failed Freedom National Bank stand to lose hundreds of thousands of dollars that they had thought was protected by Federal deposit insurance.
Officials of the community services organizations, which provide day care, programs for the elderly, foster care, housing and assistance to crime victims, had been under the impression that as long as each account was under the $100,000 limit for Federal insurance, they would be able to recover all their funds after the bank's failure. But last week they began to learn otherwise. 
The Fort Greene Senior Citizens Council in Brooklyn, for example, had $350,000 in 24 checking accounts at the bank, which is based in Harlem. But the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reimbursed it for only $100,000.
"That was not our understanding of the insurance program at all," said Sam Pinn, the council's chairman. "Obviously, we would not have left ourselves vulnerable."
 
Appeal by Abrams
 He added that the council also placed the money in separate accounts because of requirements from public and private agencies that finance some of its programs.
Although most of the charitable organizations maintained accounts less than the Federal Government's $100,000 insurance limit, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which is managing the reimbursement of depositors at the bank, considers the multiple accounts of a single depositor as a single account.
The New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, who learned of the situation late on Friday, has appealed to L. William Seidman, the F.D.I.C. chairman, for a more lenient interpretation of the deposit insurance regulations.
Mr. Seidman said in an interview yesterday that the deposit insurance applies to aggregate deposits, not individual ones, and that the agency would apply the regulations to Freedom's depositors.
"If all of the accounts were in one name and there was no indication that they belonged to other people and they were over $100,000 total, it applies the same to everyone," he said. But he added that a final decision would not be made until Mr. Abrams's letter had been reviewed.
In the largest bailout of an insolvent bank, the $4.5 billion Government takeover of Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in 1984, the F.D.I.C. did insure all deposits.
Because of the size of Continental Illinois, its failure would have had such a severe impact on the financial system that it would have cost the Government much more than the $4.5 billion it spent to bail the bank out, Mr. Seidman said. "We have to use the least costly method of dealing with failures," he said.
If the F.D.I.C. had found a buyer for Freedom or had been able to establish a merger with another bank, no depositors would lose money because the new bank would take responsibility for the deposits. "It's a rare situation," he said of Freedom, "but it can happen under the present rules."
Many of the charitable groups had deposited in Freedom, a black-owned bank, as a way of supporting economic independence in the black community, but they had distributed their money in several accounts either to take advantage of the Federal insurance or because they were required to by their financing sources.
In a letter to Mr. Seidman, the Attorney General noted: "In many instances these not-for-profits have maintained multiple accounts because they are required by their governmental or private funding sources to segregate and hold these monies in trust for restricted charitable purposes."
 
Losses May Exceed $1 Million
 In an interview yesterday, Mr. Abrams said, "Based on the preliminary information, we could be talking about many hundreds of thousands of dollars, maybe even more than $1 million, and we're just talking about the Brooklyn area."
Mr. Pinn, of the Fort Greene Senior Citizens Council, said that because of the losses, the council would be unable to pay the teachers, social workers and vendors that supply services to its programs. Among the services the council provides are meals for almost 8,000 elderly people each day and day-care centers that care for more than 200 children from low-income families.
The council will have to shut down four programs before Thanksgiving if the Federal Government does not refund the money, he said.
Mr. Abrams said he did not know whether any churches, several of which held multiple accounts at the bank, were affected.
"At this point it's hard to say," he said. "The initial indications are that this could involve a very significant number of organizations."
 
Interpreting the Rules
 Mr. Abrams said he had heard that one community service organization in Brooklyn had lost more than $700,000.
In his letter to Mr. Seidman, Mr. Abrams asked the F.D.I.C. to consider community groups as trustees or agents for the various charities and community services they fund instead of as single depositors.
He said Federal regulations could be interpreted to make a distinction for a single trustee managing funds for several charities or community service programs. "We think they should look at the beneficiaries of the account as individual entities, not only the trustee or the name on the account," he said.
Alan Aviles, an aide to Mr. Abrams, said the regulations already distinguish between formal trusts and individual depositors. He said the F.D.I.C. considers the beneficiaries of a trust, not the trustee, when applying the deposit insurance limit.
The Fort Greene Senior Citizens Council has already submitted contracts to support the argument that it is merely a custodian for funds used by many different agencies.
The losses by charities at Freedom came to light during a hearing on Friday on issues affecting the elderly in minority communities, held by Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve, Democrat of Buffalo. Mr. Eve said several executives of nonprofit organizations that serve the elderly canceled their testimony because their programs were affected by the bank's failure.
