HEADLINE: FISCAL TURMOIL;
Cuomo's Fiscal Shift

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The harsh budget-cutting plan proposed on Saturday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo represents a drastic policy shift for his administration, which is being guided by a grim new set of economic and political concerns.
 Hemmed in on one side by a shrinking economy and on the other by voters' antipathy toward new taxes, the Governor, most political and financial analysts say, had few alternatives but to propose deep spending cuts in response to the state's recurring fiscal problems. Mr. Cuomo, who was re-elected this month by a disappointing margin, seemed to concur. On Saturday he said he had "no choice" but to seek thousands of layoffs and deep cuts in state programs.
 
No New Taxes, Fees or Tricks
 But in doing so, he tacitly acknowledged that the methods he had used in the past to avert such pain had done little but delay it. Signaling a clear change in strategy, Mr. Cuomo said that this year he would reject the kind of moves he often relied on over the last three years to cushion the impact of the state's fiscal problems. 
 "I will reject any proposed tax increases," Mr. Cuomo declared sternly. "I will reject any cash manipulations. I will reject the idea of deficit notes."
Unlike past deficit-reduction plans, the one presented on Saturday calls for no new taxes or fees. It does not rely on accounting tricks and "one-shot" revenues to create the semblance of balance without the substance. Nor does it depend on increased borrowing by selling short-term notes, or deficit notes, to financial institutions, a practice that has allowed the state to avoid anguish in one year by putting it off until the next.
"It's a major departure from the last couple of years," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a monitoring group financed by businesses. "It's the first serious proposal to deal with a midyear problem that we've seen from the Governor."
The plan calls for layoffs of 10,000 state government workers over the next 17 months, which would be the largest number of layoffs in state history. With attrition, the state's work force would be reduced by about 18,000 positions, or 10 percent. The plan also includes substantial cuts in state aid to education, Medicaid spending and state grants to local governments.
The immediate goal of the plan is to deal with the current fiscal year's budget gap, which is estimated to be about $900 million. But it is also supposed to have long-term benefits: If the cuts are carried over into the next fiscal year, which starts on April 1, they would save the state another $1.3 billion. In that year, the state is facing a budget gap estimated at up to $3 billion.
The plan could have important political advantages for the Governor as well. Although Cuomo administration officials insist that the plan, and the inevitable battle it will provoke with lawmakers and labor leaders, are incompatible with White House ambitions, many Albany politicians believe Mr. Cuomo is taking forceful action now to prepare for a Presidential run later on.
"What's driving this," said one state official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, "is the whole national agenda."
Ever since New York State's finances started to deterioriate in 1988, fiscal analysts have been urging the Governor to take steps to bring state spending in line with shrinking state revenues. Most analysts said the sooner the adminstration started paring down the government, the less pain it would have to cause later on.
 
Defends Past Deficit Spending
 Mr. Cuomo had little use for that advice. He allowed large budget gaps to develop, closed them with stopgap measures and then watched them expand again, like floodwaters overflowing a makeshift dam.
Indeed, even as he presented his plan on Saturday, Mr. Cuomo unrepentantly defended the deficit spending of the last few years, saying: "The spending we did, I'm proud of. I think we needed those prisons. I think we needed those corrections officers."
With his new plan, however, Mr. Cuomo seemed to have finally acknowledged that drastic and lasting measures were needed to give the state a measure of fiscal stability. This change of heart, it seems, was provoked by a combination of factors, some fiscal, some political.
On the fiscal side, the Cuomo administration has concluded that for the near future at least, state tax collections are likely only to shrink. And by most accounts, including his own, the Governor has simply run out of the reserve funds and accounting tricks that he once turned to for temporary relief.
 
'You're Out of Room'
 "You cannot this year play any of those games," Mr. Cuomo said. "Why? Because you're out of room."
Borrowing has also become increasingly difficult. Under a plan announced with much fanfare in the spring, the state is actually supposed to be reducing its annual borrowing by paying off its long-term deficit over the next 30 years. If, less than a year after announcing this plan, the state turned around and increased its borrowing, many experts said, the financial markets would react harshly.
"From a rating agency perspective, we need to see that one of the state's principal focuses is on not building up any further need for borrowing," said George Leung, a vice president of Moody's Investors Service. The state already has the lowest bond rating in its history.
From the results of this month's election, Mr. Cuomo seemed to be politically barred from solving the state's fiscal problems through further tax increases, and he said as much.
 
Election Message on Taxes
 "They said 'No taxes,' " he said of the voters. On Nov. 6, voters rejected a proposed environmental bond issue he had backed, presumably because they thought it would cost them more money. In each of the last two years, Mr. Cuomo approved record tax increases.
Often the gubernatorial election seemed a referendum on Mr. Cuomo's fiscal stewardship, and when the Governor won the race against three unknowns by a surprisingly small margin, many politicians here said he would have to take bold action to regain his stature.
"The plan is basically a response to the criticism he got during the campaign on fiscal leadership," said Mel Miller, the Assembly Speaker. "I don't think he had much choice."

HEADLINE: FISCAL TURMOIL;
In New Jersey, a Fear of the Bad Old Days

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
From the gilded casinos of Atlantic City to tiny villages reminiscent of old New England, New Jerseyans are expressing confusion and rage about their Governor, the economy and the future of a state that until recently seemed full of optimism.
In contrast with the 1980's, when the state shed its poor public image and entered an era of economic resurgence, New Jerseyans today are greeting news ranging from rising taxes to the teetering of Donald J. Trump's empire with a fear that the state may be returning to the bad old days they have labored hard to forget. 
 "Our glory days are over," said State Senator Laurence S. Weiss, a Democrat and fiscal expert.
In dozens of interviews around the state over the last 10 days, small-town mayors, legislators and average citizens said they believed the ordinary people of New Jersey were being buffeted by leaders and institutions way beyond their control. To many, the state's Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, has come to personify the very forces that are filling the public with trepidation.
In particular this weekend, New Jerseyans were attempting to comprehend how a state that experienced years of buoyant growth, and which this year was already hit with the biggest tax increase in its history, suddenly found itself on Friday with a $600 million budget shortfall.
"I'm amazed that just a year ago, the state had a budget apparently in order and all of a sudden a new person comes in andwe're in a fiscal morass," said Harry Plonskier, a 38-year-old executive with a cellular telephone company who lives in Mahwah. "What Florio is doing is discouraging people from living in the state. He's going to cause New Jersey to lose the luster it's had for the last 10 years."
 
Liberal Program Pushed
 Such political sentiments are reflected these days in "Impeach Florio" cigarette lighters and bumper stickers showing up around the state, as well as by an Election Day poll this month showing that 80 percent of the voters who were questioned disapproved of Mr. Florio's fiscal policies.
The Governor last spring pushed a wide range of liberal initiatives through the Legislature, including a $2.8 billion tax plan designed to balance the budget and shift money from the state's more affluent suburbs to its poorer cities. On Nov. 6, voters vented their anger over the Florio taxes in the near defeat of the state's most prominent Democrat, Senator Bill Bradley.
But even more than the anger at Mr. Florio, New Jerseyans in interviews voiced concern about their ability to make ends meet as the unemployment rate rises and the cost of property taxes and insurance skyrocket. Often with a sneer, they described their political leaders as unwilling to empathize or listen.
"I never see myself being able to retire," said 39-year-old Daniel M. Koppa, a pharmacist in Manahawkin who holds two jobs and with his wife, who is also employed, takes care of their baby. "There's not a lot of time left over. Not enough time and not enough money."
 
Pride in State Slipping
 A silver-haired volunteer fireman in Wrightstown, N.J., who spoke on the condition that his name not be printed, asked, "What good does it do to talk about it? Talk's cheap, and nobody listens."
Such interviews are echoed in the results of recent public opinion polls in New Jersey showing a striking drop in residents' pride in their state, faith in their leaders and hope for the future.
In July, only 59 percent of New Jerseyans rated their state as an excellent or good place to live in, down from 80 percent in 1984, according to a poll by the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University.
Another poll for the institute, conducted between Sept. 24 and Oct. 2, found that 74 percent of New Jerseyans believed that the state "had pretty seriously gotten off on the wrong track." And a majority said the state government disregarded public opinion when it made decisions. The polls, each of 800 residents, reported margins of error of 3.5 percentage points.
 
'It's Just a Gamble'
 "It's so uncertain," said Steven Klaus, 40, operator of a service station in Hopewell, when asked about the future. "It's just a gamble. You're better off in Las Vegas on a roll."
Worries about the future in New Jersey are similar to the concerns of Americans in other states, who this fall have faced the increasing likelihood of a recession, a budget deadlock in Washington and the prospect of war in the Middle East.
But residents in New Jersey are particularly sensitive to headlines about recessions, taxes and political mismanagement. For in the 1970's, the state suffered economic troubles more acutely than the nation as a whole, and it experienced rebirth in the 1980's more dramatically than any other state in the region.
In the 1980's, New Jersey's economy created more than 500,000 new jobs, and the state shed its image of being a butt of comedian jokes, often perceived by outsiders as a toxic land bridge between Philadelphia and New York.
 
Deficit Upon Deficit
 After the 1970's, when the state lost tens of thousands of manufacturing jobs and the unemployment rate reached nearly 10 percent, residents were relieved to see their state become a magnet for tourists and service-industry jobs. Government was no longer staggering from fiscal crisis to crisis. By 1986, unemployment fell below 4 percent, and the state reported large surpluses.
On Friday State Treasurer Douglas C. Berman reported that that the state was facing a $600 million shortfall, even though Governor Florio had pushed more than $1.4 in new taxes to cover a $600 million shortfall discovered in the spring. Mr. Berman blamed a recession striking states throughout the region.
In the same week New Jerseyans learned that Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the largest medical insurer in the state, was asking for a 47.5 percent increase in premiums and that Donald Trump had defaulted on payments for the largest casino in Atlantic City, the Taj Mahal, a major employer.
Florio administration officials said the state's economy would remain far stronger than it was in the 1970's. And they argued that some of the pain of property taxpayers would be relieved next year when less affluent taxpayers and school districts receive new aid as a result of increased income taxes on richer residents.
 
From Bad to Worse
 But interviews with dozens of mayors and other municipal leaders around the state, both Democrats and Republicans, indicated that even among those who had attempted to understand the Florio tax program, there was a conviction that the plan was only going to make bad times worse.
"I'm afraid we are just going to have to start laying people off," said William S. Marple, the Republican Mayor of Elk Township, a rural municipality of 3,600 in southern New Jersey. "Most mayors agree with me, I think. This thing is completely stupid."
Some Democratic mayors said they were upset that the Governor had imposed a complex set of liberal policies without consulting with or explaining them to the public. What Mr. Florio saw as fairness looked to many outside of Trenton as ideological rigidity.
"Florio's mistake was not explaining anything to the public before he acted," said Donald Aronson, the Democratic Mayor of Englewood. "The public believes we must take care of our brothers. At the same time they see this as a redistribution of wealth. To them that is a repugnant philosophy."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EUROPE;
Designing the New Europe: Plenty to Argue About

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The leaders of the United States, the Soviet Union and more than 30 other European countries began arriving here today for an extraordinary summit meeting to celebrate the end of the division of Europe and to design ways of guaranteeing peace and democracy on a continent twice ravaged by world war in this century.
But given the pace of events since the Berlin wall fell a year ago, they also gathered under the shadow of a possible war in the Persian Gulf, disarray in the Soviet Union, a bitter trade dispute between Washington and the European Community and government crises in Britain and France.
 
Baker's Optimistic Filter
 For three days, however, the 34 leaders are to try to focus on the challenges facing the emerging new Europe, hailing the dramatic changes that have already taken place, but also approving documents and creating mechanisms aimed at preventing a return of political tension and instability. 
 "For the first time in 40 years, Europe will be meeting and discussing and planning, without an artificial East-West divide to block progress," Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d noted last week, adding that democratic and market principles were now the region's common guides.
 
Nonaggression Pledge
 The summit meeting itself, held under the auspices of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, is to open Monday with participants signing a far-reaching treaty sharply reducing the levels of conventional weapons permissible for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact in an area stretching from the Atlantic to the Urals.
The two alliances are also scheduled to sign a nonaggression pledge, while all 34 leaders are to wind up the meeting on Wednesday by approving a document establishing a small permanent secretariat for the security conference as well as a conflict-prevention center, an election-monitoring office and a legislative Assembly of Europe.
Most leaders attending flew into Paris tonight, where 10,000 police officers have been mobilized to provide security. Metal crowd barriers appear to be more numerous than trees, and the conference center on the Avenue Kleber near the Arc de Triomphe stands protected by armed guards and anti-aircraft missiles.
 
Bush's Lunch With Kohl
 President Bush, who spent Saturday in Prague, arrived here after having lunch with the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, in Bonn and immediately went to Elysee Palace for dinner with President Francois Mitterrand. The Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, flew in from a brief visit to Rome, which included a meeting with Pope John Paul II.
The American and Soviet leaders are to confer privately at dinner Monday night, one of the myriad meetings that will take place here this week, with the gulf crisis and the latest political developments in Moscow expected to dominate their planned 90 minutes of talks.
To insure continuity of the process that began when the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe signed the Helsinki Final Act in 1975, the 34 nations plan to hold regular ministerial meetings and a summit meeting every two years, with the next one scheduled for Helsinki in 1992.
Further, as a result of this meeting, continuing talks to build confidence and enhance security in Europe should be given a new push toward still greater exchanges of information on military doctrine, arms acquisitions, maneuvers and stockpiling between members of the security conference.
 
Byproducts of Helsinki Process
 Working in favor of the security conference is the recognition that from its origins it contributed to the decline of Communism; in calling for democracy, freedom of speech and respect for human rights, the Helsinki Final Act set in motion protest movements in several Soviet bloc countries and became, in Mr. Baker's words, "a beacon of hope."
Significantly, among the 11 Presidents, 21 Prime Ministers, one Minister of State and one Secretary of State here this week, there are three -- Czechoslovakia's President, Vaclav Havel; Poland's Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, and Bulgaria's President, Zhelvu Zhelev -- who suffered jail or persecution for trying to exercize rights guaranteed by the Helsinki accord.
For 15 years, the security conference was also the only European body that brought together the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including the United States and Canada, the seven-nation Warsaw Pact and 12 neutral administrations, among them tiny states like the Vatican, San Marino, Monaco and Liechtenstein.
With German unification last month, the security conference shrank to 34 members -- and the Warsaw Pact to 6. But Albania, which long preferred isolation, has now applied to join and has so far been accepted as an observer. The three Baltic states -- Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia -- are also lobbying for membership in their campaign for independence from the Soviet Union. Their foreign ministers have come to Paris this week as "distinguished guests" of the French Government.
 
History and Hyperbole
 Yet while this week's meeting has been compared, with considerable hyperbole, to the Congress of Vienna in 1815 that redrew the map of Europe after the Napoleonic wars, it is also apparent that present plans for the security conference fall far short of those advocated by the Soviet Union and several East European countries.
With the doors to NATO and the 12-nation European Community still closed to fresh members, the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact led the former East bloc nations to look to the conference to provide a new, all-European security structure for a post-cold-war era in which military alliances have lost importance.
But the United States has discouraged moves to turn the security conference into a kind of European United Nations for fear that this would weaken NATO and, in the process, erode its influence in Europe. Rather, Washington has favored building the new Europe around principles rather than institutions.
At the same time, the security conference has no mandate for involvement in two of the problems -- the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the surge of nationalist and ethnic tensions across Eastern Europe -- that most threaten European stability today, since both are considered domestic questions. But they are certain to be tackled in many private meetings here this week.
 
U.S.-West European Rift
 No less urgent a topic for discussion between Mr. Bush and his European colleagues is the dispute between Washington and the European Community that has deadlocked crucial negotiations to liberalize world trade under the so-called Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
With these talks due to enter their final week of bargaining in Brussels on Dec. 3, pessimism is rife. And while all parties have warned of the dangers of a disastrous protectionist trade war if they fail, the United States and the community remain far apart on the central issue of agricultural exports.
 
Domestic Worries
 Several European leaders are also in Paris with domestic problems on their minds. On Monday, the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Michel Rocard faces possible defeat in a vote of confidence in the French National Assembly. On Tuesday, Margaret Thatcher's 11-year rule as Britain's Prime Minister will be challenged in a vote for the Conservative Party leadership.
But while Poland has presidential elections on Nov. 25 and the first elections for all of unified Germany are scheduled for Dec. 2, it is the unstable situation in the Soviet Union that seems most likely to remind summit participants that the end of the cold war does not mean that Europe's troubles are over.
Arguing for a positive response to President Gorbachev's appeals for economic aid, a Western representative to NATO said it was essential to build "a sensible and cooperative" relationship with Moscow. "It's important to make the Soviets feel they belong to the new Europe," he said. "If we allow Moscow to feel excluded, we'll be storing up a lot of problems for the future."

HEADLINE: Despite Order, U.S. Stalls Aid to Poor Children

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Nine months after the Supreme Court ordered the Social Security Administration to stop denying benefits to poor children with severe physical and mental disabilities, hundreds of thousands of children have yet to receive assistance.
The Court held in February that for 16 years the Government had violated the law by paying Supplemental Security Income benefits only to poor children who met specific medical criteria, like deafness and severe mental retardation. The Justices said the criteria unfairly excluded many children with other disabilities, like Down's syndrome, muscular dystrophy, spina bifida, AIDS, cystic fibrosis and other chronic illnesses and birth defects. 
 But the Government, concerned that added costs could reach hundreds of millions of dollars a year, is insisting on a narrow interpretation of the ruling. The Social Security Administration, a unit of the Department of Health and Human Services, has yet to issue new permanent rules or standards for evaluating childhood disability. The Government said in May that it expected to issue the rules by Aug. 31.
 
Demand for Review of Files
 The Court decision was a major victory for advocates for the disabled. Community Legal Services Inc., a program for the poor in Philadelphia, had brought a class-action lawsuit on behalf of the disabled children who had applied for Federal benefits and were turned down.
Social Security officials are resisting plaintiffs' demands that they retrieve the files of all children denied benefits, so the evidence can be re-examined, and they have not yet sent notices to people who might qualify for assistance under the Court decision.
Senator John Heinz, a Pennsylvania Republican who has monitored Social Security disability programs for 10 years, said: "The harsh fact is that 500,000 children are no closer to justice in November than they were in February. Not one denial has been reversed, not one check mailed, not one child helped."
Social Security officials said they were eager to locate children eligible for benefits. Jean Hall Hinckley, director of the litigation support staff at Social Security headquarters, said the agency was "committed to effectuating all required relief in the most expeditious manner possible."
But she said the Government faced overwhelming administrative problems in carrying out "a court order unprecedented in scope." Mrs. Hinckley is responsible for coordinating Federal efforts to carry out the Court decision.
 
Frustration for Parents
 Under the Social Security Act, a child is eligible for benefits if the child suffers from an impairment of "comparable severity" to one that would prevent an adult from working. But the Court found that the Government often used a stricter test for children than for adults.
The Court said Social Security examiners could not disqualify children merely because they failed to meet the agency's list of medical criteria. Rather, it said, the Government must assess the impact of each child's handicap on the youngster's ability to perform "normal daily activities" like speaking, walking, washing and going to school.
For parents, the delays have meant a long and frustrating wait for benefits, accompanied by bewildering bureaucratic obstacles. Laura L. Sheeley of West Des Moines, Iowa, said she had been frustrated in efforts to get disability benefits for her 5-year-old daughter, Stephanie, who is mentally retarded and was born with curvature of the spine and clubfeet.
"The Government now acknowledges that Stephanie is eligible for disability benefits, but will not let me apply for payments owed to her for the period from July 1986 to June 1989," Ms. Sheeley said in an interview. In July of this year, she received a letter from the local office of the Social Security Administration saying "it will be quite some time" before Stephanie gets any assistance as a result of the Supreme Court decision. Ms. Sheeley said she was unemployed and had been receiving food stamps since Stephanie was born.
Earl A. Shoemaker of Iola, Wis., said he had been stymied in efforts to get six years' worth of benefits for his stepdaughter, Alicia M. Calkins, who has cerebral palsy and learning disabilities and needs surgery for congenital heart defects.
The girl's mother, Kate A. Shoemaker, said: "Social Security workers tell us that nothing has been decided and it could be a year before they know whether the Supreme Court decision applies to Alicia. We get no answers to any of our questions from Social Security."
Donna M. Lefebvre, a staff lawyer at Rural Legal Services of Tennessee, who has handled two dozen children's disability cases in the last two years, said: "I know there are good people in the Social Security Administration, trying to create humane regulations. But it does not translate into helping the children I see day to day. It's terribly frustrating because these kids need benefits.
"The Tennessee disability agency, under instructions from Social Security, is still applying Federal criteria in a narrow, restrictive way so that children are excluded, not included."
The Social Security Administration recently turned down a claim filed on behalf of a 12-year-old boy with muscular dystrophy, Michael W. Giles Jr. of Powell, Tenn., saying his condition was "not severe enough to be considered disabling." His mother, Theresa A. Giles, said that Social Security claims examiners had not met Michael but that she had seen him "suffer every day" as his condition deteriorated for three years.
The Supreme Court ruling could easily cost the Government several hundred million dollars a year in cash payments and Medicaid coverage for new beneficiaries. But no one can predict the cost with precision because it depends on many variables, including the starting date for eligibility and the number of claimants who can be found.
A White House official said this week, "Nobody in the Administration wants to hurt poor and disabled children, but we don't want to give them a financial windfall either." Back payments could average $10,000 to $15,000 a child, he said, and the Bush Administration wants to be sure the money goes to those who need it most.
Parents of disabled children and their lawyers say the Social Security claim files should be retrieved because they contain essential information: medical evidence of disability, family income data, and names and addresses that would help the Government track down people eligible for payments under the Supreme Court ruling.
But Mrs. Hinckley at the Social Security headquarters said it would be "inordinately burdensome" and "extremely costly" for the Government to retrieve the files. In addition, she said, some of the folders may have been lost or destroyed. Even if they can be located, she said, "the old files will not be useful" because they are outdated.
To fetch all the files would be a "massive undertaking," Mrs. Hinckley said, noting that the Government denied claims or terminated benefits for 283,360 children from May 1983 to February 1990.
The Supreme Court decision, Sullivan v. Zebley, affects a nationwide class of poor disabled people who were under 18 years old when they applied for benefits. Lawyers for the Government and the children disagree over how many youngsters should be allowed to take advantage of the ruling. The number would grow to 400,000 if the Government agreed to pay benefits to those denied aid since 1980. It would reach 600,000 if eligibility went back to the start of the program in 1974, as the plaintiffs want.
Supplemental Security Income is the only Federal program that provides cash assistance to children based on disability and financial need. The average benefit for disabled children is $331 a month. In most states, beneficiaries also automatically become eligible for Medicaid. The Medicaid coverage may be more valuable than the cash because disabled children often have huge medical bills.
In the past, children who were blind or deaf or mentally retarded, with an I.Q. of less than 60, could qualify for benefits relatively easily. But youngsters with more subtle or complicated impairments were often turned down.
In May, the Government and lawyers for disabled children agreed to an "interim standard" to be used in all new and pending cases. Under that standard, the Government must carefully assess each child's abilities.
 
No Appeal if Claim Denied
 The standard includes one highly unusual restriction on the rights of disabled children: If their claims are denied, they may not appeal to an administrative law judge or to a Federal court. That restriction was supposed to be temporary, until a permanent regulation was issued, but no such rule has yet been published.
Among those who have raised questions about Federal policy is Stephen C. King, son of Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn S. King. In a law review article last year, he and Elizabeth J. Jameson, an expert on children's rights, said: "The Social Security Administration has a long and troubling history of refusing to follow adverse court decisions interpreting the Social Security Act. This refusal has had a severe impact on rejected applicants and terminated beneficiaries" in Social Security disability programs.
Jonathan M. Stein, general counsel of Community Legal Services of Philadelphia, said the Government seemed to be intent on providing "retroactive relief to as few children as possible."
He continued, "While the Government delays compliance with the Supreme Court decision, eligible children are being denied cash benefits and access to life-preserving medical care."

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
A.T.& T.'s Rivals Find Out Just How Big a Giant Can Be

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has finally learned to throw its weight around effectively, battering the sales and stocks of United Telecom and MCI.
The first rival to suffer was U S Sprint, which said in mid-July that it would lay off 1,300 employees because its growth in the residential and small-business markets had slowed. As a result, shares of Sprint's parent, United Telecommunications Inc., dropped $12.50 in two days, to $25.75. 
 Now the MCI Communications Corporation, the No. 2 long-distance carrier behind A.T.&T., is also showing bruises. MCI announced layoffs on Thursday afternoon and told Wall Street analysts in the evening that its fourth-quarter sales might be smaller than those in the third quarter. MCI shares fell $1.875 on Thursday and $7.375 on Friday to close the week at $22.625.
Both companies are feeling the heat from A.T.&T.'s aggressive marketing and its offers of special discounts for big corporations.
Yet even A.T.&T. has its troubles, as a slowing economy makes it harder and harder for its huge equipment-manufacturing divisions to sell everything from multiple-line telephones for small businesses to central office switches for telephone companies. When A.T.&T. first announced these troubles on June 27, its stock fell nearly $4, to $37.625. Shares of both A.T.&T. and United Telecom have continued to slide over the last four months, slipping further on Friday in reaction to MCI's troubles.
And over the bitter legal and marketing struggles in the long-distance industry this year, there looms the specter of a recession that could, unlike previous downturns, depress overall revenues.
So, many of Wall Street's telephone industry analysts, who just last spring were strongly recommending all three stocks, have grown gloomy. "I really don't think there's any reason to buy any of these long-distance stocks," said Jack B. Grubman at Paine Webber.
In interviews, the chairmen of A.T.&T., MCI and United Telecom all played down the risks to their industry from a recession, while the chairmen of MCI and United Telecom also minimized the extent of their current problems.
William G. McGowan, the chairman and chief executive of MCI, appeared to backpedal in an interview on Friday afternoon from his subordinates' warnings to analysts the night before that the company's revenues could shrink in the current quarter. It is too early to reach such a conclusion, he said, and the fourth quarter is usually weak anyway because of slow corporate business at Christmas.
"We certainly don't see any cause for alarms about it at this point," Mr. McGowan said.
MCI acquired Telecom USA on Aug. 14, so that Telecom's sales, about a ninth of MCI's last year, were only partly included in the third-quarter results but will be fully included in the fourth quarter. The prospect that MCI's sales might shrink in the quarter, even with Telecom sales included, particularly alarmed analysts. It suggested that after years in which sales grew at twice the industry's pace, MCI's growth in market share might have stopped.
Mr. McGowan said that it was too soon for analysts to reach such a conclusion and that MCI still might continue to gain market share. "They're kind of overworking the subject of how the pie is being divvied up," he said.
William T. Esrey, the chairman and chief executive of United Telecom, said on Saturday that U S Sprint was continuing to gain market share slowly, although it had been hurt by A.T.&T.'s lavish marketing campaign in the last few months. But he said some investors had been slow to realize that the days of big gains at A.T.&T.'s expense were over.
"There are still people around who still see this as a rocket shot to the moon," he said. "They're expecting 35 to 40 percent growth rates."
Two basic changes in the long-distance industry, widely mentioned but seldom seen in a broader context, have allowed A.T.&T. to reassert itself.
One is that competition has driven down the prices of calls on all three long-distance companies to levels fairly close to their costs. MCI and U S Sprint, which have lower costs, continue to charge less than A.T.&T., but the difference is less striking than it used to be.
This has meant that customer service, advertising campaigns and direct marketing have become much more important. And A.T.&T. has an enormous advantage there. Each dollar the company spends on television and newspaper advertisements to retain old customers and win new ones can be spread over a base that is five times as large as MCI's and seven times as large as U S Sprint's.
On the other hand, A.T.&T.'s huge market share meant that it gave up five to seven times as much revenue as its rivals during each round of price cuts.
A.T.&T. has about 70 percent of the long-distance market, MCI has 14 percent and U S Sprint 10 percent. More than 200 small companies share the remaining 6 percent of the $55-billion market.
A.T.&T.'s current marketing success could backfire because the company has been asking for fewer regulations on the grounds that it is no longer a monopoly.
The other big change was the decision of the Federal Communications Commission nearly three years ago to allow A.T.&T. to charge its biggest corporate and institutional customers much less for a package of services than the cost of the services bought separately at regulated rates. A.T.&T. has since signed 77 such contracts, worth an estimated $1 billion a year, and is signing up more customers despite a recent Federal appeals court decision questioning the legality of the F.C.C.'s decision.
The F.C.C. moved on Nov. 8 to allow four more bulk discount contracts, a decision that Mr. Esrey called a surprise.
The large contracts typically include not just volume discounts to certain area codes but also features like allowing an office worker to dial a four- or five-digit number and reach a colleague down the hallway or on another continent.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EUROPE;
The Legacy of Helsinki

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Fifteen years ago last August, the leaders of the 35 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, meeting in Helsinki, signed a document called a Final Act that recognized the inviolability of the boundaries forcibly redrawn in World War II.
 The Soviet Union and its allies were confident that the Helsinki accords would indeed be a final act, setting the seal on the legitimacy of Communist domination of Eastern Europe and the Baltic nations. 
 Instead, the accords helped seal its doom.
On Monday, the leaders of the participating countries, 34 of them now, will meet again in Paris, this time to ratify a redrawing of the map that nobody expected so soon. The unexpected triumph of anti-Communist and democratic movements in Eastern Europe, encouraged by commitments to human rights and fundamental freedoms in the Helsinki accords that their Communist signers never dreamed of taking seriously, produced the reunification of Germany on Oct. 3.
 
A Less Predictable Future
 Now, seeking to make the future more predictable, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and even the new, united Germany are pressing to expand the conference into a new, nonconfrontational security structure for Europe to replace the moribund Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
But with economic chaos and political disintegration threatening to overwhelm the Soviet Union, and conflict among nationalities and ethnic groups rising all over Eastern Europe, the future is less predictable than ever. The possibility of a large-scale and destructive war in the Persian Gulf adds further to the uncertainty and to doubts that the security conference can fill a wider role.
But the process the conference began in Helsinki in 1975 has often produced momentous surprises. Erich Honecker, the Communist leader of East Germany, said confidently then of the Final Act, "Inviolability of frontiers is the decisive point."
He and other Communist leaders agreed to pledges to uphold the "universal significance of human rights and fundamental freedoms" and to let people travel freely, associate with each other as they wished and enjoy the benefits of free and wide dissemination of information, apparently regarding them as mere empty words.
"It is only the people of each given state, and no one else, that has the sovereign right to resolve its internal affairs and establish its internal laws," said Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader at the time.
Conservatives and emigre groups in the United States and elsewhere took him at his word, and charged that Helsinki was a retreat by the West, selling out the freedom of the peoples of Eastern Europe and the Baltic countries annexed by Stalin in 1939.
 
'Helsinki Groups' Blossom
 But the Helsinki conference soon had profoundly far-reaching results, not only in Eastern Europe but in the Soviet Union. All over the Communist empire, "Helsinki groups" of democrats and dissidents soon sprang up and demanded, with Western support, that Communist governments live up to their pledges on freedom and human rights.
Their leaders -- Andrei D. Sakharov in Moscow, Vaclav Havel of Charter 77 in Prague and others like Lech Walesa of Solidarity in Poland -- were exiled, arrested or imprisoned. But a decade and a half later those movements produced the democratic nucleus that came to power, in Eastern Europe at least, when the Communist regimes collapsed.
Institutionally, the security conference played no role at all in the revolutions of Eastern Europe, nor could it.
But some important European countries now want it to take over the role of guaranteeing European security that the United States and most of its allies assume only NATO can play.
"The question is whether Europe still needs a stabilizing, anchoring influence, and whether the United States has to participate to provide it," a NATO official in Brussels said. The United States and its allies will try to renegotiate the political consensus within the alliance over the next several years, following their pledge at the London NATO summit last July to transform it.
"Europe has changed in a dramatic way," said Pierre Schori, Cabinet secretary in the Swedish Foreign Ministry in Stockholm. "The summit in Paris is a turning point, with a consensus for the first time ever on the rule of law and democracy by all the European nations, and the signing of the world's largest-ever disarmament agreement."
 
A Nonaggression Pledge
 This, the treaty on conventional forces in Europe, will be signed in Paris on Monday, accompanied by a mutual nonaggression pledge by the 16 NATO members and the 6 remaining Warsaw Pact countries that negotiated it. The pact sets drastically lower limits on military forces in both halves of Europe, requiring deeper cuts by the Soviet Union than by the United States.
But in effect it only sets down on paper what the revolutions in Eastern Europe achieved on the ground last year, since the Warsaw Pact has all but collapsed and Soviet forces in Eastern Europe were being asked to leave anyway by the middle of this decade.
But the Soviet Union, assuming it can hold together, does not want to be shut out of Europe strategically, and thus sees the security conference as a way to stay in. Neutral countries like Sweden also see it as a way of moving closer. "The gulf crisis has given an out-of-area dimension to the process," Mr. Schori asserted. What he meant was that, like most members of the United Nations Security Council, all the security conference foreign ministers meeting at the United Nations in October were united in condemning Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait and in demanding a withdrawal.
But a high-level international floating crap game like the security conference will never be an effective guarantee against such aggression in the future, American officials argue, noting that even NATO, with a charter most of its members construe as being limited to Europe and the North Atlantic, has played only a limited role in the military response to the gulf crisis.
The meeting in Paris this week will be the last in which the security conference is without a permanent home. From now on, the 34 foreign ministers will meet at least once yearly, with summit meetings every two years, and more often if necessary. The meeting here is expected to approve a small, permanent conference secretariat and a headquarters for it in Prague. A separate Conflict Prevention Center in Vienna will also be established for exchanges on military questions, an office for supervising democratic elections will be set up, possibly in Warsaw, and a legislative Assembly of Europe will be established in Strasbourg.
Skeptics of a greater security role for the conference like the United States and British Governments see a more useful mission for it in strengthening the commitments of all member countries to freedom, the commitments that started the ball rolling in 1975.
"We must not make the mistake of thinking that the Helsinki accords and the C.S.C.E. can provide a substitute for NATO," Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said in Helsinki a few weeks ago. "One day it may be possible to think of a single security organization for Europe. But that day is still long distant."
Mrs. Thatcher proposed that the Paris meeting agree on "a European Magna Carta which would entrench for the whole of Europe the rights, freedoms and rule of law which we in the West take for granted."
That, according to diplomats in Stockholm, Vienna, London and Paris, is more or less what the communique on Wednesday will do. And that, from 1975 on into the next century, may be the enduring legacy of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
U.S. Export Ban Hurting Makers Of New Devices to Code Messages

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Advances in technology have created coding devices small enough to be placed on computer chips, allowing even desktop computers to code and decode material at a relatively small cost. And there is a growing appetite for such equipment among many companies and government agencies in the United States and abroad.
Many American companies are eager to battle for foreign customers. But the National Security Agency is determined to retain strict barriers to the export of such equipment because it does not have a practical way of cracking the codes.
 
Vast Electronic Net
 The agency, which is responsible for intelligence gathering and the security of military and Government computers, spreads a vast electronic net around the globe, eavesdropping on telephone, radio and computer data with the assistance of allied governments. In events like the shooting down of Korean Airlines flight 007 and the discovery of West German sales of chemical warfare manufacturing equipment to Libya, American electronic intelligence-gathering provided crucial data for Government officials. 
 So the agency is dismayed at advances in technology that have created chip-sized coding devices. That allows even desktop computers to code and decode material at a relatively small cost. In the past, such coding and decoding required more powerful, more expensive computers.
The codes involve translating a message into a string of numbers, which is then disguised by multiplying it by other numbers. The key to retrieving the message involves knowing the numbers by which the message was multiplied.
Banks routinely use coded messages to transfer money electronically around the world, and that use is not restricted by the National Security Agency or other Government agencies. But many companies and Government agencies would like to encode telephone conversations and data communications about sensitive matters.
While the security agency has no authority over how such technology is used in the United States -- where it is increasingly employed by corporations and Government agencies -- American intelligence officials have said privately that the security agency is determined to prevent the export of equipment that would make its work more difficult.
Asked to comment on the agency's approach to exports of coding equipment, a spokeswoman said in a written response: "Licenses for this equipment are reviewed on a case-by-case basis to determine the effect export could have on national security."
 
 Curbs Called a Burden
 That puts the Government at odds with major American computer and software companies, which say the restrictions are a significant handicap in international markets. They also argue that the restrictions are quickly becoming meaningless, because a number of companies in Britain, Japan and elsewhere are now selling such equipment.
"The agency is acting on ill-conceived good intentions," said Albert R. Belisle, chairman of the information systems security committee of the American Banking Association.
And Stephen D. Bryen, a former Pentagon export control official and president of Secured Communications Technologies Inc., a maker of computer security equipment, said, "This is cutting off your nose to spite your face." His company was recently denied a request to export a personal-computer encrypting system.
At the International Business Machines Corporation, executives spent almost a year unsuccessfully trying to persuade the agency to permit it to export a special encryption processor designed to work with its System 390 family of mainframe computers.
"We are concerned that we are not able to better respond to our customers' needs," said Edward B. Altman, I.B.M.'s director of technical strategy development.
 
 Different Channels
 Export license applications for data encryption equipment go through channels different from those of other computer equipment, which is reviewed by the Commerce Department. Coding equipment must be cleared by the State Department's Office of Munitions Control and the National Security Agency, and there is no right of appeal.
In August 1989, control over exports of some less important encryption software and hardware was transferred from the Office of Munitions Control to the Commerce Department. The equipment affected includes encryption technology used in message-authentication systems, access-control equipment, software-protection systems and automatic teller devices.
But many categories remain under the control of the State Department and the National Security Agency, including not just sophisticated coding equipment but also mass-market software, analog television descramblers, voice scramblers, smart cards -- wallet-sized cards with a small computer -- and related equipment.
In some cases, the restrictions force companies to produce incompatible versions of their products for domestic and international sale.
"United States' vendors cannot design, manufacture and market a secure version within the U.S. and an insecure version outside of the U.S. without inviting the ire of many, if not most, foreign customers," said Robert Courtney, a computer security consultant.
Computer security researchers say the agency's intransigence has hurt progress on new security technology in the United States. "If it were not for export controls, the quality of computer security systems would be dramatically better than it is today in the United States," said Steven Walker, president of Trusted Information Systems Inc., a software company.
He said that by crippling the effectiveness of American computer security exports, the Government is discouraging foreign buyers and taking away incentives to design more secure equipment by making it necessary to maintain two incompatible product lines.
The security researchers also argue that the dispute is leading to a growing gap between the National Security Agency and the commercial computer security community in the United States.
"I don't think they really realize the extent of the problem," Mr. Courtney said. "The problem is not that the walls have ears, it's that the ears have walls."
Government officials in other agencies argue that the security agency's resistance is doing severe damage to United States interests abroad because it leaves American companies vulnerable to industrial espionage. "Industrial espionage is a real thing and encryption is a very important feature," said one official. "But it's not permitted because the N.S.A. wants to read everything."
 
Software Publishers Curbed
 The encryption regulations also place strict limits on American software publishers, who are trying to improve the security of their products. The N.S.A., for example, told the Lotus Development Corporation that the security protection program in its Notes software, an innovative application that permits large work groups to share information, would have to be weakened substantially in the version to be sold internationally.
"It puts us in an awkward marketing position," said Eric Sall, the director of application marketing for Notes. "We don't publicize the fact that security is weaker outside of the United States."
The national standard encryption system used by banks and the Government is called the Data Encryption Standard, or D.E.S. While the specifications are widely available in public literature, equipment that uses the standard is controlled under International Traffic in Arms Regulations maintained by the State Department, which permits exceptions to the export limits only for some international banking activities.
 
Breaking the Code
 One issue that security experts have debated is whether the National Security Agency can decipher material coded to the D.E.S. Despite years of speculation by computer scientists and cryptologists, there has never been a public demonstration of D.E.S. vulnerability.
"The academic community has spent 20 years looking at it and they haven't found a way to break it yet," said John Nagle, a computer researcher in Menlo Park, Calif.
Scientists have suggested D.E.S. might be broken by using brute force, computing power that could test each of the vast number of possible "keys" used to encode information.
While computer security experts have long considered the security agency one of the few organizations with enough computing power to try such an approach, the agency's stance on export controls suggests that such code-breaking is not feasible technologically or economically.

HEADLINE: Faltering Laventhol Is Reportedly Closing

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
The roughly 350 partners of Laventhol & Horwath voted over the weekend at a hastily arranged emergency meeting to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and disband the firm, former Laventhol partners said last night.
A Laventhol spokesman, Louis J. Grossman, declined to comment yesterday on "any of the business plans discussed at the meeting." Laventhol partners were traveling home from Houston, where the meeting was held, and did not return telephone messages seeking comment. 
 Laventhol, the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, has been under financial strain because of several lawsuits that accused the firm of having done poor work on a number of audits and consulting projects. For instance, the firm is defending itself in a multimillion-dollar lawsuit in Charlotte, N.C., over its audit of the P.T.L. ministry of Jim Bakker.
Laventhol, which is based in Philadelphia, recently cut its employees' pay by 10 percent. It has been struggling to stay in business until December, when audits at the end of the year push up billings and provide cash.
But a weak economy and the costly litigation have prevented a comeback for the firm, which has had $350 million in revenues in recent years. In interviews, former partners, all of whom spoke on condition of anonymity, have painted a grim picture of a firm that is experiencing a severe cash shortage.
Still, few accountants had expected the firm, which specializes in advising the lodging industry, to take such drastic action. "This will be a shock to the industry," said Anthony G. Marshall, dean of the School of Hospitality Management at Florida International University. "The name Horwath, going back to the days of Horwath and Horwath, was just it. They were the best in the business."
Richard A. Eisner, the head of a New York accounting firm that bears his name, said the liquidation of a professional services firm like Laventhol was never easy to carry out. "This is really going to be a mess," he said.
"Finley, Kumble was nothing compared to this," he added, referring to the big New York law firm that was disbanded in 1987 but remains the subject of considerable litigation, "because it was much smaller in revenues and people."
The days leading up to Laventhol's vote to seek bankruptcy protection have not been easy. Active partners took home next to nothing after hospitalization and life insurance premiums were deducted from their October pay, said one former partner, who also disclosed the results of the weekend meeting.
 
Payments and Padlocks
 Laventhol had considered deferring all payments to retired partners until next year, an idea of Robert N. Levine, the firm's chief executive since June. After some discussion, the firm sent checks this month representing only 20 percent of the normal payout to them, the former partner said.
The firm also appears to be calling in loans it has made to partners, some of the former partners said, forcing at least two people to put their homes on the market to avoid personal bankruptcy.
Another former partner said the firm's New York landlord briefly padlocked the New York offices last Monday out of fear that the firm would not pay its rent. "It was a fairly embarrassing situation," the former partner said.
A senior official of Fisher Brothers, the owner of the firm's main New York offices at 605 Third Avenue, could not be reached yesterday, but has previously declined to comment about the accounting firm.
 
A 'Normal' Meeting
 Even the meeting in Houston became a humbling symbol of the firm's undoing. In an interview on Friday, Mr. Grossman, the Laventhol spokesman, called the gathering "our normal annual partners meeting covering normal business issues."
But former partners said the meeting was far from routine.
Past partners' meetings have been held at locations like the Boca Raton Hotel and Resort in Florida, the Doral Hotel in Miami Beach and the Pointe resorts in Phoenix.
This year, the former partners say, Laventhol was going to skip the event to cut costs. Then, when it had to reschedule the meeting to address several pressing problems, it arranged for it to be held at the Houston Airport Marriott. Partners were told to charge the trip on their own credit cards, the former partners said.
In a break from previous years, at least two dissident candidates sought seats on the firm's board this year. Before the meeting, Sol Reibstein of Philadelphia and Howard Silberman of Los Angeles had each collected the signatures of at least 5 percent of the partnership, the minimum needed to get on the ballot along with the board's nominees.
 
Many Defections
 In recent weeks, partners have been leaving the firm in large numbers. At least a half-dozen offices around the country, including those in San Francisco and Kansas City, Mo., are said to have explored splitting off from the national firm. All the firm's consultants on the lodging industry, considered Laventhol's hallmark, are talking about going off on their own.
The proposal that appeared to have the best chance of saving Laventhol was one that was believed to have the support of the firm's lenders at the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia and the Chase Manhattan Bank. The two banks are part of a consortium that is owed roughly $80 million. Their plan would have required the firm, which has about 50 offices around the country, to shed all but 25 to 30 of them.
The sale of the offices to the departing partners or to others would have raised cash to repay debt, while the remaining offices would have continued to service Laventhol's clients at least through the 1990-91 auditing season.
The proposal apparently fell apart because the banks wanted Laventhol's partners to each invest $75,000 in the firm, a former partner said.
 
Looking Ahead
 In the next few weeks, rather than prepare year-end audits, Laventhol faces the task of trying to unravel an operation that took 23 years to build. The firm is planning to fire employees on Tuesday, and partners will be invited to buy their local practices, a former partner said.
In addition, the firm's few remaining prestigious clients are scrambling to line up new auditors before they close their books for the year. For instance, Trans World Airlines Inc., the firm's biggest client, is expected to hire Grant Thornton or BDO Seidman, both mid-sized firms.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: NAICS541110 OFFICES OF LAWYERS (63%); SIC8111 LEGAL SERVICES (63%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (90%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (90%); NORTH CAROLINA, USA (79%); PENNSYLVANIA, USA (76%); 

CITY: CHARLOTTE, NC, USA (56%);

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Finish Higher

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Tokyo stock prices closed higher today, supported by lower oil prices and news that Saddam Hussein of Iraq would begin releasing hostages on Christmas Day.
The key 225-share Nikkei index had gained 346.53 points, or 1.5 percent, to 23,518.16. It ended the morning session up 174.11 points, or less than half a percent, to 23,345.74, with 180 millon shares changing hands. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 315.85 points, or 1.3 percent.
Traders said after the morning session that Friday's cut in the United States Federal funds rate helped the market. The rate is what banks charge each other on overnight loans to meet reserve requirements.
They said, however, that the market was facing stop-loss selling by institutional investors who had bought stocks six months ago when the Nikkei was in the 30,000's and rising.

HEADLINE: Study Attacks Women's Roles in TV

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Network television continues to give women fewer leading roles, both on and off screen, than it gives men, says a study released this week that analyzed on-screen portrayals and employment behind the camera during the 1989-90 television season.
Despite some exceptions, the study says, women are often still depicted on television as half-clad and half-witted, and needing to be rescued by quick-thinking, fully clothed men. 
 "The distorted TV picture of women has consequences for viewers, especially girls, who see fewer choices for themselves on screen," said Cindy Marano, director of the National Commission on Working Women, a Washington-based private advocacy group for women in nonprofessional occupations. The commission co-sponsored the study, "What's Wrong With This Picture?," with Women in Film, a nonprofit Los Angeles-based group working to improve the position and depiction of women in television and film. The study received financing from the Ford Foundation and the Tides Foundation.
 
An 'Unacceptable' Picture
 The yearlong study looked at 555 characters on 80 network shows that were broadcast in March and April, as well as employment statistics for the entire September-through-April season.
The study found that women still lagged far behind men in employment. Women made up 15 percent of producers, 25 percent of writers and 9 percent of directors of shows surveyed. About 40 percent of all series surveyed hired no female producers; 54 percent had no female directors.
"The overall picture is unacceptable," said Marcy Kelly, president of Women in Film, at a news conference here on Wednesday. Studies of television movies and feature films are planned, she said.
 
Inconsistent With Demographics
 The study also found that in the prime-time shows shown on ABC , CBS , NBC and the Fox Broadcasting Company, women held 43 percent of the roles. Their characters were typically richer than male characters were and were rarely depicted at all after the age of 40. Such portrayals fail to reflect real demographic trends in population, age and economic, the study says.
The show with the highest percentage of female producers, with 75 percent, was CBS's "Sugar 'n' Spice," which has been canceled. ABC's "Just the Ten of Us" had the poorest record, with no women as writers, producers or directors.
Fox had the best record of buying shows that employed high percentages of female directors, producers and writers, the study says. A Fox spokesman, Dennis Petrosky, said, "While we may be better by comparison, we still don't think it's good enough, and we hope to do better."
Shows on ABC ranked last in employing women in all three occupations. Jim Brochu, an ABC spokesman, said: "We wouldn't comment on that. We don't do the hiring; we only license shows. Talk to the producers."
Irma Kalish, executive producer of NBC's "Hogan Family," said Mr. Brochu's argument was specious because the networks control and approve nearly all of the creative employees on each pilot and series. "That's where it starts," she said at the news conference.
In August, a membership study by the Screen Actors Guild found that actresses continued to work less and earn less than men in films, television and commercials. And an article in The Los Angeles Times on Nov. 11 said that not one woman was currently in a position to give final approval to start production of a film.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Time to Go

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Two great bugaboos have sapped Britain's strength since World War II. One was the fear of encrusted trade unions, the belief that there was no way to break their strangling grip on industry. The other was the fear of losing "sovereignty" to the European Community.
Margaret Thatcher conquered the first. She challenged the unions, broke their power and freed Britain from their obsolete work rules and political strikes. 
 But the second baseless fear had, and has, Mrs. Thatcher in its grip. In her paranoia about Europe she has weakened her Government and divided her party. Now she is herself on the edge of a political abyss.
This week the Conservative Party holds a ballot on its leadership. For the first time since she became Prime Minister in 1979, Mrs. Thatcher faces a serious challenger, Michael Heseltine. She may survive, but she will be wounded.
Issues other than Europe will concern Conservative members of Parliament as they choose a leader. British voters are livid at a poll tax that Mrs. Thatcher introduced. Inflation is running at nearly 11 percent, three times the figure in Germany or France.
But Europe is the issue that brought Mrs. Thatcher to this moment of crisis. She did it to herself -- unnecessarily, one would almost say irrationally. In doing so she showed how powerful is the preoccupation with "sovereignty" that has bedeviled British politics for 40 years. I put the word in quotation marks because it has come to have mythic qualities.
Think about the point that Mrs. Thatcher has made her rallying cry against Europe in recent months: Britain's sovereign right to have its own monetary policy. She has been resisting the Community's movement toward a European central bank and, eventually, a European currency.
But the idea of Britain having independent monetary power is a myth. The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, already calls the tune for Britain as for all of Western Europe. The real choice is between that situation and a European bank in which Britain would at least have a voice.
The reality of monetary policy in Europe is a metaphor for the larger reality. Britain can do very little on its own these days. In isolation from the Community it would sink into economic irrelevance. Even its outstanding asset, the financial operations centered in London, would surely move to Frankfurt.
The myth of sovereignty kept Britain out of the European Community when it was formed. And successive Prime Ministers have preferred to cozy up to U.S. Presidents, playing Greece -- as they thought -- to America's Rome. Mrs. Thatcher very much fancies herself in that special relationship.
But it is an unequal relationship, doomed by facts. How can the United States put an alliance with Britain ahead of its relationship with the increasingly dominant European power, Germany?
In the end Mrs. Thatcher miscalculated with her most faithful colleague, Sir Geoffrey Howe, the last remaining member of her original Cabinet. Sir Geoffrey is a quiet man, extraordinarily patient, but his patience broke as the Prime Minister's invective at Europe grew ever shriller. He resigned and, last week, made a remarkable speech of explanation to the House of Commons.
"The Prime Minister's perceived attitude toward Europe is running increasingly serious risks for the future of the nation," he said. "We paid heavily in the past for late starts and squandered opportunities in Europe. We dare not let that happen again." He said Britain must not "retreat into a ghetto of sentimentality about our past and so diminish our own control over our own destiny in the future."
Mrs. Thatcher has always had a rather low opinion of her political colleagues, treating them as if she were their governess. But there was an exception: Lord Carrington, Foreign Secretary until he gallantly resigned to take responsibility for the Falkland Islands policy failure that led to war.
Lord Carrington had a way with Margaret Thatcher. He persuaded her to adopt a policy on Rhodesia that succeeded in producing the transition to an independent Zimbabwe. I think he would have helped her to see reason on Europe.
Without Lord Carrington, Mrs. Thatcher grew more arrogant. She could not even see that at this moment in history, with change in the air, there is an extraordinary opportunity to help build a new Europe.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Not Oil Nor Jobs

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Soon after America stepped up to its responsibility in the Persian Gulf, Senator Bob Dole -- ever the cynic, and a prime appeaser of Saddam Hussein -- spelled out the motive he saw behind our action: "O-I-L."
A hundred days later, with Americans still denied the articulation of a purpose worthy of fighting for, James Baker, ever the pragmatist, and the architect of the appeasement of the Iraqi dictator, came up with his own equally short, equally cynical answer: "jobs." 
 President Bush tried to defend that dismaying rationale in an interview with CNN. "Look what's happening in our own country right now," he said. "There's a slowdown, an economic slowdown," which he attributed to the oil price rise and the fear of further rises that Saddam Hussein could bring about. "And so -- it does mean jobs."
Here is the President espousing a line set earlier in the week by the man he has long trusted most in the formation of public opinion. Mr. Baker persuaded his boss that this pocketbook explanation of war aims, despite its negative reception with opinion leaders, would play in Peoria.
Mr. Baker is first and foremost a campaign manager. As he proved with his 1988 Willie Horton commercials and allegiance-pledging, he is not above using appeals to fear to sway public opinion. He has had time to think through the political reason for the President's severe drop in the polls, and his conclusion led to the "jobs" strategy. Let's see why.
He undoubtedly remembered how President Reagan's popularity plunged as the recession of 1981-82 drove up the unemployment rate. Mr. Baker also knows that the worsening 1990 recession has not yet pushed up the rate of unemployment, but that such a rise must accompany the economy's fall: at least 8 percent of the work force is likely to be out of work before Mr. Bush runs for re-election.
Who is to be blamed? How can the coming anger be deflected? Mr. Reagan was able to blame Jimmy Carter because his recession took place early in his first term, but Mr. Bush cannot blame Mr. Reagan. Nor can he shift the blame onto the Democrats for triggering recession by raising taxes -- because Mr. Bush joined that tax-hike caravan at Mr. Baker's urging.
The Baker answer: Blame Saddam Hussein. Never mind the conclusion by most economists that the downturn was well under way before his August invasion; that's a lot of egghead talk. Most people remember that prosperity was here last spring and it's gone this winter -- and the intervening big event was the doubling of oil prices after the invasion of Kuwait.
But it's a phony alibi. Of course the oil price hike adds to inflation; of course post-Kuwait uncertainty troubles the stock market; but the inevitable turn of the cycle after eight fat years was on its way. To try to use the confrontation in the gulf as an excuse for the coming decline of retail sales and drop in corporate earnings and loss of jobs is a cheap trick.
Mr. Baker is not above these tricks, but leads a media-charmed life. The savings and loan scandals took place on his watch as Treasury Secretary, but nobody grills him about his inattention. The sanctions to stop Saddam Hussein from using U.S. credit to buy weapons were defeated by Mr. Baker's personal decision, yet he was able to inveigle a front-page dope story saying how he really had wanted to get tough with Iraq but Robert Gates at the National Security Council wouldn't let him.
To use the crisis to avoid domestic political heat is to invite disunity. Mr. Bush should dispense with the sleazy Baker advice and follow his better instincts.
In the same CNN interview, he made a powerful point in going beyond the cliche of not rewarding aggression with face-saving concessions. "When you rape, pillage and plunder a neighbor, should you then ask the world 'Hey, give me a little face'?"
On the contrary, future would-be aggressors must be shown international crime has costs: not a return to the status quo ante, but reparations for killing and looting, war crimes trials for hostage-taking, and the verifiable elimination of all weapons of mass destruction. This is getting serious about keeping the next generation's peace.
The President noted that Saddam Hussein "has a nuclear capability that he's trying frantically to build . . . he's trying hard to get an atomic weapon."
Now you're talking about the coming threat to the lives of millions of Americans. That is the reason for finishing this war with an allied victory -- not to save our oil supply or to save jobs, but ultimately to save lives.

HEADLINE: Will Europe Spell Peace C.S.C.E.?

 BODY:
American and European hopes for a stable post-cold war order are riding on the 34-nation summit conference that opens today in Paris. It could be another Congress of Vienna, which ended the Napoleonic era in 1815 and ushered in nearly a half-century of peace in Europe. Or it could be another Paris Peace Conference, which concluded World War I in 1919 but produced an uneasy truce that lasted a scant 20 years.
To meet the higher standard, and truly open a new chapter of peace, the conferees will have to do more than endorse agreements already arrived at to cut military forces and unite Germany. They must lay the foundations for a new collective security organization, one that fully engages the United States and the Soviet Union politically, while disengaging them militarily. 
 Some of the tasks confronting the summit meeting -- known formally as the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe -- are relatively easy. For example, it need only ratify the agreement to cut conventional forces, which in a stroke would eliminate the threat of sudden attack that has hung over Europe since 1945.
Still, too much military hardware will remain. And no limits were put on most states' manpower. NATO, for example, will realize only small savings from modest force cuts. It would benefit from deeper weapons and manpower cuts and more constraints on mobilization. That's a task for further talks, possibly under the C.S.C.E. umbrella.
C.S.C.E. could also play a useful role in monitoring treaty compliance. Through a Crisis Prevention Center to be established this week, it will also monitor and discuss "unusual military activity" that could endanger the new stability.
A more robust collective security role is obviously worth exploring. During the cold war, even if conflicts did erupt into war, as between Greece and Turkey, the alliance system contained them and kept other states from becoming embroiled. As national tensions rise, C.S.C.E. will be asked to help resolve disputes and even keep the peace.
The need to address the domestic causes of conflict is even more urgent. Economic aid and investment can help the fledgling democracies of Eastern Europe through the hard times ahead and take the edge off nationalism.
And by signing and implementing a declaration of principles, a Magna Carta for the new Europe, C.S.C.E. could help guarantee the rights of national minorities and the inviolability of borders while permitting the movement of people, goods and ideas across them.
More and more Europeans are coming to believe in a Europe in which shared values conquer national differences, in which conflicts between states are resolved without war and in which a common market keeps borders from becoming barriers. If this idea of Europe is to prove more powerful than national passions, C.S.C.E. will have to do its part.
