HEADLINE: Yes, Defend the Schools, but Credibly

 BODY:
Strongly and stubbornly, Joseph Fernandez, New York City's Schools Chancellor, has been pursuing a passionate crusade to protect schools from drastic budget cuts. Mayor David Dinkins's latest demands could mean substantial teacher layoffs, and Gov. Mario Cuomo's new plan to close the state's huge budget deficit would cut $75 million from state aid to city schools.
Mr. Fernandez is surely right to fight; no part of municipal responsibility needs more help than education. But there's no denying the plunge in city revenues. At a time of widespread sacrifice, Mr. Fernandez appeared to have been taking obstinacy to the point of incredibility. New Yorkers who wish him and the schools well will welcome signs that he is moving to a more constructive approach.
 The severe downturn in the city and state economies has obliterated all budget forecasts. The city is trying to close a $388 million gap this year; the state may be short $1 billion. Despite this, the city rashly agreed to a one-year salary increase for teachers of 5.5 percent. Part of the increase, which Mr. Fernandez supported enthusiastically, would be financed with $70 million out of $153 million in state aid that is normally used to cover inflationary costs in Board of Education programs.
In a healthier economic climate, that would be acceptable. But under present circumstances, committing $70 million to teacher salaries puts Mr. Fernandez in a bind. That's because City Hall, having promised raises to the teachers, has also asked the board to cut its budget by $90 million.
Initially, Mr. Fernandez was only willing to identify $57.5 million in cuts. He notes that in the last 10 months the school system has already been asked to absorb $183 million in cuts, and that the central staff has been reduced by about 1,000 people. To pare the system any further, Mr. Fernandez insists, would cut muscle.
He may be right. But instead of making his case coolly, he spoke melodramatically about laying off 1,600 to 6,000 teachers. A more sensible strategy would have been to exhort the 32 community boards to cut administrative personnel first, minimizing the impact on educational quality. Why couldn't the Chancellor, who has been an effective advocate for a beleaguered school system, press community districts with the same energy he used to resist the Mayor?
In recent days, Mr. Fernandez appears to have recognized the need for a shrewder approach. He still disagrees with City Hall's contention that the board is merely being asked to take its fair share of cuts. But he at last seems willing to sit down with City Hall, community board leaders, parents and concerned citizens in an effort to reach consensus on a plan that will not devastate classroom services.
The city's troubles are real; the issue is not whether school cuts are needed, but how to minimize the loss.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Emigre From Canada Running Well in Poland

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Nov. 18

 BODY:
A wealthy Polish-born emigre businessman from Canada has suddenly emerged as a dark-horse candidate in the Polish presidential election campaign.
In just a few weeks, Stanislaw Tyminski, who is 42 years old and operates a cable television system in Peru, has risen from anonymity to a strong third-place showing in the polls, and is threatening to overtake Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who now places second. The latest survey by Polish television, released Friday, shows Mr. Tyminski with 17 percent, Mr. Mazowiecki with 19 percent and Lech Walesa, the Solidarity chairman, holding the lead with 35 percent. 
 Under the rules for the 25 election this coming Sunday, a runoff will be held on Dec. 9 unless one candidate tallies more than 50 percent of the votes. Polish law permits Poles living overseas to vote in the coming elections, and Mr. Tyminski is actively campaigning for the support of hundreds of thousands of expatriates in Canada and the United States.
Political experts in Poland still do not see Mr. Tyminski as having a serious chance to win the presidency. Those same experts two weeks ago saw Mr. Tyminski as nothing more than a footnote, not a legitimate contender for second place in a two-candidate runoff. But the experts also felt that Mr. Tyminski could not defeat Mr. Walesa in a runoff.
 
Little About Him Is Known
 Mr. Tyminski, who holds Canadian, Peruvian and Polish citizenship, has revealed little about his background to voters here and he refused a request to detail his biography since leaving Poland 21 years ago.
Business associates and friends recount a remarkable journey in which Mr. Tyminski founded a successful computer company in Canada, lost and made a fortune in Peru and underwent a spiritual transformation after traveling among Indian tribes in the Amazon jungle.
His political background is similarly eclectic. Earlier this year, Mr. Tyminski was elected President of the 3,500-member Libertarian Party of Canada. The co-author of the book he published this year in Poland with his own money is Roman Samsel, a former correspondent in Mexico for the Communist Party's daily newspaper, Trybuna Ludu. Mr. Tyminski was the only presidential candidate to attend the party given in Warsaw by the Soviet Ambassador to mark the anniversary of the Russian Revolution.
If Mr. Tyminski's background is elusive, there is no secret about his electoral appeal. His posters, plastered on the sides of Warsaw buses, are an appeal to voters put off by the prospect of a Walesa presidency and uninspired by Mr. Mazowiecki. "Neither one nor the other: Vote Tyminski," they say.
 
Attractive to Poles
 Mr. Tyminski's self-described success in Western business -- his campaign literature says he is among the richer men in Canada -- make him attractive to Poles looking for a candidate who can rebuild the nation's shattered economy. He frequently criticizes the Government's proposed program for privitizing industry in Poland, saying it would sell assets far too cheaply and invite foreigners to take unfair advantage of low wages in Poland.
"He's very appealing to people who would like to live in a rational world," said Jadwiga Staniszkis, a sociologist who supports Mr. Walesa. "Walesa is really rather unpredictable. When Tyminski speaks, he sounds terrible, but his campaign has been brilliant, his documents and television are brilliant. He is a very mysterious man."
His style of campaigning has created a stir. Mr. Tyminski, who speaks Polish with a slight foreign accent, travels around the country in a helicopter. On Saturday, he told an election rally that he would soon release documents proving that Mr. Mazowiecki was guilty of unspecified "treason," and he accused the Government of falsifying its econmic statistics.
The Government issued a denial.
According to his campaign literature and book, Mr. Tyminski was born in 1948 and went to Sweden in 1969 because he saw no opportunities in Poland. Neighbors in the small Warsaw suburb where grew up recall that he had a talent for repairing radios. After a brief stay in Sweden, he emigrated to Canada.
 
Founded Computer Company
 Maciej Bebenek, who works on the presidential campaign, said that after arriving in Canada, Mr. Tyminski studied computer science and took a job at Hewlett-Packard. In 1975, he founded a company called Transduction that found a niche designing computer systems for factories and power plants. Today, Mr. Bebenek said the company has between 10 and 15 full-time employees.
Frank Ollie, Mr. Tyminski's partner in Transduction, would not disclose the company's sales but said published reports that put the amount between $5 and $10 million were not inaccurate. Mr. Ollie said the company did so well in the late 1970's that Mr. Tyminski "felt somewhat guilty about all the money he was making" and began contributing to an orphanage in Peru. In the early 1980's, Mr. Tyminski took a vacation in Peru to get a first-hand look at the orphanage.
Mr. Ollie said Mr. Tyminski saw a business opportunity and built a large barge to carry fuel to Iquitos, a city in the upper Amazon.
"He was a bit naive about all the goings on in this part of the world, with the drug dealings and so on, and had his boat taken over by the Army, which considered it an excellent gunboat," Mr. Ollie said. This cost Mr. Tyminski between $800,000 and $1 million in losses and prompted him to journey into the jungle with the local tribes, Mr. Ollie said.
 
Described Travels in Book
 "Stan got very close to the people and many of their mystic ways," Mr. Ollie said. "I think Shirley MacLaine talks about these things. Stan was there long before that and participated in all that."
Later, Mr. Tyminski returned to Iquitos and founded a cable television company called TVS which, Mr. Ollie said, "put him back on the road to personal prosperity.
He returned to Canada in 1985 and made it a point to employ Poles at a home, a factory and a farm he had in Canada, Mr. Ollie said. Mr. Tyminski was said by several associates to have decided to enter the race after discovering that his book was being quoted by Polish candidates, including Mr. Walesa. Supporters of the Solidarity chairman said they could not recall him ever citing Mr. Tyminski's book.

HEADLINE: Kindly Reflections on the Carter Era

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
If events wrought havoc with Jimmy Carter's Administration at the time, history has been decidedly good to America's 39th President.
Mr. Carter took another step on his long journey from public ignominy to widespread admiration as dozens of former Carter Administration officials and scholars gathered last week at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., for a three-day conference to evaluate his Presidency. Mr. Carter addressed the conference on Friday, warning that President Bush was moving America toward war in the Persian Gulf. 
 The 66-year-old former President, relaxed and good-humored in a navy blazer and gray trousers, was praised for moral leadership, for rejecting politics as usual and for prescience in recognizing many of the nation's longterm problems. His failures -- with Iran, the economy and in the 1980 election -- were largely attributed to a combination of bad luck, being ahead of his time and being misunderstood by the public, the press and the liberal wing of the Democratic Party.
During the conference, which ended Saturday night, former Carter aides like Hamilton Jordan, Jody Powell and Bert Lance reminisced about the turbulent, idealistic days of the late 1970's, and many scholars said Mr. Carter's post-Presidential performance as a peacemaker and advocate for the world's poor had been a major reason for his enhanced public esteem.
"Jimmy Carter is looking good with hindsight," said Mark J. Rozell, a political scientist at Mary Washington College in Fredericksburg, Va. "All the things for which he was criticized are now qualities which everyone says we need." Mr. Rozell, a participant in one of 12 panel discussions, cited Mr. Carter's status as a Washington outsider, his emphasis on ethics, his concern for details and his compassion.
 
Comparison With Reagan
 "We've had the opportunity in recent years to see a President who paid attention to details and one who didn't," said Robert J. Lipshutz, the former counsel to the President, comparing Mr. Carter with Ronald Reagan. "We couldn't have had the Camp David accords if Carter had to read 3-by-5 cards."
Jody Powell, Mr. Carter's Presidential press secretary, said: "Jimmy Carter's performance and behavior were assessed on an extremely traditional model of what Presidents do. He didn't wheel and deal, because by 1976 that was already bankrupt."
Mr. Powell, who now heads a public relations firm in Washington, said he wished "we'd adopted a tougher and more aggressive policy" with the press, but he disputed the notion that Mr. Carter's relationship with Congress was strained. "He spent an extraordinary amount of time talking with members of Congress, more than his two predecessors or successors. But we had a problem, philosophically and in other ways, that Jimmy Carter was not what the established Democratic Party thought they would get."
 
Gains for Labor
 Several former aides said many of Mr. Carter's legislative accomplishments had been overlooked.
"The Carter Administration had the best labor record of any President since F.D.R.," said F. Ray Marshall, Mr. Carter's Labor Secretary. During the Carter years, he said, America not only had "the largest relative job growth of any postwar Administration," but collective bargaining was strengthened, work-safety laws were passed, and extensive job-training programs were created.
On Saturday, during a well-attended panel on the Iran hostage crisis, Moorhead Kennedy, a former hostage, recalled that the State Department and United States Embassy personnel "were so unprepared" for the seizure of the embassy in 1979. But he praised Mr. Carter as "the President who brought his hostages home."
 
Caution on Gulf Crisis
 Mr. Carter also addressed the issue on Friday in a two-hour question-and-answer session with 1,100 Long Island high school students and before a standing-room-only crowd of more than 1,500 people in Adams Playhouse at Hofstra.
Although he said President Bush had handled the gulf crisis "extremely well" at first, Mr. Carter warned that if the United States prematurely opted for a military solution, "we would reap serious and deleterious political consequences, far beyond what we've been led to believe."
"In Washington, people are talking about 10,000 to 30,000 U.S. force casualties," he added. "But we'd also be killing a large number of civilians. The Arab world would never forgive us for the massive deaths."
He also said the Reagan Administration's "lack of an energy policy is a contributing factor for our being in Saudi Arabia." He said the United States imported 30 percent of its oil when he left office, as against more than 50 percent today.
 
Former First Lady Speaks
 Mr. Carter's wife, Rosalynn, who shared the dais with him, added: "People want a country to be tough. If we had bombed Teheran, I think Jimmy would have been re-elected, even though the hostages would have died. But our country is stronger when we stand for peace and human rights."
Mr. Carter also expressed his opposition to limiting legislators' terms, praised President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union as the century's pre-eminent leader and worried that the large accumulation of debt during the Reagan years has "reduced Government's flexibility to deal with real problems" like poverty, education and pollution.
After describing his "despair" after the 1980 election, Mr. Carter talked about the efforts of the Carter Presidential Center to combat disease, malnutrition, human-rights abuses and war.
"We try to fill vacuums in the international community," he said, explaining that his center undertakes projects that governments and international agencies either have ignored or have been unable to take on. The center, established in 1982 at Emory University in Atlanta, has embarked on projects from helping produce medical prostheses in China and teaching African farmers to increasing grain production. mediating the Ethiopian civil war and supervising elections in Panama and Nicaragua.
The Democratic Party's failure to win a Presidential election since 1976 was addressed only somewhat elliptically during the conference.
While Mr. Carter criticized Mr. Reagan and President Bush, and had generally kind words about his Republican predecessor, Gerald R. Ford, he avoided talking about other Democrats. But former Carter officials criticized Senator Edward M. Kennedy for creating a rift within the party by challenging Mr. Carter in the 1980 primaries and suggested that Mr. Carter actually served as a model for future Democratic candidates.
"On social issues, Jimmy Carter was as liberal and demonstrated more compassion in civil rights and human rights as any President," Mr. Lipshutz said. "His difference with the traditional Kennedy wing of the Democratic Party was that he tried to be fiscally responsible. Hopefully, this combination will be the guideline for the Democratic Party of the future."

HEADLINE: In Louisiana, a Critical Wetland Habitat Founders

BYLINE: By CORY DEAN

DATELINE: COCODRIE, La.

 BODY:
SHEA PENLAND, associate director of the Louisiana Geological Survey, eased a 22-foot skiff out of its slip in this small settlement deep in the bayous of Terrebonne Parish. He nudged the throttle forward and the boat picked up speed, clearing the harbor and skimming over the light chop of Terrebonne Bay toward the barrier islands that protect the estuary and its fragile marsh from the Gulf of Mexico.
From the boat, the marsh seemed vibrant, a sea of green and golden grass punctuated by occasional clumps of bushes and trees. Fish and even an occasional porpoise jumped in the water, egrets and herons fished at the its edge and flights of pelicans soared overhead. 
 But this is not a healthy marsh. Salt-tolerant grasses have moved in where freshwater plants once grew. The small clusters of trees and shrubs mark a landscape in decline. "An unhealthy marsh gets real clumpy and fragmented," Dr. Penland said. "It's dying."
In about 15 minutes, the edge of the marsh had receded into the distance. "You look out there and see open water," observed another passenger, Robert S. Jones, the parish engineer. "If you look on a state map, it shows as solid marsh."
But the state's mapmakers are not keeping up with the marsh. For reasons still imperfectly understood, the wetlands here are disappearing; each year, up to 40 square miles of Louisiana quietly sink underwater. If wetland loss continued at its present rate, Dr. Penland said, Terrebonne Parish would be gone in 100 years.
More than the landscape is at stake. Louisiana has more than 41 percent of the coastal wetlands in the United States. It supports the nation's largest fin- and shell-fishery, by weight producing 30 percent of the country's commercial harvest each year. Almost every fish caught in the Gulf of Mexico spends part of its life in the Louisiana marsh. The wetlands are the wintering ground or vital refueling stop for most of the migratory waterfowl that travel the Mississippi flyway, as well as being vital in the production and transportation of much of the nation's oil and natural gas.
Fueled by industry grants, Federal appropriations and a new state trust fund financed by oil and gas royalties, scientists and engineers are struggling to save this critical resource, But they are only beginning to understand the host of influences that are combining to destroy it. Remedies like dikes, dams and even old Christmas trees are still under study.
The new research effort marks a profound change from the 1970's, when wetland loss and oil and gas development hit their peaks and the industry was accused of literally destroying the state. Today, while industry leaders acknowledge a share of the blame, there is wide agreement that the problem would continue even if the industry pulled out its rigs, filled its canals and left the state without a trace. In fact, the industry has a strong incentive to protect the marshes. Much of its equipment could not survive in open water and, under some conditions when wetlands give way to open water, "those water bottoms become the property of the state," Dr. Penland said. "If you're a private landowner you face the possibility of losing your mineral rights."
But there is plenty of disagreement as geologists, ecologists and engineers argue over how to solve the problem and whether it can be solved at all.
 
The Problem
 
Land Sinks, Waters Rise
A principal cause of wetland loss in Louisiana is subsidence. The land is made of sediment laid down over centuries by the ever-shifting Mississippi River. So much has accumulated that its weight is actually warping the earth's crust. The thicker and fresher the sediment is, the more it subsides. In parts of Terrebonne Parish, the land is sinking more than 1 inch a year.
In the past, the river would have made up the subsidence by adding new sediment in its spring floods. But by the 1950's, the dams built on its tributaries had sharply reduced its load of sediment. And the river itself has been walled off from the marshes by miles of levees constructed at huge expense to protect the land from the very floods that nourished it.
Besides subsidence, other forces are helping undermine the fragile wetlands:
*The sea level is rising.
*Hurricanes, tropical storms and even passing cold fronts erode the delicate barrier islands that buffer the marsh.
*Access canals dredged by oil and gas companies disrupt the natural flow of surface and underground water. As they erode, they enlarge the area of open water.
*Removal of oil and gas accelerates subsidence, and the brine brought up with them and dumped nearby kills marsh plants.
*Nutrias, rodents introduced to control the water hyacinths clogging navigation canals, devour the roots of marsh plants.
The exact role of all these and other factors in wetland loss is now becoming a matter of intense study.
"The only thing that's been done on wetland loss is we've measured how much has been lost," said Harry H. Roberts, a marine geologist who directs the Coastal Studies Institute at Louisiana State University. "People in Louisiana have this mind-set that everything has been studied and now we need action. But all that's been done is document how fast we're losing the land."
This month, experts from the United States Geological Survey and the Argonne National Laboratory will begin a five-year effort to classify and map sources of wetland loss. In August, the Army Corps of Engineers and the Louisiana Department of Natural Resources began a three-year study to evaluate possible ways of preventing or restoring marsh loss.
"There are an awful lot of good ideas out there," said Col. Richard V. Gorski, who heads the New Orleans District for the engineers. "We're going to tie them together, establish some priorities and recommend construction."
 
The Sea
 
Some Try to Halt Flow of Salt Water
One method of saving wetland, on which many landowners are pinning their hopes, is marsh management. Landowners have built weirs, levees and other structures that limit saltwater intrusion and scouring by tides. For example the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, an oil and gas concern, has built more than 400 weirs and other structures on its 600,000 acres. These "slow the exchange of salt water back into the fresh water," said H. Leighton Steward, the company's chairman. While they allow fish in and out, he said, they "prevent salt water in an extremely high tide from getting in there and killing the plants.
"We can look at our property where we've had water control structures in place for 30 years and look at adjacent property owners' property and see the difference," he said.
But others question the value of marsh management.
"We can show you examples where they've been effective and where they haven't been effective," Colonel Gorski said. "It's very dependent on the local circumstances, the people involved."
And few of these projects have been were systematically monitored, said Donald R. Cahoon, a plant ecologist at Louisiana State University and chief of the environmental resources section of the Louisiana Geological Survey. "The vast majority of policies on marsh management in Louisiana have been set on a very limited data base and in some cases no data at all," he said.
Dr. Cahoon and other researchers have just finished what he said was the first study to compare managed marsh areas with unmanaged controls. After surveying 16 managed areas, they concluded that marsh management was not consistently effective in preventing wetland loss. Half of the managed areas were no better off than the unmanaged controls and only 5 of the 16 showed improvement. The unmanaged areas even gained more sediment.
The United States Fish and Wildlife Service is about to begin a four-year study in which researchers will create four marsh management sites of 75 to 400 acres and compare them to unmanaged sites. Investigators will monitor sediment flow, plant growth and the amount of material plants add to the marsh.
"We're trying to take an objective stance on marsh management," said A. Lee Foote, a research ecologist for the agency. "I have some genuine, heartfelt doubts about whether this kind of marsh management works."
Dr. Cahoon says: "Marsh management is a question of trade-offs. You might have to trade off sediment, you might have to trade off some species of fish. You have to be careful what you're trading off for what."
 
The River
 
Using Fresh Water To Aid Marshes
A different approach to marsh management relies on putting the river back into the marshland rather than keeping the ocean out. The idea is to use a flood of fresh water to push back salt water and prevent it from poisoning the plants whose roots hold the marsh together.
Enormous diversion structures would carry Mississippi River water through canals or spillways to the marsh behind the levees. The Corps of Engineers is designing a $76 million diversion project at the Bonnet Carre, a $41 million project at Davis Pond, both upriver from New Orleans, and a $26 million structure downriver at Caernarvon.
In effect, these diversions will operate as giant gates, maintaining the integrity of the levee in floods, but allowing water through at most other times.
The Caernarvon diversion system, expected to be ready in January, will go into action whenever gauges indicate too much salt water in the marsh behind it.
But experts disagree about whether restoring fresh water to the marsh will create new wetlands.
Some say marshes are built primarily of heavy bedload sediment that moves along the river bottom, not the finer sediment suspended in the water. Getting bedload sediment up on land would probably require very deep cuts in the levees, elaborate pumps and, as one engineer put it, "a vast amount of money."
But others, like Dr. Roberts, say that is not necessarily the case. "Bedload is mostly quartz, which has little nutritional value" for a marsh, he said. "Most of the marsh plants are seeded on fine grain sediment which include quartz and clays."
 
The Islands
 
Restoring Barriers As a Defense Line
A third approach to reducing wetland loss is one that many experts think the state and the Corps of Engineers are neglecting: strengthening the barrier islands at the edge of the Gulf.
Like everything else in southern Louisiana, the protective barrier islands are sinking. Dr. Penland estimates that some will survive only another decade. When they go, the winds and waves of Gulf storms will accelerate the destruction of the state's marshes.
Ignoring these islands is particularly short-sighted, in his view, because they can be strengthened quite cheaply.
That is what Mr. Jones, the Terrebonne Parish engineer did on eastern Isle Dernieres, one of a line of islands whose few hundred yards of dunes is all that protects parish marshes from the full brunt of the Gulf's waters. The island was cut when a hurricane struck in 1974 and though the breach healed, parish officials feared their bulwark would fail again. When officials at the state capital did not act, Mr. Jones said, the parish decided to attack the problem itself.
The result is a project that Dr. Penland says could serve as a model for low-cost barrier island restoration.
In effect, Mr. Jones raised the island. Lacking high quality sand, he used material from the island itself to build dikes along the island's front and back. Then he filled the middle with inferior material dredged from a channel in back of the island. Finally, teen-agers employed in a summer job program planted beach grass on the new dune.
"We drug a stick to make a hole, used another stick with a Coke bottle with a hole in it to spread the seeds and then a third guy came along shuffling his feet to cover them up," Mr. Jones recalled.
The ultimate in low-tech, the 3,200-foot project was completed for less than $1 million and has survived five years of Gulf weather. "I'd call it a success," Mr. Jones said.
For Mr. Jones and others, the state's coastal wetland conservation and restoration plan is a source of continuing irritation in that it does not concern itself with barrier islands unless they actually have marsh on them.
But other experts say marsh management and diversion projects have bigger potential payoffs and funds must be concentrated on them.
"By preserving barrier islands the greatest impact you'll have is maybe 10 percent," said David M. Soileau, who heads the state's Wetland Conservation and Restoration Task Force. "Salt water intrusion and subsidence are still real major problems, even if you were able to replace the barrier islands."
Federal guidelines require all Corps of Engineers projects to show direct economic benefit. When it comes to uninhabited islands, Colonel Gorski said, "we don't have a mechanism to accurately calculate those benefits. Intuitively we know that barrier islands are good and they help protect the interior from storm surges and erosion, but we haven't determined a dollar mechanism."
While state and Federal authorities continue their studies, individuals and communities press ahead with their own small-scale attempts to save their marshes. Some set fire to the marshland's cypress trees and live oaks, a custom dating from the earliest European settlement. In theory, burning old vegetation helps newer, more vigorous plants to thrive. Others, encouraged by the Coalition to Restore Coastal Louisiana, plan to donate their used Christmas trees to trap sediment. G. Paul Kemp, the coalition's executive director, says "This year we have a goal to get a quarter of a million Christmas trees."
But some scientists dismiss the idea as a gimmick, since the trees cannot trap sediment if there is no sediment to be trapped.
In coastal parishes, where roadways are often built on land so low and narrow that people pull over and fish the bayous from their pickup trucks, officials are considering mounting their own elaborate defenses, like surrounding their towns with levees.
"The only way we're going to be able to survive down here is with levees," said Mr. Jones, the Terrebonne Parish engineer. "Eventually we'll all be living in a bowl."
 
The Outlook
 
Basic Questions And Some Hopes
While engineers and public officials debate the merits of this range of mitigation efforts, scientists are continuing their basic research into the geology and ecology of the delta.
"This is a very complicated set of processes," said Dr. Roberts, the L.S.U. marine geologist. "If someone asked me to map subsidence in the coastal plain I could not do it. And in order to control subsidence I have to know what I am up against."
Mr. Soileau of the state's wetlands restoration force said he was optimistic that research and mitigation efforts could eventually create ways to replace or restore marshland as quickly as it is lost. "I predict perhaps even in 20 years we will have reached a static relationship between wetlands lost and wetland gain in Louisiana," he said.
But for most other scientists and engineers, this "no net loss" is an impossible dream. The most they hope is to slow the rate at which their state is disappearing.
"If you look at the numbers -- sediment in the river and the techniques and cost of getting that sediment out -- the achievement of no net loss is not attainable," Dr. Penland said. "The river of today is not the river of yesterday that built the delta."

HEADLINE: K Mart Profit Up Slightly

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., Nov. 19

 BODY:
The K Mart Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailiers, reported today that its third-quarter profits increased only slightly from a year ago, mainly because of new units and some weakness in the retail economy.
The company, based in Troy, Mich., said it had net earnings of $105.9 million, or 53 cents a share, compared with $104.1 million, or 52 cents, a year ago. Its revenues rose 11.7 percent, to $7.6 billion, from $6.8 billion in the corresponding period a year ago.
K Mart said the results reflected its acquisition of two retail chains: PACE Membership Warehouse and the Sports Authority.
K Mart said sales of basic merchandise were good, offsetting weak sales in electronics and other big-ticket categories. But unseasonably warm weather hurt the company's clothing sales in September and October.
The company's chairman, Joseph Antonini, said K Mart's inventories were declining and the company was positioned better to handle projected sales.
K Mart's shares were unchanged today at $27.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Ontario's New Premier a Surprise to Business

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The gibes about the People's Republic of Ontario, which greeted the surprise election of a left-wing government in Canada's richest and most populous province in September, are heard less often these days around Toronto's financial district.
Far from being the socialist bogeyman feared by business, the New Democratic Party administration headed by Premier Bob Rae has so far concentrated on forging a three-legged partnership among itself, the party's trade-union and social constituencies, and the province's business leaders. 
 The new government has surprisedfriends and foes alike with the comforting signals it has sent to business. Mr. Rae traveled to New York last month to reassure American bankers and investors. He also met with members of the Business Council on National Issues, a group of chief executives of 150 leading Canadian corporations.
The new Premier has not repeated his campaign threats to ignore the Canadian-American free trade agreement, putting the emphasis instead on the province's readiness to help companies and workers who suffer as a result of stiffer competition from United States imports.
Despite the New Democratic Party'spolicy of public ownership of utilities, the government has also given the green light for British Gas's proposed $1.1 billion takeover of Consumers' Gas Company, Canada's biggest natural gas distributor. Explaining why the government itself had not taken over Consumers, Mr. Rae said that "frankly, we felt the cost was simply too high. We don't have the money to use in that way."
"I think Rae has done pretty well considering the constituency that elected him," said Hal Jackman, controlling shareholder of a Toronto-based financial services group, someone who normally supports the ProgressiveConservative Party. The Conservatives, despite their control of the national Government in Ottawa, only managed to finish third in the Sept. 6 Ontario province election.
In that election, the New Democrats scored one of the most stunning upsets in Canadian political history by winning 74 of 130 seats in the province's legislature, ousting the five-year-old Liberal Party government of David Peterson. Only 14 of the party's members have previous experience in the legislature.
The business lobby may be less than happy after the Throne Speech on Tuesday, when the government is traditionally given the opportunity to spell out its policies.
The speech is widely expected to focus on the interventionist, social democratic platform on which the NewDemocrats ran in the September election. Susan Murray, a Toronto political consultant, predicts that it will include an environmental bill of rights, extra protection for workers facing layoffs, plans for a public auto insurance plan and tougher employment-equity rules.
Nonetheless, Ms. Murray is advising her clients, who include several large multinational corporations, to "stay calm, to stay at the table and not to go public with their complaints." In a recent memo, she told them that "the Rae government will move cautiously and make pragmatic decisions which account for economic realities and which do not necessarily reflect traditional N.D.P. policy positions."
 However, some of the party's usual supporters are starting to get impatient. Michael Shapcott, a Toronto antipoverty campaigner, says that "Bob Rae wasn't elected to maintain the status quo."
"He hasn't clearly stood up and said, 'These are our issues and this is what we stand for.' "

HEADLINE: Bank Credit Tighter, Survey by Fed Finds

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
A survey of banks has found increased credit restraint, with a large majority tightening standards for commercial real estate loans, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
"As in past surveys, the pullback was least evident in consumer and home mortgage lending and was clearest in commercial real estate lending, a category for which a large majority of respondents continued to raise their credit standards," the central bank said. 
 The Fed survey of senior loan officers at 60 large banks in October occurred as Bush Administration officials expressed growing concern that a shortage of credit was deepening the economic downturn.
 
 Overreaction Seen
 Financial institutions and some borrowers have been complaining for months that regulators have overreacted to the savings and loan crisis by discouraging all loans, even sound ones. The regulators, however, say they are only urging prudence in response to the weaker economy.
Compared with a similar Fed poll three months earlier, the latest report said there was "increased credit restraint, with agencies and branches of foreign banks reporting more tightening than domestic banks."
Nearly two-thirds of the respondents reported tightening lending standards for commercial real estate loans, while almost half of the respondents had tightened lending standards for non-real estate commercial and industrial loans to large corporations.
They most often cited "a deterioration in the economic outlook" and "problems specific to individual industries" for the greater restraint, the Fed said. About a fifth of the banks surveyed said their capital position restricted new lending, while two-thirds said it had no effect.
 
 Tighter Standards in Northeast
 "Home mortgage lending remained relatively favored," the Fed said. But it noted that more banks, particularly in the Northeast, were reporting tighter standards even in that area.
About one in four of the banks said they were either requiring a higher down payment on home mortgages or had raised the household income needed to qualify for a loan.
"In sum, the results of this lending practices survey suggest that a deterioration in the general economic outlook since summer has prompted a sizable share of domestic respondents to tighten credit standards more," the central bank said.
In addition to scrutinizing borrowers more closely, about half the banks said they had raised their loan fees and charged a bigger spread over base interest rates. Between a third and a half are requiring better collateral.

HEADLINE: New Rift in U.S.-Japan Jet Project

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 19

 BODY:
A year after plans to co-develop an advanced fighter aircraft led to the most bruising confrontation between Japan and the United States in years, the military project has caused new discord. Both countries now blame the other for delays, huge cost overruns and technical problems that are engulfing the effort.
The joint project, called the FS-X, touched off a prolonged battle in Congress last year over charges that Japan would use American-developed military technology as a springboard for building a commercial aircraft industry to compete with the American industry. In the months of wrangling, a wide gulf of mistrust between the two countries developed. 
 But after renegotiations, President Bush and the Japanese Government agreed that Japan would develop its own flight-control software for the FS-X, thereby keeping some key American technologies out of Japanese hands. While that enabled the biggest joint military project ever undertaken by the two countries to move ahead, participants now say that the ill will, technological compromises and conflicts left unresolved in last year's debate have begun to take a toll.
In the last two weeks, the Japanese Government has conceded that the cost of developing the plane has nearly doubled. Critics, both Japanese and American, contend that the FS-X will be so expensive and late that it will be nearly obsolete by the time the first plane takes off.
Japanese officials say they do not expect the project to be killed, in part because it would involve an enormous loss of face for both Governments. But the problems surrounding the FS-X have clearly strained a relationship already burdened by a longstanding trade dispute and Japan's decision earlier this month not to send military forces to the Persian Gulf.
Among the critics of the joint project at present is Seiki Nishihiro, who, until his retirement last summer, served as Japan's Vice Minister of Defense. He also led the effort to develop the plane and negotiated the agreements with the United States.
"The FS-X project itself has completely lost its effectiveness," Mr. Nishihiro, who is still an adviser to the Self-Defense Agency, said in an interview this week. "If things are left on the course they are on now, there is the possibility that the project will evaporate into thin air."
American officials are less pessimistic, but express doubts about whether Japan's Parliament will allocate more money for the project. Many in Parliament are already eager to cut the country's military budget as the Soviet threat declines and are angry over the Self-Defense Agency's advocacy of a strong Japanese military presence in the gulf.
"Both Governments have so much invested in it, it has to work," said one American official here involved in the negotiations. "But we are discovering that last year's arguments are not over by any means."
 
 Roots in the 1980's
 Japan and the United States began fighting over the FS-X in the mid-1980's, when the Japanese military decided to build the plane alone, largely to free itself from dependence on American weapons designs. The Reagan Administration objected, and under great pressure the Prime Minister at the time, Yasuhiro Nakasone, agreed to a "co-development" plan under which the aircraft's design would be based on the F-16 fighter built by the General Dynamics Corporation. Under the plan eventually announced, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries would work with technology from General Dynamics and build the planes in Japan.
But when the agreement was about to be signed last year, Congress objected, saying that the project would give away critical technology that Japan would use for building commercial aircraft, one of the few industries in which the United States remains far ahead of the Japanese.
In many ways, the fight over the FS-X became a microcosm of the growing rifts between Japan and the United States, particularly the sense of distrust that increasingly permeates questions of national security and trade. In last year's confrontation over whether to transfer jet fighter technology, Congress said that concerns about declining American economic competitiveness should take precedence over nurturing the post-World War II military alliance with Japan. That attitude appears to be hardening because of Japan's reluctance to provide personnel in the military buildup against Saddam Hussein.
 
 Question of Cost
 Now, many in the Japanese Government are saying that the United States and General Dynamics are responsible for the troubles facing the FS-X. The original price tag for developing the plane, about $1.25 billion, is likely to rise to $2.4 billion or more. Actually building the planned 130 to 170 planes by 1997 was estimated three years ago at an additional $6 billion or more; no one will now say what the total figure really is.
Mr. Nishihiro blames General Dynamics for the increases, saying it "has doubled its original quote."
But Dr. Vernon A. Lee, the military contractor's vice president for Japan, said that it had "supplied information to the Japanese defense agency in good faith" several years ago, in response to a questionnaire.
"The next step, converting that into a budget, we weren't involved in," he said. "And there have been many changes in the program since then that we don't have any control over."
 
 Months of Bickering
 Further delays and increased costs resulted from months of bickering between General Dynamics and Mitsubishi Heavy about how to interpret the vaguely worded agreement between the Governments.
And the Japanese still resent Congressional insistence that Japan write all of the flight-control software for the airplane itself, adding considerably to Japan's costs. American experts feared that the General Dynamics software could be used to help Mitsubishi build commercial jets.
"Originally, the idea was that we could receive new F-16 technology," Mr. Nishihiro said. "That is not coming in. So the original objective of pooling technology from both sides has been lost." Mr. Nishihiro said that last year, when the American objections to the plane arose, he recommended to Noboru Takeshita, who was then Prime Minister, that "we should scuttle the whole thing," rather than further undermine relations with the United States. But Mr. Takeshita determined that it was important that the project go ahead on American terms.
 
 Twice the Cost
 Now some Japanese are saying that the plane looks increasingly like a waste of money. It will cost at least $64 million for each FS-X aircraft, more than twice what it would cost to buy the F-16 directly. Moreover, the threat the fighter plane was intended to counter, from the Soviet Union's bases to the north and west of Japan, now seems vastly reduced, and there is growing public pressure to trim Japan's military expenditures.
But Mr. Nishihiro doubts the program will be canceled, because it has become a symbol of the American alliance in a country where symbolism is everything.
"There is a kind of inertia in the Japanese executive branch," he said, "a feeling that if they decided to scrap the program, it would indicate their post-judgment was wrong."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Bush Vetos Sanctions On Chemical Weapons

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
President Bush has employed a pocket veto to kill legislation that would have imposed mandatory penalties on nations and companies that promoted the spread of chemical or biological and weapons to developing nations like Iraq.
The legislation was passed by Congress on Oct 26. In a statement released by the White House, Mr. Bush said he would not it because it would have allowed him too little discretion in punishing those who sold or transferred the equipment and technology for such arms.
"The mandatory imposition of unilateral sanctions as provided in this bill would harm U.S. economic interests and provoke friendly countries who are essential to our efforts to resist Iraqi aggression," Mr. Bush's statement, released late Friday, said.
State Department officials argued that the bill's requirement of mandatory sanctions would have infringed on the President's Constitutional authority to conduct foreign affairs.
Since Congress is not in session, President Bush's refusal to sign the measure constitutes a pocket veto. The bill would have required the President to cut off American trade for one year with any company that assisted efforts to acquire, produce or use chemical or biological weapons.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall in Light Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates rose in light trading yesterday, as dealers used news of an Iraqi troop buildup in Kuwait as an excuse to take profits.
News from Baghdad that President Saddam Hussein intended to add 250,000 more troops stirred war fears in the market. The reports also sent oil prices higher, another negative for the fixed-income market. 
 "For the time being all of the good news is out," one trader in government bonds said. "The Fed has eased, and there are no economic reports for a while. To me that's a formula that says the market stays kind of soft through this week. But it's a thin, holiday market, and you can't put too much emphasis on what's going on."
 
 Mid-December Action
 On Friday, for the second time in less than a month, the Federal Reserve signaled the credit markets that it had lowered its target rate for the overnight Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 7 1/2 percent. Analysts said another easing move will almost certainly not be considered by the central bank until mid-December at the earliest.
In deference to Thanksgiving, the Public Securities Association, an international industry group of banks and brokerage firms, said yesterday that it recommended that trading in Treasury securities stop at 2 P.M. tomorrow and Friday.
"As the week progresses, more and more people will be out on vacation," said Stephen W. Gallagher, a money market economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company. "The fact that we will have these early market closes, a full day off and no new data gives us very little incentive to trade."
 
 Back Above 8.50 Percent
 The bulk of the selloff occurred early in the session. It was sufficiently large to push long-term interest rates back above 8.50 percent, a level that had been pierced late last week.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds were offered at a price of 102 18/32, down 23/32 late yesterday, to yield 8.51 percent. Late Friday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.44 percent.
Among the note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 2/32, down 11/32, to yield 8.34 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, down 3/ 32, to yield 7.60 percent.
Rates on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills rose slightly at the weekly auction yesterday. Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.08 percent, up from 7.05 percent a week ago.
Bids on six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.05 percent, compared with 7.02 percent a week ago.
 
 New York City Notes Sold
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, a sale of $1.3 billion worth of short-term revenue anticipation notes for New York City went fairly well, according to investment bankers involved in the transaction.
The notes, which mature on June 28, 1991, were sold at a price to yield 6.50 percent. The rate was about 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above the yield on the last revenue anticipation note sale in May.
As of late yesterday, between $400 million and $450 million of the notes remained in the hands of the underwriters, the investment bankers said.
"This was a solid transaction. It was not a blowout," said one banker, who asked not to be identified.
Lehman Brothers acted as lead manager for the negotiated sale. The securities are rated MIG-2 by Moody's Investors Service and SP-1 by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
 Offerings by Utilities
 The recent drop in interest rates brought in additional borrowers to the investment-grade corporate bond market yesterday. Among the new issuers were two utility companies, including the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation. The company offered $100 million of 9 7/8 percent first mortgage bonds through an undewriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.
The securities, which mature Nov. 1, 2020, were priced at 98.80 to yield 10 percent, 1.50 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing. The securities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB-plus by S.&P.
The Carolina Power and Light Company offered $100 million of three-year notes at competitive bidding. A group led by Morgan Stanley & Company won the issue, which was reoffered to investors with an 8 1/8 percent coupon at an initial price of 99.625 to yield 8.268 percent, 55 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 3/4 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said that prices of most issues dipped by about an eighth of a point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities said that prices of most widely quoted issues slid by about half a point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off but Starts Rising After News of Move by Iraq

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar traded mostly lower yesterday, but it was lifted above its lows for the day by news that Iraq was moving more troops to Kuwait, traders said.
The dollar was mixed against major currencies in European trading. Traders said it was hurt by the Federal Reserve's decision Friday to ease interest rates, which tends to make dollar-denominated investments less appealing than other investments and hence reduces the appeal of the dollar itself. 
 That downward pressure on the dollar continued when domestic markets opened, said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange at Paine Webber Inc.
"And then we had the news that Iraq was sending some more troops on the border with Kuwait," Mr. Troni said. "The dollar strengthened a bit."
 
 Economic News Not a Factor
 He said there was no economic news of substance Monday "and so the political news was what moved the market."
The dollar traditionally is viewed as a safe-haven investment in times of international turmoil.
The dollar lost ground against the British pound and the Japanese yen but strengthened somewhat against the German mark.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 128.95 yen, down 0.78 yen from Friday's finish of 129.73 yen. Later, in London the dollar was quoted at 128.20 yen. In New York it was quoted at 128.75 yen, down from 129.50 late Friday.

The dollar bought 1.4745 German marks in European trading, up from 1.4715 Friday. In New York, the dollar traded at 1.4717 marks, up from 1.4705 late Friday. Friday's figure was a low for the dollar against the mark.

HEADLINE: New York City Agencies Told to Find Added Cuts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Preparing for the worst in the face of state budget cuts, the Dinkins administration yesterday told most New York City agencies to outline how they would cut up to 17.5 percent of their budgets for next year, and to consider eliminating some staff jobs and the purchase of nonvital supplies.
The city had already ordered most agencies to prepare cuts of 10 percent for the fiscal year that starts July 1, and contingency cuts of another 2.5 percent in case economic conditions worsened. Yesterday's announcement kept the 10 percent cut, but increased the contingency cut to 7.5 percent. Cityofficials said they hoped that not all the cuts would be needed. 
 In a directive to agency heads, Budget Director Philip R. Michael told them to review their contracting procedures to save money, for example, by cutting janitorial service to two days a week from four.
He also urged them to seek private money for city programs and to consider a freeze on the purchase of all administrative supplies, including cars and trucks.
Agencies must review whether some functions can be eliminated or consolidated with those of other agencies, he said. "I am fully cognizant of the extreme nature of the cuts most agencies are being asked to take or prepare for," Mr. Michael wrote. "Never before have potential cuts of 17.5 percent been taken in one year. To accomplish this feat, now more than ever before it is necessary to examine closely your agency's mission and close down programs and offices which are less essential than others."
The agencies' recommendations are due on Dec. 3.
Not all agencies would be forced to outline such large cuts. The Board of Education, the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the City University andthe Fire Department must propose cuts of 5 percent and contingencies of 3.75 percent. The police must outline savings of 1 percent through internal efficiency, while jails, probation, District Attorneys and juvenile justice are to outline savings of 5 percent. No criminal-justice agency would have to recommend contingency cuts.
 
 Possible Unpaid Furloughs
 City agencies have just finished cutting 4 percent of their current budgets to help close a gap of almost $400 million this year. Next year's gap is projected to be about four times as large.
Parks Commissioner Elisabeth F. Gotbaum said she hoped she could make many of the new cuts by having seasonal workers take unpaid furloughs of a few days each. But if she were forced to lay off workers, shesaid, field maintenance would be severely affected.
The 4 percent cuts already made would translate to $349 million in savings next year. To meet the other 6 percent cuts to fulfill a 10 percent target, another $410 million would be needed. The 7.5 percent contingency plan would require still another $538 million, for a cumulative total of $1.3 billion.
But some fiscal experts have said the city could not sustain cuts of such magnitude and provide acceptable service. Mr. Michael's memo did not address what new taxes might also be sought.
Mr. Michael stressed that it was not clear exactly how next year's budget problem might worsen, but said that the city needed to update its planning, given the prospect of further deterioration in the local economy and deeper cuts in the state budget. On Saturday,Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said state aid to the city would be cut by at least $100 million in the state's current fiscal year, which ends in March.
Leland T. Jones, a spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, said the Mayor had discussed the proposed contingencies with Mr. Michael and agreed to seek them before he left on Sunday for a weeklong vacation in Hilton Head, S.C.
Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said the administration was "looking at the proper magnitude of cuts" to deal with the problem. She added, "We're especially pleased that he's looking at consolidating and eliminating functions, because that will be the thrust of the Council's approach."

HEADLINE: New England Bank Reports

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Despite efforts to recapitalize $706 million in outstanding debt, the Bank of New England Corporation may still need regulatory aid or face possible insolvency, the Boston-based company said in Government documents released today.
"There can be no assurance that the recapitalization, if consummated, will necessarily be successful in restoring capital, liquidity and operating results to acceptable levels," the company said in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Even if the recapitalization is completed, Bank of New England will probably require additional funds to reach and maintain capital levels mandated by regulators or face the possibility of insolvency, the document said.
The bank's viability depends on its significantly reducing nonperforming assets and operating costs, but the continued deterioration in the New England economy and real estate market could adversely affect recovery efforts, the S.E.C. filing said.
The bank is engaged in talks with bondholders to renegotiate its $706 million corporate debt burden.
Other New England banks also said today in S.E.C. filings that the region's real estate woes would continue to take a toll.
"The widespread economic downturn continues to affect Northeast real estate markets adversely," said the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, the banking company based in Providence, R.I., considered by most analysts to be the strongest bank in New England.
The Bank of Boston Corporation also said its real-estate loan portfolio might deteriorate further, leading to increased nonperforming assets and to more credit losses.

HEADLINE: New York City Sells Notes but Pays Higher Interest

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
New York City, entering the credit markets for the first time since the emergence of significant budget problems last month, sold $1.3 billion in short-term notes yesterday, amid a strong demand from investors, city officials said.
But to attract the investors, the city was forced to pay millions of dollars in higher interest costs on the notes because of the city's fiscal troubles. 
 "We feel relatively pleased; it wasn't as bad as some predicted," City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said.
The sale of short-term notes was an important prelude to a more significant sale of more than $1 billion in long-term general obligation bonds in early December.
 
Higher Interest Cost
 The interest cost to the city on the notes was 6.85 percent. That cost is more than four-tenths of a percentage point higher than what the city paid in May, the last time it sold revenue notes. And this may understate the difference, because interest rates have fallen since then. For example, the yield on three-month treasury bills fell more than sixth-tenths of a percentage point.
For each extra tenth of a percentage point, the city pays $762,000 in interest. The notes were rated the same as the last revenue notes the city sold, MIG-2 by Moody's and SP-1 by Standard & Poor's, both a notch below the highest rating.
Stan Ciemniecki, an executive vice president at Lehman Brothers, the leading underwriter in the note sale, said the sale was a "very good deal," after taking into account that in the last few months both city bonds and notes had "deteriorated on a relative basis."
He said that underwriters received more than $1.9 billion in orders for the $1.3 billion in notes, and that at least 60 percent of the notes were bought by institutional investors.
 
Seeking Investor Confidence
 Yesterday's note sale was part of a campaign by city officials to shore up the confidence of investors since the announcements of expected budget deficits were followed by a drop in city bond prices and a rise in the return paid to investors.
Since then, the city has called for cuts to close a $388 million gap in this year's budget, as well as to begin addressing a gap of more than $1.6 billion next year.
After the fiscal problems surfaced, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Ms. Holtzman postponed the bond sale from November to December to give the city more time to develop and explain its plans to control its finances.
To avoid further uncertainty, the city canceled plans to hold an auction for the notes, and instead conducted a negotiated sale, in which the city underwriters take orders from customers and then negotiate a rate with the city based upon the demand.
Mr. Dinkins and Ms. Holtzman spoke at a meeting of investors last week, and their aides also held nine private meetings with large institutional investors to explain the city's new financial plan and reassure them that the notes were safe.
At a meeting of the city's underwriters last week, underwriters were told that the goal of the sale was "smoothness" to avoid even the hint of problems that could hurt the bond sale.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EUROPE: THE NEW EUROPE;
What Is the Need for NATO Now? Where Do East Bloc Nations Fit In?

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The signing of an East-West treaty today eliminating the Soviet Union's once-intimidating superiority in nonnuclear weapons in Europe may well be one of the final political acts of the Warsaw Pact. As a military alliance, it is already dead.
 "As a threat, you can forget it," NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, said a few days ago. "As a military structure, it has ceased to exist. There's nothing, or practically nothing, left of it." 
 But while the demise of Communism in Eastern Europe is being hailed at a summit conference here, the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact has raised unexpected questions: Without a clear enemy, what is the need for NATO? And without the Warsaw Pact, where do Moscow and others find a place in the new Europe?
In the view of many Europeans, these were questions to be tackled at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe this week, but the new structures being built here are more modest, leaving uncertainty about the future of both NATO and the former Soviet bloc.
 
All Influence Lost
 In recent months, events have seemingly moved too fast for such long-term planning. NATO experts say the Soviet Union has not only lost all influence over the armies of its Warsaw Pact partners, but is also facing increasing problems of discipline and morale, including mounting desertions, in its own armed forces.
With Moscow now committed to withdrawing all its troops from Eastern Europe, its former Soviet bloc partners have even stopped refering to the Warsaw Pact by name, describing it as the Group of Six and insisting that it retains none of the characteristics of a military alliance.
NATO has in turn lowered its guard. The United States is currently shipping half its Europe-based troops to the Persian Gulf. Britain recently announced that it would close two of its four air bases in Germany. All 55,000 French troops in Germany will soon come home. And Germany is reducing its own armed forces.
Yet the political message emanating from Washington, London and NATO headquarters in Brussels is that, more than ever, the Atlantic alliance is necessary to guarantee security in Europe. And it has both refused to find a place for the former Warsaw Pact and resisted competition from other emerging European institutions.
Specifically, while Moscow, Prague and other governments had hoped the summit conference this week would give birth to a new all-European security structure that left behind the era of the two military pacts, the United States blocked moves in that direction for fear of undermining NATO.
Further, as the 12-nation European Community begins debating the assumption of a security role of its own, perhaps by absorbing the Western European Union, a long-moribund regional defense body, the United States and Britain have insisted that this should take place only within the NATO framework.
"Any change must take place in such a way that it does not erode two essentials, NATO's integrated military structure and its political role," Mr. Worner said.
At its summit meeting in London in July, NATO recognized the new Europe by calling for a strategy that would move away from "forward defense" to a posture of "flexible response," with less reliance on nuclear weapons. But it continued to assume a Soviet threat and consider Moscow its adversary.
 
A Nonaggression Pledge
 Today, however, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact signed a mutual nonaggression pledge in which they proclaimed that they were no longer adversaries, raising additional questions about the role that an exclusive 16-nation alliance should play in a Europe that is not divided.
The gulf crisis has further complicated the search by NATO for a new identity because, under its charter, it has been unable to act militarily "out of area" beyond Europe and North America. And in the first crisis of the post-cold-war era, it has served simply as a consulting forum.
But in the debate about Europe's "new architecture," the focus is increasingly on political structures that can preserve stability. And with the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe at best the embryo of a pan-European organization, the fear is that the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe may feel excluded.
The European Community has indicated that it will accept no new members until the mid-1990's, while NATO itself has discouraged applications from Eastern Europe's new democracies. "If we accepted, say, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, Moscow could be pardoned for feeling paranoid," a senior Western official remarked.
NATO's Secretary General was even more specific, saying "we don't want to create additional problems" for the Soviet Union and its President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. "What we all want now," Mr. Worner said, "is to establish a basis on which to stabilize Europe without changing the military and strategic equilibrium."
Yet with the Warsaw Pact expected to survive just a few months longer, Western officials recognize the difficulties of maintaining an equilibrium with only one military alliance. And increasingly in European capitals, the view is that NATO should become little more than an insurance policy.
NATO planners in Brussels still argue that the alliance should broaden its scope to deal with political, economic and even environmental security matters as well as military questions. But many governments are already counting the money they can save at NATO. As one American official put it, "NATO's strategy will eventually be determined by its resources."

HEADLINE: Vote Dispute Sours Party's Victory in Mexico

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAUCALPAN, Mexico, Nov. 19

 BODY:
By renewing doubts about the fairness of Mexico's political system, the lopsided victory of the governing party in elections here appears to have turned into a public relations defeat for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, diplomats and political analysts say.
With the official vote count completed late Sunday night, Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party was declared the winner by a landslide in the elections held here on Nov. 11 in Mexico state, just outside the capital. 
 But as the debate over allegations offraud and ballot irregularities continues, experts on both sides say the vote damaged Mr. Salinas's struggle to overcome his party's reputation for electoral abuse. The election may ultimately prove even more damaging, they warn, to his wider campaign to reshape Mexico's economy and its international image.
Foreign experts say that the appearance of corruption or election fraud could particularly discourage the foreign investment that Mr. Salinas needs to smooth the transition to a more open economic system. It could also serve as ammunition for foes of other elements of the Government's economic strategy, like the conclusion of a free trade agreement with the United States.
That agreement is to be a central item on Mr. Salinas's agenda when he meets with President Bush next week for two days of discussions in the northern city of Monterrey.
"The worry is that this will give people who would be hurt by the free trade agreement a more respectable reason to oppose it," a diplomat said. "Instead of saying, 'This is going to hurt my business,' they will say, 'How can Bush make deals with a dictatorship?' "
Even before the balloting, leaders of the P.R.I., as the party is known, acknowledged that they had more atstake than simple victory or defeat.
"We not only have to win the elections," Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza, the state Governor and a leading P.R.I. official, said before the vote. "We also have to convince public opinion that we won them cleanly."
 
Questionable Margins
 But the potential conflict between those goals quickly became apparent as the vote was counted and the party began to roll up improbably high margins in a state it had lost decisively in national elections only two years ago.
The results released today showed that the party won all 34 directly contested seats in the state legislature and leadership in 116 of the state's 121 municipalities. It received 53 percent of the vote in a field of eight parties.
The results have been directly challenged by large opposition groups like the Democratic Revolutionary Party and the National Action Party, which have accused the P.R.I. of irregularities ranging from ballot stuffing to tampering with voter lists.
The appearance of election fraud has also hurt smaller parties, which in some municipalities received fewer votes than the number of candidates on their slate, curiously suggesting that some candidates had not even voted for themselves.
"Before, the central characteristic of Mexican elections was their lack of competition," wrote Lorenzo Meyer, a respected Mexican political analyst and Government critic, in a recent front-page column in the Mexico City daily newspaper Excelsior. "Today that characteristic has been reduced to the simple absence of credibility."
