HEADLINE: Auction Houses' Glitter Dims And Sellers Look to Dealers

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
The allure of the auction market in the high-flying 80's, when collectors not only paid high prices but also could be seen doing so, is increasingly being replaced by more discreet buying and selling through dealers.
The sharp decline in prices at auctions in the last few weeks has brightened the outlook for dealers in everything from Old Master paintings and Chinese porcelains to contemporary art and jewelry. 
 In the last few years, sellers often passed over dealers in favor of the more visible and glamorous world of the auction houses, which served as the focus of frenzied activity and soaring prices. But now many prominent dealers say they are being offered goods they never would have dreamed of getting a few seasons ago.
 
Visibility: a 2-Edged Sword
 The very visibility of the auction houses, which made them the center of the marketplace at a time of rising prices, has become a liability when prices turn downward.
Peter Schaffer, an owner of A la Vieille Russie, a Fifth Avenue gallery that deals in Russian artworks and jewelry, said: "Three or four years ago, the best things were all going to auction. But the pendulum is finally swinging back in favor of the dealer, as people are beginning to realize the old adage 'A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush' is really true."
Diana D. Brooks, the president of Sotheby's in New York, said she also saw the beginning of a change. "There certainly is a shakedown," she said, "a greater opportunity for dealers to compete."
Privacy is one of the most important reasons that selling through dealers
that now seems more attractive. To stimulate sales, auction houses produce lavishly photographed catalogues that are mailed to prospective clients around the world. Then important objects are taken on tour to cities like Tokyo and London. If a work sells, all the public exposure has paid off. If the work fails to fetch the price the auction house has estimated it will bring, the piece can seem to have taken on a kind of public taint, and neither dealers nor collectors are likely to want it.
"For years the auction houses looked invincible," said Lawrence Rubin, the president of M. Knoedler & Company in Manhattan, a gallery on East 70th Street that specializes in 20th-century art. "But the level of greed and speculation rose to such heights the bubble finally burst. When prices stopped rising, people got scared."
Fear was certainly evident at the auctions of contemporary, Impressionist and modern art in the last two weeks. Overall, prices were lower than anticipated despite the auction house's conservative reserves, the confidential minimum prices accepted by the seller, below which the house will not sell property. Areas like contemporary art, in which there has been the greatest inflation in the last few years, were the hardest hit. At Sotheby's, for example, 58 percent of the contemporary works went unsold.
At each of these recent sales, standing-room-only crowds gasped, and hesitant buyers sat with paddles idly resting in their laps, when works by 19th- and 20th-century masters like van Gogh, Monet, Jasper Johns and Roy Lichtenstein failed to sell.
These major fall sales are crucial as the main profit source for the auction houses. They are important for dealers, too.
"Lower prices at auction means a dealer's inventory is worth that much less," said Eli Broad, a collector and founding chairman of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. "It's a general rule that in heated markets, as we've had over the last few years, collectors do better selling at auction. But when the market begins to suffer, the dealers are a better bet. Not only will they give you a good price, but dealers are discreet: they'll just show the work to a few collectors they know will be interested. A piece is not exposed to the whole free world."
As a result, privacy is becoming fashionable. So is anonymity. "Times are tough," said Khalil Rizk, a co-owner of the Chinese Porcelain Company on Madison Avenue at 69th Street. "There are people out there in real financial trouble. They need money, but they certainly don't want anyone to know it. Selling through a dealer is a totally private transaction."
 
Moving the Goods Faster
 Selling through dealers is also quicker than consigning at auction, since sellers do not have to wait months until the right auction comes along. (Auction houses hold sales for specific categories of art only once or twice a year.) "Dealers have the advantage of being able to pay in cash today," said Chris Jussel, of Vernay & Jussel, a furniture gallery on Madison Avenue at 57th Street.
Mr. Jussel said that at the International Antique Dealers Show in New York City in October, he bought his star piece, a $140,000 George III mahogany wine cooler, from a collector who used to buy and sell only at auction. "Selling through me was simply a safer bet," he said.
Although dealers are reluctant to admit it, business is slow for them, too, these days. At this fall's most prestigious antiques shows, both in New York City and abroad, sales were way down. (Mr. Jussel's wine cooler remains unsold.) Shops report far less traffic than they have had for years. "The recession is hitting us all," Mr. Jussel said.
Still, there are many reasons people are selling now rather than waiting until the market goes back up. For some, the issue is pure and simple: the need for money. Others, however, are forming collections and want to sell objects to gain the cash to trade up.
"We're also buying a lot from people who are moving into smaller homes and no longer have space," said Edward Munves, one of the owners of James Robinson Inc. in Manhattan, an East 57th Street gallery that deals in silver and jewelry.
 
Advantages of Consignment
 Dealers do more than make quick cash deals with collectors. Often, when time is not an issue, they will agree to try to sell a work on consignment, an agreement that is by no means new to the art market. Consigning to a dealer means having the luxury of time, of waiting for the desired price without the pressure of selling at a fixed date and place.
Since generally no money changes hands until a piece is sold, this is not an arrangement sought after by buyers the trade has labeled "investors or speculators," those who jumped on the art market bandwagon purely for profit. "The investors are fast disappearing," Mr. Rizk said.
"If I were in the market to sell, I'd do the same thing now that I would have done two years ago," said John Parkinson 3d, a photography collector in New York. "I'd talk to both the auction houses and the dealers. But today I'd be far more skeptical about what an auction house could do for me. There's been too much of a change in the market recently. A lot of people have been put off by seeing auction prices become so out of line."
 
'Distress Sale' Merchandise?
 Just what dealers are being offered for sale seems to be a matter of debate. While Christopher Burge, the president of Christie's in New York, said he thought it was far too early to tell how much dealers are really being offered, he did say, "What they are getting is pretty much distress-sale stuff, things people want to dispose of fast, and it's easier to do it through a dealer."
Many dealers disagree. "It's the auction houses that are getting the distress-sale merchandise," said Harold Sack, an owner of Israel Sack in Manhattan, an American-furniture gallery on East 57th Street. "As the auction houses are trying to push up the numbers for their sales, they are coming to the dealers to see what we can give them to fill up their auctions. And dealers are sending their least desirable goods."
For the most part, dealers admit they will never attract the large estate sales away from the auction houses, since the tax obligations afford estates the luxury of time for big presale promotions giving them the chance to reach the widest audience.
"But we're still getting things that are fresh to the market and that have come from good sources," said Julian Agnew of Agnew & Sons, a London-based gallery that specializes in Old Master paintings. "People go where they can get the best price and right now auctions are not it."
 
A Pattern, With Variations
 This is a familiar pattern that has been seen during other economic downturns. But the auction world was very different in 1974 and 1982. "The numbers are so much bigger," Mrs. Brooks, of Sotheby's, said.
And the public exposure has become so much greater as, over the last decade, auction houses have become retail establishments catering as much to the private collector as to the trade. "In the old days, auction rooms were filled only with dealers who would buy very quietly, and the public never really knew who bought what," Mr. Sack said. And, he said, during the 1982 recession the great pieces went into hiding as owners preferred to wait for better times if they could.
Many fine artworks are disappearing from the market, too. While there are still pieces to sell, both dealers and auction experts bemoan the lack of truly exceptional goods for sale. "It may be a time when people simply want less flash," Mrs. Brooks said. "We're already taking a low-key approach to auctions."
For this fall's big sales of contemporary, Impressionist and modern paintings and sculpture, for example, there were fewer hardbound catalogs than in previous seasons. Nor have there been as many presale parties. Moreover, objects have traveled to fewer cities for sales exhibitions.
For the first time in years, it seems, auction houses are feeling the heat, working to compete with dealers and, in the process, cut their operating costs. "We're going to have to adapt to changing times," Mrs. Brooks said. "Ultimately there will have to be more of an equilibrium, a more even balance of business between dealers and auction houses."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EUROPE;
East and West Sign Pact to Shed Arms in Europe

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 19

 BODY:
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, joined by leaders of 20 other nations that make up the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact, signed the most ambitious arms-control treaty in history today, pledging to destroy tens of thousands of tanks, howitzers and other nonnuclear weapons.
"What a long way the world has come!" Mr. Gorbachev exulted.
Having underlined the end of the cold war that divided East and West for more than four decades, the two Presidents turned their eyes to the future, taking leading roles in the first session of the three-day Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The 34 participants at the conference -- Canada, the United States and all the countries of Europe except Albania -- hope to draw up a charter for the region. 
 The Persian Gulf crisis lurked just offstage, and Mr. Bush was quick to press for support in the effort to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait by diplomatic or military means. "Success here," he said, "can be neither profound nor enduring if the rule of law is shamelessly disregarded elsewhere."
At the meeting, held at the Kleber International Conference Center near the Arc de Triomphe, the 69 delegates -- presidents, prime ministers, foreign ministers and the like -- sat at a hexagonal table surrounding three-foot-high cutout maps of North America and Eurasia that resembled pieces from a jigsaw puzzle for giants. There were 67 men and two women: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland of Norway.
Mr. Bush hailed the treaty as "the most far-reaching arms agreement" ever negotiated. The result of two years of painstaking bargaining in Vienna, the accord was also a bit of an anticlimax. It represents a ratification in the military sphere of what has already taken place in political terms.
The military confrontation between the two alliances has evaporated, the Soviets are preoccupied with domestic economic and political crises, the Warsaw Pact's days may be numbered, and NATO is having trouble finding a new role. And today, in addition to the arms treaty, the NATO and Warsaw Pact leaders signed a declaration saying that they were "no longer adversaries and will establish new relations of partnership and mutual friendship."
 
Active Sense of History
 The air was thick with comparisons to the Congress of Vienna in 1815, at the end of the Napoleonic wars, and the Conference of Versailles in 1919, after World War I.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said that in building "a Europe of eternal peace" the conferees should look to the French Revolution, the Magna Carta and the Declaration of Independence for inspiration, as well as the writings of the 18th-century philosopher Kant, who he said was an advocate of unity among European states.
In the last two centuries, Mr. Kohl said, "Europe and my country in particular became the epicenter of worldwide catastrophes."
"It is the first time in history that we witness a change in depth of the European landscape that is not the outcome of a war or a bloody revolution," said President Francois Mitterrand. "We do not have sitting here either victors or vanquished but free countries equal in dignity."
 
Talks to Last Till Wednesday
 The summit conference will end at midday Wednesday with the signing of an agreement that will establish a conflict-resolution center in Vienna and a secretariat for the 34-member group in Prague -- a tribute to President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, who has come to symbolize the sprint toward democracy that has transformed Eastern Europe in the last 18 months.
Foreign ministers of the member countries will meet every year and the leaders every other year to monitor progress toward the creation of new European institutions and other ties. Next year the foreign ministers will meet in Berlin on June 19 and 20.
The European security process began when 35 participants -- the current 34 plus East Germany, which has since merged with West Germany -- met in Helsinki in 1975 to sign an accord on cooperation and human rights. After Mr. Gorbachev's accession to power a decade later, it took on new significance.
Today's events, five years to the day after Mr. Gorbachev and President Bush first meet in Geneva, began with the arms accord.
 
Americans Are Optimistic
 Mr. Bush said the treaty, signed beneath the glittering chandeliers of Elysee Palace, "signals the new world order that is emerging." President Mitterrand told his colleagues that they were "putting an end to the previous age."
NATO's top military commander, Gen. John Galvin, an American, said that the treaty was "good for Europe and good for the world."
A senior French diplomat involved in negotiating the pact said: "It would have been tragic if the treaty had not been achieved. Many of the ablest people in many countries worked so hard to bring it about. But it was only possible when it no longer mattered so much -- indeed precisely because it no longer mattered so much."
The 160-page agreement, plus three associated declarations, covers forces based between the Atlantic Ocean and the Ural Mountains, which cut across the Soviet Union from north to south, dividing its European from its Asian territory, and between the Arctic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea.
 
Less Hardware for All
 By far the biggest cuts will be made in Central Europe, the cockpit of the cold war, where both sides once expected catastrophe and where, instead, the revolutions of 1989 brought the confrontation to an end.
NATO and the Warsaw Pact will each be limited to 20,000 tanks, 20,000 artillery pieces, 30,000 armored fighting vehicles, 6,800 combat aircraft and 2,000 attack helicopters. The West will have to make only a tenth of the cuts, which will eliminate the Warsaw Pact's longstanding edge in the number of conventional arms in Europe.
To keep either side from concentrating its forces, limits also apply to specified zones and to individual nations. Troops are not covered, and their limits are to be negotiated later in Vienna, but the United States and Germany have agreed to ceilings outside the formal agreement -- no more than 195,000 American troops in Central Europe and no more than 370,000 in the unified German armed forces.
In fact, neither the United States nor the Soviet Union is likely to maintain as many troops in the region as it is entitled to.
In an era when the continent's problems lie not in conflicting ideologies but in economic and structural problems, like renewed conflicts in the Balkans and even the survival of a unitary Soviet state, large land armies seem irrelevant.
 
New Arms Talks Soon
 Mr. Gorbachev said in his speech that he wanted to press ahead as quickly as possible with other arms-reduction measures, presumably so that he can husband scarce Soviet resources to help satisfy the pent-up craving for food and other consumer goods.
He said he would be ready in a month or two to begin negotiations on short-range nuclear arms in Europe, and he reiterated that he wanted to extend talks to cover warships, a topic that the United States has kept off the agenda.
The Soviet leader warned his fellow delegates not to surrender to euphoria, and there was a reminder of the tensions of the past within hours of the signing of the arms treaty. President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said that the United States questioned some of the data supplied by the Soviet Union under terms of the accord.
"It looks like there may be some problems there," he told the Cable News Network in an interview. Military analysts said that the difficulty concerned Soviet artillery pieces.
Data can be adjusted by either side over a 90-day period.
Differences also emerged on the Baltic republics, with Denmark, Sweden and Italy urging the Soviet Union to give more sympathy to these areas' drives for independence and Mr. Gorbachev warning of the dangers of "Lebanonization."
 
Political Fractures Feared
 "Militant nationalism and mindless separatism can easily bring conflict and enmity, Balkanization and even, what is worse, the Lebanonization of different regions," Mr. Gorbachev said, alluding to his and other nations' problems with secessionism and ethnic strife. "Both could put a brake on European cooperation and contradict the European process."
The foreign ministers of the three Baltic republics -- Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania -- are in Paris as the guests of the French Government for the week, but the Soviet Union has succeeded in blocking their admission to the conference.
The gathering of so many national leaders in one city created extraordinary security problems.
More than 10,000 police officers were deployed, some of them as rooftop sharpshooters. The constant to-and-fro of fleets of limousines snarled the traffic in the center of the city on a bright, blustery day.

HEADLINE: An All-Black Film (Except the Audience)

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19

 BODY:
"To Sleep With Anger" is a highly praised new film that has a black cast, a black director, a black writer and tells the story of a middle-class black family. Yet to the dismay and puzzlement of those who made and are marketing the movie, it has typically been performing five times as well in white neighborhoods as in black neighborhoods.
Alarmed at Hollywood's reluctance to make films dealing with black themes and fearful that the commercial failure of an artistic all-black film will only worsen such prospects, groups like the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are now urging blacks to support the film. So far, however, those efforts seem to have had little impact, and the movie's limited promotional budget is now being directed at a wider audience. 
 Released last month to enthusiastic reviews, "To Sleep With Anger" stars Danny Glover as an interloper who disrupts the lives of a loving and tightly knit black family in Los Angeles. In New York it opened at four theaters, including the Nova in Harlem, but it is now playing only at the Angelika Film Center on Houston Street to what the film's distributors describe as a "classic art-house crowd."
 
'In Specialty Houses'
 "The numbers and the pattern have been the same everywhere, regardless of how we use television, radio, newsprint and public appearances to support this picture," said Tom Rothman, head of production at the Samuel Goldwyn Company , which is distributing the film. "This picture has performed well in specialty houses, but in so-called black theaters across the country, the performance has been significantly less."
The Goldwyn Company, an independent distributor, took on "To Sleep With Anger" after none of Hollywood's major studios showed an interest in the film. Though "To Sleep With Anger" was awarded a special jury prize at the Sundance United States Film Festival in January and won enormous critical praise at the Cannes International Film Festival in May, Hollywood has regarded it as a "difficult sell" from the start because of its subject matter and presumed audience appeal.
The director of the film, Charles Burnett, received a "genius grant" from the MacArthur Foundation in 1988, and the Library of Congress last month designated his first movie, "Killer of Sheep," 1 of 25 culturally and artistically significant motion picutres to be included in the National Film Registry. He has never had a commercial success, though, and is virtually unknown in Hollywood.
 
Question of Marketing
 Mr. Burnett, who made "To Sleep With Anger" on a budget of less than $1.5 million, said he was disappointed by the film's performance among blacks but thought it reflected not an absence of interest but rather a lack of effective marketing. "It's not that the black community is not responding," he said. "It's that they don't know anything about it. The problem has really been trying to communicate with black audiences."
The N.A.A.C.P. chapter here sent a letter to many black community groups and newspapers saying that "a wonderful family film has been released but is not being seen by our community."
"Since black audience draw appears to be the criteria by which studios evaluate the validity of black films, we are determined to provide that audience," the organization said in a separate statement, which also complained that "the picture may have been miscommunicated to our people."
"These studios need to be educated," said Patricia Tobin, a public relations agent here who is president of the Black Public Relations Society and has worked on publicity campaigns for Spike Lee's films. "We African-Americans are a special market, and you have to market to us in a certain way."
 
Role of Black Churches
 Citing one example of specialty marketing, Ms. Tobin said Goldwyn should have made more of an effort to show "To Sleep With Anger" to pastors of black churches. "The black church is a power base in the community," she said, "so you set up special screenings and get some word of mouth going."
Goldwyn executives said they did hire a black public relations specialist and that "To Sleep With Anger" was shown to special audiences, not just church leaders but also the N.A.A.C.P. and the National Association of Black Journalists, both of which had conventions here this summer. The results, Mr. Rothman said, were disappointing.
"I can't tell you how hard we have worked to get the black press," Mr. Rothman said. "We have worked day and night on this, and it is only fair to say we have been disappointed with the lack of support. The Sentinel, the black paper here, didn't even have a review of the film the day it opened, and this is Mr. Burnett's home town."
Though Jet magazine has published a story on Mr. Burnett and his film, two other leading black publications, Ebony and Essence, have not. Mr. Burnett said he thought part of the problem was that Hollywood studios "just call up out of the blue once every two years or so instead of having an ongoing relationship" with black publications, a notion that Ms. Tobin also endorsed.
 
'A Two-Way Street'
 "The major magazines are tired of giving them editorial space and not getting back any ads," she said. "It's a two-way street, so I don't blame them. It all comes back to economics." Goldwyn did buy one full-page advertisement in Jet magazine, company executives said.
Goldwyn executives also said that market research indicated race was not the primary factor in determining audience response to the film. "What we've found from looking at grosses and going to the theaters is that the audiences we have attracted have been separated not by race but by class," said Steve Rothenberg, Goldwyn's vice president for theatrical distribution. "This film is appealing mostly to the middle and upper classes, both black and white, not blue-collar blacks or whites. So we are tailoring our distribution plan to attract the upper class, and that's who is starting to discover it."
Mr. Burnett, however, has not abandoned his efforts to attract a mass black audience to the film, which has earned $325,000 at the box office. "People have been going around putting up posters in Washington and Chicago, and we've been going on radio stations" with black audiences, he said.
 
Need for More Money
 In addition, the producers of the film are now seeking more money for ads and other promotion. But Goldwyn executives argue that they cannot afford to aim such efforts primarily at the black audience that had been assumed to identify most closely with the film.
"The audience for any specialized picture is the white audience," Mr. Rothman said. "That audience tends to be more review-driven, and this film has gotten absolutely fabulous reviews. We are fighting tooth and nail to hang on until December," when it is expected that many film critics will include "To Sleep With Anger" on their annual "10 Best" lists and "get some word of mouth going so this picture can build."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Senators and Their TV Awareness

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Several players in the current hearings of the Senate Ethics Committee have noted that there are television cameras in the committee room, and viewers of C-Span and CNN may be noticing the effects of that awareness on the five Senators under investigation. 
 Without uttering a word on opening day, John Glenn managed to distance himself emphatically from the four others. He was the only one without a lawyer by his side. It was a visual declaration by Mr. Glenn that he had done nothing to require that sort of assistance. (The sight of Alan Cranston's table, occupied by two lawyers and no Senator, carried a quite different signal.)
 Mr. Glenn sat alone at his little table, back rigid, shoulders squared, looking ahead sternly while Robert S. Bennett, the committee's special counsel, presented details of the five's involvement with Charles H. Keating Jr., the soiled savings-and-loan executive. Mr. Glenn, palms down on the green felt of the table, scarcely moving, never relaxing, presented a model of rectitude, or at least of good posture.
By an accident of alphabet, Mr. Glenn was seated smack in the middle of the five, so that on Friday morning, when he was late in arriving, his empty table served to separate Mr. Cranston and Dennis DeConcini, the two whom Mr. Bennett called "by far the most active" in behalf of Mr. Keating, from John McCain and Donald W. Riegle Jr., who by Mr. Bennett's account were less involved. The gap gave visual force to the efforts of Mr. McCain to dissociate himself from his fellow Senator from Arizona, Mr. DeConcini.
In his half-hour defense on Friday, Mr. Glenn, still seated alone at his table, seemed at moments to be talking about somebody else: "John Glenn does not peddle influence, period." The self-tribute sent forth the message that this man was above the need for a lawyer, or any props to declare his guiltlessness.
Mr. McCain spoke even more briefly; he took 10 minutes to report simply that he had said no to what he considered improper requests by his old friend and contributor, Mr. Keating. In a show of self-assurance, Mr. McCain would later take calls over C-Span; the callers did not seem to have been much reassured.
It remained for Mr. McCain's lawyer, John Dowd, to blame Senator DeConcini, who could be seen making notes and occasionally shaking his head slightly in what might have been meant to signify disbelief, for embroiling Mr. McCain. Mr. Dowd made much of the fact that Mr. Keating had called Mr. McCain "a wimp" for refusing to put pressure on officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to take it easy on Mr. Keating. Some viewers must have remembered that Mr. McCain had been a prisoner of war in Vietnam.
By taking it on himself to criticize Mr. DeConcini, the lawyer spared his client the appearance of impugning the actions of a colleague, from his own state at that. And it was also more becoming that heavy praise for Mr. McCain should not issue from his own lips.
Perhaps a media consultant had told Mr. Riegle that viewers require props to abet comprehension. He brought with him a jigsaw puzzle, which he displayed to the committee and the cameras several times. The point was, "We don't have all the pieces of the puzzle." Get it?
Mr. Bennett had said only that Mr. Riegle had "played an active role in early stages in the case," a mild slap. But Mr. Riegle went on for almost 90 minutes (interrupting himself occasionally to say, "I don't want to go on too long here") and risked coming across as protesting too much. About an hour into his explanations that his contacts with Mr. Keating were in the interests of Detroit's sorry economy and his professions of commitment to public service, the camera panned over the faces of the committee members. You could see a veil of exhaustion descending. A television reviewer would have had to convict Mr. Riegle of cruelty to his peers.
The star of Friday's appearances was Mr. Cranston. The news that he was suffering from cancer of the prostate had been confirmed the day before by a letter from the Senator, which included the names of all the hospitals where his condition had been diagnosed. So his presentation on Friday would probably be the Senator's sole on-camera response to assertions that he had promoted Mr. Keating's interests even while he was successfully soliciting the businessman for hundreds of thousands of dollars in political contributions.
Several large white boards had been set up, raising the promise of some revelation. They turned out merely to carry the names of Senators and their staff members responsible for raising money; the camera duly rolled down the list, documenting Mr. Cranston's point that everybody did it, or anyway, something like it. As visual aids go, these were not enthralling, but they were all the detail that Mr. Cranston was to offer.
He used his half-hour instead to avow his reverence for "this great institution of democracy," "this body which I love." Referring to his reported pro-Keating pressures on bank regulators, he spoke harshly of "bureaucrats" and asked his colleagues, "Can you only help people who haven't contributed, or who haven't contributed lately?" He seemed bent on persuading the nation that Alan Cranston was not one to discriminate against a constituent just because he was rich.
Perhaps it was in part the viewer's knowledge of Mr. Cranston's illness that made him look so thin. His condition was an implicit plea for sympathy, to which he added family feeling. When he expressed indignation over the "false charges attacking my flesh and blood," the camera went to members of his family. And he appealed to "listeners around the country" to share his distress at having his "wonderful son," Kim, who ran voter-registration groups that received $850,000 in Keating contributions, implicated by Mr. Bennett. In its dips into bathos, Mr. Cranston's script borrowed from those made-in-Hollywood shows that tend to be more popular with audiences than with critics.
Yesterday, it was the turn of Mr. DeConcini, who, in Mr. Bennett's telling, had been particularly active in Mr. Keating's interests. Although he had tough words for Mr. Bennett's treatment of some of the evidence -- "disgraceful," "unconscionable," "biased" -- he characterized himself as the sort of hands-on, sleeves-rolled-up (at one point he actually pushed up his jacket sleeves) Senator who goes all-out for service to constituents. "What is wrong," he asked, "with intervention for someone who sends you a check for your campaign?"
The statement, which ran about two hours, not counting the remarks of his lawyer, was striking for its attacks on the motives of Mr. Bennett, who Mr. De Concini shouted, wanted "to nail somebody" and put "another trophy on the wall," and on Common Cause, the liberal lobby that brought the charges against the five. Its motive, said the Senator, was to raise money, get members and damage Congress.
If these assaults were meant to ingratiate him with viewers, they were probably misdirected at a time when negative campaigning is in bad odor. But despite an occasional remark straight into the camera, his appeal was mainly to his fellow Senators, he and they together against the bureaucracy, the press, Common Cause and Mr. Bennett. "But for the grace of God," he cautioned in his peroration, "there go I -- or you." The single blemish on senatorial solidarity was in reference to Mr. McCain, who had already failed Mr. DeConcini. In addition to suggesting that his colleague's memory was faulty, Mr. DeConcini argued that Mr. McCain had enjoyed softer treatment by the committee counsel than he had.
Whatever the television audience may have made of Mr. DeConcini's explanation of his relationship with Charles Keating, it was informative about the workings of at least one senator's office. Viewers who have never had the privilege of a personal meeting with a senator may have been left wondering: could they expect that kind of constituent service? "That's what has made me the Senator I am," said Mr. DeConcini.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baseball Is Scouting Minor League Homes

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
Major league baseball, facing a prospect that it must groom its own players because of a contract dispute with its farm teams, is scouting sites from college fields to towns long ago abandoned by professional baseball as possible homes for a reorganized system that could hold as many as 170 minor league teams.
"We've already started down the track, getting the documentation together," Bill Murray, the director of baseball operations and chief negotiator for the major leagues, said yesterday. "Franchise applications are being drawn up. Advertisements for such franchises are being prepared for the usual sports media outlets." 
 Such movement is taking place because talks have stalled on a new contract between the major leagues and the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues.
The association is the governing body of approximately 150 minor leagues teams. The contracts that bound about 60 of the minor league teams to parent clubs have expired during the battle over an overall professional baseball agreement.
 
Contract Expires Jan. 12
 Disputes over economics and control of the minor leagues have held up the overall agreement, and the current contract expires Jan. 12. As that date draws nearer, both sides are preparing for life without each other for the first time in 87 years.
Major league baseball has talked of contingencies all along but, for the first time, seems to have increased its proposed scale of operations. At first, talk centered on "complex" baseball, with games limited to those that could be played at spring training complexes in Florida and Arizona. That is now being considered on a "worst-case basis," Murray said.
"We have complexes in Florida and Arizona that could do the job," Murray said, "but that's not what we want, nor what we intend to do. What we intend to do is go out and seek as many locations where minor league baseball was played in 1990 and see how many of those sites are available. We're also going to look for alternate sites."
 
Looking for Leases
 Among the alternatives, Murray said, "would be the close to 40 cities that once had professional baseball teams but were abandoned by the minor leagues in the last 10 years."
"We've also been in contact with the N.C.A.A. and that governing body for colleges has informed us that it has no restrictions to prohibit us from renting its facilities," Murray said.
Baseball is also exploring the possibility of renting current minor league facilities but, Murray said, such city-by-city dealings would depend on the nature of each lease teams already on site have.
Murray said that as soon as leases for the new team sites are signed, the majors will abandon attempts to agree to a new deal with the National Association.
 
Inquiries About Franchises
 Murray said that the major leagues have also received inquiries about the acquisition of franchises from people who are not currently involved in minor league baseball.
The major leagues could field minor league teams in cities where the original farm clubs are still playing if the National Association operates independently.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Shoal Creek Versus Arizona

BYLINE: By Ira Berkow

 BODY:
Some view the racial implications of membership policies at Shoal Creek, and at other golf clubs that host tournaments, and the Martin Luther King Jr. vote in Arizona as the same. There are similarities, but there are more ways in which the two cases are dramatically different.
 Early last summer, Hall Thompson, the founder of the Shoal Creek Country Club near Birmingham, Ala., which was to be site of the P.G.A. Championship in August, said, "We don't discriminate in every other area except the blacks," and that "we won't be pressured" into having any as members. 
With that, black groups effectively sought boycotts by television sponsors of the tournament. Under pressure, the club then admitted a black man as an honorary member.
 The Professional Golfers' Association of America, which runs the P.G.A. Championship, the PGA Tour and the United States Golf Association have since issued edicts that none of their tournaments (including the United States Open) will be played at private clubs that have discriminatory policies concerning members.
 When on Nov. 6 the state of Arizona put to referendum whether to have a paid legal holiday in honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the voters turned down the proposal by a 1 percent margin on 1 million ballots cast.
 Immediately, the commissioner of the National Football League, Paul Tagliabue, announced that he would recommend to the team owners to remove Phoenix as host of the 1993 Super Bowl.
 Earlier this year, the N.F.L. had agreed to hold the Super Bowl in Phoenix, but with one major provision: that, in eight months, the voters of Arizona elect to have a Martin Luther King Day. Arizona is one of only three states in the union that does not have some kind of day honoring King.
 Phoenix and suburban Tempe (where the game would be played), and Tucson, however, do observe Martin Luther King Day.
 Nonetheless, said Tagliabue, no King Day, no Super Bowl Week.
 Tagliabue was being sensitive to the blacks in his league, who include 56 percent of the players. As a private organization, the N.F.L. has the right to handle its affairs in the lawful manner it sees fit. But the commissioner's implication is surely that Arizona, by turning down the proposal, is a racist state. In fact, a black state senator from Arizona, Carolyn Walker, said that "it's sad to say that this state is racist, and I keep saying we are not, but when you turn down a holiday that deals with honoring civil and human rights, the numbers show that we are."
 When the University of California at Berkeley agreed to play in the Copper Bowl in Tucson on Dec. 31, a spokesman for the N.A.A.C.P. said he couldn't understand why an institution with such a history of humanitarian concerns would play in Arizona after that vote. But there will be a halftime show celebrating King.
 And the University of Louisville's board of governors voted to play in the Fiesta Bowl in Phoenix on New Year's Day, with plans to earmark about $200,000 of its earnings from the game to minority-group student concerns at the university.
 The N.F.L. should have gone along the general route taken by those schools.
 The N.F.L. is using one issue as a litmus test for racism, and it is a faulty test, at best. The vote may have been an economic one (against another paid state holiday), or a reaction to what some viewed as "bullying" tactics by the N.F.L., or by state politicians and business people who had assured the league that the vote would be favorable.
 Regardless of how great a leader King was (and he was one of this nation's finest and most effective leaders), it remains subjective whether to honor him or anyone else who was significant. After all, not even Lincoln is honored with a day in every state. And should the N.F.L. refuse to award Charlotte, N.C., an expansion football team because Jesse Helms was again re-elected to the United States Senate, this time over a black man? Or should they never have another Super Bowl in New Orleans because David Duke nearly won a Senate seat? And while we're at it, why not remove the Cardinals from Phoenix altogether?
Arizona, meanwhile, adheres to all of the nondiscrimination laws of the nation, in jobs, education, housing and justice. Many of the nation's country clubs, however, have a clear history of discrimination. Private country clubs also are often sites for the transaction of important business affairs, and a result may be that if minority members or women aren't allowed in, then they can be at a competititve disadvantage, and their employers, or would-be employers, know it.
 Private organizations, including those in sports, ought, like anyone else, to use legal leverage when possible in matters benefiting humanity, but the Arizona football issue paints a broad brushstroke that is unreasonable.
 By extension, one contemplates that because George Bush vetoed the recent Civil Rights Bill, the N.F.L. will next decide to play the Super Bowl in Canada.

HEADLINE: Gardens of Plant Tissue in Labs Seen as Factories for Vital Drugs

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
TAXOL, one of the most promising anti-cancer drugs to be tested in years, comes from the bark of the Pacific yew, a slow-growing evergreen found in a few Northwestern states and Canada.
But about 36,000 60-year-old trees would have to be destroyed each year just to treat patients with ovarian cancer, the drug's most exciting role to date. Should the drug's early promise against cancers of the breast, lung and colon hold up, millions of trees would fall each year and the world's natural supply of taxol would soon be gone. 
 Scientists have tried to synthesize the chemical in the laboratory. But 10 years of effort have been futile; taxol's highly complex chemical structure is simply too hard to duplicate.
So the researchers have turned to tissue culture, reproducing in the laboratory bark cells that can produce large amounts of taxol. By manipulating plant cells and growing mediums, researchers can create vast laboratory gardens of plant parts that produce important chemicals quickly, cheaply and reliably in a confined space.
 
New Use for Technique
 Chemical "elicitors" can be added to the growth medium to prompt the cultured tissues to produce more than the usual amounts of certain target compounds. Such compounds are called secondary metabolites because they are normally produced by the plant in response to a particular stress or stimulus, such as an attack by a predatory insect or fungal disease or a sudden temperature change.
For years, scientists have used tissue culture techniques to improve plant lines. Researchers have altered elm and chestnut trees in hopes of creating blight-resistant strains and put the techniques to work at Kew Gardens in England after a storm destroyed many plants.
But only recently have they used tissue culture to turn plant cells into factories for needed compounds. This research was the subject of a recent conference at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
In the case of taxol, the goal is to create a "forest" of bark from the Pacific yew without having to destroy a single tree. The National Cancer Institute, which discovered taxol while screening 35,000 plants in hopes of finding cancer treatments, is underwriting studies to solve the taxol supply problem.
At least two laboratories have already established taxol-producing tissue cultures. One, Phyton Catalytic Inc. of Ithaca, N.Y., said its tissue culture of yew bark was yielding seven times more taxol than the plant naturally produced in its bark. The other, a United States Department of Agriculture laboratory in New Orleans, is seeking a patent for another less efficient taxol process.
If current production results hold up in large-scale tests, taxol is likely to become the nation's first secondary metabolite from a plant to be produced commercially in tissue culture.
But Dr. Dayuan Wang of DNA Pharmaceuticals in Stamford, Conn., said American scientists were years behind the Chinese in exploring the value of plant tissue cultures to produce medically useful chemicals. The Chinese have long derived most of their medicines from plants. But since plant resources are limited or difficult to obtain and enormous quantities of low-cost drugs are needed, Chinese scientists were quick to recognize the potential economy and efficiency of tissue culture production.
Dr. Wang, whose company has two laboratories in China, said the Chinese were studying the growth of plant parts in tissue culture to produce drugs that fight cancer, lower blood pressure, relieve pain, combat malaria, suppress coughs, stimulate the immune system and counter the damaging effects of radiation.
For example, a drug to lower blood pressure that is extracted from the bark of a tree, Eucommia ulnoides, is not only widely used in China but is also exported to other Asian countries.
"People were cutting down so many trees to extract the chemical that the Chinese would have run short of trees in just 10 or 15 years," Dr. Wang said. "So a decade ago, scientists in Beijing turned to tissue culture of the tree's bark to solve the supply problem."
He said the Chinese had also shown that a plant tissue culture could produce high yields of L-dopa, the drug that revolutionized the treatment of Parkinson's disease.
At the symposium in Brooklyn, co-sponsored by the Northeast chapter of the Tissue Culture Association, Dr. Robert Borris of Merck Sharp & Dohme 's division of natural products noted that "Mother Nature is an excellent chemist, and traditionally, natural products have been a very rich source of drugs." Among the better known medicines derived from plants are the heart drug digitalis, the anti-malarial quinine, the gout remedy colchicine and two of the most important cancer chemotherapeutic agents, vincristine and vinblastine.
 
Advantages of Tissue Culture
 In trying to capitalize on nature's bag of chemical tricks, tissue culture can circumvent many natural limitations, said Dr. John Staba, a pioneer in the field from the University of Minnesota.
In addition to producing higher yields, tissue cultures are a more reliable source of the desired chemicals. Unlike plants in nature, cultured cells do not depend on season or climate and are not subject to obliteration or inaccessibility resulting from disease or political unrest. Medicinally valuable plants are often difficult to collect from the wild or import because they may be rare or endangered species or they may carry a disease that could damage crops or, as happened to one promising plant, their native habitat is replaced by a parking lot.
The problems of relying on nature are all too obvious with regard to getting enough of the anti-cancer drug vincristine. This potent plant medicine, which has helped to save the lives of countless patients with Hodgkin's disease, is extracted in small amounts from the periwinkle plant. To maintain a supply of vincristine, Eli Lilly & Company supports vast plantations of periwinkle in Madagascar. The drug is expensive because it costs thousands of dollars to produce and isolate just one pound of vincristine from plants grown in the usual fashion.
And, Dr. Borris pointed out, the supply of drug could be seriously disrupted by a fire or revolution or a disease that wipes out the plants, jeopardizing the survival of hundreds of thousands of cancer patients.
If, instead, vincristine was harvested from high-yielding tissue cultures, it would take a lot less space and probably far fewer dollars to procure it and the supply would be infinitely more reliable.
 
Some Chemical Surprises
 Plant tissue cultures could also be a source of medically useful chemical surprises and services, Dr. Borris said. For example, once cells are growing in tissue culture, they can be subjected to a variety of treatments to see what other useful chemicals they could produce. Or plant tissue cultures might be used for "biotransformations," making use of the plant's natural enzyme systems to modify compounds in ways that are technically too difficult to be done by a chemist.
Dr. Borris said tissue cultures could also be used to perform "directed biosynthesis," nutritionally pushing the cultured cells to produce novel compounds by feeding them certain nutrients as building blocks.
Dr. Staba believes science can gain much valuable information from plant tissue cultures. "We can study tissue cultures to find out what compounds plants make, where they are stored and what purpose they serve and then use that information to make more intelligent use of plant chemicals," he said. "This could be a big boon for people. We may be able to find new insecticides and antibiotics, methods of controlling flowering, etc., just from a piece of tissue."
Dr. Ken Torres, director of the plant tissue culture laboratory at the Sigma Chemical Corporation, agreed, saying, "There are tremendous numbers of plant compounds to be found and studied, and the potential for finding new useful compounds is uncountable."
Still, he added, there are tremendous technological obstacles to surmount before American drug and chemical companies begin to take advantage of the opportunities inherent in plant tissue culture.
Dr. Stephen Tim, vice president for science and publications at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, noted that among the half-million species of plants, there was a "mind-boggling array of chemical compounds that can influence tissues and cells."
"Yet," he said, "little or nothing is known about 99 percent of the plant species in botanically rich areas like the Amazon jungle that, along with indigenous folk medicine, is rapidly being swallowed up by 20th century development."
Dr. Tim urged American medicine to explore and take advantage of this vast resource of medicinally useful plants before it is too late.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A Forest in a Test Tube: Instead of extracting a promising cancer drug, taxol, from the bark of rare Pacific yew trees, researchers are manipulating bark cells to produce the drug in laboratory cultures. First, small pieces of the bark are removed and placed in a nutrient-rich gel where they multiply and produce callus, a disorganized mass of tissue cells.;
Production speeds up Cells from the original culture are used to produce more cultures and more callus. Chemical "elicitors" can be added to stimulate the cells to produce more than the usual amount of the drug.; Extracting the drug After several more weeks, the callus is harvested and dried. HEADLINE: Dancing Fast Enough in Moscow?

 BODY:
Mikhail Gorbachev has pulled off another feat of political judo. Beset by challenges from left and right, he has responded with a sweeping government reorganization that would strengthen his own authority while offering a larger role to the restless Soviet republics.
It's far from certain whether Mr. Gorbachev, for all his tactical brilliance, can move swiftly enough to rescue the Soviet Union from turmoil and the Soviet economy from disintegration. And his praiseworthy plan has yet to win over his popular rival, Boris Yeltsin, who has been pushing Mr. Gorbachev to accelerate economic reform. 
 Yet the West is right to wish for his success and help wherever it can to alleviate distress. President Bush's offer yesterday of emergency food supplies and other humanitarian aid, in concert with America's allies, was thus timely and welcome. So were his reasons: "That's the right and humane thing to do as a country moves toward us and relations are greatly improved."
Mr. Gorbachev won approval for two changes long urged on him by reformers like Mr. Yeltsin. He empowered a Federation Council, composed of representatives from the 15 Soviet republics, to coordinate nationwide efforts at desperately needed economic reform. He set up a national security council, a presidential cabinet, to reorganize the recalcitrant bureaucracy and subordinate it to him. That left Prime Minister Ryzhkov without a job. Reformers had demanded he be sacked for temporizing on the economy and for his subservience to conservative apparatchiks.
Ominously, however, Mr. Gorbachev also moved to consolidate control over Soviet law enforcement agencies, including the armed forces, Interior Ministry troops, the K.G.B. and the police. If all else fails, he may be preparing to crack down in order to move essential goods to market.
The new Federation Council is a much-needed mechanism to help Moscow and the rebellious republics resolve differences over the pace and direction of change. By ceding responsibility as well as power to republic leaders like Russia's Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Gorbachev gives them an incentive to reach a consensus.
Mr. Yeltsin remains dissatisfied because Mr. Gorbachev's plan does not go far enough to empower the Russian Republic to proceed rapidly to a market economy. He's also worried that while Central Asian opponents of reform will be represented on the Council, reform-minded leaders in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, unwilling to settle for less than independence, won't join.
Yet the republics can't go it alone. They need goods that only others can supply. An all-Union market is meant to do just that, allowing each republic to specialize in producing what it makes best and trade for what it lacks. The sooner that market begins to function, the sooner separatism will become a spent force.
Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin may yet find a way to compromise on the sovereignty issue, especially who controls resources and factories in Russia. Such an agreement is not beyond the wit of either man; without it the council may deadlock while the economy spins out of control.
Public patience is rapidly wearing thin. Some citizens, eager for a strongman, may demand that Mr. Gorbachev use his police powers to move goods to the shelves. Others may try to take matters into the streets. Either way, Mr. Gorbachev may find himself compelled to revert to the very authoritarian rule he has sought to leave behind.
That's where the West can help. Emergency aid could ease his predicament by assuring that there's food on Soviet tables and no chaos in Soviet streets this winter. Mr. Gorbachev is dancing as fast as he can; he will need partners to keep going.

HEADLINE: Governor Cuomo's Rush to Cut

 BODY:
They said 'No taxes.' -- Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, describing voters' message on Nov. 6.
That they did, and Mr. Cuomo obviously heard them. Confronted with growing budget deficits, he has now proposed deep cuts in jobs and services and rejected his old standbys -- taxes, gimmicks and borrowing. With the state's current budget deficit at $1 billion and growing, the Governor's decision to stop finessing is to his credit. 
 But he has so far failed to draw on his talents as a persuasive leader to frame the right choices and force the public to confront the consequences.
What, in fact, will become of what Mr. Cuomo calls "the Family of New York" if the state mimics the Federal Government and abdicates its responsibility to care for its citizens? What will become of other humane Cuomo initiatives?
 New York has long chosen to provide a high level of public services, but it has done so inefficiently, with widespread waste, a bloated bureaucracy and sloppy accounting. Critics have repeatedly called on Mr. Cuomo to put the state's fiscal house in order; until recently he looked the other way. Now, his hand forced by the weakening economy, he is making difficult, often painful choices. But they are not the only choices.
There is no doubt that Mr. Cuomo has to cut the budget, and cut it deeply. With a deficit of $3 billion or more looming in the next fiscal year, the state cannot tax away its problem without taxing away its competitiveness. But a blanket refusal even to weigh tax increases makes sense only in terms of the 1992 Presidential campaign.
Over the years, as he fought budget cuts and supported higher taxes to cushion the poor, Mr. Cuomo effectively articulated the vision of a humane, caring government. No doubt he still harbors that vision, and champions the philosophy behind it.
Yet when he announced his new budget-cutting plan, it was as if the old Cuomo had given way. Instead of "We have obligations to one another, a belief in the importance of something larger than ourselves" (January 1989), the November 1990 emphasis is on fiscal prudence: "I will reject any proposed tax increases."
A fiscal problem as severe as New York's needs balanced solutions, and a public intolerant of taxes needs educating. What level of services do the people want? The Governor's plan will cut Medicaid payments to hospitals and nursing homes, eliminate funding to new teen-age pregnancy programs, reduce school aid and general revenue sharing and lead to job layoffs. The next fiscal year will bring even more cuts.
A concerned electorate needs choices. There is nobody better equipped to frame and discuss them than the articulate Mr. Cuomo. At least his no-taxes, no-borrowing stance applies to this fiscal year, which ends in March. That means there is still time and room for leadership for the coming fiscal year, if the Governor still favors explanation over resignation, and leadership over capitulation.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Five Missing Words

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal; Russell Baker is on vacation.

 BODY:
Five words are missing. Cup your ear, but in all the talk about American and United Nations goals in the Iraqi crisis you will not hear certain words uttered about the future of the Arab Middle East: political freedom, democracy, human rights.
But if you listen hard enough, you will hear the snickers of the "pragmatists" -- the Arabists and other diplomats in the Western capitals. They will tell you that such things are not part of Arab history, which is true, and that they never can be, which is false. 
 It is also stupid, shortsighted, plus ignorant. Ever since World War II, freedom and democracy have shown themselves more potent than despotism, and human rights has been proven one of the most powerful political weapons the world has known.
How ironic, how sad -- at the very time when the West fears to utter the hope of freedom and human rights for the Middle East, a convocation that is testimony to their power takes place in Paris. The collapse of Communism brought the end of the cold war confrontation. And the collapse of Communism was brought decades nearer by democratic activists who risked their lives pushing through the tiny loophole of the Helsinki treaty on human rights. The Kremlin opened the loophole contemptuously in exchange for recognition of Communist-imposed borders -- surely one of the greatest mistakes any despotism ever made.
A strange admiration for third-world tough guys is one reason the West is not inclined to bother about democracy in the Middle East. ("He keeps his boots polished; my brother and I like him," Robert Kennedy once said of a South Korean military dictator.)
Fear of the unknown is another. If freedom of political choice ever does come to the Middle East, the whole structure of monarchies, despotism and the rule of the mosque will crack open. But so will the cozy arrangements between the local rulers and Western oil companies and the profitable military deals between the West and the kings and sheiks.
And of course, the United States knows that most of its Arab allies are state-of-the-art tyrannies. In Saudi Arabia women are chattel, religious or political dissent is punishable by imprisonment or death. It takes a real expert to tell our ally Hafez al-Assad of Syria apart from our enemy Saddam Hussein.
So the U.S. maintains an unworthy silence -- saying not a word when Syria slaughters Lebanese or when the Saudis round up women for the crime of driving. Washington even tells American soldiers not to talk about women's rights or show the cross or the star of David. The Democratic House majority leader, Representative Richard Gephardt, actually says that the Saudis made a great "concession" by allowing American troops into the country to save the royal Saudi neck.
It will take years before political freedom has a chance in the Arab Middle East. Arab rulers stamp out any opposition they discover.
No illusions: the tiny pro-democracy groups that manage to survive cling to anti-Israel emotions and propaganda. They say they see the Israeli struggle against Palestinian nationalism as the major human rights issue.
Yet they exist, secretly at home, furtively abroad, and attention should be paid. An Iraqi in exile writes a book about his country whose title tells the whole story: "The Republic of Fear." In Geneva, the Arab Organization for Human Rights reports some of the truth about political murder, torture and imprisonment in the Arab countries.
The U.S. cannot and should not envelop them. But it is a scandal that we do not recognize their existence and help them if they wish. Once again, as in Iran, we are surrendering opposition to the rulers to the fundamentalists and we will pay for that.
Interesting, how rarely democracies war against each other, and how often they have to face dictatorships in combat. No great mystery: despots use war to satisfy their power-lust, or to distract their own people from the misery of their political and economic imprisonment.
The root of the conflict between Iraq and the U.S. is not in Kuwait. It is in Baghdad and in Damascus and Tripoli and all other cities of the Middle East, where government aggression against its own nation breeds aggression against a foreign nation. In the end, the only solution for war between Arab and Arab, Arab and Jew, Arab and Westerner is what the Middle East needs most, the five missing words.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Income-Tax Advocate to Be Weicker's Fiscal Chief

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr., moving quickly to deal with Connecticut's largest fiscal crisis in decades, today named State Representative William J. Cibes of New London, a Democrat who favors a state income tax, as his chief budget adviser.
The appointment of Mr. Cibes, who unsuccessfully sought his party's gubernatorial nomination earlier this year, was praised by Democrats, including Gov. William A. O'Neill. 
 But it instantly raised fears among Republicans that Mr. Weicker, who was elected as an independent, might be heading toward a broad-based income tax to help erase a projected $2.1 billion revenue shortfall for the 1991-92 fiscal year, which begins July 1.
The shortfall, which includes $562 million for this fiscal year, equals almost a third of the state's current $7.1 billion budget.
 
Income Tax Not Ruled Out
 At a news conference in the State Capitol, Mr. Weicker, a liberal and a former Republican who will take office Jan. 9, reiterated his aversion to an income tax, particularly in a recession. But, as he did throughout his gubernatorial campaign, he refused to rule one out.
He said his choice of Mr. Cibes, who is co-chairman of the General Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, was based on the Democrat's expertise in fiscal affairs and the respect he commands in both major political parties."I promised the state of Connecticut I would seek out the best," Mr. Weicker said. "When it comes to the matter of a state budget, there was really only one first choice."
The House minority leader, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol, also praised Mr. Cibes's mastery of the budget process. "He is one of the brightest people walking around these halls," he said.
Mr. Krawiecki added, though, that he was troubled by Mr. Cibes's advocacy of a broad-based income tax, an issue that has long split liberal and conservative lawmakers in the state. Connecticut is one of 10 states that does not have such a tax. It does, however, tax income on dividends, interest and capital gains on a graduated basis, with the top rate, 14 percent, the highest in the nation.
Mr. Cibes and other income-tax proponents have contended that the state's budget problems are a result of an inconsistent and inadequate revenue source: an 8 percent sales tax.
During his gubernatorial campaign, Mr. Cibes recommended a broad income tax starting at 4 percent of the adjusted gross over $25,000 and peaking at 8 percent for incomes over $100,000. He also urged that the sales tax be cut to 5 percent and the corporate tax, the highest in the nation at an effective rate of 13.8 percent, be cut to 10 percent.
The plan would generate $600 million in revenue, or $2.5 billion without the cuts in other taxes.
 
Tax 'a Step Closer'
 "It is one step closer than it was yesterday -- but it's a long journey," the State Republican Party chairman, State Representative Richard Foley Jr., said about an income tax.
Mr. Cibes, whose appointment as secretary of the Office of Policy and Management is expected to be confirmed by the General Assembly, said he would look for spending cuts before recommending ways to increase revenue in the current budget and the 1991-92 budget.
He refused to say whether an income tax was the sole solution to the state's budget problems, a position on which he anchored his gubernatorial campaign. He was resoundingly defeated by Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden in the Democratic primary in September.
"My first duty as secretary of the Office of Policy and Management will be to scrutinize every expenditure made by the state to see if it can be reduced or eliminated," Mr. Cibes said.
 
Appointment No Surprise
 The appointment of Mr. Cibes, who is 47 years old, was not unexpected. Since his victory on Nov. 6, Mr. Weicker has hinted that Mr. Cibes was one of his top choices for the job, now held by Anthony V. Milano. The post is regarded as the most prominent on fiscal policy in the state.
Mr. Cibes's position on the income tax aside, he is a widely respected and well-liked legislator who holds a doctorate in political science from Princeton and has taught political science at Connecticut College in New London since 1969. He has served in the General Assembly since 1978.
"I am a Democrat -- I will always be a Democrat," he said. "But Connecticut faces serious difficulties. It is time to lay aside strong partisan feelings to attempt to achieve the goals that we all share as members of Connecticut's community."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Sunset Publishing Goes To Canada for a Leader

 BODY:
A West Coast publishing company has turned to Canada for leadership.
The new president of the Sunset Publishing Corporation will be Ronald A. Kovas, who was president and chief executive of Southam Business Information and Communications Group Inc. of Toronto. Mr. Kovas, 48, replaces John F. Henning Jr., who becomes vice chairman after eight years as president.
The Sunset Publishing Corporation, based in the San Francisco suburb of Menlo Park, publishes Sunset magazine, a 92-year-old chronicle of life in the West with a monthly circulation of 1.4 million in 13 Western states. It also has more than 200 book titles in print through its Sunset Books publishing division.
Since June 1 the company has been owned by Time Publishing Ventures Inc., a unit of Time Inc. Magazine Company.
Mr. Kovacs, who assumed his new position yesterday, has spent most of the last decade in Canada -- with Southam since June 1988 and as president of the J. Walter Thompson Company advertising agency in Toronto for six years. But he has worked and gone to school in California, and that was important, Time officials said.
"In addition to possessing the vision, strategic planning expertise and leadership skills needed to insure Sunset's continued growth and success, Ron is very familiar with the West," said Christopher Meigher, president and chief executive of Time Publishing Ventures Inc.
Mr. Kovas received degrees in history and economics from Stanford University and an M.B.A. from the Kellogg School of Advanced Management at Northwestern University. He then spent 22 years with J. Walter Thompson's corporate parent, the JWT Group,Inc.

HEADLINE: George Bush, Meet Woodrow Wilson

BYLINE: By John B. Judis; John B. Judis is author of the forthcoming book "Grand Illusion: Critics and Champions of the American Century."

DATELINE: KENSINGTON, Md.

 BODY:
In May 1915, a year after World War I began, Woodrow Wilson called for establishment of a League of Nations, which, through collective means, would prevent future world wars from breaking out. His proposal -- partly embodied in the feeble post-World War I League and then after World War II in the U.N. -- never achieved the kind of collective security he hoped for.
In the wake of Iraq's conquest of Kuwait, President Bush seems to have revived Mr. Wilson's proposal. In his address to Congress on Sept. 11, Mr. Bush called for the creation of a "new world order . . . in which nations recognize the shared responsibility for freedom and justice." 
 Is this quest for collective security and a new world order a recurring delusion that well-meaning statesmen like Presidents Wilson and Bush use to rationalize their more narrowly conceived actions? Or is it a practical goal that is worth pursuing even if it has eluded us?
As America's place in the world has changed in the last 75 years, the argument for collective security has also changed. In 1915, the U.S. was weaker militarily than Britain and Germany but had become the world's strongest country economically.
Mr. Wilson saw the League of Nations as a means of curbing great-power imperialism, which had caused World War I, and of laying the groundwork for a disarmed world order in which economic strength -- the U.S.'s strong suit -- would prevail over military strength.
Today, the U.S. remains the strongest military power but lags behind Europe and Japan in key industries. With a decaying infrastructure and educational system and soaring public and private debt, the U.S. could fall behind even further.
It was evident in recent weeks as the Administration tried simultaneously to defend the Persian Gulf and reduce the budget deficit that the U.S. no longer has the funds and resources to act unilaterally in the world. Seventy-five years ago, it sought collective security to insure its economic superiority; today, it has to seek collective security for the sake of economic solvency.
But is collective security possible? President Wilson's proposal foundered on the Russian Revolution, which split the West; on the refusal of Britain, France, Italy and Japan to abandon imperial ambitions, and on the opposition in the U.S. of Republican imperialists and progressives.
The imperialists, led by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, insisted that the U.S., combining military and economic superiority, had to remain the master of its own fate.
The progressives, led by Senator William Borah, attacked the League as an instrument for maintaining the British-dominated division of the world.
Today, two major obstacles to Mr. Wilson's dream of collective security have been removed: the European and Japanese empires have been dissolved and the cold war has ended. What remains are domestic obstacles, a lack of urgency among the major powers (except, ironically, the Soviet Union) and an absence of inspired international leadership to forge new arrangements.
Mr. Bush's proposal for a new world order has encountered opposition from descendants of Senators Lodge and Borah. Republican conservatives are divided over tactics in the gulf. But they agree that pursuing new collective security arrangements is -- as John O'Sullivan, editor of the National Review put it -- "bunkum." They want the U.S. to remain militarily supreme and unbounded by commitments to a revived U.N. or other supranational body.
Left-wing opponents of Mr. Bush's intervention in the gulf dismiss the proposal for a new world order -- "prattle," editor Erwin Knoll's Progressive called it -- as a rationalization for imperial ambitions there. Where Senator Borah and the progressives questioned Britain's motives in supporting collective security, today's left questions our Government's motives.
The right ignores not only our country's economic plight but also the diplomatic pitfalls of unilateral action; the left, still reeling from Vietnam, sees our foreign policy through the prism of that era's lies and deceptions.
The Bush Administration has done little to meet these challenges to its policies. After proclaiming a new world order to be their "fifth objective" in the gulf, Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James Baker have been decidedly vague in spelling out what that order entails.
Does it mean a strengthened U.N.? And new regional security arrangements in the gulf and elsewhere? Will the U.S. be willing to put its own military under international leadership? In the gulf, Mr. Bush has rejected a U.N. command outright.
Sometimes, when Administration officials describe their goals, they say the U.S. must reduce its military burden and commitment. Other times, they appear determined to seek new arrangements in order to preserve U.S. military supremacy and to justify new expenditures.
In September, Pentagon officials hinted that even after Iraq was driven from Kuwait, they anticipated keeping 10,000 U.S. troops in the gulf and establishing new bases throughout the region. Mr. Baker has suggested that the U.S. could set up a NATO-like structure in the Persian Gulf.
By sending 230,000 more troops to the gulf, with the result that U.S. forces will outnumber Arab and European forces 4 to 1, Mr. Bush threatens to undermine the concept of a multilateral force and has set the stage for what may end up as a unilateral U.S. offensive. Not only Kuwait but also plans for a new world order may perish in the process.
As our involvement in the Persian Gulf deepens and becomes more perilous, it becomes important for Mr. Bush to explain fully why we are there and what larger objectives we hope to fulfill. Taking a first step toward a new world order could be a legitimate goal, but Americans have to understand better what this could involve. Otherwise, Mr. Bush's proposal, like Mr. Wilson's, may become another faded dream.
