HEADLINE: Soviet Army Coup? Not Likely

BYLINE: By Richard Pipes; Richard Pipes, professor of history at Harvard, is author of "The Russian Revolution."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Is the Soviet Army, the spoiled darling of the Communist regime, ready to rise up and seize power? Many Russians think so, and Mikhail Gorbachev even took the remarkable step last week of denying rumors that it would.
Unquestionably, morale is at an all-time low. Generals are openly grumbling about cuts in the defense budget, the surrender of Eastern Europe and, most of all, the reforms in economic and political life carried out in the name of perestroika. 
 When the Red Army was created in 1918, Lenin, worried about the counter-revolutionary potential of a professional officer corps, made certain that it was penetrated from top to bottom by the Communist Party. As it evolved, party control was exercised by two institutions.
The Main Political Administration was placed in charge of political indoctrination to insure that the military faithfully followed party directives. Party cells were introduced into all units of regimental size and higher. Three-quarters of the officers are party members and subject to party discipline; among the generals, membership approaches 100 percent.
The Red Army, however, is not monolithic. While the generals are overwhelmingly conservative, the officers of middle and lower rank sympathize with the democratic parties. The split was evident in voting records in the Congress of Peoples Deputies of the Russian Republic, where 82 percent of the generals have sided with the conservatives and only 18 percent with the democratic bloc. Among junior officers, the proportion was nearly reversed (22 percent to 73 percent). Furthermore, there are divisions between officers of Russian nationality and those from the borderland republics, especially the Ukraine.
Mikhail Gorbachev's effort to deprive the party of a monopoly over politics has met with furious resistance from the upper echelons of the officer corps. To them, the party's monopoly safeguards the military against the divisive political activities that undermined discipline and led to the army's demise in 1917.
A number of prominent officers have put the Government on notice that they will not tolerate political pluralism in their ranks. They have reconciled themselves to the emasculation of the Main Political Administration, which has been recently deprived of its traditional role as the official agency of Marxist-Leninist indoctrination. But they have managed to beat off attempts to introduce political pluralism into the armed forces.
In the future, as in the past, the only organized political activity among the military will be conducted by party cells. Since junior officers' promotions depend on Communist colonels and generals, it is unlikely that they will dare to press for greater democracy. In other words, an anomalous and potentially dangerous situation has emerged with the party disestablished in society at large but retaining a monopoly on political activity in the military establishment.
Soviet generals also resist the transition to a market economy, since they run not only the armed forces but also what it has become fashionable in the Soviet Union to call the "military-industrial complex." The projected conversion of numerous defense industries to civilian production imperils their jobs. Thus, the military sector continues to enjoy the highest priority on industrial resources.
The generals are dismayed by the decline in the prestige of the military. They speak bitterly of officers being abused and even physically assaulted. They deplore the growing trend to draft dodging (this fall, 400,000 men have failed to report for induction) and the passage of laws by several republics restricting active service by their inhabitants to the republics in which they reside. They are appalled by talk of an all-volunteer army and alternate service. They blame glasnost for what they perceive as the spread of "Russophobia" and for declining national morale.
To counter trends that diminish their power, prestige and influence, the generals are loudly warning that the country faces the threat of external aggression. Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, Mr. Gorbachev's military adviser, talks of a U.S. military menace and the dangers posed by the American buildup in the Persian Gulf. Gen. Albert Makashov, who commands the Ural military district, claims World War III is in progress and that the U.S. is winning.
Such open defiance of civilian authorities is without precedent not only in Soviet but in Russian history; indeed, it would not be tolerated in any Western democracy. In the past several months, Mr. Gorbachev's civilian opponents have quietly retired into the background, letting the generals carry the brunt of the struggle against his reforms.
This struggle seems to be nearing a climax. When Mr. Gorbachev met with more than 1,000 military deputies on Nov. 13, their booing and heckling forced him to cut short his address. The next day, Marshal Akhromeyev warned that the armed forces would not stand by and watch the Soviet Union disintegrate.
This new practice of openly challenging civilian authority has alarmed many people and fed the rumors of coups. In mid-September, word spread in Moscow that several army divisions and a regiment of paratroopers had been deployed around the city to overthrow the Government under the pretext of protecting it from a democratic insurrection. The army command denied these rumors, claiming one day that it had assembled the troops to rehearse for a parade and the next that they were to help harvest the potato crop (in full combat gear, no less). But the Supreme Soviet took the reports seriously enough to appoint two committees to look into them.
Could a military coup succeed? The yearning for law and order, for a strong hand, is prevalent in the population, and the conservatives could exploit it to introduce a Pinochet-style military dictatorship. But the difficulties are formidable.
The disparity in political attitudes between the generals and their subordinates suggests that, should they decide to strike, the generals could run into open defiance from field officers. Army and K.G.B. field commanders have stated publicly that they would disobey orders to fire on civilians. There is also no assurance that non-Russian officers, especially the Ukrainians, would do as told.
Finally, it is questionable whether the army, even in alliance with conservative party elements, could impose its will and solve the problems of a country as large and unstable as the Soviet Union. Nevertheless, the danger exists and it is troublesome not only for Soviet citizens but also for the U.S., whose defense and foreign policies assume a benign and cooperative Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Let Them Eat Bread

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
ITEM: In yet another bid to prevent the Soviet Union from disintegrating in its winter of discontent, Mikhail Gorbachev reorganizes his Government and hints that full-blown rationing will be needed to feed the nation.
Item: World trade negotiations are on the verge of collapse because European leaders cannot bring themselves to say no to their subsidy-addicted, overproducing farmers. 
 For government crisis managers from Tokyo to Washington, this adds up to trouble as usual, two more reasons to stay late at the office drafting memos. But to Jagdish Bhagwati and Padma Desai, Columbia University's distinguished husband-wife economics team, it is an opportunity to appeal to the idealist lurking in the heart of every skeptic: We have too much food, and they have too little. Isn't there room for a deal?
The Bhagwati-Desai proposal, presented in abbreviated form on The New York Times's Op-Ed page last week, is simplicity itself. With Soviet production heading south and its agricultural distribution system in chaos, the country is no longer even close to self-sufficient in bread and sausage. Widespread hunger, if not serious malnutrition, is likely in coming months unless the Government uses its dwindling foreign reserves for emergency imports. But more spent on food means less to spend for a dozen other consumer priorities, further restricting Moscow's room to maneuver in its efforts to avoid becoming the first nuclear-armed superpower to self-destruct.
Meanwhile, in Geneva, talks aimed at smoothing critical sources of trade friction among the world's industrialized democracies have reached thebrinkmanship stage. America, along with other agricultural producers, is threatening to walk unless the European Community sets a timetable for eliminating the sorcerer's apprentice subsidies that have transformed Europe's hopelessly inefficient farm sector into an unstoppable export machine.
Why not turn incipient tragedy into triumph, say Mr. Bhagwati and Ms. Desai, redirecting the fruits of Europe's offending farm subsidies from competitive world markets to Soviet dinner tables. The food need not be labeled a handout: Europe could lend the Soviets the money, with repayment scheduled for 1995 and beyond -- when the economy might be out of the intensive care ward.
There is a chance, of course, that whoever rules the 15 Soviet republics in five years will be unwilling or unable to pay back Mikhail Gorbachev's debts. Were the credits tied, however, to a Soviet commitment to eliminate consumer subsidies on nonessentials, Ms. Desai argues, the prospects for keeping the Soviet Union creditworthy would begreatly improved. Those subsidies now bloat the Government's budget deficit, threatening to bury tentative market changes in a tide of inflation.
In any case, the economists contend, Europe should take the chance. The risk of never seeing the marks and francs again seems a reasonable price to pay to placate domestic farmers and enjoy the benefits of open world trade.
It is easy to count the reasons that the deal will not be made -- and, perhaps, should not be made. For one thing, the latest Kremlin shuffle only reaffirms fears that no one retains the political and moral authority to see perestroika through to the end. Helping Mikhail Gorbachev survive the collapse of the Communist system that propelled him to power could alienate leaders of the republics -- notably Boris Yeltsin -- with greater political staying power. If the skeptics are right, moreover, there would be no practical way to attach strings to Western goodies: radical economic change is so painful that any short-term relief of the pressure for change will inevitably lead to prevarication.
Nor would it necessarily be a blessing to let Europe's farmers and their friends in high political places off the hook. European industry knows it has much to gain from a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round of international trade talks, and the opportunity to build a coalition to serve as a counterweight to European farmers may not recur for years. Moreover, if a stake does not soon penetrate the heart of the Western European farm lobby, Eastern Europe's hopes for developing an efficient, export-oriented farm sector will be dashed by their neighbors' protectionism.
Yet dreams of helping frightened, impoverished people, newly freed from the yoke of Stalinism and eager to join the community of civilized nations, do not die easily. Could the rules of realpolitik be suspended just long enough to feed Soviet pensioners and keep the trade talks on track? The only way to know, perhaps, would be to take a chance.

HEADLINE: A School in Minnesota Doesn't Have a Principal

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HILL CITY, Minn.

 BODY:
What was once the principal's office has a conference table in it now. The name plate on the door is covered with a slash of masking tape with the word "SHARE" scrawled across it.
In this remote northern Minnesota town, where the business district is half a dozen stores and the roads turn to dirt a block off the main street, the local school is conducting an unusual experiment. 
 For the third year, the Hill City School, with 28 teachers and 330 students in kindergarten through 12th grade, has no principal. Instead, a six-member committee of teachers, the Share Team, is in charge.
 
One Complaint: Discipline
 Despite complaints from some parents and students that discipline is inconsistent and cumbersome -- a group of high school students once stormed out in protest over that issue -- many here say the Share Team works. They say it has reinvigorated the staff, made the budget process easier, brought in a host of new academic and extracurricular programs and successfully dealt with teachers whose conduct was unacceptable.
"A lot of good things have happened," said Darrell Nelson, the Superintendent of Independent School District 2, who plans to ask the state for permission to continue the experiment another three years. "The Share Team might not work as well as a really excellent principal. But it is certainly a lot better than a poor one."
Other school districts across the nation, including those in Miami and New York City, are experimenting with restructuring school administrations with the aim of getting teachers and parents more involved in running the schools. But when Hill City's Share Team volunteered on short notice to replace a principal who had quit suddenly, they took the now familiar jargon of school reform -- site-based management, shared decision-making and teacher empowerment -- and stretched it farther than most.
Reform models usually involve the principal and a committee of parents and teachers making major decisions. Experts say that probably fewer than a handful of schools have gone the route of eliminating the principal's job altogether.
About 200 miles north of Minneapolis, where Highway 169 is a two-lane road slicing through hay fields and pine forests, the small cluster of buildings in Hill City do not draw enough traffic to warrant a signal light.
But in this pastoral setting, there are problems nonetheless: boredom, isolation, alcoholism, broken homes, teen-age pregnancy and unemployment. More than half the children at the school are eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches. The school, some teachers said, is the only warm and cheerful place some children have to go to.
 
Meeting Before Classes
 To run it, the Share Team meets every morning for 45 minutes before classes and on Wednesday afternoons for several hours.
At a recent gathering, the agenda included a review of a teacher's proposal to take a third grade class on a field trip on Halloween ("We'd better talk to her; if she has any idea what third graders are like on Halloween, she won't want to do that"); the problem of inappropriate displays of affection among students in the hall (bring up at a faculty meeting); the price of a junior class spaghetti dinner (after much discussion, preschoolers, free; $1.50 for students; $2 for adults), and whether $1,500 of the district's money should be spent sending a teacher to learn about a new teaching approach (the consensus was not to waste money on what might be a fad.)
A principal might have dispensed with some of these items in seconds. But Mr. Nelson, among others, argues that the team approach might save time.
"When you do it this way, you spend much less time handling the mistakes afterwards," he said.
The idea for the Share Team came from a committee of teachers studying new ways of running schools in August 1988 when the principal resigned and the school board had trouble replacing him.
"One day, we were just kicking around ideas and this was suggested and everybody started getting real excited," said Jack Burt, a science teacher who is on the Share Team. "We drafted a proposal, took it to the board and they said O.K." The Staff Helping Administer Responsible Education (Share) Team was born.
Under the plan, the team, which had eight volunteers in the first year, took over the responsibilities of the principal, from curriculum changes and budget decisions to student discipline and teacher evaluations.
 
Boost to Teacher Morale
 Most teachers say the major benefit has been a boost to their morale and creativity. Instead of having a principal dictating changes or endorsing one philosophy, the teachers have a sense of ownership and more freedom to try new things.
"It has opened things up to say: 'If you have an idea and you believe it strongly and really want to do it, go ahead,' " said Linda Bauer, the school's guidance counselor. "Nobody is going to say, 'That's not my philosophy.' "
Loren Brown, who teaches English, agrees: "We're all equals. If you have a concern, not only are you heard, but it is appreciated."
Since the team took charge, a literature-based reading and writing program and Lego/Logo construction sets, a sophisticated computer learning system using building blocks with electronic sensors, have been introduced in the elementary grades. A new math text has been chosen for the upper grades. Each student has been given a teacher adviser, and a program has been started that teaches students how to help resolve the problems of other students.
Sue Kaslow, a school board member who has three children in the school, said she has seen improvements. One of her children had had both behavioral and learning problems that have disappeared, she said.
"There are lots of different styles now," Mrs. Kaslow said. "Some classrooms are very strict. Others are not. The teachers are much happier, and there are different learning experiences for the kids."
Volunteerism among the staff has also shot way up, Mr. Nelson said. The principal used to be forced to assign staff members to watch the lunchroom and the school buses. But now teachers usually sign up and take turns.
The budget process has become friendlier. The team chose to tell teachers what their budgets were, then allowed them to decide how the money would be spent on items like supplies and field trips.
In the past, the principal had asked the teachers for lists of what they wanted but made changes as he saw fit. Since the teachers had no idea how much money was available or how much an item cost, the process usually left them frustrated and angry and took months to settle.
"The difference this has made is just incredible," Mrs. Kaslow said. "What used to take two to three months takes two to three weeks."
 
Some Mixed Reactions
 But the team concept has not been without controversy.
While teachers overwhelmingly support the Share Team, Joe Nathan, a consultant hired by the district to evaluate the experiment, found that students and parents had a more mixed reaction. Mr. Nathan, a senior fellow at the Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota, said much of their displeasure concerned discipline problems.
The school does not have an administrator responsible for discipline. Infractions are handled either by a Share Team member who is free at the time, by several team members or by the entire team at its weekly meeting.
Some students and parents say that the teachers' approaches vary and sometimes, knowing more about the students than a principal would, they tend to meddle too much in students' personal lives. Several students described incidents in which they felt the teachers had gone too far. One involved a girl who had been accused of drinking while at a concert in a nearby town. The teachers, she said, asked her if her mother had drinking problems, too. In another case, a girl was questioned about a visit to a birth control clinic.
"When there was a principal and you did something wrong, you got detention and that was it," said Desi Linquist, a senior. "Now they get too personal."
A series of disputes over discipline and the feeling that there was nobody for the students to talk to prompted a two-day walkout in March 1989, students and Share Team members said. Afterward, the president of the Student Council was invited to attend the weekly team meetings.
Still, not everyone is satisfied that these issues have been resolved. Vernon Bishop ran for and was elected to the school board last year when he felt his son had been unfairly treated by the basketball coach and there was no one to turn to in authority.
"The Share Team probably has some benefits," he said. "But it's like having the police department policing its own people. I don't think that works real well."
 
'It Works Really Well'
 The Superintendent, Mr. Nelson, thinks that has not been a problem. He said the team has taken up the issue of disciplining fellow teachers several times. One case involved telling a colleague that his language in addressing students was too abusive and derogatory. In another, a teacher's sloppy appearance was at issue.
"It works really well," Mr. Nelson said. "It seems to lend more credence to have five or six of your peers sit you down. With a principal it was easier to say, 'Oh, he's just picking on me.' "
Whether the team can continue indefinitely is unclear. Some fear the school might eventually run out of teachers willing to do the extra work.
Each member of the team is paid $4,600 above the regular teaching salary, which can go to $33,000 a year. The additional money the six team members are paid adds up to about half the principal's salary.
But many team members say they routinely spend an extra 10 hours a week at school and sometimes much more.
Elizabeth Paquin, a third-grade teacher, said that with a family to raise she could not consider putting in so many extra hours, despite the extra pay. "The way they work, it's not that much money," she said.

HEADLINE: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
WPP Is Getting a Taste of Tough Times

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
MARTIN SORRELL, the highly regarded chief executive of the WPP Group, is getting a taste of what it is like to be one of the beleaguered Saatchi brothers, Charles and Maurice, his one-time mentors at Saatchi & Saatchi, with whom he is now competing.
The price of London-based WPP's stock has tumbled since the news on Monday that WPP, the world's largest advertising and communications holding company, expected its 1990 pretax profits to be "somewhat less" than brokers' estimates of 110 million, or about $216 million. 
 In trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, WPP's shares lost more than half of their value, plunging to 1.18, or about $2.25. At one point during the day, the share price dipped below a pound.
Analysts now expect WPP's pre-tax profits this year to be about 85 million to 90 million, or $167 million to $176 million. If predictions hold true, that would still exceed last year's profits of 75 million.
Executives at WPP said the company's earnings estimates were revised because of a slowdown in advertising in the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia.
Most of the biggest agencies in this country are feeling the squeeze. Recently, Young & Rubicam, Ayer and Chiat/Day/Mojo each laid off dozens of employees in New York.
But WPP's woes were particularly troubling to analysts. "The market is very concerned about the earnings reduction," said James Dougherty of County NatWest Securities. "We thought we could have high confidence in WPP management, but we've had the rug pulled out from under us."
Last summer, when WPP's stock was trading at 6, Mr. Sorrell confidently told financial analysts that the economic slowdown in the United States and Britian would not have a negative effect on his company.
Mr. Sorrell would not comment on the revised earnings estimates and would not say what, if any, changes it would lead to.
Mr. Sorrell is considered one of the shrewdest deal makers in advertising. He engineered the first hostile takeover of an agency, J. Walter Thompson in 1987, and two years later snatched up one of Madison Avenue's most famous names, Ogilvy & Mather.
But like financially troubled Saatchi & Saatchi, where Mr. Sorrell began his advertising career, WPP paid a high price to put together its empire. Some analysts said a reason for the severe reaction in the financial markets was uneasiness over WPP's mountain of debt, about 350 million, or $686 million.
Some analysts said Mr. Sorrell's latest move was intended to placate his bankers. "The earnings forecasts were reduced to keep the banks from getting nervous about the company's financial situation," said Neil Blackley of James Capel & Company. "WPP is basically sound," he said.
WPP executives said they expected Mr. Sorrell simply to "ride out the storm." The executives also said they did not expect Mr. Sorrell to order any further cost-cutting or layoffs at WPP's two large agency networks, Thompson and Ogilvy.
Analysts said Thompson and Ogilvy were performing well, considering the industry's depressed state. Both have scored substantial successes this year, including the return recently of the $80 million Maxwell House account to Ogilvy.
Some analysts said WPP's earnings outlook would not speed up the negotiations to sell the troubled Scali, McCabe, Sloves unit back to the agency's management. The negotiations have been stalled because Scali cannot come up with the necessary financing.
Scali has been on a losing streak this year. Most recently, it resigned the $40 million Volvo account after a disclosure that a demonstration in a Volvo commercial created by Scali had been faked.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Sued Over Financing Of Health Care

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. and New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield have filed suit seeking an immediate end to the system of financing hospital care for the poor through a hidden tax on hospital bills paid by patients and insurers.
The suit, filed Monday evening in State Superior Court here, charges that the Uncompensated Care Trust Fund system, which collects the payments and disburses them to hospitals, creates labor strife, places employers who provide health-care coverage at a competitive disadvantage with those who do not, and is draining the financial resources of Blue Cross. 
 In 1989, the trust fund disbursed $500 million, collected in surcharges, and this year it is expected to pay out $618 million to New Jersey hospitals.
The system, the only one of its kind in the nation, is scheduled to end on Dec. 31. But a bill has been introduced in the State Senate to continue it for 16 months and to increase the hidden surcharge on patients' hospital bills and insurance premiums to 23 percent from the current 19 percent.
 
Seen as Delaying Tactic
 The entire State Legislature is up for election in 1991 and, in the face of voter anger over new taxes that was evidenced in this month's Congressional elections, the extension is viewed as a way to delay the financing problem until after next year's balloting.
"Unless the court moves quickly to prevent it, we are concerned that the Legislature will simply renew the current system of funding uncompensated care for another 12 to 16 months, and that would be an economic disaster for New Jersey," said Charles A. Marciante, president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. "A blanket renewal of the existing system will serve to drive corporations out of business, force union health plans into bankruptcy, and make paupers out of a whole generation of health-care consumers."
Brenda Bacon, director of Policy and Management for the Florio administration, called the suit "another clear indication of the frustration caused by a system that is rapidly driving people out."
"The system is just collapsing," she said, "and we need to find a consensus to replace this hidden tax that people don't know about with a broad-based method of paying for uncompensated care."
Ms. Bacon was the chairwoman of the Governor's Health Care Study Commission that made 90 recommendations to try to reduce health-care costs, including enactment of a payroll tax to offset the cost of caring for the poor. Employers who provide health-care coverage would be assessed $144 an employee, and those who do not would pay $1,000 a worker.
 
No Endorsement of Report
 Gov. Jim Florio accepted the commission's report last month but has not yet endorsed its provisions, especially the payroll tax, after the angry demonstrations prompted by the adoption of his $2.8 billion tax and school aid programs in June.
Joining in the suit, which seeks to have the method of financing the trust fund declared inequitable and unconstitutional, are Operating Engineers Local 68 and its welfare fund and Newark Refrigeration Warehouse Inc. and Port Newark Refrigeration Warehouse Inc., which employ Local 68 members and contribute to the welfare fund.
The cost of paying Blue Cross premiums for Local 68 workers increased from $2.3 million in 1986 to more than $6.4 million this year, according to the complaint, which was filed with Judge Michael J. O'Neil. Judge O'Neil ordered Frances Dunston, the State Health Commissioner, to respond to the suit by Nov. 30.
Spokesmen for the Health Department and the Attorney General's office in Trenton said that copies of the suit had not yet arrived and that they could not comment.

HEADLINE: Home Building Falls in Quarter

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Housing construction fell by 20 percent in the third quarter, with the Northeast suffering the biggest drop, according to a survey.
F. W. Dodge, the construction information division of McGraw-Hill Inc., said on Monday that starts on new houses, condominiums and apartments totaled 299,299 units in the July- September period, down from 371,792 in the 1989 period.
Only three of the nation's 25 largest home-building areas, Phoenix, Dallas and Indianapolis, showed gains in the period, F. W. Dodge said.
"The Northeast, with its 36 percent setback, continued to set the downward pace," said George A. Christie, vice president and chief economist at Dodge. "The North and South Central regions, with smaller- than-average cutbacks, dampened the general collapse."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Perils Seen for Hussein in New Troop Buildup

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, said today that Iraq's decision to send 250,000 more soldiers to southern Iraq and occupied Kuwait might create "new vulnerabilities" for Baghdad "rather than added strength."
General Powell, in separate appearances on three network morning news programs, did not elaborate on his remarks about the Iraqi reinforcements, which was announced on Monday. But other Pentagon officials mentioned at least three ways that Iraq might be weakened by the move. 
 First, the act could turn Kuwait into a huge trap for Iraqi forces. Concentrated in a relatively small geographic region, the Iraqi troops would be more vulnerable to air attacks, and to attempts to cut their supply and communications lines from Baghdad.
Second, feeding and supplying 250,000 more troops, on top of the 430,000 the Pentagon says are already in Kuwait and southern Iraq, would place tremendous strains on Iraq's logistical support system.
 
The Costs Mount
 Some specialists on Middle East armies have estimated that it could cost Baghdad as much as $15 billion a year to feed and supply the additional troops, taxing an economy already feeling the pinch of international trade sanctions.
Third, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would probably draw some of the additional forces -- a combination of 150,000 newly organized reserves and seven divisions of the regular Iraqi Army -- from troops defending Iraq's borders with Iran, Turkey and Syria. Iraqi defenses along those frontiers would be weakened.
If the reinforcements were diverted from the 100,000 men stationed on the mountainous border with Turkey, it would make it more difficult for Iraq to put down any insurgency among Kurds in that region.
Defense Department officials said there was no indication that Iraq had started to send any of the additional forces.
"We have not seen any evidence of that deployment," the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said. "If they're going to do it, it could take well over a month."
 
Actual Movement Uncertain
 General Powell and other Defense Department officials expressed doubt that the reinforcements would dramatically increase the threat to the 430,000 United States and other allied forces now in the gulf region.
"It's not clear that large numbers of additional, probably less capable units significantly adds to his combat power in theater," General Powell said on the CBS News program, "This Morning."
"He may be thinking of doing some rotations and some reliefs in place," he said. "But at the moment, it's just part of his headline-of-the-day program, where he tries to divert world opinion from his own aggression."
General Powell said that military intelligence would carefully monitor any Iraqi troop buildup, but that there were no immediate plans to add to the more than 150,000 American reinforcements that President Bush said on Nov. 8 would be sent to the gulf region.
 
Amphibious, but No Landing
 As Pentagon officials mulled over the Iraqi reinforcements, American and Saudi forces were completing a six-day amphibious exercise, which the Pentagon called Imminent Thunder, in northeastern Saudi Arabia.
Rough seas forced cancellation of the landing itself, and Mr. Williams said he could not predict what the Marines would do in if high swells hit during actual combat.
Mr. Williams said that despite the canceled landing, "the majority of the goals of the exercise were accomplished."
Helicopter-borne marines practiced beach assaults. Carrier-based planes practiced giving air protection to troops landing on shore. American and Saudi aircraft out drills to practice coordinating communications.
 
Not Far From Kuwait
 About 1,000 marines, 16 ships and more than 1,100 American and Saudi aircraft joined the drill, the most ambitious of three exercises the United States has conducted since sending troops to the gulf. The two others were carried out in Oman.
The bulk of the exercise was held about 100 miles south of the Saudi border with Kuwait, and a smaller land drill with marines and their Saudi counterparts was carried out about 25 miles from the frontier.
Saudi Arabia reportedly objected to conducting the exercise any closer to Kuwaiti territory, fearing that this might provoke Iraqi forces.
"We weren't trying to provoke Mr. Saddam Hussein," General Powell said on the ABC program, "Good Morning America." "But at the same time, I don't think it's a bad idea for him to see what our capability is in the region."

HEADLINE: To Quiet Its Own Critics, China Aims at Japan

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Perhaps getting tired of criticizing only the United States, China's official press has found a new target: Japan.
The flurry of critical articles may reflect the Chinese Government's desire to rally nationalist support behind it, as well as to outmaneuver dissidents who would like to hold anti-Japan protests as an implicit reproof of their own leaders. 
 Students at several universities in Beijing discussed holding an anti-Japan demonstration recently, and even applied formally with the Government for permission to hold the protest, said a university teacher with first-hand knowledge. The Government rejected the application -- it had labeled similar protests in 1985 "reactionary" -- and the students decided not to hold an illegal protest, the teacher said.
Tensions with Japan came to light last month, over Tokyo's plans to send troops to the Persian Gulf and over a territorial dispute about some uninhabited islands in the East China Sea. The dispute about ownership of the islands, called Senkaku in Japan and the Diaoyu Islands by China, aroused a storm throughout the Chinese-speaking world and led to anti-Japan demonstrations in Hong Kong and Taiwan.
The Chinese and Japanese Governments seemed to prefer to allow the matter to die down, and the leadership in Beijing may have been worried that nationalist demonstrations would spread to the Chinese mainland. In 1985, university students in Beijing and the central Chinese city of Wuhan protested against Japan, accusing it of economic imperialism and of trying to cover up World War II atrocities.
The 1985 protests were also critical of the Chinese Government, for not defending the national honor and for allowing China to become so weak that such humiliations were possible. University campuses brim with discontent these days, and the Government may fear that students would seize upon a non-political issue to start a new round of anti-Government protests.
The latest issue to bedevil relations is the assertion by a prominent Japanese nationalist that China has greatly exaggerated the Japanese Army's atrocities during the 1937-38 "Rape of Nanjing." The comment was made by Shintaro Ishihara, who is best known for his book "The Japan That Can Say No."
After a delay, as China's Propaganda Department was apparently deciding how to handle the matter, People's Daily published an article attacking Mr. Ishihara under the headline "Lies Cannot Obscure Facts Written in Blood."
Mr. Ishihara then suggested that itwas his detractors who were the liars. After another delay, People's Daily responded with a long, stinging article on Sunday, accompanied by an editorial cartoon of Mr. Ishihara and two photos of what it said were Japanese atrocities during the Rape of Nanjing.
"The troops of Japanese aggression committed monstrous crimes at Nanjing 53 years ago," the People's Daily editors wrote in a note above Sunday's article. "With extreme brutality and cruelty, they killed more than 300,000 Chinese."
Some Western estimates of the number killed are lower, but historians generally agree that the casualties were enormous and that the incident left a major imprint on the Chinese psyche.

HEADLINE: Washington to New York on 4.3 Gallons

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Some drivers are not willing to trade size and smooth ride for fuel economy, but for those who are, no car sold in the United States gets better gasoline mileage than the Geo Metro. On a recent drive from Washington to New York, the car, made in Japan by the Suzuki Motor Company and sold by the General Motors Corporation, consumed 4.3 gallons, which comes to 58 miles a gallon.
The Metro's fuel economy, as determined by the Environmental Protection Agency, is 54 miles a gallon. The average car on the road in 1990 gets 20 miles a gallon, according to the Department of Energy. If every car did as well as the Metro, gasoline consumption, now about 7.3 million barrels a day, would fall to 2.7 million barrels a day, a drop of 4.6 million barrels. 
 Last year, imports averaged 8.1 million barrels a day, so such a switch -- if not accompanied by an increase in the number of cars or the average number of miles each was driven -- would cut imports by more than half.
 
High Technology
 The Metro does the job through high technology and plain old shrinkage. The Metro weighs 1,600 pounds, halfway between an intermediate car and a bicycle.
Part of the weight loss is from the engine, which is a mere 157 pounds. It is made of aluminum and has three cylinders. (Dropping the fourth cylinder adds six miles a gallon, G.M. engineers say.) To compensate for its small size, the engine squeezes the fuel-air mixture to nine times atmospheric pressure before lighting the spark, a higher ratio than in most cars, allowing more horsepower for each pound of engine weight.
The five-speed manual transmission is wired to a light on the dashboard that reminds the driver when to shift up. The light urges shifting when revolutions per minute are low relative to when most drivers would shift on their own. That raises mileage at the expense of performance.
With its low weight, the car does not need power steering, which adds weight to other cars. The copy that General Motors keeps for test drives lacks even ordinary refinements like a passenger-side mirror and a rear-window defogger.
The model driven to Washington had an ashtray but no lighter, and no radio. And while plusher versions are available, the Metro is designed as a price leader as well as a mileage leader. The Metro is the least expensive model in the Geo line, with a list price for the 1990 version at just under $6,000.
The car handles nimbly and its performance is nothing special, a compliment for a car with mileage 200 percent over average. Pulling from a line of stopped traffic on the Baltimore-Washington Parkway into the adjacent lane, where the traffic was moving at about 50 miles an hour, the Metro performed much as any other small car would. Coming out of the toll booth at the Baltimore Harbor Tunnel, it reached 55 miles an hour in about 15 seconds, as fast as other cars were accelerating.
It does this on 58 horsepower, about half the average. But it does leave the driver feeling in much more intimate contact with the road and all of its bumps. And designers have shrunk the back seat to a size functional for no one but small children.

GRAPHIC: Photo: America's most fuel-efficient car, the Japanese-made Geo Metro sold by the General Motors Corporation, averages 54 miles a gallon. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Anticipating Jitters, Not Jingling

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Store executives across the nation, anticipating a disappointing Christmas season beginning Friday, have already cut back on merchandise and held big sales. But a few, seeing a glimmer of hope in their early November sales, say the situation is so uncertain that results could end up being much better than predicted.
Many stores, having looked hard at the stuttering sales of recent months, are not taking any chances. To try to seize control early, chains ranging from Nordstrom to Sears and from Saks to Woolworth have in recent weeks reduced the number of items they keep in stock and cut their non-sales staffs. 
 Acutely aware that this 32-day holiday shopping period will be more crucial than usual, they also began Christmas promotions disguised as "one-day," "pre-Thanksgiving Day" and "customer appreciation" sales as long as two weeks ago. Some stores have also put extra effort into their holida windows and in-store displays.
 
Canceled Orders
 In one twist, nervous buying managers appear to have canceled more merchandise orders than usual just before the season. That has given some other retailers, perhaps their competitors, the chance to scoop up the goods at cheap prices and to offer them to the public at discounts of as much as 50 percent.
"We have just bought millions of dollars of jogging suits, fleece sweaters, ties and men's shirts at one-third to 50 percent off the wholesale price that other retailers backed off from," said Joseph Levy, chairman of Gottschalks, a chain of 22 department stores based in Fresno, Calif. "That's about four to five times what we've ever done before."
Executives at the nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Company, see Christmas customers remaining cautious, particularly on big-ticket items. Yet the chain finds strong sales on the I.B.M. PS1 computer, big-screen television and camcorders, which can be considered high-ticket goods, said Matt Howard, senior vice president for marketing.
Sears has extended weekend hours at most of its stores, promoting its "bonus" plan in which credit customers get a 1 percent rebate on any purchases of at least $200 and is also offering a five-minute credit authorization to new customers on Sears cards if they have Visa or Mastercard.
Sears is also working with its most important suppliers to offer customers "special goods and special prices" on some styles and models, Mr. Howard said.
For now and the next two or three weeks, consumers will find lower prices on widely advertised national and store brands of electronics, toys and clothing. But as the bargain-hunting flurry dies down, shoppers will probably have some trouble finding the models, sizes and colors they want. That is partly because stores, afraid of being stuck with unsold merchandise, have been cautious about building up much depth in their inventories.
Normally accounting for as much as 30 percent of the year's sales and up to 50 percent of profits, a Christmas sales season that is flat could mean additional financial troubles at some of the more highly leveraged of the nation's biggest and best-known retailers inflicted with high debt. Those most often mentioned in industry circles are Macy's, which also operates Bullock's, and I. Magnin in Southern California; Carter Hawley Hale Stores, which owns the Broadway chain in the Southwest; Federated Department Stores, owner of Bloomingdale's among others, and Ames Department Stores.
The companies insist they are in no danger of going out of business, even if Christmas sales are unspectacular.
Many smaller highly leveraged companies face an uncertain future as well.
 
Impact of Mideast Crisis
 "The question of how a company might be affected by a tough season depends on how much each one owes the bank," said James F. Nordstrom, a co-chairman of Nordstrom Inc., the big Seattle-based fashion chain. "I am always optimistic. But being optimistic five years ago meant you were expected a 20 percent sales gain. Now, it means any gain at all."
The dour outlook for what should be American retailing's big splurge comes from almost a year of erratic sales combined with an even worse trend beginning in August with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Many American retailers, battered by lower third-quarter profits and disappointing October sales, are expressing only limited optimism. Others say that a lack of consumer confidence and the Mideast crisis have made this season so much of an enigma that they will not really have a handle on it until the last week or 10 days.
The Christmas pot for retailers is a huge one. In December last year, department store sales totaled $14.4 billion, up almost 6 percent from the year before. Given the average of 3.5 percent after-tax profit, this meant that United States merchants would have earned about $504 million on their sales.
 
Keeping Up an Image
 But since many retailers slashed prices just to bring shoppers into their stores, as they are doing now, their profits were lower than expected. That will probably be the case again this year. In fact, industry experts say the drumbeat of sales has conditioned consumers to expect discounted prices on a wide range of goods from an wide number of stores.
Some chains, like Brooks Brothers, are striving hard to keep up their image (and profits) by resisting the pressure. But as a top New York fashion store executive who asked not to be identified said, "Even though we hold ourselves above these constant sales, our shoppers are into it and we must not ignore that."
Some top executives at high-debt companies say the potential effects of a bad Christmas season may well be exaggerated because of cautious measures they have already taken.
"Christmas is an important part of the year's business, but we have anticipated a bit of a slowdown and factored it into our plans," said Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive of Federated Stores Inc., the parent of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, Burdines, Jordan Marsh and other stores, all of which are in voluntary bankruptcy. "In fact, I don't think the holiday will be as bad as expected by some of those who see a disastrous turndown. With our stores, unless there is a catastrophic difference between what we have planned and what evolves, it will not be a make-or-break situation."
 
'A Nerve-Wracking Business'
 Employees closer to retailing's front lines are feeling the holiday pressures.
Carol Voss, a women's sportswear buyer for Lazarus, a Federated division in Ohio, said in a telephone interview from Cincinnati: "It's always a nerve-racking business waiting for the big season. As a buyer for the last 16 years, I wouldn't call it my most challenging year but there is still a lot of tension about how it will all come out and how good will the profit be. But then again, you can take so much pressure and then you tell yourself, 'I'll let it roll off my back.' "
Despite the fact that Lazarus as a Federated division is also in bankruptcy, she added: "I find there's still an opportunity for creativity. Since we have been disciplined about orders, I still have a lot of money to spend for holiday goods. If a trend develops, we'll use the money."
The New York executive who cited the effect of constant sales also said: "I'm very cautious and we aren't going out to buy in anticipation of big increases. But I do think, too, that we are all talking ourselves into a recession, particularly with the media constantly playing up bad news. I think that this sort of thing makes people who have money feel guilty about spending it."
 
Mood of the Creditors
 A good or bad season aside, the potential effect on the high-debt companies will depend on "how indulgent their creditors are," said Andrew D. Regan, retail analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York. In Macy's case, he said that the major investors and creditors have too much invested in loans or real estate to "let Macy's slip into a bankruptcy."
"Federated is in a more delicate position," he said.
He said that Carter Hawley Hale was "in a tough situation but is not shedding millions of dollars," while Ames Department Stores was protected by already having shrunk its business "to a level of operating viability."
Daniel Levy, executive vice president of Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation, the parent of the Chicago-based retail chain, said he expected a 5 to 7 percent sales increase. He said the company had increased its advertising of apparel and added to its circulation in full-color inserts. Like a growing number of retailers this year, Wards is also participating in a joint-promotion program, with Mastercard International. Credit card users can obtain special discounts through a Ward's coupon book.
Edison Brothers Stores of St. Louis operates the Jeans West, Oak Tree and other young men's specialty apparel chains. Martin K. Sneider, president, said the more fashion-oriented chains will "be more aggressive on price." But he said that classic items, like chambray shirts and tennis sweaters, will be much in demand "and won't need any price slashing."
Predicting that retailers are being overcautious on inventory, Walter K. Levy, the New York retail marketing consultant, said: "Some retailers may be attempting to maintain liquidity by holding out buying funds and hoping thereby to pay less for the goods. But they may be disappointed because the big retailers are able to use their muscle to get what they want when they want it."
He added that "the name of the game in today's retailing is conversion -- converting the looker into a customer and the customer into a higher-ticket item." He said: "This can only be done by clearly identifying the hot item and getting rid of the clutter. Retailers do not do a very good job in that respect."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise as Commodities Fall

DATELINE: KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Another big drop in the price of basic commodities gave impetus to the credit markets yesterday. Prices of Treasury securities rose, and interest rates fell in generally thin trading.
Most of the gain was relegated to long-term notes and bonds, which are more susceptible to shifts in inflation expectations than shorter-term issues. 
 The driving force in the market was a drop in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 leading commodity prices, which fell by 3.29 points, to 223.15, its lowest level since July 1989. In addition, dealers said, a report on housing activity during October was even weaker than expected, and provided some additional support to the market.
 
Looking Down the Road
 "Clearly, the commodity markets are telling us that the primary impact of rising oil prices is to exacerbate woes in the economy rather than to promote an acceleration in inflation," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a firm in Princeton, N.J., that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. "These price movements are a leading indicator of what is in store for the economy in the months ahead."
But as on Monday, when prices slipped by about the same amount as they rose yesterday, dealers said they did not attach much significance to the moves.
"With a light economic calendar and the Fed having just made a move, all we are doing is chopping around right now," a government bond trader said. "It's what usually happens in a week that is distorted by a holiday."
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 103 5/32, up by 18/32, to yield 8.45 percent, down from 8.51 percent late on Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 101 3/8, up by 10/32, to yield 8.29 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/32, up by 1/32, to yield 7.58 percent.
 
Short-Term Rates Mixed
 Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrrowly mixed.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.08 percent, up by a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.04 percent. One-year bill rates dipped, also by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 6.84 percent.
Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a $300 million offering of 10-year notes by the ICI Finance Corporation, an American unit of ICI P.L.C., the British chemicals giant.
The 9 1/2 percent notes, which mature on Nov. 15, 2000, were priced at $99.82, to yield 9.527 percent, or 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The debt offering was ICI's first in the United States in about four years, corporate finance specialists said. In large measure, the offering was prompted by the recent big drop in the value of the dollar against the British pound and other leading European currencies. The decline has made financing in the United States attractive for many companies based in Britain, as well as on the Continent.
Goldman, Sachs & Company was lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Besides the ICI deal, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation offered $150 million of first-mortgage bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 9.75 percent securities, which mature Nov. 1, 2005, were priced at $100, or par, or 1.45 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was light, traders said. Prices of most issues rose by about a quarter of a point on the day.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about an eighth of a point in quiet pre-holiday trading.

HEADLINE: Brady Warns Regulators About Credit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
Reflecting the growing view in the Bush Administration that unnecessarily tight credit is contributing to softness in the economy, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged bankers and Government regulators last night to take steps to make loans more readily available.
In a speech at a dinner of the New York chapter of the Arthritis Foundation, Mr. Brady said that even in hard times banks had many ways to strengthen their balance sheets without restricting loans to creditworthy customers. 
 "I know that it is never easy to cut costs or even dividends or to agree to combine with a longtime rival," Mr. Brady said. "These are tough solutions to tough problems. But they've got to be faced."
To regulators, the Secretary said: "Use some judgment. Apply some balance. Don't use unrealistically negative scenarios in evaluating loans. Don't overreact."
This was the first time Mr. Brady has suggested publicly that overkill by the regulators may be partly to blame for the tighter credit policies of many banks. Within the Administration, he has generally sided with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in holding that the slowdown in bank lending reflects market forces, not regulatory practices. Other top officials, including Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, have argued that bank regulators have been too zealous.
The Federal Reserve Board reported Monday that a survey of top loan officers last month indicated that banks were continuing to toughen their lending standards and turn away good customers. If many companies cannot borrow the money they need, business activity will suffer, putting a drag on the national economy.
Asked about the Secretary's apparent criticism of regulators, a senior Treasury official said Mr. Brady did not "mean to suggest that regulators have applied improper standards." He merely wanted to say: "Use good judgment. Don't assume that $100 oil is likely to go on for two years," the official said.
Mr. Brady's appearance at the fund-raising dinner of the Arthritis Foundation, held in the Pierre Hotel, had a personal touch. He suffered for years from arthritis of the hip and underwent hip-replacement surgery last winter at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.
For months, the Treasury has been working on a study of deposit insurance and the overall structure of the banking system, and its report is due around New Year's Day.
Mr. Brady declined to specify last night what recommendations would be made but he declared, "It's time to overhaul the system."
After the report is published, the Bush Administration is expected to propose legislation that would rewrite laws enacted during the Depression that limit the capacity of banks to operate across state lines and prohibit them from expanding into such areas as underwriting securities, selling insurance and operating mutual funds.
The legislation is likely to be supported by the large banks. But the Administration may face a fight from smaller banks and the securities industry, both of which have powerful lobbies on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Brady said he was prepared for the fight. "We need fundamental structural reform," he declared, "and as Secretary of the Treasury, I am committed to this goal."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Zenith's Strategy Pressed for Time

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

 BODY:
IT has a grand name, a promising technology but a depressing record of losses. Now, with its stock in the pits and a possible takeover battle on the horizon, the Zenith Electronics Corporation may be running out of time to carry off a strategy to become a technology pioneer.
Zenith, the last American company that still makes television sets, has spent years trying to position itself for the future. Amid brutal competition from Japanese and Korean television companies, Zenith not only stayed in the business but also doubled its bet. It has sunk millions into developing high-definition systems, and decided last year to sell its desktop computer business to strengthen its balance sheet and concentrate on only one industry. In theory, this is just the kind of gutsy, long-term strategy that business experts applaud. But Zenith lost $68 million in 1989 and $38 million through the third quarter of 1990. With recession fears clouding the crucial Christmas quarter, most analysts expect more grim news ahead. 
 Now comes cash-rich Nycor Inc., which announced Oct. 31 that it had bought 8.2 percent of Zenith's stock for $10.8 million and may seek control. Nycor is a spinoff of the Fedders Corporation, which makes room air-conditioners. It is headed by the same father-and-son team that still runs Fedders: Salvatore Giordano and Salvatore Giordano Jr. Nycor has $62 million in cash and no operating business, having sold off divisions that make air compressors and automotive parts.
The Giordanos have not disclosed their intentions, and Zenith officials will not comment thus far. But both sides are gearing up for a battle. Nycor has begun a public-relations blitz to underline the contrast between profits at Fedders and evidence of "mismanagement" and high costs at Zenith. Zenith officials have reacted by reiterating the company's underlying strategy.
Nycor's official mission is to buy "underperforming manufacturing assets that fit well with management's experience in manufacturing and marketing," the company said in a news release. The elder Mr. Giordano acquired control of Fedders in the late 1940's, and remains chairman. His son, as chief executive of Fedders, has used aggressive marketing and cost-cutting to extract profit from a market that is nearly as tough as television. Nycor promoters point out that profits at Fedders climbed from $14 million in 1987 to $23.7 million in 1989. Earnings have plunged 40 percent this year, however, for which the company blames the cool weather last summer.
By many measures, Zenith stock is certainly cheap. At yesterday's closing price of $6.25 a share, it is just slightly above its all-time low and far below its price of $30 in the summer of 1988. Its total market value is about $173 million, less than one-ninth of its $1.54 billion in sales last year and about half its book value.
But some analysts contend that the real value of Zenith lies in the intangible assets, its name and its technology. Despite Zenith's losses, which stemmed largely from its sale of Zenith Data Systems and from high research costs, the company retains about 12 percent of the market and has competed well in the sale of high-end sets. Although it is hard to measure the market value of abrand name, it is surely a sizable asset.
Zenith's technology in high-definition television should also prove valuable. The company has developed a high-resolution picture tube, which it wants to use for both television and other markets, like computer work stations and medical imaging systems. Zenith is also competing in the race to develop a transmission technology that will be adopted by the Government as a standard for high-definition television. It remains unclear whether Zenith's system will win, but it is likely that the winning system will at least be a variant of it. James Magid, an analyst at Needham & Company in New York, said Zenith could be well positioned as a manufacturer of high-definition sets, even if it did not win the race. "It is a tremendously undervalued situation," he said.
By any reckoning, these benefits lie in the future. Nycor, by contrast, is clearly looking at the here and now. Citing what it sees as a "bloated work force," it points out that Zenith generated sales of only $48,400 an employee in 1989, while Fedders achieved $133,000 in the air-conditioner market. Nycor officials acknowledge that air-conditioners require far less research and development than HDTV, but they imply that Zenith has simply been frittering away money on HDTV.
But defenders of Zenith worry that the Giordanos will sacrifice the future. At a minimum, they fear that Nycor would put pressure on Zenith to slash its research. In the worst case, it would cut back on manufacturing and simply milk the Zenith name and sell sets made by other companies. "They'd probably make more money than Zenith does now," Mr. Magid said, "but it might not benefit the long-term interests of the shareholder."
Nycor responds that the Giordanos are long-term players who enjoy operating companies. Mark Greenberg, a spokesman, said, "They think they can do a better job of selling television sets, competing against foreigners and making money."

HEADLINE: Where All That Gas Goes: Drivers' Thirst for Power

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The United States' dependence on Persian Gulf oil can be explained in part by a tale of two Chevys.
The two 1990 Chevrolet Corsicas look alike and have identical legroom, headroom and trunk space. The difference is in the engines: one takes the car from a standstill to 60 miles an hour in less than 10 seconds and travels 22 miles on a gallon of gasoline. The other takes about four seconds longer to reach 60 miles an hour, but gets five more miles to the gallon. 
 One reason that Americans, who make up only 4 percent of the world's population, consume 40 percent of its gasoline is that when buyers face a choice like this, they tend to take the more powerful, less fuel-efficient engine. While the General Motors Corporation does not keep precise sales numbers, it says the only buyers who prefer the less zippy, less thirsty Corsicas are people who buy cars for other drivers -- purchasers of company vehicles or rental car fleets.
 
Cutting Consumption
 Reversing that trend and choosing the more fuel-efficient model in a given size category could be an easier way to cut gasoline consumption -- and help cut air pollution -- than some of the more frequently mentioned alternatives that many Americans find distasteful: car pooling, taking public transportation, driving smaller cars or driving less.
But since the OPEC price war in 1986, when gasoline prices hit bottom, many Americans have seen no reason to change their behavior. And their legislators have done little to encourage them to do so. Efforts in Congress and in California to nudge people toward more fuel-efficient cars both died on the vine in recent weeks.
Of course, millions of buyers apparently already consider fuel economy important enough to choose small cars or large cars that are the most efficient in their size class. Still, Americans this year bought cars that are, on average, less fuel efficient than the ones they bought in 1988.
 
Quicker and Thirstier
 According to the Environmental Protection Agency, 1990-model cars were, on average, seven-tenths of a second quicker reaching 60 miles an hour than the 1988 models and used 4 percent more gasoline. Such mild shifts in direction have a large effect on oil imports, because two-thirds of oil consumption goes for transportation fuel.
A case could be made that the public is getting contradictory signals. On one hand, much is made of the tremendous cost incurred in protecting the nation's oil supply -- sending a force that could soon number about 380,000 people to face bullets and poison gas in the Persian Gulf. And the bill for imported oil will run nearly $90 billion a year if current prices continue, up from about $50 billion before the gulf crisis.
But consumers seem more responsive to gasoline prices low enough to make speed a cheap thrill and to advertising that emphasizes power and speed.
Differences in fuel consumption mean nearly nothing to the car owner's budget. Cambridge Energy Research Associates reported recently, for example, that depreciation, maintenance, insurance fees and parking come to about 18 cents a mile for the average car on the American road. For a car that gets 22 miles a gallon, the fuel cost per mile at $1.50 a gallon would be 6.8 cents. Switching to a car that got 27 miles a gallon would cut that by 1.2 cents, or about 5 percent of the total cost of operating the car.
Of course, if the price of gasoline rose, the difference in fuel cost per mile driven would too. But as the report pointed out, "They would have to be very large increases indeed, say a doubling or tripling of real gasoline prices."
The Question Rarely Asked
Drivers may not do the calculation, but they seem intrinsically to understand the math. Car dealers say that fuel economy seems to be hardly a consideration for most buyers.
"Nobody's really mentioned gas mileage yet," said William D. Brolsma, a salesman at Fette Ford in Clifton, N.J., as he thought back over the customers of the past few weeks.
At Clifton Dodge nearby, Jeffrey R. Duda said that he had had only one question from a customer about gasoline mileage. There, the Dodge Spirit, with a four-cylinder engine that gets 26 miles a gallon, is also available in a turbocharged model. Mr. Duda said the turbocharged version is so powerful "it feels like a V-8," but it gets 6 miles a gallon less than the four-cylinder version.
"They ask about it," Mr. Duda said of the higher fuel consumption. But if a customer decides on the non-turbo model, it is not the better gas mileage but the $800 difference in price that tips the scales, he said. Buyers are sensitive to the purchase price, not the fuel costs of vehicles, a point of view that does not encourage manufacturers to spend money on research and production of cars that would be more expensive to buy but more economical to run.
 
Economy Gets Little Glory
 Indeed, while car makers are now altering some of their advertising campaigns to address gasoline mileage, popular culture still does not glorify fuel economy with the same enthusiasm it reserves for styling, acceleration and handling. This is evident in the auto makers' ad campaigns and in the car magazines.
In the October issue of Car and Driver, for example, the editor, William Jeanes, wrote that those who would mandate high fuel economy would "put all of us who love cars into devices that looked and ran like enclosed riding lawn mowers." In Road and Track, Volkswagen advertises its supercharged Corrado to drivers who are "somewhere between adolescence and responsibility."
The taste for performance may swallow the gains that could come in the next few years from technical improvements. According to the Energy Department, even with no new inventions, car manufacturers will tend to apply existing fuel-saving technologies more widely in years to come. This could raise the mileage of new cars to between 32 and 34 miles a gallon in the year 2000, from about 28 miles a gallon now if vehicle weight, size and performance stay the same, which may not be the case.
 
Manufacturers' Intent
 "The most important question is, 'Are the manufacturers going to take advantage of that technology gain by improving fuel economy, or by improving performance?' " said Carmine Defiglio, director of the Office of Energy Demand Policy at the Energy Department.
In other words, if the General Motors Corporation redesigns the Corsica body so that there is less wind resistance, uses lighter materials and switches to a high-mileage engine with four valves per cylinder instead of the standard two, it will improve the car's mileage. But it might neutralize that advantage with a bigger engine that could take a car from 0 to 60 one second faster.
The choice, analysts say, may depend on whether the auto makers are responding to public taste, or to law.
"It's going to take Congressional action, just as it did in the mid-1970's," said Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat whose bill to increase mileage standards for cars and light trucks won a majority in the Senate in the last session but lost on a procedural motion. A companion bill died in the House at the end of the session.
Mr. Bryan attributed the problem to "ideological hangups." In a recent meeting with auto executives in Detroit, he said, one complained that moving away from what the public chooses into a system influenced by the Government's view amounts to a "Stalinist regime."
The auto makers contend that the Government should not be meddling with public taste. They note that while they have high-mileage models available, cars that get more than 40 miles to the gallon accounted for less than 3 percent of sales in 1989. What the car companies emphasize instead is manufacturing quality, power, speed and sport.
Take the Chevrolet Corsica, which is available as a four-cylinder model that averages 27 miles a gallon and has a list price of $9,495, and as a six-cylinder model that averages 22 miles a gallon and lists at $10,180. General Motors would not say what the difference is in profit margin between the two models, but the auto manufacturers do acknowledge that as a rule, the bigger and heavier the car, the larger the profit.
The difference in the Corsicas' fuel economy -- five miles a gallon -- is large compared with the average mileage of cars on the road today, 20 miles a gallon.
Not every car is available in a model that gets five more miles a gallon, but many, like the Corsica, come in at least two configurations that differ substantially in mileage. The more fuel-efficient Corsica generally has a quieter paint job and top speed of 85 miles an hour, or 20 miles above the national speed limit; the model with the bigger engine generally comes with extra letters after its name and can travel at almost double the speed limit.
 
Plateau for Standards
 Through the mid-1970's until the mid-1980's, the Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards set by Congress pushed mileage higher, but those have reached a plateau, at 28.5 miles a gallon for cars. Meeting the standards was a struggle for some car makers after the collapse of oil prices in 1986, and they have fought hard against efforts to go further. Some car company executives have suggested that if Congress wants better gas mileage, it should take the onus off Detroit by passing a gasoline tax, which would make the public want more fuel-efficient cars.
But the recent budget battle in Washington showed that even a tax of 12 cents a gallon, hardly enough to make much difference in consumers' purchasing patterns, was more than Congress could stomach. It settled on a five-cent increase, and attention has moved back to new mileage standards.
 
Focus on California
 Although the Bryan bill was defeated, environmentalists and those favoring more energy independence are focusing on California, which has previously led the way for the nation in tailpipe pollution standards.
Earlier this year, the California Legislature approved a bill that would have changed the current 6 percent sales tax on all automobiles to a sliding scale, from zero to 12 percent, depending on fuel economy and pollutant emissions. Gov. George Deukmejian vetoed the bill, however.
Mr. Deukmejian leaves office next year, and backers intend to push for enactment of the measure again when the new Governor, Pete Wilson, comes in.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 6, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Nov. 21 about automobile power and fuel consumption misstated the top speed of the four-cylinder Chevrolet Corsica. It is 108 miles an hour, the same as the top speed of the six-cylinder version of the car, according to its manufacturer, the General Motors Corporation.

THE ECONOMY
Delinquent mortgages at Citicorp increased substantially in the third quarter to 3.6 percent of the dollar amount or loans, up from 3 percent at June 30, with much of the rise coming from the economically depressed Northeast. [Page D1.]
Home building plunged 6 percent in October, the Commerce Department said, extending the longest slide on record and putting starts at their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. [D1.]
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged bankers and Government regulators to make loans more readily available. [D1.]
Americans consume 40 percent of the world's gasoline, even though they make up only 4 percent of the world's population. [A1.]
Michael R. Milken is to be sentenced today on six felony charges to which he pleaded guilty. He faces a maximum of 28 years in prison, but legal experts generally predict 2 to 10 years. Whatever sentence Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood hands down, the experts say, controversy will follow. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Hudson Tolls Need $1 Rise, Officials Say

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that they would seek to raise tolls on the agency's bridges and tunnels by a dollar and the fare on PATH trains by 25 cents.
Stanley Brezenoff, the executive director of the Port Authority, said he would ask the agency's board to approve a plan that would increase the $3 round-trip bridge and tunnel tolls to $4, effective Jan. 1. The fare for the PATH rail line, which connects Hudson and Essex Counties with Manhattan, would rise to $1.25, from $1. 
 A similar plan to increase the tolls and train fare last April 1 was dropped when the Governors of New York and New Jersey threatened to veto it in the wake of a public outcry. The Governors have the right to veto any decision by the Port Authority board within 10 working days.
Port Authority officials said the proposed increase was needed to finance major capital projects already under way at airports, bridges, tunnels and PATH.
 
Closing a Budget Gap
 The authority's bridges and tunnels, PATH and the New York City Bus Terminal operate at deficits that are not offset by any state or Federal subsidies, officials said. Instead, revenues from the airports and marine terminals are used to meet the deficits at the interstate crossings. But the deficits jumped, mostly because of operating costs, from $19 million in 1989 to an estimated $50 million in 1990. The authority is scrambling to meet a projected $77 million deficit in the $2.8 billion budget for 1991.
"Nobody likes toll and fare increases, and neither do we," said Mr. Brezenoff, who was named executive director recently. "But this package is necessary. Every dollar of it goes back into our bridges, tunnels, PATH, and related transportation services over the next few years."
If approved, the proposed toll increase would apply to the George Washington, Bayonne and Goethals Bridges, the Outerbridge Crossing and the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels.
Under the plan, a 20-ticket discount book, which currently costs $40, or $2 a trip, would increase to $72 or $3.60 a trip. But the price of a 60-ticket discount book for car pools would remain at $30.
 
Can Demonstrate Need
 Richard Leone, the authority's chairman, said the agency was in a better position to obtain the fare and toll increases than it was last year because the region's economy had worsened and the agency could better demonstrate the need to increase revenues. Also, the authority has a new management team, he said.
Still, Mr. Leone said he was "not exactly optimistic about obtaining the fare increase because I realize we face a tough road ahead."
It is unclear whether the two Governors will agree to any increase approved by the board.
Peter Conroy, a spokesman for Gov. Mario M. Coumo, said yesterday: "The Governor has called for an independent evaluation of the need for a toll increase and he will not approve one until such a study becomes available by the middle of December. Until then we cannot comment on it."
Gov. Jim Florio said in a statement: "I want to hear a very detailed explanation for this request before New Jersey commuters are asked to pay for higher tolls. The Port Authority needs to be able to justify their reasons for this request not only to me but to all those who use our bridges and tunnels and PATH facilities."
