HEADLINE: Bill Would Give Unwed Couples Equal Benefits

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Unmarried domestic partners would be protected against discrimination and would be able to document their relationship officially under a bill that went before the New York City Council yesterday.
The proposed law would, for example, expand health benefits to the unmarried partners of city employees. It would also extend municipal hospital benefits and prison visitation rights to such couples and would apply to city-owned housing and shelters. Both heterosexual and homosexual couples would be covered. 
 Though some other cities have enlarged the concept of what constitutes a family, turning the bill into law in New York could be arduous.
The City Council insists that it has no jurisdiction in the matter. Although the bill went to the Council's General Welfare Committee yesterday, a Council spokeswoman said there would be no hearings because the proposed legislation was pre-empted by state laws governing marital rights.
 
'Would Be Unconstitutional'
 "The state has done so much legislation in this area," said the spokeswoman, Peg Breen. "It would be unconstitutional for us to consider it. We cannot change or modify state law."
But the bill's sponsor, Councilwoman Carolyn Maloney, said the Council had the power to enact it because it pertained only to city policies and city employees. She said she would request a hearing after the bill had been in committee for 30 days.
Groups saying they represented gay rights advocates and elderly and disabled people, among others, praised the bill.
"This bill is a universal one," Ms. Maloney said. "It benefits senior citizens, people with physical disabilities, unmarried heterosexual couples, gay men, lesbians and those who are economically disadvantaged. It's time we realized that these nontraditional families contribute just as much to our society as everybody else."
 
Formidable Hurdles Remain
 Under the bill, an unmarried domestic partnership could be established by giving a statement to a county clerk, who would file it and give the partners a certificate. Or a couple could have the statement notarized. To qualify, a couple would have to be unrelated, both unmarried, and at least 18 years old.
To become law, the bill must be approved by the Council committee, passed by the full Council and signed by Mayor David N. Dinkins. The Mayor supports the concept of unmarried domestic partnerships, a spokesman said yesterday, but he would have to study the bill before assessing its impact on city policies.
The cost of extending benefits under the measure are estimated to be between $30 million and $60 million a year.

HEADLINE: Real Men Don't Carve Anymore

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
SOMEBODY should write a book titled, "Women Who Love Men Who Can't Carve." It would be an instant best seller. Women would run to the self-help sections of book stores and snap up every copy during the holiday season.
This is a time when women of all ages complain that men in their 20's and 30's cannot carve Thanksgiving turkeys the way their fathers and grandfathers did. Men do not deny it. 
 "No men of my generation know how to carve turkeys," said David Hinden, a 28-year-old public relations executive in New York. "Our parents carve and sometimes our wives. The day they expect us to carve is the day we buy turkey parts."
In Chicago, a real estate trainee named Steve Siegel expressed a latent fear of carving. "At Thanksgiving dinner, my role right now is to eat and pass the peas," said Mr. Siegel, 22. "But it's scary to think that someday I'll be standing over my own family turkey with a knife in my hand. I'm not sure I can cut it."
Robert Krist, 38, a freelance photographer with three children and a house in Ridgewood, N.J., said he and his male friends don't do turkeys. One factor, he speculated, may be that they are the new men, sensitive and vulnerable. "We can cry, but we can't carve," he said.
Pressed for the name of a carving man, Mr. Krist suggested a college friend, an orthopedic surgeon in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. "He operated on my knee," he said, "so he could be your man." The surgeon was attending a medical convention in Florida and unavailable for comment.
Rob Cohen, 24, said everybody he knew in Los Angeles, including himself, was too busy peddling movie scripts to even consider carving turkeys. "For what it's worth," he added, "whoever carves turkeys in L.A. does it by the pool."
Talk of carving reminded many young men of their fathers. "When I was a kid he seemed like a tribal chief with that turkey," said Peter Shapiro, 30, a sales promotion executive in Manhattan. "He seemed to be making weird noises." Mr. Shapiro tried making weird noises, but gave up after awhile. "He always carved in the kitchen with the dog sitting next to him. I tried to carve once and the dog got up and left the room."
A lawyer in Houston, Steve Selsberg, 29, said he once tried to carve a good-sized turkey and ended up with "enough meat for a small sandwich." Carving is "a forgotten art," he said. "Maybe men don't carve any more because women don't cook."
That's part of it. Since nobody seems to be roasting great beasts and birds for Sunday dinner these days, nobody is getting practice at carving them. Meat consumption is down. Meat and poultry are being bought in parts at markets or eaten at restaurants. "And you can't carve fast food," said John Loring, a vice president of Tiffany's, which sells those silver carving sets that brides say are tarnishing for lack of use.
Ham might be nice for the holidays, provided somebody else does the slicing. "Did you know that three-quarters of all hams bought for the season are pre-sliced?" asked Dun Gifford of Boston. "I'm amazed."
Mr. Gifford has a mail-order food company and three sons in their 20's. "They know how to sharpen knives and to filet fish," he said, "I passed that along but, now that you mention it, I never thought of carving a bird or a ham. It may just be that this generation has lost the art. If so, that would be tragic."
The potential for tragedy deepens when you consider that carving was the most exalted art among knights of the medieval courts. George Armelagos, a food anthropologist, writes about this in "Consuming Passions," a book on the anthropology of eating. The carver was expert in many butchering utensils, he says, as well as technical terms and social rules. He knew, for example, that only the left wing of the capon would do for the lord, just as modern carvers remember to put a drumstick on Cousin Buddy's plate.
Men are still presiding over the country's carving boards, at least on Thanksgiving. A survey of 80,000 cooks who called in crisis last year to speak to home economists on the Butterball Turkey Talk-line found that 7 out of 10 turkeys were carved by men. Almost 80 percent of all birds were carved in the kitchen rather than at the dining table. "They like to carry it through the living room for the photo op," said Jean Schnelle, director of the hot line. "And then it's back to the kitchen so we don't get grease on the carpet."
When the hot line was born a decade ago, less than 10 percent of callers were men. Ms. Schnelle said that men now make 16 percent of calls and that she suspects many more men would like to call but you know how men hate to ask directions.
"They'll go to the next state before they'll stop and ask at a gas station," she said. "Some men will not ask."
Other men are quite bold. They call on speaker-phones from the table where the whole family can hear Ms. Schnelle talking them through it. After explaining how to remove the thighs and drumsticks, she often compares what's left of the bird to a football. "Cut along that line that goes from tip to tip on the pigskin. . . ."
Ken Kerbs, 30, could have used her advice last year when he found himself the designated carver at his mother-in-law's table in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn. His wife told him it was a great honor. His mother-in-law brought out the family carving set. "Hey," he said, backing away from the knife. "Be careful with that thing." Then it was turkey time. Faces shone around the table. Mr. Kerbs had a flashback to childhood: His father bending over a turkey with an electric carving knife. The knife interfering with the football game on television. The carving part was also blurry.
Staring down at the bird, Mr. Kerbs saw that it was not even a turkey. It was a stuffed goose. He attempted to steady the goose with the carving knife. It persisted in doing a shimmy on the platter. He flailed away with the knife until a brother-in-law was sent in as a carving consultant.
The brother-in-law was no help. Mr. Kerbs's wife jumped up with a camera to record the moment -- two bewildered-looking young men, symbols of a generation, standing at the end of a table over a bird, its legs sticking up in the air.

HEADLINE: Field of 162 in Majors' $1 Million Lineup

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
More than one-fifth of major league players earned $1 million or more this year, a salary survey determined yesterday.
The survey, based on contract data obtained from management and player sources, showed that the $1 million plateau was attained by 162 players, or 22 percent, of the 735 who were on major league rosters or the disabled list on Aug. 31. Last year, 106 players, or 14.7 percent, gained that level. 
 For the first time, a player reached $3 million or more this year, with Robin Yount of Milwaukee earning $3.2 million. Twenty-eight other players, up from 20 a year ago, hit or surpassed the $2 million mark.
Five teams, including the Mets and the American League's two division champions, Oakland and Boston, had 10 players who earned $1 million or more. The others were Kansas City and San Francisco.
 
Changing Faces
 Last year, the Mets led with nine $1 million-or-more players. They shed Gary Carter, Keith Hernandez and Juan Samuel from that group but added John Franco, Sid Fernandez, Howard Johnson and David Cone. The team's $21.9 million payroll, on the other hand, did not include any $2 million players this year after four had reached that plateau last year. Like many of the highest-paid players, the Mets' millionaires had opted for smaller salaries this year because of the potential lockout, which did occur but did not result in any loss of pay.
At the other end of the spectrum, the Baltimore Orioles had only one player, Cal Ripken Jr., in the $1 million class. The Orioles had the smallest payroll in the majors, $7.98 million (the only one under $10 million) and the lowest average salary, $275,244.
Player salaries are a constant source of debate among owners, players and the players' agents. Salaries have escalated dramatically since free agency was created in 1976, and they became such a sore point with owners that they engaged in a three-year conspiracy against free agents in an effort to halt the escalation, if not reverse the direction in which salaries were headed.
That period of collusion, ended by arbitrators' decisions, will cost each club $10.77 million in a settlement that is being negotiated by lawyers for the two sides. That penalty has prompted some clubs, especially those in smaller markets, to say they will have to temper their contract offers to players.
The Pittsburgh Pirates are a team that faces particularly difficult financial decisions. Their $589,980 average salary placed them 15th among the 26th clubs in the salary standings, but the combination of their division championship, the performances of many of their players and their large group of free agents will send their payroll rocketing upward.
At the moment, if they don't make competitive offers, they stand to lose Sid Bream, Zane Smith and Don Slaught, among others, as free agents. Bobby Bonilla and Andy Van Slyke, two-thirds of the National League's best outfield, can be free agents after next season, and Barry Bonds, the third outfielder and the league's most valuable player, can be a free agent in two years.
The clubs that are reluctant to spend have become critical of those that continue to spend to retain their players or obtain new ones. Oakland, with three consecutive pennants and a spiraling payroll, has become probably the primary target of the economic critics.
 
Athletics Top Salary LIst
 According to the survey conducted by The New York Times, the Athletics, who lost to Cincinnati in the World Series, had the highest average salary, $800,586. The Reds were 17th among the 26 clubs, at $555,895. Just as they were in the American League pennant playoff, the Red Sox were runner-up to Oakland in the salary standings with a $763,046 average.
The Mets and the Yankees were third and fourth, the Mets at $755,437 and the Yankees at $721,991. The Yankees had eight players at $1 million or more, but only one of them, Don Mattingly, was in the $2 million club.
The total major league payroll was $434,750,701 and the average salary $591,498, an increase of $100,000 and 20 percent over last year's average. These are unofficial figures, although baseball does not produce a universally accepted average salary.
The Players Association and the owners' Player Relations Committee each compute average salaries but, because of the different computing methods they use, never agree on the average salary. Last year the players figured the average salary to be $497,254 and the owners $489,539. The Times computed the average at $491,341.
This year, the owners' computer has emitted a preliminary figure of $586,816. Bonuses for post-season awards, which were not included, will raise the average slightly. The players' union will issue its average salary figures next month.

LENGTH: 566 words

HEADLINE: Twilight for Mrs. Thatcher?

 BODY:
Margaret Thatcher has been counted out at least twice during her remarkable dozen years as Britain's Prime Minister, and each time she has confounded the odds. Yet her narrow failure yesterday to win endorsement as the Conservative Party leader was, for a sitting Prime Minister with a towering world reputation, a towering humiliation.
To survive in her present position, Mrs. Thatcher must win a runoff vote for the party leadership next Tuesday; even if she does, it's clear that she has already been sternly rebuked, for her policies and her imperious style. 
 There is no guarantee that any of her opponents in the Conservative or Labor parties could govern the country any better. But there is evidence that she has overstayed her welcome. As the British political analyst Peter Jenkins recently observed, Mrs. Thatcher, like Queen Elizabeth I, has outlived a generation of courtiers. In the process she has grown as convinced of the rightness of her views as she is contemptuous of others'.
Her combative style has figured heavily in the two policy disputes that persuaded Michael Heseltine, her former Defense Minister, to challenge her leadership. One was her opposition to further economic and political unity in Europe, specifically a common currency. What most angered her fellow Tories was her unwillingness to listen to competing ideas. Sir Geoffrey Howe, for example, was sacked as Foreign Minister when he pushed her publicly to accept currency union.
Similarly, Mrs. Thatcher overrode the advice of many of her most trusted advisers when she imposed a poll tax on each adult citizen, replacing local property taxes. The tax is regressive, inequitable -- and explosively unpopular.
The revolt against Mrs. Thatcher is all the more remarkable given her transforming presence over the past decade. At home, she won admiration and respect for the qualities that won back the Falkland Islands and faced down the striking coal miners. And while Americans have little to fear from any possible successor, they will remember her loyalty to Presidents Reagan and Bush and her willingness, when others were holding back, to encourage Mikhail Gorbachev's revolution in the Soviet Union.
Nor is there any doubt that she changed the face of Britain. For years, Prime Ministers of both parties were content to preside over the nation's economic decline. The Iron Lady said no.
She privatized sluggish state enterprises, curtailed the stultifying power of the trade unions, reduced inflation and created a climate hospitable to enterprise. The country moved rightward and happily so; Mrs. Thatcher's opponents in the Labor Party now talk glowingly about entrepreneurship and the need for Britain to compete on even terms with the rest of the world.
Yet even she would concede that her revolution is incomplete. Britain's sluggish work habits survive, and its productivity still lags. Inflation is running at twice the European average, while public services have declined.
Not all these problems are Mrs. Thatcher's fault, but she is being held to account for them just as surely as she was rewarded for her earlier triumphs. She might have revived her image had she chosen to lead Britain boldly into a unified Europe. Instead she has turned inward, and her party now seems poised to turn her out. Even if she should survive next week's vote, the light is fading.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
The All-American Disease

 BODY:
The upset election of Bob Rae as Ontario's Premier in September was the first surprise. Then came the budget surprise. As newly elected governors are discovering all over the United States, Mr. Rae found that the province's finances were in worse shape than advertised.
Never before had Ontario, the heart of the Canadian economy, elected a Socialist government. Mr. Rae promised change -- more spending for health and education and higher corporate taxes. During the campaign, officials forecast a small surplus in the $45 billion provincial budget. Barely a week after the election, they broke the news that there would be a $700 million deficit. Mr. Rae's own people now think it may be $2.5 billion.
Incumbents always postpone bad news. Now, with Canada in a real recession, there's no hiding the shortfall. Mr. Rae is forced to concede that some things he seemed bent on doing overnight will, at a minimum, take longer. Budget quicksand knows no boundaries.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Bush's Midterm Crisis

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
President Bush's eight-day trip abroad was not planned, so far as is known, as an escape from the troubles that suddenly plague him at home. But he could hardly be blamed if he's enjoying a week of freedom from the nightly news and the daily headlines.
 First, it was the budget fiasco and the perception of the President as unable either to make up his mind or bring his party along in whatever direction he was going. This after his campaign pledge never, never to raise taxes earned him a steep drop in the polls and the prestigious 1990 Doublespeak Award from the National Council of English Teachers. 
 Worse, Mr. Bush managed to do for the Democrats what they had been unable to do for themselves. Virtually singlehandedly he created the so-called "fairness issue" by his stubborn resistance to higher taxes on affluent Americans, while doing his best to get some of them a capital-gains tax break.
 The President then took to the campaign trail, where he and the nation discovered that a number of Republican office-seekers no longer wanted his help or even his presence. Worse, on Election Day, the returns suggested that his influence on the voters -- even in Texas, one of his home states -- was smaller than his hat size.
 Almost as soon as the election was over, the bubble of support he had won for mobilizing the Persian Gulf coalition burst into a storm of criticism. His decision to send more troops to provide an "offensive capacity" (which could have earned him another Doublespeak award, since he had said originally that U.S. forces were "purely defensive") woke Congress and the Democrats and even some Republicans to the prospect of an unwanted war.
 Congress was particularly exercised because Mr. Bush and his Secretary of State, James A. Baker, did some fast footwork around the question of "consulting" its members. Would they even do the constitutional thing and ask Congress to declare the war if they decided to start it? Mr. Bush responded by asking critics to tone it down, lest the country appear to be as divided as it actually is.
 Then, on the eve of his departure for points east, Mr. Bush had to confess that he was "concerned that we're in a downturn" economically -- though he hastened to add, in one of those catchy phrases for which he is renowned, that he was "not a gloom-and-doom person." But a President who wants to be re-elected would rather be concerned about almost anything other than recession.
 All in all, it's been a disastrous autumn for a President who sailed through the summer with an approval rating above 70 percent. It's hard to remember a President who suffered such an abrupt fall from such high standing, and that it happened to George Bush raises hard questions about him and his Presidency.
 Most immediately, will his decline be lasting? Clearly, it doesn't have to be; Mr. Bush is only at the halfway point of his term and has plenty of time and opportunity to move up again in public appreciation. And if he's right that real or threatened recession won't last more than six months -- not everyone shares that view -- the economy could be in good shape again by 1992.
 On the other hand, most of Mr. Bush's political wounds were self-inflicted; witness the budget debacle and the abrupt escalation of defense into offense in the Middle East. Such perceived ineptitude has led to speculation in both parties and on Capitol Hill that Mr. Bush's political skills have deserted him, or never really existed; that his election was mostly the work of clever handlers; that his popularity derived from having had to make few tough decisions; and that an uninspired staff, particularly its abrasive chief, John Sununu, serves him poorly.
 A suddenly floundering President, moreover, does not inspire the respect, even fear, that usually is a major weapon in the White House arsenal. This could have fatal effect in Congress, where Mr. Bush seems to have only halfhearted backing even among Republicans; and it's likely to bring Democratic Presidential candidates out of the woodwork and into Iowa and New Hampshire.
 The most serious question, however, is about the core of belief on which a President, or anyone, usually can rely for guidance when issues are complex and difficult. This President's waffling on the budget, his inability to explain his intentions in the Middle East, his managerial approach to an office that demands persuasiveness and vision -- what these may tell us about George Bush's personal center is not reassuring.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
One Empire to Go

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The original purpose of the 1975 Helsinki conference was to substitute for a World War II German peace treaty, impossible to sign because of two Germanys. So the Soviets settled for a document guaranteeing the postwar borders and, in effect, recognizing two German states.
The U.S wasn't particularly interested, but its European allies led the way, insisting as a tradeoff from the Soviets that the accords include a "third basket" pledging human rights. The agreements of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe were written off as a sellout by the American right since the pledges didn't even provide lip service for democracy. 
That was a serious misjudgment. The emphasis on human rights, further advanced by President Jimmy Carter's policies, made a big difference. But the critics were proved right in their argument that Communism could not reform. They just failed to see that attempts at reform would lead it to self-destruct.
When another summit meeting was agreed for this year, the point was for all of Europe, plus the U.S. and Canada, to endorse a German settlement. But now Germany is off the agenda, restored to full and single sovereignty. Instead of bothering with the "German question," members of NATO and the moribund Warsaw Pact signed a declaration renouncing the threat or use of force against each other and proclaiming "the security of each indissociably tied to the security of all."
A French TV station ran film of the heads of government arriving and shaking hands in comic speedup, a reflection of the way history had suddenly accelerated. "It's the Congress of Vienna without the dancing," said one delegate.
But unlike the conservative conclave of monarchs establishing the European power balance in 1815, after the Napoleonic wars, this treaty enshrines the concept of military restraint. The new power balance is expressed through economic might.
So the C.S.C.E. issue has turned out to be the problem of finding a place for the "Sovreps." Mr. Gorbachev has proposed changing the U.S.S.R.'s name to Union of Sovereign Republics in his effort to hold his state together, so they can still be called "Sov," but they won't even be Soviet, let alone Socialist. It is a huge problem, and he has a lot more sympathy on it from his fellow government leaders here than from his compatriots. One of the side events was the expulsion of foreign ministers from the three Baltic republics, who had been invited as guests by the French, after the Soviets objected. Nobody wanted to embarrass Mr. Gorbachev.
The Eastern Europeans all face a period of great difficulty and fragility as they try to recover from two generations of Communist mismanagement and spoliation. But their place in the new Europe will be secure. Nobody knows how to accommodate whatever becomes of the U.S.R., if it emerges, or what to make of Russia.
It doesn't fit in the European context, but it is not an ocean away, like the U.S. The new Soviet threat, palpable to Europeans, is disintegration leading to violence. Moscow's former allies are bluntly told not to seek protection from their distraught neighbor by trying to join NATO. Manfred Worner, NATO's Secretary General, said plainly, "We don't want to create additional problems for the Soviets and for Gorbachev."
The long cold war ended without a fight in Europe, although there were proxy wars outside. But for all the fine new words of amity, the state scene has not been settled. the dangers if the Soviets cannot manage their transformation reasonably smoothly are serious, not only because of their still-huge arsenal but because 15, probably many more, new quarreling countries on the map would undermine international order.
The other key issues in Paris, at the edges of the C.S.C.E., are examples of crises that could be expected to proliferate. They are the Persian Gulf and the Uruguay Round trade negotiations, which threaten to reverse the great expansion of prosperity since World War II if they break down.
Marx preached that the capitalist state system was driven to wars by its search for economic privilege and would collapse as a result. It turned out that economic cooperation brought capitalist states to flourish and Communism collapsed, but it takes a state system to provide the base for cooperation.
There is tremendous promise for the world in a Europe that, with American help, has overcome its internecine wars. It won't be fulfilled until the Russians sort out their end of empire.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 683 words

HEADLINE: Milken's Morals, and Ours

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis; Michael Lewis is author of "Liar's Poker."

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The perversity of the public prosecution of Michael Milken was that it ignored what troubled people most. Probably, there is someone out there who turns purple at the mere thought of a man violating a half dozen of the more technical rules in our stock markets (as Mr. Milken did); there is probably someone who believes jaywalkers deserve the death penalty.
But sensible people were far more upset that Mr. Milken had helped to buy and mince America's largest corporations -- while earning himself a billion or so dollars. He seemed to mock the widely cherished notion that the market is sensible and just, and was as annoying as a double-parked Rolls-Royce. 
 Today's sentencing of Mr. Milken -- added to the $600 million fine he has already agreed to pay -- is meant to be a kind of moral resolution. The villain is being punished, once again proving that mocking American capitalism doesn't pay. But there are several reasons why this ending should trouble people who like their morality tales neat.
The first is that, of Mr. Milken's many disruptive deeds, none that truly angered people was illegal. Selling junk bonds to willing investors -- even to savings and loans -- was legal. Handing the proceeds to Ronald Perelman, Nelson ("if you aren't born with it, you have to borrow it") Peltz and Carl Icahn, who wished to dismantle America's largest corporations, was also legal. Even earning $550 million in a year was legal. And make no mistake about it: no more than a few of those dollars can be traced to Mr. Milken's crimes.
Moreover, the people who matter still feel the takeover craze was, on balance, good for the economy. Thus, we are still unclear about the ethics of the important part of Mr. Milken's behavior. Anyone who doubts this must explain why, after the collapse of Mr. Milken's employer, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., nearly every Wall Street firm rushed to hire his former cronies.
Mr. Milken's defenders say that his junk bonds filled a hole caused by the folly of America's leading bankers, and provided money to companies that needed it. The takeovers he funded forced corporate executives to trim fat. Perhaps Mr. Milken and Drexel forced the issue a bit, and arranged a few takeovers that should never have occurred. But so did everyone else on Wall Street (if you really want to see damage to the economy, visit Salomon Brothers, which created a string of disastrous leveraged buyouts).
We have prosecuted the man but ignored his ideas. Sometimes the man embodies the idea well enough to justify such a procedure: Michael Deaver, the former aide and confidant to Ronald Reagan, pretty much captured Washington influence peddling, for example. But Mr. Milken is a poor stand-in for Wall Street Greed.
For a start, he thought what he was doing was right. Unlike most of Wall Street's leading deal makers, he genuinely believed he had a mission to reform the American economy. He lived modestly ("I have one house, one wife, one cat, one car," he once said, truthfully). He didn't gloat like Ivan Boesky or preen in public like Donald Trump. He was revered by his employees and devoted to his family (to the extent that he sacrificed himself to exonerate his brother). In short, if we had to go after a man instead of an idea, we could have found a better specimen.
The moral of the Milken story isn't that greedy people always suffer a comeuppance; you have only to look in the mirror to see that isn't true. The moral is that people who force unwanted change on other people -- particularly those with power -- should always keep a lawyer on hand.
It is our dirty little secret that, even as we congratulate ourselves for the wonders of our economic system, we disapprove of many of its natural outcomes. As a wealthy investment banker friend of mine put it, "There is something wrong with making $550 million in a single year." In the end, Michael Milken mocked not only capitalism but our faith in it, too.
Mr. Milken showed how disruptive a genuinely gifted financier could be. On balance, I think, we'd prefer our bankers a little stupid.

HEADLINE: Dresden Journal;
First the Allies. Then the Communists. And Now?

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DRESDEN, Germany

 BODY:
Ulrich Aust's love affair with the Royal Palace in his hometown began in the 1960's. That is when he and other students sneaked out into the night to work hurried repairs on the charred and hollow ruin that was left after British and American bombers gutted the city, a jewel of European Baroque, in a hail of fire in the waning months of World War II.
The series of raids, carried out with phosphorus and high-explosive bombs, were ordered mainly to break German morale. But after the war they served successive East German Communist Governments as supposed evidence of the inhumanity of Western capitalism. 
 At the Zwinger, a restored stone ensemble that is the city's premier Rococo monument, a stone inscription denounces the Allied attack.
With the collapse of Communism and the unification of Germany over the last year, the ghosts of such distant events are eclipsed by the shadows of a more recent past.
 
A Second Calamity?
 Many people here say they believe that after the destruction of the city by Allied bombers, 45 years of Communist rule worked a second demolition. And burghers of Dresden like Mr. Aust, who is now building director of the Palace ruin, hope the city will be reborn a second time within their generation.
"This has always been a burning problem for the people of Dresden," he said, leading a visitor through the Zwinger.
"They long terribly for the reconstruction of monuments like the Palace, which was fought by the Communist Party. These things were tests of strength between the people and the Communists, who always argued that they stood for better, more modern values."
Not that this scarred city of 550,000, the capital of Saxony in reunited Germany, is not firmly anchored in the present. Its architecture, if charred and faded, is a twisting, soaring Baroque that was built by the royal house of Saxony in the centuries that it ruled broad areas of Central Europe from the gentle shores of the Elbe.
 
Poised to Invade the East
 But the city voted solidily pro-business and Christian Democratic in recent elections, and the House of Parliament is undergoing restoration to accommodate the new state Legislature. Local hotels are crowded with western German businessmen and Dresden's location, wedged between Poland and Czechoslovakia, buoys its hopes of becoming Germany's staging area for an economic invasion of Eastern Europe.
The Communists allowed reconstruction of a few monuments, like the Zwinger and the famed 19th-century Semper Opera. But others, like the renowned Sophienkirche, a Baroque gem, were razed, and construction of coal-burning power stations like one that is perched 700 yards downwind from the Zwinger has produced emissions that destroy what was restored.
"We hope that in this new era our dreams of reconstruction can be realized," said Harald Marx, director of the Old Masters' Gallery, the receptacle of treasures like Raphael's Sistine Madonna. He was guiding visitors through the tangled construction site that is his gallery, where reconstruction work is expected to be finished by mid-1992.
Across the way at the Royal Palace site, work proceeds to prevent further decay so that the complex can be tranformed ultimately into an ensemble of modern museums. Nearby, the graceful Taschenberg Palace, once a glory of Dresden, now a ruin sprouting trees from its halls, will be reconstructed.
 
Church Dome Stirs Discord
 But the liveliest debate focuses on the Frauenkirche, the Church of Our Lady, which is now just a hollow wreck amid the vacant lots that were once the Neumarkt, or New Market, Dresden's former business center. In their race to put up cheap concrete slab apartments at the city's edge, the Communists left the Neumarkt to rot.
Planners would like to revive it by luring western investors like Siemens, the western German electrical giant that is scooping up chunks of eastern Germany's old Dresden-based Robotron computer company, or the Dresdner Bank, Germany's No. 2 bank, which was born here in the last century.
"This is a unique chance to regain the traditional downtown area and revive it," said Walter Kockeritz, a local architect who heads the drive. "And that chance is bound up with reconstruction of the Frauenkirche."
Planners hope the church's reconstructed dome will somehow be more than just another tourist attraction, and will symbolize German revival after reunification. But it will remain an anti-war memorial, they say, and include sites for conferences and religious meetings. Seizing on this symbolism, politicans like Chancellor Helmut Kohl have used the site for rallies.
 
A Stubborn Dream
 Not everyone agrees. Reconstruction will cost an estimated $100 million, and Marian Gunther, an editor at the local paper, Die Union, said that while people were "100 percent behind the changes" that brought down the East German Government, frustration abounds over rising unemployment and the sluggish flow of business investment from the west.
The leaders of Saxony's Evangelical Protestant church, which owns the Frauenkirche ruin, say that decrepit hospitals, crumbling housing and acrid pollution require more urgent attention than church connstruction.
But others, like Mr. Kockeritz, will not abandon the dream.
"Dresden was the most exquisitely composed city in Germany before the war," he said. "This beauty was lost in the destruction and the poor reconstruction, and where it lingers on, it is intensely endangered. We'd like to set this former harmony as the measure of reconstruction everywhere."

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
How Trump Got A Second Chance

BYLINE: By Richard D. Hylton

 BODY:
TALK about the art of the deal.
After weeks of marathon negotiations with lawyers, investment bankers and bondholders' representatives, Donald J. Trump managed to keep control of his giant Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City, despite having missed a $47.3 million interest payment due at midnight last Thursday on the "junk bonds" that financed the candy-colored monolith. 
 How had he persuaded the bondholders to leave him in control? Surely with their first mortgage on the property, the bondholders could have wrested control or forced the casino into an involuntary bankruptcy?
A close look at the details of the settlement shows that the bondholders came away with a deal that is strongly weighted in their favor and that gives Mr. Trump a second chance to make the Taj meet its financial obligations. It is also clear that had it not been for the intervention of Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider and financier who is the single largest bondholder, Mr. Trump would probably not have gotten that second chance, but would have been forced into a messy bankruptcy battle in which the bondholders had the upper hand.
The settlement gives the bondholders 50 percent of the equity in the Taj Mahal but leaves Mr. Trump with control of the board. Any transactions -- mergers, sales, recapitalizations -- that would substantially change the company are subject to approval by the bondholders' appointees, who will receive three of the seven board seats. In exchange, the interest rate that Mr. Trump pays on the bonds will be reduced to 12 percent, from 14 percent, and two percentage points of that can be paid in new bonds. The maturity on the bonds has been extended two years, to 2000.
Mr. Trump has an opportunity to win back 30 percent of the equity after 10 years if the casino'sperformance comes within 15 percent of cash-flow levels to be approved by the bondholders and if he pays back the $675 million in principal at the original 14 percent rate over the next 10 years. If in any year the casino falls below 85 percent of the goal, Mr. Trump loses control of the board.
"The essence of this deal is that Donald has agreed to deliver or he'll give up control," said Mr. Icahn, who owns more than $150 million of the face value of the bonds. He is believed to have bought most of his interest at less than 40 cents on the dollar.
It is this factor -- control of the board -- that gives the bondholders the edge. If the Taj fails to generate enough cash under Mr. Trump's control, the bondholders take over, and they can reduce the developer's 50 percent stake by issuing more stock. Or they can create an issue of preferred shares for themselves that would reduce the casino's debt burden while effectively siphoning off all generated cash for bondholders. In essence, if the bondholders take control they can effectively eliminate much of the value of Mr. Trump's equity stake, while they keep the casino's future earnings.
The agreement, which is to be structured as a prepackaged bankruptcy settlement, was reached at the 11th hour after all-night talks. Although theyhad not admitted it to Mr. Trump or his executives, the bondholders had decided by late last week that he would not agree to any deal in which he would have to give up more than 50 percent ownership.
"We had several days before where we knew that he wasn't going to do a deal unless it were 50-50, and what we were fighting over was how much equity he would get back," said Wilbur Ross, senior managing director of Rothschild Inc. who represented one of the largest bondholder groups.
Despite meetings past midnight last Thursday, and a 2 A.M. conference call between Mr. Ross, Mr. Icahn and Mr. Trump, questions remained unresolved regarding how much equity the developer would get back if he met the financial goals and what those goals should be.
Mr. Trump wanted to get back more than 80 percent of the equity, and he was arguing for less stringent standards; Mr. Ross and Mr. Icahn were on the other side of the fence. By Friday morning, after the payment had been missed and no settlement reached, the bondholders decided to try one more conference call at 10 A.M. before announcing that they had reached no settlement, making an involuntary bankruptcy filing a near certainty.
"We had resolved as a practical matter that this thing was to be brought to a head on the 16th," said Mr. Ross, who two weeks earlier had flown to Tokyo to gain the support of Japanese bondholders. "We believed that the issues were narrowly defined, and there was no reason for it to last longer, so we wanted it ended on Friday."
It was then that Mr. Icahn began playing his pivotal role.
He joined the conference call of nearly 100 bondholders, at Mr. Ross's request, and made it clear that he supported allowing Mr. Trump to retain 50 percent of the equity and control of the board. With the support of Mr. Icahn, Mr. Ross's group and the Japanese bondholders, who were now actively involved for the first time, it was clear to all those on the conference call that enough bondholders supported the deal to force it on the others. Some time after noon the conference call ended, and Mr. Ross and Mr. Icahn took the final offer to Mr. Trump, who agreed to it.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Mixed Results After Day of Thin Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed in lackluster pre-holiday trading yesterday, with little news to affect the currency, traders said.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold settled at $378.90 an ounce, up $1.30 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $379.15, up $1.55. 
 David Ethridge, a vice president and currency trader at Merrill Lynch & Company, said most activity in the thin market appeared to be "mopping-up operations" ahead of Thanksgiving.
But he said some long-term investors continued to sell dollars to buy the Japanese yen, in part because of a belief that Japanese interest rates were headed higher while United States rates could drop.
Higher interest rates tend to support a nation's currency by making securities denominated in that currency more valuable.
The dollar rose against the German mark but fell against the yen and the British pound.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 127.68 yen, from 128.93 yen Tuesday. Later in London, it rose to 128.90 yen. But in New York, one dollar bought 127.17 yen, down from 128.85 yen late Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9680, from $1.9695 late Tuesday. But in New York, one pound cost $1.9670, up from $1.9660 Tuesday.
The mark traded at 1.4815 to the dollar in Europe, up from 1.4760 Tuesday. In New York, one dollar fetched 1.4770 marks, up from 1.4740 marks the day before.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.2472 Swiss francs, up from 1.2450; 4.9800 French francs, up from 4.9760; 1,109 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1582 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1593.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $378.25 an ounce, up from $377.75 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold's closing bid was $378.50, up from $377.50 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $8.17 to close at $372.13.
Silver prices rose. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $4.125 an ounce, up from $4.11 late Tuesday. In London, silver rose to a late bid of $4.11, up from $4.10 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dividend Slashed At Fleet-Norstar

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 21

 BODY:
Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc., considered to be one of New England's strongest banking companies slashed its dividend by almost 43 percent. Fleet declared a quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share, down from 35 cents, payable on Jan. 1 to stockholders of record on Dec. 15. Analysts had expected some sort of cut.
Terrence Murray, the company's chairman and chief executive, said Fleet had a 7 percent ratio of capital to assets, compared with the industry average of almost 5 percent. "Retention of capital is the most prudent course of action at this time," he said. The region is in an economic downturn, with slumping real estate values and higher loan defaults eroding the value of bank stocks and the banks' bottom lines.

HEADLINE: Leaders of New Jersey Tax Rebellion Take Aim at Legislature

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Two weeks after New Jersey voters almost unseated Senator Bill Bradley and frightened several Democratic Congressmen in a flush of anti-tax fervor, the leaders of a citizen group that helped nurture that anger are savoring their success and planning their next campaign.
Widely expected to win comfortably, Mr. Bradley was nearly upset by a Republican newcomer, Christine Todd Whitman, who skillfully tapped the voters' anger. Now, the citizens' group, Hands Across New Jersey, believes it can turn that public mistrust of government into a major issue that the candidates for all 120 seats in the State Legislature will have to address in next year's elections. 
 "We were able to channel a political storm this year," said Janet Coates of Ewing Township, who, with her husband, Tom, was among the seven people who formed Hands Across New Jersey to battle Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion program of higher sales and income taxes. "And all legislators who fail to heed the message we were bringing will be blown out next year by a hurricane."
 
Recall Power Sought
 Leaders of the organization, which now has coordinators in all 21 counties and a list of 2,000 volunteers, say they will work with other taxpayer and public-interest groups to try to force repeal of the taxes, even in the face of predictions of widening budget problems. And they plan to demand that candidates for the Legislature embrace proposals to allow the public to place binding questions on the ballot and to recall elected officials.
But there are signs that the anti-tax forces will not have the stage to themselves next year and that organized support for the Governor's tax and school aid programs is on the way.
Urban mayors who met during the State League of Municipalities convention in Atlantic City last week say they intend to begin educating their residents to the property tax relief benefits in the package, and this week leaders of several groups representing the elderly met to announce their support of the Governor.
"I deplore the political bashing of Governor Florio's efforts to improve the welfare of the people of New Jersey," said Peter Shields, founder of the New Jersey Leadership Council on Aging.
 
The Imponderables Cited
 Political experts say it is too soon to tell if the new anti-tax groups will play as important a role in next year's elections as they did this year.
"Whenever the public believes government is not paying attention to its pocketbook, groups such as Hands Across New Jersey tend to rise up in anger," said Richard Roper, director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University.
But, he added, in the months ahead "all kinds of things can happen, including a war in the Middle East, that will alter the political terrain here in New Jersey and in every other state."
"We'll just have to wait and see how things play out," he said.
A black organization rebuked Hands Across New Jersey for opposing a proposal on the Nov. 6 ballot that would have provided $135 million in loans and grants for affordable housing programs. The measure lost by 66,000 votes, while the voters approved two gambling proposals -- to allow horse racing on Sundays and to permit Atlantic City casinos to take bets on horse races.
The chairman of the New Jersey Black Issues Convention, Councilman Donald Tucker of Newark, called the defeat of the housing proposal a "misguided campaign" that helped to deny the homeless and minority residents needed housing assistance.
Leaders of Hands Across New Jersey said they were opposed to the financing mechanism in the housing plan because it could have led to higher property taxes. They said they would support a bill recently introduced in the Legislature to salvage the housing program.
 
Better Organization Planned
 John Budzash, a letter carrier from Howell Township, became the driving force behind the creation of Hands Across New Jersey when he called into a radio program that was encouraging people to air their feelings about Governor Florio's tax plan. Mr. Budzash got in touch with Pat Ralston, a title searcher from Belmar, who also had called the station.
Ms. Ralston, who said the group raised and spent about $20,000 this year, chiefly on telephone bills, said discussions were under way to form a political action committee to undertake a more sophisticated fund-raising effort and to devise more effective campaign techniques next year.
"Up to now we've received everything from 25-cent postage stamps to donations in all amounts up to $100," she said.
With Democrats controlling both houses of the Legislature, Republican Party leaders like Assemblyman Robert D. Franks of New Providence, the state chairman, say they stand to benefit next year from the campaigns by the new grass-roots organization and other special-interest groups that have been in the field for years.
 
Republicans Cautioned
 But leaders of the taxpayer groups say the Republicans will be making a mistake if they take their support for granted, and at least one Republican lawmaker believes it would be foolish to count the votes of angry taxpayers too soon.
"There is a lot of negative feeling out there, but that doesn't mean they want to anoint us," said Senator William L. Gormley of Margate.
"Republicans think they have backers now, but they're wrong," Mr. Budzash said. "What we want is accountability by all of our elected officials."
For this reason, Hands Across New Jersey and the United Taxpayers of New Jersey, formed in 1977 to protest enactment of the state income tax, are supporting a legislative agenda that calls for laws granting voters the right to place binding public questions on the ballot and the right to recall elected officials, including the governor and members of the Legislature.
They also want limits on terms of office for the Legislature, and this month a new organization that calls itself Revolt announced that it had been formed to push for such limits. Tom Blomquist of Brick Township, a retired captain in the Coast Guard and state coordinator of the new group, said it would join with the two taxpayer organizations and the New Jersey Conservative Caucus to insure that the issue plays an important role in next year's election.
 
Bill Seeks Legislature Limits
 The Assembly minority leader, Chuck Haytaian, Republican of Independence Township and one of the strongest critics of the Governor's new tax and school-aid plans, became the first lawmaker to endorse limits on terms in the Legislature. He introduced a bill on Monday to limit a State Assembly member to six consecutive two-year terms and a state senator to four consecutive terms. However, Mr. Haytaian had no co-sponsors and could not predict whether the bill wouild attract much support among his colleagues.
Samuel Perelli, president of the United Taxpayers of New Jersey, said: "We've been fighting for a voter initiative package for 15 years, and we needed a giant sledgehammer in the past to get people's attention. But now it is a demand that the lawmakers won't be able to ignore."
Mr. Perelli recalled that he thought an initiative and referendum law would pass in 1985, when it had the support of Gov. Thomas H. Kean and was part of the Republican Party platform. But he said some lawmakers who pledged their support backed down when the bill came up for a vote.
"They lied," he said,"but this time we're not taking anything for granted."
 
Signature Campaign Continues
 Mrs. Coates said that Hands Across New Jersey had collected 800,000 signatures supporting repeal of the Florio tax package and was collecting more.
Mr. Budzash said the organization was sticking to its demand for repeal, even in the face of reports by State Treasurer Douglas C. Berman and others in the Legislature that the state faced a $600 million revenue shortfall in this fiscal year and $800 million in fiscal 1992.
"It just shows that enacting new taxes doesn't help the economy," Mr. Budzash said. "It hurts it."
Hands Across New Jersey attracted the support of the Coalition of New Jersey Sportsmen, who were angered by Mr. Florio's success in enacting a law banning the sale or possession of semi-automatic rifles, and the tax group also received some advice on campaign strategy from Richard J. Feldman, a former lobbyist for the National Rifle Association. However, Mrs. Coates said the relationship of her organization with other groups and individuals "is one of mutual respect, but we design our own campaigns."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Control Data Deal With CSK of Japan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 21

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation will sell Micrognosis, which devises computer systems for the financial industry, to the CSK Corporation, Japan's largest independent computer services company, the companies said. No terms were disclosed.
Micrognosis, based in Danbury, Conn., supplies trading-room systems for the financial services industry, serving 250 banks, insurance companies, securities firms and corporations from 25 offices in 15 countries. It had revenues of about $100 million last year. The company's estimated 430 employees, most of whom work in Danbury, New York and London, will be retained, Control Data said.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Rise 72 Cents On a Decline in Supplies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices rose moderately yesterday, as the futures market turned bullish over a drop in the crude supply and France's prediction that the United Nations Security Council will authorize military action against Iraq.
Crude oil moved up 72 cents, to $29.63 a barrel, for January delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange, erasing much of Tuesday's decline of $1.81 a barrel. 
 Volume was about as light as it has been for any session since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, as traders prepared to take off for the Thanksgiving holiday. The oil market reopens Friday, but some traders planned to take a four-day weekend.
"I suppose we're having one of the dullest days we've had in several weeks around here," said Bob Baker, an oil analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
 
 Possibility of the Unexpected
 Traders were generally unwilling to enter into oil contracts because of the possibility of unexpected developments in the Persian Gulf, where President Bush will spend the holiday with United States troops.
"In the back of people's minds, they're thinking anything could happen with him over there," said Peter Beutel, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J.
Oil opened higher in response to an American Petroleum Institute report issued the night before that showed stocks of crude oil and refined products dropped in the previous week.
Crude then hit its high for the day of $30.20 a barrel after President Francois Mitterrand of France said he had told President Bush that a United Nations resolution authorizing force against Iraq was needed. The French leader said such a resolution would likely be passed within three weeks.
 
 Perceptions of the Soviets
 Adding to the market's bullish mood were perceptions that the United States and the Soviet Union had become closer in their views on the gulf crisis.
"The Soviets, who were talking about being against military intervention earlier in the week, have kind of backpedaled," said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. "Each day, we find they agree more and more with President Bush."
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union yesterday urged the Security Council to meet immediately on the gulf crisis.
As oil moved ahead, refined petroleum products also rose.
Unleaded gasoline was up 1.48 cents, to 78.95 cents a gallon on December contracts, with later contract months moving higher as well. Home heating oil was higher for all delivery months, with the December contract up 0.79 cent, at 85.24 cents a gallon.
Mr. Baker said heating oil's relatively weaker performance reflected a belief among traders that no supply problems seem likely this winter.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EUROPE;
34 LEADERS ADOPT PACT PROCLAIMING A UNITED EUROPE

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The leaders of 34 European and North American states, great and small, rich and not so rich, today proclaimed the end of the "era of confrontation and division" that followed World War II.
In a Charter of Paris for a New Europe, a kind of no-fault peace treaty marking the final denouement of the global conflict that began half a century ago, the 34 pledged a "steadfast commitment to democracy based on human rights and fundamental freedoms, prosperity through economic liberty and social justice, and equal security for all countries." 
 "Full respect for these precepts is the bedrock on which we will seek to construct the new Europe," the charter promises, and it contains none of the escape clauses that have rendered many such pledges moot in the past. [Excerpts, page A16.]
 
'Cold War Is Over'
 "The cold war is over," said President Bush, who had refrained until today from making such a statement. "In signing the Charter of Paris we have closed a chapter of history."
The drama of the words lay in the knowledge that they would have been inconceivable as a unifying formula in the Europe of two years or two hundred years ago, when the Continent was cut by ideology, treaty or religion into hostile blocs. The drama of the signing ceremony lay in the fact that its main actors were recently enemies, and that some of the supporting players, such as President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, spent time in prison not long ago for campaigning for the rights now guaranteed.
The charter's only concrete act is to set up a secretariat, called the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Its headquarters will be in Prague, with a conflict-resolution center in Vienna and an office in Warsaw to monitor elections. In addition, officials of the conference are to meet regularly, with foreign ministers gathering once a year and the leaders every two years.
President Francois Mitterrand of France closed the three-day meeting of the conference by declaring that the 34 signers, including the Vatican and 33 countries ranging from the United States and the Soviet Union to tiny San Marino and Liechtenstein, "share a common vision of the world and a common set of values."
The French President said that "the old order and the false certainties that sustained it have collapsed." All institutions "must be rethought," he said, even the European Community.
 
'Perpetual Political Discussion'
 Many Europeans have hoped that the Conference might develop into the long-sought pan-European security system. But the group has no enforcement mechanisms; it gives equal weight to the voices of Germany and Malta; and it is not clear that it can ever become more than "perpetual political discussion," as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain once termed it.
With political disintegration threatening the Soviet Union and ethnic divisions re-emerging all over Eastern Europe, there was little euphoria here this week. And there was widespread apprehension that democracy, in the words of the Finnish diplomat Max Jakobson, "is unlikely to develop in the midst of the economic catastrophe" that now faces the old Soviet empire.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union underscored the threat of famine this winter, handing Western officials an urgent grocery list that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada said included pork, beef, flour, butter, powdered milk and peanut oil.
The German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said that the European Community was considering food aid worth $1 billion, and many leaders stressed the need to help the Soviet leader survive the crisis brought on by food shortages and by mounting regional discontent with rule by Moscow.
 
Gulf Discussed Offstage
 Although much offstage diplomacy focused on the crisis in the Persian Gulf, where Iraqi troops have now occupied Kuwait for almost four months, the summit conference itself never took up the topic. The leaders made no declaration about it and the Soviet Union, despite intensive American efforts, failed to pledge support for a new United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq.
Before heading for Saudi Arabia, where he will spend Thanksgiving visiting the American forces arrayed against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, President Bush commented, "I leave Paris feeling that we are still together as countries who want to see this situation reversed and want to see" Iraqi forces get out of Kuwait without conditions, concessions or negotiations.
Later in the day, Mr. Gorbachev said the Security Council should meet without delay to consider the Gulf problem. "We can't just leave things this way without giving them closer analysis," he said, and he called for "resolute and firm" behavior but said nothing about a new Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq.
At a news conference tonight, Mr. Mitterrand predicted that a resolution authorizing force would be adopted within the next three weeks, and said France, which has a permanent seat on the Security Council, would back it. But he also said he had told Mr. Bush that such a resolution would not give the United States or anyone else the "automatic" right to attack.
 
The Signing Ceremony
 As the host, Mr. Mitterrand was the first leader to sign the concluding document, which was bound in red leather. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany followed, and then came Mr. Bush. Mr. Gorbachev was one of the last to affix his signature at the matter-of-fact, 15-minute ceremony held in the Kleber International Conference Center just off the Champs Elysees.
Human rights, not security, turned out to be the main theme here.
Opening the conference on Monday, Mr. Mitterrand referred to it as an "anti-Congress of Vienna." The celebrated meeting in 1815, dominated by Metternich of Austria, a prince, and Talleyrand of France, a prince and a bishop, "ignored the people and their aspirations," Mr. Mitterrand said, but this meeting grew directly out of the commitment to human rights undertaken in Helsinki in 1975 and the stunning revolutions in Eastern Europe in 1989.
"Democratic government is based on the will of the people, expressed regularly through free and fair elections," says the document signed today by officials of every country in Europe except Albania, plus the United States and Canada. "Democracy is the best safeguard of freedom of expression, tolerance of all groups of society and equal opportunity for each person."
 
Participation Broadened
 Michael Mandelbaum, a Europe specialist at the Council on Foreign Relations, noted last week that "peace conferences of the past and summit meetings of the Cold War period involved exclusively the great powers."
"This forum signifies the hope and expectation that Europe has reached the end of the period in which the two great nuclear powers decided its fate," he said. "This summit meeting expresses the hope and expectation that post-cold-war Europe will be a much more plural political order than it has been, not only in the recent past but, in some senses, than it has ever been before."
Before the conference even began, the 16 members of NATO and the 6 remaining members of the Warsaw Pact signed one of the most comprehensive arms-reduction treaties in history, cutting by tens of thousands the permissible number of conventional weapons between the Urals and the Atlantic. At the same time, they also signed a mutual agreement of non-aggression.
 
Debut for United Germany
 It was, of course, the first great international conference for the newly unified German nation, and the fact that there was one spokesman for Germany, not two, was another reminder of the swift pace of recent change. There was no "German question" on the agenda or in most delegates' minds.
"They're all used to it by now," said Mr. Kohl, expressing astonishment that the rest of Europe had accepted the new Germany so readily. "It's almost forgotten that the original purpose of this meeting was to give permission for our unification."
But he warned that his country should not use all the power its new size and strength might give it. He told reporters, "We Germans played big shots for 50 years. Now we should be little shots for 50 years."
And he urged the nations gathered here not to ignore the repeated appeals of Eastern European leaders for aid from the wealthy Western states.
"There must now be no borders which perpetuate the prosperity divide," Mr. Kohl declared. "The ideological gulfs that have been overcome must not be torn open again."

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Filing by Laventhol

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Attributing its problems to a litigious society, changes in the tax law, a soft economy and negative publicity, Laventhol & Horwath, once the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, filed for protection from creditors yesterday in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York.
The Chapter 11 filing is believed to be the largest by a professional-services firm. At its peak, the Philadelphia-based Laventhol had 318 partners in 52 offices and earned $350 million in annual revenues. 
 The firm was larger than Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey, a law firm whose 1987 collapse spawned several best-selling books and remains the subject of much litigation.
 
 $6.9 Million Shortfall
 According to Laventhol's court papers, the accounting firm had $6.9 million more in liabilities than assets as of Oct. 13, the date of its last balance sheet, when it recorded $146.4 million in assets and $153.3 million in liabilities.
But an attorney for Laventhol, Michael J. Crames, noted yesterday that the firm's debts were probably understated in light of the more than 100 lawsuits pending against Laventhol before the filing. The suits, accusing Laventhol of poor work, seek nearly $2 billion in damages, representing "a potential exposure in the tens of millions of dollars," the filing said.
Laventhol was the auditor for P.T.L., the discredited television ministry founded by Jim Bakker, and it is defending its work in a multimillion-dollar lawsuit in Charlotte, N.C.
 
 Other Lawsuits May Be Coming
 On top of that, Laventhol expects to be sued by some of its landlords for breaking its leases, as well as by former clients, who are expected to contend that the firm mishandled their accounts. "The big unknown is the litigation," said Mr. Crames, a senior partner with Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler in New York. "How much it will be, nobody knows today."
Bankruptcy experts said yesterday that many of Laventhol's assets could turn out to be of dubious value, which would worsen the $6.9 million shortfall. Laventhol's biggest asset is $81 million in receivables, money owed but not yet collected from clients for work it has performed.
But clients are notorious for resisting payment in such situations, and that could be especially true if they can successfully argue that the disruption forced them to hire new accountants to handle their forthcoming audits for the end of the year, and that the new auditors had to start from scratch.
"If they do not stay in business, then there'll be a real problem collecting," said Francis Musselman, the New York lawyer who is the Chapter 11 trustee for Finley, Kumble. He said he expected ultimately to collect about 40 percent of the $107 million in receivables that the law firm was owed when it filed for bankruptcy.
Like Finley, Kumble, Laventhol only intends to operate under Chapter 11 protection long enough to supervise an orderly collection of its assets. To that end, the firm has reached an agreement with many of its former partners that entitles them to 5 percent of any billed amount and 10 percent of any unbilled amount they collect on Laventhol's behalf.
 
 3,273 People Out of Work
 Besides the 3,273 Laventhol employees who lost their jobs this week, the bankruptcy leaves many creditors. The largest secured creditors were the banks that advanced Laventhol an $80 million loan between busy seasons last year. The loan was refinanced in March, leaving the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia owed $59.2 milion and the Chase Manhattan Bank owed $24.5 million.
The largest unsecured creditors, who range from landlords to retired partners, are the State Street Bank and Trust Company in Boston, which is owed $3.7 million; Tishman Midwest, the firm's landlord in Chicago, which is owed $549,150, as well as Laventhol's New York landlord, believed to be Fisher Brothers, which is owed $487,458. Smaller unsecured creditors include Deloitte & Touche, another accounting firm, and the Federal Express Corporation, the overnight package-delivery service.
 
 Filing Cites Other Factors
 In its filing, Laventhol's chief executive, Robert N. Levine, cited many external factors for the firm's financial woes, including changes in the Federal tax law that made accounting a more seasonal business than it once was and investors' quickness to sue accounting firms whenever businesses fail.
"From Laventhol & Horwath's perspective, its inclusion in such actions was more a result of the perception of it being a deep pocket than the result of deficiencies in the satifaction of its professional responsibilites," Mr. Levine said in the filing.
 
 Competitors Not Interested
 It was those looming legal risks that caused competitors to want to distance themselves from Laventhol's problems. The firm also made the unusual acknowledgement in the filing that it had talked with numerous competitors -- including Price Waterhouse, Deloitte & Touche, Coopers & Lybrand and Arthur Andersen -- in the last 10 months in hopes of striking a deal that would solve its debt problems. But Laventhol was not successful.
"Given the economic realities of today's business climate, it seems clear that no other accounting firm can be persuaded to merge with or acquire Laventhol & Horwath," Mr. Levine said in the filing. He added that morale had declined because of "continued negative publicity in the national press."

HEADLINE: THE MILKEN SENTENCE;
The Vigil in Foley Square for the Magic Number

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
It took 27 minutes for the judge to finally speak the magic number -- and seconds for Michael R. Milken to absorb the shock.
Throughout a morning of mounting drama in Room 318 at the Federal Court House at Foley Square, probably no one had an inkling there would be the electrifying theater that resulted, for probably no one imagined a magic number as high as 10 years. All that many in the audience could do was squirm and gasp. 
 When United States District Judge Kimba M. Wood gave her pronouncement -- 10 years in prison, 3 years probation -- she ended the long, tortured case against what has been viewed as the biggest scalp in the Wall Street investigations.
She also ended a long morning that began shortly after dawn as members of the press and onlookers blanketed the Court House steps, hoping for pictures and glimpses of the financial wizard, maybe the last for a while.
 
 'Hey, Junk Bond Man'
 Wearing a gray suit, the 44-year-old Mr. Milken and his wife, Lori, arrived in a Lincoln Town Car at 9:30. He stepped out first, turned and waited for his wife, then gave her his hand. He strode up the steps looking straight ahead, never heeding the repeated cries of, "Hey, junk bond man" and "Yo, Michael, baby. Look this way."
Up in the squarish courtroom, a packed house of nearly 200 people listened patiently to an hourlong plea by Arthur L. Liman, Mr. Milken's attorney. In large part, it was a reading of letters from people touched by Mr. Milken. There was one from a new employee who was so afraid of work she thought of jumping off a chair and breaking her legs so she could stay home. But Mr. Milken soothed her.
Mr. Liman mentioned the $360 million Mr. Milken had given away. He mentioned he had volunteered to be a math teacher. And he confessed that he wasn't a psychiatrist and, "I can't offer an explanation for how Michael slipped."
All Mr. Milken wanted to be remembered for, Mr. Liman said, was that he "made a difference to the children in the inner city."
Jess Fardella, an assistant United States attorney, took just 10 minutes to stress the prosecution's belief that Mr. Milken did not resemble anything like an angel and that his crimes were worthy of heavy-duty punishment.
 
 Indication of a Surprise
 It was during the 27 minutes of prefatory remarks by Judge Wood that one got the impression that a surprise was in the offing. She emphasized that she did not buy the argument that Mr. Milken had committed "subtle" and "technical" crimes. She said one had to wonder whether he calculatedly chose to commit crimes that would be hard to detect. She underscored the fact that Mr. Milken had not yet cooperated with the Government in its inquiries, something that could win a more lenient term.
Mr. Milken had sat as a silent enigma throughout an eight-day special hearing preceding the sentencing. He sobbed audibly during part of Mr. Liman's plea yesterday, but spoke only a few choked-up words of apology before the sentence was announced. He stood stoical, listening to the sentence, though there was no escaping the feeling that here was a beaten man.
After the sentence was announced, the spectators were divided in their impressions. "Brutal," exclaimed one grizzled man. "That's a long time to go up the river."
"I don't know why one man should take all the heat of the battle," a middle-aged woman said. "What about the politicians taking bribes? How about them letting kids buy houses in New Jersey for 10 percent down. It used to be 25 or 30 percent. Why just stick it to this man?"
 
 A Decade of Greed
 But there were people hoping for a verdict condemning a decade of greed. A young woman wearing a ponytail insisted that "even 28 years would not have been enough."
Rebecca Gessler brought a curious perspective to the sentencing. She was covering the event for her reporting class at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism. Before enrolling at Columbia, however, she had worked for a firm that had been hired to perform economics research for Mr. Milken's attorneys. From January through August, she and colleagues inspected every transaction that Mr. Milken's department executed, searching for foul play. She said the work was absolutely no fun.
"When I was working there, my opinion was that what he did wasn't as bad as the prosecutors made it out to be," Ms. Gessler said. "But now that I've been away from it, I feel a little different. I was shocked by the sentence. But I feel the crimes seem to warrant a long sentence."
Martin Klein, a lawyer and longtime friend of Mr. Milken, was indignant and quick to share his views. "Obviously, it's a miscarriage of justice," he said. "I think the judge may have been reacting to the hundreds of people here and is making Michael a scapegoat for the excesses of the 1980's."
"He's a good person and a strong person, and he will survive," Mr. Klein went on. "Unfortunately, the country will be deprived of his talents for a long time."
 
 Betting on the Sentence
 Many gambling pools were formed around the magic number. One young woman felt miserable that she had put her money on five years. Only her boss had picked 10, she said, "and we all thought she did that because she was ignorant."
As the lunch hour neared, hundreds of people waited outside to witness Mr. Milken's departure. An hour ticked by without anyone more newsworthy appearing than a troop of third graders who had dropped by to see a swearing-in ceremony.
Then someone came up with a reasonable answer. Mr. Milken had abruptly wised up and was upstairs finally spilling all to the Government. All over Wall Street, hundreds of people were being fingered.
Among those impatiently listening to such theories was Enid Adler, a lawyer from Philadelphia who said she was engaged in a class-action suit against Mr. Milken. She clasped a small Nikon. "After poring through thousands and thousands of documents, I think I'm entitled to a photo," she said.
But in the end, Ms. Adler and the throng were disappointed. Mr. Milken had ducked out the back.
