HEADLINE: THE MILKEN SENTENCE;
The Breakdown of 'Junk'

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Michael R. Milken was sentenced to 10 years in prison not for his role in a "decade of greed," but for crimes that were aimed at enriching himself and his clients, Federal Judge Kimba M. Wood said yesterday.
 But Mr. Milken's legacy nonetheless will be his role in the 1980's, and much of the vilification he is now receiving stems from worries that the financial excesses of the decade will lead to disaster in the 1990's. 
 The "junk bond" revolution begun by Mr. Milken and his colleagues at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. helped make it possible for many companies and entrepreneurs to get money to start and expand a wide range of enterprises. Companies including MCI Communications, now the second-largest long-distance telephone company, and Turner Broadcasting might never have grown without Mr. Milken's help.
But that revolution left many companies deeply in debt; some have collapsed and more face that danger as a recession unfolds. Fear of those consequences has intensified the criticism of Mr. Milken and may have contributed to the harshness of the sentence.
At his peak, Mr. Milken had the power to allow corporate raiders to make multibillion-dollar acquisitions, even if they had relatively few assets to begin with.
 
Winners and Losers
 Nelson Peltz and Peter May, for example, made hundreds of millions of dollars from a small start by buying two can-making companies, American Can and National Can, with Drexel money and later selling them. Others, like William Farley, stayed too long at the party. Mr. Farley's Drexel-financed effort to acquire West Point-Pepperell, a big textile maker, left him financially pressed and in danger of losing control of the other company he bought with Drexel money, the underwear maker Fruit of the Loom.
For the country, it is the added debt burden of corporate America that figures largest in evaluating Mr. Milken's long-term impact. Interest payments eat up more than a quarter of cash flow of the average American company, a record percentage and one sure to rise as the economic downturn depresses revenues. Some of the more dire economic forecasts are based on the prediction that the high debt burden will lead to a wave of bankruptcies, deepening and prolonging the recession that probably has already begun.
Mr. Milken was not the sole architect of heavy corporate borrowing, but he was both the evangelist and the innovator behind the rapid increase. By the mid-1980's, when junk bonds began to be used for hostile takeovers, corporate executives realized that a company with unused borrowing power was in jeopardy. Where once that borrowing power was seen as providing security for a rainy day, now it was seen as itself being a threat. A raider could effectively use that borrowing power as collateral for loans to buy the company's stock and throw the executives out of work.
"Milken is a symbol of the 1980's," said Samuel Hayes, an investment banking professor at the Harvard Business School. "He created something in the junk bond, and built it into a machine that was extraordinarily powerful. In retrospect, it now appears that some of the momentum behind that machine was due to illegal actions."
When Mr. Milken first entered the securities business, in the 1970's, junk bonds were relegated to an obscure part of the financial community. Known as "fallen angels," most of these securities were bonds issued by companies that once had good credit standing, but whose credit had deteriorated. Many investors automatically sold bonds that ran into such problems, driving them down to prices that Mr. Milken rightly argued more than offset the increased risk. He developed a following by buying and trading such bonds.
The business grew into underwriting and selling junk bonds for companies that did not qualify as investment-grade issuers. Buyers of the bonds generally prospered, more and more money became available for such investments, and credit standards started to deteriorate. A study by Barrie A. Wigmore, a limited partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, found the quality of junk bonds issued in the early 1980's was vastly superior to those issued later.
Not surprisingly, it is the later bonds that have most often defaulted, and those who bought such bonds in recent years generally have suffered significant losses in the collapse of the junk bond market, while bonds issued earlier have generally provided profits for buyers.
Drexel's Coterie of Clients
Drexel and Mr. Milken developed a coterie of clients, many of whom bought each other's bonds. That was especially true of the financial institutions that were involved, among them the First Executive Corporation, a life insurance company, and the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, both based in Southern California. Many of those institutions are now having severe financial difficulties.
For a period, Drexel was the only firm that could raise huge quantities of cash for certain types of hostile takeovers, notably those where the would-be buyer did not have much in the way of assets before the raid began. Some companies paid raiders to go away -- a practice known as greenmail. They viewed them as little more than Drexel creations and got Drexel to promise not to finance other raiders going after them.
In large part to find a way to compete with Drexel, many investment banks turned to bridge loans, in which they used their own money to help finance takeovers. Some of those loans went bad, producing huge losses for the firms.
Just how, or when, crime came into the Drexel picture is unclear -- and may remain so. Stock parking, in which ownership is disguised to circumvent regulations, seems to have been fairly common. Mr. Milken admitted stock manipulation in connection with a botched takeover attempt by Golden Nugget, and Drexel confessed to stock manipulation that was far more serious, by Wall Street ethical standards, because the crime seemed aimed at damaging a Drexel investment banking client by forcing the client to agree to more generous terms in a pending financing.
The accusations against Mr. Milken came from only a few sources, of which the most important was Ivan F. Boesky, the takeover stock speculator who turned in Mr. Milken in an effort to get lenient treatment after his own insider trading was uncovered. The other sources included tapes of conversations involving Drexel and a money management firm, Princeton Newport Partners, now defunct, and Drexel's own records, which led to two charges of insider trading that were dropped in the plea agreement with Mr. Milken.
 
 Narrowly Focused Charges
 The charges thus took into account a small portion of Mr. Milken's activities. The public is unlikely to learn soon if the narrow focus indicates that crimes at Drexel were extraordinary events or only that there were a limited number of informers. Having failed to provide significant cooperation to prosecutors before he was sentenced, Mr. Milken is unlikely to offer to turn in others now, although Judge Wood said she might reduce his sentence if he did so.
The financial world now is a far different place from the one that Mr. Milken dominated only a few years ago. Fear has replaced greed as the dominant Wall Street emotion, and lenders are scared of risk. Companies that could borrow many millions a few years ago now cannot get a dime. That type of reaction is inevitable in a credit cycle, and probably would have taken place even if Mr. Milken had never traded a bond.
But it is arguable that the credit cycle went on longer, and rose to greater heights, than it would have without him, and that the downturn in the cycle will therefore be all the more painful, leading to a severe recession. If that dire forecast turns out to be true, public scorn for Mr. Milken, and other financiers, could be just starting to grow.

HEADLINE: THE MILKEN SENTENCE;
Excerpts From Judge Wood's Explanation of the Milken Sentencing

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from comments by Judge Kimba M. Wood yesterday about her sentencing of Michael R. Milken in Federal District Court in Manhattan:
 Because of the extraordinary interest that has been expressed in this case and the fact that many letters to the court reflect misconceptions about what it is that Michael Milken is being punished for, I believe that I should briefly attempt to dispel those misconceptions, many of which were alluded to by Mr. Liman. 
 The letters reflect a perception that we as a society must find those responsible for the alleged abuses of the 1980's, economic harm caused savings and loan associations, takeover targets and those allegedly injured by the issuance of junk bonds as well as by insider trading and other alleged abuses, and punish these criminals in proportion to the losses believed to have been suffered. These writers ask for a verdict on a decade of greed.
While I sympathize with the anxiety expressed in these letters, the suppositions upon which these views are based cannot enter into sentencing defendant on the six counts of wrongdoing to which he plead guilty. Our system of justice protects everyone from being sentenced on supposition and it is this court's responsibility to insure that defendant receives that same protection here.
It is important to note as well that although many of those who wrote to the court believe that defendant should be treated harshly because they believe that he is the one responsible for the massive job losses and the financial failure of savings and loan associations, the Government did not charge him with responsibility here for those losses. For the Government to prove such charges would have required the Government to try to isolate the effect of defendant's actions from all of the other forces acting in the marketplace.
For similar reasons the court cannot take into account the claims of those who urge leniency for defendant because he allegedly created jobs and business opportunities or drew capital to its most productive uses. Determinations such as these would require information not before the court and would, for example, require the court to speculate on how defendant's clients would have invested their money absent his advice, and what effect those actions would have on job creation or loss, business opportunities and productivity.
I note that these letters also reflect a legitimate public concern that everyone, no matter how rich or powerful, obey the law as alluded to by Mr. Fardella, and that our financial markets in which so many people who are not rich invest their savings be free of secret manipulation. This is a concern fairly to be considered by the court.
 
Looking at Milken's Conduct
 I will turn now to the conduct for which defendant is being sentenced.
You are being sentenced for six counts of criminal activity spanning approximately three years in participation with several other people involving several different transactions that violated securities laws, tax laws and other laws.
You have attempted to mitigate these crimes by claiming they represented no more than overzealous service to your clients, that they involved mere technicalities and that they did not represent the core of how you did business.
I will speak to these points briefly before moving to the factors influencing sentencing.
To the extent that your crimes benefited your clients, that is, of course, no excuse for violating the law. In addition, there is no escaping the fact that your crimes also benefited you, not necessarily by lining your pockets directly and immediately, but by increasing your clients loyalty to you, hence, increasing your edge over competitors and increasing the likelihood that your clients would pay for your services in the future.
It has also been argued that your violations were technical ones to be distinguished from accumulating profits through insider trading and that your conduct is not really criminal or that it is only barely criminal.
It was suggested that if you were truly disposed to criminal conduct, you could have made much more money by committing more blatant crimes such as repeatedly misusing insider information.
 
Pattern of Skirting the Law
 These arguments fail to take into account the fact that you may have committed only subtle crimes not because you were not disposed to any criminal behavior but because you were willing to commit only crimes that were unlikely to be detected.
We see often in this court individuals who would be unwilling to rob a bank, but who readily cash Social Security checks that are not theirs when checks come to them in the mail because they are not likely to be caught doing so.
Your crimes show a pattern of skirting the law, stepping just over to the wrong side of the law in an apparent effort to get some of the benefits from violating the law without running a substantial risk of being caught.
In this regard, your post-Nov. 14, 1986, comments to other employees about subpoenas are of the same character as the six admitted offenses. You did not order employees to destroy or remove documents, but you communicated the advisability of their doing so in subtle terms that preserved some deniability on your part.
Your attorneys also argue that most of your business was conducted lawfully and that you would have prospered even absent the unlawful practices you admitted.
The evidence before the court on this point is sparse and equivocal. I do not know, for example, whether some of your biggest clients would have made their funds available to you repeatedly without the benefits fund managers personally received from Drexel. Statements to the contrary made by fund managers at the Fatico hearing were unpersuasive, given their self-serving nature.
There may some day be enough information for another entity, be it a court, or, as Mr. Liman suggested, a historian, to judge whether most of your business was conducted lawfully, but I cannot make that judgment today either way.
 
The Need for Deterrence
 Let me turn then to the purposes of sentencing and their application here. As was pointed out, purposes are generally thought to be individual deterrence, general deterrence, punishment or just deserts, retribution and rehabilitation.
Taking them one by one, deterring you as an individual from breaking the law again has already been furthered in part by your being barred from ever again working in the securities industry, by your $200 million fine, by the $400 million restitution fund that you have funded and by the fact that you face numerous civil lawsuits that could result in your paying even more than the $400 million that you have already paid to the restitution fund.
I am sensitive to the view that you and your family have already been punished by the sanctions I have just mentioned and by the emotional stress of living with the uncertainty of your status and your sentence since the prosecution began.
I have given considerable thought to whether a sentence of lengthy community service would be an adequate penalty here. It would have the advantages of permitting you to work productively with others which I believe you could do well rather than having you be warehoused in a prison. Nevertheless, I believe that a prison term is required for the purposes of general deterrence; that is, the need to deter others from violating the law and the possibility that the sentence given in one case will prevent others from violating law.
Prison sentences are viewed as one of the most powerful deterrents to the financial community. This view is reflected in the legislatively mandated sentencing guidelines which punish white-collar crimes with more prison time than was common before their adoption, and I have looked to those guidelines for some guidance in connection with this sentencing.
When a man of your power in the financial world, at the head of the most important department of one of the most important investment banking houses in this country, repeatedly conspires to violate, and violates, securities and tax laws in order to achieve more power and wealth for himself and his wealthy clients, and commits financial crimes that are particularly hard to detect, a significant prison term is required in order to deter others.
This kind of misuse of your leadership position and enlisting employees who you supervised to assist you in violating the law are serious crimes warranting serious punishment and the discomfort and opprobrium of being removed from society.
Although community service can further the goals of punishment and retribution in cases whereby requiring a defendant to forego remunerative employment for a while, it causes defendant to suffer financially, such would not be the case here. In this case both the sanctions already imposed and imprisonment will further the goals of punishment and retribution.
The goal of rehabilitation is likely to be furthered by your providing community service after your incarceration.
 
Factors Behind the Sentencing
 I turn now to the sentence that is appropriate.
In deciding how long a prison term is appropriate and how much community service is appropriate, I have taken into account that long before your current legal problems you took a significant amount of your own personal time to serve the community by working with disadvantaged children rather, for example, than using all of your personal time to acquire possessions. You also successfully encouraged your colleagues at work to do the same.
I have also taken into account the emotional support that you have provided to your family, neighbors, co-workers, and the fact that many colleagues and competitors found you to be forthright, honorable and honest in your dealings with them over the years.
On the other side of the scale, I must also take into account that you were head of your department and that you used others in your department to effect unlawful schemes. By your example, you communicated that cutting legal and ethical corners is, at times, acceptable.
You also committed crimes that are hard to detect, and crimes that are hard to detect warrant greater punishment in order to be effective in deterring others from committing them.
 
Question of Cooperation
 I should also note, for the benefit of those who urge the court to sentence you to the full 28 years in an effort to force you to cooperate with the Government in its investigation in the future, that a court is not permitted to do that. Instead, a court is required to select a fair sentence for the crimes that occurred, and, only after making that decision, consider whether a defendant's cooperation with the Government warrants lightening the sentence.
Where a defendant cooperates with the Government fully and is of assistance to the Government, the defendant deserves a significant reduction in sentence for assisting the Government to uncover crimes that are otherwise very resistant to discovery.
So it is that Ivan Boesky, whose cooperation was characterized by the Government as the most extensive and remarkable in the history of the securities laws and who also persuaded his former staff to assist the Government in its investigation, was permitted to plead guilty to only one count of conspiracy to file a false statement that carried a maximum prison term of five years.
As I mentioned earlier, I have no way to evaluate now the value of any cooperation you may offer the Government in the future. I have never given a defendant credit for cooperation without knowing the extent of the cooperation and without knowing how useful the information was to the Government, and I will not deviate from that practice now.
If you cooperate, and if the Government moves for a reduction in your sentence based on your cooperation, the court can adjust your sentence accordingly.
 
Disregarded Statements
 Given that defense counsel objected to the portion of the Government's sentencing memorandum that urges the court to consider imposing a sentence as long as that given to the lead defendant in the Send case, which defense counsel views as a violation of the Government's undertaking in the plea agreement not to make any recommendation as to a specific term of incarceration, I note that I have totally disregarded all statements by the Government that relate to specific terms of incarceration as well as the Government's comparison of Mr. Boesky to Mr. Milken.
I made my own independent evaluation of the conduct of and sentences given to Mr. Boesky, Mr. Levine and others based on my reading of their presentence reports and the transcripts of sentencing arguments and I arrived at my own conclusion as to the appropriate proportionality among them.
 
Details of the Prison Term
 Mr. Milken, please rise.
You are unquestionably a man of talent and industry and you have consistently shown a dedication to those less fortunate than you. It is my hope that the rest of your life will fulfill the promise shown early in your career.
However, for the reasons stated earlier, I sentence you to a total of 10 years in prison, consisting of two years each on counts two through six to be served consecutively, and I also sentence you to three years of probation on count one. A special condition of your probation is that you serve full-time community service, 1,800 hours per year for each of the three years, in a program to be determined by the court. I also impose the mandatory statutory assessment of $50 on each count for a total of $300.
I advise you that you have a right to appeal this sentence.
You may be seated at this point.

HEADLINE: THE MILKEN SENTENCE;
Judge With a Reputation For Innovative Rulings

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Federal judge who sentenced Michael R. Milken yesterday to 10 years in prison has a reputation for bold and sometimes imaginative decisions and apparently did not feel unusual pressure in sentencing one of the best-known financiers of the 1980's.
Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood normally works 12-to-14-hour days and did not change her schedule when given the voluminous files from the Milken case, said her husband, Michael S. Kramer, a columnist at Time magazine. "The notion that this has been a tense, nerve-racking thing for her is just not what I've seen at all," he said. 
 The actual length of the sentence for Mr. Milken, who became the most powerful investment banker of his era but violated a string of securities laws in the process, was a private decision for the judge. Over the weekend, Mr. Kramer said, "I asked her if she discussed it with her clerks, and she said no." He said the judge was unavailable for comment yesterday after her ruling.
 
 Novel Solutions
 Judge Wood is known in legal circles for her soft speech, solid grasp of law and economics and willingness to pursue innovative solutions to legal problems.
For example, in the settlement of a mail fraud case early last year, she devised a novel way to choose a special official who was to oversee the defendant's compliance, said Laura R. Handman, the New York lawyer who was appointed to the job and has since become a friend.
The settlement between the Justice Department and a mail order company called for a court-appointed official to review the truthfulness of the company's future mailings. When Judge Wood was presented with a list of candidates acceptable to both parties, she insisted that each candidate review the mailings that had led to the dispute and then give her an assessment, Ms. Handman said.
"It was a very ingenious, objective and useful way to go about picking a candidate," she said.
Judge Wood, 46 years old, has a bachelor's degree from Connecticut College, a master's from the London School of Economics and a law degree from Harvard University. She spent more than 15 years as a lawyer at LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae in New York, where she specialized in antitrust cases.
"Antitrust law fascinated her because of the economics and broader policy dimensions," said Geoffrey D. C. Best, a partner at LeBoeuf.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, nominated Judge Wood for the Federal judiciary in 1988. Mr. D'Amato said yesterday that he was impressed not only by her educational and professional background but also by her interest in public service.
"At a time when her career was taking off, she was willing to forgo the financial success" and take a job as a judge that would pay a fraction of her earnings as a partner at a large law firm, he said.
 
 'An Activist Judge'
 Because of the long hours required for her work, Judge Wood had to give up one of her hobbies, painting abstracts in oil, Mr. Kramer said. But she and her husband spend as much time as possible with their 4-year-old son, and the judge continues to play tennis and grow roses at a vacation home in Massachusetts.
Law professors who have read some of Judge Wood's decisions say that while her rulings are consistent with the letter of the law, they tend to reflect a concern for economic and social issues as well. "She is an activist judge in the sense that she is innovative and unafraid to follow her intelligence and research wherever they might lead," said Stephen Gillers, a law professor at New York University.
Judge Wood spoke strongly of the need to deter financial wrongdoing when she sentenced Mr. Milken yesterday. But Mr. Kramer said that his wife, although interested in policy issues, was following, "a staple of sentencing philosophy."

HEADLINE: Hard Times In Albany Dim Smile of Speaker

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Among the many sure indications of New York State's slide into economic turmoil is the subdued look on the face of Mel Miller, the normally exuberant Speaker of the New York State Assembly, a man known for addressing just about everyone he comes across in the Capitol as "Darling."
Mr. Miller, the most powerful Democrat in the Legislature and the man New York City officials most often look to for relief from Albany, is not promising any help these days. But the Speaker says that, in an almost perverse fashion, the Legislature's need to carve $1 billion out of the state's budget has made his job easier, though more troubling. He just says no. 
 "There are no winners here, no winners at all," said Mr. Miller, who was first elected 20 years ago to represent the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and who became Assembly Speaker in 1987. "This is not a situation where you have a billion dollars and you're trying to figure out who to give it to. This is a situation where you have to cut, and you're just looking to do it as broadly and as fairly as possible."
 
Backs Cuomo's Approach
 Now that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposals for cutting the state budget are out, the focus in Albany is shifting to Mr. Miller and his counterpart in the Republican-controlled State Senate, Ralph J. Marino, the majority leader. The Governor's plan, which must be acted on by the Legislature, calls for deep cuts in aid to local governments and school districts, and for layoffs of thousands of state workers.
During a bitter budget battle two years ago, the 51-year-old Mr. Miller accused Mr. Cuomo of promoting spending reductions that would hurt poor New Yorkers and "fly against the obligation of government." But he is not portraying the coming deliberations in such ideological terms.
In fact, while he declines to say whether he endorses specific proposals in the Governor's plan, he said today that he had committed himself to the Governor's approach, which involves closing the state's $1 billion budget gap through spending reductions and without raising taxes, borrowing money or resorting to financial tricks to balance the books.
 
'At the Margins'
 "I'm not sure you really have any choice about it at this point," he said, shrugging his shoulders.
Many analysts seem to agree with him. "Certainly he may seek to change some of the Governor's cuts, but it's likely to be more at the margins than at the core," said Raymond Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit monitoring group in New York City. "The basic obligation to cut is clearly there."
In staking out that position, Mr. Miller has left himself little room to maneuver in the budget minuet that will be played out here in the coming weeks, when the Legislature reconvenes in special session to take up the Governor's proposals. This is in marked contrast to a budget fight in the spring of 1989, when he prevailed against many proposed spending cuts and supported, along with Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Marino, one of the largest packages of tax increases in the state's history.
On the other hand, accepting the cuts at this point may not have a huge political fallout for Mr. Miller or for Democrats in the Assembly, who picked up three seats in the recent elections and now outnumber Republicans by 95 to 55. Mr. Cuomo drew up the list of cuts, and even if the package is adopted many lawmakers are expected to try to paint them as the Governor's.
 
Memorable Qualification
 Unlike Governor Cuomo, Mr. Miller is not exactly known for having a gift for public speaking. He is, in fact, better known for staring at the ceiling when he talks and saying things like "My head is that . . ." instead of "I believe that . . ." when reporters ask his opinions.
And, in a line he has never managed to live down, he once responded to a question about corruption in the Assembly by asserting that "personally speaking, for myself, to the best of my knowledge, I don't think I know anything, to the best of my knowledge."
Still, the Speaker has broad support from his Democratic colleagues in the Assembly and, in some contrast to Mr. Marino, his authority over his chamber has been unquestioned this year.
In Albany tradition, the Speaker, the Senate majority leader and the Governor make up the triumvirate of power in the Capitol, and many important decisions get made in so-called "leaders' meetings" among these three.
No one seems likely to challenge Mr. Miller's leadership in the near future, and the only apparent crack in his armor is one to which he has alluded himself. After an article appeared in The Village Voice, the Speaker acknowledged to his fellow Democrats earlier this year that he was under investigation concerning accusations of fraud in a 1985 real-estate transaction he conducted as a private lawyer. He has not been charged, and Mr. Miller said the allegations were unfounded.
 
'Reservoir of Credibility'
 Mr. Miller is widely recognized for his technical mastery of the state budget and other Albany arcana. When he called a meeting last week of Assembly committee chairmen, for instance, there was no dispute with his contention that cutting was the only serious option for solving the budget problem.
"There was no storm at the ramparts," said Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly investigations committee. "Mel has built an enormous reservoir of credibility with his members. No one doubted the problem was as bad as he said it was."
The Speaker's relationship with Governor Cuomo has been somewhat rockier. In 1987, when Mr. Miller took over, Mr. Cuomo engaged the Legislature in a prolonged battle over ethics legislation that was largely focused on payroll abuses that were said to have occurred before Mr. Miller was in charge.
Although a new set of ethics laws was ultimately passed, the Governor succeeded in putting Mr. Miller and other lawmakers on the defensive for most of the year.
 
A Warning of Worse
 And Mr. Miller, brushing aside Mr. Cuomo's reservations, sided with the Senate Republicans in 1987 in embracing a four-year tax cut. The state's fiscal woes have since caused the Legislature and Mr. Cuomo to defer a large part of the measure.
But relations between the two men seem far more cordial this year, and they largely agreed on budget details. And while Senate Republicans were downplaying the severity of the state's economic problems last spring, Mr. Miller backed the Governor's projections, indeed warning -- correctly -- that the problems were probably worse.
In the coming year, Mr. Miller's visibility seems likely only to increase. For one thing, he and Mr. Marino will control the redrawing of New York's Congressional district lines, a process that could be particularly tumultuous, since the state stands to lose at least three seats under current United States Census projections.
And although a run for statewide office seems unlikely anytime soon, Mr. Miller has vowed to direct some of his attention to issues of concern to upstate voters. All four new Democratic members of the Assembly are from upstate areas; of the 95 Democratic members, 38 are from outside New York City.
But for the moment, the Speaker, who normally exudes optimism, seems to have only discouraging words. "I tell people it's going to get worse," he said, spreading his arms in a gesture of helplessness. "How much worse? The downside is something you don't want to think about. The upside is, it will get only a little worse, not terribly worse. That's what I tell people these days."

HEADLINE: A Late Rally Pushes Dow Up by 9.16

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
After falling for much of the day, stocks rallied before yesterday's closing in thin trading. At that point some traders had already left to start the Thanksgiving holiday.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 9.16 points, to 2,539.36, with volume at 140.7 million shares, compared with 161.2 million on Tuesday. 
 The broader market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, gained 0.72 point, to 316.03. The number of Big Board issues advancing slightly trailed those declining, 719 to 746.
Although the market recovered from weakness, analysts cautioned that litle could be discerned from the pattern, with volume light and many market participants absent.
"One shouldn't read too much into pre-holiday sessions," said Stefan D. Abrams, chief investment strategist at Kidder, Peabody & Company. Rao Chalasani, his counterpart at Prescott, Ball & Turben in Cleveland, added, "It was one of those days when you can't really read anything into the market."
The Dow's sharp fall on Tuesday, when it lost 35 points, continued into yesterday's session, with blue chips down almost 20 points at 1 P.M. before rallying later in the afternoon.
With little economic news this week, traders looked ahead to the report on employment scheduled to be issued Dec. 7. The numbers are likely to be weak, they said, reflecting the economy, and the weaker they are, the more pressure there will be on the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy by continuing to take action to reduce short-term interest rates.
The most-active list was led by Boeing for a second day. The aircraft maker, which fell 4 5/8 on Tuesday, regained 1 5/8, to 44 1/4. Analysts at Merrill Lynch and Prudential-Bache reiterated buy ratings and said a report by Goldman, Sachs that touched off Boeing's drop had been too negative.
Banking and financial stocks continued under pressure. C & S/Sovran, a commercial banking company in the Southeast, lost 3/4, to 16 5/8. Citicorp lost 1/8, to 12 5/8. American Express fell 3/4, to 19 3/4. Smith Barney turned more negative on the Federal National Mortgage Association and several other banks and savings institutions. Fannie Mae lost 1, to 30 5/8.
National Semiconductor, the second-most-active stock, gained 3/4, to 4 1/4. The company said it planned to sell an advanced computer chip plant to Matsushita Electric for $86 million.
Square D, a maker of electric products, was up for a second day on takeover rumors, analysts said. The stock closed up 2, to 52 1/4.

 TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 22 (REUTERS) -- Japanese stock prices rose today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 583.29 points, or 2.56 percent, to close at 23,400.28. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 388.49 points.

HEADLINE: Growing Number of Parents Are Opting to Teach at Home

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
When Michael Polino's playmates trudge off to school, the 7-year-old stays at home, where the dining room table becomes his desk and his parents double as his teachers.
The youngster has started first grade at home in Lemont, Ill., in what has become an increasingly popular but much debated alternative to public school. 
 Dismayed at the troubled state of public education and certain they can do better, hundreds of thousands of parents have begun teaching their children at home. In the last five years, the number of children taught at home has increased nearly fivefold, to 300,000 children, by Government estimates, or up to 500,000, by estimates of groups that advocate teaching at home.
Educators say the movement is ill advised because it leaves some students vulnerable to well-meaning but unqualified parents and can strip youngsters of the chance to develop social skills.
Even 500,000 children represent a small a fraction of the 46.2 million students enrolled in public schools, but the recent surge in growth has been startling. In the 1970's, government and home school groups estimated that 10,000 to 15,000 students were taught at home, most in families doing so for religious reasons. Now a broader group of parents is choosing to teach their children at home, a choice that all states allow but some regulate more strictly than others.
"You're seeing more yuppies come into home schooling," said Sandy Hall of Seattle, a spokeswoman for the National Homeschool Association who teaches her two children at home. "A lot of that has to do with knowing that it is an option. So many people still assume that you have to send your child to public or private school."
In the past, those dissatisfied with public school tended to think their only alternative was private school, and for many that was too expensive. But with increasing concern about drugs and crime in public schools and about a decline in the quality of teachers, parents who cannot afford or dislike the notion of private school have felt compelled to find another option.
"These parents feel it is their duty to raise their children, and they enjoy being with them," said Patrick Farenga, president of Holt Associates, a Cambridge, Mass., research and publishing company, which publishes curricular materials for home schooling. "Also they don't want them to be hurt spiritually, physically or mentally -- and all those fall into a reaction against public school."
Home schooling has long been used by families with fundamentalist religious backgrounds, but its growth beyond that group has made professional educators and state education departments jittery.
Attacking what they call an abandonment of public education when it needs help from all, officials in many states have moved to tighten rules for education in the home. In some states, like Michigan, the changes have set off lawsuits from home school families who are upset over attempts to enact more rigid regulations.
 
Computers and Museum Trips
 On any given day, Michael Polino tackles math from a first-grade workbook, aided by numbered blocks set up like an abacus. His mother, Mary, teaches him reading and writing, while his father, Richard, tutors him on computer use. One or the other sits down with him for formal lessons for two to three hours a day, they estimate. His education is rounded out by trips to nearby Chicago museums.
"I was against the idea of home schooling at the beginning," said Mrs. Polino. But her sister had been doing it for a few years, and Michael liked the idea, partly because he had seen his cousins being taught at home and partly because he had hated the local elementary school when he visited.
So Mrs. Polino, who was worried about the quality of public education anyway, decided to try teaching Michael at home. She sold her clothing shop, and the family now lives on the income from her husband's restaurant.
She initially fretted about Michael's social skills and academic progress, but after four months of home education, Mrs. Polino is confident on both counts.
 
Soccer as Meeting Ground
 Michael has completed one-third of an alphabet and reading curriculum designed for home schoolers and intended for use through the third grade, she said. He seems to be benefiting from personal attention and from being able to learn at his own pace.
The first-grader has joined a soccer team, alleviating his mother's concerns about mixing with other children his age. He also takes ice-skating lessons and will start karate in the spring.
"He has more time to do the work," said Mrs. Polino, explaining Michael's progress. "And it's nice that he has time to do other things."
In Seattle, Mrs. Hall said she started teaching her children at home because she was worried they would not get enough attention from the teacher. The biggest difference between public school and home schooling for her 9-year-old son, Kyle, and 8-year-old daughter, Cassandra, she said, is Mrs. Hall herself.
"I listen to my children, and when they are interested in a subject I help them," said Mrs. Hall, who also uses daily errands and experiences to teach. A clock with Roman numerals, for example, became a tool for her to teach the children about Arabic and Roman numerals.
 
Time for Creative Writing
 In East Chatham, N.Y., near Albany, Seth Rockmuller and Katharine Houk started home schooling when their eldest daughter, Tahra, now 21, finished eighth grade. Mr. Rockmuller said Tahra was not being "educated in a complete sense" in public school, and the couple wanted her to have more time to pursue her creative writing.
The parents then taught their two younger children, and Ms. Houk has become a seminar leader for a national group that encourages more parental involvement in children's education, whether in home schooling or traditional school.
Under the family's informal approach, Benjamin Rockmuller, 11, and Emily Houk, 8, have become independent thinkers, reading books of their choice in the morning and pursuing their curiosities as they arise.
Benjamin, for example, recently expressed interest in engineering, so Mr. Rockmuller called up friends in the profession for information.
Mr. Rockmuller, a lawyer, said a family's expense for home schooling varies with the choice of educational aids, books and trips.
 
Concern About Isolation
 For the education establishment, the home school movement is troubling. While some school districts have agreed to help home schooling families with curriculums, textbooks and other services, many more look askance at parents who educate their children at home.
"We think that children should be in the traditional setting because home schooling takes away from a child's social skills and isolates children racially and ethnically," said Gene Wilhoit, executive director of the National Association of School Boards.
But home school advocates say that the school environment -- where educators say students should learn social skills -- has increasingly driven away parents because of drug use and other problems. Moreover, few home school families live in rural isolation any more.
While home schooling is allowed nationwide, 32 states have specific laws governing education in the home. Most states require students schooled at home to take annual achievement tests to gauge their academic progress. Only Iowa requires that home school instructors have teaching certificates.
 
Districts' Loss of Income
 In efforts that have angered home schooling families, some states have begun tightening their laws on the ground that some children taught at home might be poorly educated. Earlier this month, for instance, Oregon's education department proposed that home schooled students be required to score higher on annual state-mandated achievement tests than had previously been required; if they do not reach the mandated scores, they must return to public school.
Left unsaid by many educators is the economic impact of a shrinking student enrollment. Although the number of home schooled youngsters constitutes a fraction in any school district, it results in lost state aid, which is usually doled out based on enrollment. That has prompted some of the government backlash, some home school advocates say.
Support groups for home school families have surfaced in most major cities, organized through the national association, said Mrs. Hall, the group's spokeswoman.
"Home schooling isn't for everyone," she said. "But neither is public school or private school."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Milken Sentence
Michael Milken was sentenced to 10 years in prison for violating Federal securities laws and commiting other crimes. The sentence was the longest received by any executive caught up in the Wall Street scandals that began to unfold in 1986, and many legal experts expressed surprise at its severity. [Page A1.]
Milken was sentenced not for his role in a "decade of greed," but for crimes aimed at enriching himself and clients, Federal Judge Kimba Wood said. But his legacy will be his role in the 1980's, and much of the vilification he is receiving stems from fear that the decade's excesses are leading to disaster. News Analysis. [A1.]
The judge in the Milken case has a reputation for bold and sometimes imaginative decisions. She apparently did not feel unusual pressure in sentencing the well-known financier. [D5.]
It took 27 minutes for the judge to finally speak the magic number -- and seconds for Michael R. Milken to absorb the shock. [D5.] Excerpts from the judge's comments. [D4.]
 
Companies
Laventhol & Horwath filed for bankruptcy protection. The accounting firm, once the nation's seventh largest, attributed its problems to litigation, tax law changes, a soft economy and bad press. [D1.]
Guinness announced plans to buy La Cruz del Campo, the largest brewer in Spain, for $1.02 billion. Stroh has owned 28 percent of the Spanish brewer, known as Cruzcampo. [D1.]
National Semiconductor signed an agreement to sell an advanced computer chip plant to Matsushita for $86 million. [D1.]
The rift over the price Matsushita would pay for MCA eased. Lew R. Wasserman, MCA's chairman, was said to be seeking $75 a share, while the Japanese electronics giant offered $70. [D1.]
MCI pulled its $50 million account from Wells, Rich, Greene and gave it to Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer. [D1.]
The British Government began the selloff of its electricity industry, in its largest privatization in 10 years. The Government expects to raise $10.2 billion in the stock offering. [D3.]
A Federal jury ruled that Mobil Chemical wrongfully dismissed a top environmental official after he refused to perform acts that would have violated Federal and state environmental laws. [B3.]
A Federal judge ruled that the police must allow striking Daily News workers to expand their picket lines at the newspaper's main printing plant in Brooklyn. [B5.]
 
International

Markets
Stocks rallied before the close in thin pre-holiday trading. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 9.16 points, to 2539.36. [D7.]
The dollar ended mixed in lackluster trading, up against the mark but down against the yen and pound. Gold prices rose. [D13.]
Soybean, soy oil and wheat futures prices rose, as traders hoped for greater domestic use and exports to the Soviet Union. [D13.]
Oil prices rose 72 cents to $29.63 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. One reason was France's prediction that the U.N. Council would authorize military action against Iraq. [D2.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose on news of an unexpectedly large rise in initial unemployment benefit claims, suggesting that employment conditions deteriorated further in November and might set the stage for easier credit. [D12.]

HEADLINE: 57% of U.S. Math Doctorates Going to Foreigners

DATELINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Of the 933 doctorates in mathematics awarded in the United States in the last academic year, only 43 percent went to American citizens, the lowest percentage on record.
A survey published this month by the American Mathematical Society said that from July 1, 1989, to June 30, 1990, the number of Ph.D. degrees in mathematics increased by 3 percent over the preceding year and by 15 percent over the average of the last four years. But only 401 of the recipients of doctoral degrees were United States citizens. 
 In recent years, foreign students have won increasing shares of advanced United States degrees in engineering, mathematics and several sciences. The latest survey suggests that the trend is continuing.
The participation of blacks in advanced mathematical training also appears to be declining, the report said.
In the previous year, nine American blacks received doctorates in mathematics, a slight increase, but in the period covered by the latest survey, only four were awarded the degree. The proportion of women awarded doctorates in mathematics also fell slightly, from 24 percent to 22 percent.
 
'We Are Disappointed'
 Dr. Edward A. Connors, a director of the survey who is at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, said, "We are disappointed that the increases in awards to women and blacks reported last year were not sustained."
The survey also indicated that when new holders of doctorates take jobs in teaching or research, they cannot expect quick wealth; median starting salaries for new doctors of mathematics are $32,000 for men and $32,500 for women.
Mathematics is a core subject on which all sciences depend, and educators predict that the decline in doctoral degrees awarded to Americans in these subjects will jeopardize the nation's economic prospects.
A year ago, the National Science Foundation reported the results of a study concluding that by the year 2006, the United States would face a shortage of 675,000 scientists and engineers.
One of the problems, the foundation reported, is demographic. White men now make up 80 percent of the scientific and engineering work force in this country.
But by the year 2010, white men will account for less than one-third of the college-age population.
If greater proportions of women and nonwhite men cannot be recruited for advanced mathematical, scientific and engineering programs, the lack of trained professionals will severely hobble national technologies that sustain economic health, the study concluded.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EUROPE;
The Question Than Lingers on Europe: How Will Goals Be Achieved?

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The European summit conference this week formally buried the past of a divided continent and adopted a blueprint for unity, democracy and prosperity, but it fell short of charting a detailed course through the multiple obstacles that stand in the way of achieving those goals.
 Having gathered the leaders of the United States, Canada and 32 European nations to toast the end of the cold war, the three-day summit meeting even ended today on something of a muted note as it recognized the problems of hunger, unemployment, minorities and migration that still threaten stability. 
 The rights and freedoms endorsed today are now "less a question of definition than of application," President Francois Mitterrand of France told the closing session. He added, "We Europeans have 10 years in which to win our race against history."
In this sense, no leader better symbolized the meeting's hopes and fears than President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He was hailed for his role in allowing Eastern Europe to break with Communism, yet more than ever Europe's immediate future depends on his ability to avert chaos in the Soviet Union.
 
A Sort of Bill of Rights
 While enthusiastically committing themselves to democracy and market-oriented economies, Eastern European leaders warned the West of the dangers of unfulfilled expectations and their compatriots of the perils of a resurgence of bitter ethnic disputes.
And even Western leaders could not dwell long on their victory over Communism. Having denounced the division of Europe for four decades, they are now alarmed at the prospect of a flood of migrants fleeing the former Soviet bloc for the greener pastures of Western Europe.
In signing the Charter of Paris for a New Europe here this morning, however, the 34 leaders were not approving a prescription to cure all the region's ills but rather spelling out a sort of Magna Carta or Bill of Rights for their citizens, who number close to one billion.
For the first time in history, Europe, Canada and the United States agreed to a common set of values and objectives that are, in practice, those of the West, not least on points of human rights, democracy, economic freedom and the rule of law. They also pledged to seek security for all in the context of a united Europe.
Addressing one of the specters hovering over Europe today, the charter further insisted that "the ethnic, cultural, linguistic and religious identity of national minorities be respected." And it called a special European conference on minorities in Geneva next summer.
 
Unanswered Questions
 Yet in many areas the summit meeting held under the auspices of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe spoke in grandiose terms but failed to answer specific questions raised by the collapse of Communism and the political transformation of Europe.
The urgent issue of economic aid to the Soviet Union, for example, was tackled outside the summit setting of the international conference center near the Arc de Triomphe, with Mr. Gorbachev busily lobbying Western leaders for everything from credits to food as a tough winter rapidly approaches.
In his meeting with the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, he obtained the promise of a high-level delegation that will visit Moscow to prepare a package of aid from the European Community. And when he met Canada's Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney, he delivered a list of Moscow's food needs.
No less worrying to Western leaders is the danger of disintegration of the Soviet Union, a prospect that prompted several governments to heed Mr. Gorbachev's warning against "unbridled nationalism and mindless separatism" by ignoring the request of the three Baltic republics, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, for observer status at the summit meeting.
"Separatism is Gorbachev's deepest concern," said Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis of Italy, adding that it was no less worrying to the West. "He thinks he can tackle the economic problems. But if separatist movements prevail, the risk of disintegration is so great that he will fail in all other areas."
 
A 'Delicate' Problem
 Similarly, while the summit meeting signaled the danger of ethnic disputes, it created no mechanism to address the problem of minorities and nationalities that is again disturbing Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia and has already driven Yugoslavia close to the point of civil war.
Several Eastern European leaders warned that ethnic problems would be made worse by economic frustration and, while the West is already deeply involved in aiding Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia, they appealed for more credits and investments to help them switch from centrally planned to market economies.
Western Europe on the other hand is increasingly aware that economic failure in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will translate into uncontrolled emigration. "I consider this the most delicate problem of the next 10 years," Mr. de Michelis said, "but we can't deal with it through negative measures. We can't have a closed Europe."
The answer, many say, is economic growth and respect for minorities. Yet at the same time, Western Europeans are bracing for millions of new refugees if the Soviet Union lifts its travel restrictions. "We are convinced the problem of migrations will get worse," Belgian's Prime Minister, Wilfried Martens, said. "It is not a risk. It is a certainty."
With public opinion polls in many Western European countries reflecting unhappiness about high immigration from North Africa and Turkey, one recent United Nations estimate that as many as 25 million people may be ready to flee the former Soviet bloc has already prompted several governments to start investigating ways of keeping them out.
 
In a Vacuum
 Some Eastern European countries, notably Poland and Czechoslovakia, are also worried about an imminent influx of Soviet migrants. Czechoslovakia's President, Vaclav Havel, said on his return to Prague this evening that this was a topic he raised in numerous meetings.
Addressing what has become known as the "new architecture" of Europe, on the other hand, the West chose not to convert the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe into the all-European security structure favored by Moscow and several Eastern European countries as a substitute for the moribund Warsaw Pact.
Rather, the main pillars of the new Europe remain those of the old Western Europe -- the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the 12-nation European Community -- in which Eastern governments have no place. As a result, in the words of Mr. Havel, they sense they are in "a political and security vacuum."
For the moment, though, such often-discussed ideas as Mr. Gorbachev's "common European home" and Mr. Mitterrand's European Confederation have been put on hold, perhaps to be tackled at the next Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe summit meeting, scheduled for Helsinki in 1992. In the meantime, Europe's security will revolve around NATO and its economic growth around the community.
Thus, while the Charter of Paris describes how the new Europe should look, it does not define how it should be built. "You have to remember this is a process," Mr. de Michelis said. "There's bound to be overlapping and contradictions and confusion. We'll be in a transitional stage for at least three or four more years."

HEADLINE: THE MILKEN SENTENCE;
Milken: Pathfinder for the 'Junk Bond' Era

 BODY:
PERSONAL
Michael R. Milken was born on the Fourth of July in 1946 and grew up in Encino, Calif. As a boy, he helped his father, and accountant, prepare tax returns.
Mr. Milken graduated from the University of California at Berkeley, majoring in business administration, and married Lori Anne Hackel, his high school sweetheart.
He received a master's in business administration from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. In a study there, he concluded that a diversified portfolio of bonds rated below investment grade, now known as "junk bonds," generally is a good investment because the high interest rates paid more than offset losses from defaults.
 
CAREER
Mr. Milken was hired full time by the bond-trading department of Drexel Burenham Lambert in 1970, after working in its Philadelphia office during business school. He generatged a substantial amount of Drexel's profits by trading high-yield bonds.
In 1978, the firm allowed Mr. Milken to move the high-yield bond department to Beverly Hills, Calif. Drexel used junk bonds to finance hundreds of small companies in the 1980's, reaping hundreds of millions of dollars in fees. Junk bonds later were used to finance a wave of corporate takeovers.
Mr. Milken used some of his earnings to start charitable foundations that he and his brother, Lowell, also a Drexel employee, endowed with hundred of millions of dollars.
 
CHARGES
In late 1986, after being linked to an illegal stocktrading network, Mr. Milken and Drexel became the main targets of the Government's investigation of insider trading. In 1988, they were charged with civil fraud and other allegations by theSecurities and Exchange Commission, and Drexel agreed to plead guilty to six felonies and pay $650 million.
Mr. Milken, his brother and Bruce Newberg, a former Drexel trader, were indicted in March 1989 on 98 counts of fraud and racketeering related to insider trading and other alleged securities violations. Mr. Milken vowed to fight the charges. He resigned from Drexel in June 1989 and set up a consulting and investing firm.
 
PLEA AND SENTENCING
In a reversal, Mr. Milken agreed in April to a plea bargain. In exchange, the Government agreed to drop all charges against his brother, Lowell.
On April 24, Mr. Milken entered guilty pleas to six felonies and agreed to poay $600 million in penalties. Specifically, Mr. Milken pleaded guilty to conspiracy; securities fraud, defrauding a mutual fund; assisting Ivan F. Boesky, a stock speculator, in filing a false statement with the S.E.C.; assisting Mr. Boesky in violating net-capital requirements, and assisting David Solomon, a mutual fund manager, in filing a false tax return.
"I realize that by my acts I have hurt those who are closest to me. I am truly sorry," he said then.
Sentencing by Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood was postponed to allow for a hearing on Government allegations of crimes Mr. Milken did not admit.
Yesterday, Mr. Milken was sentenced to 10 years in prison, 3 years of probation and 5,400 hours of community service.
Source: Associated Press

HEADLINE: Indians' New Harvest

BYLINE: By Robert H. White; Robert H. White is the author of "Tribal Assets: The Rebirth of Native America."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The only news to travel from Indian country to the major media in 1990 has been news of disaster: a violent standoff between Mohawks and Government officials in Quebec; fatal gun battles over casino gambling at the St. Regis reservation in New York State; the ignoble fall of Peter MacDonald from the helm of the Navajo Nation. America has been saturated with images of incompetent Indian leadership and harebrained business schemes. As much as Native Americans seek understanding, this has been a year when many would just as soon the press had ignored them.
Many, if not most, Native Americans remain America's internal exiles, living within confines established by their conquerors. Of two million Native Americans, 400,000 at last count lived below the poverty line. On and near reservations, one of every seven people lives on less than $2,500 a year. Federal statistics (not always the most accurate) measure American Indians as our least educated, most addicted, shortest-lived citizens.
Are all American Indians doomed to failure? Is the future of Native America to be an endless story of demeaning, mismanaged Federal wardship? Will American Indians be forever alienated in their own land? Not if the remarkable success of a small but growing number of communities is any indication.
 
The Passamaquoddy

In 1980, the Passamaquoddy Indians won $40 million in a Federal settlement of their land claim against the state of Maine. Most non-Indians expected the very poor tribe to squander its windfall on new cars and booze binges. Instead, the Passamaquoddies hired investment bankers, whose advice helped boost the value of the tribal portfolio to $100 million. 
 The tribe earned $60 million last year from the sale of a cement company purchased in 1983 through a leveraged buyout; the deal is now taught as a case study in financial acumen at Harvard. With these and other earnings, the Passamaquoddies have built a network of businesses that employ Indians and non-Indians alike in farming blueberries, stitching apparel and turning discarded plastic bottles into trunk liners for luxury cars.
An invention patented by the Passamaquoddies may soon allow the rest of us to breathe more freely: a smokestack scrubber that transforms coal smoke into fertilizer and distilled water. This breakthrough in clean air technology received $4.8 million in financing from the Department of Energy -- estimated profits run into the tens of millions -- while doing some very important good.
 
 
 
The Mississippi Choctaw
 In the early 1960's, the Mississippi band of Choctaw Indians were either indigent or sharecropping in the barren red clay hills of the state. Their impoverished reservation lay seven miles down the road from Philadelphia, Miss., whose inhabitants' historic opposition to local civil rights efforts was demonstrated by the murder of three civil rights workers there in 1963. One can hardly imagine less fertile soil for Native American prosperity.
The Choctaws' only asset at the time was cheap unskilled labor. Today, by dint of strong, straight tribal leadership -- which created a vigorous manufacturing economy from auto parts to greeting cards -- the Mississippi Choctaws have transformed a rural hellhole into the 15th largest employment center in the state. The 1,700 jobs generated by Choctaw enterprises have substantially reduced unemployment among the tribe's 5,000 members and also in the surrounding population. White neighbors who once shunned Indians now receive paychecks signed by the Choctaw chief, Phillip Martin, whose tribal administration is a model of efficient and caring local government.
 
 
The Ak-Chin
 In Maricopa, Ariz., southwest of Phoenix, the Ak-Chin Indian Community has turned a scattering of meager family farming plots into a roaring, high-tech agribusiness. Ak-Chin Farms sells its harvests of pima cotton to brand-name shirt companies and employs every one of the 500 Ak-Chin Indians. This venture was established over the objections of Federal administrators charged with the tribe's economic well being. The farming operation was sustained through a long, bitter battle in Congress that eventually secured for the reservation its water rights.
Ak-Chin's executive director, Leona Kakar, has moved her constituents out of mud huts into comfortable ranch-style houses. The community's pre-school program is so good that neighboring non-Indian children are waiting to get in. The Ak-Chin government provides cradle-to-grave health care and other social services, mostly funded by Ak-Chin's business revenues. Federal funds account for $20,000 of the community's $5 million annual operating budget. How many other American communities could make a comparable claim?
 
 
 
The Confederated Tribes
 If one reservation qualifies as the "big daddy" of Indian development, it is the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, Ore. The largest employer in the central part of the state, the 600,000-acre Warm Springs Reservation boasts timber and lumber operations that gross some $30 million annually, a hydroelectric plant thqt generates 80 million kilowatt hours a year and a four-star resort.
These achievements are particularly notable given the confederation's humble beginnings. Three tribes were removed from their separate aboriginal territories in the 1800's and tossed together in Warm Springs. Their imposed home was so poor that some were living in tepees as late as the 1920's and so isolated that the first paved road entered the reservation only after World War II.
As with the Choctaws, strong political leadership made the difference. In the 1950's, the tribes began working to control their own natural resources, develop their managerial abilities and sustain their cultures. In Warm Springs today, civil servants live next door to shamans. A worker in the sewing plant may leave at the end of the day to attend a worship dance in the tribal longhouse.
These four examples by no means exhaust the catalogue of Indian success stories. The Eastern band of Cherokees owns the largest mirror company in the U.S. The White Mountain Apaches own the largest ski resort in the Southwest. The Sioux Manufacturing Corporation, on the Devil's Lake Reservation -- North Dakota's No. 1 employer in any given year -- is making 30 percent of the radar-absorbing tank camouflage for Operation Desert Shield.
Along any indicator of societal health, from education to freedom from substance abuse, these communities are gaining ground. They have succeeded in the face of truly daunting obstacles: an undereducated population, Federal regulations that seem designed to frighten off business partners and a legacy of false starts and broken promises.
Moreover, these communities appear to have sustained strong economic growth without sacrificing cherished cultural traditions. Indeed, some tribes believe their wealth has enabled them to preserve what they might otherwise have lost. Ninety seven percent of the Mississippi Choctaws can speak their aboriginal tongue, and their educational system is bilingual. The Passamaquoddies and Ak-Chin have reserved a portion of their business profits to establish their own language progams as well as ambitious tribal museum projects. A Warm Springs radio station devotes most of its programming to Native American music.
These shining examples prove that American Indian failure is not innate but imposed. They also remind us of the obvious -- that this country's native inhabitants are not (to paraphrase a Choctaw leader) mystic relics but real human beings.
But it would be wrong to infer from these triumphs that the problems of Native America are behind it, or that tribes no longer require Federal safeguards for their survival. The cruellest thing that could happen to Native Americans would be to have a pittance of good news used as yet another weapon against them.
Nevertheless, on a day when the painful history and dismal present of American Indians are drowned in day dreams of Squanto and William Bradford sharing the first Thanksgiving, we might ponder the words of a former Passamaquoddy governor, John Stevens: "Now we have a future, not just a past."

HEADLINE: La Escobilla Journal;
For Endangered Sea Turtles, Friends on the Beach

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA ESCOBILLA, Mexico

 BODY:
The lifeguards at this broad Pacific Ocean beach are more than a little bit unusual. They carry machine guns, work at night, and rest only when they see the heads of their charges plunge for good beneath the waves.
The guards, who comb the eight-mile beach on foot and in all-terrain vehicles, are Mexican soldiers and civilian ecologists. The lives they save belong to more than 80,000 giant sea turtles, of a kind that have traditionally been slaughtered here each year while returning to La Escobilla from the open sea to nest. 
 "No one knows how they find their way back to this specific beach," said Homero Aridjis, a Mexican poet and conservationist who has been a leading force in seeking protection for the turtles. "But once they are on land they are completely defenseless. Turtle hunters can just wait for them and then kill them by the thousands."
Valued for their eggs, meat, skins and huge, exotic shells, the turtles were the object of such intensive killing for so long that ecologists feared that their 150-million-year-old species had been forced into permanent decline. Not far from La Escobilla, about 350 miles southeast of Mexico City, a now-abandoned turtle slaughterhouse gives testimony to an economy that depended on the butchery of hundreds of the giant amphibians a day, and thousands during seasonal migrations.
 
A Ban on Hunting
 But the turtles' plight has attracted attention from swelling numbers of environmental groups, who have successfully pressed the Government to impose limits on Mexico's turtle slaughter over the last decade. In May of this year, facing growing protests both here and abroad, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari acceded to a ban on all hunting of sea turtles and sales of related products, including the round eggs, which are considered a delicacy here and throughout much of Latin America.
The ban, which also offered Government aid to turtle hunters who were left without work, has succeeded in eliminating the most egregious forms of killing the turtles, which can live to be 100 years old and have been shown to have a higher intelligence than many mammals.
Local fishermen can no longer openly practice their tradition of flipping the 100-pound creatures on their backs to render them helpless before stacking them in trucks and hauling them alive to slaughter.
But the ban has not ended clandestine hunts at sea by fishermen who capture approaching turtles, then dump them after slashing open their egg pouches or cutting off their flippers for sale in Japan and other foreign markets. The ban has also instituted a perpetual race between egg poachers and ecologists to see who can arrive first after a female turtle crawls from the surf in darkness to deposit 100 or more eggs in a deep nest of sand just above the water line.
 
Thousands Arrive Togther
 During mass nestings, known here as arribadas, tens of thousands of female turtles swim ashore within hours of each other for the brief egg-laying process that is the only part of their lives spent on dry land. Male sea turtles, by contrast, never return to land after hatching from their shells and crawling instinctively to the sea.
The sheer size of the arribadas makes it impossible for authorities to record those nests individually. But at other times teams of ecologists patrol the beach constantly during prime midnight nesting periods, searching for female turtles as they arrive on shore. The scientists then follow the turtle, collect its eggs and take the nest to a guarded stretch of sand where it can be protected until the eggs hatch some six weeks later.
Under a brilliant canopy of stars on a recent night, a half-dozen young scientists and volunteers combed the vast, flat beach without flashlights, searching intently in the sand for turtle tracks that amount to little more than shadows in the darkness but are even harder to distinguish in artificial light.
After finding and discarding several sets of double tracks, which indicate that the turtle has nested and returned to sea, the ecologists found a single track -- a smooth center ribbon with serrated flipper marks, like the trail of an oarsman rowing across the sand. The track emerged from the sea and led to where a female turtle was building her nest just above the high-tide line.
 
Unfrightened by the Company
 Reaching deep into the sand with flexible rear flippers that clutch the loose fill and fling it several yards away, the turtle dug a hole nearly two feet deep, covering it with her own body and three-foot-wide shell.
Lost in the concentration of labor, the turtle was unfrightened by the scientists, who dug an access hole into the nest to catch the eggs as they appeared and stroked the turtle's head with gentle encouragement as she struggled to begin her delivery.
Then, with soft, plaintive moans and sighs that could be mistaken for the sounds of a human being, the turtle produced nearly 100 perfect round eggs, each falling gently into the hand of a scientist, who counted them all and collected them for transfer to the protected nursery.
"We have to get to the eggs immediately or they will begin mature and be too fragile to move," said Cuauhtemoc Penaflores Salazar, the 40-year-old Government coordinator of the Escobilla project, viewing the interior of a new egg by holding it against the lens of a flashlight. "But the poachers have the same problem. If they don't steal the eggs within the first few days, they begin to mature and are worthless for eating."
 
'Numbers Start to Come Back'
 Before the ban was imposed, biologists say, poachers ignored numerical limits on the turtle catch, and virtually no eggs survived at this beach, one of most important nesting grounds in the world for the Olive Ridley, the most common variety of sea turtle.
"Since the ban, we've already seen the numbers start to come back," Mr. Penaflores said. "More turtles arrived in the October arribada this year than at any other time in the last five years."
As he spoke, the turtle used her rear flippers to grasp handful-size quantities of sand, refilling the hole where the eggs were laid, then tamping it down thoroughly and casting dry sand over the surface to camouflage the nest.
Blinking the grit from her enormous dark eyes, the exhausted turtle began her slow march back to the sea, moving with remarkable grace on her wing-shaped flippers. Visible only as a silhouette against the eerie, phosphorescent breakers, the turtle was rinsed and then spun around by a wave, and then finally dove strongly beneath the surface.
Watching transfixed in the darkness, La Escobilla's team of turtle lifeguards stood for a moment in silent admiration, then let out a cheer.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Britain Plans to Send 14,000 More Troops to Gulf

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
 Britain will send 14,000 more troops and additional tanks, aircraft and ships to the Persian Gulf, bringing the total number of British troops there to 30,000 by the end of the year, the Defense Minister said today.
The Minister, Tom King, told Parliament that the Government had decided to deploy an extra brigade, a division headquarters and supporting arms. "They will join the Seventh Armored Brigade in Saudi Arabia to form the First Armored Division," he said. 
 About 16,000 British troops are now in the region as part of the American-led military buildup that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. But Mr. King said it was evident that the numbers were insufficient.
"This will represent a potent increase in the fighting capability of British fighting forces in region," he said of the deployment.
 
Challenger Tank Regiment
 Outgoing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, speaking in a determined voice just a few hours after she announced her resignation, told Parliament that time was running out for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to remove his troops from Kuwait.
"The time is fast approaching when the world community will have to take more decisive action to uphold international law and compel Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait," she said.
Mr. King said a Challenger tank regiment, two armored infantry battalions equipped with Warrior fighting vehicles, an armored reconnaissance squadron, a field artillery regiment, engineers and other support staff would join the British brigade.
Lynx anti-tank helicopters, support helicopters and two minesweeping vessels would also be sent, he added.
 
British Number Rises to 30,000
 Mr. King said 14,000 troops would be involved, creating a First Armored Division in Saudi Arabia of 25,000 troops and bringing the number of British forces in the multinational force opposing Iraq in the gulf to 30,000.
He said a reconnaissance party would leave today and that the first troops would begin to move by the weekend. They would all be in place in Saudi Arabia by the end of the year.
Mr. King said the British troops would be under the United States tactical command and that an American brigade could be assigned to the new division.
 
'Clearest Possible Message'
 British troops were first sent to the gulf to join part the American-led force in countering the invasion and enforcing a United Nations resolution imposing an economic blockade of Iraq and occupied Kuwait.
Mr. King said the new deployment "is the clearest possible message to Saddam Hussein that there is a credible military option." He called on the Iraqi leader to "end his aggression, release his hostages and leave Kuwait."
The Defense Minister added, however, that it remained "the Government's firm objective to resolve this crisis as soon as possible and by peaceful means."
Michael Heseltine, a Conservative member of Parliament and former Defense Minister whose challenge to Mrs. Margaret Thatcher's leadership forced her to announce her resignation, was quick to endorse the move.
