HEADLINE: In Polish Race, No Parties Need Apply

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Poland's presidential election campaign, now entering its final stage, has embraced most of the external trappings of democracy, from bumper stickers to posters to opinion polls and last-minute mudslinging.
But as Poles prepare to vote Sunday in their first free presidential election in 68 years, there is one obviously missing element: national political parties.
When the Communist Party lost much of its monolithic power more than a year ago, there was a general expectation that it would be replaced by political groups representing the varied and often contradictory interests of such constituencies as farmers, industrial workers and the rising enterpreneurial class. 
 Instead, this fall's presidential campaign has been characterized by the politics of personality and a pervasive distrust of organized parties.
 
An Unexpected Challenger
 This trend is being disclosed by the remarkable showing of Stanislaw Tyminski, an emigre businessman from Canada and Peru, who has come from nowhere in three weeks to mount a serious challenge in public opinion polls.
Mr. Tyminski was virtually unknown when he announced his candidacy. Moreover, unlike his more established rivals -- Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki -- he played no role in the struggle to overturn Communist rule.
"In the absence of parties, we have something like the Greens in West Germany or like Proposition 13 in California," said Andrzej Wroblewski, the editor of the Polish financial weekly Gazeta Bankowa. "People here are angry at anyone who could be seen as an authority."
The latest public opinion poll shows that Mr. Walesa leads with 28 percent of the vote, with Mr. Tyminski at 21 percent and Mr. Mazowiecki at 17 percent. Under the election rules, a second round will be held Dec. 9 if no candidate wins a majority on Nov. 25.
 
Emulating Solidarity
 For the last month, the six candidates in the race have done their best to try to emulate the Solidarity movement, which at the start of the decade was able to attract 10 million members with a program of anti-Communism designed to appeal to all Poles, regardless of their trade, profession, social group or geographic region.
In interviews, Mr. Walesa always portrays himself as being above or apart from any political parties.
Mr. Mazowiecki, the candidate with the greatest appeal to the most educated voters, has for his part sought to reach out to rural dwellers by promising telephones in every village within two years and stressing a platform promise that "Polish farmers should have no fears for the future."
That optimism stands in sharp contrast to the statements of Ryszard Bujak, one of Mr. Mazowiecki's leading supporters, who repeatedly says Poland's economic restructuring requires the bankruptcy of millions of small, inefficient farmers.
In both the local elections earlier this year and the presidential race, politicians in Poland quickly concluded that declaring themselves members of a "party" inevitably invoked memories of "the party."
"We think of ourselves as a party that has not yet consolidated," said Stanislaw Rojek, the secretary of the Center Alliance, a group that someday hopes to play a role similar to the Western Europe's Christian Democratic parties.
 
No More Big Parties
 "There is a considerable dislike of people for political parties as such because of the Communist past," Mr. Rojek said. "But this is something that is slowly changing. Still there won't be anymore big parties in Poland. Their time is over."
The Center Alliance, which has 60,000 to 70,000 members among Poland's 27 million voters, has been the most vocal force behind the candidacy of Mr. Walesa. Broadly speaking, its supporters come from the center-right of the political spectrum. Its main opponent, the Civic Movement for Democratic Action, has been organizing on behalf of Mr. Mazowiecki.
A third major grouping, bidding to become the political voice of the 30 percent of the Polish population living in rural areas, is the Peasants' Party. Its presidential candidate, Roman Bartoszcze, has hovered between 5 and 10 percent in the opinion polls.
Mr. Wroblewski said the lack of established political structures in Poland -- coupled with an intense longing for simple solutions to complicated problems -- explains the sudden emergence of Mr. Tyminski.
"What party structure means is not only an electoral machine to win elections," Mr. Wroblewski said. "It's a certain system of gradual filtration of programs, of people. When you're in a political party, you have some place where you can turn to the person next to you and ask: 'Does this comply with the philosophy of our party?' That hardly exists here. The very idea was completely compromised by the Communist system."
 
'A Pole Can Do It'
 Supporters of Mr. Tyminski said in interviews that they saw him as a fresh face. They were attracted to his success in Western business, and, in the words of Mr. Wroblewski, "he says to people, 'A Pole can do it.' "
After weeks of ignoring Mr. Tyminski, the Polish press reported today that he had been refused entry into the military in the 1960's because of mental illness. Another report said he had often traveled to Poland before the fall of Communism, despite his statements to the contrary. The report noted that he obtained visas several times from the Polish Consulate in Tripoli, Libya.
Polish television and newspapers also criticized Mr. Tyminski for falsely charging that the Prime Minister planned to sell state enterprises for too low a price. The documents cited by Mr. Tyminski as proof of this charge actually refer to the company's annual sales, not the offering price.
But it was unclear whether the attacks on Mr. Tyminski by established press organizations would not be counterproductive, since for many years Poles say they have learned not to trust what they read in the newspapers or see on television.

HEADLINE: Mid-Rise Apartment Houses Making New York Comeback

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Some developers and city planners think they have conceived an ingenious solution to New York City's housing shortage. It is a squat building, about six stories tall, with individual living units arrayed along a central corridor and an elevator connecting the floors and the street. It is called an apartment house.
Once the mainstay of New York's housing stock, framing broad boulevards like Ocean Parkway and the Grand Concourse and dominating countless side streets in Brooklyn, Queens, northern Manhattan and the Bronx, the mid-rise apartment building fell out of favor over the last three decades. 
 New York's zoning law encouraged taller, thinner structures, and the city's economy made building a six-story apartment house too expensive for the working- and middle-class families who had called them home for much of the century.
But even in the midst of an economic downturn, the mid-rise building is making a comeback, spurred by new zoning rules and innovations in construction techniques. About 35 new four- to seven-story buildings with elevators have gone up in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx in the last three years, city planning officials say.
The re-invention of the mid-sized apartment house was probably inevitable. High-rise towers cost so much to build that they are appropriate only for the well-to-do, and then primarily in Manhattan. The new two- and three-story town houses that have become popular in the boroughs outside Manhattan are less expensive, but they do not provide enough apartments for a large city that is desperately short of housing.
"The model of the six- to eight-story building is what we would design if we were starting over," said Kathryn Wylde, the president of the New York City Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group that helps develop middle-income housing.
The mid-rise building achieves a scale appropriate for many parts of New York, planners say. It provides more housing than low-rise town houses, and it offers a more direct and comfortable relationship with the streets than do high-rise towers.
 
'Manageable in Scale'
 The six-story building is "coming back for all the right reasons," said Roberta Brandes Gratz, the author of "The Living City," a book on urban planning.
"It's very appropriate for an urban redevelopment, much more appropriate than these ridiculous suburban-style developments that are going up in cities," Ms. Gratz said. "It's manageable in scale and it allows for secure courtyards and good street-front observation, a closer sense of community than high-rise buildings."
The mid-rise building also offers the city government a new model in its ambitious, multibillion-dollar subsidized housing program. The effort, begun four years ago, concentrates on two basic housing types: rebuilding abandoned structures in poor neighborhoods and constructing two- and three-story row houses and town houses for the middle class.
But since the city is likely to run out of vacant buildings in the next few years, it will have to decide whether it can afford to build new housing for the poor and, if so, how to do it. The choice of many housing specialists is the mid-rise apartment house.
 
A Model in the South Bronx
 A possible prototype for the next generation of mid-rise housing, some housing experts say, can be found in the South Bronx, four blocks north of Yankee Stadium. There, a six-story slab of salmon and beige sits almost complete on a small hill overlooking the elevated subway. Tenants are to begin moving in early next year.
The exterior is bright and cheerful, the apartments spacious and comfortably appointed. In the back, a sleek playground in a landscaped courtyard looks out on the private parking lot.
Construction has taken only 10 months, about half the ordinary time, because the developers used new prefabrication techniques. The walls are panels, made in a factory out of heavy gauge structural steel with an acrylic, stucco-like exterior. The floors and ceilings are factory-built concrete planks that are pieced together at the site.
The prefabrication techniques prevent bad weather from slowing down the job, makes the entire process more predictable and reduces security costs and the theft of building materials. "The speed is phenomenal," said Philip E. Aarons, the president of the General Atlantic Realty Corporation, the general partner in the development team. The pace reduces the cost of interest on the construction loan.
 
Adding Up the Costs
 Mr. Aarons said the construction of the building, which is at the corner of Gerard Avenue and McClellan Street, cost $75 a square foot, at least 25 percent less than the usual construction cost of comparable mid-rise buildings. High-rise buildings can cost at least $130 a square foot to build. Other costs, including land, financing and architectural and legal fees, added another $25 a square foot to the total development cost of Gerard Gardens.
Even with the innovations, the apartment house was sufficiently expensive to build that the developers would have to charge rents of $1,100 a month for it to be "marginally profitable," Mr. Aarons said.
Few would pay such rents to live in the South Bronx, though. Rents for a one-bedroom apartment in the building will be about $415 a month. Two bedrooms will rent for about $480.
The developers will use two new government subsidies to keep rents low and still earn their profit. One, the Federal low-income tax credit, allows corporations to buy credits on their taxes by investing in housing for the poor.
The other subsidy is a city program, in which developers obtain large tax abatements for market-rate housing in Manhattan by building low-income housing elsewhere. The developers can use the abatements themselves or can sell them, in the form of certificates, to other developers.
 
An Appealing Notion
 In general, these government housing programs define low-income families as those with incomes below $25,000 a year.
City housing officials were skeptical of Mr. Aarons's construction cost estimates, but they said they found the idea of mid-rise apartments appealing. "The notion of $70 to $75 a square foot, it's only Phil who has done it," said the City Housing Commissioner, Felice Michetti, "We have not looked at the actual, real numbers."
Many housing experts said six-story buildings may once again make financial sense for private developers in middle-class neighborhoods.
"There was a time when that minimally built, very modest, stock six-story building was the sensible thing for a developer to build," said Ada Louise Huxtable, an architecture critic and consultant. "It was a completely natural and logical thing to do, and it made economic sense."
Most of the new mid-rise structures built recently are in affluent neighborhoods like Bay Ridge, Park Slope and Windsor Terrace in Brooklyn. Unlike Mr. Aarons's building, which was built at six stories fundamentally for economic reasons, most of these were built at that scale largely because of new zoning rules.
When the city's zoning law was overhauled in 1961, tall, thin buildings with large, open public spaces were fashionable. By the 1980's, though, many planners and architects had second thoughts about the 1960's vision, called "the tower in the park."
"We began to see that these very tall buildings and badly designed plazas were not the absolutely perfect way to build a city, as they had been presented," Ms. Huxtable said.
In 1987, the city's zoning was again modified. In some areas, mid-rise buildings are now required. In others, they are offered as an alternative to tall towers.
The mid-rise building "is kind of like a comfortable pair of shoes that you are used to," said Richard L. Schaffer, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "It feels right to people, and provides a good solid form of housing."
"Good ideas do sometimes fall out of favor," he added. "But if they are good ideas, often they come back into vogue."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After a period of tall, thin buildings, the mid-rise building is making a comeback. Above, a six-story apartment building under construction at Gerard Avenue and McClellan Street in the South Bronx. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times) (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: SHIFT IN SAN JUAN ON VOTE ON STATUS

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Leaders of Puerto Rico's governing party say that unless there is quick agreement in Congress on a referendum on the island's political future, they will call off their effort to hold such a vote in 1991.
In the vote, Puerto Ricans are to decide whether they want the island to become a state or an independent nation or to remain a commonwealth of the United States, with revisions in the way its status is drawn. 
 The House approved legislation for a referendum in 1991, but in October the Senate put off consideration of its bill.
 
Who Should Decide?
 The House bill provided for Congressional approval of the voters' decision before it could be carried out. But the Senate bill would give the voters the final word, putting their decision into effect without Congressional approval.
The island's governing party, the Popular Democratic Party, which supports commonwealth status, decided last weekend to back a vote in 1993 rather than 1991 unless Congress acted quickly to resolve the measure's wording.
The party leaders say they are trying to put pressure on Congress to take swift action. But other politicians in Puerto Rico say the party is backing away from its commitment to a referendum as the drive for statehood has gained momentum.
Statehood supporters emphasize the representation in Congress and the right to vote in Federal elections that would go with that choice. A Puerto Rican state would have two senators and at least five House members, they say. Statehood would also oblige residents to pay Federal income taxes.
Proponents of independence contend that Puerto Rico should be self-governing and argue that only as a free country could it preserve its own history and culture. They say Puerto Rico's national will has been weakened by its dependence on the United States.
 
Argument for Commonwealth
 Commonwealth supporters say Puerto Ricans derive distinct financial benefits from their relationship with the United States that would be lost through statehood or independence. These include special tax benefits intended to stimulate investments from United States companies, which account for about half of the $22 billion in private investment on the island.
President Bush has been a longtime supporter of statehood. The Puerto Rican Governor, Rafael Hernandez Colon, supports the commonwealth option, with some modification of Federal laws and regulations aimed at encouraging the island's economic growth. He has been severely criticized for the time he has spent away from the island, lobbying in Washington for the referendum.
The party leaders say that unless a Congressional agreement is reached within a month after the new Congress convenes, it is unlikely that a referendum could be held in 1991.
"Nobody wants a plebiscite in 1992," said Jaime B. Fuster, a leader of the Popular Democratic Party and the island's nonvoting representative in Congress. "We have our own elections in 1992, and they will be complicated enough."
"There is a stalemate in Congress, and we don't see any signs that it's going to change," Mr. Fuster continued. "The people of Puerto Rico have been left dangling, with great expectations, and the Governor has had to devote too much time to this issue."
 
'Take Us Seriously'
 Mr. Fuster, a co-sponsor of the House bill, views the party's decision as a move to pressure Congressional leaders to break the legislative deadlock. "We're putting the ball in the leadership's court," Mr. Fuster said. "We're saying, 'Take us seriously, or let us be.' "
The party's leaders, including Mr. Hernandez Colon, made their decision last weekend at a two-day conference in Ponce, P.R. The vote was 174 to 5.
Luis A. Ferre, former Governor of Puerto Rico and a founder of the pro-statehood New Progressive Party, assailed the Popular Democrats' decision. "This amounts to putting a termination date on the right of self-determination," he said.
Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat who is sponsor of the Senate bill, has scheduled a trip to Puerto Rico next week to meet with supporters of all three options. Claire M. Miller, a spokeswoman, said the Senator had no comment on the position taken by the Popular Democratic Party.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Excerpts From Speech By Bush at Marine Post

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's remarks yesterday at a Marine outpost in northeastern Saudi Arabia, as provided by the Federal News Service, a Washington-based transcription agency.
 You know, Thanksgiving is the oldest, some, some might say the most American of holidays, dating back to our very origins as a people. And it's a day, I think we would all agree, separate and apart from others. It's a day of peace, it's a day of thanks, a day to remember what we stand for, and what it means to be an American, and why our forebears sacrificed so much to cross an ocean and build a great land. 
 And on this day, with all that America has to be thankful for, it is fair for Americans to say, Why are we here? It's not all that complicated. There are three key reasons why we're here with our U.N. allies making a stand in defense of freedom. We're here to protect freedom, we're here to protect our future, and we're here to protect innocent life.
And number one, protecting freedom means standing up to aggression. You know, the brutality inflicted on the people of Kuwait and on innocent citizens of every country must not be rewarded, because a bully unchecked today is a bully unleashed for tomorrow. And last Aug. 2 this brutal dictator set out to wipe another country from the face of the earth, and Kuwait, a little tiny country, awoke to the flashing guns of cold, cold-blooded troops, the fire and ice of Saddam Hussein's invasion.
And now Kuwait is struggling for survival, an entire nation ransacked, looted, held hostage. And maybe you can strike a name from, name from the maps, but you can't strike a country from the hearts of its people. The invasion of Kuwait was without provocation, the looting of Kuwait is without excuse, and the occupation of Kuwait will not stand.
 
 Protecting Security
 And number two, our mission is about protecting national security, which is to say protecting our future, because energy security is national security for us and, indeed, for every country.
Last year on a snowy Thanksgiving eve up there at Camp David, I spoke to the American people about the newly fallen Berlin wall, and the piece of the wall that sits on my desk is a reminder of our steadfast role in the worldwide explosion of freedom. But now, the march of freedom must not be threatened by the man whose invasion of Kuwait is causing great economic hardship in the countries which can afford it the least.
We saw it in Czechoslovakia. Barbara and I are just back from Czechoslovakia, where the progress of their peaceful revolution has already been damaged by the shock waves from Iraq's aggression. President Havel told me that Saddam's aggression is having a severe effect on his struggling economy. And every day that goes by increases the damage.
But when he was asked if our action in the gulf was taking too much money away from the problems of Eastern Europe, he answered plainly. He said, "All the resources that are expended on resisting aggression anywhere in the world are finally turned to the good of all humankind." This from that playwright that was jailed not so many months ago by aggression itself. Listen to the words of this man who stands for freedom.
Vaclav Havel is right. Iraq's aggression is not just a challenge to the security of Kuwait and the other gulf neighbors but to the better world we all hope to build in the wake of the cold war. We're not talking simply about the price of gas. We are talking about the price of liberty.
 
 Innocent Lives at Stake
 Number three, we're here because innocent lives are at stake. We've all heard of atrocities in Kuwait that would make the strongest among us weak.
Turns your stomach when you listen to the tales of those that have escaped the brutality of the, Saddam, the invader. Mass hangings. Babies pulled from incubators and scattered like firewood across the floor. Kids shot for failing to display the photos of Saddam Hussein. And he has unleased a horror on the people of Kuwait.
And our diplomats and our citizens held hostage must be freed. And it's time to stop toying with the American hostages. And it's time to start, to stop trying, for Saddam to stop trying to starve out our little beleaguered embassy in Kuwait City. And the same, General Courtingly, is true of the British Embassy that is courageously holding on. The two of us, side by side in Kuwait, as we're shoulder to shoulder in the sands of Saudi Arabia, and it's time to put an end to this cruel hostage bazaar, bartering in human beings in the days, like the days of the slave trade. Because if we let Iraq get away with this abuse now, Americans will pay a price in future hostage-taking for decades to come. And so will other nations.
Three simple reasons: protecting freedom, protecting our future, protecting innocent lives. And any one is reason enough why Iraq's unprincipled, unprovoked aggression must not go unchallenged. And together they make a compelling case. For you to be away from your families on this special Thanksgiving Day, they make a compelling case for your mission. No president is quick to order American troops abroad. But there are times when any nation that values its own freedom must confront aggression.
Czechoslovakia, they know firsthand about the folly of appeasement. They know about the tyranny of dictatorial conquests. And in the World War that followed, the world paid dearly for appeasing an aggressor who should and could have been stopped. We're not going to make that mistake again. We will not appease this aggressor.
 
 Gravity of the Threat
 As in World War II, the threat to American lives from a seemingly distant enemy must be measured against the nature of the aggression itself. A dictator who has gassed his own people, innocent women and children, unleashing chemical weapons of mass destruction, weapons that were considered unthinkable in the civilized world for over 70 years. And let me say this, those who would measure Saddam Hussein's, those who would measure the timetable for Saddam's atomic program in years may be seriously underestimating the reality of that situation and the gravity of the threat.
Every day that passes brings Saddam one step closer to realizing his goal of a nuclear weapons arsenal. And that's why, more and more, your mission is marked by a real sense of urgency. You know, no one knows precisely when this dictator may acquire atomic weapons, or exactly who they may be aimed at down the road. But we do know this for sure: He has never possessed a weapon that he didn't use.
What we're confronting is a classic bully who thinks he can get away with kicking sand in the face of the world. So far I've tried to act with restraint and patience. I think that's the American way. But Saddam is making the mistake of his life if he confuses an abundance of restraint, confuses that with a lack of resolve.
Over the past four months you have launched what history will judge as one of the most important deployments of allied military power since 1945, and I have come here today to personally thank you. The world is watching. Our objectives in the gulf have never varied: We want to free and restore Kuwait's Government, protect American citizens abroad, safeguard the security and stability of the region. A united world has spelled out these objectives in 10 United Nations Security Council resolutions.
To force Iraq to comply, we and our allies have forged a strong diplomatic, economic and military strategy. But the Iraqi dictator still hasn't gotten the message. And maybe he's confused by his own propaganda. This ridiculous radio broadcast, that I understand the marines have labeled the Baghdad Betty, well, she plays all the oldies, so one guy suggested that we send Iraq a tape of M. C. Hammer and a, a note that says: This is how we entertain ourselves; just imagine how we fight.
We have been patient. We've gone to the United Nations, time and time again. I'm prepared to go another time. We still hope for a peaceful settlement. But the world is a dangerous place. And we must make all of these options credible.
 
 We Want You Home
 Those in uniform, seems to me, will always bear the heaviest burden. We understand something of what you endure, the waiting, the uncertainty, the demands of family and military life. And we want every single troop home. We want every Brit to be able to go home as soon as possible. We want every single American home. And this I promise. No American will be kept in the gulf a single day longer than necessary. But we won't pull punches. We are not here on some exercise. This is a real world situation. And we're not walking away until our mission is done, until the invader is out of Kuwait. And that may well be where you'll come in.
As we meet, it is dawn in America. It is Thanksgiving Day. The church bells ring. An hour of prayer. A day of rest. A nation at peace. And especially today, Americans understand the contribution that you all are making to world peace and to our country.
Year after year, on this special day, no doubt each of you has given thanks for your country. This year your country gives thanks for you. Thanksgiving is a day of prayer, a day when we thank God for our many, many blessings. And I've done that today.
This has been an unforgettable visit, an unforgettable visit. And I leave, as I know our Congressmen do, and I know Barbara does, with prie in our hearts, a prayer on our lips.
God bless you all. God bless our faithful allies, the United Kingdom. God bless the marines. And may God bless the greatest, freest country on the face of the earth, the United States of America. Thank you and bless you all. Thank you. Good luck to all you guys.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Trying to Soothe Scared Bankers

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
ADDRESSING the New York chapter of the Arthritis Foundation this week, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged bankers to keep lending to their good customers. He is afraid the bankers may be spooked into creating a credit crunch by their fears of an economic slump and their worries about meeting tougher regulatory standards. To ease the latter worry, Mr. Brady told regulators not to use "unrealistically negative scenarios in evaluating loans."
"There are many ways to strengthen a balance sheet," said the Treasury Secretary, once an investment banker, "without shedding loans" -- like cutting costs, reducing dividends and merging with rival banks. Some large banks are determined to make mergers that would give them a chance to cut expenses and increase earnings. They fear that unless a banking crisis is prevented, the current economic slowdown could become the most severe recession of the postwar period. The banks are driving to protect themselves, and cutting loans is one way of trying -- but one that poses severe risks to local communities and the economy as a whole. 
 Prices of the securities of many leading money-center banks and regional banks have been falling, and their yields have been rising, in some cases to "junk bond" levels. Thus far, public notice has focused on the banks' falling common stocks, rather than on the climbing yields of their subordinated debt and preferred stock. Yield levels on the common stock, debt and preferred shares of most banks have climbed sharply, although Mr. Brady asserted, "Over all, the banking system is healthy, despite some pockets of difficulty."
Morris W. Offit, the president of Offitbank, an investment management bank, sees the situation the other way around, with general weakness and pockets of health. He thinks that "nobody has made the connection between the banks and the risks to the real economy." He also argues that thesoaring costs of capital are making it increasingly difficult for banks in every region to raise the money to meet tougher regulatory standards. Mounting pressures on the banks, Mr. Offit says, create risks of a "tremendous contraction" of the economy.
Although not all banks have felt the squeeze, many are seeing their costs of capital climb. Citicorp, the nation's biggest bank, has seen the yield on its subordinated debt climb to 13 percent, from 10.5 percent two months ago. Yields on the debt of many other banks are even higher: Chase Manhattan was at 14.2 percent this week; Baltimore Bancorp at 14 percent; Bank of Boston at 18.5 percent; Dominion at 15.5 percent; First City of Texas at 25 percent; First Fidelity at 15 percent; MNC Financial at 27 percent; Midlantic at 21 percent and Shawmut at 17 percent.
But some banks can still finance debt in the open market at much lower yields, among them are J. P. Morgan, at 9.6 percent; Bankers Trust and Security Pacific, at 10.7 percent each; Mellon, at 11.3 percent, and Wells Fargo at 11 percent.
The anxious bankers contend that if a financial crisis is to be headed off, some big steps will have to be taken by the Government and the Federal Reserve. They insist that the Fed should go further to ease money to counteract recessionary forces andthey maintain that the Fed can do so with much lower risks of inflation than in the 1970's. Some even perceive a threat of ruinous deflation, if downward pressures on the economy are not soon checked.
Some bankers want Government officials "to stop bashing the banks in public." Bank-bashing, they say, is making it harder for them to raise the capital they need to meet the standards of the Bank for International Settlements. To date, however, most banks are meeting those standards.
And the bankers are pressing the Administration to speed up a restructuring of the industry that would enable them to reduce their risks and costs, and expand their earnings, by merging with other banks. A revamped system would also allow banks to conduct business nationwide and expand into areas banned by existing law, especially the Glass-Steagall Act, like underwriting securities, selling insurance and operating mutual funds.
Without specifying exactly what banking legislation the Administration may propose soon after New Year's Day, Secretary Brady said in his Arthritis Foundation speech this week, "It's time to overhaul the system." He called for "fundamental structural reform" of the laws enacted during the Depression that have produced an "outmoded, burdensome and inefficient" financial regulatory system. This was his strongest statement on the subject to date. But the legislation is likely to face a tough fight in Congress, with small and regional banks fighting their larger money-center rivals.
For its part, the Federal Reserve, clinging to its historical secrecy, insists that it is well aware of the dangers of a banking crisis and has plans for dealing with one. The Fed thinks -- a Fed, as well as a White House, can think anonymously -- that it would only worsen anxieties in the marketplace, and possibly drive up interest rates and hurt the economy, if it talked publicly about its plans to rescue banks, provide liquidity and protect the economy and the financial system. The Fed insists that it knows more about the risks, and how to deal with them, than the nervous bankers do.
It feels that it demonstrated that capability, along with other central banks, after the October 1987 stock market crash.

HEADLINE: CHANGE IN BRITAIN;
Excerpts From Talks in Commons

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's appearance yesterday before Parliament, as provided by the Federal News Service, a Washington-based transcription company: 
 SPEAKER. Questions to the Prime Minister. Tony Marlow.
MARLOW (Conservative). Would my right honorable friend -- would my right honorable friend, excepting those of us on this side who share her objectives, whatever our roles may have been in recent weeks, but this is a day -- this is a time of sadness and happiness. Sadness -- sadness -- sadness for her -- sadness for her from the great well of affection that exists throughout the House. Happiness in celebration of what has been, is and will remain the greatest peacetime political reign of this century, and a day of dedication to sustain and build on the massive achievements of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.
THATCHER. Mr. Speaker, may I thank my honorable friend. The same person in a slightly different capacity will be available to serve Britain in whatsoever way it happens.
SPEAKER. Neil Kinnock.
KINNOCK (Labor). Mr. Speaker, may I pay tribute to the Prime Minister and to her decision this morning. She showed by that that she amounts to more than those who have turned upon her in recent days. Mr. Speaker, the right honorable lady, I know, considers the principle of choice to be extremely important and that is rightly so. Does she agree with me that the people of Britain should now be given the power of choice in a general election?
THATCHER. Mr. Speaker, may I thank the right honorable gentlemen for his earlier comments. In reply to his later question, the answer is no. No more than we had an election when Mr. Wilson changed to Mr. Callaghan.
SPEAKER. Mr. Churchill.
CHURCHILL (Conservative). Is my right honorable friend aware that she deserves the gratitude of the entire nation for her -- for her part in bringing to an end the Soviets' part in the arms race and burying once and for all the cold war between the superpowers. It is in that capacity that she will be remembered as the greatest peacetime prime minister this country has ever had.
THATCHER. I'm grateful to my honorable friend for his staunchness in defense and for his remarks. It was a great privilege to attend the C.S.C.E. conference in Paris and to sign some of the disarmament agreements and for the new C.S.C.E., which merely ushers in a new order in Europe, and I hope, a very successful peaceful one.
SPEAKER. Mr. Ashton.
ASHTON (Labor). Mr. Speaker, may I say to the Prime Minister that many of us recognize that she had to take a very tough decision this morning and we believe she took the right decision and took it with great dignity.
May I also say to her that however wide our political divisions, and they are, of course, very wide, no one can doubt the special style she's brought to that dispatch box, nor her courage, conviction, and determination which she has brought to her premiership.
Mr. Speaker, perhaps I might ask her to use this opportunity to offer to the House any advice she might have for her successor.
THATCHER. Mr. Speaker, I thank -- apart from the last bit, may I thank the right honorable gentleman for his kindness. May I remind the House that I expect to be here on Tuesday afternoon, and possibly even on Thursday afternoon -- [laughter] -- so I hope the House will be as kind then as it is today. [Laughter.]
SPEAKER. Dame Elaine Kellett-Bowman.
KELLETT-BOWMAN (Conservative). Will my right honorable friend accept from me the love and affection of millions of people in my part of the world who have looked to her over the years with a gracious admiration and delight?
THATCHER. I'm particularly grateful to receive that from my honorable friend. We were at college together, and I think we've been together ever since.
SPEAKER. Mr. Greville Janner.
JANNER (Labor). Mr. Speaker, may I be permitted to thank the Prime Minister for many personal kindnesses which she has given over many years to back benches on both sides of the House? May I at the same time say how deeply concerned my constituents are that she has left the place in such a shambles? Is she aware that they are desperately worried about poll tax, about the deepening recession, about the health problems, and they are worried about the educational system and about the whole poor shambles?
THATCHER. He can speak to any brief and I don't believe he believes a word of it.

HEADLINE: As Economy Slows, Malls Brace for a Blue Christmas

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 19

 BODY:
Christmas has already come to the mall. But along with the gaudy white tulle trees, the enormous ornaments bobbing from the ceiling and Santa Claus and his sneaker-wearing elves, there is anxiety here. You can see it among the merchants, many presiding over shops with few or no customers on the Monday before Thanksgiving. And you can see it among the shoppers, many who shop without buying.
In boom times, people expect great business. In bad times, they hope for the best. But this season, with the crisis in the Middle East, budget deficits at every level of government and a sense that the economy is poised for a painful downturn, the mood here is glum and cautious. No one is quitesure what is going to happen. 
 The Stamford Town Center, as this mall is called, has hardly had a terrible year and seems to be doing much better than many others. Michael S. Fenley, its general manager, said that a recent survey of 30 stores showed that sales are running slightly ahead of last year's levels. And some store managers say that despite a downturn since the summer, the pre-Christmas business has been much better than expected.
"If you have a positive attitude and don't mention anything about the economy, customers don't say anything," said Robert T. Hoffman, manager at the Shop for Pappagallo, who said that business had improved since last year. "But once you bring it up, they won't buy anything.
Everyone is worried. And for all the stores that say they are holding their own, there are as many admitting that things look bleak. As the 132 or so retail outlets here prepare for their biggest season of the year, many are reducing expectations, holding bigger and longer sales and steeling themselves for what some worry could turn into the saddest Christmas in recent years.
"Most people don't really want to talk about how bad their business is going," said Stephen J. DeMaria, store manager of the Custom Shop Shirtmakers, a store that makes men's shirts for about $65 and suits starting at $695.
The Stamford Town Center is one of Connecticut's premier malls, catering to people with average incomes of $70,000 with stores like Brooks Brothers, Abercrombie & Fitch and Saks Fifth Avenue.
In recent years, the mall has seen some of its specialty boutiques replaced by trendy chain stores like the Limited and the Gap, and a larger portion of its clientele are from moderate-income homes, said Walter Loeb, a retail consultant and president of Loeb Associates in New York.
 
Mall to Have a Blue Christmas?
 "The mall will definitely be impacted by recessionary trends in this area," said Mr. Loeb, "but it is a mall where you find that people have adequate incomes and adequate money to spend."
This Christmas, many store managers say, customers seem to be putting off shopping longer. They are looking for bargains. And while they have not stopped buying, they are not buying as much.
"It's obvious to everyone that there isn't as much money going around," said Diane Galbreath, the assistant manager at Sportstuff. "People are being more careful; they're not buying things on a whim." But while business has definitely slowed down, she said, "It's not near as bad as I expected."
At the Custom Shop, business is off by about 25 or 30 percent from last year. "The customers have cut back," Mr. DeMaria said. "You get one who might order two or three suits a year, one for every season. They may now come in and get one thing that will wear better year around, that will last through the two or three seasons."
On the floor below, Eric Seemann, the store manager of Black, Starr & Frost, an expensive jewelry shop, said that business was as bad as he could remember. A store promotion has bolstered November sales, he said, but otherwise, things are dismal.
 
Still Shopping, but Spending Less
 "I'd say we were experiencing closer to a depression, personally," Mr. Seemann said. "I can honestly say that fewer people are coming in."
Many regular customers are still shopping, he said, but spending less. "The ones who were spending $7,000 are spending $5,000. The ones who were spending $10,000 are now spending $2,000 or $3,000."
"They say, very simply and bluntly, 'Times are hard, money's tight and the boom years are over,' " said Mr. Seemann.
Many of the stores are shifting their strategies. Black, Starr & Frost has begun selling more items that are less expensive, so that the average sale this year will be below $1,000, down several hundred dollars from last year. At the Sharper Image, which sells grown-up toys like enormous fish tanks and audio-visual gadgets, the manager, Joseph Booth, said: "We've gone with a larger assortment of lower-priced goods. We'd now carry more goods that are $100 and less, like the electronic tie rack for $35. We're selling 20 to 30 a day."
 
'Before, I Bought Everything'
 Carol Mack, a computer operator who lives in Stamford, is one customer who the mall is seeing more of this season. Overextended and worried about the economy, Mrs. Mack has decided to pay for everything in cash. "Before, I bought everything in sight. I would buy what I wanted and put it on a card," she said, biting off bits of a chocolate as she shopped. "But several stores have almost doubled the interest rates they charge, and it's not worth it."
Mrs. Mack is being more careful about what she buys. "Before, I would have bought a lot of frivolous things, or toys for the kids that they don't really need but are cute anyway. Now, instead of getting a panda, a bunny and a wind-up toy, I'll just buy one."
Another shopper, Joan McGirr, was leaving an eerily quiet Macy's, one of the mall's flagship stores and part of a chain that has been in trouble. "I just went from J. C. Penney to Macy's looking for something for my granddaughter, and as you can see I'm empty handed," Mrs. McGirr said. "I used to spend $32 on little outfits for her, but there just isn't much money around now, and the prices are very high."
It is not usual for stores to have Thanksgiving and pre-Christmas sales, but this year the sales started earlier and will last longer. "The customers are looking for sales rather than walking in and buying without checking the prices," said George Kontaxis, a sales associate at Abercrombie & Fitch.
 
Marked Down Half From $300
 Many store managers interviewed, even those who said that business was good, said they had to try harder to woo customers this year. "People are holding on to their cash a little more than usual," said Diane Vecchiarelli, store manager of the Narragansett, a woman's clothing retailer. "They're waiting to see if things are on sale."
She held up a suede skirt, which used to sell for $300. It had been marked down twice, to $150. "Whereas before people would just buy right away, now they're looking, coming back for a second and third look."
At Gantos, a moderately priced clothing store, huge signs in the windows announce a 25 percent to 40 percent reduction in prices. Suits are on sale: Buy one; get one free. "It's been horrible," said Shawndra Michel, an assistant manager. "People are being more careful. there's not much impulse buying, so we're trying to entice the people to come in, to give them every possible advantage to spend their dollar."
Even the stately Black, Starr and Frost has been forced to hold promotions. It is offering 10-month interest-free loans for customers. And after Thanksgiving, said Mr. Seeman, it plans a major sale, something that has never happened before in the pre-Christmas season.
"Selling three-quarters of a loaf is better than selling all of nothing," Mr. Seeman said.

HEADLINE: Man Screaming to Satan Held in Mother's Killing

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A 23-year-old Queens man screaming "Don't worry, I won't die, Satan," stabbed his mother to death and wounded his father with a kitchen knife at a Thanksgiving Day gathering yesterday, the police and neighbors said.
The man, Joseph Bergamini, was arrested on a street corner near his home yesterday afternoon shortly after the police and neighbors rushing to respond to screams found his mother, Kathleen, in the family's kitchen at 109-33 112th Street in Ozone Park. She had been stabbed in the chest, a police spokesman, Sgt. Norris Hollomon, said. Mrs. Bergamini was taken to Jamaica Hospital, where she was pronounced dead in the emergency room. 
 The young man's father, Arthur, was also found in the kitchen, stabbed in the back, Sergeant Hollomon said. He was in serious but stable condition at Jamaica Hospital last night.
The police recovered a carving knife in the kitchen that they believe is the murder weapon.
Sergeant Hollomon said Mr. Bergamini refused to make any statements to investigators about the stabbings. He was being held last night in the 106th Precinct station house on charges of murder and assault.
Just before noon, neighbors said they heard a screaming fight in the apartment. Joseph Guadagno, 19, who lives above the Bergaminis, said his family was watching the Thanksgiving Day parade on television when they suddenly heard a commotion below.
"There was a lot of screaming," he said. "Somebody said 'Stop it! Stop it!' Then I heard 'Don't do it!' Then I heard Joseph yell, 'Don't worry, I won't die, Satan!' "
 
 Daughter Pounds on Door
 Moments later, Mr. Guadagno said, the Bergamini's 25-year-old daughter pounded on his door, rushed in sobbing and called the police, saying her parents had been stabbed. Then he saw Joseph Bergamini run out onto the quiet street of duplexes and single-family houses.
Mr. Guadagno said Mr. Bergamini lived with his parents, his sister and her husband and a younger brother, Michael, who is 19. Joseph was apparently unemployed and habitually stayed out until 1 or 2 A.M. Often he would ring the Guadagnos' doorbell when he came home late, trying to sneak in without waking his parents, who frowned on his late hours, Mr. Guadagno said. "He'd ring our doorbell and say he forgot his keys," he said.
Other neighbors said Mr. Bergamini's father had been a construction worker until he was disabled at least three years ago while waterproofing a roof. His mother worked for a local bank, they said. The couple, in their 50's, were known as friendly people who often entertained neighbors in their backyard.
Some neighbors said Joseph Bergamini had acted erratically in the past. Once he jumped out a front window of the house to escape a loud argument with his parents. At a block party in 1987, neighbors said, Mr. Bergamini violently attacked his younger brother. His mother stepped in between the two and ended the fight, they said.
"He did have a few skirmishes a couple years ago with his younger brother and his mother intervened to protect him," said a neighbor, Matthew Mauser. "His actions may have been a bit abnormal."

HEADLINE: A Thanksgiving Feast, Under the Highway

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
There was an obvious question to ask Walter Wengert Jr., yesterday: What does a 40-year-old unemployed man living beneath the West Side Highway have to be thankful for? But at noon he was too busy to ponder it. Company was coming for dinner, and he was behind schedule building an oven.
The oven was a rusty old file drawer scavenged from the garbage that he was lining with aluminum foil. It would go on top of the wood fire blazing inside the blue tarpaulin that makes the walls of his home. On the dirt floor nearby were a 13-pound turkey, the ingredients for stuffing and pumpkin pie, sweet potatoes, corn on the cob, biscuits and a cookbook -- also scavenged from the garbage -- titled "Larousse Gastronomique." 
 "I've always loved to cook, but I ain't had much chance to do it the last few years," said Mr. Wengert. "Last Thanksgiving I was living in a parking lot in Chelsea." For the last six months he has been living at the edge of Riverside Park at West 72d Street, next to the entrance of a two-and-a-half-mile railroad tunnel.
The tunnel is home to squatters who sometimes call themselves the Mole People. Several would be emerging for dinner with Mr. Wengert and his neighbors under the highway. The exact number for dinner was uncertain -- one invited guest, for instance, was a possible no-show because he was in hiding after stabbing a man -- but Mr. Wengert was cooking for 10, an unusually large gathering among squatters who like to keep to themselves.
"Normally I don't invite others," Mr. Wengert said. "But a couple of us got the idea of pooling our food stamps for a Thanksgiving feast, and we got plenty of food, so I thought today would be a good day to be cool about it with others that aren't as well off. That's what Thanksgiving's about."
That sentiment was shared by Douglas, 45, one of the squatters, who did not want his children to read his last name. "We'll be glad to give them food," he said of the guests, as he helped Mr. Wengert with preparations. "But they'll have to bring their own plates. We don't have enough to go around."
Dinner preparations had gotten off to late start the night before for a couple of reasons. One was the second jug of wine the men had consumed. The other was a faulty alarm clock, which caused Douglas to miss his 9:30 appointment for his regular job, parking the car of a clerk at the Offtrack Betting Corporation parlor at West 72d Street near Amsterdam Avenue.
 
A Little Last-Minute Shopping
 Douglas responded by beating the alarm clock to death with a log. "I only get angry at inanimate objects, never at people," he said good naturedly, and headed off to forage for firewood in Riverside Park. Mr. Wengert went up to the Gristede's at 263 West 72d Street for some last-minute shopping: raisins, whipped cream, pie-crust mix.
He had to improvise on some things. After deciding that a hammer handle would not make a good rolling pin, he flattened the pie-crust dough by hand. But he had the essentials of a kitchen -- table, cutting board, utensils -- just as he had the essentials of a home: chairs, bed, lanterns, batterpopowered radiand television.
There is no running water, but there are fire hydrants not too far away that provide water for the dozens of squatters on the railroad land and outside and inside the tunnel. Some have built wooden shanties; others have been living for as long as 15 years in cement-block buildings scattered along the length of the tunnel.
 
'The Media Leeches Descended'
 Their secluded life was interrupted this year. An article about the Mole People appeared in The New York Times in June, and soon there were camera crews from American and foreign television networks tromping through the tunnel. "Donahue" inquired about doing an entire program inside the tunnel.
"The media leeches descended," Douglas complained.
Another intrusion has been the new track that Amtrak is laying in the tunnel for its trains from Albany to Pennsylvania Station. In April trains are scheduled to start using the tunnel for the first time in a decade. Officials from Amtrak and the city's Human Resources Administration have been visiting the squatters, telling them they will have to move, and offering to help them relocate.
Many of the squatters, as well as some city and railroad officials, say they doubt that it it will ever be possible to keep people off the railroad land. But the squatters are concerned about the new track, and it was a topic of conversation as the guests watched football on television and Mr. Wengert finished preparing dinner.
"This could be the last Thanksgiving anyone's going to have here," said Douglas. Whatever happened in the spring, he said, he hoped to be gone before then. He said he was planning to enter a treatment program for alcoholism. "Booze is what cost me my last job and apartment," he said.
Mr. Wengert said he was also hoping to be gone soon. A native of the Bronx, he said he had been working steadily in the late 1980's -- as a security guard, bouncer at a topless bar, short-order cook -- while living rent free in the basement of a building in Chelsea run by a friendly superintendent. He lost that home when the building was sold in the summer of 1989.
"Then it was just one bad thing after another," he said. "I lost a job, and then pretty soon everything was gone. I've been out looking, but it's kind of hard to get back up when you're down here.
"But your luck can turn," he said. "I'm planning to get my driver's license, get a job as a courier, save some money and get a floor-refinishing and window-washing business going with my brother."
 
2 Pies and a Good-Looking Turkey
 Mr. Wengert finally got a chance to relax after dark yesterday. The oven had turned out two nicely browned pies and an appetizing turkey. There was stuffing with onions and mushrooms for the turkey, and a topping for the pie with peaches, strawberries, honey and blackberry brandy.
There were eight people, all neighbors, for dinner: seven men and one woman. It was probably one of the more racially diverse Thanksgiving parties in New York, and probably one of the more jovial. The guests brought their own plates. Before eating they considered what there was to be thankful for.
"Life. I think that says it all," Douglas said.
"Health and strength," said Isaiah Laray Davis, 25.
"I'm away from all the racket," said C. Harris, 30. "Away from all the phony people sitting at the table praising things they know they don't live up to."
"It's just another day, that's all," said Mr. Wengert's 37-year-old brother, Thomas, who lives with him.
"No, it's not," Mr. Wengert said to his brother. "This is the first Thanksgiving dinner you and I have had together in 10 years. I'm thankful for that. This is a day you should be with your close friends and family, not at some dinner in a church. When I go to one of those church dinners, I feel like an inmate getting fed. I'd rather go back to jail.
"Today I got to make all this good stuff and everyone will have something to enjoy. I got a lot of good people around me. We ain't in Penn Station, we ain't in a parking lot, we ain't sleeping in a cement truck somewhere. It's a great, beautiful day."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Visiting U.S. Troops in the Desert, President Talks Tough About Iraq

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Soaring across eastern Saudi Arabia today on a whirlwind Thanksgiving tour of the troops, President Bush suggested that there was an imminent threat of Iraq's acquiring nuclear weapons and told a group of marines that they "may well" be the ones to drive President Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait.
As he flew in his Marine helicopter into the Saudi desert and onto an amphibious assault ship in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Bush warned Mr. Hussein: "Free the hostages, all the hostages. Free them today or you'll pay the price." 
 "We won't pull punches," he said at a Marine outpost less than 80 miles from the border of occupied Kuwait. "We are not here on some exercise. This is a real-world situation. And we are not walking away until the invader is out of Kuwait." [Excerpts, page A16.]
 
Security Is Very Tight
 Then, as scores of American marines and British Desert Rat tank troops cheered, Mr. Bush said, "That may well be where you come in."
Security was even tighter than usual. F-15 fighter-interceptors screamed aloft from Dhahran to escort Air Force One, while Awacs surveillance planes circled far overhead to watch for Iraqi aircraft. Helicopters with 50-caliber machine guns accompanied Mr. Bush's unarmed helicopter, and as he spoke in the desert, a German-made vehicle capable of detecting chemical, nuclear or biological attack stood guard.
Like all those who accompanied him, Mr. Bush was issued a gas mask and given instructions on how to put it on, within 9 seconds, if a gas attack occurred.
 
Bush Waits in Line
 The President waded eagerly into the enthusiastic crowds of soldiers, reveling in their cheers, rhythmic grunts and whistles, and waited in line with them at the Army outpost for a lunch of turkey roll and mashed potatoes.
Mr. Bush, who said tonight that it had been "an emotional day" for him, told American servicemen and women that he had acted "with restraint and patience." But he said, "Saddam Hussein is making the mistake of his life if he confuses an abundance of restraint with a lack of resolve."
He did not say exactly what course he had in mind, to the disappointment of many who heard him speak. But throughout the day he groped for ways to bolster domestic support for the gulf operation and hold together the international alliance against Mr. Hussein at a time when the United States fears that the Iraqi leader is not taking the danger of military action seriously. Mr. Bush is also seeking United Nations authorization for the use of force should he decide to go to war.
He referred indirectly to those efforts today.
"We've gone to the United Nations, time and time again," he said. "I'm prepared to go another time. We still hope for a peaceful settlement, but the world is a dangerous place, and we must make all of these options credible. Those in uniform, it seems to me, will always bear the heaviest burden."
He repeated familiar themes during the day: economic security, the need to oppose aggression and the threat to American diplomats and other "innocent lives." And he often did so with the same passionless phrases and intellectual policy arguments that have drawn assertions that he is not adequately explaining the mission in the gulf.
 
A More Ominous Tone
 But as the day wore on and the President moved from Air Force to Army to Navy and then Marine units around eastern Saudi Arabia, he began striking what White House officials said was a deliberately more ominous tone toward Iraq. He came closer than he ever has before to a direct threat of war and added a significant new element to his oratory: a heavy emphasis on the danger that Mr. Hussein might soon acquire atomic weapons.
"Those who would measure the timetable for Saddam Hussein's atomic weapons program in years may be underestimating the reality of the situation and the gravity of that threat," Mr. Bush said at the Marine outpost in his fourth and toughest speech of the day.
"No one knows precisely when this dictator may acquire atomic weapons or who they may be aimed at down the road," he said. "But we do know this for sure: He has never possessed a weapon that he hasn't used."
Administration officials have been saying for some time that Mr. Hussein, who has used poison gases against the Iranian military and against his own citizens, might develop atomic weapons in less than two years. They said today that there was no new evidence indicating that might occur sooner.
Some other international nuclear experts have said that Iraq could probably make one fairly crude but very dangerous bomb relatively quickly, but that it could probably start manufacturing nuclear warheads only in about 10 years.
 
Nuclear Argument Favored
 Recent public opinion surveys have suggested that eliminating the potential threat of Iraqi nuclear weapons is a powerful argument with the Americans questioned for going to war against Iraq, while the other goals Mr. Bush has outlined for his gulf policy are not as effective.
So Mr. Bush included the theme in three of his four speeches, starting at the Dhahran air base, where he spoke in front of an F-16 fighter-bomber, an F-15 fighter interceptor and an A-10 anti-tank bomber. He steadily strengthened his message as he went to an Army outpost 80 miles from here, to the assault ship Nassau in the gulf and to the Marine outpost.
The President began his speeches with one-liners.
"Hey listen, thanks for that warm desert welcome -- and I mean warm," he said at the Army post, where he arrived in his helicopter, Marine One, amid a swirl of desert sand and a phalanx of armed guards, aides and television cameras.
"Now look, look," he said, sounding for all the world like a stand-up comic. "We know that the days can get pretty long out here, and you'll be glad to know that if it goes on too long we have a secret weapon in reserve. If push comes to shove, we're going to get Roseanne Barr to go to Iraq and sing the national anthem."
 
President Seems Tired
 As he worked the crowds, Mr. Bush seemed clearly tired from the grueling schedule he has kept since he left Washington last Friday on a seven-day, seven-nation tour that is scheduled to end Friday in Cairo and Geneva.
And as he waited for his lunch, he seemed somewhat subdued. Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said: "He's moved by these kids. He talked to them, and they're all so fresh and bright and young."
The President wore a blue work shirt open at the collar and rolled up at the sleeves, khaki slacks and desert boots, with a floppy desert camouflage hat that he kept tucked in his back pocket. He was accompanied by his wife, Barbara, who wore a brown camouflage jacket.
The four leaders of Congress trailed along: the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley; the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell; and the minority leaders of the Senate and House, Bob Dole and Robert H. Michel.
 
Bush Mixes Freely
 Despite the tight security, the President mixed relatively freely with the troops, hopping down from the stage in Dhahran to shake the hands of the Americans in the audience. A group of Saudi airmen stood in an isolated knot within the crowd.
At the Army outpost, Mr. Bush came out of the food line to be greeted by Second Lieut. Emiciades Alcon, 23 years old, of Fort Benning, Ga., who said, "Thank you, sir, for showing up here in the desert."
Mr. Bush said, "That's what Woody Allen said: 'Ninety percent of life is showing up.' "
The pool of reporters who accompanied Mr. Bush said that the troops he met were generally enthusiastic and that there were none of the embarrassing offers of hot drinking water that marred an earlier visit by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
"I didn't expect him to come out here," said Sgt. Kevin Schuler, a marine from Grand Forks, N.D., aboard the Nassau. "But he's here. That's cool."
Sgt. Clyde L. Williams, 27, of Forestville, Md., said, "It makes me feel he at least took the time to come and see us and that he cares."
 
5,000 Hear Him Speak
 Some soldiers grumbled that Mr. Bush had not seen more troops. Officials estimated that 5,000 to 6,000 heard him speak at his four quick stops today.
Pvt. Richard Alcivar, 20, of Brooklyn, an Army Scout, said: "After all, he sent us here. Some thought he ought to have seen more of us."
But the more common complaint was that Mr. Bush did not bring any concrete news for men and women who have waited -- some for three months -- in the heat and uncertainty of the desert wondering if they would go to war with Iraq or be sent home.
"We're hoping we get some news from the President," said Capt. Joseph O'Donnell, an Army officer from Avon by the Sea, N.J. "We hope he's got a date."
For war or to go home?
"Either one," the captain said.
 
Bush Arrives in Cairo
 CAIRO, Nov. 22 -- President Bush arrived tonight for an overnight stay in Cairo, where he will confer with President Hosni Mubarak before flying to Geneva for talks with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.

HEADLINE: Airlines Are Nervous About Rapid Spread Of 2-for-1 Fare Deal

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
What began as a small promotion offered by one airline to a small group of customers has grown into a nationwide giveaway that has delighted tens of thousands of passengers but is hurting the industry and infuriating travel agents.
Earlier this month, American Airlines mailed coupons to members of its frequent-flier plan in Chicago, offering them a chance, on certain routes, to buy a second ticket for $50 on flights for which they had purchased excursion fares. When other airlines learned of the offer, they matched the promotion, then went one better. Within days, the nation's large airlines were all offering a companion ticket without charge to people who bought a round-trip ticket at the most inexpensive advance-purchase fares. 
 The promotion is one of the most aggressive in years and all the more striking for its timing, as the industry enters what is normally a prosperous holiday travel season.
After years of record-breaking growth in the numbers of passengers during the Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year holiday season, the airlines are predicting no increases this year. And whether they make or lose money through the new promotion, they are clearly demonstrating that their highest priority is to keep their share of the market out of the hands of their rivals.
Only a limited number of seats are available on any given flight in the companion-ticket promotion. The airlines do not disclose how many seats are made available under the offer, nor does the law require them to set aside a minimum number.
Under the promotion, a passenger flying between New York and San Francisco on Trans World Airlines can pay $428 for a round-trip ticket and receive a second one without charge. The average cost per person: only $214.
The latest promotions, like many before them, represent a guessing game by the airlines. In offering a two-for-one fare, will the airlines attract enough business to offset the loss of income from customers who would have flown without the special incentive? Airline executives can never be certain, but they feel they must follow their competitors' promotions to avoid losing market share.
The number of miles flown by paying passengers has grown 1.8 percent this year, but the number of available seats has increased 6 percent as planes ordered years ago are now entering service.
Add the sharp increases in fuel prices as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis, and the industry is expected to lose more than $1 billion this year.
Given the problems facing the industry, some analysts and travel agents question the wisdom of the current offer.
Indeed, at least one airline, Continental Airlines, acknowledges that it will lose money on the promotion, which is generally valid for travel through Feb. 28. "This isn't something that I want to do," said John Nelson, executive vice president of marketing for Continental Airlines, which has aggressively advertised the companion tickets. "If this happened a year ago, I'm not sure our reaction would have been the same." At that time, airlines were not under as much pressure from slower traffic, higher fuel costs and tighter economic times.
 
 Many Restrictions
 The promotional fares carry many restrictions, including a requirement that the tickets be bought at least seven days in advance. The offer is not valid during certain "blackout" dates during the holiday season, and tickets must be purchased by Nov. 30.
Travel agents are angry because they make no commission on the free tickets and sometimes have to return parts of commissions when tickets are reissued at a lower fare. "You have to write the ticket three or four times to make nine bucks," said Richard Copland, president of Hillside Travel in New York.
The travel agents also complain that the airlines have made too few free seats available. They spend a fair amount of time, they say, trying to make reservations on flights for which the offer is not available.
"It's driving us absolutely crazy," said David Perelman, president of D.M.S. Travel Group in New York.
 
 Hungry for a Bargain
 But the airlines insist that they have allocated no fewer seats for this promotion than any other. They suggest that fewer seats may be available because consumers are hungry for a bargain. Citing higher fuel costs, the airlines have raised fares three times since August. Domestic fares have risen at least 10 percent and fares for international flights have risen as much as 16 percent. "There is definitely sticker shock out there," said Mr. Nelson of Continental Airlines.
Northwest Airlines' reservation-call volume rose 23 percent since its promotion began, said Robert Gibbons, a spokesman. "It was computer meltdown," he said. Other airlines report a similar response.
The companion-ticket promotion snowballed in the past few days as each airline sought to better its competition's offer and no airline was willing to stop the momentum. Midway Airlines, for instance, was the first to make the offer available to the general public, not just members of a frequent-flier program. On Monday, Northwest Airlines eliminated the $25 charge for companion tickets.
Even American Airlines, which began the promotion, said that in retrospect it might have been a mistake. "We never expected it to go this far," said an executive at American who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
 
 'A Ridiculous Level'
 Gail Ruderman, president of Ruderman Travel in Trenton, N.J., also questioned the wisdom of the promotion. "We don't think it makes an awful lot of sense," she said. "The airlines complain about massive losses, and then they reduce a fare to a ridiculous level."
But it is those very losses, the airlines argue, that incite them to offer the generous giveaways, which are aimed at stimulating travel during the normally slow winter months. "People may have it in their brain that there is no sense taking a trip," said Mr. Gibbons of Northwest. "You make no money with an empty seat."
Lee Howard, chairman of Airline Economics, a consulting firm in Washington, said: "It shouldn't be any surprise. It's a highly competitive environment out there."
 
 Weaker Airlines Will Suffer
 Still, some industry analysts said the giveaways will only weaken the industry's already feeble financial pulse. "This is something the industry can live without," said Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley.
Mr. Murphy said that while financially sound airlines, like American and United, can afford to give away seats, weaker ones like T.W.A. and Pan Am will be hard hit by the promotion.
There is already mounting evidence that a recession -- or at least the fear of one -- is beginning to discourage travel. The airlines predict they will carry nine million passengers during the Thanksgiving holiday, marking the second consecutive year of stable traffic -- with no growth. And after a steady 1 or 2 percent monthly increase in passengers for most of the last 12 months, the number of passengers in October dropped slightly, said Tim Neale, spokesman for the Air Transport Association, the industry trade group.
Top executives from most of the major airlines met with Samuel K. Skinner, Secretary of Transportation, earlier this month and warned that without Federal assistance to bring down jet-fuel prices, several carriers could fold in the next few months. Some airline executives are calling on President Bush to release more of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, designating some of the supply for jet fuel.

The Milken Sentence
Michael Milken's lawyers could not have determined that he would be sentenced to a prison term as long as 10 years. Based on information compiled by the U.S. Attorney's office in Manhattan, the term fell outside the boundaries of any of the more than 75 sentences handed down against white-collar criminals on Wall Street in the last decade. [Page D1.]
Judge Kimba Wood said in her sentencing that she wanted to send a message. Whether they view Mr. Milken as a hero, a villain or a scapegoat, a variety of people contacted afterward said the judge's message came through loud and clear. [D4.]
 
The Economy
What began as a small promotion by American Airlines to an exclusive group of customers has escalated into a nationwide giveaway. The nation's large airlines are offering free tickets to the traveling companions of all comers, delighting passengers but cutting into industry profits and infuriating travel agents. [A1.]
The Bush Administration has drafted an ambitious plan for expanding highway construction, broadening the network of major national roads, providing incentives to reduce congestion and allowing states to charge tolls on more highways. [A1.]
 
Companies
Two of the world's biggest deal makers are behaving as if mergers had not fallen by nearly half and that the "junk bond" market had not collapsed. Forstmann Little and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts are trying to persuade pension funds and other big investors to replenish their coffers so they can buy more companies. [D1.]
Brooks Brothers has stuck with tradition, in the clothes it sells and how it sells them, even though its sales have slumped. [D1.]

The Miami City Commission has approved an ordinance requiring the police to report drug arrests to employers. [B21.]
 
International
One of Italy's industrial titans resigned unexpectedly as chairman of Ferruzzi Finanziaria, the country's second-largest private company. Raul Gardini, who has been emboiled in a dispute with a state-owned energy company, said he would leave the business world for "ideological reasons." [D1.]
A new airport going up in western Japan has become the focus of an angry dispute between the U.S. and Japan over the failure of an American-German venture to win a big contract. [D1.]
Argentina's privatization program took a big step forward with the transfer of control of the national airline, Aerolineas Argentinas, to a group led by Iberia, the Spanish carrier. [D1.]
 
Markets
Britain's markets closed virtually unchanged, although they rose sharply after Margaret Thatcher announced she would resign as Prime Minister. Most other European trading was subdued. U.S. markets were closed for the Thanksgiving holiday. [D6.]
