HEADLINE: CHANGE IN BRITAIN;
THATCHER SAYS SHE'LL QUIT; 11 1/2 YEARS AS PRIME MINISTER ENDED BY PARTY CHALLENGE

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Her leadership of the Conservative Party slipping away, Margaret Thatcher announced today that she would resign as Prime Minister as soon as a new leader was elected next week, ending an extraordinary era in British politics that lasted 11 1/2 years.
Her immediate successor will be one of three men: Michael Heseltine, the 57-year-old former Defense Minister; Douglas Hurd, 60, the Foreign Secretary, or John Major, 47, the Chancellor of the Exchequer. 
 It was Mr. Heseltine who broke Mrs. Thatcher's hold on the leadership by winning the votes of 152 of the 372 Conservative members of Parliament in an initial leadership ballot on Tuesday. Mr. Hurd and Mr. Major entered the race today after the 65-year-old Prime Minister withdrew from the second ballot.
The winner will be chosen either by a simple majority in the second ballot next Tuesday, or, if none of the three wins a majority then, in a runoff ballot next Thursday.
 
Surprise and Relief
 Mrs. Thatcher's resignation was greeted with surprise and sadness, but by wide relief in the ranks of her divided party. The immediate cause of the split was her resistance to European economic and political union, but the roots of discontent lay in her combative personality and leadership tactics.
The leader of the opposition Labor Party, Neil Kinnock, said the news was "good, very, very good indeed" and called again for an immediate general election that public opinion polls say Labor would easily win if it were held now. The no-confidence motion by which Labor sought to force snap elections was defeated tonight by a vote of 367 to 247, but general elections must be held by mid-1992.
Abroad, many government officials paid warm tribute to her leadership. President Bush, in Saudi Arabia, described her as an "outstanding ally for the United States" and said he would miss her personally. But in much of Europe her resignation was taken as a hopeful sign that the pace of European unification would quicken. [Page A14.]
Iraq's Information Minister said she had "lost her party, her job and even her reputation" even as her Government announced that it would send 14,000 more British troops to the Persian Gulf as part of the allied effort to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. As part of a vigorous defense of her policies in the House of Commons debate on Mr. Kinnock's no-confidence motion this afternoon, Mrs. Thatcher warned that the time was "fast approaching" for "more decisive action" against Iraq.
The manner of Mrs. Thatcher's going was as extraordinary as her long career. The Prime Minister who led Britain to victory in the war to recapture the Falkland Islands from Argentina in 1982, who only a year and a half ago was unchallenged, universally respected and prepared to go "on and on," was being disavowed by her own party even as Britain prepared for a much larger war in the Persian Gulf.
"It's a funny old world," aides reported her saying to the hushed Cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street this morning at which she announced her decision, "that here I have won a majority but feel I have to go."
But she put her feelings behind her and put on a game performance in Parliament this afternoon, after going to Buckingham Palace to inform Queen Elizabeth II of her decision to resign.
 
Self-Confident in Parliament
 In the debate in the Commons the Prime Minister displayed her usual combativeness and self-confidence, but was relaxed enough to let her sense of humor show, though she sounded hoarse and tired.
When a Labor member suggested that she might now become Governor of the Bank of England, she said, "What a good idea!" In that position, she said, she could prevent the independent central European bank and single European currency that she so vigorously opposes as an intrusion into British national sovereignty.
"I'm enjoying this, I'm enjoying this," she said, though it seemed doubtful that she was.
After hearing the conflicting advice of friends, party leaders, and Cabinet ministers who came to the Prime Minister's residence at No. 10 Downing Street on Wednesday night to advise her, she decided early this morning to resign, going back on earlier pledges to fight on to victory.
 
Released at 9:34 A.M.
 "A whole range of Cabinet ministers said, 'Look, we don't think you're going to win, and it would be better if you didn't run,' " said Sir Norman Fowler, a former Cabinet minister himself. It was known that Mrs. Thatcher's support among Conservative legislators was eroding, but it was not known whether she saw this as merely an ominous trend or whether a tally by her aides actually showed Mr. Heseltine winning the vote.
Mrs. Thatcher reached her decision at 7:30 this morning, aides said, and then informed her Cabinet. The announcement was released to a stunned British public at 9:34 this morning.
"The Prime Minister, the Rt. Hon. Margaret Thatcher, F.R.S., has informed the Queen that she does not intend to contest the second ballot of the election for leadership of the Conservative Party and intends to resign as Prime Minister as soon as a new leader of the Conservative Party has been elected," it said.
Appended was a personal statement by Mrs. Thatcher: "Having consulted widely among colleagues, I have concluded that the unity of the party and the prospect of victory in a general election would be better served if I stood down to enable Cabinet colleagues to enter the ballot for the leadership. I should like to thank all those in Cabinet and outside who have given me such dedicated support."
The news filled the radio and television airways all day and was even relayed to riders on the London Underground by intercom. They took the news in silence. Later a small crowd gathered outside the gates to Downing Street, and some people brought bouquets and wreaths of flowers.
 
Caretaker Prime Minister
 A few hours later, now as caretaker Prime Minister, Mrs. Thatcher appeared in the House of Commons to argue against the Labor Party's call for immediate elections and to hear many allies and opponents alike pay tribute to her courage, though most also said that she had done the right thing by deciding to go.
Though her departure seemed tragic to old friends like Lord William Whitelaw, her first Home Secretary, it was sadly deserved in the view of many, former allies and opponents, who had felt the sting of her sharp tongue in Cabinet meetings and parliamentary debates over the last decade.
"Those who live by the sword shall perish by the sword," said Lord Callaghan, who as James Callaghan became Labor Prime Minister in 1976 after Harold Wilson stepped down as that party's leader, the last time a British Prime Minister resigned as a result of discontent within the governing party.
Mr. Heseltine, who walked out of Mrs. Thatcher's Cabinet as Defense Minister five years ago, was determined to unseat her partly because of the way he said she had steamrolled him in Government debates. He made his move against her last week after a wounded former friend of the Prime Minister, Sir Geoffrey Howe, resigned as Deputy Prime Minister and denounced her hostile attitude to Europe in a House of Commons speech that many viewed as his revenge on her for removing him as Foreign Secretary in July of 1989, for urging her too hard to accede to European monetary union.
Mr. Heseltine is widely seen as the front-runner to win next week, because of his success in getting 152 votes in the first round. He will need 187 votes, a majority, to win in the second round next Tuesday. If no one gets a majority, a third ballot would be held next Thursday, in which Conservative legislators would be asked to select first- and second-choice candidates from among the three. If no candidate receives a majority of first-choice ballots, the weakest candidate will be dropped and the next Prime Minister will be decided on the strength of second-choice support for the two survivors.
Mr. Hurd and Mr. Major, Thatcher supporters in the first-round vote, made clear today that they had entered the contest to try to stop Mr. Heseltine.
 
Attack From Kinnock
 "We have decided to let both our names go forward in friendly contest so that our party colleagues who take the decision can choose which of us is better placed to unite the party," they said in a joint statement. But separately, each said he had the best chance of doing so, and it was not clear whether their candidacies would weaken support for Mr. Heseltine or merely divide opposition to him.
In today's debate in Parliament on the no-confidence motion, the 48-year-old Mr. Kinnock, who would become Prime Minister if Labor won, attacked the Conservative Government's divisions on Europe and catalogued a long list of Conservative failures: an inflation rate of 10.9 percent; the "community charge," an unpopular new head tax for local government services; rising unemployment, and cuts in public spending for social benefits.
"What a record! Eleven oil-rich years, with a recession at each end and a miracle in between," he said. "How can anyone have confidence in a Government with Cabinet ministers who in the last week have been privately telling the press that the Prime Minister is finished and then minutes later supporting her position in the television studios or going off to a private meeting in order to contrive the coup against the Prime Minister?"
"In a democracy," he said, "there is only one fitting conclusion to today's events -- a general election."
 
Thatcher Defends Herself
 Mrs. Thatcher, rising to her own defense with Tory ranks doing their best to try to support her, looked back to the situation she said she had inherited from a Labor Government when she won her first election on May 4, 1979.
"Eleven years ago we rescued Britain from the parlous state to which socialism had brought it," she said. "Once again Britain stands tall in the councils of Europe and of the world. Over the last decade, we have given power back to the people on an unprecedented scale. We have given back control to people over their own lives and over their livelihoods, over the decisions that matter most to them and their families. We have done it by curbing the monopoly power of trade unions to control, even victimize the individual worker.
"We have been the driving force behind the single market," she said, referring to the European Community's decision to drop all internal trade and tariff barriers by the end of 1992. "With all this we have never hesitated to stand up for Britain's interests."
"They want a Europe of subsidies, a Europe of socialist restrictions, a Europe of protectionism," she said of the Labor Party. "They want it because that's how they would like to run, or is it to ruin, this country."
Even on Europe, she did not retreat a single inch. But Europe was the issue that finally brought her down.

HEADLINE: Tom Otterness's Wicked World of Human and Beastly Folly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON

 BODY:
With his commission for the north park of Battery Park City, Tom Otterness has reached a new plateau. The opportunity to make sculptures for children and adults to live with in a public space has helped him focus the playful, sinister and allegorical impulses of his work. It has also enabled him to give his tiny Jiminy Cricket-like people and his menagerie of exotic or mundane animals a narrative and a home. His bronze sculptures at the Brooke Alexander Gallery in SoHo are like a fable about desire, curiosity and folly.
In the gallery's main room, which presents many of the sculptures that will be installed in the Battery Park City playground in 1992 (the north park, at the end of Chambers Street, is still being built), the variety of creatures from fairy tale and myth is startling. So is the range of influences -- from Egyptian, African and Renaissance art to natural history and anthropology -- that are evident in the four sketchbooks lying open on stands in front of two park benches, inviting perusal. 
 Mr. Otterness is at his best when he is carried along by the imagining and modeling (in clay) of his figures. He can still run into trouble when his work is overtly allegorical. It is understandable that he would feel the need to include within his work a recognition of the obsession with money and power in the Battery Park City and Wall Street area. But "Fat Cat and Rats," which associates the church and banking with rattiness and greed, and "Nero Apartment House," in which Nero as Humpty Dumpty fiddles as his house filled with coins is pulled down, are a bit heavy-handed.
Most of Mr. Otterness's Battery Park City project, however, looks like an unqualified success. The sculptures will bring to this Hudson River site a community of frogs, sprouting "alien" tadpoles or locked in combat like sumo wrestlers. One friendly frog sits in front of the benches, watching over them. Nearby, and just as unexpected, is a turtle whose head -- a grasshopper still wedged in its mouth -- is detached from its body, as if it had been lopped off by the scythe of the reaper of death sitting atop a nearby lamppost. Throughout the Battery Park City installation, there is a sense of the good will, paranoia and mayhem of New York.
Much of what happens in this room is interrelated. "Food Chain" shows a big cat, low to the ground, haunches tensed, ready to pounce on a bird with woman's breasts that has tracked down a giant worm that is looking at the bird and sticking out its tongue. Alongside this chain of predation is a bulldog chained to a water fountain, champing at the bit at the sight of the cat. In Mr. Otterness's world, just about everything is observing and being observed. In much of Mr. Otterness's work, humans and animals are slobbering slaves to desire.
Two creatures preside over this Battery Park City fable. The only one who sees everything, but who is not being seen, is the small reaper, atop the lamppost, looking at his watch, symbol of the thriving harvest of death in New York at night.
The other creature is ridiculous but no less inescapable. The nearly three-foot-tall dodo is the largest animal in the show. Its wings are stumpy, useless. Its body is like a globe. Its egg is like a grenade. It stands at attention like a general observing his troops. Mr. Otterness's dodo is like an aviary Edsel, or like an emblem of military folly, misplaced pride and a spectacularly expensive aircraft that can barely get off the ground.
Mr. Otterness's belief that there are two ineradicable sides of human nature -- one noble and inspiring, the other foolish and bestial -- is unmistakable in two sculptures in the show that were not made for Battery Park City. "Neanderthal II" is the bust of an ape-man who is both musclebound brute and doubting spirit. "Neanderthal I" is the same man as modern warrior -- a relative of the gas-masked soldiers of Otto Dix -- or as futuristic robot.
Mr. Otterness clearly believes the prehistoric side of the human animal will be every bit as strong in the future as it has been in the past. These sculptures, like his work as a whole, have several sides, none easily compatible with the others. Mr. Otterness's feeling for human nature may not be particularly encouraging, but he is always trying to understand what the human animal is, and he is getting better and better at communicating his sense of fun, fear and surprise.
 The sculptures of Tom Otterness remain at the Brooke Alexander Gallery, 59 Wooster Street, through next Friday.
 
Joel Shapiro
Paula Cooper Gallery
155 Wooster Street
Through Dec. 1
 Joel Shapiro's new work moves in several directions at once. His vocabulary remains simple, even childlike, in its dependence on unadorned, elongated rectangular blocks, sometimes standing on spindly legs, always organized into constructions suggestive of elementary actions, like walking. In one large polychrome work, Mr. Shapiro evokes, with characteristic economy, a figure leaning way back, or striding vigorously forward, bearing a cross, or twirling its arms in celebration and relief.
Throughout the show, however, there is the sense of an artist experimenting with new ideas, moving shapes around, testing out balances, exploring different possibilities of abstraction. In one large sculpture that from one point of view suggests a marching, kicking figure, the topmost rectangle is attached to the main body in a way that is jarring, like a head or arm that has slightly slipped off its torso. The shift stops the easy emotional flow and makes the work less an answer than a question.
The two most unexpected works in the show have a kind of anonymity that also seems new. One is a sculpture by the window in which a roughly triangular form, a bit like a horse's head, is attached at the top of an upright rod like a flag to a pole. The other, made of basswood, has two elements, each with five parts. While the sculpture by the window rises off the floor, this one nearly collapses. Each of the two parts periodically coalesces into an image of a figure, curled up, perhaps looking at the other. Mr. Shapiro has not courted dissolution and disjunctiveness this way before.
 
Eugene Leroy
Edward Thorp Gallery
103 Prince Street
Through tomorrow
 For many years now, Eugene Leroy has been building up and stripping down canvases, making them seem naked or impenetrable, burial grounds or inexhaustible repositories of images and light. In his new paintings, as before, paint is woven across the canvas in thick strands squeezed directly from the tube. Sometimes areas of the canvas, even alongside the mounds of paint, are scraped away, so that the weave of the canvas is visible. In this process of adding and subtracting, Mr. Leroy continues to search for something that sometimes takes years to find.
What he finds always has something to do with the human image, which is always vulnerable in his paintings, always threatened, but capable of carrying on. The imagery held within his knots of paint is basic: heads and bodies; men and women; mothers and children; water and earth. They come through the paint, they are inside the paint, they are the paint. It is never clear exactly where they are and what they are, but they have to exist.
What is most distinct about Mr. Leroy's recent paintings is how close the images are to disappearing. In "Visage sur Lumiere Verte et Rouge," the paint seems to part slightly to reveal a head in the pictorial mud like the head of Daniel-Henry Kahnweiler in the Cubist grid of Picasso. In "Claire," one head emerges at the lower right, another in the center left, both facing us -- perhaps. The figures in these paintings seem to be part of some processional march that began some place beyond memory. Although the images seem capable of being extinguished or called back at any second, they also have the capacity to endure, in the memories of those who see them, for a good while.
 
Stephen Ellis
Koury Wingate Gallery
578 Broadway (near Prince Street)
Through Dec. 1
 Stephen Ellis is trying to put everything he can into abstract paintings that come out of the stripes and grids of modernism but bear a very personal stamp. In all three three-panel paintings and in the two single-panel paintings in this show, there is a vertical scaffolding built with ink lines. Interlaced are horizontal strips applied with paint that is diluted and often creamy and glowing. The brushwork pulled across the canvas has its own life, sometimes creating illusions or reflections of landscape that bring to mind paintings by Monet.
The tensions within these paintings are generally convincing but still somewhat schematic. If the paintings are suggestive of architectural scaffoldings, they are also earthy. If they seem to have a mathematical precision, the process through which they are painted also seems highly intuitive. It is sometimes hard to tell what paint is over and what paint is under, or what is figure or ground. There is often no absolute sense of direction: some paintings almost ask to be turned on their sides. This dialectical approach has a self-conscious aspect to it now, but Mr. Ellis is an artist of intelligence and ambition, and these paintings promise a great deal.

HEADLINE: The Debt's Progress

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tom Wicker states in "America's Real Deficit" (column, Nov.7) that the national debt "is growing about the same pace as gross national product." The national debt ended the fiscal year at more than $3.2 trillion, an increase of $376 billion, or about 12 percent. The debt increase will likely continue on its upward surge, while the gross national product may not increase at all for some time.
At an average rate of 9 percent, interest on the debt will be almost $300 billion a year. That is an obligatory Federal expenditure, encompassing funds that are thus not available for environmental cleanup, public housing repair, education for at-risk youth or the many other neglected social needs that Mr. Wicker recites.
 
SEYMOUR B. DURST
 New York, Nov. 12, 1990

HEADLINE: After Mrs. Thatcher

 BODY:
With her vision, her intellect and her commanding presence, she dominated Britain's politics, and its relations with the U.S., for more than a decade. Americans will miss Margaret Thatcher, but there is no reason for concern about the likely direction of British policies after her.
Yesterday she bowed to a Conservative Party revolt and resigned. The swiftness of her fall and the competition to succeed her guarantee some unpredictability. But on the issues that affect America most, substantial continuity is assured under any of the Conservative contenders -- Michael Heseltine, Douglas Hurd or John Major -- or even under the Labor leader, Neil Kinnock. 
 Washington's most urgent concern is the Persian Gulf. Saddam Hussein would be foolhardy to anticipate any weakening of British resolve. Britain's Defense Secretary, Tom King, sent a powerful signal by announcing the dispatch of 16,000 additional troops, doubling the British contingent.
Mr. Heseltine once served Mrs. Thatcher as Defense Secretary. Mr. Hurd is Foreign Secretary, and Mr. Major served in that post before taking control of economic policy as Chancellor of the Exchequer. All are tough-minded Conservatives.
On the opposition side, Mr. Kinnock has steered the Labor Party away from its flirtation with unilateral nuclear disarmament, winning the respect of Washington. Labor has also shed its enthusiasm for nationalizations. That reflects Mr. Kinnock's own views, but it is also a tribute to the intellectual revolution Mrs. Thatcher brought.
Policy changes are far more likely on the two issues that brought Mrs. Thatcher down: the degree of Britain's integration into the European Community, and the unpopular and regressive poll tax introduced earlier this year. While taxation is a purely domestic concern, America can only welcome a turn away from Mrs. Thatcher's Little England nationalism, which so divided her from her Tory colleagues.
Convinced that her West European partners schemed to ensnare free-market Britain in a morass of crypto-socialist regulation, she acted as if Britain were still an economic superpower, able to make its way in the world entirely on its own. This stubbornness threatened to undermine her greatest achievement: convincing Britain's private-sector entrepreneurs that they could no longer live off past glories and must adapt to competitive realities.
Margaret Thatcher's special strength was to marry ideological commitment to political realism, as in her early appreciation of how Mikhail Gorbachev's policies overturned cold war orthodoxies. Britons rewarded these qualities with three consecutive general election victories, giving her the longest lease on office since universal suffrage began. She was more than a political phenomenon. She wrought the kind of changes that warrant whole new chapters in history books.
Had she not strayed from her political instincts in blind pursuit of the chimerical Little England, she might indeed have gone "on and on." In the end, Mrs. Thatcher regained her balance. She bowed to the inevitable, still a winner, proud of her eleven-and-a-half-year record -- and justly so.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Park Avenue Lady

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
On a fine autumn morning in New York, just before Thanksgiving, when the streets were full of handsomely dressed people off to work, a gray-haired woman about 60 years old stepped off the curb at Park Avenue and 67th Street, raised her dress, bared herself, and defecated in the gutter.
I did what everybody else did. I turned my head in disgust and walked away toward the office. But that morning I found it a little harder to walk away from the mentally ill of the city. 
 A demented man was stretched on his back, near Madison Avenue, eight blocks south of the woman in the Park Avenue gutter, shouting out loud to the demons of his mind. A mile on, a few steps away from the office, a woman lay in a doorway as she does every day, in filth of body and pain of mind. She clutched the bottle of liquor almost never out of hand -- the gift of death by poison that passers-by give to her with their coins.
About 15,000 mentally ill people live on New York streets -- almost one-third of the homeless. But this is not one more New York horror story. I have seen the Park Avenue lady and the raw faced woman in the doorway in Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Houston, Miami. If you travel America, try getting away from the homeless mentally ill -- try.
How did we get to this point, where Americans calmly accept the fact that we cannot deal decently with scores of thousands of destitute Americans who suffer so desperately in their minds that they cry their pain in the streets, where we send them to live? When and why did this country accept madness in the streets as part of the city scenery, turn its back on the deeply disturbed, unless they happened to defecate in front of our delicate eyes? In the mid-50's, there were more than 550,000 patients in American public mental health hospitals. Now there are about 100,000.
The public saw the mental hospitals as snake pits. Some were, and some were not, but closing them was supposed to save the states a nice pile of tax money. A little later, tranquilizer drugs speeded the emptying of the wards. But on the streets, without care or attention, the mentally disturbed did not take the drugs, and regressed rapidly.
The idea was to give the mentally ill post-hospital care in halfway houses or community centers. Officials and taxpayers never came up with enough money. When the hospitals closed, the mentally ill poor went into the street. That helped push at least a third of them into even more nightmare worlds -- alcoholism and drug addiction.
They found friends -- organizations and individuals who try to help them get off the streets. But God help them, they also found some "advocates" who insist that living on the sidewalk month in month out, freezing or baking, the prey of human street rats, eating garbage, and refusing treatment or even food and shelter is an acceptable alternative life style. As long as they do not commit a serious crime -- not just the misdemeanor of befouling private or public property -- they have the right to live in the streets and the right to die there.
Some advocates argue that there is no such thing as mental illness, just another way of looking at reality. Maybe they are right. Is what we have come to accept really sanity -- that mental illness is a right to be exercised to the point of suicide rather than a disease demanding medical care for the victim?
Is it sanity to say that if you are bleeding from a car accident an ambulance will take you away, but if you are bleeding from the mind you can lie there until you rot?
Is caring for people too sick to know they need care truly a violation of their freedom?
It is a disservice to all the homeless to lump their problems together. That makes homelessness seem unsolvable, when it is not.
The economically destitute homeless need economic help -- and can respond to it as full members of society, not some murky, psychically troubled mysterious underclass.
The addicts or mentally disturbed -- estimated at 70 percent of the homeless -- need a range of treatments if they are to escape the streets into decent housing. Is it beyond the American legal and medical mind to provide that help, even to those who do not grasp that they need it?
If we won't put enough taxes -- yes, taxes -- or attention into doing the job, let's have the honesty not to blame the Governor or Mayor. Let's just shut up, keep on walking away from the lady on Park Avenue, and enjoy our next Thanksgiving.

HEADLINE: Of Small Farms and Sacred Cows

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BROHL-LUTZING, Germany

 BODY:
On his 75-acre family farm tucked away in the rocky hills some 20 miles southeast of Bonn, Alfons Schmitz tends his 20 dairy cows, grows a small crop of wheat and watches with deep concern the bitter dispute between the United States and the European Community over farm subsidies.
The issue of cutting the generous government subsidies paid to Europe's mainly small, inefficient farmers has deadlocked the final talks in the four-year round of negotiations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which regulates global commerce. And the political power of people like Mr. Schmitz is the main obstacle. 
 Europe's 9.7 million farmers -- nearly triple the number in the United States -- are not only numerous but also politically well organized. So while high farm subsidies raise food prices and dampen economic growth, the prospect of making deep cuts in agricultural payments is anathema to most European leaders.
In Germany, the nation's 682,000 farmers and 1.69 million agricultural workers are a potent political force. Like Mr. Schmitz, they are nearly all supporters of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party, the Christian Democratic Union.
 
 Meeting in Brussels
 "I don't belong to the C.D.U., but I vote for it," Mr. Schmitz said. "It's the tradition of the farmers."
Moreover, the country's agricultural politics have been complicated by the unification of the two Germanys, bringing in an additional 959,900 agricultural workers on 3,844 state farms in what used to be East Germany. Maintaining high subsidies, political analysts say, could be a way for the Christian Democrats to expand their farm constituency.
In the trade talks, the United States, Australia and other efficient agricultural producers are advocating deep cuts in both price supports and export subsidies, which would drastically reduce the payments the European Community makes to its farmers. For their part, the Europeans have countered by offering more modest reductions in price supports but no cuts in export subsidies.
Trade ministers from 100 member countries will meet in Brussels at the end of this month to try to find a solution to the long-running farm dispute. If they succeed, the agreement would then open the way for the GATT to be significantly expanded to liberalize trade in new fields, such as financial services and intellectual property.
In the view of Mr. Schmitz, a lean 29-year-old with the heavily muscled forearms of dairy farmers the world over, the American proposal to slash price-support levels by 75 percent over the next decade and export subsidies by 90 percent is unrealistically draconian. Even the European Community's counterproposal to trim price supports by another 15 percent in the next five years, he says, might drive him off the farm his grandfather bought in 1926.
 
 Average Income of $21,963
 "I won't be able to cover my costs," Mr. Schmitz said. "It wouldn't be worth it to farm, and I would have to give up and find some other line of work."
Although European price supports have been trimmed gradually in recent years, they are still high by world standards. For example, the current guaranteed price for milk is $16.87 per hundredweight in the community, compared with $10.10 in the United States. For corn, the community-guaranteed price is $5.85 a bushel versus $2.75 in America. For soybeans, the European guaranteed price is $17 a bushel against $4.92 in America.
Yet the subsidies in Europe have declined, crimping farm incomes. A spokesman for the German Agricultural Ministry said the average German small farmer, working without hired help, earned $21,963 in the 1988-89 fiscal year ended last June. This fiscal year the average will be about $19,727.
Mr. Schmitz refused to say how much he made from the farm last year, but expects to make less this year.
The Schmitz farm is about averge size for Germany, where 95 percent of the farms are less than 120 acres. The Schmitz farmhouse and barns form a courtyard on a narrow street on the village outskirts, while the acreage is outside of town. About half the land is pasture, with the remainder planted in wheat, corn and mixed grains. His herd produces 10,560 pounds, or 292,000 liters, of milk a year.
 
 Insurance and Pension Payments
 The milk is picked up every two days and taken to a dairy in the city of Koblenz. Some of it is then shipped to Italy and sold. Wheat is Mr. Schmitz's other cash crop, and it is sold to grain dealers who resell it. The corn and mixed grains are used exclusively as fodder for his livestock.
Like most German farmers, Mr. Schmitz does not know precisely how much of his income comes from subsidies paid by the European Community through the auspices of the German Government. Though prices can fluctuate somewhat according to changes in supply and demand, the Government maintains minimum prices on agricultural products, typically administered through food wholesalers. In addition, the German Government pays $10 billion a year for farmers' insurance and pension programs.
The various proposals for cutting farm payments in the GATT talks would appear to have a greater impact on Mr. Schmitz's wheat crop than on his milk production. Mr. Schmitz raises about 20 acres of wheat, producing roughly one ton a year.
The European Community offers its farmers one of the largest grain subsidies in the world, so they would be hard hit by big cutbacks. The community pays a subsidy of about $120 on a ton of wheat, which sells for about $77 on the world market. Such practices put developing nations and countries that cannot afford to pay subsidies to their farmers, like Argentina, at a huge competitive disadvantage. Argentina is selling its wheat for $71.50 a ton.
 
 'A Dangerous Strategy'
 American wheat sold on the world market is also subsidized, but at far lower levels than in Europe. United States wheat currently sells for $77 a ton, with the Government paying $41 a ton in subsidy through the Export Enhancement Program.
Secretary of Agriculture Clayton K. Yeutter says that the European Community, as the most generous in its price supports and export subsidies, is distorting agricultural policy worldwide by, in effect, undercutting prices in the United States and developing countries. "What we are attempting to do in GATT is achieve significant reforms that are long overdue," Mr. Yeutter said last week.
Both Mr. Yeutter and Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said that failing to reach a solution to the agricultural impasse could endanger progress toward liberalizing world trade and warned that Europeans may be underestimating the American resolve to hold out for large cutbacks.
"I've gotten the feeling that in Europe people believe that at the end of the day we'll blink and they won't have to come off their position on subsidies or only nominally," Mr. Yeutter said. "That's a dangerous strategy doomed to be proven incorrect."
 
 14-Hour Days and Cutting Wood
 Reducing overall tariff and non-tariff barriers by one-third, as the United States has proposed, would make the global economy grow by $4 trillion over the next decade, Mrs. Hills said, with the European Community economy growing by an additional $1 trillion. Reducing farm payments should also benefit European consumers, who pay more for their food. For example, the retail price of a gallon of milk is about $3.20, compared with just under $2.50 a gallon in the United States.
Though supported by subsidies, Mr. Schmitz still works 14-hour days. The home he shares with his parents is heated by a wood-burning stove, and he cuts his own wood. It is, he says, a life he loves. Still, he seems reconciled to giving it up eventually.
"If they pay me a direct subsidy to not plant or produce, that would be all right," he said. "I just can't afford to lose any more income. And I'm willing to listen to alternative crop schemes and all that. But I don't have any illusions. What comes probably won't be any improvement. I'd just like to have a healthy departure from it, if I could."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The current round of global trade talks is stalled by a dispute over farm subsidies. Alfons Schmitz, a German dairy farmer, is part of the agricultural constituency that makes the issue of farm subsidies a political concern, rather than an economic matter, for German leaders. (Ferdinand Protzman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Bond Prices Down in Slow Day

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury securities declined moderately in thin trading yesterday, largely in reaction to another sharp rise in crude oil prices, to $31.90 a barrel. But the shorter Treasury maturities, which are less influenced by inflation fears and pressures, were basically unchanged.
Many market participants extended their Thanksgiving holiday, rather that take part in a shortened trading session. The Treasury market closed at 2 P.M. Also, the important Tokyo market in United States debt issues was closed for Japan's annual Labor-Thanksgiving Day national holiday. 
 As it was, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, were offered at 103 11/32, down 8/32, or $2.50 for each $1,000 of face value. The long bond's yield thus rose to 8.43 percent, from 8.41 percent at Wednesday's close, but was one basis point below last Friday's 8.44 percent.
 
 Down About 25 Basis Points
 The yield on the bellwether long bonds has declined about 25 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, in the last month, mainly on the belief that the nation was in or about to enter a recession that would depress interest rates generally.
"We may already be in a recession, but it will be a mild and brief one," said Eugene J. Sherman, senior vice president and chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Board of New York. "Consequently, we don't see interest rates going into a free fall. In fact, we expect the recession to bottom out in the first quarter of 1991 and the economy to turn upward by late spring. Bond investors who expect the inflation rate to decline below current levels will also be disappointed."
Given this assessment, Mr. Sherman said he doubted that the yield on the long bond would fall below 8 percent because "the brevity and shallowness of the recession will not allow much slack to develop in the economy."
 
 Stimulation of Exports Seen
 One reason he believes the recession will be brief is that he expects the dollar's weakness to stimulate exports further and to reduce imports. Moreover, the deepening Federal budget deficit, even without a shooting war in the Persian Gulf, will prevent any significant decline in inflation for the foreseeable future, he added.
Meanwhile, the closely watched Treasury long notes, the 8.5 percent issue of November 2000, lost 5/32, at 101 16/32, for a yield of 8.27 percent. The long notes are often compared for investment purposes with 10-year Japanese and German "long bonds."
While the yield on the Treasury's long notes dipped to 8.27 percent from 8.29 percent since the previous Friday, the yield on the similar Japanese maturity dropped to 7.47 percent from 7.76 percent, while that on the same German bond maturity fell to 8.79 percent from 8.89 percent during the week.
 
 Bill Rates Unchanged
 At the short end of the Treaury market, the discount rate on 90-day bills was unchanged at 7.03 percent. The six-month bills were also unchanged at 6.98 percent. But the one-year bills rose a basis point, to 6.79 percent.
Dealers said the bill rates reflected in large part the steady Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans. The funds closed at 7.5 percent after trading at that level for most of the session. Many credit market analysts now view 7.5 percent as the Federal Reserve's new target level for this key interest rate. The Fed, meanwhile, was absent from the market, having apparently supplied reserves to the banking system on Wednesday that would be ample through the holiday weekend.
On Tuesday, the Treasury plans to auction $12.3 billion of new two-year notes, and $9 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday. The two-year notes traded on a when-issued basis to yield 7.47 percent, down from 7.51 percent last Wednesday. The yield on the five-year notes was unchanged at 7.90 percent.

HEADLINE: Women's Push Into Work Force Seems to Have Reached Plateau

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Although women seem as committed as ever to holding jobs, they are no longer piling into the labor force as rapidly as they did in the 1970's and 1980's.
The change of pace, which is just beginning to show up in Labor Department data, suggests that the number of women working or job-hunting is being held down by such developments as the incipient national recession and a rising number of births, which are keeping many new mothers temporarily at home. 
 Some economists and sociologists contend that women, as a group, might be approaching the upper limit of participation in the work force, one imposed by a society that gives women primary responsibility for children yet does not furnish adequate child care. Most of these experts agree that the ceiling, if it indeed exists, will rise again, perhaps by the end of the decade, if the child-care barrier and other issues are resolved.
"The pattern is changing; the rip-roaring increases in labor participation among women have indeed finally leveled off," said Thomas Plewes, an associate commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. "Is this permanent? Our best thinking would say that it is not. Women in the labor force behave more like their fathers than their mothers."
The milder growth rate might have a silver lining, perhaps helping to reverse a 20-year trend in which the median incomes of all workers have failed to keep up with inflation. "If women enter the work force in smaller numbers, labor could become a scarcer commodity, one that can't be thrown away or underpriced so easily," said Frank Levy, a University of Maryland labor economist who specializes in income trends.
 
Rate Holds Steady

 
For nearly two years, the percentage of all of the nation's working-age women actually in the labor force, that is, the women holding jobs or actively seeking them, has leveled off at around 57.7 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports. Not since the early 1970's has the rate held steady for so long. By comparison, 75.6 percent of working-age men are in the labor force.
While the participation rate of men has been dropping very gradually, that of women has climbed sharply since 1960, when it was about 37 percent.
More significant than the overall figure, the labor participation rates for women in the two largest age groups -- 25 to 34 years old and 35 to 44 -- have risen since 1986 at a much slower pace than in the previous 10 years. In the 25-to-34 age group, for example, the participation rate is 73.1 percent as of last month, an increase of only two percentage points since October 1985. In contrast, the rate jumped 5.6 percentage points from 1981 through 1985, and 9.8 points in the late 1970's.
Labor economists and sociologists say the recent trends in women's participation in the labor force have not yet been sufficiently studied to identify precisely the forces at work. But in more than a dozen interviews and in a review of the data several major themes emerge.
 
 Slump in the Service Sector
 One is that the slowdown in the American economy is hitting hardest at industries in which women are heavily represented, including service businesses like financial services and retailing. That is a contrast to recessions in the early 1980's and mid-1970's, which decimated manufacturing, with its concentration of blue-collar male workers. Now, women losing their jobs might be staying home for a while rather than searching for scarce jobs, economists say.
Young women are also dragging down the participation rate, especially those below 24 years of age. In the 20-to-24-year-old group, the percentage of women in the labor market has actually declined, to 71.8 percent last month from a high of nearly 73 percent in 1985.
Rising college enrollment helps explain the absence of these women from the labor force. So does low pay, often less than $8 an hour for the less educated. These women frequently make ends meet by living with parents or they enter the labor force only sporadically, economists say.
Young black women in particular have much lower participation rates than white women under 24. In addition, Hispanic women of all ages, many of them first-generation immigrants, also have much lower participation rates than white women. Many Hispanic women prefer to be homemakers, sociologists say.
 
 Birth Rate Soars
 The sudden rise in birth rates might be the most important factor of all. Married women in their 30's and early 40's, women who delayed having children while they established their careers, are now having children. At the same time married women in their late 20's are also having children, rather than delaying parenthood as their older colleagues often did.
"The younger women are going ahead with motherhood even if it means giving up the extra income for a while and facing a declining standard of living," said Katherine Newman, a Columbia University anthropologist who is studying the phenomenon in a middle-class New Jersey community near New York City that she declined to name.
More than four million children were born in the United States last year and more than 4.1 million births are likely this year, the Census Bureau estimates. Those are the highest numbers since 1964, the last year in which baby boomers were born. And it seems to mean that more women are taking time out for childbirth and child-rearing.
Labor Department data are not clear on this point, mostly because information for 1989 and 1990 is not yet available for the crucial age groups involved. But participation rates for married women of all ages living with their husbands -- a group that represents more than 30 million of the nearly 58 million women in the nation's labor force -- shed some light on what is happening. Fewer than 60 percent of these women with children under age 6 are in the labor force. But three-quarters of those with older children either work or seek work. And the labor force participation rate of all women -- married or not -- with children under 1 year of age, which rose with great speed in the 1980's, has stagnated at 52 percent since 1987.
 
 Perceptions About Roles
 The pressure to stay home with young children is often self-imposed, according to Ms. Newman's findings in her study of 160 men and women in the New Jersey community -- half 1970 graduates of the local high school and half 1980 graduates. All are old enough to have been raised, for the most part, by mothers who were homemakers.
"The model of their mothers exerts a considerable pull on them," Ms. Newman said. "But I want to emphasize that dropping out of the labor force is not without regrets. The whole issue is filled with tension. Women are held responsible for the intellectual development of their children, and they don't want to be blamed for messing it up. But while the urgency to have families is chafing at them, they also want a certain standard of living. They worry about making the mortgage payments, and the husbands of women in their 20's want the second income."
The pressure to raise young children in person helps to explain why the labor participation rates of American women, while among the highest in the industrial world, are still well below those of Sweden, where child care is publicly financed, the Government encourages women to work and the participation rates are nearly equal to those of men.
In Sweden, for example, more than 90 percent of women 25 to 54 years old are in the labor force, compared with only 74 percent in this country. That leads some American experts to the conclusion that a Government-financed child-care system of the sort that is widely accepted by the Swedish public would free more American women to participate in the work force.
Child-care centers have multiplied in the United States in the last decade and Census Bureau surveys show their average cost to be less than 10 percent of a working mother's income, says Heidi Hartman, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research.
"But certainly, if we had publicly financed child care and national quality control, women would be able to play a greater role in the labor force," she said.

HEADLINE: Japanese Portables Threaten American Lead in Computers

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
It happened in cars and in office copiers. Now the computer industry, a star of the American economy, is being threatened by a new wave of small Japanese products.
In the last two years, lightweight portable computers have become the fastest-growing part of the computer business. And as the machines get smaller and smaller, the Japanese have used their expertise in miniaturizing computer electronics to strengthen their foothold, industry executives and analysts say. 
 "What is happening is a new kind of product coming into the industry: high-volume consumer computers," said Andrew S. Grove, president and chief executive of the Intel Corporation, which makes the microprocessors that serve as the brains of most personal computers. "As this hits, the center of gravity of the industry will move to Japan."
 
'Heading Into Trouble'
 The American computer industry, he added, is "heading into trouble."
But others say the American computer industry still leads the world by far and continues to innovate. They add that earlier warnings about Japanese gains in the computer market proved unfounded.
Portable computers include laptops, which weigh up to 17 pounds and can be carried around and propped up on the lap for typing, and notebook computers, which weigh four to seven pounds. In addition, industry experts say, entirely new kinds of small computers are coming to market, including tiny "palmtop" computers that weigh one to three pounds and mobile message-sending computers that communicate by radio. Additional uses of computers might result from yet another new class of small machines that recognize handwriting and are operated by writing with a stylus instead of typing on a keyboard.
 
Growth Predicted for Portables
 Nearly 40 percent of personal computers sold in the world in 1994 will be portable machines, compared with only 14 percent now, predicts Dataquest, a market research concern based in San Jose, Calif. Japanese companies, which have only a 9 percent market share in the American personal computer market over all, sell about 40 percent of the portable computers, according to market research firms. The figure represents only the machines with Japanese brand names.
Japanese companies have not been successful to date in the American personal computer market because they have had trouble keeping up with rapid changes in the industry and have lacked strong distribution and software. While they have not sold many complete machines, Japanese companies have instead become major suppliers of components needed to make a computer, including memory chips, floppy disk drives, monitors and printers. The insides of laser printers come from Japanese copier makers.
 
 Designing and Manufacturing
 But with laptop computers, Japanese companies are moving from parts suppliers to co-designers and manufacturers of complete machines. Experience in making calculators, watches, television sets and Walkman stereos have given Japanese companies expertise in miniaturization and the ability to build the flat screens used in portable laptop and notebook computers.
"If you want to dance in the laptop market, you need a Japanese partner," said Bruce Stephen, an analyst with the International Data Corporation, a market research company.
The latest evidence of this idea is that Apple Computer Inc., which has designed and built all its own computers, is now talking to two Japanese companies, the Sony Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation, about having them build small lightweight versions of Apple's Macintosh.
The Compaq Computer Corporation turned to the Citizen Watch Company of Tokyo for help in building its LTE machines, six-pound notebook computers that have been a hit. Citizen and Compaq jointly designed the machine, and Citizen manufactures machines for sale outside the United States.
 
American-Japanese Partners
 The Tandy Corporation, a maker of personal computers, gets most of its laptop computers from the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, known for its Panasonic brand. The Zenith Data Systems Corporation, a unit of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, teamed with the Sanyo Electric Company for its laptop computers, although its notebook machine, which is even smaller, is made in Taiwan. Texas Instruments Inc. developed its new notebook computer with help from the Sharp Corporation.
Toshiba and the NEC Corporation, which had little success before in the American personal computer market, are among the leaders in laptops under their own brand names.
Gains by Japanese companies in the market for portable computers are worrying some United States executives. In a stark speech to a ballroom full of semiconductor industry executives recently, Dr. Grove said Silicon Valley was becoming "technologically irrelevant" and predicted that the market share of Japanese companies in the worldwide data processing industry would be greater than that of American companies by 1992.
Such a reversal of market shares would come not only through laptop computers but also in giant mainframe computers, a market long controlled by the International Business Machines Corporation in which Japanese companies are also making strides.
 
Scoffed at by Many
 Many computer industry executives and analysts scoff at such dire predictions. In certain crucial areas, including software, computer design and computer chip design, American companies are unmatched, they say.
The trend lines shown by Dr. Grove and others are "somewhat accurate," said Ken Kay, executive director of the Computer Systems Policy Project, a new lobbying group formed by the nation's largest computer companies. But he added that American computer executives did not see themselves losing ground as quickly as Dr. Grove does.
American companies still had a 61 percent share of world sales of computer systems in 1989, compared with 22 percent for Japanese companies, according to the lobbying group. Nevertheless, since 1983, the American share dropped from 81 percent while the Japanese share nearly tripled, from 8 percent.
 
Best Opportunity Yet
 Despite disagreements on the size of the threat, most executives agree that the trend toward miniature computers gives the Japanese companies their best opportunity yet. "Certainly they are going to have a much stronger presence in this decade than they did in the last decade because of the shift to laptops," said John V. Roach, chief executive of Tandy.
One reason Japanese companies excel at laptops is that Japan's cramped offices require smaller machines, so Japanese manufacturers have tended to concentrate on them more than American manufacturers have. In addition, laptop computers are usually used in isolation from other computers. In systems with machines connected together in large complex networks, American companies still lead.
But the main reasons are the expertise in miniaturization and the fact that Japanese companies are the leading suppliers of flat liquid crystal display screens, which can account for 25 percent of the cost of a notebook computer. Liquid crystals make up the technology used in many digital watches, calculators and pocket television sets.
 
'Dumping' Accusations Made
 Some small American companies are trying to make flat screens but have had trouble keeping up with the huge investments made by the Japanese. Eight American companies recently accused Japanese makers of flat screens of "dumping," selling their screens at unfairly low prices to drive out competition.
The case of portable computers seems to support those executives who have been arguing that the nation needs to develop high-definition television and other consumer electronics products or risk the erosion of its computer industry. "The loss of consumer electronics in the 70's is coming back to haunt us," Dr. Grove said.
Still, some executives say, previous predictions of Japanese assaults have proved groundless. "I heard the same thing a few years ago," said Andrew Czernek, vice president of product strategy and development at Zenith Data Systems.
 
Reference to Early 1980's
 He was referring to the early 1980's, after the personal computer industry standardized around the design selected by I.B.M. It was feared that the establishment of a standard would free companies to compete strictly on price and the Japanese would win.
But the Japanese had little success. Rather, manufacturers from Taiwan and South Korea penetrated the market with low-priced clones. But the American computer companies still set the directions for the industry.
There is also the prospect that American companies could take back some of the manufacturing of miniature computers. Apple Computer executives have already said the company will design and manufacture some of its own small computers. In a reversal of roles, Tandy recently arranged to supply one model of a laptop computer to Matsushita. And Sharp is selling a notebook computer made by Texas Instruments.
 
Others Entering Business
 Other companies are also entering the business. At the Comdex trade show in Las Vegas, Nev., this month, numerous American, Korean and Taiwanese notebook computers were introduced, presenting a new threat to Japanese companies already in the market.
AST Research Inc., a successful maker of personal computers in Irvine, Calif., and the Airis Computer Corporation, a Chicago start-up company, are among the newcomers introducing laptop computers they will make themselves. Officials of both companies said they considered a Japanese partner but concluded that a partner would offer nothing they could not do themselves.
The pessimists say American computers are becoming merely packaging for Japanese components. Dr. Grove estimated that Japanese components represented about 20 percent of the bill for parts of the original Apple II computer, introduced in 1977. The Next Inc. computer, introduced in 1988, had about 70 percent Japanese parts, he said.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops by 12.13; Week's Loss Is 23.02

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
In a post-Thanksgiving Day session marked by a morning power interruption, trading on the New York Stock Exchange fell yesterday to its lowest point since the day after Christmas in 1986.
Stock prices sagged toward the close, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 12.13 points. 
 Volume reached only 63.35 million shares, compared with 48.86 million on Dec. 26, 1986. A traditionally sleepy post-holiday session, when many traders take an additional day off, was made weaker by the morning power failure, which lasted from 9:41 to 11:15 A.M.
 
 Analysts Divided on Meaning
 The Dow industrials closed at 2,527.23, bringing the loss in the holiday-shortened week to 23.02 points. Analysts were divided on what the decline meant. Some said the loss marked the end of what many have called a bear market rally, which began in mid-October and which would now be replaced by the bear itself. Others saw the poor showing as a pause before a traditional year-end rise takes hold.
Yesterday's broader market was a bit lower. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks closed off by 0.93 point at 315.10. Declining issues outnumbered advancing stocks by 680 to 650.
When the market resumed trading after the power failure, it showed good gains and tried to take a cue from its soaring British cousin. In London, stocks shot ahead on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's decision to step down, with the hope that a successor would cut interest rates and open economic opportunities with Europe. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index jumped 42.6 points, to 2,170.5, a gain of 2 percent for the London market.
 
 Oil 'Clipped the Market'
 "Against the background of a traditional light day, the British market could have added a pop," said Tracy G. Herrick, an economist with Jefferies & Company in San Francisco. "There was not much to counter a strong thrust. But the carrythrough never went anywhere, as oil moved up a bit, and that clipped the market."
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price of crude oil for January delivery surged $2.27, to $31.90 a barrel. The move put pressure on the stock and bond markets over all. But some energy issues moved higher, including Texaco, up 1/8, to 57 1/8; Exxon, up 3/8, to 51 1/8, and Amoco, up 1/8, to 52.
Although the British market failed to push the New York market higher, individual British issues trading here were sparklers. British Gas added 2 5/8 at 47 3/8 and Imperial Chemical Industries rose 2, to 71. British Telecom added 1 5/8, to 57 1/8, and British Petroleum rose by 11, to 79 5/8.
Looking ahead, Mr. Herrick of Jefferies was not optimistic for market prospects next week. "I think bonds are going to call the tune," he said. "Utilities have not been doing that well, signaling to me that the bond rally is running out of gas, and the stock market could be in for a slower period."
 
 Disappointment on MCA
 MCA was the second-most-active Big Board stock, trading more than 1.6 million shares and losing 3 1/8 at 65 3/8. Traders were said to be disappointed at the range, between $70 and $75 a share, that Matsushita Electric was reported to be discussing as an acquisition price for MCA.
I.B.M. showed weakness, losing 1 1/2 points at 112 5/8. But NCR rose a point, to 54 3/4.
Caterpillar lost 3 points at 39 3/8, and was among the most active stocks. Goldman, Sachs reduced its earnings estimate for the company.
Square D, a maker of electric goods whose stock has been up recently on takeover speculation, rose an additional 2 1/2, to 54 3/4.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Yugoslav Merger Planned by SPI

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: COSTA MESA, Calif., Nov. 23

 BODY:
Yugoslavia's largest pharmaceutical company has agreed to merge with the California-based SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc. in one of the biggest East-West transactions in Yugoslavia since World War II.
Under the agreement, which was announced on Thursday in Belgrade, the assets of Galenika Pharmaceuticals will be transferred to a new joint company, to be called ICN Galenika. The combined company is expected to have annual sales of $370 million. 
 SPI will own 75 percent of the new company and Galenika will own 25 percent, according to company officials. SPI is based in Costa Mesa and is an 89 percent owned subsidiary of ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc.
The transaction will provide Galenika with capital to modernize equipment and improve its international marketing position, the company said.
Galenika is the largest manufacturer of pharmaceutical and chemical products in Yugoslavia and serves markets throughout Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Owned by the Yugoslav Government, Galenika expects sales of about $230 million this year and employs 5,800 workers. SPI has estimated 1990 sales of $140 million.
"We expect significant marketing synergies to occur from the consolidation of our businesses," said Milan Panic, chairman and chief executive of SPI and its parent, ICN.
The merger agreement is subject to final approval by the Federal Secretariat for External Economic Relations of Yugoslavia and the boards of SPI, its parent and Galenika.
The consolidation was made possible by changes in Yugoslav law in late 1988 permitting privatization of Government-owned businesses, SPI said.
Mr. Panic has been trying to expand ICN into Europe while reducing the debt it took on in the mid-1980's to make acquisitions.
The shares of the company are far from their peak in the $30's during the height of speculation over an AIDS drug it promoted in 1986 and 1987. The stock rose 62.5 cents today, to $3.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its gain of 19.2 percent was the second best of the day.
Late last year, after three years of disagreements with Federal officials over the results of its clinical tests, ICN abandoned efforts to win Government approval to market its anti-viral drug, ribavirin, as an AIDS treatment. The company took a $71 million write-off on its investment.

HEADLINE: Outplacement Business Is Almost Too Good

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
"The key to the whole process," the counselor at Fuchs, Cuthrell & Company, a New York City outplacement service, was saying brightly, "is learning how to market yourself -- just like positioning a product."
But in the world of outplacement, the corporate casualty ward for executives and middle managers who have lost their jobs, the merchandise is not moving the way it once did. 
 Dismissals and layoffs have swelled the ranks of unemployed executives in New York and other Northeast cities this autumn: more than 50,000 jobs have disappeared on Wall Street since 1987, and tens of thousands more white-collar workers have been laid off this year. The companies that specialize in helping the jobless seek new positions have a backlog.
 
Hand-Holding in Nervous Times
 It makes for nervous times behind the placid facades of these companies, which shun attention as studiously as does a safe house for spies.
About 20 companies in New York offer such services, usually for a fee of 15 percent of a year's salary. Outplacement is part of the severance package many large companies offer executives. By providing a small office, shared secretarial help, expertiseand a lot of hand-holding, outplacement executives say they increase the chances that someone looking for a job will be hired before severance pay runs out.
In this cramped new world, the out-of-work rewrite resumes, mail queries with opening lines like "My plan to pursue a new, more challenging position is prompting me to write. . . ," trade gossip and sometimes curses about their former bosses, keep their chins up and root for the day when they make a successful "landing."
"Losing a job is a kick in the gut and a blow to the ego," said Eva Grzelak, 38 years old, who lost a position in June as vice president of international marketing for a Wall Street company. "Being in outplacement is good for the morale because you talk every day with others in the same boat and understand they're fine, competent people, so you can't be so bad just because you lost your job."
Friendships are made and contacts are shared. When months drag by with no landing in sight, self-doubt becomes the enemy and self-improvement takes over. Under prodding from counselors and psychologists, the job seekers may shave a beard or dip into savings to freshen a wardrobe. Nearly everyone who needs to loses weight.
Deprived of personal secretaries, many job seekers are forced into unfamiliar acts, like placing their own business calls.
"I now know what it's like to be on the other end of the phone waiting for someone to pick up," said Marilyn Jerome, who was a marketing officer for a New York soft drinks and distilled spirits company until she was let go in January. "And when they finally come on the line, the first thing they ask is what company do you work for. Eeek!"
 
The Old Arrogant Days
 For many of the two dozen men and women interviewed at outplacement services recently, there is rue for their old arrogant days.
"I reflect back on the thousands of resumes that used to come across my desk and I never opened," said Jim C., who resigned under pressure as vice president of sales for a domestic apparel manufacturer last spring and who spoke on the condition that his identity not be fully disclosed.
"I won't do that again even if I have to answer every one myself," the 47-year-old Westchester man vowed. Last week, with the assistance of the Right Associates outplacement company in New York, which has 74 offices nationally and abroad, he was hired by another manufacturer at a higher salary than at his last job.
Andy B., who was dismissed in September as director of marketing communications for what he described as "a prestigious insurance company that used to boast they never let anyone go, even in the depths of the Depression," was happy about Jim C.'s new job, but sad to see him leave the partitioned cubicle they had shared. They had covered each other's telephone calls, gone to lunch together and and even swapped recipes.
 
Like the Stages of Grief
 "When we went out on interviews, we'd check each other out," said Andy B., 44, a bluff amiable man with a raucous sense of humor. "I'd brush off the back of his jacket or tell him he had a loose string on his collar. I would've been embarrassed before to ever tell a man that."
That protectiveness extended to others in the office who "haven't gotten their heads up and still can't look at themselves in the mirror," said Jim C. " 'You look down in the dumps. Let's get out of here and get a cup of coffee,' " he recalled telling others who looked depressed or sick with worry.
Nancy B. Hutter, a counselor for Fuchs, Cuthrell, said, "If someone's been with a firm for 20 years and suddenly finds himself out the door, he goes through something very much like the stages of grief. There's denial, anger and mourning over the loss of one's identity. Only then does acceptance come, and then action."
When someone lands a job, it breaks the gloom, and perhaps a few beers and a bottle of wine are passed around.
 
Don't Directly Ask for a Job
 "Personally, I'd much rather work out of home," said Dennis E. Carlton, a 43-year-old lawyer who was ousted this summer as a senior vice president with a six-figure income at a New York investment company. "But it's good stimulus to be around people landing jobs."
But then celebrators return to their cubicles, pick up the telephones and resume the dead-earnest business of networking.
"Networking is the art of talking to as many people as you can without directly asking anyone for a job," said Richard Bambrick, a 42-year-old publisher who has been out of work since September, when his electronic automotive trade magazine was folded by the parent company.
Mr. Bambrick said he considered himself "a dinosaur" because he worked with one company for 15 years, rather than switching employers to climb the corporate ladder. Now he has to scramble to make contacts outside the corporate world he inhabited.
 
Over 45? Expect a Pay Cut
 "There are a lot of executives, mostly men, who were not risk-takers, who worked at a job and not at a career, and now find themselves on the street with no network to help them," said Linda Kline, president of Kline-McKay, a small outplacement service in New York.
If they are above age 45, the prospects for finding a job at the same salary are dim in today's marketplace, she added.
Equally vulnerable is what is known in the trade as the corporate nun, a career woman who devoted herself to her company to the exclusion of everything else. Loss of employment to such a person can be shattering, experts said.
"The biggest skill these people need today is stress management," said Joseph McKay, Ms. Kline's partner. "Even if they find a new job they'll worry about losing it in today's economic climate."
 
It Takes Longer to Get Work
 In that climate, outplacement service is one of the few growth areas. But the success is double-edged.
Outplacement has traditionally been open-ended until a candidate lands a job. In the boom days of the 1980's the turnaround time between old job and new job was less than four months. In today's souring market it takes twice as long to find a job at the midmanagement level or higher. Outplacement services are struggling to house the newcomers without displacing those who have been job-hunting for more than a year.
"I suspect some firms are going to cut outplacement for midmanagement types who now expect it as a perk if they get fired," Ms. Kline speculated. "If that happens, there are going to be a lot of unhappy people working out of the basements of their homes."

HEADLINE: Fearful Auto Dealers Cut Back on Orders

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Acting on fear that a recession is beginning, American automobile dealers are cutting back orders for new vehicles, and that is leading to widespread shutdowns of assembly plants.
William Carroll, a spokesman for the Ford Motor Company, said recent retail sales had been slightly ahead of the weak sales in the 30-day period a year earlier. But they were not strong enough to encourage dealers to place more orders with the manufacturer, he said. 
 Like other business people, the dealers face a dilemma when the economic outlook is gloomy: if they cut their orders in expectation of a recession, they stifle manufacturing and other economic activity, leading to layoffs like those planned by the auto makers and raising the odds of a serious downturn. On the other hand, if they increase their orders, they may be stuck with large inventories of unsold vehicles if the economy continues to slump and buyer demand falls.
American auto dealers had a 78-day supply of cars and trucks at the end of October, well above the 60-day supply considered normal. Stocks of unsold light trucks were especially large, with dealers reporting a 99-day supply of pickups, vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles through Oct. 31. Auto makers are speculating that some buyers who had been choosing trucks for personal transportation have been switching to cars recently because they are generally more fuel-efficient.
Leon Mudry, manager of Galeana Chrysler-Plymouth in Fort Myers, Fla., said he had ordered only 30 to 40 percent of the cars and light trucks normally allocated to the dealership for November and December. Mr. Mudry said he had held new orders down to bring the dealership's inventories in line.
"We expect our sales to be 15 or 20 percent behind 1989 by the time we close out the year," Mr. Mudry said.
 
 Persian Gulf Impact
 The shutdowns fall squarely on the Big Three auto makers, which account for the vast majority of American automotive production. Most of the United States assembly plants operated by Japanese car companies are raising their output as sales of their vehicles continue to rise.
The lower demand from dealers is likely to reduce the auto makers' fourth-quarter profits, which are tied directly to the number of vehicles shipped to dealers.
The dealers' hesitation to order more cars comes as a number of economic reports portray a weakening economy. Consumers, who have been stung by higher oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, are also showing more reluctance to make big purchases while the prospect of war hangs over the Persian Gulf.
As the Christmas season approaches, hundreds of thousands of auto workers will be temporarily laid off at assembly plants, parts plants and factories operated by suppliers for the industry. But many of the workers are covered by income-protection plans in their union contracts and will be able to collect about 90 percent of their regular, straight-time pay.
The latest blow to fourth-quarter production plans was a series of plant shutdowns announced on Wednesday by the Ford Motor Company, idling six American car and truck plants. The shutdowns will result in the temporary layoffs of 12,700 workers and will cut about 23,000 vehicles from Ford's production schedule.
 
 Slow Sales of Pickups
 Scheduled to be closed for the next two weeks are the Norfolk, Va., plant that builds F-series pickup trucks, the St. Paul plant that builds compact pickup trucks and the Edison, N.J., plant that builds compact pickups. Sales of pickups have been especially hard hit by the recent sharp drop in comsumer confidence and the rise in gasoline prices.
Ford will also temporarily shut a plant in Dearborn, Mich. that builds Mustangs, and another in Wayne, Mich. that builds Escorts.
In addition, a Ford plant in Lorain, Ohio, that produces Thunderbirds and Cougars on one assembly line and Econoline vans on a second line will reduce its output to one work shift, from two, for the rest of the fiscal quarter, which ends on Dec. 21. The entire industry shuts down for two weeks at that time.
The Chrysler Corporation announced this week that it would shut down an assembly plant in Toledo, Oio, next week. About 4,700 workers will be laid off at the plant, which builds Jeep Cherokees. The Cherokee, an important money maker for Chrysler, has been hurt by the popularity of the recently introduced Ford Explorer sport-utility vehicle.
In late October, the General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, said it would idle 16 assembly plants for varying amounts of time to keep its inventory of unsold vehicles from rising. According to Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, G.M. cut its planned fourth-quarter production by 284,000 cars and trucks, to a total of 680,000, compared with 711,000 last year.
 
 Two-Week Shutdowns
 G.M. said it would extend shutdowns for two more weeks at plants in Van Nuys, Calif., where the Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird models are made, and in Fairfax, Kan., wwhere the Pontiac Grand Prix is built. Both plants were temporarily idled beginning on Nov. 5.
The two-week shutdowns will also include a G.M. plant in Wentzville, Mo. that makes full-size Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Pontiacs; two plants in Lansing, Mich., that turn out compact cars sold by Oldsmobile, Pontiac and Buick, and a truck assembly plant in Detroit. The shutdowns will result in the temporary layoffs of about 18,500 workers.
G.M. will also shut down two Canadian plants, both in Oshawa, Ontario, where it makes Chevrolet Luminas and Buick Regals. About 7,600 workers will be laid off.
