HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Asks Allies to Help Move Troops to Gulf

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The United States today appealed to European allies in Brussels for planes and ships to carry reinforcements to the Persian Gulf, American officials said.
The request was presented at North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters in Brussels by William H. Taft, the American representative to the alliance, to meet the demands of quickly transporting American troops, many of them based in Europe. 
 The American military's transportation capabilities were initially strained by President Bush's decision in August to send more than 200,000 troops to the gulf. The rapid deployment of these forces, many of them based in the United States, left the transfer of forces lagging behind schedule.
Now that Mr. Bush has decided to send more than 150,000 reinforcements, the United States is looking for allies help to insure that they get there in the next month and a half.
 
Europeans in Better Position
 Since the bulk of the additional Army troops being sent to Saudi Arabia are coming from Europe, the NATO allies are in a better position to help than before. In addition, Western European help in transporting American forces is a way for the allies to counter criticism that they are not doing their share, despite requests for help by Washington.
Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, complained in a recent report on international performance in the gulf crisis that "Europe has not fully measured up to expectations."
"The bulk of our European allies have given solid (and painless) political support, passable economic support, and mere token military support," wrote Mr. Aspin, who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee and who has generally supported the Bush Administration's decision to send huge reinforcements to the gulf and to threaten military action to evict Iraqi soldiers from Kuwait.
An American official said Washington wanted the allies to contribute planes for carrying troops; roll-on, roll-off ships that vehicles can drive on and off of, and ships to carry lubricants and high-grade refined fuels for military equipment.
 
Allies Yet to Respond
 The allies have yet to respond, and the United States plans to make more specific requests when the issue is taken up by Washington's NATO partners. Detailed arrangements would then be worked out by NATO's Civil Emergencies Preparedness Committee, a 16-member body founded to plan for wartime situations.
Mr. Cheney is going to Brussels in early December for a previously scheduled NATO meeting, which will provide another opportunity to discuss steps by Western European nations.
At the Pentagon today, Defense Seretary Dick Cheney formally gave the Army authority to extend periods of enlistments and delay retirements to keep up strength as the service builds up its forces in Saudi Arabia. Administration officials said on Wednesday that Mr. Cheney planned to take this action.
The Army said today that it would use this authority, thus preventing about 5,500 people a month from leaving the Army because of retirement or the expiration of their enlistments.
 
Training Centers to Stay Open
 In addition, the Army is stopping the transfer of soldiers deployed in Europe and other overseas posts to the United States, an action that will affect up to 1,500 people a month. The service will also keep open all training centers and military schools during the Christmas vacation period.
An Army statement said mandatory retirements, hardship cases and involuntary discharges would continue.
Mr. Bush gave the Pentagon the authority in August to stop military personnel from leaving the services when they were needed because of the American military operation in the gulf. But until today this authority was used only to retain personnel involved in the operation. The Army is the only service that has asked that the authority to retain personnel be extended to all of its personnel, regardless of whether they are involved in the gulf mission.
Under its previous, more limited authority to retain personnel, the Army had been keeping about 1,500 people a month who might have ordinarily left the service. The Marine Corps says it is planning to retain up to 12,000 active and reserve marines under that earlier authority.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Security Council Members To Discuss the Gulf Crisis

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Foreign ministers of most of the 15 members of the United Nations Security Council are expected to gather here next week to hammer out a new resolution on the Persian Gulf crisis that may still fall short of giving the Bush Administration the permission it seeks to use military force against Iraq.
The United States wants the Council to approve a new resolution authorizing military action in the gulf if Baghdad still refuses to give up Kuwait before the end of the United States' monthlong Council presidency next Friday. 
 Such a resolution, diplomats say, would allow the United States to wind up its presidency by sending Iraq's leader, President Saddam Hussein, his severest warning yet and demonstrate the continued cohesion of the international alliance Washington has assembled in the Security Council since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
But it is still unclear whether President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who have made a resolution authorizing use of force a major goal of their recent travels, have yet won sufficent backing to get their way next week, particularly from the Soviet Union and China, which as permanent Council members have a veto over all decisions.
 
A 'Very Precise Warning'
 Today the Soviet Union's United Nations Representative, Yuli M. Vorontsov, said Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze would attend next week's planned meeting in order to vote a new resolution that he insisted must send the Iraqi leader a "very strong, a very serious and very precise warning" to withdraw from Kuwait.
But he refused to say whether that resolution would also contain language permitting those countries with forces in the gulf area to use them against Baghdad if it still does not adhere to the Council's demands, as the United States wants.
"These are things being discussed by the big bosses," he said, evidently referring to the high-level contacts currently under way between the United States, the Soviet Union and other Council members.
He continued: "One thing is absolutely sure. There is need for a very strong warning. He must get out of Kuwait and we're not joking about that. This is not comedy hour in the Security Council."
 
Gorbachev Evasive on Backing
 In Moscow, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev also declined to commit Moscow specifically to supporting military action in the gulf and seemed vague about the precise purpose of the new Council meeting, which he also said he expected in the next few days.
Mr. Gorbachev told a press conference that he and President Bush agree that "the situation is not becoming simpler, but rather more complicated," adding, "It has potential for danger, very great danger."
"Time dictates that we call a meeting of the United Nations Security Council," the Soviet leader said. "The Security Council must examine everything. I do not rule out that the meeting will take place at Foreign Minister level in the next few days."
Mr. Gorbachev said the Soviet Union would take part in such a meeting "with great responsibility."
 
Requirements for Approval
 American officials say Mr. Baker, who as Council president this month would chair any ministerial-level meeting held in November, is planning to come to New York next Wednesday and stay through Friday if necessary.
The United States is urging the 15 members of the Council to approve a new resolution authorizing force before handing over the presidency to Yemen, the Council's only Arab member and a country that has sometimes sided with Iraq during the crisis.
For a new resolution to be approved, at least nine members must vote in favor and none of the five permanent members -- who also include the United States, France and Britain -- may vote against it.
But in practice, the 10 resolutions the Council has adopted so far in the crisis, impose economic sanctions on Iraq and declare its annexation of Kuwait null and void, have all been supported by at least 13 members, including all five countries with permanent seats.
 
Eluding Cuba and Yemen
 And a substantially reduced majority for a new resolution approving force would be seen as a setback for American leadership in the crisis.
An earlier plan for the Council president to issue an approved statement instead of voting a formal, binding resolution, appears to have been dropped, diplomats said.
That is because it might be even harder to get the unanimous agreement of all 15 members needed for such a presidential statement, with Cuba and Yemen resisting any text favored by the United States.
In London, the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, also told a news conference today that the Security Council would probably meet next week to discuss the new resolution that he said would sanction military action against Iraq's occupation forces in Kuwait if they do not leave.
But he emphasized that such a resolution would "not be a signal for immediate use of force but the latest of the peaceful pressures on President Saddam Hussein to get him to withdraw."
 
Foreign Ministers to Meet
 British officials say it is unclear whether Mr. Hurd would be able to attend a Council meeting next week in person because of the leadership struggle underway inside the governing Conservative Party after Margaret Thatcher's resignation as Prime Minister on Thursday. He is a declared candidate.
The French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said in Paris that he also expected to travel to New York soon to take part in Security Council discussions on a new resolution permitting military action.
But he suggested final agreement might still be several weeks away.
"The United States has already prepared a text, the Soviets are reflecting on it, France has some ideas," he said. "In three weeks we can come up with a good text."
The French Foreign Minister stressed as well that there is no automatic link between adopting the new resolution and using arms.
 
Briefing by Kuwaitis
 "When we have this instrument in our hands, the question will arise as to when it is used," he said, adding that all moves against Iraq should take place through the United Nations.
Next week's proposed Council meeting will be preceeded by another session at which Kuwait's Government-in-exile plans to brief members, and the international community at large, on attrocities committed by Iraqi's army of occupation against Kuwaitis and other citizens in the territory they have seized.
Kuwaiti diplomats said they hoped Kuwaiti refugees would appear before the Council to describe some of the violence and looting they witnessed before escaping.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. to Veto Huge Colorado Dam

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that he would veto construction of the Two Forks Dam in Colorado, a large water project sought by developers and opposed by environmentalists.
The Administrator, William K. Reilly, said in an interview that the proposed $1 billion dam, which would be the most expensive dam in American history entirely financed by a state and localities, would cause "unacceptable environmental damage." 
 The project was intended to augment long-term water supplies for Denver and surrounding communities, but Mr. Reilly said there were other, more acceptable sources of water that would not destroy valuable wetlands, wildlife areas and a scenic canyon. Mr. Reilly, who previously served as president of the Conservation Foundation and the World Wildlife Fund, two leading environmental groups, had spoken against the dam before.
 
Not the Last Word
 The veto, under a provision of the Clean Water Act, would be a milestone, but not necessarily the last word, in a decadelong struggle between Western developers and local officials, on the one hand, and and environmentalists, on the other. In previous disputes, Federal policies favored growth.
Mr. Reilly said the E.P.A.'s decision was final, but added, "We fully expect this to go into litigation." The decision can be challenged in Federal court.
It was the first major dispute in the last decade in which the Government came down on the side of environmentalists. It was not unexpected, given the environmental policies of the Bush Administration, which supported and helped enact the renewed Clean Air Act and opposed offshore oil drilling.
The dam was championed by Republican lawmakers in the West. Senator William L. Armstrong, Republican of Colorado, said that although the veto was expected "we're very disappointed, discouraged and upset."
 
No Federal Money for Project
 The proposed project was a huge one. The 615-foot dam was to have been built on the South Platte River near its confluence with its North Fork, about 25 miles southwest of Denver. The dam, as big as Hoover Dam, would flood six towns as well as much of Cheesman Canyon, a wilderness area beloved by trout fishers, hikers, campers and boaters, and would have turned the canyon into a 7,300-acre reservoir, creating the largest lake in Colorado. The project was to be financed locally, without any Federal money.
Officials in Denver and its suburbs contended that the area's population would nearly double to three million people by the year 2000, and that the dam was vital to insure the region's water supply. But local public opinion polls showed that most Denver residents were concerned about the project.
Mr. Armstrong said that without the dam other water sources would be found, and he warned that Weld County, a lush farming region, would be deprived of water it needs for agriculture to continue. "What it means is that some rather serious environmental and economic damage is likely to occur in my state," he said.
He said the population would keep growing whether or not the dam was built, and added: "What's really at stake are the lawns, parks and trees of the state. There will be plenty of water for drinking and bathing. The question is whether there will be the environmental amenities."
 
Dam Proposed in 1930's
 The dam was first proposed in the 1930's, but intense planning began only a decade ago. More than 40 units of government, including cities, towns, water districts, were involved in the planning, at a cost of $40 million.
Mr. Reilly said the decision to block the project was made by Lajuana Wilcher, the agency's assistant administrator for water.
The Reagan Administration had supported the project. Last year, the Army Corps of Engineers approved a permit to build the dam. Customarily, regional administrators make decisions for the E.P.A. on such projects, but after Jim Scherer, the regional administrator, indicated his support, Mr. Reilly initiated a review. Last August, Lee A. Dehihns 3d of the agency's Atlanta office, selected as an impartial official from outside the affected area, recommended against the project.
Mr. Dehihns said that the stretch of the South Platte flowing through the canyon was unsurpassed in the West as a natural habitat and recreation area, and that far less expensive and destructive alternatives were available.
Dams are as much a part of lore of the West as are cowboys and gold mines. Since 1884, when the first important dam was completed on the Bear Creek near San Bernardino, Calif., 37,000 dams have been built west of the Mississippi River.

HEADLINE: Throngs Brighten Retailers' Day

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Dispelling, if only temporarily, widespread forecasts of a gloomy Christmas for retailers, the 1990 holiday shopping season began in earnest yesterday, with stores around the country reporting throngs of shoppers streaming through the aisles.
In New York, Boston, Atlanta, Minneapolis, Seattle and San Francisco, heavy crowds surged through the shopping areas, filling the major stores for a good part of the day. 
 They were greeted by "sale" signs and special holiday sales promotions put up by nervous store managers reluctant to take much for granted even on what is considered the busiest shopping day of the year. In anticipation of the waves of customers, many stores threw open their doors at 8 A.M., two hours earlier than usual. The Rich's store in downtown Atlanta had its bleary-eyed sales clerks standing at their cash registers at 7:30 A.M., although as in most other stores, the turnout was thin until about 10.
Retail executives said the initial sales results were promising, but a few soberly noted that the first weekend after Thanksgiving Day was always a busy one.
In the noon hour yesterday, the main floor of Macy's Herald Square, the nation's largest single department store, was busy, as were the eighth-floor toy and china departments, but traffic was relatively light in other departments.
In 1989, Macy had a disappointing holiday period, resulting in heavy markdowns, which hurt operating profits.
"We are confident that this year's Christmas at Macy's will be successful and more typical than last year's holiday period," said Arthur Reiner, chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company's Northeast division, which includes the New York stores.
"We're doing a lot of business today," said Robert Gottlieb, senior vice president for marketing of the Jordan Marsh Company, Boston. "But we look at it a bit cautiously considering the state of the regional economy. But still, for a while this morning, you could hardly move in our flagship store at the Downtown Crossing."
 
 Atlanta Retail 'Encouraged'
 Donald Van Suilichem, senior vice president for marketing at Rich's Inc., in Atlanta, said, "We're very encouraged by the strong, early beginning and we are tracking at least as well as last year." Several hundred shoppers were outside the main store and the one at the Perimeter Mall, on the city's north side, before the stores opened, he said.
The longer view of store executives and customers on the remaining 31 shopping days was varied. Depending on the rise or fall of their own incomes this year, individuals and families out shopping yesterday said they were either buying more or less than last year.
Standing next to display cases of expensive jewelry at the Tiffany & Company store on Fifth Avenue, Kelly Panfil, who sells real estate title insurance in Naples, Fla., said that she was still just browsing. "Inflation is going up and I'm not making enough to keep up with it," she said. "Our market is dying."
 
 Lining Up at F.A.O. Schwarz
 At F.A.O. Schwarz, the toy and gifts store on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, shoppers lined up to get through the main doors and clotted the aisles inside. In the stuffed-animal section on the ground floor, Carole Zamor, a nurse from Pawtucket, R.I., said inflation and the economic downturn were throwing a shadow over her shopping plans for her two children, Riche 9 years old, Risha, 12.
In Pawtucket, she said, "homes aren't selling, factories are closing, people are moving out of state. Prices are going up and paychecks are at a standstill."
"It's as simple as that," she went on, "you can't buy what you'd like to buy. It makes it difficult on the family."
 
 The Talk Outside Macy's
 Outside the Macy's Herald Square store, Chris Stokes, a painting contractor from Bowie, Md., who was visiting New York, said, "We're buying more because my business is up and we have a long list of gifts."
Clifford Fournier, a retired medical technician from Green Bay, Wis., said, "We're buying a bigger family gift and fewer individual ones because prices are high and we are on a fixed income."
In Minneapolis, the Dayton Company's floor traffic in midmorning was so dense that "you couldn't elbow your way through the store," said Ann Barkalew, vice president for public relations of the parent Dayton Hudson Corporation. "Gift items for the home, like espresso coffee makers, children's wear and Christmas decorations" are selling the most, she said.
 
 Upbeat View at A.&S.
 At the A.&S. Plaza, John P. Hoeller, vice president and general manager of the Abraham & Straus anchor store, which opened in September 1989, said: "We actually started our holiday season on Wednesday with a 'Thanksgifting Sale.' The results of that, as well as the response today, show that our new store continues to perform above expectations."
Like many other stores, the Emporium's main San Francisco store on Market Street, between Fourth and Fifth, pulled out all the stops. The store, part of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., opened at 8 A.M. for two hours of a roof carnival and other special events designed to attract customers. It reopened for shopping at 10 A.M. The store had special departments ready, like a Holiday Express shop offering low-priced gifts like hand-massagers and fancy-design calculators, for under $25.
In Seattle, Blake Nordstrom, store manager of the Nordstrom Inc. store at Pike and Pine Streets, reported that his flagship store opened at 8 A.M. to only a small crowd. But by 9, he said, "We were awfully busy." He added, "We are very encouraged by what has happened in just the first few hours."
In New York, Peter L. Harris, president of F.A.O. Schwarz, said that "our 1 o'clock numbers are significantly ahead of last year so that shoppers appear to be buying and not just looking." The 20-store chain's catalogue sales have been strong as well, although inconsistent. "We really think we will have a very, very strong Christmas," he added, despite predictions that the toy business would suffer the same fate of lagging sales as general merchandise.
Not so sanguine was Donald E. Leftt, president of Toy Park Inc., which operates two Manhattan toy stores. He said that the widespread layoffs and business failures in the New York area could result in a poor, perhaps even the worst, season for his company since 1981.
 
 Crowded Along Fifth Avenue
 The sidewalks of Fifth Avenue were at times nearly impassable yesterday, as shoppers and tourists inched along.
Some foreign visitors seemed the most pleased with what the stores were offering. A honeymoon couple, Diego Ferro and his wife, Mercedes, both from Buenos Aires, said that they were on a buying spree during their Manhattan stay.
They had bought sheets, towels and raincoats because they were "60 percent cheaper than in our country and the quality is good."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shoppers at the A.& S. Plaza store yesterday, the first day of the Christmas shopping season, were greeted by in-store sale signs, an indication that retailers were making every effort to get the season off to a strong start. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: Florida - A Special Report;
Economists Predict Florida Can Keep Recession At Bay

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla.

 BODY:
Can Orlando's economy of hotels and amusement parks help save Florida from the apparent recession up north? Economists and business leaders here are persuaded that it can, thanks to people like Mr. and Mrs. George Seagroatt.
The Seagroatts live near Oxford, England. They brought their son and daughter-in-law and two grandchildren to spend two weeks touring Walt Disney World and the surrounding attractions. One night, all the Seagroatts went to dinner at Fort Liberty, a restaurant that advertises "hoot-hollerin' good times" in a cowboys and Indians setting. 
 The morning after, as he sat outside Disney's Epcot Center, among tourists attired in Mickey Mouse shirts and eating ice cream bars that have Mickey Mouse faces, Mr. Seagroatt noted that the dinner had cost him $64.
 
A Visitors' Center

 
"What it cost us for the meal," he said incredulously, "was what it would cost us at home for the meat. Everything's 50 percent cheaper. Food, cars, clothes, electrical goods."
Tourism isn't everything in Florida, but it dwarfs everything else around Orlando, the state's No. 1 tourist destination, and by some measures it is the state's No. 1 industry. So far, Florida tourism has suffered little of the trouble that has struck many industries in northern states. Economists expect scant growth in the number of tourists next year, but they don't expect a decline, either.
Like all states, Florida has plenty of trouble, including ailing banks and rising unemployment, bankruptcies and foreclosures. The economy has been softening for the last couple of years even as Florida has hurtled from the seventh-largest state in 1980, with 9.7 million people, to fourth a decade later with 12.8 million.
But along with tourism, much of it from foreigners who are benefiting from the five-year decline in the dollar, Florida is getting help from the migration here of out-of-state retirees. They keep bringing new money into the economy, and many keep up their spending because they have less to fear from a recession than working people do.
 
Avoiding Recessions

 
Also helping the state skirt a recession are a scarcity of volatile manufacturing industries, expectations of a good citrus crop this year and less of the overbuilding that has sunk the Florida economy in the past.
Carol Taylor West, the director of economic forecasting at the University of Florida in Gainesville, predicted that Florida's unemployment would edge up to 6.5 percent next year. She said incomes and the numbers of new jobs would also grow next year, though modestly, and that by 1992 the economy should be speeding up again.
Economists note that Florida avoided the nationwide recession of 1981-82 and all others since 1950, with one exception. The Arab oil embargo in 1973 and vast overbuilding, especially of condominiums in Miami, drove the state into the big recession of 1974-75.
Florida's relationship to the national economy resembles its bouts with the weather, said Buell G. Duncan Jr., chairman of SunBank, Orlando's biggest. "We get our weather from the north and west," he said, "but we get it last, and when it gets here, it's not as severe. And then, when things get better, they usually get better here first."
 
Help From Abraod

 
More worrisome to Floridians are cracks in the underpinnings of the economy that have been magnified by the slowdown in growth: crime and overloaded prisons, clogged roads and landfills, one of the nation's weakest school systems. Pressure for new investment in the state's public works has coincided with the slower economy's lower than expected state tax revenues and resulting cuts in public spending.
In tourism, foreigners enjoying a five-year drop in the value of the dollar have been making up for a decline in business from the many Americans who have lost jobs or who have turned cautious about their spending. Foreigners account for 15 percent of the state's tourists, up from just 2 or 3 percent in the mid-1980's, said Abraham Pizan, director of tourism studies at the University of Central Florida in Orlando.
Mr. Pizam said they also spend more than Americans and stay longer -- two weeks typically, compared with four or five days. "That's our savior," he said. "International tourism."
Irwin Glick, a director in the Miami office of the Levanthal & Horwath accounting firm, said, "I think 1991 will be the same as this year," he said, adding, "People might spend a little less, and conventions might be cut a day short."
 
Less Fun at Theme Parks

 
The forecasting center at the University of Florida predicts that next year the number of tourists will reach 43.2 million, up infinitesimally from the 43.1 million expected this year. That's well below the average 6.2 percent increases of 1987 through 1990. "There'll be a significant softening," said David Lentz, an economist at the center, "not a decline but a softening."
Some of the theme parks that compete for Disney World's traffic have been struggling. Universal Studios opened its theme park here in June, but several rides did not work for a while, and the "Jaws" attraction is still down. The company has cut its attendance projections for this year to 5 million from 6 million. Another park, Baseball and Boardwalk, nearby in Haines City, has closed.
More than the slower economy, boosters of tourism worry about acts of God and war. As of this week, 27 of the state's 67 counties had been struck by a mosquito-borne disease, St. Louis encephalitis. David Adams, a spokesman for the state health authorities, said it was the worst outbreak in 13 years, with 184 presumed and confirmed cases and seven deaths. Orlando's Orange county has had one death and the most cases, 23. This month's delayed arrival of colder weather should check the outbreak, Mr. Adams said.
The rise in gasoline and aircraft fuel prices after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has also slowed tourist traffic a little, but with memories still fresh of the collapse of Florida tourism after the Arab oil embargo of the mid-1970's, hoteliers fear shortages of fuel much more. "We were devastated," said Harris Rosen, who owns four low-budget hotels and is Orlando's second biggest hotel operator after Disney. "If you want to look at what can hurt Orlando, look at the availability of gas."
 
 Too Many Buildings

 
Vacant Offices, Foundering Banks
 Apart from tourism, Florida certainly looks sick, if not as sick as some other states. The state's perennial nemesis of overbuilding is showing up now with more than 20 percent of the office space in most of its big cities standing empty. In the Palm Beach area, the Coldwell Banker real estate company reports a vacancy rate of 28.7 percent. Among the large and medium size cities the firm monitors, only Stamford, Conn., is higher , with 29.9 percent.
"But overbuilding is nowhere near where it was in 1974 and 1975," said Mark P. Vitner, an economist at Barnett Banks Inc. in Jacksonville. Little overbuilding has shown up in the residential market, and economists say office vacancy rates reached their current levels a year or two ago. With little new construction underway, demand for offices should recover when economic growth picks up, hastening the day when buildings fill up and builders get back to work.
Banks are hurting, too, if less than some of the giants in New York. Florida's biggest bank, Barnett, reported a 60 percent decline in earnings for July through September, its first quarterly decline since the mid-1970's recession. The Southeastern Banking Corporation in Miami cited a surge in defaulted real estate loans in reporting a $86.9 million loss for the same quarter, compared with a profit of $30 million in the same quarter last year.
Like Texas and California, Florida is also reeling from the collapse of big savings institutions, including the spectacular case of CenTrust Bank in Miami, whose former chairman, David L. Paul, has been charged by the Federal Government with misuse of depositors' accounts. Federal regulators, who have seized the bank, have put on the block CenTrust's shimmering, largely unoccupied headquarters.
Banks, insurance companies and other big lenders, prompted by tighter Federal regulation and a new prudence toward lending, have been foreclosing on many other new properties rather than extend the developers new loans as they often would have in the 1980's.
David A. Pederson, a real estate consultant in Fort Lauderdale, said foreclosures in the southeastern counties of Dade, Broward and Palm Beach make up 25 percent of all real estate transactions. "Usually it's minuscule," he said.
 
 Too Few Jobs

 
Unemployment Exceeds Nation's
 Layoffs, concentrated among builders, banks and military contractors, are up as well. Florida's unemployment rate was 6.2 percent in October, moderately above the national rate of 5.7 percent and comparable to the 6.3 percent rate in recession-battered Massachusetts.
"This agency will register 1 million people this year," said Robert R. Arnold, an official of the state Job Service. "We registered about 750,000 last year and about 600,000 in 1988." But Mr. Arnold said some of the applicants are people from out of state who flee to Florida when they can't get jobs at home.
Layoffs could soon be up in the capital of Tallahassee, however. Even though the Floridians' average tax burden is the fourth lowest in the nation, according to the Census Bureau, antitax sentiment runs strong. In the November election, for instance, Miami's Dade County voters rejected a one-cent sales tax to meet a shortfall in county revenues. So they now face cuts in public services.
Faced with this hostility to taxes, Governor-elect Lawton Chiles, the Democratic former Senator who defeated the Republican incumbent, Bob Martinez, promised to look first at government jobs.
 
 More Bankruptcy Filings
 Bankruptcies, too, are up. In Tampa, Alexander Paskay, chief judge of the Federal Bankruptcy Court that oversees the central region encompassing Tampa, Jacksonville, Orlando and Fort Myers, said filings of bankruptcy petitions by businesses and consumers by early November this year exceeded 10,000, the most ever and 37 percent more than in November 1989. He attributed some of the increase to lawyers looking for work but some, too, to debts amassed in the 1980's.
Apart from its robust tourist businesses, Orlando is showing some strain. Cuts in Pentagon spending have led to small layoffs among military contractors, including the biggest industrial employer here, the Martin Marietta Corporation.
Downtown, the Government has taken over a big savings institution that failed, American Pioneer Savings Bank. Of the 10 buildings that form the downtown skyline, nearly all with the names of banks emblazoning their brows, the tallest is the 35-story SunBank building, which is two years old and about 35 percent vacant.
The second tallest is a two-year-old, 28-story tower that is 50 percent occupied and now enmeshed in foreclosure proceedings. The building is a project of the city's own celebrity developer, William du Pont 3d, scion of the Wilmington Du Ponts. Mr. Du Pont's investments include the 1-year-old National Basketball Association team called the Orlando Magic, of which he is the principal owner, and a $6 million stake in American Pioneer Savings Bank, now probably worthless.
 
 But Lots of Luck

 
Built to Survive In Recessions
 Florida founders less than most states in recessions in part because only 10 percent of its labor force works in factories, where layoffs are likeliest, compared with 19 percent nationally. Thirty percent work in services, the highest rate among the 10 biggest states.
Florida's citrus harvest, decimated by last year's freezes, should help too. The United States Department of Agriculture forecasts a 50 percent larger crop this year. And like foreign tourism, Florida's foreign trade benefits from the cheaper dollar. Stephen O. Morrell, chief economist at Southeastern Bank, says trade is running 9 percent stronger than it did a year ago.
More important, Florida fares better than other states in the ways it it feeds on the other states' wealth. Tourists bring in the savings they might otherwise spend at home, and migrant retirees, more from New York than any other state, bring pension and Social Security checks, stocks and bonds and the proceeds from sale of their homes.
Lured by sun and low taxes, the retirees have accounted for almost 90 percent of Florida's population growth in the last decade. People 65 and older make up 18 percent of the state's population, the highest level in the nation. And in bringing in more and more money, they drive a perpetual motion machine that keeps the economy growing.
 
 And Ever More People

 
Retirees Put Economy in Drive
 As they come, the retirees spur secondary waves of tens of thousands of other newcomers -- job-hungry youths from northern states, the Caribbean and Latin America -- who come to build the homes and work in the theme parks, the hotels, the banks and shopping centers. Many more find they can get jobs here faster than in other states because the Florida economy creates jobs faster than most others.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that of the 11 most populous states, Florida created 190,000 new jobs between October last year and October this year, the largest relative gain of any of the six that added jobs. The people who come here to take the jobs stay on, build their homes and become new sources of economic growth.
Beyond their role in driving the economy, the retirees help the state by making modest demands on public services. They don't, for instance, use the schools. At some point, public officials fear, the retirees will make costly demands on public health services, reclaiming their contributions to the economy as they age. But those concerns may be overdrawn.
In a study last month of migration from 1975 to 1980, two professors, William Crown at Brandeis and Charles Longino at the University of Miami, found that 70,306 households of people 60 and older, mostly vigorous couples, moved from New York to Florida. But 3,420, mostly widowed and older, moved back, presumably to be with their children and, coincidentally, to seek health-care assistance there instead of in Florida.
 
 Outside Help on Taxes
 All these people from somewhere else, both tourists and new settlers, keep the government going, too. Florida, like only five other states, has no income tax. As taxes go, the 6 percent sales tax is a boon to long-established Floridians because people from somewhere else pay a disproportionate share of it.
Retirees from out of state pay a disproportionate share in buying big-ticket items -- appliances, furniture, carpets -- to equip their new homes. And tourists are taxed on nearly everything they buy, including their meals and hotel rooms, and they buy few of the things that the state exempts, like groceries and medicine.
But every so often the migration machine slows down, reducing the flow of money into the state, and it is slowing down now. Economists expect the state's population to grow 2.2 percent a year in the 1990's, well below the 3.2 percent annual rate in the 1980's. Already the rate has slipped, from 3.3 percent a year through 1987 to about 2.8 percent this year. A reason for the slower growth now is the Northeast's depressed real estate market.
More important, the baby-boom generation of job seekers who moved into Florida has settled down, to be followed by the smaller baby-bust generation born since the mid-1960's. Also, later this decade the state can expect greater numbers of deaths and departures among retirees -- the millions of retirees who moved here over the last two decades -- and Mr. Vitner says this will offset the numbers of new immigrants.
 
Academic Ignominy
 Slower population growth is a mixed blessing. The growth of demand for public works should subside, but so should the out-of-state money that helps pay for public works. The school system creates the most concern. Student test scores, already low by national standards, have been declining. And in terms of the percentage of high school students that the state graduates -- 58 percent, according to the Federal Department of Education -- the schools are the worst in the nation.
Alone among the five most populous states, it has no universities of great academic renown and little of the high-paying and innovative industry that such institutions spawn. "We don't have Silicon Valleys or Route 128's," said Ms. West, the University of Florida economist. "Neither do we have a Stanford or a Harvard. We have the lower tech of the high tech."
"Florida is an adolescent state," said Dominic M. Calabro, president of Florida Tax Watch, a nonpartisan, public interest organization in Tallahassee. "It's just emerging from the pioneer days. One thing Florida has lacked is a strong commitment to public and private institutions."

LENGTH: 1123 words

HEADLINE: Fate of Domestic Policy Lies in a Battle of Aides

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
In an Administration in which collegiality has gone the way of the "no new taxes" pledge, the latest internecine struggle is between Richard G. Darman, the pragmatic budget director, and a group of young White House conservatives who are trying to revive the late-60's idea of putting power in the hands of the poor.
The end result of this battle will help shape the State of the Union Message, the future of White House domestic policy, and President Bush's relationship with the fractured conservative wing of his party. It will also signal whether Mr. Darman will continue dominating domestic policy. 
 Proponents of empowering the poor believe that such "positive" conservatism is the key to attracting members of minorities to the Republican Party. Their politics of self-help embraces free markets, decentralization and individual choice. They promote programs like inner-city entrepreneurship, government vouchers that allow parents to choose their children's schools, and tenant management or ownership of public housing. They want a substantial overhaul of the welfare system. Their push for individual choice does not include abortion rights, however.
 
Great Society, With a Twist
 The junior White House officials who endorse empowerment are alarmed at both the President's cozy cooperation with Democrats in budget negotiations last summer and fall, and the abdication of his pledge on taxes. Embracing empowerment, they believe, would give muscle to a vaguely defined Bush domestic policy. Some call it a neoconservative, supply-side twist on the Great Society social agenda.
They have had the encouragement and leadership of conservative lights like Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia; William J. Bennett, the soon-to-be Republican party chief, and Vice President Dan Quayle.
Mr. Kemp heads an empowerment task force within the Administration. The junior officials get together for an informal empowerment breakfast once a week and invite Administration officials and outside experts to speak. Mr. Darman, who has had an open invitation, has never attended.
James Pinkerton, a 32-year-old deputy assistant to the President for policy planning who is the unofficial ringleader of the junior set, coined the term New Paradigm to describe initiatives he said were meant to change the image of poor people from a liability in society to a potential asset.
Mr. Pinkerton's last claim to fame came in the 1988 campaign, when he discovered the value of the Massachusetts prison furlough issue that would turn Willie Horton into a household name.
 
Igniting a Storm
 The New Paradigm approach, read into the Congressional Record by Mr. Gingrich in March and discussed in a speech by President Bush in April, has become a rallying point for conservatives who worry that the Bush White House lacks a purpose, a message, a vision and a set of ideas and ideals that can carry it through the 1992 campaign and the next decade.
When Tom Wolfe wrote about empowerment in the late 60's, a time when advocates for the poor were trying to seize more power from an often-bewildered social welfare bureaucracy, he called the phenomenon "Mau-Mauing the Flak-Catchers." If he were writing about the Republican empowerment movement of the 90's, he might call it "Mau-Mauing the Budget Flak-Catcher for No-no-ing the Neo-neo-ism of the Young Turks."
Mr. Darman believes in an Establishment-oriented approach, emphasizing the art of the deal, and he touched off a conservative storm last week when he poked fun at the empowerment crowd. Conceding that the "no-no-ism" inspired by a deficit-straitened economy had dampened domestic initatives, Mr. Darman dismissed the "neo-neo-ism" of the New Paradigm as mere "sloganeering."
Noting that Presidents feel obligated to come up with bold programs like the New Deal, the New Frontier, the New Federalism (twice), the New American Revolution, the New Realism, several New Partnerships and two New Beginnings, Mr. Darman said, "It's a bit like soap operas brought to the viewing audience by Tide, New Tide and Insistently New New Tide."
Mr. Darman is not alone in his skepticism about catch phrases and rushing to carry out new policy initiatives without evaluation and testing.
There is no money in Bush Administration coffers for domestic initiatives. As John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, told a conservative group recently: "There's not a single piece of legislation that need be passed in the two years" remaining in Mr. Bush's term. "In fact," he said, "if Congress wants to come together, adjourn and leave, it's all right with us."
 
History of Empowerment
 And empowerment has had a tortured history. In the Great Society era, it was a buzz word among advocates of black power who wanted to increase the power that members of minorities could exercise outside the "system" -- although with the help of considerable government money.
But as bureaucrats (flak-catchers) were harassed (mau-maued) by community action agencies financed with government dollars, many experts and many politicians came to distrust efforts to change social behavior with large-scale government intervention.
"The 1960's were a very poignant time for social policy," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. "Just when the Federal Government was in a position to enact just about any social policies it wanted, the social scientists arrived and said, 'Don't waste your time; it won't work.' "
But Mr. Moynihan now praises the Republicans' attempt to revive empowerment because "at least it means they're trying something." And he concedes that the Democrats have "no competing ideas on our side."
 
This Time It's Different
 On Wednesday morning, Mr. Darman stopped by the meeting of the White House Empowerment Task Force, a group of deputy assistant secretaries and mid-level aides. "It was like a five-star general coming to the noncommissioned officers' club," said one White House official.
Mr. Darman told the group that he believed in empowerment, but that "New Paradigm" was just "phraseology" that would get the Bush Administration nowhere.
Mr. Pinkerton had been told by Andrew Card, an aide to Mr. Sununu, not to exchange any more barbs with Mr. Darman, and he kept quiet when the budget chief criticized his concept.
But Administration officials are watching the situation closely to see whether it spells the end of the alliance of Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu. Some officials believe that Mr. Sununu will support the empowerment case as a way of wooing back disaffected conservatives, and that would put him at odds with his former partner in the budget negotiations.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 Women are no longer entering the labor force as rapidly as they did in the 1970's and 1980's, even though they seem as committed as ever to holding jobs. The reasons, economists and academicians say, include the incipient national recession and a rising number of births in a nation with a paucity of child-care facilities. [Page 1.]
The American computer industry is being threatened by a new wave of small Japanese products, as were the automotive and office copier industries. The Japanese have a strong hold on the fastest-growing part of the business, lightweight portables. [1.]
The holiday shopping season began merrily, with stores around the country reporting throngs of shoppers, dispelling, if only temporarily, widespread forecasts of a gloomy Christmas for retailers. But special holiday sales promotions were widespread, and many shoppers expressed a need to be frugal. [27.]
Florida may be spared the apparent recession up north, thanks to Orlando's Mickey Mouse-inspired economy of hotels and amusement parks, the state's economists and business leaders say. [1.]
Any cooperation Michael R. Milken gives the Government may be too late to be of much help in filing new charges in its investigations of Wall Street crime, despite a hint from United States District Judge Kimba M. Wood, who sentenced him to 10 years in prison, that cooperation could reduced his term. [27.]
 
Markets
Oil prices soared $2.27 a barrel to $31.90 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, on the belief that President Bush's visit to the Mideast had bolstered international support for the use of force in the Gulf. Oil futures were up nearly 6.7 percent in a week. [27.]
An electrical failure at the New York Stock Exchange halted trading for more than an hour and a half, bringing trading to its lowest point since the day after Christmas in 1986. [27.]
The Dow industrials gave up 12.13 points, to close at 2,527.23 in a slow post-Thanksgiving Day session. That brought the loss in the holiday-shortened week to 23.02 points. [30.]
Prices of long-term Treasury securities declined moderately in thin trading, largely in reaction to the sharp rise in crude oil prices. But the shorter Treasury maturities were little changed. [30.]
The dollar was mostly higher against other currencies. Gold prices jumped $4.80 an ounce to $383.70 on the Comex. [36.] Soybean futures prices rose in Chicago as Soviet grain buyers prepared to visit the United States next week. [36.]
 
 Companies
Automobile dealers in the United States are cutting back orders for new vehicles, for fear of being left with inventories of unsold cars. That is leading to shutdowns of assembly plants at Ford, General Motors and Chrysler. But Japanese car companies are raising their American output, as their sales continue to rise. [27.]
Abraham & Straus has stopped buying ads in the Daily News, union officials said, as has Macy's. Neither the News nor A.&S. would confirm the report. The striking unions are campaigning to get advertisers to boycott the paper. [23.]
Yugoslavia's largest pharmaceutical company agreed to merge with the California-based SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc. The assets of Galenika Pharmaceuticals will be transferred to a new joint company, ICN Galenika, which is expected to have annual sales of $370 million. [29.]

Taxpayers can whittle down their income-tax liabilities now with the help of a number of excellent books and computer programs. After the first of the year, little can be done to reduce 1990 taxes. Your Money. [28.]
A way to prepare mouthwashes and medicines like cough syrup in a convenient powder form that contains no alcohol has been patented by an entrepreneur and a dentist in Houston. Patents. [28.]

LENGTH: 594 words

HEADLINE: Pump More Air and Less Gasoline

 BODY:
Motorists in the United States waste the equivalent of 100,000 barrels of oil a day because the tires on their cars are underinflated. Now, especially with the increases in gasoline prices, drivers who want to save money should buy an accurate tire-pressure gauge and check their tires regularly.
 Gauges are relatively inexpensive and easy to use. And it pays to keep tires up to the proper pressure: the Federal Energy Department estimates that motorists can save 2 percent of their total gas bills each year. And tires that are neither underinflated nor overinflated are also safer and last longer, and they will help a car ride and handle as it should. 
 "From a consumer's point of view, proper tire inflation makes sense because you will save on fuel and tire wear," said Clarence M. Ditlow, the executive director of the Center for Auto Safety, an advocacy group in Washington.
Mr. Ditlow and other experts recommend that motorists buy their own tire gauges because studies have found that many gauges built into service-station air pumps are inaccurate.
Tires should be inflated to the pressure recommended by the tire manufacturer or the car maker (if the recommendations differ, Mr. Ditlow said to use the pressure suggested by the car maker, for the best stability and handling). Readings, measured in pounds per square inch, should be taken when the tires are cold.
There are three types of gauges: the pencil type, also called a stick gauge, and the dial and digital types. All are accurate, experts say, but they differ in readability, durability and price.
The pencil gauge is the most common and least expensive. Many experts also say it is best because it is easy to store and hard to break, although the readings can become inaccurate if the measuring stick becomes bent or gritty.
"You can carry it around in your pocket," said Wayne Jensen, the product manager for K-D Tools in Lancaster, Pa., a maker of pencil gauges.
The major disadvantage is that the numbers on the measuring stick are small and can be hard to read in low light or by people who can't see well.
Some cost as little as $1, and good quality pencil gauges, made of either metal or plastic, are less than $5.
The big advantage of the dial gauge is readability: the pressure is measured by a needle moving across a face, which is usually marked at one-pound intervals. Experts advise buying a dial gauge that holds the reading after it is taken. An angled head (also known as a chuck) can make it easier to push the gauge against the tire valve.
A disadvantage of dial gauges is that they break more easily than pencil or digital models and will not withstand bumping around in a glove compartment as well as a pencil gauge. In 1987, Consumer Reports magazine found that every dial gauge tested lost its accuracy after being dropped onto a concrete floor from a height of three feet.
Dial gauges are also more expensive: they cost about $7 to $25 or more.
The newest pressure gauges give their readings digitally. Charlotte Hart Cuomo, the marketing director at Beverly Hills Motoring Accessories , a California mail-order company that has a showroom on South Robertson Boulevard, said the numbered displays were easier to read than pencil or dial gauges. She also said digital gauges were more convenient: some models beep when the correct pressure is reached.
But she added that although they are durable, digital gauges can be more fragile than mechanical ones. The most popular digital model sold by Beverly Hills costs $24.95.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pencil-type air-pressure gauge by K-D Tools, at near right, costs $4.30. Milton Industries Model 902 dial gauge, center, retails for about $17. The BHMA digital gauge by Beverly Hills Motoring Accessories, top right, is $24.95, plus $3 shipping. (K-D Tools (left); Milton Industries (center); Beverly Hills Motoring Accessories (right))

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL BOOKS;
Are We Doomed?

BYLINE: By Malcolm W. Browne; Malcolm W. Browne is a science reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
THE CHANGING ATMOSPHERE
A Global Challenge.
By John Firor.
145 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95. 
 BY now most of us are aware that sinister forces are reshaping our habitat. As the human race burgeons (it has doubled in just 37 years), it is fouling the global nest at a horrifying rate. Already we are witnessing the death of forests and lakes, the dwindling of genetic diversity and the spread of cancer.
These changes are not pleasant to acknowledge, and we cling to the straws offered by uncertainty. Since the scientists assessing the damage to our land, water and air constantly disagree with one another, we are permitted to hope that the Cassandras are simply wrong. Some commentators buttress this hope by reminding us that the earth is an astonishingly resilient place that has always managed to absorb the blows dealt by humans and nature.
John Firor, a scientist who directs the Advanced Study Program at the National Center for Atmospheric Research, in Boulder, Colo., throws ice water on such cozy assumptions. Scientific debates about the atmosphere abound, he concedes, but they are mainly about how much and how soon the dreadful consequences of our profligacy will become manifest, not whether they will come about at all. In the space of a few dozen decades man has profoundly (and perhaps irreversibly) changed the terrestrial habitat, and the rate of change is now increasing almost beyond belief. It is folly, he writes, to use scientific quibbling over details of this cataclysm as a pretext for inaction.
"The Changing Atmosphere" is about even larger human issues than air pollution. The thrust of Mr. Firor's argument is that none of the environmental issues now facing us can be considered in isolation; the danger that the warming of the atmosphere will melt polar ice and raise sea levels enough to destroy most of Bangladesh, he demonstrates, is directly related to the educational status of an African woman cooking a meal in an earthen pot over an open fire.
Mr. Firor's book is persuasive because it is based more on evenhanded analysis than on advocacy. He does not assert, for example, that failure to correct our erring ways will bring certain doom; he merely suggests that inaction will limit human options in ways that will enormously complicate our survival. He suggests that even if most animal and plant species fall victim to the environmental changes we are bringing about, we will create new, more useful species, by genetic engineering or other means. And even if our chlorine-based pollutants eventually weaken nature's ozone shield so that ultraviolet radiation wipes out global soybean production and other crops, he says, substitutes can probably be developed.
But Mr. Firor warns that if we decide to shoulder total responsibility for readapting the world to the changes we are imposing on it, we must complete our preparations before doing away with Mother Nature altogether. We must be ready with new systems of agriculture, industry, economy and society -- along with governments strong enough to make them work -- if we are not to face an agonizing period of transition.
Most of "The Changing Atmosphere" is devoted to clear explanations (illustrated by simple graphs) of the relationships between acid rain, climate warming and stratospheric ozone depletion, as well as to their causes and effects. This book could serve as a primer for anyone confused by the wealth of technical information that has been published about these complex atmospheric phenomena.
UNLIKE many books about the climate, though, this one focuses sharply on some of the social mainsprings of atmospheric change, notably the population explosion. The author repeats the familiar injunctions to wean ourselves from fossil fuels, develop alternative energy sources and use all our resources more efficiently. But he adds that "each problem discussed here, and indeed almost every global problem facing us today, is driven in the first instance and exacerbated by growth in the world's population."
He argues that only by stemming population growth -- perhaps by raising the economic and educational standards of women in the third world and by providing incentives to raise smaller families -- will we be able to manage the complications caused by pollution and the depletion of resources.
"The Changing Atmosphere" is about as agreeable as a dose of ipecac; the reader is left with a sense of astonishment that human intelligence could have permitted us to reach this predicament. But perhaps the era of complacency is ending and we have at last begun to think about saving ourselves.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 632 words

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL BOOKS;
If It's Broke, Why Not Fix It?

BYLINE: By Michael Oppenheimer; Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, is the author, with Robert H. Boyle, of "Dead Heat: The Race Against the Greenhouse Effect."

 BODY:
REMAKING SOCIETY
Pathways to a Green Future.
By Murray Bookchin.
222 pp. Boston:
South End Press. Cloth, $25. Paper, $10. 
 WITH chunks of the Berlin Wall up for sale and Eastern Europe rushing to join a global free market, people who question the virtues of capitalism are generally as welcome as gnats at a nudist party. But the 1980's were also the decade of the ozone hole and global warming, both of which arise chiefly from the emission of industrial gases, which increase during breakneck economic expansion, the sine qua non of capitalist success.
One of those gnats buzzing about the capitalist celebration is Murray Bookchin, who has been warning of the conflict between economic growth and environmental stability for nearly 30 years. Mr. Bookchin, the author of nine other books on society and ecology, is an anarchist in the utopian tradition, dispensing as much contempt for the totalitarian Marxists who ruined the landscape of Eastern Europe and the health of its denizens as he doles out for the capitalists. Mr. Bookchin argues that the original sin of humankind is the development of hierarchies. The dominance of one human over another, he believes, led inevitably to the domination of one sex by another, one class by another and, in a cascading sequence of hierarchies, to the domination of nature by humans.
Mr. Bookchin's solution is to recoup some of the elements of earlier civilizations, characteristics that were snuffed out by the Industrial Revolution. He envisions confederations of small communities, governments built around town meetings and shared labor based on the artisanal model of customized production. He is no Luddite, but looks to what he calls ecological technologies, such as solar energy, to restore the "balance between town and country." In fact, he expresses withering contempt for the wing of environmentalism known as deep ecology, some of whose adherents regard humans and their technologies as a cancer on the pristine body of nature. Mr. Bookchin sees nature, humanity and society as one piece. If people are fouling their environment, the problem lies in particular socio-economic systems, not in the very essence of human beings.
Mr. Bookchin is rather kind to mainstream environmentalists (of whom I am one) who try to reform capitalism with weapons like air pollution regulations. After all, someone has to forestall more Chernobyls, and it is difficult to argue credibly for reform and revolution at the same time. Yet with environmental degradation now threatening our global life support systems, reformists need to reconsider radical questions that have been banished from mainstream debate for over a decade: Can the ethic of individual gain be reconciled with the collective need for common resources, such as air and water? Can permanent growth be reconciled with the limited resilience of the natural processes that sustain us, such as climate?
"REMAKING SOCIETY" is a strident, didactic, poorly edited and downright irritating book, with so many uses of "organic" and "ecological" that it constantly teeters on the brink of mushy philosophizing. Its anthropological inferences about older societies are too sweeping to be credible, and its utopian vision seems hopelessly romantic and unrealistic.
Nonetheless, the big capitalist party of the 1980's is coming to a crashing end. Questions of fairness and wealth distribution are again in the air. Once more, nations are hostage to their voracious thirst for oil. The central governments of the two big cold warriors are in disarray. Environmentalism is no longer about wilderness protection; it's about saving the collective neck of humanity. In this turbulent context, the questions raised by Murray Bookchin, that annoying gnat, should not be ignored.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy
<By>George Johnson

 BODY:
BATTLE FOR JUSTICE: How the Bork Nomination Shook America, by Ethan Bronner. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) When Robert Bork was nominated for a seat on the United States Supreme Court, he and his conservative allies considered him a sure thing. In documenting what went wrong, Ethan Bronner has written a book whose strength "is in the personal details of the story, expertly elicited and sympathetically conveyed," Garry Wills said in The Book Review last year.
KEEP THE CHANGE, by Thomas McGuane. (Vintage, $9.95.) Joe Starling, a failed painter who supports himself by illustrating instruction manuals, steals his girlfriend's pink convertible and heads back to his ranch in Montana. "I don't know of another writer who can walk Thomas McGuane's literary high wire," Beverly Lowry said here last year. "He can describe the sky, a bird, a rock, the dawn, with such grace that you want to go see for yourself; then he can zip to a scene so funny that it makes you laugh out loud. 'Keep the Change' takes up where the excellent 'Nobody's Angel' and 'Something to Be Desired' left off. In these days of hot early starts and quick nasty fall-offs, it's encouraging to see a good writer getting better."
THE TRULY DISADVANTAGED: The Inner City, the Underclass, and Public Policy, by William Julius Wilson. (University of Chicago, $12.95.) Taking on both liberals and conservatives, a sociologist argues that it is not racism or welfare so much as a declining economy that has led to the development of the underclass. " 'The Truly Disadvantaged' far surpasses other attempts to explore these complex issues," Robert Greenstein said here in 1987.
A WILD SHEEP CHASE, by Haruki Murakami. Translated by Alfred Birnbaum. (Plume, $8.95.) Disillusioned with contemporary Japan, a Tokyo advertising man with a very Western case of ennui stumbles across a right-wing conspiracy whose mastermind is a sheep with extraordinary powers. "We are on our own despoiled modern turf (a turf as international as it is locally Japanese), hearing our own irreverent colloquial language, the Esperanto of the postatomic generation," Ann Arensberg said here last year. "Haruki Murakami is a mythmaker for the millennium, a wiseacre wise man."
STRANGERS FROM A DIFFERENT SHORE: A History of Asian Americans, by Ronald Takaki. (Penguin, $11.95.) A University of California professor who is himself a descendant of Japanese plantation workers provides a panoramic look at the struggles of Asians to be accepted on an equal footing in America. "His impassioned and perceptive history is a tribute to one of the branches of the American family and a service to them all," Jon Foreman said here last year.
THE CHILDREN OF SEGU, by Maryse Conde. Translated by Linda Coverdale. (Ballantine, $9.95.) In this sequel to "Segu," the Bambara people of 19th-century western Africa are caught up in an Islamic holy war. Last year our reviewer, David Goodwin, said the novel lost something in its translation from the French, but "behind the verbiage is a bold story that refuses to sentimentalize the African tribal experience in the face of expanding colonialism."
AN OLD MAN'S TOY: Gravity at Work and Play in Einstein's Universe, by A. Zee. (Collier/Macmillan, $9.95.) Having delved into the quantum world in his book "Fearful Symmetry," a physicist explores the outer cosmos and the gravitational force that shapes it. Last year our reviewer, Marcia Bartusiak, said A. Zee "can clearly evoke the imagery hidden within a mathematical equation, treating some rather formidable material with enthusiasm and delight."
SILVER WEDDING, by Maeve Binchy. (Dell, $5.95.) As they prepare for their 25th anniversary, an Irish couple living in London face the fact that their children's lives have turned out to be disappointments. "You can sense a remarkably gifted writer beginning to flex her muscles," Robert Plunket said in The Book Review last year.
ACTS OF WORSHIP: Seven Stories, by Yukio Mishima. Translated by John Bester. (Kodansha, $6.95.) In the title piece of these recently translated works, a professor goes on a pilgrimage with his maid. "These stories demonstrate Mishima's ability to render atmosphere and theme through a complex yet orderly mixture of sharply observed physical details and introspective musings," Fred Misurella said here in January.
LOVE OR HONOR, by Joan Barthel. (Avon, $4.95.) An undercover detective for the New York City Police Department becomes so close to the mafia don he is tailing that he becomes romantically involved with the man's daughter. Last year our reviewer, Maria Gallagher, said the protagonist of this true story "emerges as a tarnished hero who wins his gold shield, but loses life as he knew it."
A CHILD'S WAR: World War II Through the Eyes of Children, by Kati David (Avon, $7.95.) A Dutch journalist compiled these first-person accounts of what it was like growing up in a war. In February The Times's Herbert Mitgang called the result "a small education in itself, a book that could well be read by young people to discover the sorrows instead of the glories of war."
A PLACE AT THE TABLE, by Edith Konecky. (Ballantine, $3.95.) As she approaches her 60th birthday, Rachel Levin is fighting cancer, pulling out of a lesbian relationship, and trying to console her friend Deirdre, who is going mad. "The attractions, repulsions, similarities and differences between these two lives are rendered with a sure and subtle touch," Barbara Fisher Williamson said here last year.

HEADLINE: Fashion;
THE GREAT AMERICAN COCKTAIL

BYLINE: BY CARRIE DONOVAN

 BODY:
START WITH SEVERAL JIGGERS OF NOSTALGIA: 1960's is this season's favorite vintage. Throw in a dash of inspiration from other designers. Chanel and Armani are the recommended brands, though Lacroix, Azzedine, Courreges and Montana are also popular. Don't forget a soupcon of saleability. Top it off with some sprinkles of originality (optional). Shake well and serve neat. That's the great American fashion cocktail for spring 1991.
Instead of assuming a cautious conservative stance -- which would have been dull but understandable considering the current bleak retail scene -- the majority of New York's designers, stylists and manufacturers have come up with surprisingly buoyant and high-spirited spring collections. At the American showings earlier this month, almost every designer stepped out with clothes that were perky and positive, even optimistically sunny. Skirts continued to be short. The dress returned with a vengeance. Pretty colors like hot pink predominated, though every designer showed something in white. Shine has become a major statement, with plastic or vinyl and splashes of sequins for day or night. But it was the ferocity of the 1960's revival that was most remarkable. Sleeveless cookie-cutter dresses, saucy A-line shapes, big heads of hair, batty eye makeup and accessories like little white gloves and small, structured handbags became commonplace. Sometimes the 60's flashback was so heady it seemed as if the only thing missing were the old Courreges white go-go boots. 
 The positive side of this 1960's flashback was that the new spring clothes had a strong underpinning of manipulated shape, something that has slid out of fashion in recent years. Not that clothes have been shapeless by any means; thanks to miracle fibers, some have fit so tight that they accentuate every line of the body. But the 60's-like silhouettes enforce a preset shape on a woman's form. One assumes designers presume that large numbers of women will welcome styles that instantly give them a trimmer structure, instead of depending on their figures to supply it. But will they?
American women have become completely indoctrinated with the sportswear concept. Mixing blazers, jackets, pants and skirts as one wishes is a comfortable, functional mode of dressing. In contrast, the 1960's attitude brings with it a high quotient of girlishness; there is almost a cartoonlike quality to a lot of this new stuff. Granted, it is the nature of fashion to change constantly; stimulation is fashion's raison d'etre. But is a rehash of the 1960's really the right direction -- especially in today's economic climate? It is doubtful that these styles have the real depth and versatility to stick it for the long run. While a sprinkling of these looks would enliven a woman's current wardrobe, a wholesale immersion in the 1960's look would truly be frivolity.

SAAC MIZRAHI WAS ONE DESIGNER WHO CAUGHT THE essence of the 1960's without slavishly reviving it. Mizrahi's clothes were blithe and bright, and his was the season's best collection. At his show, staged in a huge SoHo loft, the atmosphere was electric; international top models pranced down the long runway in their high-heeled suede mules with Pilgrim buckles, their hair and makeup done in delicious parodies of the 1960's. Many styles had Peter Pan or ruffled collars and big floppy bows at the neckline (all removable). Hems of loose chemise dresses and pleated skirts flipped high above the knees, while a few mid-calf ones flounced over mildly stiffened petticoats. They were wonderfully colored in peaches, pinks, greens, blues or whites, with shiny lashes of clear plastic (raincoats) or patent leather (zip-front jackets). Though Mizrahi's company reportedly has had problems delivering merchandise that looks like the dollars it costs and that fits to perfection, no one can question his ability to capture the spirit of the moment.
Certainly, for most designers, the intensive furrowing through the 60's has been a boost. It added an extra patina, for example, to the wares of Michael Kors, who as usual gave the trends of the day a slick rendition. And it was a natural for Carolyne Roehm, who is most at home when she has definite shapes to work with. Louis Dell'Olio, the stylist for the Anne Klein company, bounced back from a lackluster fall with his spring showing that socked the 60's message out smartly in shapes pressed from blocks of colors like red, black and white or red and fuschia. The 60's style also seemed to revitalize Carolina Herrera. Her models' hairdos may have resembled Marilyn Quayle's flip, but the clothes were younger in line and attitude. This 60's washover even affected two of America's most sophisticated stylists, Bill Blass and Oscar de la Renta. For spring, each has done some svelte chemise dresses. Blass's suits and color and pattern combinations in particular were superb.
There are, of course, some designers who always go their own way, and Ralph Lauren is definitely one of them. While he did include a sleeveless chemise -- handsomely executed in rows of wood beads and black sequins -- his strength was in his quiet, well-bred separates like softly tailored jackets, sexy halter tops or nice skirts and pants with an insouciant flip to them. Unfortunately, he has not continued his quirky uniform-influenced styles, a maverick fashion idea that had great appeal. At Calvin Klein too there was no trace of the 1960's. Instead, Klein continues to be mesmerized by the philosophy, attitude and designs of Giorgio Armani. Retailers privately refer to Klein's clothes as "Armani at half the price." This is undoubtedly why Klein has had a spectacular selling record for the last two seasons, something no other designer -- except for Armani -- can claim. And none of this has changed for next spring. Klein's smooth, easy, plain-as-possible sophisticated shapes, like Armani's, will be in sinuous fabrics shaded in beiges, greiges or whites.

HEN GEOFFREY BEENE PADDED DOWN the runway to take his bow, he was wearing a sweater emblazoned with an American flag. Why not? He's the best we've got. Completely original, totally in control of his craft and at least two steps ahead of the time any time, Beene did not come up with new ideas for next season. No 60's variations either. Instead, his collection was rife with twists on his recent inventions like slip dresses cut to show slices of skin veiled with gossamer laces and dresses with uneven hemlines. No doubt something will be made of the fact that one of Beene's models wore an ankle-length T-shirt jersey dress, but the rest of his hemlines were high as kites.
What a startler Donna Karan's collection turned out to be. Karan, who has seemed recently to have been under the influence of Armani or Italy's romanticist, Romeo Gigli, did a complete turnaround. Instead of showing slouchy and simple silhouettes, Karan has now sprung to styles that were all construction and covered with decorative zippers, sculptured buttons and satin bandings. Clearly, Karan is now heavily swayed by Parisian designers: Lagerfeld, Azzedine and Montana. Karan aficionados may have been dismayed by this turn of events, but she has obviously made a smart commercial move. Her designs looked sexy -- and in a high-style way, very salable. Vive la difference!
An increasingly important element in this country's fashion mix is the young designer label. While two of the most popular -- Marc Jacobs for Perry Ellis and Gordon Henderson -- were disappointing, others, particularly Randolph Duke, were outstanding. Duke's styles may have been inspired by the 1960's, yet they were direct and sharp as a tack. Gemma Kahng, Zang Toi and Isani have made snug Chanel-like styles laced with crunchy detailing of buttons and pockets, all in appealing color combinations like geranium with grass green.
Where does this leave women who want to buy something new but expect it to last a reasonable time? Their safest bet will be to look for a simple structured daytime dress, something they probably have not had in their wardrobes for a long time. Some of the new color combinations may be irresistible. It may even be fun to experiment with a longer skirt, a vinyl raincoat or a touch of 1960's accessories, makeup or hair. But the 60's influence is best imbibed in moderation.
