HEADLINE: Sad Tales of the Sagging Co-op Market

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
THERE are about 14,000 co-ops and condos for sale in Manhattan, 4,000 more than a year ago, and behind most of them there is a story about frazzled owners who wish they had managed to sell out a few years ago, before the sun went down on apartment values.
That was when market was still strong, and buyers -- including many of today's sellers -- were frantically bidding against each other to secure a foothold in Manhattan's golden mountain of rising housing prices. Now, to hear the owners tell it, the market has gone south, their apartments are losing value, and the brokers seem to be cosseting the scarce buyers rather than the anxious sellers who will pay their commissions. 
 And the buyers, well, the buyers are like neurotic pirates, larcenous but indecisive, who invade apartments almost without notice, brandish insulting offers, change their minds as the market sinks, and then come back to try to capture a home for less.
There are sellers whose apartment sales became entangled in the gears of a bitter divorce, forcing delay and further losses and more heartache. There are sellers who toyed with the idea of selling five years ago, but kept their Manhattan property because the rent it was producing was paying for new homes somewhere else.
There is a Fifth Avenue matron who was two days from a closing on her co-op when the buyer threatened to pull out and forfeit a $280,000 deposit unless she came down a half million dollars.
And there is an East Side couple who accepted the lower of two bids just because, after a year of dickering, they had come to hate the higher bidder's guts.
Yet for all their gripes and difficulties, Manhattanites who are passing through through the trials of selling often display a Zen-like calm about all that money they thought they had but now will problably never make. Alicia Chalfin, owner of Evie B. Industries, a women's clothing concern, fears she could loose more than $100,000 on her West Side apartment, but if she is upset, she doesn't show it.
"I don't happen to believe I was put on this earth to make money from real estate," she said simply.
But she did permit herself a wistful sigh about the way fate and the arrival of her now one-year old, Maurice, put her and her husband, Seth, at the wrong end of the real estate cycle, making them buyers in a seller's market, and sellers during a glut.
The Chalfins bought their two-bedroom apartment at 186 Riverside Drive, at 91st Street, in 1987, just before the stock market crash. They were also in time to experience one of the most hair-raising bits of financial chicanery an overheated market can devise: the late bid.
"We had a handshake deal at one price, and then we got a frantic phone call from the broker saying that someone else had put in a higher bid, and if we wanted the apartment we'd have to top it,' said Mrs. Chalfin. To this day, she does not know if there really was another bid.
She did know, and so did the seller's broker, that she had already hired decorators and engineers to plan extensive renovations in the apartment. It was too late to pull out, so the price for two bedrooms overlooking the Hudson River on Riverside Drive went up another notch, to $525,000.
AFTER spending $130,000 on new plumbing, wiring, walls and floors, the Chalfins are asking $575,000. "If I get $500,000 I'll be getting a lot," Mrs. Chalfin said. That would be a hard step down for a lavishly renovated apartment that the seller's broker assured her, in 1987, would never lose money.
"I feel I was misled," she said, "and I feel that the brokers these days are taking better care of the buyers than the sellers, which is a turnaround from 1987, when they were trying harder to keep the sellers happy."
Several buyers repeated this theme, that real estate brokers tend to favor the strong hand in any market, cajoling sellers when the prices were high and now favoring scarce buyers against the interests of the sellers.
Clark Halstead, a leading broker who is head of the Halstead Property Corporation, said he had heard these complaints from sellers, too.
"Any seller is going to be categorically angry with the broker because the whole process has been so disappointing to him," he said. And if today's sellers are recent buyers, he added, the anger is likely to be sharper.
"Two years ago, buyers just couldn't believe the extent to which they were being roughly handled by the brokers," he said. "They were told they had to have their offers in within an hour, and often when they got it in, the brokers would say, 'Too late, two more offers have been made higher than yours, so if you still want it you have to make a better offer, and you have one hour to do it.' The buyers were really being roughed up."
Another Manhattan brokerage, the Corcoran Group, recently invited people with apartments for sale to a seminar on tips for making the sale. The response surprised Barbara Corcoran, head of the agency, as fur coats and expensive suits overflowed the East Side meeting room. Although her speakers focused on the economy ("no recession yet") and on sprucing-up apartments ("put out flowers; lose the cat"), many in the audience wanted to talk about the anger they felt toward brokers for not getting them the price and the buyers they wanted.
"I think it's the old story of killing the messenger who brings bad news," Ms. Corcoran remarked afterwards.
David Little, a computer systems consultant, lost all of his equity in the sale of his West 114th Street co-op, yet left New York for his new job in Boston with a deep sense of gratitude to Dan Douglas, the Corcoran Group broker who arranged the sale and did so much more than just showing the apartment and conveying bids.
"This story gets really Dickensian," said Mr. Little, by way of introduction. But no Dickens novel depicted a dissolving marriage, a suddenly departed wife and the end of the double income that had made their co-op on West 114th Street affordable.
Mr. Little had bought the two-bedroom apartment for $367,000 with a down payment of his own money gained from an earlier, luckier real estate sale. Forced to sell by his wife's departure, he put the unit on the market at a modest $395,000 last September and within a month got an offer for $370,000.
But his estranged wife, who as a mortgagee had to consent to any sale, refused to go along, as she did again the following year, as the bids went lower and lower -- to $350,000 in January and $325,000 in March -- and Mr. Little's equity slowly evaporated.
Finally, Mr. Little said in an interview, Mr. Douglas got a lawyer who persuaded Mrs. Little to agree to a separation agreement that included a consent to sell the apartment. Last month, when a buyer bid $275,000, the amount of the mortgage, the sale went through. Mr. Little was wiped out, he said, but he was free. Pressed to say what he might have done differently, Mr. Little wondered whether the Corcoran Group was not a little too upscale for a co-op on West 114th Street.
"GOING to Corcoran was a big step up for Dan," he said of the broker, "but his clientele were more high scale now, and he said that some of them were concerned about living above 96th Street. Maybe if I had gone with brokers who were more West Side-y they would have brought people who already knew what a nice neighborhood it is up there."
But Mr. Little rejected any reproach. "I'm eternally grateful to Dan for getting me out of my legal entanglement," he said.
In Boston, he rents.
It was the buyer, not an estranged spouse, who drove down the price on Siri von Reis in a kind of nightmare scenario that shows how even a hard contract can fall apart in a sinking market.
Miss von Reis, a poet, had paid $120,000 for her five bedroom co-op at 1107 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, in 1976. In March of last year, with her children grown and no longer needing so much space, she put it on the market for $3.7 million.
The price was a little fanciful, she admits, but not out of line with the earnest admonition of a neighbor, who was concerned about the value of his own apartment, not to go below $4 million. Last February she cut the price to $3.3 million, which produced a sales contract, after much negotiation, of $2.8 million on March 23.
The buyer requested an extension in the original closing date of Sept. 17, and on Oct. 17, two days before the closing, his lawyer called Miss von Reis's lawyer with news: Because the market had gone down so much -- including during the month of the buyer's delay, Miss von Reis points out -- the buyer would forfeit his $280,000 deposit and walk away unless Miss von Reis agreed to drop the price even more, to the vicinity of $2 million to $2.25 million .
"I just felt so angry I wanted to take his money and let him go," said Miss von Reis in a voice so sunny and well-spoken that it would be hard to imagine her angry at anyone. But by then the apartment was empty, stripped of the 200-odd paintings and hundreds of books that had given it such style, and she knew buyers always seem to smell blood when they encounter an empty apartment.
Besides, her advisers at Halstead suggested, the market might sink still further and wipe out her $280,000 windfall. On top of it all, Miss von Reis had already contracted to pay $1.5 million to buy and renovate her new seven room co-op at 1136 Fifth Avenue, at 95th Street. She felt she had no choice but to drop the price, and agreed to $2.5 million and accept a truth about some New Yorkers.
"What I find hardest to accept is that he didn't come to me openly and say, 'Look, we love the apartment and we really want it, but we see the market is slipping and we feel we have to come down.' Instead he behaved in a very shabby and a very" -- she paused to dig out a scorcher -- "ungentlemanly way."
Yet taking a cut in price may be easier for those like Miss von Reis, who bought low before the big price inflation of the early and mid-80's, and Read Jackson, a Hollywood screenwriter, is one of this lucky group. In 1977, he paid all of $47,000 for a one-bedroom co-op in the Hotel des Artistes, the venerable arts colony on West 67th off Central Park West. It was just two years after New York City all but went bankrupt, and real estate values had sunk lower than the city's credit rating.
"My friends told me I was nuts, but some bankers I knew told me to buy, the city was going to turn around," said Mr. Jackson, whose current credits include the publicity video for Kevin Costner's "Dances With Wolves."
"I guess they were right," he added.
By 1985, Mr. Jackson and his new bride, Deborah Kramer, were getting offers of $400,000 for the apartment. That was the year Mr. Jackson left his job as a public television producer to move to the West Coast, and the couple might have taken all that money with them except that they found they could rent their place for $2,300 a month and cover the maintenance and their rent in Los Angeles.
"I just couldn't believe the way things had escalated," Mr. Jackson said, "but I guess I should have sold in 1985."
His first clue that things were slipping in New York came when his tenant refused to renew the lease at the same rent. In July he took his broker's advice and put the apartment on the market for $375,000, but the mood of the buyers had obviously soured.
"People would walk in and say, '$375,000 for this? Are you crazy?' and walk out," Mr. Jackson said. "The broker told me to keep it there and eventually I'd get my money, but I figured, eventually I'll be 50, too."
So with his big profit cushion, he started slashing his price, and when he reached $275,000, a buyer signed, 90 days after the apartment had gone on the market.
Yes, he said, he could have made more if he had sold earlier, but Mr. Jackson said he loses no sleep over what might have been, even though what might have been had a lot of dollar signs on it.
"I think a lot of people are still caught up in the high market, and they just don't want to let go," he said. "But that was dream money, paper money, a fantasy. Wishing for lost paper profits is chasing the wrong sacred cow."
Anne Thomas, is another ex-New Yorker who sees, with the benefit of hindsight, that selling her co-op at 340 Riverside Drive two years earlier would have been the right move. Although she would not discuss the price, she made it clear that by the time she, a stock market analyst, and her husband, an editor of specialized magazines, decided to move to Boston last summer, the market was already treating sellers with an unaccustomed rudeness.
"A lot of people starting coming in with ridiculously low bids, almost insulting bids," she said in an interview. "They didn't stand to lose anything, they just wanted to see if they could get it, and we had to tell the brokers that they would save their time and our time if they stopped bringing in bids that were 50 percent lower than the asking price."
THE Thomases gained one insight into the ways of the city's real estate market -- the often debated question of whether one should list an apartment exclusively with one agency, meaning that agency shares in the commission no matter who sells it, or take the more common approach and invite any brokerage to seek a buyer.
They accepted a broker's argument that the promise of a full commission would produce more customers in an exclusive listing, and signed such an agreement.
In the end, she said, they did not get more customers, but more of other brokers visiting their apartment, familiarizing themselves with it for the day the exclusive agreement expired to open the field to all comers.
"The number of showings went up very significantly once we took it off exclusive," she said. "So we realized that although we kept it exclusive longer than we should have, it helped advertise us among the brokerage community."
Last month, after a year on the market, their apartment sold for 23 percent less than the asking price. The Thomases did not make as much as they might have if they had sold earlier, but neither, she said, did they lose anything.
"It had its moments of anxiety, but overall I would say it was relatively painless," she said. "In the end we even had two people bidding against each other, but we didn't try to run them up too high. In that market, too many things can go wrong."
For a couple on the East Side -- he's a securities broker, she raises their two children -- things also went oddly right when it came to getting a $15,000 laugh on a devious buyer.
The woman, a client of the Cochran Group who related her experience on condition that her name and address be omitted, had put their apartment in the East 80's on the market a year ago at $775,000 so the family could move to a bigger co-op 10 blocks north.
The family became embroiled in a long and difficult negotiation with a bidder who finally agreed to a price but, before making a deposit, changed his mind. The market was still falling, the bidder said, and he would rent instead.
Angry and frustrated, the couple waited another year, watching their equity shrink, until late last summer. Then two bids came in, one for $590,000 from a young couple who were about to marry, and the second from the vanished bidder of a year before. His offer was $15,000 higher than that of the couple but $100,000 less than the price he had shaken hands on last year.
"My husband and I said, well, $15,000 is $15,000 and that's a lot of money, but we just said, the heck with this guy, he's not going to get away with a stunt like that, we can't let him have our apartment," the woman declared. "So we gave it to the couple, and when we told the man we had gone with the other couple, he almost dropped dead."
And she laughed.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1380 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Multifamily Workouts;
The Listing Ship of Overfinanced Rentals

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN moderate-income neighborhoods of New York City, the late 80's were a time of feverish property buying by a handful of owners. Prices were paid by some on the basis of heady expectations of what rents might be expected in the short term for upgraded buildings, and how successfully they might be converted to co-ops.
The morning after has arrived. The largest such buyer, Abram Gin, and his management company, Artha Mangagement, was looked upon only five years ago as the city's leading rehabilitator of older rental buildings. 
 Now he and his company are both in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, along with his partner, Alex Zaika, and Mr. Zaika's construction company, All-Z Construction. A trustee has been appointed in Federal court to manage and dispose of a large portfolio -- 71 buildings with 2,900 apartments in northern Manhattan and the Bronx.
Thirty lenders are holding $100 million in first mortgages on the properties, $20 million in second mortgages and $10 million in third mortgages, said the trustee, John Pereira. General creditors such as suppliers and small contractors are owed $20 million more.
Artha Management's has not been the only failure among residential owners. The youthful investor Steven Green lost 11 properties to lenders. Ike Portnoy of Forest Hills, Queens, operating under the name Gem Management, also lost a handful of buildings. Receivers are managing them.
The toll in these failures embraces not only owners and their partners and lenders but also many small businesses and contractors who are owed money. Tenants of affected buildings may have experienced a loss in services. That should improve under receivership management.
The longer-term issue is how the shakeout will affect the prospects for investment in moderate-income housing. Much of it came about because of a ready availability of credit. Will lenders turn away from the Bronx, Brooklyn and northern Manhattan, large centers of rental housing? Some say that this is already the case, although it may result mainly from market conditions generally.
The principal lender of the 80's, the Federal National Mortgage Association, of Freddie Mac, is already out of the market for new loans. During the decade Freddie Mac vastly increased its urban portfolio, which for New York and New Jersey currently stands at 2,847 loans with a mortgage value of $2.69 billion. Most of these loans are in the Bronx, Brooklyn or Manhattan.
Freddie Mac reports that $147.9 million in loans on 154 properties New York or New Jersey are either in foreclosure or delinquent more than 60 days. This is a 5.3 percent delinquency rate, which compares with 3.8 percent nationally.
The combination of the Artha Management failure and the rise in delinquency on Freddie Mac loans draws attention to excessive financing's potential to be as lethal a blow to moderate-income housing as insufficient financing. In a sense it is the other side of the redlining coin.
MR. GIN, the founder of Artha Management, is a civil engineer who emigrated from the Soviet Union in the mid-70's. He learned English while driving a taxi for two years and began slowly to buy and renovate small buildings. Later he did moderate rehabilitations financed by the Community Preservation Corporation and the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, in northern Manhattan and the Bronx. Nine of these buildings are being managed by Ralph Langsam Associates, a Bronx management firm. They were not overfinanced and the lenders are not likely to experience losses when the properties are resold.
Mr. Gin also built a big organization that needed a large cash flow. At one point he had 400 employees, including superintendents, with an office staff of 150. He entered into ventures with Time Equities, Inc., amajor converter, and received financing from Mark Scharfman, a mortgage lender. According to Mr. Pereira, Mr. Gin gave control of 60 properties to one or the other.
The major Artha buying spree came in 1988. "Gin bought more in 1988 than in all the other years combined," said Mr. Pereira. "He created the market in Harlem. If others would pay $1.5 million, he would pay $2 million."
The management that has inherited most of this inventory is Norwax Associates, a 30-year-old firm based at 1 East Fordham Road. Norwax is managing 55 properties for the United States trustee.
"Artha was rehabilitating apartments and renting them out for $600 to $900," said Jerome Waxenberg, a principal in Norwax. "They only problem is that in many of those locations people can't afford rents that high. It's only a question of time before a lot of those tenants default."
Mr. Waxenberg said he would lower asking rents in vacant apartments of many buildings to make them affordable to people earning about $18,000 a year. People at that income are not likely to be able comfortably to afford rents of more than $500 a month.
Mr. Waxenberg gave the example of the three occupied buildings that Artha renovated at 145-155 Edgecombe Avenue in Harlem. "It was a decent job," he said. "They did steamcleaning and pointing, put in new windows, new boiler and burner, new front doors, new intercom, new apartment entry door on all units, new roof." The building needed the work, he said. But the problem is that the market cannot afford the rents asked for the vacant apartments. Moreover, since some existing tenants have trouble meeting the new rent levels, delinquencies have risen.
ACCORDING to Mr. Pereira, the trustee, payments have been suspended on the mortgage liabilities and debt to general creditors, and money from rents is going to operations and escrow accounts for taxes to the city, which total $2.2 million a year. Creditors will be repaid gradually from the proceeds of sales of the buildings.
As for Freddie Mac, many outsiders believe the seeds of its loan problems were planted by the underwriting standards it adopted when it determined to build up its portfolio of urban multifamily loans in the 80's. It was lending $8 for every $10 of appraised value, but standard appraisal techniques may have given a rosier picture of operations of New York City moderate-income apartment house than justified.
Some mortgage brokers who got Freddie Mac financing for building owners -- so-called servicing agents -- were offering income data based not on actually collected rents but rather on nominal legal rents, insufficiently accounting for the gap caused by delinquencies. Values were derived from "comparable" market sales, which were often at prices driven by expectations of near-term co-op conversions. And the amounts of capital needed for maintenance and repair were sometimes drastically underestated.
Furthermore, some owners compounded the problem by getting second and third mortgages on properties, often without authorization from the first mortgagee. Now large increases in property taxes and sewer and water charges are combining to threaten overfinanced buildings even more. Increases in fuel oil prices loom. And a weaker economy may have weakened rent-paying ability generally. Some owners declined to take all the financing that Freddie Mac was offering. Others evidently overindulged.
Now, as many buildings are seen to need such expensive improvements as new plumbing, it becomes difficult to provide the financing without partially writing off existing loans.
A year ago, representatives of the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition went to visit Freddie Mac officials to complain about conditions in various buildings Freddie Mac had financed, and last October they met with them again.
Coalition leaders said they urged the mortgage lender to assure enforcement of repair clauses in their mortgages, resume lending but in a "responsible" fashion only, and consider turning over foreclosed properties to tenant associations and nonprofit housing companies.
Nonprofit companies are unlikely to be able to put enough of their own capital into a purchase to satisy creditors. At the same time, merely to change operators in overfinanced properties can be a recipe for decline when operating costs -- for water, taxes and fuel -- are rising. The financial underpinning of housing must be secure before decent housing conditions can be expected.

HEADLINE: Talking: Energy Use;
Steps To Lower Fuel Bills

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THE specter of going through the winter with sky-high heating and utility bills is a powerful reminder of the need to revive some of the energy-saving measures that lapsed into disuse after fuel prices dropped in the late 70's. The measures are also worth considering because they could help make a home easier to sell.
"Since the oil scare began in August, buyers have been asking a lot more questions about energy-saving devices when they go to look at a home," said Ginni Treadwell, manager of the Madison, Conn., office of Prudential Connecticut Realty. "They want to know about insulation levels and how they can bring more sunlight into a house. They ask about the availability and cost of wood. In the last two weeks I've even had questions about which way a house was facing -- questions we haven't heard in years." 
Take, for example, the attic, traditionally viewed by experts as the most important place to insulate and therefore one that most people would assume was adequately treated during the energy crisis of the 70's.
 Not so. A 1988 survey by the Alliance to Save Energy, a nonprofit group based in Washington, suggests that 60 percent of the one-family houses in the Northeast may still have underprotected roofs. While attic insulation should be 10 to 14 inches deep, the houses surveyed typically had only 4 to 6 inches.
"We were astounded by the results," said Bion D. Howard, a researcher with the Alliance. "The older homes were especially low."
 In some cases, homeowners had been misinformed about their needs. In others, the low level of insulation came from what is known in the industry as "diminution" -- shrinkage resulting from improper materials, faulty installation or roof damage. Thus Mr. Howard recommends that all homeowners check their attics, especially if a new roof has been installed within 10 years or there has been a change of ownership.
 The alliance also discovered that many homes and multifamily buildings still use single-pane windows, despite the barrage of publicity about the value of storm windows or double-paned replacement windows.
"We know that single-pane glass is 10 times less energy efficient than a wall," Mr. Howard said, "and that a change would provide one of the highest returns on investment."
 The other major recommendation from the alliance is to install a "smart" clock thermostat. Considered a costly hi-tech item 10 years ago, it is now available from most hardware stores for around $30. It can be easily installed by a homeowner and programmed to automatically lower the heat at night and in those day hours when family members are normally out of the house.
 However, Mr. Howard warned against lowering the temperature more than about 10 degrees below normal at any time. Too much energy will be needed to get the temperature back to comfort level.
 State-financed low-cost, or even no-cost, loans are still available in most areas for energy-related improvements. Details can normally be obtained through the state's energy office (under state listings in the blue pages or by calling the National Association of State Energy Officials at 1-202-639-8749 for a local referral). In some places the local utility companies are handling such loans.
 Utilities also do home energy audits. These started about 12 years ago and although some were dropped when consumer enthusiasm and energy prices started waning in the mid 1980's, a sizable number remain. New York, for example, still requires its utility companies to offer these audits free.
 Consider the Long Island Lighting Company's updated SAVINGPOWER audit program. Available for any home built before 1980, it is conducted by an energy specialist who spends about an hour in the home and provides a written report three weeks later that analyzes the needs and estimates the relative energy efficiency of the mechanical systems and major appliances.
OF particular interest is a new feature the utility started in July. It calculates the percentage of the monthly bill consumed by a particular appliance -- say, the refigerator. "We tend to forget how much of our bill is due to the appliances we use every day," said Mary Ring, Lilco's energy conservation supervisor.
 One homeowner, for example, was told that 26 percent of her electric bill was traceable to the air-conditioners, even though it had been a relatively cool month.
"It could have meant they had some old window units that needed replacing or were inadequate for the space," said Ms. Ring. "Or perhaps the family was leaving the air-conditioning running longer than necessary. In any event, it gave them the opportunity to think about making some useful changes."
 The energy audits are showing, she said, that the refrigerator is probably a household's worst energy guzzler, representing, on average, 25 percent of a month's bill. One reason is that most are more than 10 years old and thus built when energy efficency was not a serious design consideration.
"Also, most people don't clean the coils," said Ms. Ring. "The seals also get worn."
Replacement might therefore be a worthwhile investment. Other energy could be saved, said Ms. Ring, by remembering to run a dryer or dishwasher only with a full load.
The American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, a nine-year-old conservation group with headquarters in Washington, has just published a 250-page paperback book called "The 1991 Consumer Guide to Home Energy Savings." Full of brand name evaluations to help a homeowner make more knowledgable purchases and including useful life style tips, it is scheduled to be in most bookstores starting this month for $6.95.
 Warren Cronacher, president of Tauscher Cronacher, home inspectors of Rockville Centre, L.I., warns against the following common blunders he notices in homes he visits and that he maintains gobble energy: allowing plush carpeting to prevent baseboard heaters from circulating hot air freely, leaving a fireplace damper open when it is not in use, leaving the garage door open day and night and forgetting to seal off an attic fan in the winter.

HEADLINE: Development Rights, Affordable Housing

 BODY:
The article "State Program Keeps 'Em Down on the Farm" (Oct. 28) underestimates the significant economic and social costs of the state program of buying development rights from farmers. Obviously, for the state to pay $8,000 to 9,000 an acre for such rights appears a bit frivolous during a time of economic and budget crisis.
More importantly, this program incurs an even greater economic and social cost by actively discouraging the development of affordable housing at a time when the same state government is trying to encourage such construction. Typically, affordable housing is most likely to be built on farmland peripheral to urban areas such as Levittown in the 1950's, the San Fernando Valley in Southern California, and rural areas of Connecticut. Low land prices provide developers the opportunity to create housing at affordable prices. 
 When the state effectively removes land from the marketplace, the government directly eliminates one affordable housing development opportunity. Like restrictive zoning, government purchases of development rights reduces the supply of developable land and drives up the cost of the neighboring land and housing.
It is not surprising that farmers and their neighbors, who economically benefit from higher land prices, are advocates of the state's program of purchasing development rights.
 
JIM PURNELL
 
Greenwich

HEADLINE: Opponents Remain Wary as Pipeline Construction Approaches

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
AFTER a four-year fight, backers of the newly approved $600 million natural-gas pipeline from Canada to Long Island say that they are hoping to begin construction in Connecticut in the early spring.
The first task will be to obtain the remaining rights of way for the Connecticut portion of the 370-mile pipeline, which should be easier now that a Federal agency has approved the project, said Gary Davis, a spokesman for the Iroquois Gas Transmission System, the pipeline's developer. 
 About 40 percent of the land needed for the project in New York and Connecticut has already been obtained, he said, although the percentage for Connecticut alone is probably lower. Iroquois had encountered resistance from some propety owners along the route, Mr. Davis said, adding that much of that opposition should evaporate, now that the project has been licensed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The commission gave unanimous approval to the project on Nov. 14.
In addition to seeking the rights of way, he said, Iroquois will begin seeking bids for the purchase of pipe and building materials and for the construction of the underground pipeline. "We just signed an order for $91 million worth of pipe," Mr. Davis said.
Since it was proposed more than four years ago, the pipeline, which will carry natural gas from western Canada to six Northeastern states, had engendered bitter opposition. Steven J. Whitman, executive director of the Housatonic Valley Association in Cornwall, which has been active in the pipeline fight, said his group will soon decide whether to appeal the decision.
 
Positive Changes Noted
 "We haven't made a decision on appealing it yet," Mr. Whitman said. "Despite the fact that we're in disagreement with the decision, we feel there have been many changes which have been positive." He noted that the pipeline route is now shorter than originally proposed, and an auxiliary pipeline, known as the Farmington Lateral, which would have crossed through several additional Connecticut towns, was dropped.
Anyone seeking to appeal the license ruling must file a petition for a rehearing within 30 days; the commission then has 30 more days to respond. Only after that would a complainant be allowed to file an appeal in Federal court.
The gas will be sent from western Canada to Iroquois, Ontario, through the Trans-Canada pipeline, and then south into New York State at Waddington. It would cross the Hudson River south of Albany and turn east at Poughkeepsie. The pipeline would enter Connecticut at Sherman and pass through New Milford, Brookfield, Newtown, Monroe, Shelton, Stratford and Milford before crossing Long Island Sound to Northport, L.I.
Mr. Davis said the pipeline will be built in three stages, with the first, under Long Island Sound, proceeding this winter. Construction on the Canada-to-Albany segment would start in April 1991 and continue through October, he said. The rest of the pipeline is to be built between June and December 1991. Gas will start flowing to Albany next November, he said, and through the entire pipeline in January 1992.
The project is backed by a consortium of 13 fuel and energy companies in Canada, New York, Connecticut, and other parts of the United States.
Iroquois said it will maintain close contact with the Connecticut Siting Council, the state agency that has jurisdiction over the pipeline. In October, the council approved the pipeline's Connecticut portion. But that approval came with several stipulations designed to insure proper construction, said the council's executive director, Joel Reinbold.
"This is a very large, complicated project which has the potential for a great deal of environmental damage," Mr. Reinbold said, adding that the council will require a "very, very refined version of the construction plan."
 
Independent Inspections
 In addition, he said, the council is requiring Iroquois to submit detailed plans on the protection of trees and vegetation along the route, as well as marine life, like the oyster beds in the Housatonic River and Long Island Sound.
Special construction techniques in environmentally sensitive areas must be used, he said, and land inhabited by songbirds and used for wintering over by bald eagles must be taken into consideration. The council is also requiring independent inspections of the construction, Mr.Reinbold said.
Mr. Davis said he does not foresee any problems in complying with the Siting Council's requirements.
During its discussion earlier this month, the chairman of the Federal commission referred to the Iroquois issue as "one of the most contentious" to come before the panel. Since the filing of the plans in the spring of 1986, the proposal has sparked much opposition along the proposed route, which changed during the years of debate.
The path was shifted to spare several Litchfield County towns originally on the pipeline's route. Opponents said the change was made because of opposition from the towns' politically influential and famous residents. The pipeline's backers maintain that the shift was made for economic reasons.
Among those expressing disappointment at the Federal regulators' decision was Terry Jones, a fifth-generation farmer whose Jones Tree Farm in Shelton lies in the path of the pipeline. He said the project imperils the future of his farm, as well as others along the route.
"In our case, it threatens to open up access corridors from highways and subdivisions," Mr. Jones said. "It'll be a pathway, and vehicles could cut across it, which is really why we're opposed to it."
 
Echoes of Persian Gulf
 Mr. Jones added that now that the pipeline has been approved, he is "hopeful that the people making decisions on the final route will be sensitive to our concerns."
Henry Dutton, chairman of the Northwest Sherman Civic Association, said he is very upset about the approval. He said the Federal regulators acted hastily, possibly because of the perceived threat to the nation's oil supply posed by the Persian Gulf crisis.
"There's been so much hysteria over this Gulf situation and the impact it has on oil, that it's been hard for the ordinary person to evaluate," Mr. Dutton said. "But it really is a tempest in a teapot."
Liba Fuhrman, chairwoman of the Stop the Pipeline organization in New Milford, said an appeal is still possible, although it depends on what other groups want to do.
If construction does proceed, she said, "We'll be working very closely with the Connecticut Siting Council," to make sure all precautions are taken.
But Patricia Pellegrini, head of Newtown Opposition to Pipeline Encroachment, said she did not see how the project could be stopped.
"At this point," she said, "we've done as much as we can do."

HEADLINE: Regional Approach To Services Reconsidered

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
IN a recent speech at the New Jersey State League of Municipalities convention in Atlantic City, Gov. Jim Florio, as a way of countering the state's mounting fiscal crisis, exhorted municipal officials to take a new look at an old idea: regionalization of municipal services.
The concept of regionalization, which has had a long and controversial history in New Jersey, is perceived by some as the antithesis of the state's time-honored doctrine of home rule and by others as the most efficient and cost-effective way of running the state's 567 municipalities. 
 Some say that regionalization makes elected officials less accountable by shifting responsibility for important municipal functions to "anonymous bureaucrats."
Police and fire officials say that regionalized public safety departments would not be as responsive to citizens' needs as a local department and that it would be difficult under the best of circumstances to combine varying contractual agreements covering salaries, pensions, medical benefits and vacations. Proponents of regionalization, however, say the idea has proved effective in such areas as cooperative purchasing systems, already in place in most counties, and in the 70 regional school systems now operating in the state.
The call for a greater focus on regionalization comes as administration officials grapple with a declining economy, an angry electorate and the realization that despite recent tax increases, decreasing revenue will result in a $600 million shortfall in the state budget.
"I don't need to convince most of you about the merits of regionalization," Mr. Florio said in his speech to municipal officials 10 days ago. He cited examples of successful regionalization efforts like joint libraries, combined police and fire communication systems, countywide recycling programs and shared health inspectors.
"I think regionalization will have popular support as well," Mr. Florio said. "People care a lot more that they get good services at good prices than they care about who is actually providing those services."
But political experts say that Mr. Florio's assumption of popular support for regionalization may be unjustifiably optimistic.
"Everybody talks about greater efficiency," said Dr. George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of city planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "But in a society like ours, people want the ability to walk down to City Hall and holler, and they're going to be kind of upset if somebody takes that ability away from them."
 
From Town Hall to 'Anonymous Place'
 The establishment of regionalized municipal services, Dr. Sternlieb said, does just that.
"The real functions of government, and the people to complain to, disappear from your local Town Hall and reappear in some anonymous place," he said.
In addition, Dr. Sternlieb said, regionalization will meet with opposition from many local officials who will be hesitant to relinquish control of important municipal entities like police and fire departments and municipal courts.
"It absolutely obliterates home rule," Dr. Sternlieb said. "You'll have the name but not the essence."
Home rule has long been highly valued in New Jersey. Essentially, home rule allows local officials to govern their municipalities with little outside interference. At the same time, it also provides residents with relatively accessible officials who are directly responsible for municipal functions.
And while most officials agree that regionalization will at the very least dilute the concept of home rule, some legislators say that municipal officials may have to make that sacrifice in order to keep tax increases to a minimum.
"I happen to believe that home rule is a good servant but a harsh master," said State Senator Gabriel M. Ambrosio, Democrat of Lyndhurst. "But we've got to make government smarter and more efficient because the tax dollar is constantly shrinking."
<> <> Mr. Ambrosio said he and other lawmakers were looking for ways to legislatively encourage regionalization without requiring it.
 
Throwing Out the 'Carrot'
 "What we're trying to do is come up with program of financial incentives that rewards municipalities for combining their resources," he said. "We want to throw out the carrot, but we don't want to see regionalization mandated by Trenton."
The Assembly minority leader, Garabed Haytaian, Republican of Independence, said that while he agreed that regionalization should not be required, he did not believe that financial incentives should be used as "a carrot and a stick."
"That's still a mandate, and in New Jersey today, mandates are not looked to very kindly," Mr. Haytaian said. "I would rather see municipalities agree to regionalize without giving them any outside incentives."
 
Joint Street-Paving Program
 With varying degrees of success, some municipalities have already made attempts at combining their resources. The Bergen County towns of North Arlington, Lyndhurst and Wood-Ridge, for example, recently entered into a joint street-paving program.
"We all share the same engineer, so we went out for joint bids on projects in all three towns," said Mayor Leonard Kaiser of North Arlington. "If we are going to have to make do with less, then we're going to have to get into more of these cooperative agreements."
But some municipal services, Mr. Kaiser said, may not be as easy to combine with other towns as street paving. "When I call the police," he said, "I want a North Arlington police officer to show up at my door."
That sentiment is shared by residents of the Warren County borough of Alpha, whose police department was combined with that of neighboring Pohatcong in 1981. "A majority of the residents were displeased," said Chief John Hajdu of the Alpha Police Department. "They felt that they lost their personal touch with the police department."
The two departments worked together for five years, Chief Hajdu said, before voters in Alpha put the issue on the ballot and returned to separate departments in 1986.
 
'Both Desperately Shorthanded'
 And though residents of the two towns once again have their own police departments, that change did not come without a cost.
"Now we're both desperately shorthanded," Chief Hajdu said. He added that from a public safety perspective, the merger had been successful; the problem, he said, was the public's perception.
"The two governments rushed into it without any planning," he said. "But the people just weren't prepared for it."
Officials in Bridgewater, Somerville, Branchburg and Raritan, who are also considering consolidating services, are hoping to avoid that kind of mistake.
"We have embarked on a major program of merging, consolidation and regionalization," said Mayor James T. Dowden of Bridgewater. Officials of the four municipalities have set up separate task forces to look into the merging of police departments, public works departments, courts and school systems.
 
School and Court Systems
 While consolidation of police departments and public works departments require mainly economic analyses and logistical changes, the merger of municipal courts and school systems appear to be more complicated. By law, when municipal courts are combined, for example, the power to appoint judges and prosecutors passes from local officials to the Governor's office.
And with regard to regionalizing school systems, Mr. Dowden said, officials are finding that they cannot consolidate on a trial basis first to assess the effectiveness of the merger. "You can't try things with the school systems," Mr. Dowden said. "The law provides for marriage and no divorce."
Many school systems, however, have already successfully regionalized.
"There are 70 regional school districts containing many municipalities of many different sizes," said Frank Belluscio, spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, a federation of more than 600 local school boards.
 
Diversity in Courses
 The incentive for regionalization of school systems, Mr. Belluscio said, is increased services at lower costs. Course offerings, for example, can be more diverse in a larger school system and the financial incentives are readily apparent.
"Automatically you find you have to employ fewer people," he said. "Instead of having two superintendents of schools, for example, you suddenly have one."
Another area of successful cooperation among local governments involves cooperative purchasing. Daniel Kaminski, a community service officer in the State Department of Community Affairs, said there were 29 cooperative purchasing systems registered in the state. Those systems consist of 678 different governmental entities.
"Municipalities, school boards, counties, commissions -- all have common needs," Mr. Kaminski said. When several group together, he said, buying power increases, "and everybody gets a better price."
Not all municipal services can be so easily regionalized, however, and the example often cited is fire protection.
 
Fire Protection Studied
 In Hudson County, for instance, officials have conducted at least two studies over the last 20 years aimed at combining municipal fire departments; one examined the possibility of a countywide department, and the other assessed the merits of a North Hudson department. Neither study resulted in any change in the fire departments themselves, though officials did establish a fire communications system serving all of North Hudson.
William F. Flynn, president of the New Jersey State Firemen's Benevolent Association, a Rahway-based union representing 5,100 of the state's firefighters, said there were built-in obstacles to forming a regional fire department when starting with established departments.
Salaries differ from municipality to municipality, he said, as do health benefits, vacations, minimum staffing requirements, sick leave and other contractual agreements.
In addition, he said, in a combined department there are usually fewer promotions available, making regionalization objectional to the rank and file, and there is always the issue of which chief will ultimately be in charge.
On the other hand, Mr. Flynn said, there might be a hidden advantage for firefighters who find themselves part of a regional fire department.
"Maybe the towns will all get together and choose the contract with the highest salaries, and the best benefits and give them to all involved," he said.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
PATRICIA GRIFFIN and her two children started this year living in a single room at the Carlton, one of Newark's biggest welfare hotels. They had spent a dreary Christmas there. They had marked a bleak New Year's there. They worried they might be in that room for a long time.
Then her social worker told Ms. Griffin about Harmony House, a transitional housing complex in the Central Ward. Ms. Griffin did not know anything about Harmony House, but she knew it had to be better than the rank hallways of the Carlton. 
 On Feb. 23 she packed her family's belongings into seven plastic garbage bags, loaded them onto the back of a large truck that made the bags seem even more inadequate, and rode up front with the driver to Harmony House. On her first day in the one-bedroom apartment where she was supposed to put back together the shattered pieces of her life, she swore she would be out by June.
"I think I can do it," she told a reporter a few days later. "As a matter of fact, I am going to do it."
Almost nine months later, on a wind-whipped day in the middle of November, Ms. Griffin was still at Harmony House. Desire, even conviction, it turns out, had not been enough. Not in Newark. In an interview, she admitted that part of the reason she had not yet found her own place was that for a while she simply stopped trying. It was too hard to go on, too easy to just sit back and let somebody else worry about her.
But it was more than just that temporary lapse that trapped Ms. Griffin, and those other causes underscore how intractable this problem of homelessness has become in the cities of New Jersey and the nation.
They are not in the news much anymore, especially when the weather remains unseasonably warm, but the homeless are still out there. Some 700,000 on any given night are sheltered by the streets or good will, according to the National Alliance to End Homelessness.
People like Ms. Griffin did not benefit directly from the economic expansion of the 1980's. She did graduate from Shabazz High School in Newark, but that did little to prepare her for the kind of jobs available today. And besides, though she graduated in 1975 when she was just 15 years old, with high marks in math, history and English, Ms. Griffin had a baby the following year.
She has not always been on welfare. She used to work as a security guard, and just over a year ago she was working at the big garage on Doremus Avenue, logging in buses. She had her own two-bedroom apartment on South 12th Street and although she did not earn much money, she felt good about making it on her own, in spite of the odds against her.
But then she was pushed flat against the wall by fate. Her 10-year-old daughter, Chantrey Ladonna, fell while playing in one of Newark's many vacant lots, shattering her hip and forcing Ms. Griffin to stay home and take care of her. Ms. Griffin lost the job at the garage. Then one day a city inspector knocked on the door of her apartment. The building had been condemned. She had a week to move.
Ms. Griffin found herself at the welfare office on Rector Street, bewildered and looking for help. Someone used the word homeless, and she thought they were talking about somebody else, not her.
That night she, Chantrey and 14-year-old Lamont were sent to one small room at the Carlton, just one cell of bad luck amid a whole building of misfortune.
Every victim has a refuge, and Ms. Griffin's is laughter. "I'm not a complainer," she says, smiling. She got the hotel managers to give her a board to put on the bed so her children would have a desk on which to do homework. She bought cold cuts and fast food and tried to keep the children from dwelling on their bad luck. When they started to whine, she told them: "Stick with me for a while. I'm doing the best I can."
Not far away, the Harmony House complex was just opening its doors. A project of a nonprofit local group called the New Community Corporation and a big commercial developer, Hartz Mountain Industries, the 102-unit building was designed and built as temporary housing in which families, like Ms. Griffin's, could find their way out of despair.
As they filled the tight new apartments with single mothers and their children, Harmony House administrators invited Ms. Griffin. She was told that an apartment, with a kitchenette and bath, would be hers, but not forever. The closets have no doors, to remind people that Harmony House is intended to provide a transition, not a future. No one is expected to be there more than one year.
So far, the Harmony House concept appears to have worked. Jeanette Page-Hawkins, the top administrator, said 78 families had passed through, entering homeless, exiting to jobs and apartments. They stayed an average of 130 days.
While the successes have been many, Ms. Page-Hawkins said, some have slipped though the cracks. "What went wrong with Patricia, I really couldn't tell you," she said. "Finding the right place that's affordable is not something you can just do."
But Ms. Page-Hawkins said she did not consider Ms. Griffin's time at Harmony House, even as she approaches her deadline to get out, a failure. "We find success in a person increasing her educational levels or improving her job seeking skills," Ms. Page-Hawkins said.
Ms. Griffin met with employment counselors and went on job interviews. When she had time, she also took buses to apartments that real-estate agents found for her. But she never seemed to find the job that suited her or the apartment she could afford.
"I got depressed all over again," she said. "What was the use? Forget it. I'm not going to look anymore. I'm not going to do anything."
But Harmony House would not let her just sit back. The easiest way to make the Harmony administrators happy was to walk across South Orange Avenue to the re-election headquarters of Councilman George Branch of the Central Ward.
There she found more than busy work. "He said, 'Give it another try,' " Ms. Griffin said. "He treated me like I was his daughter."
Not long after the campaign, a representative came to Harmony House from the World of Foods, a courtyard of seven kiosks in the new Pathmark mall a few blocks away. Ms. Griffin was hired on the spot. Now she works the cash register, or serves food or cleans tables. She started at $4 an hour and has moved up to $4.50. She is there six days a week.
She has found a two-bedroom apartment in East Orange that costs $450 a month. Her welfare grant comes to $424, and she thinks her social worker will let her take the apartment, certain she will be able to pay the rent without falling behind.
Ms. Page-Hawkins said it was unlikely that Ms. Griffin or any other person at Harmony House would be evicted after one year. But she said she really wanted them to understand that Harmony House was not home.
Now that she is close to being on her own again, Ms. Griffin says being homeless was not so bad. She had expected to have to sleep in the subway. Instead, she found people who wanted to help.
The worst part of it all, she said, is wondering what memories of the last year might do to her children. She is hoping that Lamont and Chantrey will be able to forget all about the Carlton and even about Harmony House because of all the failure they represent.
"I'm still hoping they can chalk it up as a bad dream," she said. "Once we move out of here, and I really think I can do that, once we leave there's no reason we will ever have to come back."

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER

 BODY:
Smith's article reminded me of stories I heard in June while running a seminar on American literature in "occupied" Estonia. My students, middle-aged teachers of high-school English, were excited about Estonian moves for independence; and while they were worried about repercussions from Moscow and a skidding economy, they often seemed more concerned about the lasting effects of decades of Russian control. A whole generation has been infected by what one teacher called the "Russian disease." She spoke of her two teen-age sons who are rebelling at the idea of attending the university: "Why? So we can end up like you? And wait 10 years for an apartment?" One of them wants to be a doorman at a restaurant, where he'll get big tips and the chance to purchase booze and meat that he can use to get his name moved up on lists for apartments, and the like. The other, for similar reasons, wants to drive a van or cab.
All of these teachers spoke, as did Smith, of the warmth and generosity of individual Russians, but they wondered how long it might take for Estonians to become truly independent of Russian attitudes about work and social responsibility.
 
GARY L. AHO
Professor of English, The University of Massachusetts at Amherst
Amherst, Mass.

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER

 BODY:
No doubt about it, Russians have pilfered from the state for years. Blat (connections) is a way of life. As it is in the United States. Even in the Green Mountains where neighbor trusts neighbor and you can leave your key in your car, innkeepers, to keep their licenses, give inspectors whatever they want. And is not the world's biggest and most destructive influence peddling -- the savings and loan robbery -- done under Federal regulation with Government connivance?
As a market economy develops, some Russians may become as selfish as some capitalists or as corrupt as some drug dealers. But, for the time being, most Russians remain stolidly normal, deeply upset, for example, about founding an exchange that willy-nilly, by selling and buying stock shares, will legalize 250 million black-market rubles. No junk bonds for them.
Most Russians, like most peoples in the Soviet Union, have lived in poverty for generations. One ruling class after another has imposed it on them. Economic reform, guided by middle-class values and promising technological comforts, now makes a new perspective possible, no matter how improbable it may seem in this bleak winter. The Russians are victims of their circumstances, not of their character, which is their own and as fine as anybody's.
 
F. D. REEVE
Mount Holly, Vt.

LENGTH: 2881 words

HEADLINE: Tanii-san Goes Fishing in Hollywood

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: OSAKA , Japan

 BODY:
A FEW weeks ago, Akio Tanii, president of the world's biggest consumer electronics manufacturer, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, invited his nemesis over for dinner. It was Norio Ohga, president of the Sony Corporation. No one will say much about what they talked about, but history may record it as Japan's back-to-the-future rendition of the days when Louis B. Mayer dined with Samuel Goldwyn.
Indeed, by all appearances, it was a meeting of Hollywood's two newest movie moguls. 
 A year ago, Mr. Ohga engineered Sony's $5 billion buyout of Columbia Pictures; before that, he got CBS Records. In the past few days, operating by phone and fax from Osaka, Mr. Tanii intensified negotiations on a $7 billion or so deal for MCA Inc., the owner of Universal Studios, one of the country's biggest record labels, a publishing house, theme parks and large chunks of Los Angeles real estate.
If Matsushita and Lew R. Wasserman, MCA's chairman, reach a final agreement, as now appears likely, Mr. Tanii and Mr. Ohga will control more than a quarter of the American movie market, a fact that does not sit well with the many who regard movies as the ultimate expression of American culture. MCA, after all, would be the fourth major American studio (the others are MGM/UA and 20th Century Fox) to fall under foreign ownership, the inevitable result of Hollywood's voracious appetite for new capital it cannot get at home.
In the negotiations, Matsushita has made it clear that it feels compelled to follow the still-unproved logic that hardware and software must be combined. That is, the giant maker of consumer electronics devices now feels compelled to control the huge variety of movie, music and television products packaged to run on their machines. And, like Sony, Matsushita feels it can achieve that dream only be owning a major movie studio, even if it cannot yet explain exactly why.
 
Eye on a Tuna, Net on a Whale
 For Japan, Hollywood suddenly seems both an irresistable lure -- and a potential disaster, both economic and political. At a time when America is worried that too many decisions are being made for it in Japan, Matsushita is betting that his country's second venture in Hollywood will be more easily accepted than the first. But there is clearly tension over the matter. And even Matsushita's leaders here seemed startled by the thought of their buying into Hollywood on such a scale. As one said of Masahiko Hirata, who was leading the negotiations in New York:
"He went fishing for tuna, and he came back with a whale."
For his part, Mr. Ohga says he thought better of giving his dinner host any specific advice about how to survive in the same pool with the studio that made "Jaws."
 "Tanii-san, he is such a gentleman, I love him," mused Mr. Ohga, a former opera singer who at times is even beginning to sound like a studio executive. "But this is a whole different world, and he doesn't know it yet. I still have to turn a switch in my mind, thinking about hardware and then thinking about software. It will take him a while to learn, too."
In Osaka these days the question is whether Matsushita, the reluctant multinational, can really learn to flip the switch.
Without question, Mr. Tanii has in the past four years successfully awakened the company from its post-videocassette revolution lethargy. He has created a computer division to take on International Business Machines and Fujitsu, turned the company into a major force in industrial equipment and semiconductors and wrestled to consolidate a vast Matsushita empire that embraces 87 Japanese companies and nearly as many abroad. Yet Matsushita, known in the United States particularly for its Panasonic consumer electronics products, has always depended more on sheer size than Sony-type savvy. And there are many people in Osaka who think that this time Matsushita's first instinct -- to follow Sony's lead -- could prove far more treacherous than fighting it out over ever-smaller Walkmans, high-definition televisions, fancier video cameras and the newest in computer chips.
"We are taking an enormous risk," said a Matsushita senior manager, insisting on anonymity. "It is difficult to say if people are more excited or more scared."
If Sony seems a bicultural child, born in Japan but raised in California, Matsushita is a place where most employees still wear drab blue uniforms that give them the vague look of air-conditioner repairmen and learn by heart the lyrics of the company song, "Love, Light and a Dream," which blares from loudspeakers at 8:30 A.M. and again at the end of the day. Though they deny it, it seems unbelievable that had Matsushita's executives not been dragged into Hollywood by a fear of Mr. Ohga, they would venture any further than the movie theaters near Osaka Station. Though Mr. Tanii has spoken frequently of his company's new "areas of emphasis," he had never before mentioned entertainment software. That was always something left to a weak subsidiary, JVC.
 
Three Sets of Risk
 The risks, insiders say, are threefold. The first is a question of vision. So far, beyond the usual platitudes about the "synergy between software and hardware," the company has yet to articulate its strategy for turning Universal's backlots and vast film library ("Jaws," "E.T. -- The Extraterrestrial" and "Back to the Future") into a strategic asset. The company's top executives, Mr. Tanii included, have declined to be interviewed on the subject. But many of the company's own employees say they are mystified about the exact reasons for the new undertaking.
The answer may simply be control -- control of the software that will be placed on everything from the CD's and video disks to CD-ROMS, computer disks packed with data, music and pictures all intermingled in what is coming to be known as "multimedia." Then there is high-definition television; beyond that, mediums yet uninvented.
"It is a chance to buy one-sixth of a unique industry," says Fay Vincent, head Coca Cola's entertainment business when it owned Columbia Pictures and now baseball commissioner. "Every major Japanese consumer-electronics company must be thinking: 'If we don't control it, who will?' "
The second set of risks is political. Sony's purchase of Columbia raised a storm of protest in the United States that centered on whether the message of Hollywood's powerful medium -- to say nothing about its profits -- should be controlled from Japan. Sony quelled those concerns largely because its white-haired, omnipresent chairman, Akio Morita, used his wit, his fluent English and Washington contacts to convince America that it would keep its hands off Columbia.
Matsushita and MCA have already been tripping over each other on this point. Even as negotiations were under way, MCA dispatched politically connected board members and lobbyists to spread the message that the deal is designed to infuse the American company with much-needed cash and that current management will continue to call the creative shots. But back in Japan, Matsushita has declined several chances to offer any reassurances of a hands-off approach. And when American Jewish groups complained last month that Matsushita still observes the Arab trade embargo against Israel, implying that that should be a guide as to how the company will deal with controversial movies, Matsushita's executives froze, refusing to discuss the issue.
Matsushita seems to be betting that a second Hollywood purchase will be easier than the first, especially at a time when Congress is preoccupied with a potential war in the Middle East. But Tokyo makes no secret of its discomfort. "We are worried about the potential reaction of Americans," said Yukiharu Kodama, Vice Minister of the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry. "If I am asked by Mr. Tanii, I would say, 'Be very careful.' "
Finally, there is the risk that Matsushita's management team will not be able to learn to run an entertainment business, a business that bears as little resemblance to consumer electronics as grimy, crowded Osaka does to Beverly Hills. Even at Sony -- a company that ran a joint venture in the record business, the CBS/Sony Group, for two decades before it plunged headfirst into music and movies -- there are continuing questions about whether the company could be bled dry by Hollywood producers who see Japan's electronics giants as a source of financing for huge movie projects that may never turn a profit.
Matsushita could be even more vulnerable.
But if ever a company knew how to turn humble goals into oversized returns it is this giant founded by Konosuke Matsushita in 1918, with $50 and an idea for a new kind of electric light socket. By the time he died here last year, Mr. Matsushita was hailed not only as a genious of management and manufacturing, but as the man who had brought the everyday appliances of life -- rice cookers, televisions, bicycles, kerosene heaters -- to a society still emerging from its feudal past.
More than two decades ago, just outside the company's modest-looking, low-rise headquarters here, Mr. Matsushita built a huge memorial to some of his heroes. At the center is a giant statue of Thomas A. Edison. Below him, smoking a cigar, is Anton Philips, the Dutch industrialist whose giant company is now struggling for survival, chiefly because of competition from the likes of Matsushita. The circle around Edison's feet is completed by a series of Western inventors and theoreticians -- Andre Ampere, Gugielmo Marconi, Georg Ohm -- and some Japanese little known outside the archipelago. There are no movie producers.
In many ways, the statues defined Mr. Matsushita's vision. He was always something of a rebel, focusing on consumer products when the zaibatsu, the huge industrial groups that dominated Japanese business before World War II, largely served industrial customers. By the time war broke out, he had built his electric-socket maker into an enterprise employing 10,000 people. When the American occupation army finally took him off its list of businessmen to be "purged" for their contributions to Japan's war machine, the company had shrunk to a third its previous size. But not for long. Looking for quick growth, Mr. Matsushita bought JVC, a major air-conditioning company, a maker of facsimile machines, later even Quasar, Motorola's television business. "We have always done M.&A.," said Hiroyuki Mizuno, Matsushita's head of research and development. "It's just that we have usually done it in Japan."
 
The Ancestoral Way
 But if Mr. Matsushita became one of Japan's most famous industrialists, he was a purely Japanese phenomenon. While Sony concentrated on America, Matsushita built a remarkable network of distributors in tiny stores in every Japanese neighborhood. It entered the United States early, in 1953, and spread its tentacles throughout Asia, but that was not the focus. Japan, the founder once said, must bring about "prosperity without becoming dependent on foreign trade only. Our ancestors did it."
Only under Mr. Tanii, who took over in 1986, has the company begun to resemble a true multinational. Medium-tech goods like refrigerators and air conditioners are now shipped from outside Japan to the United States and sometimes to Japan itself, freeing Japanese factories for the highest value-added work. (The other day, in one of many moves to lessen its huge corporate trade surplus, Matsushita said it would begin to import 3,000 television tubes a month that it makes in the United States, where it is also producing mobile phones, batteries, microwave ovens and components for air conditioners and refrigerators.) Faster than almost any other company, Matsushita has automated and pared its manufacturing costs.
But between 1985 and 1989, Matsushita's video business declined 18 percent in yen terms; sales of audio equipment have barely budged in five years. "The VCR era came and went and Matsushita was among the last to adjust," said Boris Petersik, an analyst at Barclay's de Zoete Wedd in Tokyo. "Only now are they turning it around."
 
Learning How to Quarrel
 Until now, Matsushita's chief battleground has not been the movie set but rather a drab white building here, where engineers like Shigeo Kuninobu are scrambling to get back into the computer race that Matsushita once quit. Mr. Kuninobu and a few dozen young computer engineers have been working up a new line of engineering workstations. Most of those workstations have been developed in Longmont, Colo., by a startup company that Matsushita helped create and now controls, Solbourne Computer. Designing the computer from the processor up, Matsushita regularly sends teams of engineers to Colorado for months of training.
"We've learned how to quarrel," said Mr. Kuninobu. "Ordinarily it is not something you do here in Japan, so at first we were pretty confused." Matsushita is learning fast: It is making laptop computers for Tandy Corporation, Siemens and I.B.M. In Osaka, it is developing and advanced parallel processor, called Adena, a stab at the most advanced technology.
Matsushita is spending billions in its fight against Sony. Earlier this year it brought out the S1 "Single Hand Movie" camera, with features Sony lacks, such as a stabilizer to keep video images from shaking. Next Saturday, the same day as Sony, Matsushita will begin selling the world's first high-definition television sets -- for $34,000 apiece.
But turning now to Hollywood and the software battle, Matsushita may well find the cost of its new acquisition relatively small in the next few years compared with the enormous amount of management time that will be spent dealing with such a boom-and-bust industry. The cost of a big movie production these days runs about $60 million. Nevertheless, Japanese companies are finding Hollywood irresistible. Entertainment is what, in Japan's view, America is best at. It is the part of the business that defies Matsushita's skills. There is only so much of it around. And Matsushita does not want to miss out.
 
 
 
THE PERSONAL WEALTH OF MATSUSHITA
 WHEN Konosuke Matsushita died last year at the age of 94, he left not only a sprawling corporate empire but also what was easily the biggest estate in the history of Japan.
In life, Mr. Matsushita lived modestly, befitting a man who got his first job at age 9, as an errand boy, and raised capital by pawning his wife's kimono, so the legend goes. As his company's fortunes rose, he gave away a huge amount of his wealth, creating the Japan Prize and the Peace and Happiness Through Prosperity Institute, which now publishes an influential English-language magazine and scores of books. He built hospitals, recreational facilities and houses for his employees and a even special school he hoped would turn out honest politicians.
Still, at his death, according to the National Tax Bureau, Mr. Matsushita left an estate worth roughly $1.88 billion. Half of it went to his widow, and $687 million or so to his only child by marriage, a daughter.
Executing the will ran into complications, when four illegitimate children -- three sons and a daughter, each of a different mother -- emerged to claim shares. In the end, each of the four reportedly settled for $60 million to $70 million.

 
 
NORIO OHGA'S AMERICA
 WHEN the Sony Corporation paid $3.4 billion last year for Columbia Pictures -- and then upwards of $1.5 billion more for the services of one of Hollywood's hottest producing teams, Jon Peters and Peter Guber -- there was sniping on both sides of the Pacific that Sony would never make it all profitable. A year later, the sniping continues.
Sony does not report results for its subsidiaries, so it is impossible to tell exactly how the big venture on the silver screen is going. But evidence suggests the going is indeed rough.
Mr. Peters and Mr. Guber have been leading the way in Hollywood's rush to pay top dollar for scripts, directors and actors. And until recently, the box office take for films released by Columbia and its other studio operation, Tri-Star, has been nothing to write home about. "They will never make any money, ever," insists a top industry executive, who predicts that the talent will leave once Sony is no longer willing to finance their wildest dreams.
Norio Ohga, Sony's president, says that he has heard it all before, and is unworried. "I look at every budget," he says, and he has supported the big spending. "If we don't make really good movies, we throw away our money. Hollywood wants big movies now, and the production cost is high. But we can sell a big movie for 10 or 15 years." Anyway, Mr. Ohga argues, Columbia's revenues lately are above expectations and there were some profitable months in the fall.
But though Mr. Ohga has said he does not want to interfere with the "software" -- movies, music and TV programs -- he is spending a third of his time on the entertainment business, in part because of the head of CBS Records, which Sony bought in '88, was recently edged out. So much time on airplanes to the States, in fact, that Akio Morita, Sony's chairman, recently joked that corporate headquarters should be relocated to Anchorage.

A chart last Sunday headed "Matsushita and MCA Compared," with an article about the Matsushita Electric Industries Company's negotiation to buy MCA Inc., mislabeled equivalents of Matsushita's revenues and earnings for the years 1986 through 1989. HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Winners Are Those Who Didn't Play

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IN the late 1980's, the takeover game often seemed like the only game on Wall Street. Those who wouldn't play were dismissed as irrelevant. Now, it appears, the only survivors after this recession may be those who by luck or brains managed to stay on the sidelines. The rules have changed.
Michael Milken, the man who more than any other wrote the rules of the last decade, learned last week that in the new one he will have to either cooperate with the Government -- rat on his accomplices, to use the type of language normally reserved for a different class of criminal -- or spend a large part of this decade in prison. 
 It is widely believed that Mr. Milken will emerge from prison a rich man. But given that many of his investments seem to have been in securities of the leveraged companies that dominated the Drexel client list, it appears certain that he is less rich than he used to be, perhaps a lot less.
Another supposed winner, Martin Sorrell of Britain's WPP Group, who for a time seemed intent on gobbling up every advertising agency that his London rivals Saatchi & Saatchi failed to buy, last week allowed that profits were going to be a bit below forecasts. The stock fell $9.625, to $6.125 in New York trading. And that in a generally dull week when the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 23.02, to 2,527.23.
How can a profit disappointment cause a company to lose most of its value? Simple. The worry is that WPP will default on loans it took as it bought such agencies as J. Walter Thomson and Ogilvy & Mather. Last year's Ogilvy acquisition now seems especially expensive.
It is not Mr. Sorrell's fault that advertising revenues are soft in most markets of the world. But he seems to have left his company in a vulnerable position for that eventuality.
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation feels that weakness even more directly. Last month he was saying he did not want to sell assets in the current atmosphere of deteriorating prices. Now he is looking for buyers for $1 billion of properties as he asks the banks for easier terms on existing loans. Moody's last week cut the company's debt ratings from a relatively high level of "junk" to a lower one.
News shares have risen in the last couple of weeks, on the welcome news that the company had cut a deal to merge with its rival in British satellite television. But while that will stem some losses, assuming a new British Government does not block it, it does not solve News's need for cash.
A year ago, it would have been taken for granted that operations like WPP and News would simply borrow more money to keep going. But now there is, in Moody's delicate phrase, "greater conservatism within the capital markets," meaning that bankers have found religion when it comes to loan standards. And neither of those companies looks quite as sterling as it did a year ago.
Shareholders of both companies may have some nervous moments while waiting for the bankers to reach their decisions.
