HEADLINE: Business Diary/November 18-23

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Milken's Exile From the World That Milken Built
 
He spent tens of millions on his defense, and his lawyers were the very best. But on Wednesday, Michael R. Milken, the most powerful financier of his time, was sentenced to 10 years in prison, to be followed by 3 years of community service. It was the toughest sentence by far for anyone caught in Wall Street's recent scandals, from a judge familiar with the financial community's ways. Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood gave up a lucrative partnership in a New York law firm, specializing in antitrust law, for the relatively modest pay of the bench. She offered Mr. Milken the prospect of a milder sentence if he helped prosecutors snare others, but he is banned from the securities industry for life. Some mourn Mr. Milken's exile, saying that the collapse of the "junk bond" market since he left Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. proves how indispensable he is. But how much are those bonds truly worth if their value depends on the fate of one firm and one man?

Accountants Go Under
 
Laventhol & Horwath ultimately couldn't even balance its own books. The nation's seventh-largest accounting firm asked for bankruptcy protection from creditors on Wednesday -- apparently the largest such filing by a professional services firm. The firm had a negative net worth of $6.9 million as of Oct. 13. It also faces lawsuits seeking nearly $2 billion over its handling of such clients as the P.T.L. ministry and its favorable feasibility studies for real estate projects that would have needed divine intervention to succeed. Those trying to collect from Laventhol at this point might do just as well directing their prayers to Jim and Tammy.
 
Bad Mortgages at Citicorp
 
How can a bank lose by pumping out plenty of mortgages when the housing market is strong? As long as borrowers provide a fat down payment, why bother pawing through piles of their financial records? Citicorp's latest experience is providing some answers. The company said mortgages delinquent 90 days or more or in foreclosure have risen from 3 to 3.6 percent of dollar volume during the third quarter. Falling home prices, especially in the Northeast, are partly to blame, but Arthur P. Soter, a banking analyst at Morgan Stanley, also points to relaxed lending criteria. The surprise is that it happened at Citicorp, the nation's largest home lender. "This is not some mad dash for growth by an inexperienced, wet-behind-the-ears player," Mr. Soter said. Citicorp has decided to take more care in verifying applicants' income and down-payment sources. But more loans might go sour. As Mr. Soter said, "Problems related to real estate tend to have a fairly long tail."
 
Move Over, Wayne Gretzky
 
The sports world's probable greatest money-earner was laid to rest in an oak coffin a week ago at age 29 in Canada, where he was bred. Northern Dancer's achievements only began with his victories in the 1964 Kentucky Derby -- a track record -- and the Preakness. At stud, he enriched his thoroughbred breed with foals, including 123 stakes winners, that won more than $26 million. His descendants included more than 1,000 stakes winners. Bidding by European breeders and Arab sheiks for his royal bloodline pushed prices for his yearlings past $10 million, and his stud fee to $1 million. "He was a national hero in Canada, along with Wayne Gretzky," the hockey star, said Bernard McCormack, general manager of Winfields Farm near Toronto, where Northern Dancer rests. Wait 'til all the athletes concerned that their multimillion-dollar salaries are lower than someone else's hear about all this.
 
Buyout Funds Reborn
 
Merger mania still lives. Forstmann Little & Company and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company are having some initial success in raising new buyout funds of $1 billion to $2 billion.
 
CBS Plot Thickens
 
Maybe CBS should consult a script doctor to straighten out its tortured plot. The network is in the awkward position of telling affiliates about its weaknesses and advertisers about its strengths. CBS executives said last week that they expect a loss this quarter, and they asked affiliated stations to swallow a 20 percent, $30 million cut in payments to carry CBS shows. Instead of planning the usual three-day bash for affiliates in Los Angeles next year, with parties, invitations to spouses and walk-ons by network stars, CBS will hold a sober day-and-a-half meeting in New York in June just for station managers. Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS, said increased competition for viewers and advertisers is "changing the fundamental economics of network television." CBS is boasting to advertisers, meanwhile, that it will remain the best way to reach a huge audience, with spots on "60 Minutes" likely to have as many viewers as a blanket campaign on cable networks.
 
Air Fare Bonanza
 
The airlines might fill up their seats with two-fers, but barely have money to go on with the show. In a frenzy to retain market shares, the nation's airlines are offering free companion tickets, most until Feb. 28. "The industry is going to lose a fortune," said Helane Becker, an analyst at Shearson Lehman. With the high cost of fuel, she added, "A couple of airline companies are going to have great difficulty surviving." Buy now, she said, because the deals are unlikely to last into March.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Easing Up on Bankers
 
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady promised last week to do more for bankers than urging them to be generous with loans. Mr. Brady, sharing the Bush Administration's concern that tight credit is choking the economy, asked regulators last week to go easier in examining bank finances. "Use some judgment," he said. "Don't overreact." Bankers say they need an overhaul of regulations that fragment and restrict their industry, and Mr. Brady promised to recommend new laws by next year.
 
Trading at a Crawl
 
A power outage halted trading for 94 minutes Friday at the New York Stock Exchange. Business was so sluggish that some said they failed to notice when trading resumed.
 
Oil prices rose $2.12 last week, to $31.90, after President Bush's tough talk in the Middle East.
 
What little other economic news there was last week was discouraging. Initial unemployment claims for the week ended Nov. 10 rose to 488,000, the highest level in seven years. "An ominous sign," Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist of Hongkongbank said.
 
Economic Justice
 
The economic slowdown has struck some of the healthiest states the hardest, while leaving weaker states improved. October unemployment figures indicate that even with the auto industry in retreat, Michigan's jobless rate was lower than a year ago, as the agriculture and machinery sectors picked up. In Texas, farm exports and Mexican trade quickened before the jump in oil prices, leaving unemployment just one-tenth of 1 percent higher than New York's. And California, its defense plants and real estate ailing, has a higher jobless rate than the nation's.
 
Fear of Science
 
Americans continue to shun advanced study in technical fields essential to the nation's economic health. According to a recent survey, only 43 percent of the 933 doctorates in mathematics awarded in the United States in the last academic year went to American citizens -- a record low. Engineering and several other sciences show similar trends. Many foreign students do stay to seek their fortune in the United States. But for top scientists and engineers, it is a scant fortune: a median starting salary for mathematicians of about $32,000, less than many Wall Street M.B.A.'s earn their first six months out.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL


The Bush Mold in Britain?
 
Will Great Britain turn to a George Bush, of sorts, for conservatism with a lighter hand? After 11 1/2 years of unwavering right-wing rule under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, her Conservative Party chooses a new leader, and Prime Minister, this week. Michael Heseltine, whose challenge brought about her resignation announcement on Thursday, proffers a renewed role for government in aiding the poor, improving schools and reviving inner cities. But Mrs. Thatcher's resignation also throws the contest open to two members of her Cabinet. Douglas Hurd, the Foreign Secretary, is more pragmaticthan she is -- and, like Mr. Heseltine, more pro-European. Only John Major, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, might closely follow the Thatcher line. A defender of free markets and a critic of a federated Europe, he appears to be Mrs. Thatcher's first choice.
 
Guinness in Spain
 
When Ernest Hemingway was in Spain, it is said, he liked nothing more than an aged Rioja. Guinness P.L.C. is betting that Spaniards and latter-day Hemingways will switch from sherry and red wine to beer. The London-based company last week announced an agreement to pay $1.02 billion for the Spanish brewer La Cruz del Campo S.A. Cruzcampo has more than a fifth of Spain's beer market, with the fastest growth and strongest profits.

HEADLINE: A New Geography For the Coal Industry

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
THE rumble of change is being heard in the coal fields of America.
Utilities are exploring the costs and availability of lower-sulfur coal. Miners in central Appalachia and the western United States are contemplating big gains in production. Railroads expect a surge in shipments. And the high-sulfur mines of the Midwest and northern and southern Appalachia are looking at leaner times. 
 Under the new Clean Air Act approved by Congress last month, restrictions on sulfur dioxide emissions, which contribute heavily to acid rain, will take effect in 1995 and tighten in 2000, with each round requiring more coal-burning utilities to find lower-sulfur fuel or to install scrubbers or other cleanup technology.
These restriction have not previously been applied to old plants. By some estimates, one-eighth of the coal-burning plants in the United States will have to shift to different suppliers, sometimes more than 1,000 miles away. Supply relationships that have existed for decades will be disrupted.
"This is going to be the biggest change in the use of coal at utilities in the past 50 years," said Scott B. Sitzer, an economist at the Department of Energy.
Among producers, Ashland Coal will see compound annual earnings growth of 20 percent through 1995 because of increased demand for central Appalachian low-sulfur coal, said Rafael A. Villagran, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. Another Appalachian producer, Westmoreland Coal, and a company in the Powder River Basin of northeast Wyoming, Nerco Inc., will also benefit, he said.
The losers will probably be "mom-and-pop" mining companies that lack the resources to buy low-sulfur reserves or build the mines to produce them. Bigger companies may already have such reserves or be able to acquire them. The largest company, Peabody Holdings, a subsidiary of Hansen P.L.C., has big low-sulfur reserves in Montana, but offering that coal to its customers may mean a cut in profits. Because of daunting transportation costs, Western supplies, even with their attractive low sulfur levels, sell for less at the mine than do Peabody's extensive coal holdings in the East.
Consolidation Coal, a subsidiary of Du Pont, is the second-largest American coal producer, and does not have extensive low-sulfur reserves, but it is regarded as highly efficient and, as one expert said, will "be the last guys to go."
Among railroads, CSX and Norfolk Southern would benefit because they would haul more coal from central Appalachia, said Sandor J. Toth, senior analyst at the Fieldston Company, of Washington, a coal transportation publishing and consulting firm. In the West, Burlington Northern Union Pacific and Southern Pacific would haul more coal, he said.
Eastern Enterprises, which owns the Midland Enterprises barge company, would also benefit, said Mr. Villagran of Shearson. Its barges ply a variety of inland waterways, including the Ohio and Mississippi rivers.
AS for consumers, higher transportation charges and the cost of scrubbers will almost certainly push up electric rates sharply in places -- primarily in the Middle West -- now using high-sulfur coal. Coal accounted for 32.3 percent of the energy produced in the nation last year, and represents the vast majority of American fossil-fuel reserves. The United States has more than one-third of the world's coal reserves.
When the Clean Air Act was first passed, in 1970, it meant big changes for new generating stations, but older coal-using plants were exempt.
This time, all the older plants are affected, and some experts say that so many utilities will rush for new supplies at once that they will bid up the price of rail freight. The market for coal at the mine is also likely to change, with the now-modest price spread between low- and high-sulfur coals likely to widen. Similar price changes occurred in the oil market back when regulators set limits on sulfur dioxide emissions from oil-burning plants.
C oal does not now operate in a national market. For one thing, the product varies sharply from deposit to deposit in energy content per pound and other factors, and most boilers can handle only a small range of coals. For another, proximity has historically been the most important determinant, with relatively little coal shipped over long distances.
Currently, the difference in price between low-sulfur and high is small. In Eastern Kentucky, where high- and low-sulfur coals are available, the premium for low-sulfur is usually about 25 cents per million British thermal units, said A. Denny Ellerman, a vice president of Charles River Associates, a consulting firm. (A million B.T.U.'s is an amount of heat sufficient to make about 100 kilowatt-hours of electricity. That is a little less than the typical American household uses in a week.) But the premium exists only for the lowest-sulfur coals; intermediate grades actually sell for about the same as high-sulfur fuel.

THE reason is that under the current regulations, a generating station is either in compliance or it is not; being most of the way there is of no help. The new act, however, allows averaging of the emissions of plants owned by the same utility.
According to Department of Energy figures, coal-fired plants comprise 300 gigawatts of electrical capacity, or 44 percent of the total generating capacity. The balance includes plants fired by natural gas and oil, nuclear reactors and hydroelectric stations. The coal plants work more of the year, however, producing about 56 percent of the electricity.
Of the total capacity of 300 gigawatts, 70 gigawatts are already treated with scrubbers, according to the Department of Energy. Additional plants with a total of 42 gigawatts of capacity will probably switch to lower-sulfur coal, and plants with 92 gigawatts of capacity will install scrubbers, said C. Hoff Stauffer Jr., a vice president of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc.
Shearson's estimate runs a little lower: plants with 40 gigawatts will switch fuels and plants with 55 to 60 gigawatts will add scrubbers.
A few plants will try other solutions, like building new boilers that produce less pollution, or burning coal with natural gas to cut emissions. But under a system of emissions-trading approved by Congress, not every plant will have to change. A utility that adds a scrubber to its biggest, dirtiest plant would save so much sulfur dioxide that it could apply its "overcompliance" to smaller units that it did not clean up.
Even with the wide expectation of large-scale coal switching, the low-sulfur coal producers are not rushing into new investments, however. At ARCO Coal, in Denver, which owns the Black Thunder mine, the biggest in the country, Curtis E. Burton, a spokesman, said the first step was to see which strategy the electric companies favor to comply with the new rules -- low-sulfur coal or scrubbers. "Every utility has to sit down and do some serious calculation, what makes sense for them to meet the new standards," Mr. Burton said.
The Black Thunder mine, in the Powder River Basin in northeast Wyoming, produces nearly 30 million tons of coal a year, or about 3 percent of the United States' total. It is very low-sulfur coal, suitable for blending with high-sulfur coal to produce a mix that still burns with emissions below the Federal limit.
AN ANALYSIS performed for the Environmental Protection Agency by ICF Resources Inc. in July predicted that a bill like the one that eventually passed Congress would cut coal production by up to 97 million tons from the high-sulfur areas of the Middle West and northern Appalachia by the year 2005, compared with what production would have been without a new law. The replacement coal would come mostly from central Appalachia, with some from the West. The Western coal is extremely low sulfur, below 0.7 percent; central Appalachian coal is between 0.7 and 2 percent.
Companies in both the Appalachians and the Powder River Basin have ample capacity to produce low-sulfur coal and can expand capacity quickly, so big low-sulfur price changes are unlikely. Mr. Burton said his company foresaw "very small increases" in prices. Even with a higher demand for Powder River Basin coal, he said, competition would still be strong among producers of that type. "We're going to have to go out and hustle for every new piece of business," he said.
A bigger barrier for Western coal is the cost of transportation. Delivery to power plants in the Middle West or Southeast can run as high as $25 a ton. Coal from the region generally sells for $5 to $7 a ton, so transportation can account for four-fifths of the delivered cost for the coal, although this is an extreme case; rail charges are usually closer to half the cost.
But the effect of the Clean Air Act on the price of rail transport is hard to predict because costs are expected to rise sharply with volume, Mr. Toth said. If many utilities switch quickly to Western coal and begin hauling their fuel 1,500 miles instead of 200 miles, "you're talking about a lot of new cars, and a lot of new locomotives," he explained, adding, "Unless the railroads do some upgrading, we think there will be some problems."
At the moment, Mr. Toth noted, "You can get rail rates from the Powder River Basin of a penny a pound a mile." And "Some utilities are going to make their investment decisions based on that number." That could turn out to be a big mistake. If railroad costs rise, he said, a trip that formerly cost $12 a ton could jump to $14.
In any event, the railroads are reluctant to take major steps, he said, until it becomes clearer precisely what steps and what combinations of strategies the utilities are going to pursue, just how much low-sulfur coal will be shipped and how many new scrubbers will be installed instead.

 
 
TRADING IN THE RIGHT TO POLLUTE
 THE new Clean Air Act will let coal-burning utilities produce, buy and sell something besides electricity: the right to pollute.
In a system that has some economists cheering and utility regulators scratching their heads, the law will allow utilities to overcomply -- by reducing sulfur dioxide emissions below the legal limit -- and then "sell" the extra to another company.
Suppose two companies each have to remove 1,000 tons of sulfur dioxide a year; one can do the job for $400 a ton, the other has to spend $600. The first can remove 2,000 tons and sell the extra reduction of 1,000 tons to the second company. If the price is more than $400, the first company makes a profit; if less than $600, the second company saves money.
Scrubbers are, in fact, most cost-effective on big plants, especially the nation's 107 "big dirties," as they are known. A scrubber on a big dirty might cut sulfur-dioxide emission by 99 percent -- from 5 pounds per million British thermal units, say, to 0.05 pounds. Since the standard, when fully phased in, is 1.2 pounds, a plant that installed a scrubber would have 1.15 pounds to sell or to store against problems that might come up in the future.
Estimates vary on the worth of this pollution commodity, but Paul R. Portney of Resources for the Future, in Washington, puts the figure at about $2.5 billion.
"There is a shared savings," said Ashley C. Brown of the Ohio Public Utilities Commission, adding that savings can reduce rates.
But it is not clear who should benefit, shareholder or consumer. Normally, electric customers pay for all construction through their electric bills, and get the benefit in available electricity. They could be asked to pay for extra anti-pollution equipment, and, indeed, get the benefit in reduced rates if the pollution trade works.
But there will be some risk, both in trading in the volatile energy market and in using machinery that can quickly become obsolete. If the trade goes bad -- if the utility, say, finds itself having spent more to create a pollution credit than it can sell the credit for -- then the investment might be judged imprudent by state regulators. In that case, shareholders might have to eat the loss in the form of reduced dividends.
Should the shareholder be asked to assume that level of risk without the possibility of gain?

HEADLINE: All About/Movie Theaters;
The Crunch Comes to Cinemas

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
WHEN movie ticket sales peaked seven years ago, the theater chains continued to expand. They added 4,000 screens, for a 1989 total of nearly 23,000. Only now are they retrenching, trying to sell their theaters as well as their tickets.
Average ticket prices have risen to $4.58 last year from $2.69 in 1980, but after inflation the increase is slight. "It is a nongrowth business that has become highly competitive," said Sumner Redstone, whose National Amusements Inc. owns nearly 700 screens. "Real growth does not come from raising your admission prices year after year. With everyone fighting for market share, the question is: how well can companies manage what they own?" 
 Many companies have not managed very well. The nation's three largest chains -- United Artists Theater Circuit, with 2,550 screens, Cineplex Odeon, 1,690 screens and American Multi-Cinema, 1,620 screens -- are all selling off some holdings. During the late 1980's, companies like American Multi-Cinema Inc. of Kansas City seemed to open a new multiplex, or theater with more than one screen, every week. Now, heavily indebted, they are cutting back. American Multi-Cinema and Cineplex Odeon both had losses last year.
Meanwhile, film rental and advertising costs are going up, and a higher minimum wage has raised the cost of labor. "Margins are being squeezed for almost all circuits," said Jack Holland, vice president of marketing for American Multi-Cinema.
 
Synergize, Synergize

When Piggybacking Seemed So Sensible
In the giddy 80's, every studio executive, an investment banker by his side, was primed to bid for theater chains. "Synergies," they said -- combine studios with theaters, and inevitably there would be synergies.
And once a film company saw a competitor buying theaters, it feared having its own offerings shut out of major markets. For the studios, "owning theater circuits became a defensive strategy," said Jeffrey Logsdon, an analyst at the Seidler Amdec Inc. investment firm in Los Angeles. Paramount Pictures and Warner Bros. became joint partners in CineAmerica. MCA bought a stake in Cineplex Odeon, and Columbia bought Loews Theaters. Only the Walt Disney Company, among the major studios, held back.
Theater owners, meanwhile, went into movie production. As ticket sales flattened, they thought that making movies would raise their share of theater admissions and bring them earnings from distribution. The United Artists Theater Circuit was encouraged to launch a film production business in 1988 because the company's parent, Tele-Communications Inc., is the nation's largest cable operator. Executives reasoned that as long as Tele-Communications controlled the distribution of films through cable, movie theaters and an investment in the Blockbuster Video stores, it could profitably expand into film production too.
But making hits takes very different skills from distributing them, United Artists found. "There was no synergy in the way that was originally visualized," acknowledged John Neil, president of United Artists Entertainment. "At least there is nothing that I have noted."
United Artists closed its film production division earlier this year and chose 400 theaters, out of 2,700, to sell. "We are already down to 2,550," Mr. Neil said. "We have closed some, but we have sold more than we have closed."
Garth Drabinsky, as chairman of Cineplex Odeon, also launched a film production division. In December 1989, Mr. Drabinsky resigned after an unsuccessful bid to take the company private. New management is holding a huge yard sale, selling off theaters and its half interests in the Film House production laboratory and Universal Studios in Florida. The Cineplex film production unit is being disbanded.
Harold Vogel, a media analyst at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, said that theater owners have given up the synergistic search, frustrated that they reaped neither increased market share nor profits. They are left with a familiar excuse. In Mr. Vogel's words, "At the time it looked like a good idea."
 
Hot Tickets, No Legs

This Year, a Dearth Of Durable Hits
Too few Batmen, not enough Pretty Women mean meager profits for the owners of theaters. The decline in major releases, to 472 in 1989 from 515 films in 1984 , has hurt them, even though the cause has been small, independent companies going out of business.
Compounding the theaters' problems this year was a dearth of durable hits. Eager for megahits like the previous summer's "Batman," many studios produced big-budget action films and promoted them with brassy advertising. "Another 48 Hours," "Days of Thunder" and "Air America" all had sensational openings, but, in the industry's term, no legs. Some, like "Days of Thunder," soon yielded to days of silence, leaving the theaters after a few weeks.
Theater owners were sorry to see them go. The owners prosper most when the same movie fills their theaters month after month, buoyed by good word-of-mouth. After they keep enough of the box office receipts to cover their operating costs, theater owners split their gross with the distributors. Initially, the distributor gets 90 percent. Only after a film has been playing for several weeks does the exhibitor claim a increasing share. "Batman" was a bonanza, showing for months and giving exhibitors time to take a healthy cut of the box office gross.
Disney's "Pretty Woman" and Paramount's "Ghosts" were successful this year, but not as successful as "Batman." Several owners say total revenues are down at least 5 percent at most of their theaters this year. And Mr. Logsdon estimates that the lack of other durable hits has cut the theaters' take of box office revenues from 52 percent in 1988 to 48 percent this year.
How about the current Christmas season? Theater owners are hoping that Paramount's "Godfather III," bursting with blood and gore, will still give the year a happy ending.
 
The Small Survive

Once More, Into the Niche
In the theater business, size does not necessarily spell success. It might be an obstacle.
Consider Carmike Cinemas of Columbus, Ga. With 982 screens, Carmike shuns major markets for cities like Albany, Ga., and Montgomery, Ala. First it opened theaters across the South, then reached into the smaller towns of the West. Sending an endless stream of "Rambo" and Arnold Schwarzenegger films into cities near the South's many military bases is a Carmike specialty. Revenues grew from $54.9 million in 1988 to $65.0 million last year, while profits rose from $3.3 million to $6.2 million.
At National Amusements Inc., Mr. Redstone has built a distinctive company by buying, rather than leasing, his sites, and building large, technically advanced multiplexes. "We will spend several years developing a single multiplex, preferably at the intersection of major highways, which has the advantages of accesiblity and visibility," Mr. Redstone said. "We spent three years finding the site and getting the correct zoning for a site in Berlin, Conn., that is scheduled to open on Dec. 7." National Amusements is privately owned, but competitors say it has done well -- well enough to have helped Mr. Redstone buy Viacom Inc., the diversified media company.

 
 
GOING ABROAD FOR GROWTH
NOW that American theater chains have glutted their own market with screens, they are looking abroad. The major companies are buying land, signing up partners and building more theaters, especially in Western Europe.
The theater chains have found a ready market, with American films as popular as ever. They have concentrated on Europe for its healthy economic growth and more reasonable land costs than Japan. In many European countries, movie theaters never expanded into the suburbs. Theaters there are often outmoded, with picture and sound equipment that American companies consider antique.
Perhaps the greatest growth has come in Great Britain, because of the common language. Five years ago, ticket sales were sagging as viewers favored videocassettes at home over larger screens in shabby, outdated theaters. The industry, spearheaded by American companies, then added more than 300 movie screens for a total of 1,700. British ticket sales rebounded from 52 million in 1988 to 92 million last year. Industry executives estimate that one-fifth of those sales were generated by new multiplexes.
Cinema International Corporation, a joint venture of MCA and Paramount, plans to continue building in Britain, to raise its screen count from 131 this year to 310 in 1991. Sumner Redstone's National Amusements is also expanding in Great Britain. Mr. Redstone said that he has built seven multiplexes, buying the land as he goes, much as he does in the United States.
American companies are active, but less ambitious, elsewhere overseas. Cinema International is carrying out plans to nearly double its screen count on the Continent to 80 from 42 this year. Time Warner Inc. is building a theater complex in Germany, and has a joint venture for two complexes in Denmark. It is also looking at locations in Spain, Portugal and the Far East. And, to make sure the Soviet people enjoy the full benefits of glasnost, the company has announced plans for theaters in Leningrad and Moscow.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Hot New Global Income Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to mutual fund marketing, only three things matter: yield, yield and yield. So that's what folks think about when they dream up new fund products, and they've hit the jackpot with short-term global income funds.
These funds promise higher yields than money market funds or certificates of deposit -- and less fluctuation in value than long-term bond funds. They've become the hottest funds of the year. 
 Assets of short-term global income funds have soared to nearly $7 billion, from $400 million at the beginning of the year, with most of that growth coming since late summer. Nearly a dozen funds have hit the market and several more are in the works.
 But even as money flows into these funds at an astonishing rate, at least five big groups -- Franklin, Dreyfus, Federated, Vanguard and MFS -- have decided not to set them up. They worry that investors don't understand that these funds carry some risk and that they may not be able to sustain the high yields, now about 10.5 percent.
"We feel there are risks involved that we don't feel comfortable with," said Chuck Johnson, senior vice president of corporate development for Franklin Resources Inc., in San Mateo, Calif.
The granddaddy of short-term global income funds is the $3.4 billion Alliance Short-Term Multi-Market Trust, which started in the spring of 1989, pretty youthful for a granddaddy. Since then, it has built a remarkable record: For the 12 months ended Nov. 1, it has yielded an average of 10.9 percent, and its total return -- yield plus changes in principal value -- was 12.95 percent. That compares to a 10.48 percent return for all world income funds, said Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds.
Meanwhile, the value of the fund's shares has remained stable. The fund's net asset value, which equaled $9.70 when the fund was first sold in April 1989, hit a low of $9.55 in June and a high of $10.01 in September. Its principal-only return -- which reflects changes in the value of fund shares, without yield -- was -2.1 percent. By contrast, the average long-term bond fund lost 4.8 percent, according to Lipper.
How does Alliance do it? It takes advantage of interest rates elsewhere that are higher than United States rates, and invests in securities that mature in less than three years. Short-term holdings minimize interest-rate risk, and the average maturity of Alliance's holdings ranges from 6 to 14 months. And to minimize credit risk, the fund holds government securities and corporate short-term paper, which are rated AA or better by Standard & Poor's, and certificates of deposit.
The fund must keep at least 25 percent of its assets in American dollar-denominated paper. Right now, the rest is in other currencies: Canadian (15 percent), Australian and New Zealand (15 percent) and a basket of European currencies (45 percent). Having such a large part of its portfolio denominated in dollars means that some currency risk is eliminated, but it could also cut the return.
The heavy exposure abroad, by contrast, increases currency risk -- but also potential return. To minimize swings in share price, Robert Sinche, the fund's manager, relies on sophisticated hedging techniques. The cost of an ordinary hedge would bring the yield on the foreign paper down to United States rates. So Mr. Sinche "cross-hedges" instead -- he buys long a high-yielding currency and sells short a low-yielding one. That is less expensive than straight hedging but riskier: For the system to work, the relationships between the high- and low-yielding currencies must remain stable.
And stability can be elusive. For example, last year the spread between the West German mark and the British pound ranged from 3.03 to 2.74 -- a variance of about 10 percent. "There's margin for error here," Mr. Sinche said.
There are other problems. Effective hedging requires fancy footwork. "Few fund managers are able to hedge successfully on a consistent basis," said Catherine J. Gillis, senior analyst with Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual fund consultants.
And because these funds' yields are compared to money market yields, investors might think they are just as safe. Are they? "Absolutely not," said Mr. Sinche. Global income funds are permitted under their bylaws to have a much longer average term -- three years rather than one for money market funds -- which increases interest-rate risk. They also carry currency risk, unlike money market funds, and the value of their shares can fluctuate.
"The funds claim that they hedge, but you can't hedge 100 percent and still deliver excess yield, which is the deceptive part of this product," said Greg Melvin, a vice president for Federated Investors, in Pittsburgh.
As investors burned by junk bond funds have learned, you pay for high yields one way or another. The high yields aren't much good if the principal is eroding. The global income funds are"an attractive package," Ms. Gillis said, "but it has that familiar ring of a hot product that can quickly go awry."

 
 
UNDERVALUED SINGLE-COUNTRY FUNDS
 SINGLE-COUNTRY funds look like bargains now because they are selling at steep discounts. Prices for these closed-end funds, which trade on exchanges like stock, are set by supply and demand, and fund shares trade at a premium or discount to the value of the stocks in their portfolios.
While the single-country funds were the most overpriced closed-end funds on the market when the year began -- the outlook for foreign economies was much brighter then -- they are now the most undervalued group. After a stable spring, discounts deepened on bad news in the Middle East, hitting nearly 15 percent during panicked selling in September. While discounts have shrunk, prices are still down and that's "a clear buy signal," said Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser. He said prices should stay low through yearend as people sell investments that have gone sour in order to take a tax loss for 1990.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Become a Technological Wasteland

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Japanese companies, you report (front page, Nov. 11), have begun to establish theoretical computer science research institutes in the United States, staffed by scientists lured from American universities and industrial research laboratories.
This is a deeply distressing development, but it is no surprise to those close to the American technology scene. Fresh Masters of Business Administration, with two or three years of postbaccalaureate education, get salaries of $50,000 and up in this country; established lawyers in the New York area are reputed to average $250,000 a year.
Contrast the case of a Doctor of Philosophy scientist with five to eight years of postbaccalaureate study, largely consisting of on-the-job training in research. He or she will start with at most $40,000 in a Government or industrial lab.
Those Ph.D.'s impecunious enough to consider university research jobs are faced with typical starting salaries in the low to mid $30,000's as postdocs or assistant professors. Typically, such researchers must then spend at least a year, sometimes much longer, on a full-time search for research funding before they can seriously resume their work. This situation is worst in mathematics and applied mathematics, fields in which theoretical computer scientists often take their degrees.
Stars can make more money, but it takes years of hard work and low pay to establish a scientific career. Some of us keep at it, but the grossly declining pool of Americans pursuing Ph.D.'s in science and engineering should come as no surprise.
Salaries are just a symptom of the generally low value placed on the technical elite who generate ideas and technologies that drive the United States and world economies. Japanese companies have apparently realized this and are out to correct it, naturally for their own profit.
Unfortunately, the state of the marketplace probably makes the Japanese vertical integration of the semiconductor industry, from wafer production to software, irreversible. An entire industry will have been moved across the Pacific in less than 20 years, starting from nothing but a well-considered and directed plan and intent. It is unlikely that United States industry and academia can compete with Japanese companies, in salary or the preferred perquisites of scientists -- access to the newest and best research equipment.
The impoverishment of our universities in equipment has been documented in Department of Energy and National Science Foundation studies. Studies indicate a "deferred technology base maintenance" deficit of tens of billions of dollars in equipment alone. This money will not be coming from Federal or other sources in the foreseeable future.
Furthermore, salary distortions and other factors have led to gross declines in the undergraduate science and engineering student base that supports faculty hiring in these fields.
This has also been documented in National Science Foundation studies.
Graduate education is in worse shape, with about half the graduate engineering students in the United States resident aliens. This proportion is, of course, much higher in the elite universities (for example, 65 percent in some Stanford University departments). The nationals of some countries apparently know a closeout bargain when they see one.
The United States electronics industry is shorn of the mass-market manufacturing profit base that for years supported the David Sarnoff Labs, A.T.& T. Bell Labs and the like. These research facilities have largely been sold, closed or redirected in ways that are causing wholesale desertion of their staffs, as you mention. Struggling to maintain profitability in our much-vaunted "free trade" environment, these companies can ill afford to enter a bidding war in the high-risk area of research, which can obtain long-term returns at best.
A colleague of mine built a complete microfabrication facility at San Francisco State University, containing millions of dollars in equipment, for $50,000. Behind this accomplishment is the collapse and dismantling of high-tech industry in the United States. Facilities that cost tens of millions of dollars and hundreds of man-years to establish are being sold for scrap or donated to ambitious and frustrated university researchers who don't need to show a profit.
Every month I visit yet another closed-down semiconductor custom manufacturing facility in New Jersey to scavenge donations of valuable equipment for my lab. Bitter employees show and tell the unsurpassed technical and manufacturing feats of their moribund employers, then tell a familiar story of foreign acquisition or predatory competition, followed by financial failure and dismantling of the facility.
There has been no reported foreign rush to hire American M.B.A.'s, lawyers or financiers, stars or otherwise. As the old Silicon Valley joke goes, it takes a good lawyer, a good M.B.A. and a good engineer to start a computer company. When the company is sold or goes broke, the M.B.A. has all the money, the lawyer has all the patents, and the engineer is looking for a job.
It appears that, if he or she is good enough, the engineer may at last find prospects for a great job looking up -- working for a Japanese company, of course.
 
C. J. MARTOFF
Associate Professor of Physics, Temple University,
Philadelphia, Nov. 11, 1990

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Can the Sanctions Work? Many Aides Are Doubtful

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 As President Bush pursues authorization from the United Nations to use military force against Iraq, Administration officials and Congressional critics are increasingly focusing on the question of whether economic sanctions alone could force Saddam Hussein's hand.
State Department, Defense Department and intelligence officials say the sanctions have succeeded in blocking nearly all of Iraq's international trade and financial transactions and are causing shortages of many items, including tires and grains.

 BODY:
 But they added that despite these successes, the sanctions would not significantly hamper Iraq's military for at least six months. President Saddam Hussein, they say, has managed to protect vital civilian and military industries and services by manipulating his state-planned economy to shuffle resources.
 
What Hussein Is Doing
 To alleviate the pain for his civilian population, the Iraqi leader is shifting factory workers back to the countryside, where they are expected to increase food production over the next several months. Mr. Hussein has also hoarded food stolen from Kuwait and closed nonessential factories to preserve spare parts for vital plants.
Even if the civilian population begins to feel the pain, Administration officials doubt that Mr. Hussein will care, or that his security apparatus will have any trouble squashing any incipient social unrest.
The officials say the sanctions are not likely to topple Mr. Hussein or bring about an Iraqi retreat from Kuwait before the spring at the earliest, an analysis that has provided ammunition for those who think the United States should act militarily, sooner rather than later.
Shortly after President Bush announced earlier this month that he was sending an additional 150,000 or more troops to the Persian Gulf, a senior Administration official explained: "We're not prepared to give this guy unlimited time, whoever's side time is on. Clearly, sanctions are not at the point where he is seriously constrained."
 
Disagreement in the Senate
 But others disagree, including Senator Sam Nunn, the chairmen of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and Senator Claiborne Pell, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. The two senators, who plan to hold hearings on the Gulf crisis over the next two weeks, have wondered in recent days why the United States should risk the lives of tens of thousands of American soldiers before giving the near-airtight sanctions the time to strangle President Hussein.
President Bush, speaking as he returned to Washington on Saturday, refused to specify how long he would wait for sanctions to work against Iraq. He said that at the United Nations, "We'll be discussing not only the need to consider further action, but perhaps a time frame."
Administration officials say the goals of the embargo remain the same as those stated when the sanctions were approved by the United Nations Security Council in the weeks following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2: to incite a military or popular revolt, or persuade Mr. Hussein that whatever benefits he gained from conquering Kuwait are not worth the economic punishment. But officials concede that none of the preferred outcomes are likely to occur any time in the next six months, and possibly not for another year or more.
"Are the sanctions biting?" the State Department official asked. "The evidence is contradictory." The official said that while a country like the United States needed two years to get its economy on a war footing, Iraq's system of economic planning was ready to withstand hardships from the very beginning of the crisis.
 
Breakdown of Effectiveness
 Officials and foreign-policy specialists familiar with the sanctions offered the following breakdown of their effectiveness:
*Administration officials say that 90 percent of food imports have been halted, and that supplies of tea, sugar, rice and white bread are running short. Rice, flour and cooking oil are being rationed. Some foods have risen in price by as much as eightfold. But Iraqis are not going hungry, and the markets remain full of most foods. Stolen Kuwaiti frozen and canned foods and grains should assure stocks of vegetables for months to come.
*Approximately 40 percent of the nation's industrial capacity has been shut down. But careful Government planning is helping to limit the damage. Nonessential plants, like those producing clothing, have been closed to save lubricants, chemicals, spare parts and electricity for vital industries, particularly those that are military-related. This "cannibalism" of parts from one industry to another will eventually damage machinery, but that will take several months.
*The embargo is costing Baghdad $1.5 billion every month in lost oil sales, figured at pre-invasion oil prices. The embargo has succeeded in blocking all but a trickle of Iraqi oil exports. Administration officials say that the oil that filters through the Jordanian border is not a serious problem because its sale merely pays off Iraqi debts and does not raise new capital.
*Administration officials say international authorities have succeeded in freezing virtually all Iraqi and Kuwaiti bank accounts. But they are not certain whether the embargo has succeeded in halting the Iraqis from selling gold stolen from Kuwaiti coffers, valued at up to $500 million.
*An Iraqi official said last weekend that medical supplies, which are exempt for nonmilitary purposes, were running short, but State Department officials were dubious of the report.
 
Well-Stocked Military
 Administration officials note that Mr. Hussein has said his troops will be the last touched by the sanctions.
For more than a decade, the Iraqi president employed his nation's oil wealth and borrowings to buy and stockpile enough guns and ammunition to sustain his million-man army for the long war with Iran. Since the Aug. 2 invasion, Mr. Hussein has hoarded additional supplies of fuel and food -- sometimes depriving his civilian population in the process -- in order to keep his military well stocked.
Administration analysts doubt the embargo will lead to a military revolt, but they suggest it might hurt Iraq's ability to fight in the event of war. There have been reports of difficulties in retreading tires for military trucks and armored vehicles, shortages of spare parts for their French-made radar systems and their elite fleet of Mirage F-1 fighter jets.

HEADLINE: Irish Wait to Escape Emigre Shadow

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

 BODY:
A furtive existence, life in the shadow of the law, is about to end for thousands of Irish immigrants who have been living in this country without visas or legal documentation.
They work as nannies in Manhattan, taking the subway in from Queens to look after other people's children, or in pubs at the north end of the Bronx, pouring pints of Guinness while cursing English soccer teams on television. Many work as drivers in the horse carriage trade around Central Park. Above all, they have tried to remain invisible to Federal authorities. 
 Now, communities of young Irish immigrants in New York, Boston and San Francisco are awaiting President Bush's signature on an immigration bill that would more than double the number of visas available to natives of Ireland. They see the immigration bill as their ticket out of a life in fear of discovery. "Ireland is an economic disaster right now," said Finola Doherty, who came to New York two years ago and found a home, and a succession of jobs, in Woodside, Queens. "Here, there is work and a community where you can fit in, but we've had to keep our heads down."
 
Expired Tourist Visas
 The Irish, of course, are not singular in their status in America as illegal aliens. But they have been hard hit by recent immigration policies that have made it impossible for most of those who wanted to stay in this country to become legal residents, with work visas known as green cards.
The overwhelming majority of the Irish here illegally have overstayed six-month tourist visas. The bill, which Congress passed in October, will guarantee that applicants for work visas will not be arrested or deported for overstaying while the application is processed.
Since 1980, more than 180,000 Irish, or about 5 percent of the population, have left the Republic of Ireland. Fleeing a country where nearly one in five people are out of work, the new Irish immigrants have come to America, in large part, for the same reasons that drove previous generations across the Atlantic. More than 40 million Americans now trace their ancestry to Ireland, according to the Census Bureau.
But unlike earlier Irish immigrants, most of the new Irish exiles are hiding from Federal authorities, rather than registering with them.
 
Immediate Family
 "When you're looking at this country through a barred window, you can't take full advantage of it," said Sean Minihane, national chairman of the Irish Immigration Reform Movement, an organization that advises immigrants.
Of the more than 600,000 applications for visas in the last three years, about 54 percent were from natives of Ireland; the vast majority of those Irish were turned down, in part because immigration policy favored applicants with immediate family mmembers already in the United States. A gulf of nearly 40 years between the last big wave of Irish immigrants and those who have come in the last decade has made it hard for most of those who want to stay now to qualify for work visas. Recent immigrants from Latin America, Southeast Asia and Africa more commonly have immediate family members here.
In an attempt to redress the imbalance, Congress included a provision in the new immigration bill that would grant work visas to nearly 50,000 Irish over the next three years -- more than double the number granted in the last three years. All told, the new immigration bill would allow about 700,000 people to come to this country in the next three years, up from 500,000 that would have been admitted. Federal officials say between 40,000 and 110,000 Irish are living in this country illegally, and most will be able to stay, either with the new work visas or through marriage to Americans.
 
Black-Market Birth Certificates
 In New York, they have transformed parts of the Bronx and Queens into neighborhoods where Gaelic can be heard and Irish soda bread is sold alongside potato knishes. Cafes display appeals for hunger strikers in Northern Ireland, and folk songs heavy with expressions of lyrical sorrow are sung late into the night.
Some of the new arrivals say they have purchased false birth certificates, which are sold on the black market for prices that can equal a month's salary.
Most of the illegal Irish immigrants live on a cash economy, the men working day labor jobs or in bars, the women working as baby sitters or house cleaners or waitresses. Without a green card, they have been unable to get driver's licenses, open checking accounts or qualify for health insurance. When they are injured on the job, they cannot qualify for public health care or assistance.
Their biggest fear, they say, is being deported. In San Francisco two weeks ago, a group of Irish immigrants were rounded up by Immigration and Naturalization Service officials who were acting on a tip from an informant, their lawyers said. They were allowed to stay in this country pending a hearing.
"Quite a few people have been picked up here in the last year," said Maire O'Mahony, a schoolteacher from Ireland who works with immigrants in San Francisco. "Following the earthquake, there was a lot of work here for the Irish in construction, but now they are encountering a great deal of heartache."
 
Threats and Insinuations
 Fewer run-ins with immigration officials have been reported in New York. But the fear of being turned in and sent back to Ireland is no less real. The informants, in some cases, have been Irish-Americans, say some immigrants.
Derry Clark, trained as an electrical technician in Ireland, has been working in New York as a bartender and in day labor on construction jobs. He is paid in cash and has had to live with threats and insinuations about his legal status. The Government's shadow, he said, is never far.
"Last August when I went home for my sister's wedding, the American immigration authorities were there at the airport in Ireland with a list of questions about what I planned to do," he said. "I told them all I wanted was to find some work."
As soon as the immigration bill is signed, he plans to apply for a work visa, which would allow him to stay in this country indefinitely. "I'm tired of having to put up with all the whispers and uncertainty," he said.
The threat of deportation has been used by landlords to deprive tenants of a damage deposit that may rightfully be theirs or by employers to withhold wages, say those who work with the Irish.
"They came from a place where there is no work and very little future, so employers tend to take advantage of them, playing off that fear of having to go back," said Sean Benson, who has worked on behalf of Irish immigrants who say they have been cheated by employers. "Whenever you have a group that is not protected by the laws, they can be exploited. Employers feel these people have no resources, no place to turn."
It has also worked the other way around.
"I find, in this town, that the Irish accent is an advantage," said a red-bearded bartender from the Bronx named Colin who has been living as an undocumented alien in New York for four years. "In some bartending jobs, I've got one up on the other lad by virtue of how I sound."

HEADLINE: FLORIO UPSETTING CONSERVATIONISTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
When Gov. Jim Florio came into office with a strong environmental record in Congress, New Jersey environmentalists saw him as a savior. But in less than a year they have grown disillusioned, worrying that the Governor may be too accommodating to industry and developers.
"I think they forgot their job is to protect the environment," said D. W. Bennett, executive director of the American Littoral Society. "They don't seem to have in the upper echelon people whom I would call flamethrowers -- people who reflect a real keen interest in natural resources, open space and the ecosystem. 
 "I think the idea was Florio was going to be the environmental governor and maybe he'd be the flamethrower. So far, this administration has been somewhat of a disappointment."
Mr. Florio's aides defend the Governor's record, saying his commitment to the environment remains firm. They say he is simply trying to strike a balance between environmental protection and growth as the state's economy and building industry sags.
 
Knight in Tarnished Armor
 Many environmentalists, however, are unpersuaded and share Mr. Bennett's misgivings. The concern was unexpected a year ago, given the image of ardent environmentalist that Mr. Florio had shaped in his 16 years in Congress. He was a principal author of the Federal Superfund program to clean up toxic waste sites around the country.
"Deep in our hearts, we thought he was a knight in shining armor and we'd see big changes," said Marie Curtis, head of the New Jersey Environmental Lobby. "And we haven't."
William R. Neil, an assistant director of the New Jersey Audubon Society, said, "On 'green-side' protection -- which is land conservation -- the signals from the Governor have been very cautious and deferential to the business community."
Environmentalists say they see no signs of a major retreat in Mr. Florio's strong environmental philosophy. In fact, some of his first acts as Governor elated them. They include naming a special environmental prosecutor against polluters; pushing for one of the nation's toughest clean-water bills, the Clean Water Enforcement Act; declaring a moratorium on construction of huge garbage-burning incinerators and setting a statewide goal to recycle 60 percent of all trash.
 
Trenton Hirings Questioned
 Since these early high points, the signs have been unsettling, environmentalists complain.
For the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, Mr. Florio named a state judge, Judith A. Yaskin, who once threw out on technical grounds a state indictment against Ciba-Geigy, the pharmaceutical company. Joseph Finan, a lawyer for Ciba-Geigy who won dismissal of that indictment, is now Ms. Yaskin's chief aide for policy and planning. Another of her top aides, John Keith, is former environmental affairs manager for Hoffman-LaRoche Inc.
In an interview, Ms. Yaskin said the two men were hired for their management skills. But environmentalists say they fear their presence gives the regulated industries in New Jersey a sympathetic ear in the highest echelons of the Environmental Protection Department. Also, the post of deputy commissioner -- normally filled by a strong environmentalist -- has been vacant for months. State officials say they are still interviewing candidates.
Ms. Yaskin and Mr. Finan have begun overhauling the 20-year-old, $200 million department, in part because of persistent complaints by industry and state legislators that it is a slow, inefficient bureaucratic behemoth.
 
Reorganizing a Behemoth
 The reorganization would create tougher pollution controls on industry and a single office to issue all air, water and land discharge permits for industry. It would centralize various related environmental functions like hazardous-waste cleanup, land management and water and sewer planning, now scattered across several divisions of the department.
Environmental groups say they endorse the overhaul as long as environmental standards are not relaxed. At the same time, they worry that rules against construction in protected wetlands are being chipped away.
In response, Jon Shure, the Governor's director of communications said:
"What there's going to be and needs to be is a sense of balance. He will accept nothing short of super-aggressive environmental protection. But he wants people who need permits to get them in a timely manner. The objective is to make sure air and water is as clean as possible, to prevent and clean up pollution, and to save time by not creating unnecessary obstacles for growth of the state."
On the issue of building in wetlands, environmentalists fear two plans. One state proposal in Westfield would allow the filling of one acre of wetlands for construction of court-mandated housing for poor and moderate-income people. Ms. Yaskin defended the idea as a "public-purpose development."
The other plan deals with a private housing development in 150 acres of woodlands sliced by streams and ravines in Norwood, in northeastern Bergen County. Environmentalists say they were not informed of talks between the state and the developer on a revised stream encroachment permit, which the department granted.
Ms. Yaskin said that she was aware of their objections to the project and that the new permit was as restrictive as legally possible.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AIMS AT A HEART TEST TO TRIM EXPENSES

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Since the early 1900's, physicians have relied on a brief test called an electrocardiogram to measure the heart's impulses and alert them to signs of problems. And insurers and patients have usually paid whatever the doctor charged for the test.
Now the Government, trying to slow the growth of medical costs to help balance the Federal budget, has decided that physicians are charging too much for the electrocardiogram and 1,400 other procedures they perform on the elderly and disabled patients insured by the Federal Medicare program. 
 It plans to save $725 million over four years by trimming about 40 percent from payments for this heart test. Many heart specialists and spokesmen for other medical specialties are angry, and say they hope to persuade Congress to change the law before it goes into effect.
 
Battle on Many Fronts
 The battle is a prime example of many being fought between the people who pay for medical care and those who provide it. Medicare has already sharply reduced its payments to doctors for cataract surgery, reading X-rays and other diagnostic tests, and is planning further cuts in many other procedures. At issue in these cases is whether doctors have raised their fees too high, well aware that payment will come in most cases not from the patient but from the Government or a faceless private insurer with seemingly deep pockets.
In challenging the payments for electrocardiograms, the Government's rationale is simple, said Tom Scully, associate director of the Office of Management and Budget: "Should doctors get paid an additional $20 to $30 for reading an electrocardiogram, which normally takes an average of 30 seconds to 60 seconds to read, when they are already being paid" for doing the tests and for interpreting other tests in the price of an office visit? In an electrocardiogram, wires placed on the chest and limbs pick up patterns of electricity generated by the heart, which are recorded on a paper chart.
 
'Potentially Harmful'
 Physicians argue that reading an electrocardiogram can be important in life-and-death situations, requires specialized knowledge and should be paid for accordingly. They also say their charges for electrocardiograms partly compensate for inadequate Medicare payments for the office visit.
"The law is potentially harmful to the patient and unfair to the physician," said Dr. Adolph M. Hutter, a heart specialist at Massachusetts General Hospital and vice president of the American College of Cardiology. Reducing payments "will be a tremendous financial disincentive" for doctors to perform an electrocardiogram, which could mean that an important diagnosis might be missed, he said.
Medicare paid doctors $470 million for 29 million electrocardiograms that the Government classified as routine in 1988, the latest year for which statistics are available. The expenditure caught the attention of Congressional and White House negotiators last month as they searched for items to trim in the 1991 budget. Some negotiators -- it cannot be determined exactly who, since no one is now willing to accept responsibility -- suggested that savings could be realized by eliminating payments to doctors for interpreting the routine electrocardiograms.
Currently, Medicare pays an average of $20 for doing a routine electrocardiogram and an average of $12.50 more for interpreting the test. Some doctors may have been charging an additional amount to the patient. Medicare also pays $25 for the office visit during which the test was administered. (Electrocardiograms given to patients admitted to a hospital are paid for under different rules.)
 
Assertions of Overpricing
 "There is no doubt that the electrocardiogram tests were overpriced," said Dr. John M. Eisenberg, an internist and professor of medicine at the University of Pennsylvania who is a member of a Congressional advisory commission on payments to physicians. "A modestly trained person can perform an electrocardiogram and provide it to the physician for interpretation. And the equipment is relatively inexpensive." The equipment typically costs $2,000 to $15,000, depending on how sophisticated it is.
Dr. Eisenberg said if a physician is uncertain about how to interpret a test, the results can be sent electronically to a hospital or specialist for a quick review. Specialists themselves can then bill Medicare.
William Hsiao, a medical economist at the Harvard School of Public Health who has directed Federally financed studies of Medicare payments, found that a typical office visit to an internist required four times as much time and six times as much mental effort, clinical judgment and technical skillas taking and interpreting a routine electrocardiogram. Yet Medicare currently pays an average of only $25 for the typical office visit, and $34 for a typical electrocardiogram.
Fearful of Budget Squeeze
Recognizing that problem, Medicare expects to pay about one-third more for each office visit under fee schedules that go into effect in 1992. But many physicians wonder whether they will ever see those increases, given the budget squeeze.
In the search for budget cuts last month, the House voted to eliminate the Medicare payment for interpreting routine electrocardiograms. But Senate Finance Committee staff members noted that there had been little chance to consult with doctors and health economists. So the reductions were put off at least until January 1992 to allow time for further study.
Under the budget agreement signed by President Bush, Medicare will still pay physicians for administering the routine electrocardiogram. And the program will still pay for the interpretations of tests classified as more complex, like electrocardiograms during exercise on a treadmill.
"The fight will be over which electrocardiograms are, by definition, non-routine," said Gail R. Wilensky, who heads the Government agency that operates Medicare.
What Is Routine?
Indeed, some doctors argue that hardly any electrocardiogram for a Medicare patient should be classified as routine. "Very few electrocardiograms are done as a routine," said Dr. Glen F. Auckerman, the president of the American Academy of Family Physicians. He said his patients in rural Jackson Center, Ohio, are often people "who come in complaining of chest pains and passing-out spells, or emergency rescue squad patients."
Budget negotiators estimated that the cuts in payments for electrocardiograms would yield only half the potential savings because some doctors would compensate by increasing other charges. "Physicians have become very sophisicated in figuring out how to get paid," said Representative Pete Stark, a California Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee on health. "It is always a close call: 'Is this a routine or complex procedure?' "
The agreed-upon savings on electrocardiograms of $725 million over four years would be part of $9 billion to be subtracted from Medicare payments to doctors in the budget law. All told, Medicare payments are to be cut by $34 billion over five years, with most of the rest coming from payments to hospitals. The program will get $10 billion more from increases in premiums and deductions paid by people receiving Medicare. (Working people will pay $26 billion in added payroll taxes.)
 
Doctors Are Critical
 Spokesmen for doctors criticized the cuts. "Every time you take more money out of the system it means you can provide less services," said Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association.
While Medicare paid for 29 million routine electrocardiograms and 3 million classified as complex, about 136 million more were given to patients covered by other insurance programs or paying out of their own pockets. While doctors often try to make up for Medicare cuts by charging their other patients more, private insurers often fight back by following Medicare's example in how much they will pay. As a result, many private insurers will probably lower their payments for electrocardiograms, adding to the financial pressure on the doctor.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, for example, pays separately for electrocardiogram interpretations, but some insurers like Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas already do not allow such charges.
No one seems ready to take responsibility for the electrocardiogram cuts. Mr. Scully, the White House budget negotiator, said the idea had come from the House Ways and Means Committee. Committee members said that was not so.
"This proposal did not come from Congress," Representative Stark said. "It came from the Administration."

GRAPHIC: Chart: Amount Medicare currently pays for electrocardiograms and office visits (Source: Harvard University study for Federal Health Care Financing Administration) (pg. 32)
