HEADLINE: Hard Work Can't Stop Hard Times

SERIES: Scraping By: First of three articles.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WATERLOO, Iowa

 BODY:
Donald and Mary Dalton followed all the rules and held fast to the American dream. They worked five days a week, saved their money and reared five children. Someday, they hoped and believed, they would retire to a lake in Minnesota.
Then, in the mid-1980's, the bottom dropped from their lives. Like millions of other working people around America in the last decade, the Daltons were swept into a kind of economic free fall. At middle age, they became casualties of the new and sometimes brutal order remaking the nation's workplaces. 
 Some people, especially those in low-wage work, have lost ground just by standing still. They stayed at their jobs through a decade or more in which inflation rose faster than wages. Their money has bought less each year, withering the belief in economic self-improvement that is so dear to Americans.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the earnings of American workers in fields like construction and manufacturing and in clerical jobs like store clerks plunged sharply from 1970 to 1989. Workers who were earning an average of $186.94 a week in 1970 were making just $172.74 in 1980, when inflation is taken into account, and only $166.52 in 1989.
Others, like the Daltons, paid an even steeper price. Battered for more than a decade by nonunion competitors and falling profits, the aging Rath meat packing plant where Mr. Dalton had worked for 38 years went bankrupt and closed its doors.
As other factories in town laid off workers, the grocery that employed Mrs. Dalton for 21 years went out of business. Mr. Dalton lost most of his company pension in a futile attempt by employees to keep the plant running. Within two years, the Daltons' income fell to $6,000 a year from $35,000.
The couple found themselves, in their 50's, suddenly scrambling to survive, burning up their meager savings and living off food stamps and whatever work they could find.
"I didn't expect to work most of our lives to have it come to this," said Mrs. Dalton, who is now a clerk at the local Wal-Mart, making $4.75 an hour. Her husband took on everything from janitorial jobs to parking cars at the dog track until illness forced him into disability. "We never meant to quit our jobs," he said. "They quit on us."
In recent months, fears of a recession have become widespread across the country. But for many men and women who planned their futures on the assumption that their blue-collar jobs would provide economic security, the real damage has already been done, and is likely to remain long after the latest swing or two of the economic pendulum.
Over the last decade, industries pressed by low-wage competitors overseas, among other factors, have trimmed their work forces or closed aging factories, eliminating more than 850,000 jobs in manufacturing, most of which paid well.
In their place have come millions of new jobs. But not only do these jobs generally pay less and offer fewer benefits; many are also part time.
What emerges is an economy riddled with sometimes cruel ironies, an economy measured in recent years by falling unemployment rates and record levels of job creation, but also an economy in which more and more people have all they can do to make ends meet and afford basic needs.
According to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington, which studies economic trends, the number of working people whose incomes fall below the poverty level has increased by 28 percent since 1978. The poverty level is $12,675 for a family of four.
 
 Shocks Across Economy
 These economic shocks, rippling through society, produce countless varieties of havoc. Many blacks, just now struggling to enter the middle class, must spend much of their money and energy caring for relatives and friends who lag behind. Young people who hoped to skip college and follow their fathers into stable blue-collar work confront instead a bleak array of jobs paying barely more than the minimum wage, always with the threat of layoff just ahead.
The dismantling of the old blue-collar world has left its debris in nearly every town and city in America. In Ware Shoals, S.C., most of the 900 workers at the Reigle textile plant, the town's largest employer, either retired or left town when the company, crippled by low-cost foreign imports, closed its factory for good in the mid-1980's.
And in Berkshire County, Mass., plant closings by both the General Electric Company and the Sprague Electric Company eliminated hundreds of good-paying manufacturing jobs in the late 1980's.
Lawrence Mishel, the research director at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, a group that studies job and wage trends, said the shift toward lower-paying jobs has profound effects that go beyond simple questions of income and poverty.
 
Deep Worries in Waterloo
 "What happens to families where both the parents are now working more hours just to stay even, often at crazy hours, at more than one job?" he asked. "What does this do to our notions about traditional values and family life?"
During a week of conversations with dozens of people in Waterloo, a manufacturing city of 70,000 people in northeastern Iowa, these kinds of deep worries were mentioned again and again, by many of the very people who are now trying to make sense of their own place in the new economy; people who work, but who are barely making a living.
Like many others, the Daltons have been forced to forgo their dreams. With the help of friends, they were able to hang on to their three-bedroom house in Reinbeck, near Waterloo. But there are no vacations now, and there is no more talk of a retirement cottage.
 
 The Comeback

Building on Jobs That Pay Less
Just five years ago, cynics in Waterloo used to joke, "Will the last one out of Waterloo please turn out the lights."
Back then, local unemployment was 12 percent. The Rath meat-packing plant had just closed, permanently laying off more than 1,000 workers, and the John Deere factory -- the town's economic anchor and largest employer, the place generations here have referred to as Papa John -- was sending more than half its workers home for good. Hard hit by the sinking agricultural economy, which dried up the market for its tractors and other farm machinery, Deere reduced its employment here to 6,200 from 16,300.
Amid this gloom, voters elected Bernie McKinley as Mayor. Mr. McKinley was a former insurance man who used to preach at motivational seminars for company salesmen, and his buoyant optimism seemed the perfect tonic for the times. In appearances before business people and city officials, he preached an insistent gospel of civic self-assurance.
"We can be anything we want to be, if we just set our minds to it," he told the City Council, and then exacted a pledge from his fellow civic leaders that Waterloo would do whatever was necessary to add 1,000 new jobs each year.
 
8,000 Jobs in 4 Years
 In fact, Mayor McKinley and the city's economic development boosters have done far more than that. In four years, Waterloo and surrounding Black Hawk County have added 8,000 new jobs and more than 120 new businesses.
Some are manufacturing jobs in small, nonunion shops. But most are service jobs in the new health centers and strip malls and other businesses that have appeared along roadsides, emblems of Waterloo's growing, nonindustrial job base.
Mr. McKinley, a nattily dressed man who drives a blue Cadillac, likes to take visitors on tours of the new Waterloo. He shows them the $2 million renovation at Crossroads Mall on the south side. There are three new motels and a sleek greyhound racing track that employs 200 people.
 
Factory Wave of Future
 Northwest of town, near the airport, two new telemarketing companies employ a total of 400 people. And in the cornfields east of the town, the biggest catch of all: the factory of IBP Inc., formerly Iowa Beef Processors.
If the old Rath plant represented what used to be -- an old, inefficient behemoth where workers earned more than $10 an hour and full benefits -- IBP is the new wave. It built a sleek, $50 million, technically advanced meat-packing plant where starting wages, under a new contract with the United Food and Commercial Workers, are just $6.50 an hour and everyone pays $30 a month for minimum family health coverage.
Mayor McKinley acknowledges that the work pays only a fraction of the wages and benefits that workers earned at Rath, or the $17 an hour still paid at Deere.
"But before IBP came here, we had people riding up to Charles City, more than 100 miles round trip, just to work in a chicken factory for $3.75 an hour," he said. "These days jobs don't pay what the old jobs did. But any job is better than no job."
 
 The Struggle

Life for Four On $4.20 an Hour
In the living room of John Terrones's small, cluttered house in nearby Cedar Falls is a cardboard box piled high with travel booklets; bright, glossy brochures put out by state tourist agencies in South Carolina, Michigan and Colorado.
Late at night, after his two children are put to bed, Mr. Terrones says he sits down and browses through the catalogues, lingering over the photographs of sunsets and green mountain vistas.
"I don't know if I'll ever be able to really see any of these places," said Mr. Terrones, who is 30 years old and works 40 hours each week as an orderly at a nursing home, where he is paid $4.20 an hour. "But this way, at least I can say I know what they look like."
Every two weeks, Mr. Terrones brings home about $300. On weekends, he makes a few dollars more, cleaning houses or doing yard work for neighbors for $5 an hour.
 
Mother Must Stay Home
 Out of that, he pays rent of $150, a car payment of $131 and utility bills of about $100. The telephone costs another $25 and gas that much more again. In the end, there is barely enough left over for groceries.
Mr. Terrones's wife, Linda, does not work. She has to stay home with their son, Tony, 2, who has developmental problems and can neither speak nor sit up.
This year, because of Tony's medical disability, the Terrones began receiving supplmental Social Security payments of about $386 a month. Still, the family's annual income totals barely $13,000, which puts them just over the poverty line.
"I've looked around for other jobs, but they all pay around $5 an hour," said Mr. Terrones, who has worked in the past as a clerk in a fast food restaurant and as a school janitor.
When Mr. Terrones graduated from high school in Cedar Falls in 1979, he said, he hoped to be a cook and someday run his own restaurant. These days, he will settle for something much simpler. "What I wish for now is a decent job at decent wages," he said. "Someday, I'd like to be able to live without having to scrimp for every penny."
 
 A Divided City

Declining Hopes Amid Decay
From his rectory windows, the Rev. George Karnik can see the towers of the Rath plant. Abandoned, it looms over St. John's Roman Catholic Church and the surrounding neighborhood, a symbol of a time that has gone and will probably never return.
The city would like to tear down the old packing plant, at one time the world's largest, employing 7,000 workers, and turn the site into a riverfront industrial park. But the plans will have to wait. The demolition bill alone is estimated at $5 million.
"You can't begin to absorb what it means when a plant like that closes," Father Karnik said.
The city has changed. To the south and to the west of Waterloo, there are new stores and new houses, even a whole new high-rise office complex where, Mayor McKinley hopes, as many as 2,000 workers will be someday.
 
An Area Left Behind
 But here, on the east side, there is a feeling of a place and of people left behind.
Al and Myrna Costa used to stand behind the bar at Babe's Tavern and count out as much as $100,000 in cash every payday, waiting on the regulars who would stop in after their shift ended to cash their paychecks and have a few cold ones.
"Now I'm lucky if I see a couple of Social Security checks," said Mr. Costa, who not long ago had to take a second job, working as a bank courier, so he and his wife could keep the bar open.
"Used to be, you worked hard, you figure you got someplace," he said. "Now I got to work two jobs to stay even."
The changes sadden Father Karnik. "The days, the weeks, used to have a rhythm for people," he said. "People came home at night. They had weekends. Now people got to settle for whatever jobs they can get. They work odd hours. They come and go at different times of the day. They work whenever they can."
In the waiting room of the Cedar Valley Food Bank, a half-dozen people sit on folding metal chairs. It is quiet. No one looks up when someone walks in the door.
A volunteer is at the front of the room. Every so often, she calls out a number, and a person stands up and steps forward to fetch a cardboard box in which there are breakfast cereal and rice cakes, day-old baked goods and butter, crackers and cookies.
 
Still a Need for Food
 Ruth Toney, the director of the food bank, said the number of hungry people who are coming in for help has stayed constant or grown slightly over the last four years, despite the thousands of new jobs in town.
Meanwhile, donations of money and food have declined. "People don't want to hear the bad news," Mrs. Toney said. "They hear about all these jobs, and they see the new stores on the edge of town, and the ads on TV where IBP is looking for workers, and they don't think people are hungry or need help."
A growing share of the food bank's recipients are now working people, Mrs. Toney said. "They have jobs," she said. "But what difference does it make if those jobs just don't pay a living wage?"
Jethroe Parsons, his wife, Linda, and their three young daughters, live in a tumbledown house on the edge of downtown Waterloo. Sheets and blankets are stretched over the windows in place of curtains. The living room and dining room are empty, except for a plaid sofa and a plastic milk box that the Parsons turn upside down and use sometimes as a stool, sometimes as a dining table.
Two months ago, they moved from Milwaukee's inner city, seeking steady work and a better life. In Wisconsin, they were living in public housing in a neighborhood plagued with drug dealing and crime. Mr. Parsons said he had worked there, but the jobs were usually in the suburbs and only paid a dime or so above minimum wage.
 
Misfortune and Problems on the Job
 At first, the Parsonses thought they had struck gold in Iowa. Both were hired at IBP, working separate shifts and earning about $400 a week between them. Their children were in good schools. And they found a three-bedroom house to rent for just $325 a month.
But Mrs. Parsons became ill and had to quit. Then Mr. Parsons pulled his thumb out of its socket on the job, and he said he got into a dispute with a foreman over whether he was well enough to come back to work.
Company officials said that was not the problem. They said he missed too many days of work during his 90-day probationary period. He was dismissed in early November and is now looking for work again.
"We'll make it, one way or the other," Mr. Parsons said. He said he had been to the employment office and there were other jobs, which pay minimum wage mostly, as a night janitor or a nursing home orderly. "All in all, we're still better off here than in Milwaukee," he said. "Half a loaf is still better than none. In Wisconsin, we didn't even have any bread."
 
 The Future

Working More And Playing Less
As the economic landscape of Waterloo has changed, so have the demographics of work and play.
When Rath was running at full speed and Deere employed twice the people, said Adrian Erickson, the owner of the town's biggest bowling establishment, Cadillac Lanes, he used to work around the clock, running industrial leagues.
As recently as 1982, nearly 12,000 men and women were enrolled in leagues in Waterloo, filling Cadillac Lanes' 50 alleys. Last year league membership fell below 5,000.
"People don't have the big paychecks anymore," Mr. Erickson said. "And they don't have the leisure time. Both the husband and wife work, sometimes at more than one job."
Nearby, at Local 838 of the United Automobile Workers, the average age of the membership has climbed steadily as the union's membership rolls have declined.
Layoffs at Deere took the younger workers. Now, most Deere workers are men with at least 14 years of seniority, those in their early to mid-40's, said Jim Schuler, the union's regional representative.
"Young people don't really have much of a chance here anymore," Mr. Schuler said, recalling the days when, as a high school student in Waterloo, he would talk with friends about whether they would try to get a job at Rath or Deere after graduation. "Nowadays, you listen to the kids, and they're talking about what state they are going to go to look for work."

HEADLINE: ANTI-DRUG EFFORT DRAGS OUTSIDE U.S.

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Nearly two years after President Bush declared his war on drugs, Administration officials say they have made little progress toward blocking narcotics trafficking from Latin America into the United States.
"We've had a degree of success," said Melvyn Levitsky, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, "but nowhere near what we want to have." 
 Administration officials say better progress has been made on cutting demand for drugs. They say that drug consumption has been reduced among some sectors of American society and that this answers Latin American criticism that not enough is being done to tackle drug abuse at its true source -- the abuser.
But the Administration's program, as outlined in a White House report to Congress in January, includes among its goals a reduction of imports of cocaine and other illegal drugs by 15 percent by the end of 1992 and by 60 percent by the end of the 1990's. Administration officials said they could not be sure if imports of cocaine, the drug that is exacting the greatest toll on the United States, had been cut by even 5 percent in the last year.
 
Shipments Redirected
 The officials noted that while they have succeeded in stemming nearly half of the cocaine trafficking through the Caribbean into Florida, statistics on drug seizures indicate that shipments have merely been redirected through Central America and Mexico into the American Southwest.
John P. Walters, who will be acting director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy when William J. Bennett's resignation takes effect at the end of the month, acknowledged that "there's the risk of failure" in American efforts.
"These are countries with enormous economic and social problems," Mr. Walters said of the Latin American drug-producing nations. "At times, we're working in areas where governments don't even exercise control."
For example, Administration officials said that while the Colombian Government has made much progress interrupting the operations of the cocaine ring based in Medellin, Colombia, it has overlooked the growth of the country's other major cocaine ring, operating out of Cali. The disruption of the Medellin ring has also encouraged new drug gangs and coca cultivations to appear in Bolivia, Ecuador, Brazil and Venezuela.
"It's like hitting mercury with a hammer," said a State Department official who deals with drug policy.
 
Panama Banking Laws an Issue
 The problem extends even to Panama, where the United States invaded 11 months ago to overthrow a Government allegedly linked to drug traffickers. American officials noted that the new Government is resisting attempts to rewrite banking secrecy laws that are utilized by drug money launderers. Panamanian officials insist that the current laws are more than adequate to prevent such abuses.
Some officials said they worried that while the Administration concentrated on limiting cocaine production and shipments from the Andean countries, cultivation of heroin poppies was rising in Guatemala and Mexico.
The Bush Administration approach links trade preferences to anti-narcotics efforts and emphasizes disrupting trafficking organizations by destroying processing labs over the more traditional approach, crop eradication. Central to its war on cocaine is the so-called Andean Initiative, a five-year, $2.2 billion aid program to break up cocaine production and trafficking organizations and strengthen local economies and government institutions.
Administration officials said that the disruption of some trafficking has caused a substantial drop in coca leaf prices in parts of Bolivia and Peru, prompting some peasants to switch voluntarily to legal crops, and that a modest decrease in cocaine imports in some parts of the United States resulted in a decrease in the potency and an increased in the price of cocaine sold in several American cities.
 
$2.2 Billion Aid Program
 But American officials point to Peru as the toughest problem facing the Administration's drug war in Latin America. With 300,000 acres of land planted in coca and 200,000 peasants employed in its cultivation, Peru is by far the largest source of the raw material for cocaine. The Peruvian Army is reluctant to disrupt coca-growing for fear of driving the farmers into the arms of the leftist Shining Path guerrillas, and the rebels profit from the coca trade by taxing traffickers.
A State Department official who recently traveled to Bolivia described visiting a farm owned by a peasant named Florencio in the Chapare coca-growing region. Florencio had destroyed more than 40 acres of coca plants in the last year in exchange for thousands of dollars in American economic aid, and now cultivates papayas, black pepper and macadamia nuts.
But not all is going well at Florencio's farm. He and his family still live in a dilapidated shack. He complains that life was easier in the days when the cocaine middlemen used to come to him to buy coca leaves; now he has to drive his pickup truck four hours on bad roads to sell his produce. And he continues to grow a few acres of coca as a hedge.
"Florencio is the model but he is still not getting ahead," said the State Department official. "He told us he made more money last year growing coca. It's discouraging."

HEADLINE: Japanese Believed Near Purchase Of the Owner of Universal Studios

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
MCA Inc., one of the nation's largest entertainment companies, and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan are expected to announce as early as today that Matsushita is acquiring MCA.
People involved in the negotiations cautioned yesterday that some issues remained to be settled. But simply that the negotiations have come so far, in a difficult economic climate, reflects the voracious foreign appetite for American entertainment companies. 
 The board of MCA, which owns Universal Studios, Universal Pictures and MCA Records, is expected to meet in New York today and accept Matsushita's offer, which is believed to total $6.7 billion to $6.9 billion.
That would bring MCA stockholders $72 to $74 a share. In recent days MCA's stock has been trading in the high 60's. When the companies first disclosed in late September that they were negotiating, MCA stock was trading around $34.50.
If the deal is completed, Universal will become the third major Hollywood studio to be acquired by foreigners in about a year. In the fall of 1989, the Sony Corporation, a rival of Matsushita, bought Columbia Pictures for $5 billion. Last month, the Pathe Communications Corporation, owned by the Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti, completed its $1.3 billion acquisition of the MGM/UA Communications Corporation. A fourth studio, 20th Century Fox, is owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which is incorporated in Australia.
Matsushita (pronounced maht-SOOSH-tah), best known for its consumer-electronics products sold under the Panasonic, Quasar and Technics brand names, controls an empire of 87 companies in Japan and nearly as many abroad. [Business, section 3.]
The drive by foreigners to acquire American movie companies is a natural one, given that no other country's film industry has ever been able to produce movies with worldwide appeal. And American moviegoers, who make up one of the world's biggest audiences, have little interest in foreign films. As such, foreign entertainment companies have difficulty selling their films in the United States. Taken together, those conditions make movies one of America's biggest net exports.
MCA owns an extensive film library -- including the "Jaws" films and "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial." It also operates a broad television production business that has produced "Miami Vice" and other hit series. Its relatively small record division was recently bolstered by the acquisition of Geffen Records, whose artists include the rock group Guns 'n' Roses.
The company's other main business is theme parks. MCA operates the Universal Studios tour in at the company's headquarters in Universal City, Calif., just outside Los Angeles. Recently, it opened a second studio tour in Orlando, Fla.
 
Skyrocketing Costs
 At least in the opinion of some experts in the movie business, profits may have peaked and it is time to sell. Certainly the Japanese are buying in as film production and distribution costs are skyrocketing and as profit margins for many American film companies could begin to slide.
"Profits will be down slightly in 1990, down more in 1991, and they could be down again in 1992," said David Londoner, a media industry analyst at Wertheim Schroeder & Company. "Basically, things have just gotten out of hand. Costs have skyrocketed, but the box office is essentially flat. The home video business is still growing, but more slowly."
But how well the Japanese investment will pay off remains unclear.
In buying first CBS Records and then Columbia Pictures, Sony officials said they wanted to achieve "vertical integration," in which their company would make and sell hardware for entertainment -- Walkman tape players, videocassette recorders, compact disk players and so on -- and also produce the "software" played on those machines.
Since then, vertical integration has become an entertainment industry buzzword, and Matsushita and its president, Akio Tanii, apparently felt compelled to follow Sony's example.
 
Long View of the Japanese
 Harold Vogel, a media analyst at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, notes that the Japanese are known to take a long-term view.
"The assumption is that the ability to sell multimedia products is the key to future market share growth," he said. "But there is no indication to date that the strategy will be successful in the movie business. At this point in time, the theory has not proven right or wrong."
If the MCA deal is completed, Matsushita plans to keep MCA's management in place, people involved in the negotiations say. But Matsushita has not said how closely it will oversee them.
Sony, on the other hand, spelled out a hands-off management strategy for Columbia. But that goal has run into an unexpected hurdle at Sony's record division. The Japanese had counted on Walter Yetnikoff, the chairman of CBS Records, who orchestrated its sale to Sony, to stay in place. But Mr. Yetnikoff said recently that he had decided to step aside. Sony's president, Norio Ohga, is effectively running that company for the time being.
 
Boon for Shareholders
 However the anticipated MCA deal works out for Matsushita, it should prove a boon for MCA shareholders. Lew Wasserman, who has been MCA's chairman for decades, had originally hoped to get as much as $90 a share for the company, according to industry reports. While the purchase price will be lower, it is nevertheless higher than MCA's stock has ever traded.
Mr. Londoner, the media analyst, estimated that if a deal was completed at $72 a share, MCA shareholders would receive $69 in cash and a share of stock or a fraction of a share of stock worth about $3 in MCA's television station in the New York City area, WWOR-TV.
The merged company would be forced to create a separate company to own WWOR-TV, Channel 9, which is based in Secaucus, N.J., because Federal laws prohibit foreign ownership of broadcast stations.
MCA, founded in 1923 by Jules Stein as the Music Corporation of America, has one of the most stable managements in the entertainment business. Along with Mr. Wasserman, its president, Sidney J. Sheinberg, has been at the company for decades.

 
Biggest Beneficiaries
 The merger will make Mr. Wasserman and Mr. Sheinberg enormously wealthy. Another beneficiary will be David Geffen, the record executive who acquired 10 million shares of MCA stock when he sold Geffen Records to MCA this year.
The final negotiations have had their moments of volatility, particularly because Mr. Wasserman is an unusually tough negotiator who resisted selling his company during a decade marked by mergers, despite repeated interest from blue-chip buyers.
After negotiations started in New York last Monday, things did not go smoothly, and as recently as Wednesday night there was considerable skepticism among the negotiators that a deal would be reached.
Mr. Wasserman was said to be unhappy with the price that Matsushita was offering.
But by Thursday the mood was better, a person involved in the talks said, and the price gap narrowed.
 
Shuttling Between Law Firms
 Bankers, lawyers and the principals themselves shuttled between Simpson Thatcher & Barlett, the law firm representing Matsushita, and Watchel, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, MCA's law firm, throughout the weekend.
Felix G. Rohatyn, a partner in Lazard Freres & Company, the investment banker representing MCA, returned from a Thanksgiving holiday for talks on Friday and Saturday.
Herbert Allen, a partner at Allen & Company, the investment banking firm representing Matsushita, joined the negotiations, as did Michael Ovitz, head of Creative Artists Agency, which had brought the two companies together.

HEADLINE: Lean Times for Daily News Strikers

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
For Ruben Vazquez, the hardest thing about being on strike against The Daily News is hearing the playful squeals of his youngest granddaughter, Ivana.
"I don't have money to buy presents for my granddaughters, and it makes me feel so sad that I don't look foward to Christmas," he said as the toddler tumbled into his lap in his Bronx apartment. "I see them and it breaks my heart to think that on Christmas I will come up short." 
 As one of 2,300 striking union members, Mr. Vazquez is having to scrimp to make ends meet with meager strike benefits, limited savings and a new-found frugality. Co-workers who have crossed the picket line have suggested he follow them back to work, saying that his $53,000 job supervising the computer room is still open. But he has refused, saying that he will only return when his union, the Newspaper Guild, has signed a new contract.
He spent the day after Thanksgiving doing some cajoling of his own in front of the stores on Fordham Road in the Bronx, buttonholing Christmas shoppers and pressing leaflets into their hands urging them to boycott stores that advertised in The News.
 
$800,000 Strike Fund
 Other families are cutting back expenses, juggling bills and feeling the pressure as the strike enters its second month. Members of eight of the nine striking unions are entitled to as much as $150 in weekly strike pay as long as they put in a minimum of 16 hours a week distributing handbills or walking the picket lines. Only drivers union members get no strike pay. If the strike continues into mid-December, all the strikers will be eligible to collect several hundred dollars more each month in unemployment benefits.
Barry Lipton, president the Newspaper Guild of New York, said the strike benefits provided by the international headquarters of his union were, on average, higher than the other unions'. His local had also built up an $800,000 strike fund, augmented by $35,000 in donations from sympathetic people and unions in other industries, which the union is using for printing, telephones and transportation.
In cooperation with the New York City Central Labor Council, the Guild has set up a telephone number for strikers to call if they need personal or financial counseling or help working out payment problems with creditors. One local bank is offering $2,000 loans to qualified strikers, Mr. Lipton said.
 
Determined to Make It Through
 Mr. Vazquez, a boyish, quiet-spoken 49-year-old whose black hair is flecked with gray, is determined to make it through the strike. At the outset, he and his wife, Millie, huddled with their children and set financial priorities, deciding that the rent, utilities, food and credit card debt would take precedence over any other expenses.
Luckily, they pay only $405 monthly for the five-and-a-half room apartment in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx where they have lived since they were newlyweds.
They no longer eat out, and Mrs. Vazquez buys food in bulk, foregoing red meat for chicken and carefully saving leftovers. Their two grown daughters who live with them, Vicky, a law firm secretary, and Elena, a corporate travel agent, have also begun to chip in, bringing home sacks of groceries and helping with a few hundred dollars here and there. Their two other children who are married, Julie-Ann, a bank secretary, and Eric, an appliance salesman, have helped, too.
The couple also got a two-month deferment from credit card companies to whom they owe $6,000.
 
Dipping Into Savings
 The Vazquezes have dipped into the $10,000 they had saved toward retirement, and say that as a last resort, they will sell the quarter-acre they own near Fort Myers, Fla., on which they had planned to build their retirement home.
Mr. Vazquez said that the strike benefits and the $264 he expected to collect in unemployment insurance would help. "I feel I can budget myself, counting there is no illness or something tragic," he said.
In their bright living room, where one wall is covered with dozens of pictures of their children, Mrs. Vazquez said that the strike has helped bring the family closer together, with most of them -- including grandchildren in strollers -- regularly going out to rallies along with their father.
She said she sat down with the children in the early days of the strike while her husband was out of the house and bluntly told them that the uncertain future would test their mettle.
 
'We Have to Pick Him Up'
 "Now Daddy is down and we have to pick him up," she explained. "That moral and emotional support surprisingly helps a lot. If I nagged him about the bills, that would destroy him."
Still, she said, she is worried about the toll the strike has taken on her normally cheerful spouse, saying that he can overreact to the slightest irritation and that most mornings he awakens at 4 o'clock and lies in bed staring at the ceiling. "All of a sudden this Rock of Gibraltar is being moved," she said.
Mr. Vazquez said he has invested too much time in the union to back off now, even though his wife had urged him to look for another job rather than endure the constant tension.
"This is not for me, but for the labor movement," he said. "It's because of the unions that the average person in large cities is making a better salary."
He said that if he saw no progress in the strike by early next year, he would consider looking for a part-time data-processing job that would leave time to devote to the strike.
 
Some Have Not Waited
 Some strikers have decided not to wait, including a number of high-profile writers who joined other news organizations. Mr. Vazquez said he understood the defections.
"Offers only come around once, especially nowadays, no matter how good you are," he said.
But he does not understand those who have crossed the picket line, including those who have told him they could not bear the financial burden of striking. He said he had reminded them of single mothers who had vowed to stand firm despite the hardship.
"We all need the money, but if these girls can stay out on strike, how could somebody else be so weak?"

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Minors and Majors Are Ready to Split

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
"Bye-bye, minor leagues."
Margaret Bavasi, the co-owner of the Class A minor league team in Everett, Wash., was devastated when she saw that headline recently in a local newspaper. 
 "People here are confused," Bavasi said from her Washington home. "The city of Everett trusted us to have baseball here, in place. What they're reading in the paper makes them think we won't have baseball here anymore. What is happening has threatened my livelihood, my family, my community."
What has happened? Negotiations between the major and minor leagues have failed to produce a new professional baseball agreement. The current contract expires Jan. 11. With it could go a relationship that has existed since 1901.
Close to 60 minor league clubs have seen their contracts with the parent clubs expire. Other clubs are still affiliated with major league teams, but they also belong to the National Association, the minors' governing body. And that association vows to fight on the merits of its positions even if it means bolting from the majors. Sal Artiaga, commissioner of the National Association, said: "We feel we have to retain the right of self-governance. That's free enterprise. You have to have the right to control your own destiny."
 
Thorny Questions
 The very idea of two minor league systems is already prompting questions, such as who will own the territorial rights to cities and what assignments of players will be honored if the majors start moving players from the secessionists to new outfits.
As much as fans might like to think otherwise, the idyllic image of a minor league life style may be shattered for good by the economic hardball and power plays more readily associated the big leagues. That should not surprise, however. The relationship between the majors and minors has changed. It has done so, in large part, because the minors -- and their worth -- have changed, something the majors couldn't help but notice.
"The 26 major league clubs pay the travel expenses to and from spring training for the players, signing bonuses, the instructors, the managers, the coaches, the trainers," said Bill Murray, the majors' director of baseball operations. Now, he said, the minors' latest proposal would add $150,000 per team to what each major league club already pays, approximately $4.5 million to $6 million per year.
"We train them in spring training, then drop them off on their doorstep," Murray said. "Look, all we're looking for is a fairer shake in setting the structure, seeing to it that it is able to meet the needs of our clubs."
If that is not attainable through negotiations, Murray said, the 26 major league clubs are willing to start a new farm system. And he has warned that a negotiating session in New York on Tuesday may be the last before the split does, indeed, occur.
 
Clock Is Ticking
 How close is that? "I believe the clock is relevant now," said Marvin Goldklang, a limited partner of the Yankees and co-owner of four minor league teams, including Triple-A Oklahoma City. "And I believe it's tied very closely to the timetable of winter meetings."
The minors will gather in Los Angeles and the majors in Chicago the first week of December. "That's where contingency planning sessions will be held and that irreversible step could take place," Goldklang said. Still, Goldklang, for one, remains optimistic. "I believe this will be resolved because people, for the most part, do not commit mass suicide," he said. "It's simply got to be resolved because, if it isn't, if ball parks across the country start going dark, we're not only all going to be losers, but big losers."
Bavasi, though, is more than concerned. "This has really blindsided us," she said, even though her team is still affiliated with the San Francisco Giants. "It shows us we really aren't in control. For seven years, we had an excellent relationship with the Giants. Now, we can't sell season tickets or advertising. We really thought our future depended on how well we operated. I didn't think that major league baseball, or make that the commissioner's office, would come in and do this to us."
 
Seen as Encroachment
 The latter comment refers to an issue that has apparently touched quite a few nerves. The majors have attempted to formalize rules regarding scheduling, travel and ownership transfers. Minor league owners see that as attempted encroachment not by owners but the office of the baseball commissioner.
"The commissioner has always had the authority to step in," Murray said, referring to a "best interest of baseball" clause historically included in contracts between the majors and minors. The new proposals, he said, came from the ownership committee, not Fay Vincent, the commissioner. "It's important for us to know that the system works well," Murray said. "We don't think that it does."
Still, the proposals were so troublesome to Bavasi she decided to try to go right to Vincent. He declines to speak publicly on the contract issues, however, saying he is not a part of the negotiations. Instead, he refers all questions to Murray and the owners involved in the negotiations. And Murray, the chief negotiator, has talked to Bavasi.
Still, Bavasi said: "We need to know where the commissioner stands on this. What is broken that he thinks needs to be fixed? He seeks to control us, we've been told, but he has yet to say anything on the problems we're having in negotiations. I don't know what kind of man he is. Can we trust him? I don't know who's hands my future is in."
 
Business Is Booming
 Just as sensitive an issue is economics. The minors are enjoying a resurgence. Attendance in the 17 leagues exceeded 25 million this year, a 37-year high. While there are "mom-and-pop" operations among the approximately 170 teams across the United States, Canada, as well as the Dominican Republic and Mexico, there are also big-business success stories.
In 1976, Joe Buzas bought a team in Reading, Pa., for $1. Ten years later, he sold it for $1 million. Ben Bernard, who bought the West Haven, Conn., team for $75,000 in 1979, then moved it to Albany a year later, sold that club for more than $2.5 million in 1985. The Edmonton team in the Pacific Coast League is reportedly changing ownership for $6 million in Canadian currency. Teams in the Class A California League that sold for $125,000 a few years ago now go as much as $1.2 million.
The majors look at such numbers, their expenses and wonder about the formula. Murray, giving one example, said the average expenditure for player salaries on a Triple A team is $785,000. The parent club pays all but $21,000.
"We've indicated our willingness to play a greater economic role," Artiaga said. The minor leagues have offered to relinquish annual payments made by the majors for the right to beam national television broadcasts into the minors' territories; the fees totaled $1.8 million last year. The minors have also offered to hand over 5 percent of their net ticket revenue; that could amount to $1.5 million in 1992.
While the minors would prefer the status quo, some owners say the money is negotiable, but only so long as the control issue is taken off the table. And the minors are not ready to give up as much money as the majors want.
So there's no settlement. Bottom lines being what they are, neither side has moved far away from its own to make a difference yet.

HEADLINE: The New Order;
Peace Isn't So Simple as the End of Cold War

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WHEN revolutions or wars turn things upside down, the politicians, craving stability, always start trying to institutionalize the new world order. After Napoleon came the Holy Alliance, after World War I the League of Nations, after World War II the United Nations. So last week, 34 countries -- the United States, Canada and all the European states except Albania -- had a go, around a hexagonal table in Paris, at inventing something to replace the cold war and its institutions.
The conference did better at architecture than at construction, describing and to a degree designing the common European home that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union likes to talk about, but not actually building much. 
 It ratified the end of the cold war -- even Mr. Bush finally overcame his reluctance to confine that conflict to the dustheap of history -- but all it actually created were three offices (in Warsaw, Prague and Vienna) and a schedule of future meetings for foreign ministers and heads of government.
Worse, all sorts of uncertainties kept crowding in upon those who had come to Paris, reminding them how many unresolved questions they faced.
Groping its way toward a new foreign policy whose prime aim may be to contain conflict that threatens its economic interests, rather than containing Communism, and toward a new multilateralism, based in considerable degree on the United Nations, the United States finds itself curiously dependent upon the old adversary, the Soviet Union.
Before and during the conference, Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d held three long and apparently difficult meetings with Mr. Gorbachev and with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, seeking, in effect, their blessing for the use of force against Iraq. The United States no longer feels completely comfortable about going to war, as it did in Vietnam, without clearing it with the Soviets and with many others.
If the United States needs the Soviet Union in that respect, Moscow desperately needs Washington and Washington's old cold war allies if it is to have any hope of successfully tackling its economic difficulties. Facing the onset of winter with grocery store shelves bare, Mr. Gorbachev went shopping in Paris for food.
He gave Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada a list of shortages that included flour, pork, cooking oil and other commodities, and he won the promise of an early visit from a high-level European Community delegation bearing the details of emergency assistance worth at least $1 billion.
The United States is reluctant to pour money into what it sees as an impossibly inefficient system. But even if most of the effort is wasted, Washington will find itself obliged to try to help ward off famine; that issue, along with new arms-reduction initiatives, is sure to stand at the head of the agenda for the next Bush-Gorbachev meeting, tentatively scheduled for January.
But an even greater concern was discussed here, though not reflected in any of the official documents or much mentioned at news conferences. Finnish, Czech and Polish officials talked openly with their colleagues about their fears that Mr. Gorbachev may open his borders, allowing millions of refugees, many with ethnic ties outside the Soviet Union, to head west.
Such a tidal wave of migration, if it developed, might put a particular strain on Germany, which is already struggling to bring its eastern regions up to the level of the western areas, and which must also absorb ethnic Germans from the wobbly new democracies across Eastern Europe.
There is little that the rest of Europe can do about migration; there is nothing it can do about the threat of national disintegration in the Soviet Union. While Mr. Gorbachev has comprehensively reorganized his country's system of government for the second time in a year, there is no assurance that the new system will take hold in the republics far from Moscow, and Boris Yeltsin is still threatening that Russia may have to raise its own army.
There is much irony in all of this, of course. Perestroika and glasnost have made freedom in Eastern Europe, arms reduction and the end of the cold war possible; in that sense they have helped to build stability. But they have raised expectations where once there were few, unleashing economic and ethnic and political forces that have helped to destroy stability.
The tanks facing each other across central Europe are no longer the problem, in other words, but the economic and political tumult swirling about them can be every bit as lethal.Jozsef Antall, the Hungarian Prime Minister, spoke here of the dangers of replacing the Iron Curtain with a Welfare Wall.
In such a situation, there can obviously be no certainty that Mr. Gorbachev will last until January. The tenuousness of power was demonstrated for all to see during the conference, not only by his troubles, rumbling away over the horizon, but also by those of leaders who live nearby. The minority Government of Premier Michel Rocard of France survived a censure motion by only five votes, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher didn't survive at all.
Mrs. Thatcher's downfall introduces another uncertainty into Mr. Bush's calculations. If Mr. Gorbachev has been the agent of change over the last decade, working with two American Presidents to dismantle decades of hostility, the Iron Lady has been the most reliable ally in all things, from the bombing of Libya to preserving NATO to the crisis in the Persian Gulf.
 
A New Tune?
 None of the three contenders to succeed her is likely to change the words that constitute British foreign policy, but each will have his own music -- Michael Heseltine, who first challenged Mrs. Thatcher and ran her a close enough second on a first ballot for the Conservative Party leadership that she chose not to stay in the race for a second, or John Major or Douglas Hurd, who both joined the fray after Mrs. Thatcher withdrew on Thursday.
The Soviet Union and Germany want the mechanism established here, known rather cumbersomely as the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, to grow eventually into a pan-European security system to replace NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
Britain and the United States have prevented that, for the moment. But the leader who succeeds Mrs. Thatcher, together with Mr. Bush, will eventually have to find some means to ease Moscow's feeling of isolation from Europe's main organizations, NATO and the Common Market, and to assure Eastern European nations that they are not permanent poor cousins.
Vaclav Havel, the President of Czechoslovakia, says his country and others in Eastern Europe sense that they are in "a political and security vacuum." That kind of feeling breeds resentment, especially when accompanied by reawakened nationalist emotions.
If they are to achieve the stability they want, the leaders of the big countries will have to find ways to address that problem, along with all the others, before meeting next in Helsinki in 1992.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Leftovers;
Musings on Cold Turkey

BYLINE: RICHARD F. SHEPARD

 BODY:
THE weekend after Thanksgiving is one that finds the American home deep in the leftovers that are a challenge to the hands that rule the kitchen. The turkey often gains flavor on the second day, certainly when, with the help of barley and vegetables, it is transformed into turkey soup, or, in a lighter vein, into turkey salad and, not at the top of every gourmet's list, turkey croquettes. It is also, perhaps, a time for musing about leftovers of other kinds.
The idea of leftovers is one that runs through the story of humankind, where what to do with surpluses on the one hand and shortages on the other
have led to war, to invention, to skullduggery, to idealism. 
 A political visionary named Joseph limned an economic program for Egypt whereby the leftovers of seven good years would put pita on the table during seven lean ones. For thousands of years, the idea of storing left-over water from flood periods kept slaves building dikes along great rivers of the world.
Left-over people are basic to the ethnic conflicts erupting in areas where enclaves of groups, like Armenians, Indian Moslems, Jews and Arabs, Greeks and Turks, were left over during the great migrations.
In many ways, the left-over situation is one that hints of a prosperity, a surplus to be disposed of, a superfluity that may benefit others. The United States is lucky to be a country strong on leftovers. Excess grain is shipped off to places that are short on wheat. Army and Navy surpluses are sold in stores that cater to the chic or the frightened, with the heavier leftovers, like old airplanes, tanks and bombs, going to fuel the smaller wars whose players are willing to fight with leftovers.
The idea of having something left over is built in to the psyche of a country that counts Ben Franklin, the American Adam Smith who preached that a penny saved is a penny earned, among its founders. Savings implies leftovers, so it is small wonder that the spectacular failure of savings and loan institutions not only hit the nation in the pocket but in its belief that savings insured there will be something left over.
Paradoxically, the concept of left-over goes hand in hand with the concept of shortage. The label endangered species is an urgent call to preserve a breed -- elephant, rhinoceros, bald-headed eagle -- that has been hunted to the point where it has become a leftover, not a surplus but a struggling remnant. Left-over timberland, left-over houses of rare vintage, all of these become more dear as there are fewer of them. The left-over automobile of last year goes into a scrap heap, the automobile left over from 50 years ago becomes a rarity.
The rule is that a big left-over may be a problem, but if it dwindles to a minuscule left-over, it becomes precious.
But not always. The danger of degenerating into a left-over hangs over persons, peoples and nations. The homeless, the jobless, the rootless, all are part of the left-over problem in a nation grown used to surpluses, mostly of the good sort.

HEADLINE: The Region;
Albany Looks Longingly at Land It Can't Pay For

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
QUIETLY but arduously, New York State has been negotiating over the last few years to buy some of the most spectacular plots of privately held land in the state. Among these are Sterling Forest, an 18,000-acre parcel in Orange County that is the largest stretch of woodlands left in the New York City metropolitan area, and the Whitney Property, 51,000 acres of wilderness that includes one of the largest undeveloped lakes in the Adirondacks.
But with the voters' rejection earlier this month of the $1.975 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act, nearly half of which was to be spent on land acquisition, the state has no secure source of funds with which to buy such properties. And in the midst of the current financial straits -- legislative leaders will confer here this week to consider Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's call for up to 10,000 layoffs of state workers and sharp cuts in aid to local governments -- the odds that much money will be found in the general budget look slim. 
 Land acquisition was by no means the only casualty of the bond act's defeat, which lost in a 51 to 49 percent vote in the Nov. 6 election. The $175 million for park renovations and historic preservation and $100 million for part of the much-delayed, post-Westway esplanade along the Hudson River in Manhattan will not be forthcoming either.
There is also the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars that the state would have shared with local governments for closing leaking landfills, protecting water supplies and initiating recycling programs. Officials here say the state simply cannot provide anything close to these amounts without the level of borrowing that the bond act would have entailed.
Wittingly or unwittingly, the voters seem to have said that the costs of many projects would have to be borne at the local level, which most municipal leaders have already said will lead to steep tax increases. Closing landfills, upgrading sewage-treatment systems, even recycling -- all are burdens for local governments, many often mandated by the state. The only question left is how they will pay for them.
Land acquisition, however, is a separate issue. Nobody, it seems, "has to do it." But the bond act's defeat raises serious issues of whether the state would be wise to forego all land purchases, particularly those above the Long Island aquifer or in the Catskills watershed that help protect the drinking supply for millions of people in the downstate area.
Some efforts have been made to protect such land by revising zoning restrictions, but they have been known to run into legal challenges and often wind up forcing the state to pay anyway, by indemnifying private owners against any loss in land-use value. Not only has New York no money to buy land outright, but it has also run out of funds to purchase such conservation easements.
 Since the days of Theodore Roosevelt, the state has had a conservation tradition that served as both a legacy to future generations of New Yorkers and a model to other states in the nation. Forest preserves in both the Adirondacks and the Catskills, for instance, were set aside and declared, in the words of the state's constitution, to be "forever kept wild."
But for all the eloquence that Governor Cuomo sought to muster during his exhaustive personal campaign to push through the environmental bond measure, the voters' decision has, for now, left the state without the financial means to act on preservationist visions.
To many of the groups that fought the bond act, this is not a bad thing.
"Our basic position was that the state already owns nearly half the land in the Adirondacks," said Frederick H. Monroe, chairman of the Adirondack Fairness Coalition, which represents a group of North Country residents embittered by the push for wilderness.
 
Economic Issues
 Members of the coalition believe that preservation comes at the expense of the local economy, which is already depressed.
"The question that they wouldn't answer," Mr. Monroe said, "is, when is it all supposed to end?" About 13 percent of the state is owned by the state government, 300,000 acres of it bought with $240 million that came from two now-depleted 1972 and 1986 environmental bonds approved by voters.
Proponents of land preservation, however, ask the question differently: is now the time to stop altogether? Even some of the state officials who argued against the bond act on fiscal grounds, including State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, said they certainly did not believe that the state had run out of environmentally sensitive parcels to protect.
Many environmental groups, while bitterly disappointed at the bond act's narrow loss, are trying to put a brave face on the situation. "Whenever you have a defeat, you have an opportunity," said David J. Miller, the Northeast regional vice president of the National Audubon Society. "It awakens people."
The defeat "was by no means a vote against the environment," Mr. Miller added. "It seems to have sprung from fiscal concerns."
If borrowing to buy land is not in the offing, several environmental leaders said, then now is the time for the state to establish a permanent fund for land acquisition, probably with tax revenues set aside specifically for that purpose. Last year the Legislature created a new 2-cent-a-container tax whose revenues -- around $84 million -- were to be used to pay off debt on the bonds. Now that money will become available for other needs, with literally dozens of interests competing for it.
The state's environmental conservation commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, has said the state must look for alternative ways to finance land purchases, but he has yet to propose specifics.
The Governor, who was one of the few people anywhere in the state to warn early on that voters' fiscal concerns could easily run afoul of their Earth Day fervor and who is currently struggling to close large gaps in his budget, has already said that land acquisition cannot now be a priority.
"He made it clear all along -- without the bond act, the money would simply not be available," said Frank Murray, Mr. Cuomo's chief adviser on environmental affairs.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
For Immigrants, Tough Customers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
JOHN EDWARDS sometimes hears from angry customers who come into his clothing shop in Chicago's mostly black Roseland neighborhood, bringing their complaints about the Korean merchants whose stores are up and down 113th Street.
They tell him the Koreans are rude. They say they charge too much or sell produce that is not fresh. They say the Koreans treat all black people as if they were shoplifters. 
 "But mostly, they don't like it that these stores in their neighborhoods are owned not by black people, but by Koreans or Arabs," said Mr. Edwards, a black who is president of the local merchants association. "Their main complaint is, why are these people here?"
 These are increasingly familiar laments about the Asian, Arab and other foreign-born merchants who dominate the network of street-corner markets and liquor stores in inner-city neighborhoods around the country. Whatever the city and whatever the merchants' origins, the stories are strikingly similar.
The most clamorous fight is in Brooklyn, where a boycott of two Korean-owned markets is nearing its anniversary despite negotiations, a court order and a report from a mayoral task force that distributed blame in several directions. The picketing began after a black woman was chased from one of the stores last January. The grocers said she had refused to pay for all her purchases; the woman said she was assaulted without provocation.
In Philadelphia, two black men were shot in separate incidents last summer by Korean shopkeepers who said the men were attempting to rob them. The incidents provoked angry protests and picketing.
The targets of resentment are sometimes Indian or Chinese or Cuban, and in the Midwest, particularly, they are likely to be Arab. Earlier this year, Arab-American groups in Chicago were outraged by a sign that a white storekeeper put in the window of a store he was remodeling in a mostly black West Side neighborhood. It advised that "no Arabs will be involved" in the store's management.
For decades, many poorer neighborhoods, both black and white, have been served by small shops run mostly by immigrant entrepreneurs. Where there are Arabs and Koreans today, there were once Jews and Italians and Greeks, who pooled family resources and turned to wives and siblings and cousins to work long hours for a slim profit.
"To them, the store is everything," said Cherif Bassiouni, professor of law at DePaul University and president of the Mid-America Arab Chamber of Commerce. "It is their future and their hope. So when they see kids shoplifting, this is like taking the food from their mouths. They will fight back."
Among many Koreans, mostly immigrants who scraped together what they could to buy a small foothold on the American dream, complaints like the ones Mr. Edwards hears are galling. Yoon Lee, a sociologist and president of a Chicago-based Korean-language cable television station, said Koreans resent being cast "as scapegoats for the failure of American society to deal with the inequality among the races."
"I know black people look at us and see us succeed, and it only reminds them how far they are still behind," said Mr. Lee. "But you cannot blame Koreans or Arabs for that."
Many blacks see something different. "What they see are people who are not black, who are soaking up economic opportunities that ought to be available to them," said Ivan Light, a sociologist at the University of California at Los Angeles who has studied immigrant entrepreneurs. "They see people who are taking their money out of their neighborhood."
This resentment is compounded by cultural misperceptions. Koreans or Arabs who do not make eye contact or engage in small talk with customers, for example, are often perceived as rude when they are behaving as shopkeepers in their home countries do.
Judith Goode, a sociologist at Temple University, said foreign-born merchants do not necessarily share retailing traditions like "service with a smile."
"Americans manufacture affect as a part of commerce," she said, "whereas others feel business is to be done brusquely and quickly."
According to Dr. Goode, the number of mom-and-pop stores owned by immigrants also reflects the realities of the inner-city market. While such enterprises are opportunities for those with poor language skills, very few upwardly mobile blacks -- or, for that matter, American-born whites -- want to invest in small, marginal businesses in declining and sometimes dangerous neighborhoods.
And less well-off blacks who might be interested in a vacant store simply do not have the networks of informal financial support and business advice that is commonplace in immigrant communities.
Last summer, the tensions in the Roseland neighborhood led to picketing of some Korean-owned stores, as well as a march organized by Robert Shaw, a Chicago alderman. In response, the merchants promised, among other things, to hire more blacks and to deposit some receipts in black-owned banks.
Even Alderman Shaw now applauds the Koreans' efforts. And while he is still unhappy that it is Koreans or Arabs, rather than blacks, who are running stores, he said the real culprits are not the immigrants but lenders who won't help blacks buy into the American dream.
"I'm talking about black banks, too," said Mr. Shaw. "They loan somebody $80,000 in a blink to buy a new Mercedes, but they won't come up with $18,000 to make a down payment on a food market."
Unless black small business is encouraged, said Mr. Shaw, the situation will never change. "Except," he said, "that 20 years from now, it will be some other immigrant running the store where black people will still be spending their money."

HEADLINE: A Defense of Doctors In Treating AIDS

 BODY:
In a very informative article on the AIDS challenge in the suburbs ["The Challenge AIDS Presents in the Suburbs," Nov. 4], the limitations of space severely curtailed the elaborate commentary I provided on physicians' responsibility and involvement with AIDS in Westchester County.
I would like to elaborate on the complex issues relative to this incapacitating illness and assure the public that Westchester physicians are already extensively involved in the management of these patients -- and point out the factors that limit their ability to further participate. 
 It is quite unfair to suggest, as did the executive director of AIDS Related Community Services, that the Westchester County Medical Society has "not taken the leadership role it could have."
First and foremost, neither that organization nor its executive director has ever approached the Westchester County Medical Society asking for assistance.
The Westchester County Medical Society is a representative organization for physicians, not an advocacy group. The Medical Society represents physicians in economic, legislative, peer review and regulatory affairs, and the Academy of Medicine of the Westchester County Medical Society is its educational arm, providing continued medical education and assuring the quality of medical programs for physicians in Westchester.
In fact it is the Westchester County Health Department (a component of the New York State Department of Health) that has the responsibility for health-care advocacy, particularly for the disadvantaged with health-care problems. In spite of this clear division of responsibility, the County Medical Society has been and remains open to all who seek its assistance on health care matters -- when they are asked and to the degree they can offer moral directions, because there is no public financing available to the Medical Society, as there is to the Health Department.
The involvement of the Medical Society and individual physicians, however, is curtailed by the vastness of medicine and the interests of physicians in a multitude of worthwhile pursuits. AIDS may be of paramount importance to some, but I dare say that heart disease, cancer, lupus, sickle cell disease, cystic fibrosis, Lyme disease and a thousand other afflictions demand and receive the attention of physicians. I don't believe on this basis alone, or on the relative prevalence of these diseases, that physicians in Westchester have not reasonably participated in the management of Westchester patients afflicted with AIDS and its related syndromes.
The real impediment to physicians' involvement with AIDS patients is an outrageous, cumbersome regulatory process imposed on physicians in New York State. It is based on the belief, held uniquely in New York State, that AIDS is not a communicable and sexually transmitted disease.
Long ago, New York State physicians asked that AIDS be treated in the same fashion that syphilis, tuberculosis, polio and all communicable diseases have traditionally been treated in this state. Recognizing AIDS as a communicable disease would have allowed physicians to directly test their patients in the privacy of their offices, allowed enhanced epidemiological assessment and permitted contact tracing.
Instead, only in New York State is elaborate counseling mandated before testing is begun, and physicians are virtually compelled to refer patients for testing to State Health Centers. The anonymity required and the time involved in the burdensome regulatory process imposed on physicians has discouraged physician involvement with these patients.
There are many other problems that may be limiting physicians in caring for AIDS patients. This is a new disease, involving sophisticated understanding of the immune system. Many physicians, as yet, may have had little experience or training in managing this disease and its associated severe complications. As physicians are further exposed and their knowledge increases, so will their involvement. (A similar experience is evident in the care of Lyme disease in Westchester County.)
Under the best of circumstances AIDS in its debilitating phases is an illness that requires frequent consultation by experienced hands. That is why there already exists an elaborate network of experienced clinicians, oftentimes in hospital-based clinics, managing these patients with elaborate referral conduits to and from the Westchester County Medical Center and community hospitals.
AIDS is economically disabling even to the private paying patient, and medical (or public) assistance is often needed. For such visits the practicing physician is allowed $7.50 ro $11 per office visit, in spite of the time and effort involved in the care of these patients. Yet Medicaid pays hospital emergency rooms and clinics $60 to $80 a visit. Is there any wonder why there might be some reluctance to treat an AIDS patient in the office?
There are other troubling aspects about the directions health care is taking these days. There are still some aspects of this disease that expose physicians to enormous risks. In the current era of demeaning the medical profession, of constant challenge, unrelenting and oppressive regulation and significant curtailment of the economic rewards of medical practice, physicians are beginning to adjust to the public perception that medicine is just a business. They are accepting their loss of public esteem by looking at their own self-interests, in terms of their availability and the degree to which they are willing to accept risks, especially those that jeopardize their families.
But while such baser instincts are still in the minority, the inflammatory threats that emanate from the Department of Health and the public do bridle physicians -- as in your article, "many doctors will not treat patients with AIDS, although they face legal complications for refusing AIDS patients."
Unfortunately, too many patients still don't know how to find or choose a personal physician. If you live in Westchester, the simplest way is to obtain the name of a primary-care physician from your local community hospital or from the County Medical Society's referral panel. Then call the doctor, indicate you are sick and ask for an appointment. Don't challenge the doctor with the admonition: "I have AIDS! Will you see me?"
Once seen by the doctor, be guided by his advice or referral and try not to impress him with your superior knowledge. Most physicians are caring, supportive and will undertake to do as good a job as they are capable of performing.
There may, in fact, be some reluctance to treat AIDS patients on the part of some physicians, unable to deal with what they believe to be this population's antisocial behavior, or the moral judgments of some physicians, or the economics of the situation; unable to comply with and cope with the regulatory process, or the unavailability and access to adequate backup resources. There may even be physicians who are unable to face the trauma of watching the young die -- while being relatively helpless in the process.
However, the major obstacle to reasonable access of AIDS patients to routine care is the failure of the state to recognize AIDS as a communicable and sexually transmitted disease with office-based testing of patients and the same protections for privacy that have always existed for every other communicable disease.
It is the cumbersome environment that exists in this state that has retarded earlier recognition and more office-based treatment of AIDS patients, and that is where the blame should be placed. Physicians in this county have and will continue to do more than their fair share, irrespective of the derogatory inferences suggesting otherwise.
 
 DR. SANFORD A. KAPLAN
President-Elect
 Westchester County
 Medical Society

HEADLINE: For a Nickel, You Get History

 BODY:
The residents of Westchester may be shocked to learn that they are getting something for a nickel these days. And yet, that nickel could soon be eliminated or cut to a few cents ["Budget Plan Links Cuts to Fate of Sales Tax," Nov. 18].
Taxpayers in Westchester, which has one of the richest histories of any county in the United States, are pressing legislators to cut county spending. The County Board of Legislators is caught between the "rock" (mandated programs) and the "hard place" (popular services like the parks). 
 History could appear frivolous when weighed on the scale of human needs. No one freezes on a park bench when historical services are cut. No one gets sick or dies.
When historical services are cut, we take the incredible risk that we allow history to repeat itself. We lose our ability to connect with the past that has shaped us. And if we cannot make these connections, we lose our ability to plan for the future.
If we cannot teach students how their village's history relates to national and world history, we fail to place events on their most personal and meaningful level. History remains something far away and vague that happens on the beaches of Normandy, not in Peekskill or New Rochelle. World War II is something fought far away if you don't know that parachutes were made in Yonkers and airplanes in Tarrytown.
The county annually gives the Historical Society what amounts to a nickel per citizen, for collecting and saving the enormous history of the people, institutions and events of the past. The bulk of our budget comes from membership dues, corporate and personal donations and grants for specific projects.
So what do county taxpayers get for their historical nickel?
1. Two cents rents the only professionally staffed historical library in the county. It is open to the public free. This library, started in 1874, has by far the largest, most comprehensive collection of local history in Westchester, and it is maintained in a temperature- and humidity-controlled space (so the documents won't turn to dust before the next century when our grandchildren need to use them). The library is used each year by hundreds of researchers.
2. Two cents goes toward publishing The Westchester Historian, a quarterly journal now in its 66th year. We're one of the few historical societies that publishes a journal, and we do it because the printed word lasts long after an exhibition is dismantled or a program viewed. The Historian's articles and photographs tell the story of Westchester, such as the history of David's Island in New Rochelle and the almost lost industry of shad fishing on the Hudson. Almost every public library in Westchester subscribes to the journal.
3. The last cent means someone answers the telephone.
Three final points:
First, people sometimes say "Get your funds from the rich corporations." The reality is that a lot of Westchester corporations are not in the best of economic health. Some have merged. Some give only to health or homeless projects. Sadly, a growing number of Westchester corporations are now controlled by conglomerates whose top officials see no need to support Westchester.
Second, why do we need the Westchester County Historical Society when we have so many local historical societies? Because we do not duplicate what they do, and we do things they cannot do. In addition we cover the many localities that have no historical societies.
Third, what happens if we don't have that nickel? The residents of the future will suffer the most: if our doors are closed, future residents won't be able to use the records we have saved up until today.
If you think you are getting your nickel's worth, write or call your county legislator and ask him or her to continue supporting the Westchester County Historical Society.
And if you don't think you are getting your nickel's worth, write or call me and tell my why, because we are here to serve you: 2199 Saw Mill River Road, Elmsford, N.Y. 10523; 592-4323.
 
 KAROLYN WRIGHTSON
 Executive Director
 Westchester County
 Historical Society
