HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
The 'Super' Concept

BYLINE: Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Now that the Soviet Union has been deflated, and may even be breaking up, does the world still need the U.S. as a remaining superpower?
Can the U.S. still play that role? It's clear that maintaining superpower status is becoming more difficult -- nearly impossible -- for the United States. Even in the Middle East, allies are having to pick up much of the tab, allies necessarily have substantial control over U.S. actions, and an ultimate triumph is by no means assured. 
 At home, and no matter what U.S. policies are abroad, American society and the American economy are anything but super. Congress and the President have just demonstrated that they can't even manage the Federal budget; and Washington veterans will be surprised if the nation finally sees anything like the $460 billion in savings projected for the next five years.
Nor is the deficit the only economic problem. Billions are needed for investment -- in education, in infrastructure, in environmental cleanup, to restore the dwindling ability of states and cities to provide necessary public services. The shameful savings and loan scandal adds to the problem. A struggling and badly undercapitalized banking system limits the availability of needed credit for the present, and threatens economic collapse for the future.
The nation's energy vulnerability has been dramatized by the Middle East crisis; but the country seems paralyzed when confronted with the obvious need for greater energy independence. Research and development, once a prime U.S. strength, lag behind the efforts of Japan and Western Europe.
Even a President who denies being a "gloom and doom person" concedes that the economy is heading into a recession, and some economists think it may be the worst of the postwar era.
Compounding all this is the apparent reluctance of the voters -- who now are only about half or less of those eligible -- to approve any form of new taxes. Yet, after a decade of reduced taxes and inflated military spending, there may be no way to attack some of these problems without well-targeted taxes -- on gasoline, for instance, to reduce oil imports, help clear the air we breathe and produce needed new revenues for, say, education and infrastructure. Better such a tax, even if stiff, than the higher price now being paid at the pump, mostly to enrich foreign potentates.
Where is the superpower in all of this? And where is it to be found in other American ills -- crime, homelessness, inadequate child care, limited and costly medical care, a growing underclass? Even the military, upon which so much American wealth has been lavished in the last half-century, demonstrated crucial weaknesses in the great victories in Grenada and Panama, not to mention Vietnam.
If the most pressing U.S. problems therefore lie at home (not least the lack of political will to face them), playing the superpower role abroad is hard to defend. It also emphasizes the corollary: Is it necessary?
The need to match a second superpower, dollar for dollar, bomb for bomb, has disappeared. The need to organize, arm and lead the "free world" in deterring and/or defeating the Communist world no longer exists. The need to provide capital to what used to be the Communist world, as well as to Latin America and other friendly nations, can far better be met by Japanese and European financial interests -- who have, in most cases, as much at stake as the U.S.
In a multi-polar world, composed of at least Japan, Western Europe, China and the United States, as well as whatever power (including nuclear) remains to the Soviet Union, the need for any one of these to claim status as a lone superpower -- policeman and banker to the world, the dominant voice among all -- is hard to see. The ability for any one to achieve or maintain such status may be nonexistent.
Regional discord no doubt will continue to require United States military power to be projected occasionally, at least in the third world; few would wish such power to be Japanese, German or Chinese. But that's a different scale of power, for a far more limited purpose, than the vast military establishment once required for what looks more and more like the outmoded concept of the superpower.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: 'I Was 17, Poor and Joined the Marines'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "(Class) War in the Gulf" by John Kenneth Galbraith (Op-Ed, Nov. 7): What nonsense!
I was once 17 years old, poor, a high school dropout with no ambition or plans for my life, and I joined the Marines. I went to China and Japan, all at the Government's expense. I survived, I returned home, I found ambition, I went to school on the G.I. bill, bought a house under a G.I. mortgage, worked hard, raised a family, worked hard, went to college, worked hard and became a professional and, like Mr. Galbraith, am relatively well off, and I use gas.
All thanks to the United States Government for giving me a stake and a chance to improve my life so my children will not have to put themselves in harm's way because they are economically disadvantaged or have no family.
Seems to me those deployed in Saudi Arabia, who are there for those reasons and who survive, should take advantage of the many opportunities afforded by the Government as I did (isn't that what the Armed Forces recruiters tout?). Get educated, work hard, raise a proper family and maybe, just maybe, someday they will be able to keep their children out of harm's way, that is, if they choose to do so. That is what the system is all about, thank you.
 
BOB DOMINIANNI
Hauppauge, L.I., Nov. 8, 1990

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Legal Crack? No Sale

BYLINE: DAVID C. ANDERSON

 BODY:
Crack created a crisis of criminal justice -- and revived support for legalizing drugs. Aren't the violence and other public costs of keeping drugs illegal even worse than the harm caused by the drugs themselves?
That's the question posed by a corps of responsible people, as conservative as William F. Buckley, the columnist, and as liberal as Ira Glasser, head of the American Civil Liberties Union. 
 They base their case on economic arguments, on the violence created by making drugs illegal and the fearsome public expense of arresting, prosecuting and incarcerating drug violators. Yet their arguments pass far too quickly over a single practical question:
How would legal drug distribution work?
Promoters of legal drugs say that's just a detail to be worked out by bureaucrats once society accepts the concept. But in fact, the "detail" is a central concern.
It is also the subject of an article in The Public Interest by James Jacobs, a New York University law professor. By fleshing out what legalization would mean in practice, Mr. Jacobs says he hopes to advance the debate.
That he certainly does. The "simplest, yet boldest scenario," he asserts, is to lift most prohibitions on drugs so that they may be sold as freely as alcohol or tobacco. Some supporters of legalization say that would not result in much more drug abuse than occurs now. Mr. Jacobs says that's naive, given America's interest in chemicals that seem to solve problems or bring happiness.
Legitimate purveyors of drugs would naturally seek to expand their markets. Inevitably, they would spawn side businesses -- magazines to educate consumers about drugs, legal crack houses where addicts gather to socialize. The likely result would be a dramatic expansion of drug addiction. Any gains from reduced criminal justice costs might be powerfully offset by increases in addiction, child abuse and similar social ills.
Other questions multiply. How would the present machinery for regulating food and drugs deal with heroin and cocaine? Would they have to run the formidable gantlet of Federal testing and review designed to show that they are "safe and effective for a specified use"? That would defeat the main goal of legalization: making drugs quickly available so as to put the black market out of business.
Yet exempting hard drugs from such regulation would create an awkward anomaly -- crack and heroin would be sold like candy, while many cough medicines, diet pills and antibiotics would still need a prescription.
Exempting the hard drugs from regulation would also increase, perhaps prohibitively, the manufacturer's liability for suicides, overdoses and injuries traceable to drug abuse. It's unlikely producers would feel protected by the warning label Mr. Jacobs imagines: "Crack is a powerful psychoactive product that can lead to hyperactivity, extreme depression, and addiction . . . . Use by pregnant women causes addicted and damaged babies."
Not all those who support legal drugs favor selling them over the counter. Some suggest distribution through "state stores" run by government agencies. It's an idea that collapses on a moment's reflection.
If such agencies followed the example of those regulating gambling in Nevada and New Jersey, it's likely they would soon focus on maximizing drug sales to maximize government revenues. But if they behaved more responsibly, limiting access to drugs, that would defeat the goal of destroying black markets.
"Advocates of drug legalization," Mr. Jacobs writes, "in effect are urging the country to engage in a massive experiment" with extreme risks. Those who think it can work have a responsibility to explain how.

HEADLINE: Cold, Fragile, Invisible

 BODY:
Economists argue: Will there be a recession? Are we in one already? But there are many for whom the debate is irrelevant, even frivolous. They are the poor, the fragile elderly, the homeless, the children of poverty. They need not consult economic indicators; they have been suffering the pain of recession -- no, of depression -- for a long time.
Many New Yorkers have adjusted their eyes and minds to ignore the visible symptoms of poverty and need, people who live in the street. But their presence tells only a small part of the story. Many more are invisible. 
 They are stored away in welfare hotels or in shelters that offer neither the safety nor comfort the term misleadingly suggests. They are children without a proper home, without even a permanent school. They are families, described as the "working poor," desperately hanging on to their threadbare lodgings.
More than a year ago, the Bush Administration promised a new "war on poverty, homelessness and despair." Perhaps victory in that war will come -- someday. But for those who are jobless and hungry and for whom the ravages of winter's cold are a present threat, there is desperate need now.
Private charity cannot be a permanent, or even an adequate temporary substitute for sound and compassionate government policies. Yet quick and non-bureaucratic help is more urgently needed than ever. Hope for a better but distant future cannot house today's dispossessed, comfort the neglected young or the impoverished, forgotten old.
One way to help now is to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which begins its 79th annual appeal today. Once again, the urgent call goes out, as young and old prepare for the holiday season. It is a call to conscience that begs for an answer of generosity and civic responsibility.
The fund, known as the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund when created in 1912, has long since outgrown such limited numbers. Today, it reaches thousands.
The fund passes every dollar to the neediest through seven private social service agencies. No money is kept back for administration or solicitation. Contributions are deductible for income-tax and estate purposes. Any amount is welcome. Checks should be payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to Post Office Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: Experimenting at Harvard

BYLINE: By AIMEE L. STERN; Aimee L. Stern is a freelance writer based in Cambridge, Mass., who often reports on business topics.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
ON a crisp fall day recently, the 80 students in an accounting class at the Harvard Business School listened intently as Mary Barth, an assistant professor, described how bonds are classified on a company's balance sheet. The students nodded their understanding. Except for one, Alexei Maximov, who frowned and whispered a question in heavily accented English to his neighbor. He was completely lost.
With his faded blue jeans, scruffy loafers and harried, somewhat frantic expression, Mr. Maximov looks like any other first-year student at the school. 
 What sets Mr. Maximov apart is that he is one of four Soviet students in the class of 1992, the first Soviet group to pursue M.B.A.'s at Harvard and perhaps at any American business school. And aside from having problems with English, Mr. Maximov and his countrymen are struggling, like the Soviet Union itself is, to learn how to talk business in what amounts to a cram course in capitalism.
For Mr. Maximov, at least, the process already seems to be paying off. "Step by step, I feel as though I'm getting somewhere," said the 31-year-old student, who back home is a research associate at the Soviet Institute of Foreign Economic Relations.
The experimental Harvard program comes at a time of great change and confusion in the Soviet Union as the Kremlin gropes for ways to shift to a market economy and to find a new generation of managers to run its enterprises.
At home, students can now pursue M.B.A.'s for the first time at the Russian-American University, an independent school that opened this fall in classrooms at Moscow State University.
The program here is an outgrowth of a joint research project involving Paul R. Lawrence, a professor of organizational behavior at the business school, and the Soviet Institute of Foreign Economic Relations. Professor Lawrence traveled extensively through the Soviet Union to gather material for his book "Behind the Factory Walls."
When officials at the institute suggested that the business school admit Soviet students, Professor Lawrence helped to win backing for the idea. The business school "tends to be on the cutting edge," he said. "When the political situation changed, it became a natural for us." The program is jointly financed by the Soviet Government and Harvard.
THE first class of Soviet students was selected from a pool of approximately 100 applicants. The four men who made the grade passed a comprehensive English exam and then faced a battery of interviews with Harvard alumni; executives of Zyl, a Soviet truck manufacturer that had been studied by Professor Lawrence; staff from the foreign relations institute, and the business school's director of admissions, Laura Fisher.
The Soviet hopefuls also had to complete the business school's exhaustive 10-page application form.
In the Soviet Union, educational applications only request basic information like date and place of birth. By contrast, the Harvard Business School asks applicants to describe which character traits they wish to change or improve and to analyze an "ethical dilemma" they have experienced first-hand.
One of the four successful applicants, Alexei Kolesnikov, a 27-year-old senior analyst at the U.S.S.R. Chamber of Commerce and Industry, spent two months sweating over his papers. His early drafts contained short, factual answers touting his qualifications. After reading the questions and his replies countless times, Mr. Kolesnikov finally decided Harvard wanted to him to think, not just regurgitate facts. His final draft was calculated and intellectual, written as he thought an American would respond.
Besides Mr. Kolesnikov and Mr. Maximov, those accepted were Joseph Bakaleynick, 38, deputy director general of the Vladimir Tractor Works, and Besik Sikharulidze, 25, who two years ago helped found the Science and Engineering Development Center in Tbilisi, Georgia. All of the men brought their wives and children to the United States for the two-year program.
To limit the students' culture shock and help them develop a grounding in American business, they were each assigned to an internship with an American corporation for at least six months, beginning last January. The companies, which were suggested by business school alumni, amounted to something of a cross-section of American industry: S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. of Racine, Wis., the maker of household products; Johnson & Johnson, the baby care and pharmaceutical company based in New Brunswick, N.J.; Braxton Associates of Boston, a strategic consulting division of Deloitte & Touche, and Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. of Des Moines, which develops computer systems. [See box.]
With capitalistic work experience under their belts, the Soviet students were ready to confront the rigors of Harvard's famed case-study method of business training. The case studies present actual business problems for which the students devise potential solutions. First-year students read an 12 to 15 cases each week.
THREE of the four Soviet students opted to attend a six-week summer course designed to introduce foreigners to the case-study method. Some business scholars criticize the case method as archaic, but the Soviet students say it offers snapshots of how American companies operate in their industries. To them, it is a good way to master how American managers think.
The Soviet students are still struggling with the dynamics of a free market system, however. Each is assigned to a study group which tries to address case questions before class. But for the visiting students, some of the questions contain an extra issue or two to puzzle out.
When a management communications class discussed the leak of a confidential company memo to a newspaper, for example, Mr. Sikharulidze had trouble sorting out the legal and ethical ramifications for all the concerned parties. After all, Mr. Sikharulidze said, newspapers in the Soviet Union don't exactly chase that kind of story.
"When you come from a culture that has been isolated from the rest of the world for many years, you're going to look at things differently," he said. "It's a terrific experience for me. After every class I've learned something new."
The business school works hard at assimilating foreign students into its culture, sponsoring numerous social and intramural sporting events. This year, 16 percent of the 800-member entering class is from outside the United States. The foreigners are split up and assigned to different sections of the class to speed the assimilation.
Mr. Kolesnikov says the integrated curriculum at Harvard helps him understand how different pieces of American business fit together. For instance, he studied inventory control systems in both his finance and marketing classes. In Soviet professional schools, he said, departments operate as fiefs and faculty rarely speak to their peers in other departments, much less plan classes together.
SOME business practices do transcend cultural barriers, the Soviet students have found. Mr. Bakaleynick, for instance, recently read a case study on just-in-time inventory control systems. Mr. Bakaleynick, who holds a Ph.D. in economics from Moscow State University, employed the same system as a top manager at the Vladimir Tractor Works, but referred to it by another name.
Next summer, the four students plan to get another dose of work experience as interns. And after their second year at Harvard, they all plan to return home, where they expect to work in international trade.
"I see myself as a bridge between different cultures because after school is over, I will know how both sides feel," said Mr. Maximov.
"My main role," added Mr. Kolesnikov, "is to bring a real knowledge of the American market system to Soviet business. It's easy to say we'll adopt cost accounting, but if no one knows what it really means, how can it be done?"
For now, though, the Soviet students are still hitting the books.
"Not all my questions are answered," Mr. Maximov said, "but I expect they will be by the end of the second year."
 
 
 
THE SIX-MONTH IMMERSION
 BEFORE starting classes this fall, the first Soviet students to attend the Harvard Business School worked for at least six months at a variety of companies in the Northeast and Middle West.
The internships gave the students some practical lessons in American capitalism as well as an eye-opening introduction to a very alien culture.
Coming from a country where shortages and endless lines are the norm, the Soviets were astounded by American stores and the sheer variety of merchandise they sold.
"People in the U.S. spend a lot of time thinking about money and how to spend it," said Alexei Maximov, who worked the first half of the year in Racine, Wis., at S. C. Johnson & Son Inc., the maker of household products. "I always just went to the store and bought something."
Indeed, for the Soviets, consumer marketing was a completely foreign element of the manufacturing process. Few Soviet companies, after all, have salespeople and once a truckload of goods leaves a factory, management rarely frets over its fate.
To learn about marketing, Mr. Maximov attended product development meetings, went on field trips and observed the development of a new advertising campaign for Pledge, the furniture cleaner. In the evenings, he paced the aisles of Racine grocery stores, trying to figure out what purposes all the different products served.
The interns were also struck by the diligence of American employees. In the Soviet Union, workers are notoriously lackadaisical, often working half days or failing to show up at all. There is little incentive to improve because performance usually does not translate into higher salaries and workers are rarely fired.
Alexei Kolesnikov, who spent his internship at Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick, N.J., said he was impressed with "how hard the Americans worked."
He also said that it is much easier for American managers to confer with their superiors.
"If you don't know the top guy at a Soviet company when you start working, you'll never get to know him," Mr. Kolesnikov said. "There's an unofficial hierarchy which says you can only write a memo to the person one level above you. Other memos are signed by whoever is the boss and he takes credit for them."

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
In Havana, Where They Really Dance To the Music

BYLINE: By NED SUBLETTE; Ned Sublette, a composer and band leader, is a field producer for "Afropop Worldwide" on National Public Radio. He is setting up an American-Cuban cultural exchange program for Dance Theater Workshop in New York.

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
La Tropical is the only dance hall in Havana that's open regularly. It's a big, open-air beer garden that has seen decades of service. The legendary singer Benny More used to play here, and the dance band Conjunto Casino has been here plenty. On this night, as Conjunto Casino finishes its set, the club is jumping, packed with maybe 1,500 people.
Times are hard in Cuba, and getting harder. Manufactured goods are scarce, right down to matches. Billboards scream "Socialismo o Muerte!" ("Socialism or Death!"). Many items can be bought with only United States dollars, possession of which is illegal for Cubans. But among the things that can be bought with Cuban pesos are beer (which they do run out of), rum (which they don't seem to run out of) and music. It costs a peso (about 16 cents at the black-market exchange rate) to get into La Tropical, where you can hear some of the best dance bands in the world. 
 Conjunto Casino was formed in 1940, before its present lead singer was born, before the music they play was called salsa. The young audience mostly ignores the band. Then Irakere takes the stage. Known outside Cuba as a jazz band, Irakere can also play hard-charging music, and soon the stage is overrun with dancers. The teen-age girls are doing that dance, the one they call the pigue, rotating their hips wide and fast while moving their arms back and forth high above their heads, meanwhile sticking out their tongues and working their entire bodies up and down.
Most of this audience is black; indeed, at the core of Cuban music is African culture. Various African religions, brought to Cuba from the Yoruba, Congo, Dahomeyan and Ejagham civilizations, are widely practiced. And in the singing and drumming of religious ritual is a mother lode of rhythmic polyphony that permeates Cuban music at all levels.
While North American songs are popular -- people in Havana can tune to Miami radio, and late at night Cuban television runs a few current videos -- home-grown dance bands rule. A number of these bands go back to well before the revolution (one poster spotted recently advertised a band "founded in 1882"), and new ones are started all the time. The groups are large; 14 pieces is not unusual. Many bands are on salary with state-affiliated organizations, and the good ones rehearse every day, producing near-telepathic ensembles.
It would be only natural for Cuban dance bands to join in the world-beat explosion that has introduced the likes of Martinho da Vila of Brazil and Baba Maal of Senegal to listeners in the United States. But North Americans have only limited access to their neighbor's music.
Better-known Cuban bands play in Canada, Latin America, Europe and Japan, but not in the United States (a 1985 executive order prohibits granting visas to employees of the Cuban Government, which the State Department construes to include musicians). It's also not easy to find recordings of Cuban music. Until August 1988, it was illegal to import Cuban records; now they are allowed in as informational materials, and American labels can release already-produced Cuban recordings. But American companies may not finance recording projects, which would violate the Trading With the Enemy Act of 1917. Most post-1959 Cuban recordings on sale in the United States are imported from third countries or licensed through European intermediaries.
Of the bands Cubans are listening to, some, like Los Van Van and Orquesta Reve, have records on sale abroad; but most, like N. G. La Banda and Dan Den, haven't been heard in the United States.
Los Van Van, the most popular band in Cuba by almost any measure, was formed in 1969 but has released only one album in the United States: 1989's "Songo" (Island/Mango 9825; all three formats), a collection of their 80's hits but rerecorded in Paris. Led by the bassist-composer Juan Formell and powered by the percussionist Jose Luis (Changuito) Quintana, Los Van Van provided a point of departure for subsequent Cuban bands. By removing the bongo and the campana (the heavy cowbell usually played by the bongo player) and adding electric instruments to the typical charanga flute-and-violins orchestra, Los Van Van changed the timbre of Cuban records.
Their style, which they call songo (partly to differentiate it from salsa), is a marvelous balance of simplicity and complexity. They have retained the clave, the two-bar rhythm that is the spine of Cuban music, but have articulated it in such a way that the most leaden dancer can easily find the beat. Over the years the sound of Los Van Van has evolved. The present-day group includes an electronic wind instrument, two keyboard synthesizers and electronic percussion. But the group is still a charanga orchestra, with its original three violinists and flutist, plus three trombonists.
Los Van Van's best-known tune, "Muevete" ("Move"), was popularized outside of Cuba by Ruben Blades, who heard the song while sharing concert bills with the band in Europe; after writing new (and more political) lyrics, he scored a hit in 1985. Van Van's original 1984 recording, "Anda Ven y Muevete," is available in the United States on the compilation "Sabroso! Havana Hits" (Virgin/Earthworks 91312; all three formats), with a later version on "Songo." Van Van, which was dropped by Island Records after one album, is currently without label affiliation outside of Cuba.
"La Explosion del Momento!" (Virgin/ Real World 91304; all three formats), a compilation of three albums by Orquesta Reve, was released in 1989 and is easily available in the United States. Elio Reve's typical form is the changui, a fast-paced cousin of the son (the blend of African beat and Spanish song style that flowered in eastern Cuba in the early 1900's). But Mr. Reve's music also includes rumba, merengue, the Afro-Haitian drumming of eastern Cuba and African religious rhythms. The singers' high nasal style (known as "old woman's voice") was fashionable in the 20's; the electric bass plays with a fat, modern-sounding slap-and-pop. Live, the band's montunos, in which a chorus repeats a refrain while a soloist improvises, are extended to trance-inducing lengths.
Mr. Reve, who formed his orchestra in 1956, can count some of Cuba's top band leaders among his band's alumni, including Mr. Formell of Los Van Van. Now in his 60's, Mr. Reve still plays to large audiences of young people. When two prominent members of his band left to form the group Dan Den, he scouted the next generation of talent and continued unperturbed. "Suave Suave," his first hit with the new lineup, includes the lyrics: "I'm repeating the talk/ The street-corner talk/ They say la Reve/ That la Reve went to ruin/ I tell you, people/It was all a lie."
A band's street-corner reputation is everything in Cuba, where songs become popular long before a record goes on sale. The public learns the tunes from seeing bands live and on television. During the many months' lag between recording and pressing (a year or more is not uncommon), unreleased albums circulate informally, copied from cassette to cassette and heard blasting from windows and construction sites all over Havana. Radio stations play specially supplied copies.
When an album finally appears on the market, a group's popularity can be gauged not by how many copies it sells, but by how long it takes to sell out. There are rarely second pressings, so a popular album is a collector's item almost from the moment it's released.
There were long lines in front of the record store in downtown Havana last July when two eagerly awaited albums were released the same week -- the debut album by Dan Den, a sort of breakaway Orquesta Reve but funkier and more electronic, and "En la Calle," from N. G. la Banda, the most popular of the newer bands. N. G. (for Nueva Generacion, or New Generation) is led by Jose Luis Cortes, a former member of both Irakere and Los Van Van. Like Irakere, N. G. has a virtuosic horn section and aims at a dual dance-band and concert-stage identity. "La Expresividad" was probably 1990's biggest hit on Havana's streets. A Cubanized bomba with Van Van-style electronic percussion, it uses an old trick -- a long, catchy break in which each of Havana's barrios receives a salute in verse.
There are many other bands in Cuba. Import-watchers might look for albums by La Original de Manzanillo, Son 14 and Adalberto Alvarez y Su Son. And the spectrum of Cuban music runs from African- and Spanish-based traditional music to jazz, rock and experimental. Yet even when the influences come from outside, the music still sounds characteristically Cuban.
"Ancestros," a 1987 album by the group Sintesis, features scrupulously authentic performances of Yoruba and Arara ritual songs with the percussion stripped away and replaced by synthesizer-heavy pop instrumentation. Another album, set for release in Cuba in 1991, is a collaboration between a pop group, Mezcla, and Lazaro Ross, a master singer of Yoruba music. These two albums, by groups whose names mean "synthesis" and "mix," respectively, provide a refreshing counterpart to stateside pop musicians' attempts at cultural fusion. There are reports they will be released in Germany next year and may then be available in the United States at least as imports.
But Cuban musicians, who like their countrymen face tense conditions economically and politically, are expressing themselves with beauty and dignity -- whether North Americans hear it or not.
 
 
WHERE TO FIND CUBAN RECORDS
 The Center for Cuban Studies, 124 West 23d Street in Manhattan (212-242-0559), is a nonprofit research center and library that sells records and videos of Cuban music.
Elsewhere in Manhattan, the Times Square Record Mart (212-840-0580), in the Times Square subway station near the BMT line, has a good selection of Cuban music.
Many large record stores also carry some Cuban titles in their world-beat sections.

LENGTH: 1187 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Western North Carolina;
Homes Bloom in Piney Mountain Country

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
GROWING up on a farm in the western North Carolina mountain community of Whittier (pop. 1,000), Bill Gibson often felt isolated from the world and considered it a treat to meet someone new. Now, Mr. Gibson, who is 42 years old, feels fortunate to see someone he knows.
Newcomers are moving to western North Carolina at such a pace that people around there are chary of advertising the area's strengths for fear of attracting more. Real estate brokers attribute the growth to a greater awareness of the low cost of living and the four distinct -- but mild -- seasons. 
 In the last five years, thousands of primary and secondary homes, ranging from simple trailers to million-dollar mansions, have been built in the piney woods and on the mountainsides west of Asheville, 35 miles south of Whittier.
And there is no evidence that the economic troubles roiling real estate markets in many parts of the nation have hurt the market in that section of North Carolina.
In Flat Rock, about 50 miles south of Whittier, a 150-acre subdivision built on land that once was part of a large estate is a year ahead of its sales schedule.
In Hendersonville, Flat Rock's neighbor, the golf-course architect Tom Fazio is building a course-side golf community with lots selling in the $100,000 range.
In Tryon, 10 miles south of Flat Rock on the South Carolina's border, an upscale condominium project in what is known as Hunting Country, an area of horse farms and rolling hills, is finishing its last group of $139,000 to $400,000 units after a seven-year development schedule.
"One can pick a point along any major artery and the preponderance of license plates are out-of-state and most are from Florida," said Mr. Gibson, director of the Regional Council of Governments in Whittier, which provides planning services to local governments in the seven westernmost counties of the state. "In some counties, most property tax bills are mailed out of state.'
Mike Orr, a real estate agent in Hendersonville, said the reason for the growth is simple.
"People found out we have four distinct seasons and none of them are very harsh so they're starting to live here year-round," he said. "Florida is too hot in the summer."
Summer temperatures average about 72, with considerably less humidity than Florida's, and in winter they average about 39, with much less snow than New England gets.
Newcomers, Mr. Orr said, especially retirees, also like the low property taxes and the growing cultural activities. In Hendersonville, property taxes on a $100,000 house, with three bedrooms and a half-acre lot, are roughly $450 a year.
In addition, the community has a 70-member symphony orchestra made up of retired musicians. Nearby Flat Rock is the location of the State Theater of North Carolina, a summer theater of some renown.
In Mr. Gibson's area, the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, the most visited of all national parks, Cherokee National Forest and Pisgah National Forest cover thousands of acres of preserved wilderness.
The growing construction of homes has left western North Carolina with a recession-proof economy, said Mr. Gibson. Those who are building -- practically all out-of-staters -- are either wealthy families building second homes or retirees who want to live in the region year-round.
 Yet, Mr. Gibson said, he sees a growing resentment among some residents, particularly among young people and even among those who make their living directly from second-home construction or from the tourist industry.
 Communities are grappling with over-burdened water and sewer systems, two-lane roads too narrow for heavy traffic and not enough enforcement by the state of its sedimentation pollution law, said Mr. Gibson.
"HOMES go up the hillside and the dirt comes washing down," he said.
He does not advocate halting development, but he said he wants to make sure it is compatible with the scenic beauty of the state, which is the location of Mount Mitchell, at 6,684 feet above sea level the tallest mountain east of the Rockies.
The state has moved to control some development, making it illegal to build tall buildings along the ridgeline of mountains. The law was passed a few years ago after public outcry over a 10-story condominium-hotel built on the ridgeline of Sugarloaf Mountain at Boone.
The state has also moved to entice some development. State and local officials see tourism and second-home development as a good primary industry for the historically poor area. But one obstacle has been the levels of three major western North Carolina lakes, which are controlled by the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Studies conducted for North Carolina suggest that the state loses $13.6 million a year in tourism because the T.V.A. drains water from the lakes early in the summer season and keeps the levels low until late fall. The state, in turn, has asked for a shorter drawdown term. The request is now under negotiation.
The drawdown produces electricity and makes room for any flooding that should occur with the spring thaw.
"They are making problems worse for an economically disadvantaged area of North Carolina," said John Morris, director of the water resources division of state government. "We feel they should work for the betterment of all the Tennessee River basin."
T.V.A., the largest utility in the nation, was founded during the first 100 days of Franklin D. Roosevelt's Administration in the throes of the Depression. The three-member commission appointed to oversee the authority was to expand hydroelectric generation, develop fertilizer and control soil erosion in the vast and poor Tennessee River Valley.
In those days, little thought was given to fostering recreational uses of the lakes built by T.V.A. But now recreation is seen as the best hope for bolstering the economy of the area surrounding Lake Fontana and Lake Chatuge, which in late summer look as low as a tidal basin at low tide.
SOME areas of Lake Fontana get so low that boats cannot be launched and docks are left high and dry.
"It begins to look like a little bit of water at the bottom of a canyon," said Mr. Morris, who added that the power produced by the water drawn from the North Carolina lakes mostly goes to people in Tennessee and Georgia.
"They are taking benefits away from us to serve another area," he said. "Plus other agencies operate under policies where they have to provide recreational benefits. It is just considered a cost of doing business."
The authority says it would cost millions to replace the power generated by hydroelectric plants with power produced at fossil fuel plants.
Earlier this year, T.V.A. undertook a study of North Carolina's concerns, among other things. One of its recommendations is to start the drawdown later in the year, but not as late as North Carolina would have it.
A decision is expected by the end of the year.
Mr. Gibson said the issue has been an emotional one for the people of his area; they want the levels kept high for their own use but do not necessarily like the idea of encouraging tourism and resort development.

HEADLINE: A Business Seminar On Investment in Israel

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
DESPITE the heightened tensions in the Middle East, business opportunities for American companies trading with Israel appear strong, said speakers at a recent trade seminar here for county business people.
Several speakers noted the arrival over the last year of 100,000 Soviet immigrants to Israel, with an additional 250,000 expected over the next two years. 
 "By the end of the decade, that means that we will have a 25 percent increase in our population," said Shimon Bar-Tzill, an officer of Bank Leumi Trust Company, and one of the speakers. "That would compare with an increase of 60 million in United States population. And what it signifies is rapid growth for the Israeli economy."
The seminar, held at the White Plains Hotel this month, was sponsored by the County Office of Economic Development, the World Trade Club of Westchester and the U.S.-Israel Economic Forum.
 
200,000 New Jobs Needed
 Because Israel is on the edge of great economic growth, Mr. Bar-Tzill said, it offers unusual investment opportunities for United States participation. "We will need, for instance, 200,000 new jobs," he said. "Sixty percent of the emigres arrived highly trained for work in sophisticated industries, but they need to be retrained in Western ways of doing things."
Leon Fassler, vice president of Kings Electronics in Tuckahoe, a company that has been doing business in Israel for several decades, discussed the practicalities and difficulties of trading with Israel.
"It's not easy to do business in Israel, but it's not impossible, either," Mr. Fassler said. "Israel is a small market, but an intense one. There is great enthusiasm there to import products, services and technology."
Stressing that he believed the most important thing for would-be exporters is to be careful in selecting a firm to represent them, Mr. Fassler said: "Be sure your rep firm is large enough or broadly based enough to do your job for you. Israel is a very small country and everyone involved in the same marketplace knows everyone else."
The bulk of his company's exports to Israel goes to the military and government market, said Mr. Fassler, who added that "we find the commercial market tougher."
 
The Value of Co-Production
 Edward J. Borroazzo, president of Loral International in Yonkers, a division of the Loral Corporation, said his firm had received orders from Israel amounting to $300 million to $400 million in the last 15 years, but he stressed that co-production projects with Israel were part of Loral's involvement.
Forty-five percent of the financing for Loral from the United States Defense Security Assistance Agency, for example, was spent in Israel.
"The Loral-Israeli connection is a two-way street," Mr. Borroazzo said. "Our experience with Israeli industry has been very good. The work ethic, for example, is exceptional in Israel, and there is a wide breadth of technology there. But market penetration would not have been achievable without a transfer back and forth of technology."
Mr. Borroazzo said Israeli companies had the technology but might lack the manufacturing resources. "Our policy is to share equally in the development costs and production benefits," he said. "Our efforts to sell products through joint ventures with Israeli industry have been successful."
 
Expanding in the Defense Market
 Geotek Industries is a bi-national company with headquarters, finance and marketing divisions in the United States, and product design and development in Israel. Yoram Orom, president of Jerico Precision in Yonkers, part of the Geotek Defense Group, said a base in the United States was considered essential for his company's growth.
The company sells about 60 percent of its products to the defense market and needed to expand outside Israel, Mr. Orom said. "We couldn't push beyond the $5 million to $6 million sales figures because the Israeli market is too small."
So the company bought American companies on the edge of bankruptcy, with the aim of upgrading them. Jericho Precision in Yonkers, for example, which was acquired by Geotek in 1989, had suffered a $2 million operating loss.
"We brought in new management and reorganized the company," Mr. Orom said. "This year, Jerico should have sales of $18 million. Half our products are now sold in Israel, the other half in the United States. The research and development is conducted in Israel; production and marketing are done in both places."
 
Penetrating the Electronic Market
 The United States is the biggest market for welding electronic products used for construction, said Avi Mazori, president of Zika Electrode Works in Israel, the largest welding factory in the Middle East. Eight years ago he opened a warehouse and distribution network in the United States to penetrate the large American market.
"We realized immediately that to be successful we had to understand the U.S. customers' needs," Mr. Mazori said. "American customers want a lot of service and we know we have to provide it if we want to compete with the Taiwanese, the Chinese and everyone else who is supplying this market. And that, I think, is basically the most important factor in successful export: understanding the local market."
No other country tries so hard to promote trade as Israel, said David C. Williams, a lawyer who spoke about the free-trade agreement between the United States and Israel.
"Although the flow of goods between the two countries has tripled since the Free Trade Act went into effect in 1985," he said, "with Israelis selling high-tech products to the U.S. market, the U.S. consumer products exported to Israel have not fared as well as our commercial products because they are competing with European exports."
 
A Familiar Legal System
 But the Israeli legal system, which is based on the British system, makes it fairly easy for American companies to set up corporations in Israel, Mr. Williams said.
The "brain power" emanating from members of a large, well-educated and trained work force was referred to several times during the seminar as Israel's No. 1 export product.
"Because of our skilled work force, we expect our high-tech exports to increase by 20 percent by 1995," said Mr. Bar-Tzill.
Roni Hefetz, executive vice president of CI Systems in Hawthorne, the American branch of an Israeli engineering company, said the company began solely as a research and development organization.
 
Solving Complex Problems
 "In Israel, we were selling solutions to complex problems and we had a rep here," Mr. Hefetz said. "But some months ago we decided to develop our own products, mainly night vision devices that are used in defense projects. I was sent here with $5,000 to open an office and, hopefully, raise capital. I managed to raise $2.5 million from private investors and so the company was launched."
Now, he said, customers in other, non-defense markets "are asking us to design systems for them."
"There are many opportunities for Israeli-American companies to be successful when you use the special advantage that exists in each country," Mr. Hefetz said.
Another speaker, Asher Fensterheim, a lawyer with offices in Manhattan and White Plains, said: "Israel may get investment capital fairly easily because many Americans are concerned that Israel remain a successful Jewish state. It's an emotional thing, but it's still advisable to get professional business advice before you go to Israel."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Businessmen at a trade seminar in White Plains about business opportunities for American companies in Israel.
(Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mild Seasons And Low Taxes Bolster Market

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: WHITTIER, N.C.

 BODY:
Growing up on a farm in this western North Carolina mountain community (pop. 1,000) Bill Gibson often felt isolated from the world and considered it a treat to meet someone new. Now, Mr. Gibson, who is 42 years old, feels fortunate to see someone he knows.
Newcomers are moving to western North Carolina at such a pace that people around here warn each other against advertising the area's strengths for fear of attracting more. Real estate brokers attribute the growth to a greater awareness of the low cost of living and the four distinct -- but mild -- seasons.
 
 In the last five years, thousands of primary and secondary homes, ranging from simple trailers to million-dollar mansions, have been built in the piney woods and on the mountainsides west of Asheville, 35 miles south of here.

Mike Orr, a real estate agent in Hendersonville, said the reason for the growth is simple.

Summer temperatures average about 72, with considerably less humidity than there is in Florida, and winter temperatures average about 39, with much less snow than there is in New England.

HEADLINE: National Notebook: Galveston, Tex.;
Picking Up The Strand

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

 BODY:
FOR 14 years, George Mitchell and his wife, Cynthia, have tried doggedly to revitalize the Strand, a 17-block historic district on the National Register of Historic Places adjacent to Galveston's downtown. They have spent more than $40 million buying and restoring 16 buildings and soon will start on a $6.3 million hotel, restaurant and retail development overlooking the harbor a block away.
The project, scheduled to start in January, will be the first phase of a $26 million waterfront festival marketplace planned jointly by the Mitchells and the Woodlands Corporation, the real estate arm of Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation, of which Mr. Mitchell is chairman and president. It is part of his overall aim to bolster the port's economy by increasing tourism to 8 million visitors a year from 5 million, making the city of 58,000 residents the state's No. 2 tourist attraction (San Antonio, with 13 million visitors a year, is No. 1).
The city, a 32-mile-long barrier island 50 miles south of Houston, was called the "Queen City of the Gulf" in the last half of the 19th century, when 60 percent of all goods shipped to the Southwest came through its port. During the island's golden era in the 1870's, the Strand, its commercial area, was known as the "Wall Street of the Southwest." In 1900 a hurricane killed 6,000 residents, and the dredging of the Houston ship channel, in 1911, drew business away from Galveston.
By the time the Mitchells bought their first Strand building in 1976, the area had become a skid row. They paid $50,000 for the dilapidated three-story brick League Building, with its a cast-iron front, and spent more than $1 million restoring it for shops and a restaurant. In 1985 they converted a former merchandise mart into the 120-room Tremont House Hotel. Then they revived Galveston's Mardi Gras celebration, which now draws more than 350,000 people each February.
Their latest project, on a 10-acre former banana terminal site leased from the Port of Galveston, will include a 40-room bed-and-breakfast-style hotel called Harbor House; it will occupy the second and third floors of a three-story building with 24,000 square feet of retail space at ground level. A 10,000-square-foot building for shops and a restaurant will be built next door, overlooking a small marina.
The project, whose architects are Ford Powell & Carson of San Antonio, will be financed in part by a $900,000 Urban Development Action Grant from the Department of Housing and Urban Development and $2.4 million generated by city tax reinvestment zone bonds. The Mitchells and the Woodlands Corporation will put up the remaining $3 million.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Tremont House Hotel in Galveston, Tex., was a former merchandise mart. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Economy

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The Hong Kong Government Friday revised the growth forecast for this British colony's gross domestic product in 1990 to 2.3 percent from 2.5 percent predicted in August. It also revised the inflation rate to 9.7 percent from 9.5 percent. The Government's chief economist, K. Y. Tang, said the colony's economy could have been hit harder by the slowdown in domestic exports to the United States, Britain and Japan if not for continued strong growth in re-exports, which involve goods assembled in Hong Kong of components made elsewhere.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Direct-Mail Plan Upsets Newspapers

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The newspaper industry is up in arms about a proposal by the United States Postal Service to create a new third-class mail category that could potentially cost newspapers millions of dollars in lost business.
The proposal would give a 20 percent discount to direct-mail companies that use the mail to saturate an area with advertising circulars -- in direct competition with newspapers. 
 "This is the first time the Post Office has proposed anything as blatantly discriminatory," said W. Terry Maguire, senior vice president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
The association's chairman, Lloyd G. Schermer, who heads Lee Enterprises Inc., an Iowa newspaper chain, has sent an urgent appeal to fellow publishers to write postal authorities in hopes of defeating the proposal. "Do not delay!" his letter urged.
The Direct Marketing Association, which includes direct mailers, and the Postal Service defend the discount as fair and sensible.
"It's an automation discount," said Chester G. Dalzell, a spokesman for the association.
The proposal, if approved in January by the Postal Rate Commission, would reduce the cost of mailing each advertising circular by 20 percent if the circulars were mailed to a minimum of 75 percent of the stops on a delivery route and arrived at the post office in the order in which they were to be delivered.
Direct-mail companies like Advo System Inc. usually want their advertising circulars to reach every household on a route and they would generally meet the 75 percent threshold.
With many advertisers wanting their circulars to reach every household in an area, newspapers have increasingly been offering total market coverage by distributing circulars in their papers and mailing circulars to nonsubscribers. Normally, nonsubscribers would account for about 25 percent to 60 percent of the residences on a given mail route, but would rarely reach 75 percent. Therefore, under the proposal, the newspapers would pay the higher postage rate.
 
 $168 Million Loss Is Possible
 Because cost of delivery is a main factor in the fierce competition between direct mailers and newspapers for advertising circulars, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau estimates that newspapers stand to lose as much as $168 million in lost circular delivery business.
Indeed, the bureau estimates that half of the 59 billion advertising circulars that are delivered by newspapers could be at risk if advertisers shifted to direct mailers to get the postal discount.
The fundamental objection of newspapers, Mr. Maguire said, is that the new rates are a calculated effort to favor mailers over newspapers because the Postal Service wants to attract more revenue. But, he argued, since the Postal Service is owned by the Government and is not a private enterprise, it is obliged to set rates that are nondiscriminatory.
Thomas P. Shipe, principal economist for the Postal Service, said the discount was justified because so-called saturation mail was a very cost-efficient method of delivery.
 
 Seeking 95 Percent
 Most saturation mailers aim for 95 percent or more of the 500 deliveries that comprise a typical mail route. Mr. Shipe said he conducted tests that demonstrated such near-total saturation was far less costly on a per-piece basis than 25 percent saturation because the saturation mail was easier to merge with other mail.
Newspaper executives have argued that there is no proof that 75 percent saturation is more cost-efficient for the Postal Service to deliver than, for instance, 40 percent saturation, which is a standard most newspapers might be able to reach.
With newspaper advertising in a deep trough in most areas, the prospect of the Postal Service giving an advantage to mailers is particularly threatening to newspapers.
Vincent Giuliano, vice president for government relations at Advo System, argues that newspapers have a "blended rate" for advertising circulars that is based on a mixture of carrier delivery and mail. This blended rate, he said, would keep newspapers competitive with direct mailers, even with the 20 percent mail discount.
 
 An Issue of Fairness
 But Phillip J. Meek, president of the publishing group for Capital Cities/ ABC Inc., said the main issue was fairness, not the cost structure of newspaper advertising.
Mr. Meek sees advantages on both sides of the question because he oversees both Capital Cities's 10 newspapers and also its saturation mailing operation, which covers 1.7 million households in California. But he opposes the discount proposal.
"Just philosophically, I think for a Government-mandated monopoly like the Postal Service to discriminate against any particular party because it thinks it can generate added revenues for itself through differential pricing is just unfair," he said.
The Postal Rate Commission, an independent body, must make its recommendation on the proposal and other proposed postage rate increases by Jan. 6. The Postal Service's board of governors will then set new rates, which are expected to take effect in February.
